description: Senator Goldwater makes good sense now and then, but he has been associated for so long with lost causes that the Republic pays him little heed even when he makes very good sense.

title: TV: Woman Doctor Serves Darkest Appalachia
description: DANGED if you ever see'd anythin as tarnation foolish in all your born days as The Incredible Journey of Doctor Meg Laurel, which will be shown from A to 11 tonight on CBSTV. The folks

title: CitizenDoctor Efforts Rejoin Leg of Girl, 11, After a Train Severs It
description: Some good people, including four doctors and an offduty ambulance volunteer, may have performed what a grateful father called a miracle for an 11yearold Long Island girl whose right leg had been cut off by a railroad train.

title: Alice Ayars Joyce Is Married To Allen Robbins of Rutgers
description: Alice Ayars Joyce of Somerset, N.J., was married yesterday to Allen Bishop Robbins, professor of physics at Rutgers University.. The ceremony was performed in the Bridgewater (N.J.) United Methodist Church by the Rev. James White.

title: Article Questions Kheel Business Deals
description: A magazine article said yesterday that Theodore W. Kheel, the labor lawyer, had been involved in business deals over the years of such questionable nature that he came close to serious legal difficulties and economic ruin.

title: K.F. WOODWARD DIES; CHILD PSYMIATRIST
description: Dr. Katharine F. Woodward, a child psychiatrist in New York, died yesterday at her home in Manhattan. She was 78 years old.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Tuesday, Jan. 2 ,1979

title: New Bidder Possible for Columbia
description: A potential new bidder for Columbia Pictures Industries emerged yesterday with the disclosure that the General Cinema Corporation, the nation's largest movie exhibitor, was considering plans to offer in excess of $24 a share for a 20 percent stake in Columbia.

title: Houston Trounces Arrows In Indoor Soccer Play, 91
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 2 (AP)  Houston Summit, Soccer unleashed a scoring barrage tonight for a 91 rout of the New York Arrows in a Major Indoor Soccer League game.

title: Some of the Candidates For Top Post at Ford Fund
description: For the last year the Ford Foundation has been conducting an elaborate, and largely secret, nationwide talent hunt for its next president. Now the search has narrowed, from hundreds of names to fewer than a dozen.

title: Contest for Bartenders Has Many Winners
description: PARIS In an atmosphere of high seriousness normally reserved for sporting events or beauty contests, the Concours International de Cocktails brought bartenders representing some 27 nations to the Concorde Layfayette Hotel here on a recent weekend to, among other things, show off their skills.

title: A Treasure Galleon That Sank In 1641 Is Found by American
description: ANNVILLE, Pa., Jan. 1  In 1641, the galleon Concepcion smashed into a coral reef 85 miles northeast of what is now the Dominican Republic and sank with a huge store of silver and gold in her hold. In late 1978, a Pennsylvanian of little means named Burt B. Webber Jr. found the ship. It was a major discovery, according to historians.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: Just as we grew complacent, expecting the mild weather to last forever, winter came in howling and sent us huddling near fireplaces or under electric blankets. But we can't hibernate  there are jobs to go to, errands to run and parties scheduled on frosty nights. If you turn blue walking the dog or find a weekend in an underheated country house a form of torture, you'd better equip yourself with warm clothes.

title: Television
description: 8:00 P.M. Tony Orlando Special (4)

title: Q&A
description: Q. Not long ago I visited a vegetable market where eggplants that were porcelain white were being sold. Are you familiar with this edible?

title: Sweden and Soviet Union In Junior Hockey Rematch
description: KARLSTAD, Sweden, Jan. 2 (UPI)  Sweden beat Finland, 52, today and the Soviet Union tied Czechoslovakia, 22, in the final round of the world junior hockey championships, setting the stage for tomorrow's decisive match between the Soviet Union and Sweden. The Russians beat the Swedes, 52, in last year's championship game.

title: Population to Exceed 220 Million in January
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (UPI)  The population of the United States will surpass 220 million this month, the Census Bureau has estimated.

title: The Governor's Beginnings
description: Flushed with a sense of the accomplishments of his first four years in office, and gratified by his uphill reelection victory, Governor Carey delivered an inaugural address that sought to convey not only the record of his achievement but his feelings about it. Although the record is praiseworthy, he would have done better to emphasize his pride in the past a little less and his sense of the future a little more.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: American companies with plants In Iran are DeIng rorcea to halt production there, at least temporarily. Du Pont stopped work at fibers plant employing 2,000 workers., General Tire said it would close a factory Friday, laying off 1,000. Other companies also are suspending Iranian operations. All are joint ventures with wealthy Iranian allies of the Shah, which raises questions about their future under a new government. (Page D1.)

title: Chess:
description: It's time for the cream of the crop of young grandmasters to show what they can do in world championship competition. So far, only Brazil's Henrique Mecking, 26 years old, has advanced to the candidates' matches.

title: Bridge:
description: There is one paradoxical defensive stroke that most players never think about at all and the experts almost invariably think about too late  in the postmortem. It does not have a name, but it might be called the second-highentryblock. The simplest form would be this:

title: Private Lives
description: WHEN the only friend you have who happens to be an Iranian comes to town for the 93d annual convention of the Modern Language Association, you expect some inside information. My only Iranian friend could, and did, explain the various factions, using a fork, a spoon and the salt and pepper shakers, all in the magnetic field of the Shah. And he had a fair idea the sort of coalition that would be necessary before he could return to his country. But he was without inside information. I seem increasingly to belong to a generation without inside information; it is as though history whittled on us with a knife.

title: Ban on Children in Rental Housing Upset on Coast
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 2  A California appellate court has ruled that landlords may not automatically bar children from rental housing but must apply a balancing test between the rights of families with children and those of persons desiring to avoid children in considering whether a building or complex should be restricted to adults.

title: Banks' Sale Opposed
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2  Virginia's banking commissioner formally recommended to the Federal Reserve Board today that it turn down an application by Arab investors to set up a bank holding company to buy and operate Financial General Bankshares Inc.

title: Iranian Students Riot in California As Shah's Mother Visits His Sister
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Jan. 2 Throwing rocks and bottles and overturning cars, hundreds of Iranian students marched here today. on the home of the sister of the Shah of Iran.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: RECENTLY, my husband and I, and two friends, walked along 57th Street, writes Dorothy Rosencrans Just before we reached Fifth Avenue, another couple walked toward us.

title: Prices of Lead Raised
description: Two leading producers Of lead, the St. Joe Lead Company, a division of the St. Joe Minerals Corporation, and Asarco Inc., announced yesterday that they were increasing the price of lead by 2 cents, to 40 cents a pound, effective immediately.

title: Building Outlay Up
description: WASHINGTON Jan. 2 (AP)  Construction spending increased at an annual rate of 1.4 percent in November, sign that the building surge that began in 1977 is continuing, the Government said today.

title: Spain's. Parties Prepare as Surez Risks an Election
description: MADRID, Jan. 2  With Spain's Parliament officially dissolved, the nation's political parties began mapping their campaigns today for general and municipal elections called by Prime Minister Adolfo Surez in a highstakes gamble.

title: Mrs. Denman Is Picked For the Bench by Carey
description: ALBANY, Jan. 2  Governor Carey repaid a political debt today by appointing M. Dolores Denman of Buffalo to be a justice of State Supreme Court.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Amelia Ramsey, Helped Produce Records, Books, Articles on Jan
description: Amelia J. Ramsey, who assisted her husband, Frederic J. Ramsey Jr., a jazz historian, in the production of records, books and articles on jazz, folk and church music, died of cancer New Year's Day in the Hunterdon Medical Center, in Flemington, N. J. She was 56 years old and lived in Stockton, N.J.

title: Schembechler Scores Official For Rose Call
description: PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 2 (AP) Bo Schembechler reversed his field today, criticizing officials on their controversial call that beat his Michigan team in the Rose Bowl yesterday.

title: U.S. Calls Cubans in Africa Bar to Ties
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2  The State Department said today that as long as Cuba maintained large numbers of soldiers in Africa the United States would have very real problems in any kind of normalization with Fidel Castro's Government.

title: Australia Nearing Victory In Cricket Versus England
description: MELBOURNE, Jan 2 (Reuter) Australia was in sight of winning the third cricket test against England at close of play on the fourth day here.

title: Economic Scene
description: INFLATION, one of the most ancient economic problems, remains unsolved. But many economists, businessmen, bankers and even Government officials think its solution is no mystery at all. They contend that all one needs to do to stop inflation is to quit printing so much money and keep the Government from running big budget deficits. ....

title: Steel Shortage May Shut VW
description: WOLFSBURG, West Germany, Jan.2 (AP)  Volkswagen will be forced to halt auto production at its six West German plants if a fiveweekold steel strike is not settled by Jan. 15, the company said today.

title: A 19thCentury Culinary Crusader.
description: During the 187879 season, in the kitchen of a large house on St. Mark's Place, more than 1,200 New Yorkers learned to stuff breast of lamb, to fillet fish and to fix ragouts instead of roasts.

title: Brazilian Military Regime Permits Expiration of. Vast Array of Powers
description: RIODE JANEIRO, Jan. 2  The military regime in Brazil, the oldest and most firmly established military government in Latin America, has formally relinguished a vast array of arbitrary powers with the expiration of the law that has been the pillar of its dictatorial authority for a decade.

title: The Severed Leg: Too Early to Tell
description: SMITHTOWN, L.I., Jan. 2  It will take at least 10 days before the four surgeons who worked for six hours on Sunday to reattach the leg of an 11yearold girl know whether they were successful.

title: Carter to Resubmit Request for Aid For Cities With High Jobless Rates
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2  President Carter will resubmit a bill providing aid to cities with the highest unemployment rates under a program scaled down from the one that died in Congress last fall, White House aides disclosed today.

title: The Sweet Prince
description: Not to Ernest Jones, Johann Wolfgang von Goethe, Samuel Taylor Coleridge, George Bernard Shaw, A. C. Bradley or other Hamlet scholars, but to Gloria Swanson, the author of this monograph wishes to say a simple thanks.

title: Wine Talk
description: WHATEVER it might have meant to other people, 1978 was a big year for wine lovers. Not necessarily a great year, considering the prices of some wines, but certainly an active year and an interesting one.

title: Murder Trial Ordered for Suspect in Ryan Slaying
description: GEORGETOWN, Guyana, Jan. 2 (AP)  A Guyanese magistrate ruled today that Larry Layton, a member of the People's Temple, must stand trial in the slaying of Representative Leo J. Ryan. It was the murder of Mr. Ryan that preceded the mass deaths of more than 900 members of the cult at Jonestown.

title: Personal Health
description: CAUTION: Winter's chill may be hazardous to your health. Fiveyearold Jimmy was having so much fun making snow statues with his friends in Minnesota that he never noticed the painful tingling in his fingers under his soakedthrough mittens. By the time he got home, his fingers were numb  frostbitten. Although no surgery was needed, they remained stunted like a small child's while Jimmy grew to be a strapping sixfooter.

title: Suns Top Knicks, 114102
description: The Knicks' threegame streak of to- getherness and winning ended last night.

title: Cambodia Appeals for U.N. Help Against Vietnam
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Wednesday, Jan. 3 (AP)  The President of Cambodia said yesterday that Vietnamese forces had penetrated deep into eastern Cambodia, and he appealed for help from the United Nations and from countries far and near.

title: 7Nation TV Unit's Effort To Be Seen Next Month
description: In the summer of 1977, broadcast or ganizations of six European countries and the United States formed a production consortium for a series of documentaries on Europe's most critical issues: The international collaborative effort, involving a pooling of money, research and journalistic resources, was the largest ever attempted in the realm of public affairs.

title: Letters
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: Brandt Says Giants Need Stability, Better Passing
description: The Dallas Cowboys have developed the most sophisticated organization in professional football. They have reached the postseason playoffs in 12 of the last 13 seasons, won Super Bowls VI and XII, and will play in the National Football Conference championship game Sunday.

title: Deaths
description: ADLER  Samuel N. Beloved husband of Sophie. Devoted father of Muriel Levine, Carole Lichtenthal & David Adler. Dear brother of Martin. Cherished grandfather. Services were held Tuesday. January 2, at Gutterman's, Rockville Centre, L.I.

title: A Rescue Operation for Turkey
description: Turkey, NATO's southeast anchor, is in serious trouble, the kind that requires friends to rally round. Economic crisis, governmental instability, mounting political violence  these are some of the symptoms a deepening malaise.

title: A Listing of New Books
description: A Shaft of Sunlight, by Philip Mason (Scribner's, $12.50). Biography of an Englishman who helped shape future of modernday India.

title: AID FOR GUERRILLAS SPLITS CHURCH UNIT
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica, Jan. 2  A sharp debate over grants from the World Council of Churches to groups fighting for political causes has erupted here during opening sessions of the Council's Central Committee.

title: Peking TV Hit: Lollobrigida.
description: PEKING, Jan. 2  For two hours this evening, virtually all activity at the Nationalities Hotel came to a stop. Bellmen and waitresses, elevator operators and interpreters all sat watching television.

title: Turkish City's Ruins Tell a Story of Religious Strife
description: KAHRAMANMARAS, Turkey, Dec. 31  The streets of this city were mired in mud today, its walls covered with political slogans, its people grim and silent.

title: California Life Fights Bid for Unit
description: The California Life Corporation announced that it had filed with the Federal Reserve Board a petition for an order prohibiting the acquisition of the CollegeUniversity Corporation by the BaldwinUnited Corporation. California Life is a large shareholder of CollegeUniversity, holding about 17 percent of its stock.

title: Stocks Open '79 With 6.41 Gain
description: Led by gambling issues, the speculative favorites of last year and several glamour stocks, prices pushed higher on Wall Street yesterday in the first trading session of 1979. Volume of 18.34 million shares, however, was the lowest in more than five weeks and indicated the continuing caution of most investors.

title: 10Day Car Sales Off 5.1%
description: DETROIT, Jan. 2  Sales of Americanmade passenger cars were down by 5.1 percent in the latest 10day sales period from the record for the comparable period a year ago, with only Chrysler showing a gain for the period.

title: China's OpeningDoor Policy
description: PARIS To the degree that it is not being thwarted by a timid bureaucracy frightened by his initiatives, Teng Hsiaoping's policy of openness seems deliberately aimed at exhibiting to foreigners the reality of China's backwardness and of holding before the eves of the Chinese the provocative images of a superindustrialized anti superdeveloped Japan and West. The aim is to educate through shock, and thus to achieve acceptance of the clear necessity and urgent priority of modernization.

title: Trip for Shah: Some Say No
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 2  In spite of the tremendous hostility to the Shah that exists in Iran, not everyone in the country is pleased with the likelihood that he will leave, at least for a time, once a new civilian government is established.

title: Deaths
description: MALKIN  Freda (nee Carmel) on December 25, 1978. Beloved wife of Julius, devoted mother of Milton, Sylvia Oberter and Lillian Geraci. Loving grandmother and greatgrandmother. Private services were held.

title: Western Union and Visa Offer Money by Phone
description: The Western Union Corporation announced yesterday an expansion of its electronic moneyorder service to permit the 54 million holders of Visa credit cards to transfer funds by telephone, effective immediately.

title: New York State's New Chief Judge
description: When the State Court of Appeals is in session in Albany, Lawrence H. Cooke,, the new Chief Judge, is in his chambers by 5 in the morning and he stays until 10 at night. He then walks two blocks to his $215amonth apartment, sips a cup of broth, doeS some reading and goes to bed.

title: Wall Street Bonuses Cheered Some in '78
description: It has been a mixed picture this season for a timehonored Wall Street tradition: the yearend bonus that for decades has gladdened the hearts and fattened the paychecks of the financial community.

title: Paterno Promises Return
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Jan. 2 (AP) Joe Paterno, the Penn State coach, denied his goal to win a national championship, told an undaunted group of soggy wellwishers today that We're going to be back.

title: Adams Opposes New Plan for Amtrak
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2  Transportation Secretary Brock Adams is opposed to an Amtrak proposal that the rail passenger service change its relation to the Government and operate under a Federal contract.

title: Real Estate
description: IN the 1940's the Durst Organization started assembling properties on Third Avenue in the midtown area, envisioning that once the Third Avenue El was down new development would make the avenue one of the great office and commercial thoroughfares of the city.

title: Best Buys
description: CONSUMERS were bracing themselves for another budgetary blow as the warning came last week that hamburger prices could rise 40 to 50 cents a pound this year. The fear of shortage was in the air, and the more cynical shopper, having already suffered the coffee, the orange juice and the lettuce crisis, began murmuring about industry conspiracy.

title: Moondog Refines Music in Germany
description: BOCHUM, WEST GERMANY FOR 30 years he was a landmark for New Yorkers. Decked out in a bizarre mockViking outfit, a horned helmet on his head and a spear in his hand, he stood on the corner of 59th Street and Sixth Avenue, majestically ignoring the giggles ana wisecracks, selling his poems and copies of his sheet music and playing what one critic called delicate Coplandesque rhythms on weird instruments of his own design. He called himself Moondog, after a dog he liked, and was unfailingly courteous and patient with the curious.

title: Careers
description: LOOK south, jobhunter. That is the advice from a nationwide survey of business and government hiring plans issued by Manpower Inc., a large supplier of parttime administrative and clerical personnel.

title: Calculating America's Taste
description: WHAT does natural taste like? When someone says he likes the oldfashioned flavor of a tomato sauce, what does he mean? If a food tastes processed, can that taste be described?

title: The City
description: Electricity, telephone and water service was restored to hundreds of families in the Coop City apartment complex in the eastern part of the Bronx, where a waterline break poured four feet of water into the basements of three buildings and knocked out utilities for hours.

title: A. T. Cross Raises Prices
description: The A. T. Cross Company, producers of writing instruments, announced yesterday that it had increased its prices an average of 7.5 percent on all Cross products containing precious metals such as gold and sterling silver, effective Dec. 30, 1978.

title: De Forest Billyou, 58, a Counsel In Finance for I.T.T. Corporation
description: De Forest Billyou, assistant general counsel for financial affairs of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, died yesterday morning of a heart attack on the way to his office at 320 Park Avenue in Manhattan. He was 58 years old and lived in Bronxville, N.Y.

title: Kitchen Equipment
description: TO a significant extent, cooking is a matter of control  making your tools do exactly what you want them to. And nowhere is control more important than in the use of the paring knife, a tool that is often called upon to do the most delicate kinds of work. When I find one that has just the weight, just the balance I want, a knife that has a grip that feels molded to my hand, I never give it up. (Testimony to that is a paring knife in my kitchen that I've used almost every day since the 1930's.)

title: CREDIT MARKETS Record Yields Expected In Treasury Sale Today
description: The Treasury is scheduled to sell oneyear bills today and 15year bonds tomorrow, and Government securities dealers yesterday estimated that the bills would yield roughly 10 percent and the bonds 9 percent. Both yields would be record highs.

title: On Taxes And Prices
description: WASHINGTONJonathan Swift said, The devil is the author of confusion. Swift might also have said, Confusion is the author of tax legislation.

title: Zambia Announces New Cabinet
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Jan. 2 (Reuters) Zambia's President, Kenneth D. Kaunda, announced today the appointment of a new, smaller Cabinet. Mr. Kaunda reduced the number of ministers from 29 to 19.

title: Marjorie Warren Karol is Wed
description: Marjorie Warren Karol of Weston, Mass., widow of Arthur S. Karol, was married on Monday to Martin S. Kramer, chairman and chief executive officer of Gimbel Brothers Inc. Rabbi Stephen S. Pearce performed the ceremony at Temple Sinai in Stamford, Conn. Mr. Kramer's first wife died.

title: More Dealing With Chinese
description: Prospects for expanded trade with China continue to improve following the United States' normalization of relations.

title: Dictaphone Bid Of Pitney Gains
description: PitneyBowes Inc. announced yesterday that it had received tenders of more than two million shares of common stock of the Dictaphone Corporation under an offer that expired at P.M. The company said it would make public as soon as possible the exact number of shares tendered.

title: 21 Rebels in Nicaragua Said to Die in Fighting
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Jan. 2 (UPI)  Fighting between rebels and Government troops grew in intensity in Nicaragua today. Military sources reported that at least 21 guerrillas of the Sandinist Napional Liberation Front had been killed in the last 48 hours.

title: U.S. Sending Kerosene to Iran
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (UPI)  The Carter Administration issued export licenses for $8.3 million worth of kerosene to be sent to Iran to relieve the critical shortage there, officials said today. Iran is normally a major exporter of petroleum products.

title: 8 Officials of Illinois Village Jailed In a Dispute on Building Permits
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 2  Eight top officials of Carpentersville, a village of 25,000 people about 45 miles northwest of Chicago, were jailed today for disobeying a court order requiring them to issue building permits to an area developer.

title: Getting Acquainted With Jean Piaget
description: REUD's name comes up constantly in conversation. Even people who've never read anything he wrote will frequently launch into a spirited attack or defense of his theories. But Jean Piaget, the most distinguished student of human development alive today, and thus the nearest thing to being Freud's contemporary equivalent, is almost never the topic of casual conversation. Few nonspecialists can summarize Piaget's principles despite the fact that this 82-year-old Swiss scholar has worked tirelessly to make his ideas known and a phalanx of authors has prepared compendiums, Summaries and interpretations of his work.

title: Arctic Air Expected to Drop Snow in Wake of 63 Day
description: After a wet and unseasonably warm day, the mercury in New York City began dropping last night, pushed down by a chilly blast of Arctic air that threatened to leave a sprinkling of snow.

title: Argentina Won't Let Jewish Publisher Out
description: BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 2  Jacobo Timmerman, an Argentine publisher who has been under arrest for 20 months without formal charges, did not attend the wedding in Israel this week of his oldest son, Daniel.

title: Advertising
description: THE Hertz Corporation, the dominant force in motor vehicle renting, has decided to review its relationship with Ted Bates & Company, its agency since 1973. The company, although experiencing its seventh consecutive year of record profits, has, trade sources say, lost a trifle of its share of the market. It is not used to this.

title: Palmer Sparkman, 44, Executive
description: Palmer D. Sparkman, director of Johnson & Higgins, international insurance brokers, and chairman of Johnson & Higgins of Texas Inc., died Monday of a heart attack at his home in Houston. He was 44 years old.

title: A.M.C. Price Rise
description: DETROIT, Jan. 2 (AP)  A.M.C., following the lead of the big three American auto makers, announced today that it was raising prices on its optional big engines for passenger cars and Jeeps by an average $53, or about seventenths of 1 percent.

title: Output of Steel Down in Week
description: Steel production for the week ended Dec. 30 fell to 2.59 million tons, down 2.8 percent from the previous week's total of 2.67 million, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: News of the Theater Meryl Streep to Open Next Month in New Babe Play
description: JOSEPH PAPP, never at a loss for showmanship, has just performed a deft Juggling act at his Public Theater. As a result, Meryl Streep will stay with him for two new productions.

title: Deaths
description: HASS  Peter. Beloved brother of Pearl Shapiro, Phyllis Adelstein and Philip. Adored uncle. Services Wednesday, 12:30 PM, BoulevardPark West, 115W 79 St, NYC.

title: New Publisher at Putnam
description: Phyllis Grann, who started in publishing in 1959 as Nelson Doubleday's secretary, has been named publisher of G. P. Putnam's. Sons, one of the older book companies in the United States. She becomes one of the few women to occupy the top post at a major hardcover publishing house.

title: Pennsylvania Republicans Win House Speakership
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Jan. 2  A longrunning dispute over control of the Pennsylvania House of Representatives was settled today in favor of the Republicans, who elected a party member as Speaker.

title: Americans' Iran Plants Halt Output
description: The turmoil in Iran has so disrupted the country's economic base that most American companies with factories there are being forced to halt production. at least temporarily.

title: World News Briefs
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Jan. 2 (Reuters)  A draft constitution for a blackruled Rhodesia was published today with a major surprise: the name of the new country will be Zimbabwe Rhodesia:

title: 2 Killed in Blast on West Bank
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 2 (Reuters)  Two Arab men were killed in an explosion last night in the village of Isawiya, just east of here, in the occupied Wett Bank of the Jordan, the police announced today. A spokesman said there was evidence that the two had been preparing a time bomb to be used for sabotage purposes when it exploded prematurely.

title: A Plan to Raise Flock Of Whooping Cranes Seems to Be Working
description: BOSQUE DEL APACHE, N.M., Jan. 2 (UPI)  Despite a mortality rate that has been higher than expected, a threeyearold experiment to establish a new flock of whooping cranes in the Rocky Mountains appears to be working.

title: Queen Lib, a Filly, Gains N.J. Thoroughbred Award
description: TRENTON, Jan. 2  Raritan Stables 4yearold filly, Queen Lib, has been named New Jersey thoroughbred of the year by a special committee acting on behalf of the state Equine Advisory Board. it was disclosed today.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: TROUBLES Two significant stage revivals are bowing in tomorrow Off Broadway and Off Off Broadway: William Gibson's The Miracle Worker at the Equity Library Theater, 103d Street at Riverside Drive, and Alice Childress's Trouble in Mind at the Henry Street Settlement's Pilgrim Theater, 240 East 3d Street.

title: South African Is Killed by Shark
description: DURBAN, South Africa, Jan. 2 (AP) A police officer was killed by a shark while skindiving with a friend in Sordwana Bay, The Johannesburg Star reported today. The victim's diving partner speared the shark, causing it to release the victim's legs, but the policeman died before reaching shore. It was the first fatal shark attack along South Africa's Natal. Province coast in 15 years, the police said.

title: COMPANY NEWS Chrysler Sells Unit To PeugeotCitron
description: DETROIT, Jan. 2 (UPI)  The Chrysler Corporation announced today the sale of its European financial operations to PSA PeugeotCitron of France for an estimated $80 million.

title: EARNINGS Chessie Winds Up Year With Strong 4th Quarter
description: Chessie System, the nation's leading coal hauler, reported yesterday a 37 percent jump in earnings for the final quarter of 1978. But the full year's earnings were down 19 percent, reflecting a $67 million loss in the opening quarter due to the 110day coal miners' strike.

title: Weather Fails To Reduce Aid To the Neediest
description: The inclement weather has failed to dampen the enthusiasm of the supporters of the 67th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: One Dead, 30 Missing As Caribbean Tanker Catches Fire in Storm
description: MIAMI, Jan. 2 (UPI)  A Cypriot tanker that caught fire in a storm in the Caribbean Sea yesterday, leaving 30 of its 35 crewmen missing and another known dead, apparently sank late today, the Coast Guard reported.

title: Julia Rush Biddle Henry
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 2 (AP)  Julia Rush Biddle Henry, a leader of Philadelphia society, died Sunday at Chestnut Hill Hospital. She was 92 years old.

title: Good Old Boy Woody Hayes
description: People keep saying that Woody Hayes is a great football coach who overstayed his time. This implies that there was time when slugging a member of the opposing team was proper coachly deportment.

title: Four Arraigned In Death of Man In IRT Dispute
description: Four young white men from Long Island were arraigned in Manhattan Criminal Court yesterday on charges of seconddegree murder in the fatal stabbing of a young black man from Queens during a fight in the Times Square subway station early New Year's Day.

title: Deaths
description: GINSLEY  Sidonia R. Beloved wife of the late Bernard Ginsley, devoted sister of Frances Bromberg and Florence Rosenberg. adored Aunt and Great Aunt. Funeral service will be held, The Riverside, 76 St & Amsterdam Ave., 10:15am, on Wed, Jan 3, 1979

title: Teng Invites Senator Goldwater to Peking for a Talk
description: PEKING, Jan. 2  The senior Deputy Prime Minister, Teng Hsiaoping, today invited Senator Barry Goldwater, an outspoken opponent of America's normalization of relations with China, to visit Peking and discuss the situation.

title: Connecticut Auto Inspections
description: HARTFORD, Jan. 2 (AP)  The number of Connecticut Motor Vehicles Department traveling inspection teams has been cut back from three to one since a Federal grant supporting the program ran out, officials say. However, the single team will continue doing spot checks until 1980, when the department begins a combined safety and emissions inspection program. Officials say the spot checks found that more than half of the 4,500 vehicles inspected passed during the threeyear project.

title: Around the Nation
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 2 (AP) Federal investigator said today that the pilot of a DC8 jetliner that crashed when it apparently ran out of fuel Thursday night might never talk to investigators.

title: Two Indicted in Bronx Murder
description: An indictment returned yesterday accused two teenagers of the sledgehammer murder of an 84yearold Bronx widow last month. District Attorney Mario Merola of the Bronx said that Miguel Cruz, 18 years old, who lived in the same building as the victim, and Oscar Arroyo, 15, had been charged with murder, arson, burglary and robbery in connection with the Dec. 10 killing.

title: Dividends
description: TUESDAY, JAN. 2, 1979

title: Death
description: SHERMANFlorence Louise Loc. schhorn, Adjunct Professor in Psychology and Academic Foundations at Passaic County Community Collette (Paterson, N.J.). Died gently at age 32, on December 31, 1978. A remarkable and good young woman who brought warmth to all who knew her. She will be deeply missed by her family, friends, colleagues, and students. Services at Vander Platt Funeral Home, 257 Godwin Ave, Wyckoff, N.J., Thursday, January 4, 2 PM.

title: JERSEY WILL REMOVE LIQUOR PRICE RULES
description: TRENTON, Jan. 2  The Byrne administration announced plans today to deregulate the liquor industry, a move officials said would reduce the price of a fifth of liquor by 67 cents to $1.25 and eliminate illegal kickbacks in the industry.

title: Miss Bellamy Says Koch Won't Give Budget Data
description: New York's City Council President, Carol Bellamy, said yesterday that Mayor Koch had refused to give her necessary information about upcoming budget cuts despite a formal request she filed under the state's Freedom of Information Act.

title: Carey Names Cooke ChidJudge; 68 Recess Appointments Also Set
description: ALBANY, Jan.2  Governor Carey today named Judge Lawrence H. Cooke, a liberal Democrat who is Mr. Carey's philosophical ally, to be chief judge of the Court of Appeals. He was the first judge to be appointed under the state's new judicialselection procedure.

title: Notes on People
description: Physically, President Carter was described as in fine shape, but that doesn't mean he is without discomfort. First, the good news. According to the White House press secretary, Jody Powell, Mr. Carter is feeling very well after his hemorrhoid troubles, well enough to have resumed jogging during his holiday stay at Camp David. The bad news  assuming that's the right characterization  is that the President's brother had unkind things to say about the White House.

title: Code Set On Buying By Nations
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2  The United States and its major trading partners are close to adoption of new standards for government procurement.

title: South Korea's President Assailed By Rival just Freed From Prison
description: SEOUL, South Korea Jan. 2  The recently freed leader of the South Korean political opposition, Kim Dae Jung, has criticized President Park Chung Hee in much the same way that led to Mr. Kim's imprisonment 33 months ago.

title: The Region
description: CHERRY HILL, N.J.  Kenneth N. MacDonald, vice chairman of the New Jersey Casino Control Commission, recommended that Resorts International be censured by the commission for failing to notify the state that $179,195 was missing from its Atlantic City casino.

title: Sports Today
description: Sports Today

title: Brooklyn Bridge Troupe Plans Double OneAct Bill
description: A double bill of oneact plays by Kenneth Koch will open the second season of the Brooklyn Bridge Theater Company on Jan. 12.

title: Head Resigns At Lafayette
description: The chief executive of the Lafayette Radio Electronics Corporation has resigned, citing policy differences with the company's board of directors. This was the latest of two recent events involving the company, including last month's announcement by Lafayette that preliminary indications showed it would be in default on its bank loans, and, last week, the proposal by Commodore International Ltd. to acquire Lafayette.

title: FOES OF COSTSAVING VEX PENTAGON CHIEF
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2  Nearly two years after taking over the Pentagon, Harold Brown expresses puzzlement and some dismay over the political pressures and interservice rivalries that he says thwart him in efforts to save more money and to improve efficiency in the Defense Department.

title: ExInformant for D.A. Guilty in Sotheby Case
description: A former paid informant for the Manhattan District Attorney's office pleaded guilty in State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday to trying to trick Sotheby Parke Bernet into paying $100,000 for information about a nonexistent investigation of the auction house.

title: Market Place
description: THE decision by UV Industries Inc. to sell the Federal Pacific Electric Company to the Reliance Electric Company for $345 million creates a dilemma for VictOr Posner, the controversial financier.

title: Woman, 71, Going on Trial For Conspiring to Kill Judge
description: A 71-year-old woman who lives at the Plaza Hotel went on trial yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan on charges of having conspired to murder the Rockland County surrogate who granted her wealthy husband a divorce:

title: Alleged Robber Shot in Queens By OffDuty Nassau Policeman
description: An offduty Nassau County police officer last night shot and wounded a man who was allegedly attempting to hold up a Queens doctor's office where the policeman was a patient.

title: Cold Delays Search for More Bodies Near Chicago
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 2  Hampered today by more than nine inches of snow that fell over the New Year's weekend and a wind chill factor of 40 degrees below zero, Cook County sheriff's investigators delayed the resumption of the search for more bodies at the suburban Norwood Park Township home of John Wayne Gacy.

title: Life Insurance Sales Practices Said to Harm Buyers
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2  Buyers of life insurance policies often lose money because salesmen do not give them enough information to purchase policies on the basis of suitability, quality and cost, a House subcommittee charged in a report on life insurance marketing released today.

title: An IRT Change Clerk Slain Inside His Booth By Bandit With Knife
description: A Transit Authority change clerk in the Bronx was fatally stabbed in his booth at the 161st Street IRT station outside of Yankee Stadium yesterday morning following what the police said was a struggle with an assailant he might have known.

title: COMMODITIES Gold Futures Down $5; Pork Bellies Up 2 Limit
description: Spirited trading in precious metals highlighted otherwise lethargic sessions on most commodity futures exchanges yesterday. On the Comex in New York, gold futures opened stronger on news of a weaker dollar in Europe.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: BIC Pen Corporation, Milford, Conn., announced the formation of a BIC Special Markets division, formerly known as the Ad Specialty and Premium division, and named Rudy Hasak president.

title: Marks Beats Ashe in 5 Sets, Gains Final With Vilas
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 2 (AP)  John Marks of Australia outlasted Arthur Ashe today and moved into the $300,000 Australian open tennis final. Marks defeated the American in a marathon centercourt semifinal battle, 64, 62, 26, 16, 97.

title: Entertainment Events
description: METROPOLITAN OPERA, Lincoln Center, Puccini's Tosca, 8.

title: TV: Wheelchair Drama, Some Kind of Miracle
description: IN what might be called wheelchair drama, a young man, as in The Men or, more recently, Coming Home, or occasionally a young woman, as in The Other Side of the Mountain, must come to terms with a crippling injury. Despite very great problems, it can be safely predicted, courage, love and deepening wisdom will find a way.

title: Technology
description: FOR almost two decades, various industries have looked longingly at the idea of running their hydraulic pumps and valves with a fluid that is mostly water instead of conventional hydraucoil.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M., WNCN. Vocalise, Rachmaninoff; Danse macabre, SaintSans; Overture to the Birthday Ode, Boyce; Fanfare for the Common Man, Copland; Sonata in D Minor for Violin and Guitar, Corelli.

title: TV: Tony Orlando Back Brimming With Energy
description: THE act used to be known as Tony Orlando and Dawn, the latter consisting of two female backup singers for the star. Then, about two years ago, around the time of the suicide of Freddie Prinze, Mr. Orlando went through a period of emotional strain and temporarily dropped out of show business. He returns to television tonight, on NBC at 8, and he is just about on his own.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE Mrs. Shortway Promoted At Bergdorf Goodman
description: Kay Larson Shortway, who for the last 18 months has been vice president and general manager at Bergdorf Goodman's only branch store, in White Plains, yesterday was named to a new Bergdorf corporate post as senior vice president and general merchandise manager.

title: Deaths
description: CHILL  Harry Dear brother of Ida. Adored uncle and greatuncle. Services Wednesday, 12 noon Jeffer Funeral Home Hillside Ave at 188 St. Hollis, L.I.

title: U.S.C. Ranked No. 1 In Last Coaches' Poll
description: In a surprising conclusion to a series of unexpected bowlrelated incidents, the University of Southern California was named the 1978 National Collegiate champion yesterday by the United Press International board of 35 major college coaches.

title: Emerson and Skil Agree to a Merger
description: The Emerson Electric Company and the Skil Corporation said jointly yesterday that the directors of both companies had agreed to a merger calling for Emerson to pay $30 a share in cash and stock, or about $58 million, to shareholders of Skil.

title: Investment Trust Extends Exchange
description: Institutional Investors Trust, a real estate investment trust, announced that the exchange offer to holders of its $20 million, 7 percent senior subordinated notes due 1980 had been extended to Jan. 19, 1979, when the exchange, offer will terminate.

title: E. Carolina 25Footer Sinks Iona, 7675
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Jan 2 (AP)  George Maynor's 25foot jump shot with two seconds remaining lifted East Carolina to a 7675 college basketball victory over Iona tonight.

title: Mexico Says Oil Reserves Jump
description: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 2 (UPI)  Mexico's proven oil reserves almost doubled in the last five months of 1978, jumping from 20.2 billion to 40.1 billion barrels of crude oil, the director of the state oil agency said today.

title: EXODUS FROM IRAN GROWING AS TROOPS TAKE OVER AIRPORT
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 2  The exodus of foreigners from Iran accelerated today as the Iranian armed forces sent additional troops to the Teheran airport to make sure that departure was possible.

title: News Summary
description: The exodus of foreigners from Iran accelerated as Iranian troops sent extra forces to the Teheran airport to insure that departure was possible. With Iranian military air controllers replacing striking civilians, about 2,000 foreigners departed. Of the 38,000 Americans still in Iran, 5,000 are expected to leave this week. [Page A1, Column 6.]

title: Companies Report Earnings
description: For periods as shown. (N) indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Stock Exchange and (O) overthecounter

title: European Snowstorm Is Over
description: LONDON, Jan. 2 (UPI)  The winter's worst storm tapered off across northern and eastern Europe today, but slippery roads and huge snowdrifts made getting to work hazardous.

title: Historical Society Begins A New Admissions Policy
description: For the first time since it opened its doors in 1804, the NewYork Historical Society has instituted a discretionary admissions policy under which visitors may pay whatever they choose  but they must pay something. The suggested contribution is $1.50 for adults and 75 cents for children.

title: Turkey's Interior Minister Quits Following Riots and Martial Law
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 2  Turkey's Interior Minister, Irian Ozaydinli, resigned today after a week of martial law affecting a third of the nation's population.

title: ExRights Activist Sworn In As New Washington Mayor
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2  Marion Barry Jr., a former civil rights activist who was the first national chairman of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee in 1960, was sworn in today for a fouryear term as Mayor of the District of Columbia.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 2 (AP) Harold Enarson, the president of Ohio State University, named a committee today to conduct what he called a national search for a new football coach.

title: Xerox Increasing 5 Rental Prices
description: The Xerox Corporation said it had increased the rental prices on five of its early copier machines and that the increase was within the Carter Administration's antiinflation guidelines.

title: Cuba Arrives at Fork in the Road: To U.S. or Africa
description: MIAMI, Jan. 2  Twenty years after the revolution that brought Fidel Castro to power, Cuba is not doing as well as its Government would have the world believe, and not nearly as badly as its enemies would wish.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRIVING TOMORROW Jan. 4

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: There are many men  sometimes hunters, sometimes not  who regard fine guns with the same reverence an art collector displays before the work of an Old Master.

title: ExBronx Councilman Says He Quit to Seek Borough's Presidency
description: Stanley Simon said yesterday that he had resigned his City Council post last Friday in order to seek the Borough presidency of the Bronx, the office that was vacated on New Year's Day by Robert Abrams, the state's new Attorney General.

title: Stage: Monteith & Rand on Broadway
description: THE harshest possible test of an improvisational comedy duo is to put it up on a Broadway stage, with all its distances and its protocol of expectation.

title: WASHINGTON
description: PARIS  The one unmistakable and unavoidable thing for an American visiting Western Europe these days is the inflation. We complain about high prices in the United States, but over here they make even the Fifth Avenue stores in New York seem like bargainbasement cheapskates.

title: British Paper Widens Scope
description: BONN, Jan. 2  The Financial Times, Britain's major business newspaper, published its first issue in Continental Europe today as part of a drive to increase its United States and European readership.

title: Jazz: Directions Band Plays at Circle in Square
description: WHEN Jack DeJohnette introduced the latest edition of his band, Directions, at the Public Theater a little over a year ago, it seemed to this reviewer that it was really two bands coexisting rather Uncomfortably as one. When Mr. DeJohnette was playing fast and hard on his drums behind the trumpet pyrotechnics of Lester Bowie, the music was expressionist new jazz. When Mr. DeJohnette played piano, blending with the guitarist John Abercrombie and the bassist Eddie Gomez, the music was impressionist chamber jazz. The twain never met, and there was not much reason to think they would.

title: Dr. Walter R. Benyhill; A Professor of Medicine
description: Dr. Walter Reece Berryhill, Sarah Graham Kenan professor of medicine emeritus of the University of North Carolina's Medical School, died Monday at the North Carolina Memorial Hospital in Chapel Hill after a long illness. He was 78 years old and a resident of Chapel Hill.

title: Queens Police Precincts Revised
description: A revision of police precinct boundary lines in Queens that forces changes in many of the 644 foot posts and 189 radiocar sectors will go into effect today.

title: Books of The Times
description: TIRED of the old descriptions of the world, Ann Beattie has evolved new ones. In place of people trapped- by necessity, she writes about those who are burdened by freedom. She is interested in what people do when they drop out of convention.

title: High Rates: Do They Work?
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2  Last Nov. 1, facing the dilemma of a deflated dollar and an inflated economy, the White House announced an increase of one full percentage point in the discount rate of the Federal Reserve System.

title: Islanders Rout Canucks
description: UNIONDALE, L. I.,Jan. 2  Playing with a puck that appeared to belong only to them, the Islanders continued to amass extraordinary statistics tonight in a 90 trouncing of the Vancouver Canucks.

title: Blast Could Delay Space Shuttle
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (UPI)  A pump in a test version of a space shuttle engine exploded in a ground firing last week, the space agency reported today. The failure threatened a new delay in the craft's maiden orbital flight.

title: Khomeini to Stay on in France
description: PARIS, Jan. 2  Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the Iranian religious leader, has received permission to stay on in France after the normal deadline for his departure passes this Friday, according to an aide.

title: PPG Purchases Allegheny Unit
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 2 (UPI)  PPG Industries has purchased the Chemical Products division of the Chemetron Corporation, a subsidiary of Allegheny Ludlum Industries, it was announced today.

title: Gooding Leaves Syracuse To Play for Iona College
description: Ed Gooding, a 6foot7inch freshman forward from New York City, has left Syracuse University and intends to enroll at Iona College in New Rochelle, N.Y., where he would become eligible to play by the middle of next season. Gooding, an allcity selection at Xavier High School, was apparently upset about his lack of playing time with the Orangemen. He played in only three of Syracuse's first nine games.

title: Scotch Whisky Revives An Island
description: IT seemed an unlikely spot to open a whisky business. A small island in the Inner Hebrides, a tidal whirlpool sealing off its northern shore, five snowcapped peaks rising from its rocky terrain, acres of wild brush, and the occasional patch of heather or pine. Its inhabitants: 4,000 red deer, countless species of birds and about 100 men and women, mostly selfsufficient crofters speaking a lilting Gaelic tongue, living off land where their ancestors had settled under feudal conditions centuries before.

title: N.C. State Women's Five Upsets U.C.L.A., 9069
description: RALEIGH, N.C., Jan. 2 (AP) Genia Beasley scored 26 points and Trudi Lacey added 18 as the 10thranked North Carolina State women's basketball team upset fourthranked University of California, Los Angeles, 9069, tonight.

title: Topics Adult Education
description: Winning football games was the vocation of Wayne Woodrow Hayes during his 28 years as head coach at Ohio State. But even a coach as successful as Woody Hayes occasionally found his teams losing. Then, sometimes, he would rage against the fates  and those unfortunate enough to cross his path, like the hapless television cameraman whom he kicked and punched last year. ,

title: 60Minute Gourmet
description: ITHIN recent years there has been an unusual trend in the proprietorship of restaurants. Years ago, when I first arrived in New York for the World's Fair of 1939, the vast majority of restaurants in America were owned by entrepreneurs who might have known a good deal about food and table service but who themselves were almost wholly unskilled in the kitchen. They could flame a crepe table- side or prepare a dish like steak Diane for the delectation and delight of their customers, but they never became involved with the intricacies of saucemaking and so on.

title: GatewayGila Deal
description: The Gateway Sporting Goods Company of New York announced that, subject to approval of its board of directors, it had purchased, for a nominal consideration. 33 1/3 percent of the mineral leases, gold mines, gold claims and gold prospects of Gila Monster Gold Mines in Gila County, Ariz.

title: Patriots Sue to Keep Fairbanks
description: The New England Patriots, whose Super Bowl dreams evaporated last Sunday, filed suit in United States District Court in Boston yesterday to prevent the University of Colorado from hiring away Chuck Fairbanks.

title: Fink Is Named 98th Speaker Of Assembly by Democrats
description: ALBANY, Jan. 2  Stanley Fink was unanimously named the 98th Speaker of the New York State Assembly tonight by the Democratic caucus on the eve of the convening of the 202d session of the Legislature.

title: U.S. Court Assails Judge On Practical Joke at Trial
description: Justice Gerald S. Held of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn was criticized yesterday by a Federal Appeals Court that said his poor taste was exceeded only by his astonishingly bad judgment in playing a practical joke during a criminal trial.

title: New Yorkers,etc.
description: FOR awhile, it was China, but even before President Carter's announcement of diplomatic recognition, it was slipping as the ultimate vacation spot with the people who care about ultimate vacation spots. The slippage occurred when almost every fashionable party boasted among its guests not one recent returnee from Peking, but two or three. Oneupmanship was impossible under such circumstances.

title: Two Young Stars From Gascony
description: OST American tourists in Europe, seeking the pleasures of the table, gravitate to Paris, Burgundy, Alsace, Bordeaux and the south of France. One of the lesser known regions is that of Gascony, that land to the southwest of France most celebrated as the home of the Three Musketeers. Actually it is a territory with numerous restaurants and chefs who have achieved high praise for their gastronomic derringdo, and that number includes Andr Daguin of Auch and JeanLouis Palladin of La Table des Cordeliers at Condom.

title: Carter, Fearing the Impact on Iran, Tells Navy Unit Not to Head There.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2  President Carter has decided against sending an American carrier task force into Iranian waters so as not to inflame further the internal situation in Iran, Administration officials said today.

title: China's Mission to U.N. Celebrates New Ties
description: China's delegate to the United Nations, Chen Chu, gave a buffet party for hundreds of Chinese and Americans here yesterday to celebrate the renewal of diplomatic relations with the United States.

description: More executive posts were filled by United States corporations in 1978 than in former years, with such hiring up 32 percent from 1977. Because of uncertainty now about the economy, 1979 is

title: How Blacks View Their Lamer Role in Rhodesia's Army
description: BALLA BALLA, Rhodesia  In Rhodesian terms, Lieut. Fani Ndhluvu has passed through the eye of a needle. At the age of 37, he is a black officer in the Rhodesian African Rifles; a key component of a Government army that reserved its officer corps exclusively for whites until two years ago.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP)  Forty percent of the nation's medical schools question prospective students about their views on abortion, but a survey sponsored by the Department of Health, Education and Welfare found that only one school acknowledged that those views could be a factor in the admissions process.

title: Unbeaten Temple, Friars Post Victories at Palestra
Maryland Women Defeat Tar Heels. 9382
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md., Jan. 3 (AP)  Maryland converted seven one-andone foul situations in the last 31/2 minutes, held off a North Carolina rally and defeated the Tar Heels, 9382, in an Atlantic Coast Conference women's basketball game tonight.

title: Company and Union In Dispute as Women Undergo Sterilization
description: WILLOW ISLAND, W. Va., Jan, 3 (AP)  The manager of the American Cyanamid plant here says he cannot explain why five female employees had themselves sterilized rather than accept new lobs at the plant.

title: CHINA BACKS POSTER AS CITIZENS FORUM; Party Says Heavens Will Not Fall if Variety of Views Is Allowed
description: PEKING, Jan. 3  China gave strong official support today to the right of people to put up wall posters, some of which have become increasingly daring in demanding democracy and have shown signs of incipient underground organization.

title: Con Eatson Purchases Load of CutRate Funeral
description: solidated Edison Company has made bargain purchase of Indonesian res ual oil that it said would save custom ers about $1.8 million in fuel and lated tax costs on their bills during next several months.

title: Vehicle Output A Record in 78
description: DETROIT, Jan. 3 (UPI)  Car and truck production in the United States reached a record 12,622,549 units in 1978, surpassing last year's total by 1.2 percent, the four major manufacturers have reported.

title: Landmark Unit Facing a Cutoff Of City's Funds
description: Mayor Koch is expected to tell the Landmarks Preservation Commission that it must come up with private financing to support its activities or virtually go out of existence, City Hall aides confirmed yesterday. The action is part of continuing effort on the part of the Mayor to close the city's budget gap.

title: Upstater Mentioned as Possible Assembly Leader
description: ALBANY, Jan. 3  The State Assembly moved toward reorganization of its leadership last night with Daniel B. Walsh considered by those close to the new Speaker to be the leading candidate to become majority leader, and the jobs of several current committee chairmen reportedly in jeopardy.

title: GOVERNOR PROPOSES ADDITIONAL TAX CUT TO FOSTER ECONOMY  $225 MILLION DECREASE URGED Carey Also Says He Will Bar Rises in Fares for Mass Transit Better Services Vowed
description: ALBANY, Jan. 3  Governor Carey, entering his second term without the resources for costly new initiatives, opened the 202d session of the Legislature today by stressing plans to streamline and improve a government wedded to austerity and by calling for a $225 million tax cut.

title: FRANCIS ELLSWORTH BARED

title: Koch's Budget Unit Urges Closing Of 15 Schools, Higher Lunch Fees
description: The Mayor's Office of Management and Budget has asked the Board of Education to make cuts in its 197980 budget that would close 15 schools, increase the cost of school lunches and pupils bus and subway passes, and eliminate fullday kindergartens.

However, a working paper of the Office of Management and Budget that outlined final budget decisions for the health pro- grams, a copy of which was obtained by The New York Times, indicates that many of the programs will be financed at a lower level than in the fiscal year 1979, which ends Sept. 30.
