title: Film:Saga From Japan:In Political Milieu
description: "MY Love Has Been Burning," the English translation of the Japanese title of the 1949 Kenji Mizoguchi film, must rank with "The Flavor of Green Tea Over Rice" as the English-translated Japanese title least likely to mean anything whatsoever to Western minds. Yet the film, which has its New York theatrical premiere today at the Cinema Studio 2, is one to which attention must be paid, being, as it is, a product of that director's last great productive period, from 1946 until his death in 1956, when he turned out such works as "Utamaro and His Five Women," "A Geisha," "Ugetsu" and "Sansho the Bailiff.""My Love Has Been Burning" is not the equal of those masterpieces, if only because its politics confuse its passions, at least to someone not familiar with modern Japanese history. Though one of Mizoguchi's principles was always to identify the society in which his characters functioned, the milieu of "My Love Has Been Burning" effectively obscures the film's major concerns until the movie is halfway through.The time is 1884, when Japan was moving erratically toward a form of democratic government. The film is basically the story of two young women, friends from childhood, and their different responses to a revolution that changed everything in their world except the status of women. Eiko is a well-born provincial who runs away to Tokyo to give her hopes, pride and virtue to the radical Liberal Party. Chiyo, the daughter of the servants in Eiko's house, is sold into servitude by her father. Though Eiko is serious, dedicated, firm of purpose and not very attractive, and Chiyo is silly, willful and pretty, they both suffer equally at the hands of men, even those who pledge themselves publicly to women's liberation  and behave like shoguns at home. Eiko is first betrayed by her childhood sweetheart, who pretends to be dedicated to the liberal cause but is actually a government spy, and then by her husband, Omoi, the head of the Liberal Party, who takes Chiyo as his mistress, a half-lot that is accepted by Chiyo until her consciousness is raised.The screenplay by Yoshikata Yoda, Mizoguchi's long-time screenwriter, and Kaneto Noda spends so much time establishing the political scene that it appears to discover the film's center  the relationship between these two very different women  only by accident. This, of course, is not true. Mizoguchi and his collaborators knew what they were up to from the start, though we don't. The early scenes, some hauntingly beautiful, are essential, but they have no life of their own, nor does the film, until Mizoguchi fixes his attention on the personal stories of Eiko and Chiyo.When the two women wind up in the same prison  Eiko for subversive political activities, Chiyo for setting fire to the mill where she works, an act of personal pique that, to her fury, is regarded as political sabotage, "My Love Has Been Burning" becomes a vivid, tumultuous emotional drama, Zolaesque in the way it details the horrors of the new industrial society.Kinuyo Tanaka is splendid in what at first appears to be the thankless role of the suffering Eiko. Her small, stumpy figure and purity of heart are not initially endearing, but as the performance progresses, she becomes transformed. She never becomes exactly beautiful, though there is real beauty in her intelligence and unheroic fortitude. Mitsuko Mito is lovely as the frivolous Chiyo, even if her final reconciliation with Eiko seems to be less a revelation of character than a convenience of the film."My Love Has Been Burning" lacks the cool grandeur of Mizoguchi's greatest films, which may be because it seems filled with the sort of close-ups he usually used so sparingly. It's not the film one should see as an introduction to Mizoguchi, but it's a must for anyone remotely interested in the career of one of the great directors of the sound era.

title: $1.5 Million Is Stolen From an Armored Car In Town in Michigan
description: LAKEPORT, Mich., Jan. 4 (UPI)  An armored car was robbed of more than $1.5 million tonight while two of its three guards sipped coffee in a restaurant. The police were Seeking the third guard

title: Therapy Assisted by Neediest Cases Fund Helps to End Young Woman's Depression
description: Miss B., who lives on Long Island, was 16 years old when her father died leaving her, a younger sister and her mother to support themselves. Ever since, Miss B. has suffered from a depression that subsequent events have deepened.

title: Business and the Law
description: ONE company has been wronged by another or thinks it has. The second company is sued. And material that might decide the lawsuit memos, confidential correspondence, what-have-you  is tucked away in its chief executive's righthand drawer. alone with a lot of other sensitive files.

title: The Carey Appointments
description: ALBANY, Jan. 4  When Governor Carey decided to use the 60 hours between the death of the 201st Legislature at midnight on Dec. 31 and the first rap of the gavel of the 202d Legislature to force his annointees into office without Senate re- view, he expected some political fallout. He precipitated a heated battle instead.

title: Japan Reserves At New High
description: TOKYO, Jan. 4 (AP)  Japan's gold and foreign exchange reserves stand at a record high $33 billion after gaining $10.1 billion in 1978, the Finance Ministry reported today.

title: Weight Watchers Moved To Doyle Dane Bernbach
description: Weight Watchers International, which has its famous weightcontrol program, and Foodways National, which sells Weight Watchers frozen dinners, were both acquired last year by the H.J. Heinz Company. Now both have been assigned to Do yle Dane Bernbach.

title: Cabaret: Tony Powers
description: IN his dark, doublebreasted suit, dark shirt and loud tie, and with his hair slicked back and parted in the middle, Tony Powers looks as if he were auditioning for the role of Robert DeNiro's thuggish older brother in Godfather III. In fact, he's a singersongwriter who is performing nightly except Sundays through Jan. 14 at J.P.'s an Upper East Side club.

title: Broadway
description: New Levin comedy about a critic waits in the wings.

title: Workers on Job With No Strike At Cemeteries
description: Cemetery workers who had threatened a strike throughout the metropolitan area continued to work yesterday after their leader called off the walkout and began a hunger strike.

title: Relatives of Missing Latins Press Drive for Accounting
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 4  Shortly after the 1964 military coup in Brazil, a politically moderate federal deputy and welltodo businessman named Rubens Paiva was stripped of his political rights by the new regime.

title: 11Second Blast Winds Up Reign Of the Blenheim
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 4  Seconds after 10 A.M. today, the domed concrete facade of the Blenheim Hotel, a certified state treasure, crumpled into rubble, blown apart by 400 pounds of dynamite.

title: Rotz Named a State Steward
description: John L. Rotz, who rode more than 2,800 winners in his jockey career, was appointed by The Jockey Club yesterday as steward at New York Racing Association tracks.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: ?? ?? ?? ?? ?? about the Eternal Light radio program incorrectly identified Dr. Louis Finkelstein as the late chancellor of the Jewish Theological Seminary. Dr. Finkelstein is alive and is emeritus chancellor of the seminary.

title: New Faces: A Guide to Fresh Talent in the City Now
description: Following are some of the brightest new faces now appearing on the New York scene in the opinions of eight arts critics for The New York Times:

title: U.S., in Court Suit, Battles to Bar Admission of Data on Waterway
description: GREENVILLE, Miss., Jan 4  Government lawyers fought with little success today to bar, as evidence for a Federal court, a series of documents, including a report to Congress, tending to show that the United States Army Corps of Engineers exceeded its authority in widening the Tennessee Tombigbee Waterway. The waterway widening project is now under construction throgh Alabama and Mississippi.

title: News Summary
description: The United States pledged cooperation with Iran's new civilian government, whether or not the Shah remained in Iran. After intensive talks, the Carter Administration decided to endorse the new regime in advance. It expects the Shah to take a temporary vacation abroad, leaving several days after the civilian regime is installed tomorrow. [Page A1, Column 6.]

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Major retail chains reported strong December sales, raising hopes for a livelier consumer buying pattern in early 1979. The performance contrasted with pessimistic projections for the national economy. Only Sears, Roebuck had a sales decline for the month, while some other chains experienced doubledigit gains. [Page A1.]

title: City's Fiscal Plan Includes Reduction of 7,000 Jobs to Cut Deficit for 1980
description: Mayor Koch yesterday announced a series of cuts he is likely to order to close next year's budget gap, and said he was relying on the state and Federal governments to give the city more than twothirds of the $439 million it needs to elimi nate the deficit.

title: Ford Raises Cars 1.7%, Trucks 1.8%
description: DETROIT, Jan. 4 (AP)  An acrosstheboard auto price increase averaging $124, or 1.7 percent, was announced today by the Ford Motor Company.

title: Action Called Slow in BMT Death
description: The Transit Authority said yesterday that a subway motorman and a train dispatcher had been sluggish in their response to the plight of a 66-year-old man who died of a heart attack aboard a BMT train last month as it rolled for a halfhour through 13 Brooklyn stations with angry passengers pounding on the motorman's door, before finding help.

title: Kennedy Gives Priority to Antitrust Policy and to the Criminal Code
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4  Senator Edward M. Kennedy said in an interview today that he intended to run the Senate Judiciary Committee firmly and wanted it to deal quickly with antitrust and criminal code legislation. while beginning a longrange look at the increasing cost and inaccessibility of the judicial system.

title: Dow Adds 8.75 as Stocks Gain for 3d Straight Day
description: The stock market chalked up three winning sessions in a row for 1979 yesterday, with prices bolstered by steady dollar in fore'gncurrency dealings and by reassurances from Federal Reserve Board governor about the nation's troublesome trade deficit.

title: Moscow Says Drive Into Cambodia Is by VietnameseSupported Rebels
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 4  The Soviet Union, indicating approval of the Vietnamesebacked military offensive into Cambodia, today reported a string of victories and said the campaign was continuing.

title: Flyers End Islander Streak, 32
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 4  An aggressive and slightly desperate band of Philadelphia Flyers handed the New York Islanders one of their rare National Hockey League defeats tonight, rebounding from a 20 deficit early in the second period to register a 32 triumph before a capacity crowd of 17,077 at the Spectrum. They did it with three powerplay goals in the second period. the final one by Bobby Clarke.

title: Continuum Salutes Virgil Thomson at Tully Hall
description: Both as a composer who has steered his own, clearheaded course and a critic whose judgments have been confident, concise, and intoxicatingly urbane, Virgil Thomson has been a vital force in American music for well over half a century. At the age of 82, he still writes music, he still says what he thinks, and he still lives at the Chelsea Hotel on West 23d Street. In sum, he is an original, and he is about to be honored at a Virgil Thomson Retrospective tomorrow night at 8 P.M. in Alice Tully Hall.

title: LINKS OF ESTROGEN TO CANCER REVIVED
description: BOSTON, Jail. 4 (AP)  The largest study ever conducted on women who take estrogen in menopause concludes that the medicine can cause cancer of the uterus and that the risk increases the longer the medicine is used.

title: Peking Appoints Close Associate of Teng as Party Secretary General
description: PEKING, Jan. 4  A close associate of Deputy Prime Minister Teng Hsiaoping has been appointed to the recreated post of secretary general of the Chinese Communist Party in a major political move.

title: The Foster Care System: Few Homes for Minorities
description: The foster care system in New York City has come under scrutiny as a result of citizen group reports, journalistic investigations and Comptroller's office inquiries. One of the oldest challenges to the system is contained in the allegations in a lawsuit that hal been pending in the Federal court here for five and a half years. Essentially, the complaint alleges that the public authorities in New York City

title: Ski Reports
description: All ski areas are operating on very limited terrain. Figures in parentheses show total trails and number open at each area. Skiarea forecasts appear on the weather page. For information: New York, (212) 7558100; New Jersey, (609) 2928456 Thursdays and Fridays from 2 to 4 P.M.; Pennsylvania, (717) 4215791; New Hampshire, (603) 2242525; Vermont, (802) 2290531, and Massachusetts, (800) 6285030.

title: Conrad Hilton, Founder of Hotel Chain, Dies at 91
description: Conrad N. Hilton, one of the world's leading hotel men, died of pneumonia Wednesday night at St. John's Hospital in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 91 years old.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Blount Inc., Montgomery, Ala., an international company mainly involved in construction and agribusiness, has appointed Robert L. Blackmon to the newly created position of president and chief executive officer of all agricultural operations.

title: U.S. Sells Bond Issue At 9% Peak
description: The Treasury sold $1.5 billion of 15year bonds yesterday at an average rate of 9 percent  the highest in history for an issue of longterm Government securities.

title: Restaurants
description: IN the last six months or so, there have been close to a dozen new French bistros opening around the city, and several more are promised in the months ahead. Two of the most attractive of these newcomers are La Gauloise, on the Avenue of the Americas near 13th Street in Greenwich. Village, and La Gamelle, on Grand Street in SoHo.

title: C.A.B. Says Airlines Must Further Restrict Cigar and Pipe Users
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4  The Civil Aeronautics Board agreed today to order the airlines to provide wider separation between nonsmoking passengers and those who smoke pipes or cigars, and set in motion a proceeding that could lead to a ban on pipe and cigar smoking on Planes.

title: Madden, Citing Health, Resigns as Coach of Raiders
description: OAKLAND, Caiif., Jan. 4  John Madden's 10year career as head coach of the Oakland Raiders ended today at the same OaklandEdgewater Hotel site where it began.

title: Reader's Digest Plans To Condense the Bible
description: Reader's Digest, which for years has been condensing bestsellers and binding them with three or four companions, has set its sights on the Bible  the best seller of them all.

title: Gilbert, Felix Merging Into DancerFitzgerald
description: The Nikon camera people, who have not been in TV advertising for a long, long time, have decided to get back into it. The problem was that their agency of over 25 years, Gilbert, Felix & Sharf, though expert in communicating the technical aspects of the photographic equipment, wasn't highly skilled in the TV medium.

title: Oil Imports Up Before Price Rise
description: For the first time since the bitter winter of two years ago and for only the third time ever, American oil companies imported an average of more than 10 million barrels a day during a single week, the American Petroleum Institute said yesterday in reporting its figures for the week ended Dec. 29.

title: Japan Plans
description: TOKYO, Jan. 4  Japanese monetary authorities are preparing to allow foreign banks, along with their Japanesecounterparts, to issue yenbased negotiable certificates of deposit.

title: Man's Best Friend, Next to a Dog, Of Course
description: Goldilocks sat in the great big chair. It was too hard. She sat in the middlesized chair. It was too soft. She sat in the baby chair. It was just right  but it broke when she sat on it.

title: The New Agenda at Guadeloupe
description: The informal conference that starts today in the sun at Guadeloupe was planned as the first politicalmilitary summit of the United States and its three chief NATO allies, West Germany, France and Britain. But in just a few weeks, the emphasis has shifted to more urgent economic and monetary problems.

title: Art: A LatterDay PreRaphaelite Out West
description: IN common with other critics of his era, the late Harold Rosenberg had little time for regional painting. He defined it as the product of artists convincing themselves that art could, too, be made outside of New York City. Despite the swaggering tone, the point is well taken (in an essay entitled Place Patriotism and the New York Mainstream), though not necessarily for the reason he gave. Rosenberg felt that New York was action central because of the way that the question asked in the boondocks, Is art possible here? became in the city the more metaphysical Is art possible?

title: Canadian Banks Lift Prime
description: Several Canadian banks increased their prime interest rates yesterday to a record 12 percent from 11 percent. Those announcing the increase were the Royal Bank of Canada, TorontoDominion Bank, Bank of Montreal and Bank of Nova Scotia. The move followed the action taken on Wednesday by the Bank of Canada, the central bank, which raised its bank rate to a record 11 percent from 10 percent.

title: Seton Hall Defeats St. John's, 7670
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Jan. 4 Seton Hall's young basketball wizards put on a twoact magic show that first amused but then dazzled St. John's tonight at Walsh auditorium.

title: Back From Obscurity
description: Since their army days in Shensi Province in the 1940's, Hu Yaopang has never strayed far from the side of Teng Hsiaoping. But as a soldier, a youth organizer and a party administrator, Mr. Hu has always worked somewhat in the shadow of Mr. Teng, his mentor and China's senior Deputy Prime Minister.

title: Assemblyman Walsh, an Upstater, Is Named Majority Leader by Fink
description: ALBANY, Jan. 9  Assemblyman Daniel B. Walsh of Franklinville was appointed majority leader of the New York State Assembly today in a move that legislators saw as an effort to broaden the appeal of the Democratic Party upstate.

title: Suit Charges That Lance Falsified S.E.C. Filings
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4  The principals of a bankholding company here have charged in a civil court suit that Bert Lance and a group of Middle East investors have falsified filings before the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Economic Scene
description: WHY have the United States and West Germany, with roughly comparable rates of monetary growth in recent years, differed so greatly in their rates of inflation? One of the oldest pieces of apparatus in the economist's tool kit  the socalled equation of exchange  implies that, if greater monetary growth in the United states was not the cause of the higher inflation here, then blame must attach either to a relative speedup in the velocity of circulation (the turnover of money) or a slowdown in the rate of productivity growth or both. In fact, both factors appear to be involved.

title: Grace, in Surprise Bid, Seeks Daylin Takeover
description: Daylin Inc., which made unsuccessful attempts in the last six months to take over, first, Dymo Industries, the embossing machine maker, and, second, Uarco Inc., the business forms company, found yesterday that it had become a takeover target itself.

title: After a Death, Help for Those Left Behind
description: When a husband or wife dies, the sense of loss can be so deep that even family and friends can't be much help to the surviving spouse.

title: Parkway Modernization Is Urged
description: WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 4  William C. Hennessy, the State Transportation Commissioner, said today that $320 million in improvements were needed on parkways and highways in Westchester County and nearby areas, but he put off until March a decision on how to finance them.

title: Focusing on the Toughest TeenAgers
description: In its zeal to encourage the release of petty delinquents, has the Federal Office of Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention neglected the possibility of helping serious offenders? Are they being held in state correctional facilities with too little thought about alternatives providing greater individual attention to their prospects after release?

title: Auctions
description: THE New Year starts on a high note at New York's top two auction galleries. The first sales of 1979 are of old masters, which are commanding far more serious attention by collectors, dealers and museums these days than at any other time since the 1930's. One reason for the interest is that many of the paintings coming up for sale have been hidden away for decades in collectors' homes or museum storage rooms.

title: For Shah's Son, Quiet Texas Life
description: LUBBOCK, Tex., Dec. 31  The two policemen in plain clothes walked down the curved driveway, past the guardhouse and up to an iron gate barring the way to the $250,000 home where the Crown Prince of Iran has been living on week. ends since he came here in the summer to train as a jet pilot under United States Air Force instructors.

title: Cigarette Price Increase
description: The R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, the nation's largest cigarette producer, yesterday announced a price increase of 55 cents a thousand for all of its domestic cigarette brands and Winchester Little Cigars, effective Jan. 15. The move follows price increases by other cigarette producers recently. The company is a subsidiary of R. J. Reynolds Industries.

title: Deaths
description: DORFMANFlora (nee Yudkin) Beloved and devoted mother of Lawrence, Jerome and Zelna Cohen. Dear sister of Ben, Joseph and Charles Rubin and Ruth Mitnick. Loving grandmother and greatgrandmother. Service today 10:30 AM Parkside Chapels, Queens Boulevard and 66th Ave,Forest Hills.

title: Oil Rationing For Emirates?
description: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates, Jan. 4 (AP)  This oilrich Arab federation may be compelled to ration refined fuel supplies for its citizens if the current turmoil in Iran continues much longer.

title: Church on Coast Is Placed in Receivership
description: PASADENA, Calif., Jan 4  The Worldwide Church of God, the prosperous organization founded by Herbert W. Armstrong, an advertising man turned radio evangelist, was placed in temporary receivership yesterday after state officials accused church officers of pilfering its assets.

title: Shanker Insisti He Won't Renegotiate the Terms, be He Will See Koch
description: Mayor Koch yesterday rejected the contract worked out between the city's Board of Education and the teachers' union, saying it exceeded the economic gains won by other municipal unions last year.

title: Marine Midland Branch Robbed
description: SLOATSBURG, N.Y., Jan. 4 (AP) The Marine Midland Bank branch on Route 17 here was robbed this morning, and the police took into custody a New Jersey man about 20 minutes later in Haverstraw. The town police in Haverstraw said they had arrested David Ruff, 46 years old, of Allendale, N.J. They said nearly $5,700 taken in the holdup was recovered.

title: Schrader to Use Trigere Designs
description: The Abe Schrader Corporation and Pauline Trigere, one of the country's bestknown designers of highpriced fashion apparel, announced that Miss Trigere would design a collection of mediumpriced coats for the Schrader concern.

title: Austin Advances In Tennis
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) Tracy Austin defeated Diane Desfor, 62, 62, tonight to set up a quarterfinal duel with the other teenage star of women's tennis, Pam Shriver, in the $125,000 Washington tournament, the first of 11 on the winter indoor tour.

title: Vietnam's Push in Cambodia Has Neighbors Worried
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 4  The Vietnamese onslaught against Cambodia, after months of warfare limited to the border region, has greatly intensified apprehension in Southeast Asia over Vietnam's ultimate aims.

title: Forest Service Seeking 36 Million More Acres For Timber and Mines
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4  The Forest Service today signaled the beginning of another conservation battle by recommending that 36 million additional acres of roadless land within the National Forests be opened for timber cutting, mining and motorized recreation and by calling for the creation of 15 million acres of new wilderness areas.

title: Weaver Named Yank Farm Aide
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 4 (UPI)  J. Edward Weaver, former athletic director at Ohio State University, has been named a vice president of the New York Yankees, the team's owner, George Steinbrenner. said today.

title: Liberal Group Criticizes President and Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP)  The liberal Americans for Democratic Action gave failing grades today to President Carter and Congress for one of the worst session: of Congress in recent history.

title: Columbia Is Given 16Carat Diamond
description: It was right out of the olden days of Persia and its Peacock Throne, when a shah once plucked a diamond ring from his finger and bestowed it upon a departing scholar to take back to the visitor's wife.

title: Cavaliers Rout Knicks, 117103, Sparked by Russell's 26 Points
description: RICHFIELD, Ohio, Jan. 4  Bill Fitch, the Cleveland Cavaliers coach, has a favor to ask of his fellow coaches. He needs their vote to put Campy Russell on the Eastern Conference team in the National Basketball Association AllStar game.

title: Secrecy On Oil Data Requested
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4  Executives of the Exxon Corporation and the Standard Oil Company of California made a private appeal today before a Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee to safeguard the confidentiality of company documents subpoenaed by the subcommittee.

title: Hans Gerth, Scholar; Translated Max Weber
description: Hans Gerth, a scholar and translator of major works into English by the German economist Max Weber, died last Friday at the age of 70 in Frankfort, West Germany.

title: Starrett Risks Big Loss in Iran
description: The Starrett Housing Corporation, which built the Citicorp Center, Roosevelt Island, the Empire State Building and Starrett City in Brooklyn, has invested its hopes and perhaps half its funds in a country that offered a buffer against the hazards of operating in New York.

title: Donation Allows Extended Hours At Public Library's Main Branch
description: Thanks to two private gifts, the New York Public Library's Central Building at 42d Street and Fifth Avenue will extend its hours for the first time in three years, staying open until 9 P.M. three days a week.

title: Citibank Unit to Aid Foreign Companies
description: Citibank said it had established a new banking department to serve the rapidly growing number of foreign companies making or considering direct investments in the United States.

title: U.S. Fights Data Release On Bahamas Payments
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4  The State Department, citing possible departmental effects on United States relations with the Bahamas, is resisting disclosure of information that it possesses about possible illegal payments by United States companies in the Bahamas.

title: Turning a Career Into a Revue
description: Arthur Schwartz has laurels enough to rest on if he were of a mind to, but resting is apparently not something that interests him very much. Composer of some of, the most enduring popular songs of the last 50 years You and the Night and the Music,

title: The Pop Life
description: IN the course of 1978, Elvis Costello established himself as about the most important figure in British newwave rock  so important, in fact, that he pretty much obliterated the very notions of punk or new wave, at least as they apply to him. He was too oddly bookishlooking to be punk; the image, instead, was of computer salesman crossed with Buddy Holly. And he was too fervently traditional in his adherence to rock basics to be an artsy new waver. What he was was an original, like all great rockers.

title: Chinese Leader Hints Peking Will Not Back Cambodians by Force
description: PEKING, Friday, Jan. 5  Deputy Prime Minister Teng HsiaoPing indicated today that China would probably not intervene in Cambodia to stop Vietnam's invasion, but he said Peking would support Cambodia's call for a meeting of the United Nations Security Council on the incursion.

title: Deaths
description: LIPPMANN  Herbert. Passed away Jan 3, 1979. Beloved husband of the late Elise Jerard, Loving uncle of Robert L. & John F. Arrangements private. For information the Riverside.

title: Federal Agencies, for Budget Efficiency, Were Required to Rank Programs Against Other Departments
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4  The Federal agencies, already hard pressed by President Carter's demand for austerity in planning their programs for the fiscal year 1980, have also been subjected to new, exquisitely refined instrument of torment called interagency zerobased budgeting.

title: Art People
description: THE quiet, clean old town of Essex, Conn. (population, 5,100), has a cause clbre  a messy artist in its midst. And it has served notice on him that he must cease and desist from cluttering up his property with the raw material from which he makes his art.

title: Music: Strauss Suite
description: THERE was Molire's famous comedy, Le Bourgeois gentilhomme. To it Richard Strauss composed incidental music for a Max Reinhardt production in 1912. In German, it was called Der Brger als Edelmann. Later this work developed into the StraussHugo von Hofmannsthal opera, Ariadne auf Naxos. It is a complicated history, much more so than the bare facts related here. In 1919 the composer arranged a suite from the Reinhardt production, and this Burger als Edelmann (Op. 60) is the one commonly heard in concert halls.

title: Finn Leads Austrian Jump
description: INNSBRUCK, Austria, Jan 4 (AP) Pentti Kokkonen of Finland won the third of four stages of the annual fourski jump tournament today and increased his overall lead going into Saturday's final stage at Bischofshofen, Austria.

title: Western Summit With a Difference
description: ST.FRANOIS, Guadeloupe, Jan. 4 The fourpower Western summit meeting starting here tonight reflects an evolution in America's relations with Europe, as well as something of a shift in the policy

title: Letter: On the City as Landlord
description: To the Editor:

title: President Sets Procedure For Contacts in Taiwan
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4  The. United States will maintain contacts with Taiwan after March 1 through an unofficial intrumentality in corporate form, according to a memorandum from President Carter to all Government departments and agencies.

title: Melodrama, and Method, Over the Budget
description: It added a bit of drama to a dreary fall to read of President Carter's decision to squeeze the Federal budget deficit below $30 billion in fiscal 1980, even at the price of cutting the social programs that are usually sacred to Democratic Presidents. It was good sport, too, to watch the lobbyists and journalists scramble and scrap over whose oxen should be gored. It was a great relief to learn later, two days before Christmas, that Mr. Carter was not Scrooge after all and that he will somehow scrape together another $2 billion for social programs. And now it is calming to learn that some of the deep cuts anticipated in Federal health programs have also been restored.

title: Lorillard Introducing Kent III
description: Lorillard, the nongiant tobacco company that has a big name in lowtar cigarettes, is coming out with still another extension of its successful Kent brand, first introduced in 1952. This time it's Kent III, with three milligrams of tar, which follows by three years Kent Golden Lights.

title: Administration Declines to Change Wage Laws as AntiInflation Move
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4  The Carter Administration, which had been seriously considering bolstering its antiinflation program by asking for changes in the minimum wage law and in another law that sets wages on Federal construction projects, has decided against such changes, Administration officials reported today.

title: TALKS DUE ON PACT WITH OIL REFINERIES
description: DENVER, Jan. 4  When unions such as the United Automobile Workers or the United Steelworkers of America bargain on a national contract, they and their industry counterparts meet around a big table to work out their differences.

title: Chinatown Choosing Sides Over Recognition of Peking
description: Like a tiny Taiwan in the China Sea of Chatham Square, the old Braveman Building, a lofty stack of garment factories at 2 East Broadway, stands with its back against the pagoda roof of the Manhattan Savings Bank on the traffic island they share.

title: Cypress Gardens to Expand
description: CYPRESS GARDENS, Fla., Jan. 4 (UPI)  Cypress Gardens, the amusement and botanical park here, will undergo a major expansion, its chairman, Dick Pope Sr., said today. Fourteen acres of new attractions will be added to the 228acre park at a cost of $5.5 million.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Gold prices pushed ahead yesterday, impelled by a firmer price for the precious metal in the London market.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: Off Off Broadway: Fish Story
description: BOB CARROLL's Salmon Show and Others (on weekends in the Envelope at the Performing Garage) is an outlandish fish story. This is nothing less than the life cycle of the salmon  as told from the point of view of the salmon  combined with a cosmic dissertation on the Industrial and other Revolutions. The evening is ecological, ebullient, and as purifying as a mountain stream.

title: Dance: The Insouciant Bertram Ross
description: ON Wednesday evening the Bertram Ross Dance Company opened the 1979 Riverside Dance Festival at the Theater of the Riverside Church. Because Mr. Ross is a wellknown dancer and choreographer, seasoned dancegoers present must have thought that, oh yes, they knew just what sort of program to expect.

title: Cambodia Vows to Fight to End
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Friday, Jan. 5 (AP)  Prime Minister Pol Pot of Cambodia said in a speech today that Vietnam with Soviet support was making an allout effort to conquer Cambodia, but we pledge to fight them to the end to keep our national prestige.

title: Giants Look for D.O.
description: The search for the next head coach of the Giants has been discontinued until the search for the next director of operations is completed, Timothy J. Mara, the National Football League club's vice president, said yesterday.

title: King's 29 Lift Nets Past Jazz, 125112
description: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 4  The New Jersey Nets ended a losing streak at six games tonight by overwhelming the New Orleans Jazz, 125112. It was the Nets' first victory ever in the Superdome.

title: No Masters For Vilas
description: Guillermo Vilas, who won the Australian open singles title on Wednesday, has decided to bypass the Grand Prix Masters tennis tournament next week at Madison Square Garden. His spot in the eightplayer field will be filled by Arthur Ashe.

title: London Soccer Clubs Ask Fans to Help Clear Snow
description: LONDON, Jan. 4 (AP)  Two London soccer clubs appealed to supporters today to help clear snow from pitches to ensure that matches scheduled for Saturday can be played.

title: Deaths
description: WARD  Col Charles S. (US Army Ref.) of 200 Westhill Road, Stamford, Conn. On January 3, 1979. Husband of Mildred Portlock Ward. Recipient of The Legion of Merit and The Cross of Lorraine. Graveside Interment will be held Tuesday, January 9, 1979 at 1:30PM at The U.S. Military Academy, West Point, NY. Mrs. Ward will receive her friends at her home 200 Westhill Road, Stamford. In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts to the West Point Fund, Highland Falls, NY would be appreciated.

title: Nippon Univac Sale
description: The Sperry Rand Corporation said that the Taiyo Kobe Bank, one of Japan's largest banks, had ordered a largescale computer system, valued at about $10 million, from Sperry Rand's Japan joint computer marketing venture, Nippon Univac Kaisha Ltd.

title: Flutist and Friends With Casual Airs
description: In what seems to have settled in happily as an annual event, Paula Robison, the flute virtuoso, will open a series of three informal Saturday afternoon joint recitals tomorrow at 3 at Alice Tully Hall.

title: Another Vote for U.S.C.
description: ST. LOUIS, Jan. 4 (AP)  Southern California, conqueror of Michigan in the Rose Bowl, has been named the nation's top collegiate football power in final rankings by The Sporting News, a weekly publication.

title: Beyond the Oil Bonanza: II OPEC's Future
description: The prognosis for the world's oil supplyanddemand balance in the late 1980's is disturbing, and that disquiet is bound to intensify if we examine the prospects for development programs among members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

title: Bridge:
description: CHERRY HILL, .N.J., Jan. 4  A group of Texans jumped into the lead at the start of the international teams trials here this afternoon, hoping to become the North American representatives in the world championship in Brazil next September.

title: WEEKEND MOVIE CLOCK
description: ART (GR 37014) Fri. Sat. Bread & Chocolate 1, 3, 5, 7, 9, 11. Sun. 1:50, 4, 6, 8, 10.

title: Grow Chemical To Buy Trewax
description: The Grow Chemical Corporation said it had signed an agreement to purchase for an undisclosed amount all of the outstanding stock of the Trewax Company of Los Angeles, a manufacturer of chemicals and machines for the cleaning and maintenance of carpets, floors, furniture and automobiles.

title: EARNINGS
description: The KimberlyClark Corporation yesterday reported record sales and earnings in the quarter and year that ended Dec. 31.

title: Long Lines Authorized For I.T.T.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4  The Federal Communications Commission today authorized the International Telephone and Telegraph Company to provide a domestic longdistance telephone service, largely for business customers, in competition with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: Javits Vows to Run All the Way'
description: Senator Jacob K. Javits said yesterday that if he sought reelection next year he would run all the way even if he lost the New York State's Republican primary.

title: Tubbs Outpoints Turner
description: Tony Tubbs, a muscular 20yearold college student who hopes to win the heavyweight gold medal in the 1980 Olympic Games, scored an emphatic decision over Ron Turner last night in the final of the A.A.U. intercity boxing championships at the Felt Forum.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: The SCM Corporation, a diversified company with products in the chemical, food, paper and business equipment fields, announced yesterday that it planned to offer for sale its 30 retail copier branches.

title: Pentagon Seeking Shift in Nuclear Deterrent Policy
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4  The Defense Department has drafted a change in strategic policy designed to deter or counter a Soviet nuclear strike, Government sources said today.

title: McGuire Selects S.I. Commander To Be Police Chief of Operations
description: Bypassing is In?? ?? Police Commissioner Robert J. McGuire has selected Patrick J. Murphy, a 45yearold deputy chief, for the post of chief of operations; the department's highest uniformed position.

title: Chrysler Scraps Plans for Plant
description: DETROIT, Jan. 4 (UPI)  The Chrysler Corporation has scrapped plans to build a $160 million plant at Richmond, Ind., and instead will expand its facilities at Kokomo, 80 miles away, the auto manufacturer announced today. The change in plans was the result of continuing cost studies we have carried out, a comnanv sookesman said.

title: Books of The Times
description: ALICE LET'S EAT: Further Adventures of a Happy Eater. By Calvin Trillin. 182 pages. Random House. $7.95.

title: Curb Urged On Pipeline Ownership
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4  Senator Edward M. Kennedy asked the Federal Trade Commission today to prohibit oil companies from owning pipelines and to order oil companies to divest themselves of pipelines they own now.

title: At the Movies
description: ALTHOUGH California Suite marked Walter Matthau's fourth performance in a Neil Simon film and his fourth under the direction of Herbert Ross, it wasn't any bed of roses, Mr. Matthau said, sighing with remembered pain. During rehearsals Herbie Pet buried me with criticisms, he recalled. He tore me apart. He said: You're not trying.... You're giving an exhibition your former skills.... You've turned into just another Hollywood hack.... He didn't let me get one sentence out. Finally, I just said: Leave me alone or get someone else to do the role.

title: Pennsylvania Shipyard Struck
description: CHESTER, Pa., Jan. 4 (UPI)  Some 2,500 workers at the Sun Shipbuilding and Drydock Company went on strike today as their contract expired without agreement. Three unions that are involved include Locals 802, 804 and 806 of the International Brotherhood of Boilermakers, iron Ship Builders, Blacksmiths, Forgers Helpers.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: The nation's money supply declined late in December, but bank reserves jumped sharply and borrowing from the Federal Reserve remained unusually high for a yearend week, the central bank's weekly figures showed yesterday. The data indicated that a rise in the discount rate was possible soon.

title: Many Skiing Areas Are Low on Snow
description: MANCHESTER, Vt., Jan. 4  The temperature on top of Bromley Mountain this afternoon was zero, and light snow was falling. Thus skiers were spending as much time in the base lodge as they were outdoors. The skiing on half the trails was good, but the numbing weather tended to be discouraging.

title: Molire Adapted Comes to 42d Street
description: A oneact adaptation from Moliere called The Flying Doctor will be performed in the 17thcentury Commedia dell'Arte style by the Sidewalks of New York Theater Company through next weekend at the Sidewalks Theater on the 12th floor at 152 West 42d Street

title: World News Briefs
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 4  Israeli militants, protesting the Government's obstruction of attempts to build new settlements in occupied Arab territory, blocked the TulkaremNablus road today and scuffled with angry Arabs.

title: Dividends
description: THURSDAY, JAN. 4, 1979

title: Efforts to Stop Fight Continue
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson and three other leaders of the planned protest against the Kaltie Knoetze bout in Miami Jan. 13 met yesterday with David A. (Sonny) Werblin, the president of Madison Square Garden, and with Frank Smith, the president of CBS Sports, in efforts to get both parties to forsake their roles in the bout. The Garden is copromoting the fight, and CBS will televise it.

title: Tampering With Nuclear Fuel Shipment Reported
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4  United States Government officials said today that a consignment of nuclear fuel was shipped to Rumania last month despite evidence that the containers used to carry the material were tampered with before the shipment left the United States.

title: The City
description: New York State began a new lottery yesterday so that New Yorkers will no longer have to go to Atlantic City to play the slot machines, the director of the State Lottery Division said yesterday.

title: In the Land of Freeways, Carless and Carefree
description: In Los Angeles, you need a car to get to your garage.

title: Deaths
description: SULGER  John J. The Fordham Rowing Association, with the Fordham Univerisity Crew & alumni, mourn the passing of its esteemed & devoted founding father & coach. We express deepest sympathy to his family.

title: McEnroeFleming Duo Gains
description: LONDON, Jan. 4 (UPI)  John McEnroe and Peter Fleming of the United States scored a 76, 46, 63 victory over lie Nastase of Rumania and Sherwood Stewart of the United States today and gained the first semifinal berth in the $200,000 World Championship Tennis doubles tournament at the Olympia.

title: The Region
description: The Long Island Rail Road disclosed yesterday that it had suspended for 90 days without pay one of the two female engineers that it employs after she had run a stop signal waved by a flagman near Shea Stadium in Queens.

title: A Porsular Catholic Weekly in Poland Mirrors ChurchState Conflict
description: CRACOW, Poland, Dec. 30  Copies of (he weekly newspaper Tygodnik Powszechny are being. bootlegged in Warsaw kiosks for the equivalent of $25  more than its editor in chief earns for a day's work.

title: Phil Bieber and His Hurricane
description: Phil Bieber is in his winter home in Florida, thinking beautiful thoughts and writing letters to keep warm. Until this week's freeze, there had been no hint of winter down there, but a few days after Christmas Miami was hit by an electrical storm so violent that it took Phil back to 1938 at Rockingham Park. As he tells it:

title: Sports News Briefs
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Jan. 4 (UPI)  Calvin Griffith, president of the Minnesota Twins, said today that he had withdrawn contract offers to Rod Carew because there seemed to be no hope of meeting his demands. Griffith said he was trying to trade the first baseman, who was the American League's most valuable player in 1977.

title: People
description: Sidney M. Smith has been appointed to the new position of senior vice president for marketing at the American Enka Company.

title: Appointments Clash Spreads As 2 Claim Battery City Post
description: ?? ?? ?? ?? ?? ?? and the State Senate's Republican majority over the Governor's recess appointments sparked a, Clash yesterday over who now heads a major development agency. And it brought a warning that there would be grave consequences in general for New York City and the state.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Sandra S. Jaffee has become the first woman to be named a senior vice president at Citibank, joining 53 men who hold that title.

title: Events and Openings

title: Advertising
description: YOU know what you think about certain advertising, but how do the real pros feel?

title: Television
description: TOP WEEKEND FILMS

title: Major Issue at Guadeloupe: U.S. Stand on NATO Defense
description: The future of the American military investment in Europe is expected to be the principal security issue discussed at the Western summit meeting at Guadeloupe.

title: WHEEE!
description: Youngsters all over the world love climbing and sliding. The higher, the better, and the speedier the descent, the louder become the squeals. This spiral slide under the IND tracks near the Gowanus Canal in South Brooklyn is in a vestpocket park and has this giant slide, a child's whizzing delight. And it doesn't cost a penny.

title: Publishing: Going After the Customers
description: EVERYBODY beefs: People don't buy books; this isn't literary society; in comparison to records, books hardly sell at all. But nobody does anything about it. We're doing something.

title: 3 ExAides at G.S.A. Plead Guilty To Kickbacks From Contractors
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP)  Three former employees of the General Services Administration have admitted taking kickbacks from private contractors, raising to 26 the number of guilty pleas entered in current investigations of corruption in the agency.

title: U.S. Is Not Committed On the Cambodia Issue
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4  Although the United States suPports Cambodia's request for an urgent meeting of the United Nations Security Council to discuss Vietnam's invasion of Cambodia, it is not committed to a particular position in that debate, the State Department said today.

title: Carter Notifies Congress of Plan To Sign International Trade Pact
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4  President Carter officially notified Congress today that the United States would shortly sign a new international trade agreement that constitutes the first major effort of industrial nations to regulate use of nontariff barriers, the basic impediment to freer trade.

title: Bradshaw Is a Joker, But Not on the Field
description: Terry Bradshaw was the most prolific touchdown passer in the National Football League this season, and that's the quarterback the Houston Oilers will confront Sunday in the American Conference championship game in Pittsburgh. Bradshaw, however, also is the most prolific prankster in the Pittsburgh locker room, and that's the quarterback the Steelers must contend with every day.

title: Notes on People
description: Phase 1  to use a phrase suggested by the city's Cultural Affairs Commissioner, Henry Geldzahler  didn't work out terribly well, and so he explained, we're now going into Phase 2. Translation for the mystified: Ed- ward Villella, Phase 1, discovered too many frustrations in serving as chairman of the advisory Commission for Cultural Affairs while keeping up his dance schedule. Phase 2 involves the appointment of the sort of person more traditionally assigned such a job  not a performer, but a lawyer with a staff of his own and solid connections to. foundations.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Thursday, Jan. 4, 1979

title: Defense Summing Up at Theater Trial
description: Defense lawyers began summations yesterday to counter the prosecution's charges that the defendants in the Westchester Premier Theater trial had stolen hundreds of thousands of dollars.

title: Charles B. Eddy Jr., an Executive With the Chemical Bank, Was 70
description: Charles B. Eddy Jr., retired executive vice president of Chemical Bank, died yesterday at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J., after a long illness. He was 70 years old and lived at 238 Old Short Hills Road, Short Hills, N.J.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Deaths
description: APELLRose (Nee Weiss). Beloved wife of the late Harold J. Devoted mother of Helaine A. Honig, Loving grandmother of Norma Honig & Sara Terhune, Greatgrandmother of Michael Terhune.Servlce Friday 1PM at The Westchester Riverside, 21 W Broad St, Mt Vernon NY.

title: Carter and European Leaders Arrive in Guadeloupe
description: ST.FRANOIS, Guadeloupe, Jan. 4 President Carter and the leaders of West Germany, France and Britain descended in quick succession on this sundrenched Caribbean island this afternoon to begin two days of discussions of common problems.

title: New Governor Takes Over Divided Massachusetts
description: BOSTON, Jan. 4  The Massachusetts political landscape changed abruptly here this afternoon with the inauguration of Edward J. King, a conservative Democrat, as Governor of one of the nation's most liberal states.

title: Adolfo's Spring Comes in Zinging With Color
description: It's more than a fashion show  it's social event.

title: A Vietnamese at U.N. Opposes Cambodia Bid
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Jan. 4 (Reuters)  Vietnam said today that charges of aggression made against it by Cambodia in a request for a Security Council meeting were flagrant calumnies.

title: 9 New York Food Places Are Cited for Violations
description: The New York City Health Department yesterday released the names of nine food establishments it said had violated the health code.

title: California Aides Veto Federal Plan for Dam, Citing Quake Dangers
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 4  After years of controversy, California today effectively vetoed a Federal design for a billiondollar dam on the American River near Sacramento, citing earthquake dangers.

title: For Children
description: SNOW WHITE AND ROSE RED, a play by Jane Stanton and Thomas Dougherty, with music by Andrea StrykerRodde, presented by the Penny Bridge Players on Friday at 7 P.M. and Saturday at 2 P.M. in the Assumption Church, Cranberry Street (between Henry and Hicks Street), Brooklyn Heights. Admission, $1.75; group rates available. Call 8556346.

title: WASHINGTON Carter's Moves In Iran
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4  The Carter Administration is now concentrating its efforts on maintaining the unity of the Iranian armed forces behind the new civilian Government headed by Shahpur Bakhtiar.

title: Books: Casino and Statehouse, Uneasy Partners
description: HOUSE OF CARDS. By Jerome H. Skolnick. 328 pp. Little Brown. $13.95.

title: Art: Exponent of HardEdge Abstraction
description: THE career of the American painter Lorser Feitelson (18981978) reads, in some respects, like a seismographic report in which the successive tremors of art history in this century are vividly registered and duly responded to. By turns a Cubist, a Futurist, a Surrealist, a postSurrealist, a Federal Art Project muralist, and a NeoRomantic figurative painter, he turned, in the 1940's, to a form of illusionist abstraction, and by the early 50's he found at last a permanent home for his restless sensibility within the rigorous confines of hardedge abstraction.

title: 1978 Car Sales Up; Late December Off
description: DETROIT, Jan. 4  Sales of new Americanmade cars fell 6.8 percent in the final 10day selling period of December, the four major American car makers reported here today. But for the year, the industry reported gain of 2.3 percent over 1977 and set the thirdbest selling record in industry history.

title: Fezler Leads Golf Match; Wynn One Stroke Behind
description: MONTEREY, Calif., Jan 4 (AP) Forrest Fezler opened with three birdies en route to a 65 today and held a onestroke lead at the halfway point of Monterey's $100,000 golf tournament.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: It is 18 years now since the joyous tunes of The Music Man first captivated Broadway. But 76 Trombones still blares out loud and clear across the country, most lately at An Evening Dinner Theater, which is in Elmsford, N.Y., two miles north of Exit 2 at the western end of the CrossWestchester Expressway. The musical, starring Willard Waterman, is playing with a full cast on the thrust stage of the amphitheater at 11 Clearbrook Road in the CrossWestchester Executive Park, just off Route 9A. The price of admission includes a reserved table, a buffet dinner, the show and the tax. It's $19.64 tonight and $21.37 tomorrow, with doors opening at 6:15 P.M., buffet at 7 and show at 8:20; on Sunday, everything happens an hour earlier, and tickets are $19.06 each. Information: (914) 5922222.

title: U.S. WILL COOPERATE WITH A NEW REGIME IF SHAH STAYS OR NOT
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4  The United States said today that it was prepared to cooperate fully with the government of Prime Ministerdesignate Shahpur Bakhtiar whether or not Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi remained in Iran.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M. WNCN. Wedding March from A Midsummer Night's Dream, Mendelssohn; Overture to Coal fan tutte, Mozart; Valsette, Kodaly; Trumpet Concerto, Torelli; Clair de Lune, Debussy.

title: Canadians Worried On China
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 4  A strong effort to increase and diversify Canadian exports to China will be made next week amid some disquiet about stronger competition from the United States for Chinese markets.

title: December Retail Sales Surged
description: The nation's largest retail chains, in a confirmation of the strong individual reports on sales during the Christmas shopping season, yesterday said that December sales gains in most cases ran to doubledigit levels, comfortably exceeding the inflation rate.

title: Deaths
description: FOGLIOPhilip P. On January 3, 1979. Beloved husband of Ottille. Devoted father of Philip, Carol and Laura. Dear son of Philip and the late Ebba. Loving brother of Marie Rizzo and Vera Hellmer. Reposing at the David J. Hodder and Son. Inc Funeral Home, 899 McLean Avenue (near Kimball Avenue), Yonkers. Mass Friday, 11AM at Our Lady of Perpetual Help Church, Ardsley. Inferment Fernciltf Cemetery. Visiting hours 24 and 710PM. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Heart Fund or charity of your choice.

title: Market Place
description: IF investors by the thousand give institutions millions of dollars to invest, the managers of those institutions must be smart, right? Ralph Coleman Jr. doesn't think so and he lays it on the line in the latest issue of his magazine, The OTC Review.

title: Art: A Beauty That Refuses to Flinch
description: IT is not every New Year in the galleries that begins as well as this one. The collages of Varujan Boghosian at Cordier & Ekstrom, 990 Madison Avenue, at 77th Street, are models of delicacy and precision; like everything that Mr. Boghosian does, they speak for a turn of mind in which learning and independent speculation are nicely allied.

title: Truck Crash Starts Fatal Fire
description: DINGMAN'S FERRY, Pa., Jan. 4 (AP)  One person was killed and a truck driver was critically injured last night when a tanker truck crashed into an antique store, exploding into a ball of flame, the state police said.

title: Around the Nation
description: CLEVELAND, Jan: 4 (UPI)  The layoff of 400 city workers ordered for tomorrow by Mayor Dennis J. Kucinich was put off for five days today by a judge Who agreed that the Mayor should first lay off workers without Civil Service protection.

title: CARTER AIDE FINDS LIMIT TO PARTY AIMS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4  President Carter's chief adviser on domestic policy told an audience of Democrats today that new realities require both the President and his party to reshape the Democrats historic mission of helping the poor, the unemployed, minority groups and the disinherited.

title: Editorial in Post Termed Slander to Puerto Ricans
description: Statements by the New York City and State Commissioners of Human Rights accusing The New York Post of slandering Puerto Ricans in an editorial on the city's hospital problems were made public yesterday by the National Puerto Rican Forum.

title: Stage: Polka Melodrama
description: BIG STOSH and the Stardust Boys are the best polka band in northeastern Ohio, and here they are in Stosh's basement, where they are about to hear of the new dreams of glory projected by their leader. What follows is a melodrama about broken dreams, about four men, toward the middle years, who are desperately unhappy and lonely. That is The Legendary Stardust Boys, a play, by D.B. Gilles that is running at the Wonderhorse Theater, 83 East Fourth Street.

title: Ohio Approves $675,000 to Settle Suits in 1970 Kent State Shootings
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 4  Ohio's State Controlling Board today approved an outofcourt settlement that would pay $675,000 to the victims and families of victims in the Kent State University shootings of May 4, 1970.

title: A 1700's Neil Simon Restaged on 13th St.
description: For most theatgoers today, the name John O'Keeffe is not a familiar one. But London audiences of the late 18th and early 19th centuries loved his light satirical romps.

title: Lucia Chase to Quit Ballet Theater Post
description: Lucia Chase, the founding patron of American Ballet Theater and its artistic director during the company's rise to international status as a major American performingarts group, will resign her position as director on Sept. 1, 1980.

title: Firedoor Bankruptcy Ends
description: The Firedoor Corporation of America announced yesterday that it had received a $900,000 loan from the United States Department of Commerce's Economic Development Administration that permitted it to obtain trade credit, hire more employees and get out of bankruptcy. The company had been operating under Chapter XI of the Bankruptcy Act since May 1977. It makes hollow metal doors and bucks for the construction industry.

title: Corporate Earnings Reported
description: For pperiods as shown. (N) indicafes stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange,(A) the American Stock Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Guy Richards, at 73, A Former City Editor Of JournalAmerican
description: Guy Richards, a former city editor of The New York JournalAmerican and a prizewinning reporter, died Wednesday at his home at 340 East 57th Street in Manhattan. He was 73 years old.

title: Army Hires Saban of Miami as 28th Football Coach
description: Facing the task of rebuilding its football team while the National Collegiate Athletic Association starts an investigation of its entire athletic program, the United States Military Academy hired yesterday Lou Saban, a muchtraveled college and professional coach, to be Army's 28th head football coach.

title: China Says U.S. Press Can Open Offices Soon
description: PEKING, Jan. 9  The 28 American journalists in China to report on the the normalization of United StatesChinese relations will have to leave Jan. 12, when their twoweek visas expire.

title: 4 Women Assert Jobs Were Linked to Sterilization
description: WILLOW ISLAND, W.Va., Jan. 4 (AP)  Four women say that they had themselves sterilized after an American Cyanamid official implied the surgery might help save their jobs at the chemical plant.

title: Mexican Mines Official Is Really a Conductor
description: You are the music director of the Academy of Music at the Palacio de Mineria in Mexico City. What is it, exactly? The question was put this week to Jorge Velazco, who will make his New York conducting debut tonight at the Brooklyn Academy of Music with members of the Brooklyn Philharmonia. It's a long story, he said, but I think an interesting one, and I will tell it to you if you have the patience.

title: Oil Workers on the Spot
description: Apart from requiring a new bureaucracy, the President's new antiinflation program has had almost no effect so far. Organized labor plans to ignore it. The business community generally, though it talks of compliance, has so far done little to demonstrate firm support. And inflation continues unabated.

description: A multitude of reasons sent soybean prices higher again on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday, where contracts added 3 cents to 5 cents bushel.

title: Hoechst Price Increase
description: Hoechst Fiber Industries, a division of the American Hoechst Company, yesterday became the third textile fiber producer to announce price increases on staple polyester yarn. Hoechst raised prices on its Trevira brand 5 cents a pound effective March 5. Others that had taken the step earlier were the Celanese Corporation and the Monsanto Company.

description: The New York Rangers beat the Vancouver Canucks last night, 69, at Madison Square Garden in a National Hockey League game that was part hockey and Dart brawl.

title: Foreign Car Sales in U.S. Declined by 3.3% in 1978
description: DETROIT, Jan. 5 (AP)  Foreign car sales declined about 3.3 percent in 1978, but imports still enjoyed their second best year in this country, according to final figures reported by importers today.

title: City Considering Giving Hospital to Archdiocese
description: Officials at City Hall are exploring the possibility of giving the Metropolitan Hospital Center, at First Avenue and 97th Street, to the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, which would operate it as a church-sponsored medical center.

title: Russian Flu Cases Are Reported In 15 States and in Puerto Rico
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 5 (AP)  Outbreaks of Russian flu have been confirmed in 10 states, with cases reported in five other states and in Puerto Rico, the National Center for Disease Control reported today.

title: Members of U.N. Council Confer On Cambodia's Call for Meeting
description: UNITED NATIONS, Jan. 5 (Reuters)  Security Council members conferred privately today on Cambodia's request for a meeting of the Council to condemn Vietnam's aggression against Cambodia and to call for a ceasefire.

title: Guard Held in $1.5 Million Theft Of Bank Funds in Armored Car
description: DETROIT, Jan: 5 (AP)  A 28-year-old guard who left a note saying give me time to get away was arrested today for allegedly stealing three bags of money totaling $1.5 million from an armored car he was supposed to protect, the police said_

title: Civil Guard Shot in. Basque Area
description: LLODIO, Spain, Jan. 5 (Reuters) Gunmen believed to be Basque guerrillas shot and seriously wounded a paramilitary Civil Guard in this northern Basque village today, police sources said. Members of the Basque nationalist group E.T.A. have killed three people this week.

title: The Region
description: TRENTON  Guards at eight New Jersey prisons were ordered yesterday to remove American flag patches some of them have worn on their uniforms for 25 years.

title: Southern Japan Volcano Erupts
description: TOKYO, Jan. 5 (UPI)  One of the three volcanoes on Sakurajima, a southern peninsula on Japan's southetnmost island of Kyushu, erupted twice today, sending smoke nearly two miles into the air, according to the Meteorological Agency. There were no reports of casual. ties.

Urstadt said tonight that he would relinquish his post as chairman of the Battery Park City Authority and turn it over to William D. Each evening, Laura Taylor takes her 7yearold son, Tony, a secondgrader at the Clinton School here, to the quiet of his bedroom and spends from 7 to 7:45 P.M. reviewing his homework, discussing his classroom assignments and helping him with his reading, which, Mrs. Taylor says, gives him some trouble.

title: Mexico Will Limit Oil Output
description: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 5  Just days after Mexico's official estimate of proved oil reserves was doubled to 40 billion barrels, President Jose Lopez Portillo has warned that oil production here will not be increased beyond the country's ability to digest the resulting income.

title: Rohatyn Urges More City Cuts Now to Avert Surgery
description: In a parting salvo as chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, Felix G. Rohatyn warned yesterday that Mayor Koch's announced plans for closing New York City's budget gap did not go far enough, and he urged more cuts now to avert what he called really terrifying surgery in 1981.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 - George Bush, former Director of Central Intelligence, filed with the Federal Election Commissiontoday as a candidate for the Presidency but told reporters the move was just short of a formal declaration that he was running for the nomination.

description: CLEVELAND, Jan. 5  Cleveland once again escaped layoffs of hundreds of police officers and other city employees today because pf its fiscal crisis, but the courtordered postponement may be only temporary and the delay may worsen the city's defaultridden financial structure.

The 10team league is now down to two teams.

title: Thailand Ends Ban on Meetings
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 5 (Reuters)  Thailand's National Assembly today revoked laws banning political gatherings in public places. The vote, which was unanimous, opens the way for campaigning for general elections scheduled in April. The laws had been in effect since a military coup in 1976.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP)  Consumers borrowed money at nearrecord levels in November as they used credit cards instead of cash for preChristmas purchases, the Federal Reserve said today.

description: PEKING, Jan. 5China has evidently decided there is little it can do to halt Vietman's invasion of Cambodia, although it will support a call by Cambodia for a meeting, of the United Nations Security Council, Deputy Prime Minister Teng Hsiaoping indicated today.

description: GREENVILLE, Miss., Jan. 5  A Federal district judge today refused motion to dismiss a suit that contends that the.Army Corps of Engineers is constructing the $2 billion TennesseeTombigbee Waterway without proper authorization.

description: A new computerized system to detect fraud in Medicaid payments in New York City has been so successful that the Federal Government hopes to use it nationally, Joseph A. Califano Jr., the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, said yesterday.

description: CAIRO, Jan. 6 - While the golden death mask of Tutankhamun and other precious objects from the tomb of the boy king draw millions of visitors to American museums, the bulk of the Tutankhamun collection reposes in cluttered hallways of the cavernous Egyptian Museum.

description: DENVER, Jan. 6  The oil workers and refiners continued today to seek some way to get around Federal wage guidelines in their new contract bargaining. Contracts covering 60,000 workers at 100 companies, including the major oil producers, will expire at 12:01 A.M. Monday.

description: Twenty years later, there are more than 100 distributors of children's films documentaries as well as features. Films are standard in most school curricula, although quantity has hardly made for quality.

The ceremony was performed in Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn.. by the Rev. Bradford Hastines.

title: Legislators in Illinois, Under Fire, Defer Part of $8,000 Pay Increases
description: SPRINGFIELD, III:, Jan. 6 - Illinois legislators, responding to expressions of outrage from state residents over $8,000 annual pay increases for state officials, voted today to defer $3,000 of the amount for one year.

title: The Price of Public Order
description: By Paul Boyer. 387 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $18.50.

title: HEAVYARMS SALES 5110IN SOVIET AHEAD
description: A study prepared by the Central Intelli- gence Agency says that in a threeyear period the Soviet Union sold and deliv- ered to the lessdeveloped countries more fighters and bombers, tanks, antiaircraft guns and artillery than did the United States. The Soviet Union also sold war- ships with greater total value than did the United States.

title: Temple's Late Goal Conquers St. John's
description: An undefeated flock of Temple Owls, who strangely have not been able to crack into the nation's top 20ranked college basketball teams, chalked up their 11th victory last night  a tingling 7473 decision over St. John's at Alumni Hall in Jamaica, Queens. With five seconds remaining, Keith Parham, a sophomore guard, scored the winnwiped out a 1point advantage for the Redmen.

title: Parents Get Some Tax Help
description: ALBANY FOR parents faced with the task of putting their children through college New York State is offering unprecedented new help in the form of tax deductions and tax shelters. While the Congress last year wrangled over various versions of bills to provide Federal tuition tax credits  a concept vehemently opposed by President Carter and eventually killed in a HouseSenate conference committee  the Legislature in Albany whisked its own version into law. For good measure it added a system of tax breaks to parents who plan ahead for financing their children's educations.

title: ABOUT CARS
description: STANLEY ZAREMSKI, a usedcar dealer in the suburbs for 18 years, has watched a lot of changes in the business. He feels that some of them are good for him and that some he can live with. And some are like the new Federal Trade Commission proposal that dealers label defects in their vehicles and be responsible for any undisclosed faults.

title: Studying in Real Laboratories
description: THE two girls were greeted by disheveled young chemist who, as he led them through a labyrinth of laboratories, talked excitedly about indicting mushrooms as carcinogens. The dark bags under Jell Tusk's eyes and matching blotches on his wrinkled lab coat impressed upon the youngsters the fact that he had been working since 6 o'clock that morning, and .was interrupting his work to give them a daylong introduction to the rigors of scientific research.

title: Japan Plays a China Card, Keeps Russia Up Its Sleeve
description: TOKYO  Individually, they are little moves but together they are signs of a trend. After a decade of negotiations, the Soviet Union finally agreed on Dec. 28 to let Japan build an embassy in Moscow on a new site three times as large as that accommodating the cramped and aging property used by. the Japanese since they established diploma t ic relations with the Soviet Union in 1956.

description: Continued

title: POINT OF VIEW; Is Treasury the Right Path to the Top?; Too Many Cooks; Allies Take UP Slack; Carter excepted, the major Western heads of state rose by way of financial posts.
description: The President of the United States is conferring in Guadeloupe this weekend with President Valery Giscard d' Estaing of France, Prime Minister James Callaghan of Britain and Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany. Aside from the fact of his residence on the other side of the Atlantic, Mr. Carter is odd man out on another level: He is the only one of the foursome who has not been his nation's chief financial officer.

description: YONKERS

title: Authors Queries
description: As a collaborative effort with the Musee Rodin ig Paris, we are seeking letters and documents in the collections of individuals and institutions to be published in a corpus of Rodin's writings. We would appreciate it if you would call our attention to the existence of such materials.

title: ANTIQUES
description: RITA REIF

title: Another Peek Through The Bamboo Curtain
description: My trip to China last fall was my seventh; my first was while covering the Ping Pong teams in 1971. This time I went as correspondent for an NBC News special focusing on the educa- tional system and efforts at modernization in China. We were lucky both in the subject and the timing. The results of that trip  China: A Class by Itself  will be telecast Thursday evening from 10 to 11. The trip also afforded an insight into the changing state of television in China.

title: The 9,500 Buildings Seized for Taxes Are Not Getting Any Better
description: When New York City decided in 1976 to foreclose on real estate that was delinquent in taxes by one year, instead of waiting for three years, it was warned that it was getting into something it couldn't handle. But the city went forward anyway, and today it owns 9,500 rundown apartment buildings and has the additional responsiblity of caring for the people who live in them. Apparently without design or intent, and certainly without preparation, the city itself has become the largest slumlord in town.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: At the Guadeloupe summit conference, the most urgent concern of the four Western leaders was Iran. Its revolution threatens Western strategy in the Middle East and Western oil supplies from that revolutionridden country.

title: Snow Brings, Snarls to Roads, Smiles to Youngsters
description: The first major snowfall of winter, which surprised some forecasters by its volume, dumped 3 to 10 inches of snow in the metropolitan area yesterday, causing dozens of traffic accidents and delays on slionery highways.

description: Jazz has produced only a handful of names known to the general public. Louis Armstrong, Dave Brubeck, Benny Goodman, Duke Ellington and Miles Davis grew rich and famous, and they bent to popular taste to do so.

title: TV Sports Still Walks a Delicate Tightrope
description: The recent controversies over net work coverage of the postseason college bowl games underscore the delicate problem that confronts sports as a television attraction.

title: Business Is Picking Up For Indochina Experts Watching in Bangkok
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 6  The small community of Indochinawatchers here is busy these days exchanging opinions and interpretations on Vietnam's largescale invasion of Cambodia. It does so in the full knowledge that its data base is extremely narrow.

title: G.O.P. Begins Its Efforts for '80 With Longtime Rifts Left Behind
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 The Republi- can Party, whose internal battles have often been as passionate as those it fought against the Democrats, is beginning the 1980 Presidential campaign less divided than at any time since World War II.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: The Aldrich Museum of Contemporary Art in Ridgefield is true to its name Soon we will stop selling anything from the 1950's, said Larry Aldrich, the wellknown dress designer turned patron of emerging young artists. The new exhibition opening Saturday is called Prospectus: The 70's, and it exemplifies Mr. Aldrich's continuing purpose: to show the transition and development of the newest in art forms and techniques. Some of the works by Nevelson, Rauschenberg and Lichtenstein project the 1960's into the 1970's. Others, by newer, less recognizable names like Bell, Russell and Cunningham, explore the 1970 trends in abstractillusionism, pattern, painting and high tech.

title: John C. Spain Will Marry Caroline A. Ferris in June
description: The engagement of Caroline Atwater Ferris to John Christopher Spain, has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Dakin Bennett Ferris of Rye, N.Y. Mr. Spain is a son of Susanne E. Spain of Sun Valley, Idaho, and John Paul Spain of of Mahopac, N.Y. The wedding is planned for June.

title: After 15 Years, Plot Theories Still Thicken
description: WASHINGTON  The record of the House Select Committee on Assassinations, disbanded last week after a twoyear, $5.8million investigation, may tell more about the times t.han the murders of President Kennedy and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

description: HOLLYWOOD (UPI) - China has purchased rights to the film Futureworld for general release.

title: FollowUp on the News
description: The action by the New Jersey Public Health Council was heralded in April 1978 as one of the most sweeping prohibitions in the country against smoking in indoor public places. After almost a year of discussion, the council had revised the State Sanitary Code to outlaw smoking in virtually all public buildings, unless the building set aside specially designated areas for the smokers.

title: Women Find Political Success Elusive
description: PATRICIA MITCHELL wasn't shy about what she wanted. When she heard that three seats on the Suffolk County Legislature would become vacant as a result of the November elections and that one of those seats was trom ner community in Islip, she gave two copies of her resume to a Republican committeewoman to submit to the town's screening committee But no one called her to set up an inter, iew. Then she read in a newspaper tt,at Anthony Pace, the Islip Town Republican leader, had denied ever seeing her resume. So Mrs. Mitchell, an assistant professor of interpersonal communications at Hunter College, had another copy of her resume handdelivered to Mr. Pace's office.

title: In Banking, The Street Is Getting Crowded
description: A MAJOR structural upheaval is under way in the banking industry with the forces for change coming from both outside and inside. The banking landscape is being transformed by the growing presence here of foreign banks.
