title: Amy Paula Miller, Walter C. Dennison Are Wed on Coast
description: Amy Paula Miller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Miller of New York and Hampton Bays, L.I., was married at noon yesterday to Walter Charles Dennison, son of Dr. Edwin W. Dennison of San Diego and Dr. Laura B. Dennison of Claremont, Calif.

title: DINING OUT
description: WE have often been asked how we select the restaurants to be reviewed. Sometimes we have had previous experience with a restaurant; at other times we have gathered recommendations from friends, from readers or from other journals. A desire for diversity determines the exact order.

title: Transit Police Officers Are Ordered to Learn Ways of Local Discos
description: Sanford D. Garelik, chief of the Transit Authority police, has ordered his II district commanders to familiarize themselves with the location and activities of the discotheques in their areas and to expand police coverage on subway trains when crowds surge out of the clubs.

title: SHOP TALK
description: IF you're still trying to balance your checkbook and figure out t way to get through January after the expensive holiday season, you might try shopping Korvette's. The store has eight branches in Nassau and Suffolk Counties (Huntington, Lawrence, Massapequa, Hempstead, Valley Stream, Hicksville, Commack and Lake Grove) and provides a variety of practical merchandise at nofrills prices.

title: Pittsburgh Plan Is to Stop Campbell Rushing
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 6  The date is two weeks earlier and the site a few degrees cooler, but suddenly the Super Bowl is here. Just ask Dan Pastorini.

title: Margery Constantine and A.D. Weekes 3d, Formerly With Chemical Bank, Are Wed
description: The marriage of Margery S. Constantine, daughter of Hermann C. Schwab of Oyster Bay, L.I., and Mrs. William R. Deering of Smith's Parish, Bermuda, to Arthur D. Weekes 3d took place yesterday at St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I. The Rev. Carleton Lee performed the ceremony. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. Weekes Jr. of Oyster Bay and the late Nancy Milburn Weekes.

title: 2 Brothers in Ohio Deny Charges In Slaying of 3 by .22Caliber Gun
description: NEWARK, Ohio, Jan. 6 (AP)  Two brothers have pleaded not guilty to seven counts of aggravated murder, robbery and burglary stemming from the .22-caliber killings of three persons.

description: WASHINGTON - I don't believe in deregulation, A. Daniel O'Neal Jr., chairman of the Interstate Commerce Commission, said a year ago. I think we need improved regulation to get the kind of competition that will help the trucking industry and shippers.

title: Shah's Advisers Are Divided On His Leaving or Staying
description: We went for a waik around the grounds and there was the Queen elipping a rose bush. This is the Queen, said George. How do you do, she said . . . . When I left the King said: Well, maybe we'll meet in the States sometime. Like all Greeks, he wants to get over to the States.

title: Alan Waldenberg to Wed Sadye Rittenberg
description: Dr. and Mrs. Alvin L. Rittenberg of Charleston, S.C., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Sadye Beth Rittenberg, to Alan Stuart Waldenberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Waldenberg of Wyckoff, N. J., and Great Neck, L. I. A March 4 wedding is planned.

title: Business Is Big In Education, Too
description: LAST year the American Telephone and Telegraph company spent $700 million on education programs for its employees, or more than three times the $213 million annual budget of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

title: Suspect in Bank Theft Uses Bus as Escape Car
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Jan. 6 (AP) Robbery charges have been brought against a 32-year-old woman who tried to use a bus as a getaway car yesterday after allegedly holding up the Industrial National Bank's main branch.

title: Moslems in Soviet Caught Between Faith and State
description: KHIVA, U.S.S.R. - The mudbrick walls and domes and minarets were si- lent; no mournful chanting calls to wor- ship echoed in the ancient streets. At the doorway of a 14thcentury mausoleum, a Moslem woman appeared wrapped in bright shawls, followed by four boys.

title: Bending Wage Guidelines; Tests for Wage Guidelines; A calendar of major contract expiration dates; Jan. 7; March 31; April 19; April 30; May 30; June 30; July 15; Aug. 31; Sept. 14; Sept. 30; Nov. 16; Dec. 1
description: LABOR settlements this year may fall within the Government's 7 percent guideline  as long as the Government is willing to bend the guidelines to match the settlements instead of expecting the settlements to meet the guidelines.

title: Halpern, the Boxer, Held With 2 On Charge of Setting Bronx Fire
description: Three men, including a retired New York City policeman and the heavy- weight boxer Bobby Halpern, were ar- rested early yesterday and charged with having touched off a gasolinefed fire that swept through a dozen stores in the Bronx.

title: Catherine Johnston Is Engaged
description: Catherine Holohan Johnston, a nurse and teacher at the Boston University Medical Center, plans to be married in June to Robert Morrison Mullin Jr., a sales consultant for the Xerox Corporation in Lexington, Mass. Their engagement has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. William S. Johnston of Tarrytown, N.Y., parents of the future bride, whose fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Mullin of Belmont, Mass.

title: Tobacco Institute Battles Restrictions on Smoking
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP)  In city halls, statehouses and Congress, the Tobacco Institute's army of lobbyists, lawyers and publicists is building dikes ,against a rising tide of government efforts to discourage cigarette smoking.

title: DANCE VIEW; ANNA KISSELGOFF; What Will the Jos Limn Company Do Next?; DANCE VIEW; The Limn Troupe
description: In its one week at the City Center, the Jos Limn Dance Company managed to raise the most questions  and eyebrows  of the season. Very possibly, it became the first moderndance company to strike out in a new, even tenuous, direction that bears little relationship to modern dance's own perception of itself in the past. In 1932, when there was a great deal of explaining to be done about an art form that was still in its initial stages development, John Martin, dance critic of The Times, offered a most cogent definition. The modern dance is not system, he declared, It is a point of view. He was, course, telling us that modern dance was not classical ballet. Modern dance, he said, did not rely upon a codified movement idiom. Its own idiom was a new language that embodied the personal expression of its various choreographers. These points of view made up a collective point view toward dance in general.

title: French Schools Help the Very Senior Class
description: TOULOUSE, FRANCE PROF. PIERRE VELLAS had observed wide differences between the urban and rural elderly in the farming areas around Toulouse. What a difference, he said, between old people in cities, or those who don't benefit from family solidarity. Whereas those in the country live with their children, nourish themselves en the farm, give of their servicesthey continue to participate in life.

title: ON THE ISLE
description: James Conlon, the up-and-corning young conductor who made a big splash on national television recently with the Metropolitan Opera's Tosca, is back on his native Long Island this week, and both the Orchestra Da Camera and the Suffolk Symphony have him. Today at 3 P.M., he will lead the chamber orchestra and Kun Woo Paik, the pianist, in Da Camera's second allMozart concert of the season. Tickets are $9 and the concert will take place at Half Hollow Hills High School West, Wolf Hill Road, Dix Hills. 3213249. On Saturday, Mr. Conlon moves to Hauppauge High School, Town Line Road, where at 8:30 P.M. he, the Suffolk Symphony and Lynn Harrell, the cellist, will offer some Schumann, Schubert and Dvorak. Tickets for this are $6 to $10. 7977791.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: A collection of United States gold coins, almost all purchased in the years shortly after World War II for total outlay of less than $14,000, was sold at auction last month by Stack's of New York for something over $1.2 million.

title: Music in Review
description: Lola Odiaga, a Peruvian harpsichordist who teaches at Yale, the Hartt College of Music and Wellesley College, made an impressive New York debut at Carnegie Recital Hall on Wednesday night, playing music by Antonio de Cabezon, John Bull, J.S. Bach and Domenico Scarlatti.

title: ...And Still Counting
description: Like a man in a minefield, Shahpur Bakhtiar, the new Prime Minister of Iran, moved ever so carefully last week to compose a platform and a government that could gain the support or at least avoid the open antagonism  of the volatile opposition. He got through the first few days but there were bigger minefields ahead.

title: Profit Gains Expected For Most Industries Profit Outlook
description: DESPITE rising inflation, a devastating weakness in the dollar in the third quarter and talk of a recession, major industrial sectors of the economy, although remaining cautious, foresee limited gains this year. Analysts are forecasting a 6 percent to 10 percent growth aftertax corporate profits for 1979, compared with an 11 percent gain estimated for 1978. We share the general view that growth will be slow in 1979, but we do not expect the kind of recession that would impact profits and dividends severely, said Arnold Bernhard, research chairman of the Value Line Investment Survey. We think the dividend level will hold. In fact, it may go up more than profits. The payout ratio is very low.

title: A Home
description: lowers her eyes with some embarrassment, but becomes aware of the obvious interest and appreciation of those listening. This comes as a surprise to her, for in our society, the hidden scholar  the scholar without funding, title, or institutional base, is still regarded as an oddity, and most people would be astonished to discover how many of us there are.

title: Byrne to Act On Ski Bill
description: ALTHOUGH it has been unable to solve the problem of rising automobileinsurance costs, the State Legislature recently showed that it still had the ability to respond to an insurance crisis. The lawmakers man- aged to push through both houses in the same week  and send to the Governor for his action  a bill establishing the limits of responsibility for skiers and skiarea operators.

title: Authorized, Unacceptable
description: By Lord Birkenhead. Illustrated. 421 pp. New York: Random House. $15.

title: Brazil Alters Its Export Mix
description: RIO DE JANEIRO Once again last week, Brazil raised the tax on textiles bound for the United States; by year's end, the imposts will total a rousing 37.2 percent. Such moves, inevitably painful to the industries affected, have a kind of silver lining, though. They are responses to American anger over Brazilian trade policies, a kind of negative recognition that Brazil's exports matter, and not simply on the agricultural side.

title: Can Joel Grey Make Jacobowsky Sing?; Can Joel Grey Make Jacobowsky Sing?
description: Such was the power of Joel Grey's portrayal of the leeringly androgynous master of ceremonies in the 1966 musical Cabaret  for which he won a Tony Award and later an Oscar for the film version  that, even now, a visitor to his apartment almost expects to be met at the door by that satanic host of the decadent Kit Kat Klub in 1930's Berlin. Instead of the sardonic strains of Willkommen, however, there is Mozart in the air as Mr. Grey, softspoken, slight and spare as ever, jauntily leads the way into his lightfilled hying room high above Fifth Avenue and Central Park.

title: Carter Aides Assail Koch on Cuts; Fear a Discussion of Bankruptcy
description: An internal White House memorandum prepared for President Carter warns that Mayor Koch should have cut the New York City budget more than he did in the last year and that, unless major cuts are made in the year ahead, there will be serious discussion of bankruptcy for the city in 1981 and 1982.

title: McEnroe Moves In As Test for Connors
description: It is always Jimmy Connors against Someone. First it was Rod Laver, then John Newcombe, Arthur Ashe, Manuel Orantes, Ilie Nastase, Guillermo Vilas and Biorn Borg.

title: They've Grown Accustomed to Winning
description: IF the Mount Vernon High School basketball team has a problem, is ennui. The team's twoseason, 30game winning streak is hardly a wonder to the city's sports cognoscenti. It has even prompted a local sports- writer to say: They're boring. They'll only be interesting if they lose.

title: News Summary
description: Civilian government was restored in Iran as Prime Minister Shahpur Bakhtiar presented his Cabinet to the Shah. The first Cabinet meeting was held later to discuss ways of dealing with the rioting that has shaken the country and with its economic problems. The new Government was scorned by one of the Shah's prinCipal opponents, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, who called on employees at the Iranian Government ministries to lock the new Cabinet ministers out. title: James Fagan and Madeleine Robinson, Banker, to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. John M. Robinson of Clifton, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Madeleine Diamond Robinson, to James A. Fagan, son of Mrs. Robert K. Fagan of South Orange, N.J., and the late Mr. Fagan. The wedding is planned for December.

title: Serenity of Egyptian Monks Is Broken By Stir Over John the Baptist's Relic
description: WADI ELNATRUN, Egypt - Long before the desert sunrise splashes light across the sand hills, the blackrobed monks of the St. Macarius Coptic Orthodox monastery are awake and in their church, breaking the chill morning silence with psalms.

title: Inaugural Pomp And Uncertainties
description: HARTFORD INAUGURATION DAY was a time for pomp and circumstance, ruffles and flourishes, loaves and fishes. Governor Grasso. chane- ing costumes several times throughout the long day, swore in other high state officials, reviewed ceremonial troops and military bands, received a 19gun salute, was sworn in herself, and gave an inaugural address that proposed to almost everyone almost everything that they could reasonably expect. Then she went on to a whirl of official photographs and more ceremonies as well as an inaugural ball.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: ALL things considered, Vinnie had given it a good run. He had stayed late in the city to do some serious beer drinking and there were eight empty bottles lined up in front of him on the table.

title: The Other Sarasin Sets Up Political Base
description: HARTPORD AREPUBLICAN from Beacon Falls named Sarasin capped his Nov. 7 election victory last Wednesday when he was sworn into office at the State Capitol here. He is Warren. the other Sara- sin, brother of Ronald, who had hoped to be taking a different oath on Wednesday.

title: Design
description: LEFT: Architect Peter Schneck made the swimming pool by damming up a large fissure in the outcropping of granite upon which the house is built. On top of the dam is a terrace with two cabanas and an alfresco dining area which looks out to the Mediterranean.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: IN most cases when a toilet flushes sluggishly and does not seem to carry waste away as efficiently as it should, the first thing the home handyman or handywoman will suspect is a cloued or partly blocked drain. However, if, after probing with a drain auger and vigorous working with a plumber's force cup, the drain seems to show no signs of a clog or obstruction and the toilet still does not flush as forcefully as it should, then chances are that the problem is because of a slow or inadequate flow of water into the bowl during the flushing cycle.

title: Jersey Man Found Dead in Maui
description: LAHAINA, Maui, (AP) - The police on the island of Maui today identified the body of a 22-year-old tourist as Arthur Goldin of New Brunswick, N.J. Mr. Goldin's body was found yesterday in a motel room at this seaside resort, wrapped in a blanket. The police said death apparently was caused Dy severe head wounds inflicted with a blunt instrument. No weapon was found, and the police do not have a motive for the killing.

title: Commissioner's Model for the 1980's
description: TWENTYONE years ago, the Russian satellite Sputnik streaked into the sky and set off a national debate about the nation's schools. Today we find ourselves in the midst of another intense debate about the goals and effectiveness of our schools. The nation's class- rooms have become the It tin lines, not only in the battle against ignorance but also in the civil rights revolution of the 1960's and 70's.

title: Washington Post to Build Plant
description: WASHINGTON, AP) - The Washington Post says it plans to build and begin operating a suburban printing plant by the fall of 1980 to handle part of its expanding daily press run. The plant will probably be near Springfield, Va.

title: On the Ethics Of Using Recordings Posthumously
description: Elektra Records recently released an album by Jim Morrison and the Doors called An American Prayer. On it, the late Mr. Morrison declaims his poetry and, sometimes, sings, while the three instrumentalists of the Doors either ac- company him in the conventional rock manner or, more often, provide instru- mental backing somewhat akin to what jazz musicians used to supply to beat Poets.

title: AROUND THE WORLD IN 73 DAYS.
description: Chinese cities, it seems, are quiet at night. Though the streets are dark, there are lights that are tiny and widely spaced. Kweilin was crowded. Everyone was out to savor the coolness of the night after the heat of a summer clay. We walked through a park built around a lake. There were trees and flowers, paths and benches, most of them occupied by people talking quietly.

title: Lincoln Kirstein As Critic And Patron
description: of the New York City Ballet, which he founded with George Balanchine. This in itself would be sufficient claim for fame, but for more than 50 years Mr. Kirstein has been much involved elsewhere in the arts, too, and this preliminary record of his writings on many subjects is an indispensable guide to his remarkably versatile career  one of the Ca reers, it is well to remember, that has helped to shape some of the most valuable parts of our present culture.

title: National Economic Survey; Inflation: A Showdown Is At Hand
description: Sometime last year, inflation underwent a seachange in the United States; it changed from being regarded as a tolerable to an intolerable problem. And now the course of business will in large measure be shaped by tie efforts of the Federal Government and the monetary authorities to solve this problem that has eroded confidence in the American economy, both at home and abroad.

title: Future Events
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: Long Island
description: MINEOLA LONG Island, whose economy has depended for years on a rapidly expanding population and increasing numbers of manufacturing jobs, developing a new economic base.

title: The Friend That Failed
description: The quaint charade of the past week about whether Uncle Sam was giving the Shah of Iran a weekend holiday, an extended vacation or an indefinite leave of absence betrayed again a dangerous tendency in the American psyche. No matter how compelling the case for recognizing the downfall of a friend, the truth had to be denied because other friends might judge us unfaithful. No matter how urgent the need to forge ties with the Shah's successful opponents, it seemed even more important to demonstrate American constancy to the world beyond Iran than to protect American interests inside Iran. As an unnamed White House official remarked,, The goal now is to bend over backward to reassure a lot of jittery allies that we are prepared, if necessary, to go up in flames with the Shah. As so often before, a major crisis abroad was being treated as a test of our will as well as our wit.

title: Of Special Interest
description: Second Season

title: Rationale for Guadeloupe
description: PARIS  The significance of last week' s conference in Guadeloupe can easily be misunderstood. It was the first time since World War II that the leaders of the United States, Britain, France and Germany met alone to discuss the full range of world issues, but probably not the last. It is likely that the Big Four of the Western world were creating a new club where they can occasionally meet to privately exchange views, coordinate policies, make deals and exhibit the fundamental common interest binding them together.

title: Wine
description: We had driven down to Beaune, the unofficial capital of Burgundy, from Vougeot and were having the last drink of the night at the Hotel de la Poste. The conversation was all about the dinner we u just attended at the ???? vougeot, one of several given every spring and fall in the famous old Cistercian abbey by the Confrerie des Chevaliers du Tastevin, the wine society that owns the abbey.

title: Terri Ascher Fiance of Doctor
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harris Ascher of Franklin Square, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Terri Ascher, to Dr. Alan 1. Benvenisty, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Benvenisty of Merrick, L.I. The bridegroom-to-be is completing his residency in surgery at the Columbia Presbyterian Hospital.

title: SPORTS
description: MOST of the time, athletes  professional and ama teur  are taught how to run, jump, throw, kick shoot, swing, catch, tackle, swim skate and so on, but not how to eat Above all. not how to eat.

title: Head of Housewives for E.R.A. Says Measure Would Aid Family
description: SIDNEY, III., (UPI)  Anne Follis, wiping the remains of lunch from her baby daughter's face, spoke with a determined voice.

title: 3 on Snowmobiles Feared Dead
description: OAKLAND, Md. Jan. 6 (AP) Four snowmobiles plunged through the ice into the freezing waters of Deep Creek Lake early today, and the authorities said that one person had been killed and two others were missing.

title: Pointing
description: AUSTIN, Tex.One Tuesday night last fall, the farmers of Panhandle, Tex., and their wives gathered at Panhandle,High School. They looked over a.table full of pamphlets and then filed into the auditorium. Soon George Eller, a farmer, introducect tne man they had come to hear. J. C. Lewis modestly acknowledged the applause and began to talk, calmly and convincingly.

title: WhereWe Stand
description: There is widespread fear across the country that Proposition 13 will spread. Wherever I have traveled in recent months the issue has been raised. Public employees arc afraid that they will lose their jobs in the near future. College students worry that there will be no jobs for them when they graduate. Citizen groups are concerned about the erosion of public services, about lowerquality schools, police and fire protection, libraries and health services. The same question is asked over and over again: What can we do to stop Proposition 13?

title: THE APPEAL OF THE DEATH TRIP
description: Was anyone prepared for the Rev. Jim Jones and his People's Temple? The death drama staged in Guyana jolts us not only because of its incredible statistics and the dreadful of a mad leader over his followers, but because we sense in it a terrible caricature of real struggles taking place in American society. To sort out what happened at Jonestown, it is necessary to examine three basic issues: the pattern of killing and dying that took place there, the quality of obedience behind that pattern, and the psychological and historical readiness of young, and not so young, people for such cult experiences.

title: Housing - It Shelters More Than the Family
description: D ESPITE high prices and tightening credit, demand for housing has remained strong with people increasingly relying on home purchases as a hedge against inflation.

description: To the Sports Editor:

description: GREAT NECK

title: Notes: A ife.ssage From the Image Makers
description: The jaded traveler,:that invetvrate globetrotter who hAs been everywhere twice  and hated it  had better go back and take another look. The world is chaneine. or at least the tourist promoters and Madison Avenue types insist it is, so perhaps the time might be ripe to take a look.

title: Vencedor Captures Sprint at Aqueduct
description: Topweighted Vencedor turned in midsummer's performance in winning the sixfurlong, $54,100 paumonok Handicap impressively yesterday at snowcloaked Aqueduct. The 5-year-old favorite was clocked in a speedy 1:10 on a track labeled good.

title: GARDENING
description: BIRDS add a delightful dimension to winter. Even those who do not put out birdfeeders can delight in their visits to the lawn where birds hunt for whatever seeds, grubs and worms they can find in the frozen turf.

title: Al Hibbler, Jazz Vocalist, at Club
description: Al Hibbler, who sang with Duke Ellington's orchestra in the 1940's and has been out on his own since then, is a puzzling singer who encrusts his performances with an unwieldy collection of mannerisms that are, at the least, distracting when they are not actually disturbing.

title: David D. Comey Dies at Age 44; Active in Environmental Affairs
description: David Dinsmore Comey, president and executive director of Citizens for a Better Environment, died Friday in an automobile accident in Columbia County, Wis. He was 44 years old and lived in Chicago.

title: New AntiCommunist Actions Were Reported - and Denied - Last Week
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Long known as the wild men of Arab politics, the Iraqis now speak the language moderation. The metamorphosis did not come overnight and is by no means total. Iraq still affects progressive posture in Arab and world affairs and has been careful not to burn its bridges with its chief arms supplier, the Soviet Union, as a visit to Moscow last month by the Iraqi Vice President made clear.

title: Carter Aide on Women's Issues Is Stressing Economic Problems
description: WASHINGTON, (UPI)  In her job as White House adviser on women's issues, Sarah Weddington has been as. signed the arduous role of peacemaker to the warring factions that have polarized viewpoints among women.

title: BOOK ENDS
description: WHEN a visitor interrupted his labors, William Styron was cor- recting proofs of his new novel, Sophie's Choice, a work to which he had devoted live years and a quarter of a million words and which Random House is bringing out next June. Because reading proof more or less marks the end of the creative trail, one would think that Mr. Styron would he in a buoyant mood. Well, he was, but going over proofs, he indicated,. was no unalloyed pleasure.

description: To the Editor:

description: posed to offer the public a chance to see the recent Broadway hits it might have missed? I ask this because of the Hartman's current production of Absurd Person Singular, which closed its Broadway run only three years ago.

description: 'I LOOK like an acton' Jack Aranson concedes. I'm a hit tweedy, with colorful scars and dark, menacing overcoats and a slouch hat.

title: Westchester
description: WHITE PLAINS DEALING with the economy can make writing monthly reports very very dull, said Richard Kappus, a labor market analyst with the regional office here of the State Department of Labor. It's all so stable. and STEADY.

title: Diane Boardman Dance Company Offers 3 Works
description: Though well within the Murray Louis tradition from which she developed, the choreographer Diane Boardman brings to that cheerful scattershot of clipped, small movements and gestures a kind of implosive energy. The three short new and recent dances presented by the Diane Boardman Dance Company on Friday at the Eden's Expressway loft theater had the overall effect of stifled sneezes.

title: Coins Litter Road in Toronto
description: TORONTO, (Reuters)  Policemen and security guards spent more than an hour on their hands and knees in the bitter cold here yesterday picking up $921 in coins that had spilled from an armored truck along a suburban road. The coins were in bags that fell out of the truck and burst.

title: Wallpaper Days, Music Nights
description: PORT JEFFERSON 'YOU'LL notice that they play wintry music here, Rick Leckie said between sets, and he was right. The custommade tape of gentle but crisp popjazz at Raspberry's on East Broadway here gave one the feeling of having found a cozy refuge from the chill outside. Here, even the tenderskinned could fantasize in safety about frosty moonlight, swirling snowdrifts, howling winds and saltlaced air.

title: Jim Jones and His People
description: The inside Story of the Peoples Temple Sect and the Massacre in Guyana. By Marshall Kilduff and Ron Javers. 201 pp. New York: Bantam Books. Paper, $2.50.

title: And You Needn't Ea The Bookshelves
description: THE day I was accepted at Yale College, I spent the morning dancing around the house, smiling at myself in every mirror on the way. Around lunchtime, my mother told me to cut it out and come into the kitchen. They didn't give you enough money, she said.

title: Holtz to Remain In Arkansas Post
description: HONOLULU, Jan. 6 (AP) Lou Holtz, the Arkansas football coach, repeated denials today that he was a candidate to replace Woody Hayes as coach at Ohio State University.

title: IN BRIEF
description: The Energy and Justice Departments charged nine major oil companies in Federal District Court last week with overcharging on natural gas liquids totaling $930 million. The Energy Department, which said it was its larg- est enforcement action so far, earlier had alleged $316 million in overcharges by the Exxon Corporation, and this was included in the new suit. The remaining $614 million was charged against the Mobil Corporation, Texaco Inc., the Standard Oil Company (Indiana), the Shell Oil Company, the Phillips Petroleum Company, the Gulf Oil Corporation, the Atlantic Richfield Company and the Cities Service Company. The companies say they were following traditional industry pricing, and accused the department of contradictory interpretations of regulations.

title: Church Council Body Moving to Harlem in Protest
description: The Interreligious Foundation for Community Organization will leave its headquarters at 475 Riverside Drive tomorrow for a new home in Harlem because of the dismissal of a prominent black minister, Lucius Walker Jr., by the National council of the Churches of Christ.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 By the 1980 election, President Carter's tight budget for the fiscal year 1980 would trim the Federal civilian payroll to almost the same level as when Mr. Carter took office in 1977, the Administration will tell Con- gress later this month.

description: Ellen Joan Greene, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Greene of Passaic, N.J., was married last evening to Ira Seth Friedberg, son of Mrs. Julius Fenster, also of Passaic, and the late Robert Friedberg. Rabbi Joseph Herman performed .the ceremony in Millburn, N.J.

title: Dear, Those Little Habits of Yours Are Slowly Driving Me Crazy
description: It would seem unlikely that a woman now married for the second time, would end up with a man who eats fried eggs in exactly the same peculiar manner as her first husband. But she did, and whenever there are fried eggs on the plate, there's divorce in the air.

description: THE securities industry, seeking a greater return on its investment after years of inadequate performance, will be pulling out the stops in 1979 to achieve better results. And with the concept of the financial department store becoming more popular, indications are that most ,any growth will come from the biggest firms.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6  Ahmed clShahati, head of Libya Foreign Liaison Office, will meet with Billy Carter tomorrow in Georgia as part of a visit designed to improve understanding between the Libyan and American people.

title: Sisters Attend Holly Bartlett At Her Bridal
description: Holly Lockwood Bartlett, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David McIntosh Bartlett of Bronxville, N.Y., was married yesterday in the Reformed Church of Bronxville to Pierce Newberry McCreary Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. McCreary of Larchmont, N.Y. The Rev. Joel E. Strauch, brother-in-law of the bridegroom and a minister of the United Church of Christ, performed the ceremony.

description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Paul Hamill of Woodmere, L.I., and Lawrenceville, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter, Cynthia Louise Hamill, to Charles Garabedian, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank K. Garabedian of Hewlett, L.I.

description: The annual convention of the Amencan Horse Shows Association, which has been a calm meeting involved with technical changes in recent years, is scheduled this week and could develop into a conference that will leave numerous hard feelings.

title: Gail Sander to Be Wed June 9
description: Mr. and Mrs. H. James Sander of New Rochelle, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Gail Eleanor Sander, to David Michael Astrove, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Astrove, also of New Rochelle. The couple expect to graduate next May from the University of Pennsylvania and to be married June 9.

title: POLITICS
description: THE high cost of running for Governor of Connecticut last year has produced general criticism but few specific sug- gestions on what ought to be done about it. Governor Grasso, the winner, has called the amount of money spent on the latest campaign terrible and a disgrace. The criticism, she noted, was bipartisan and applied to her own campaign as well as to the unsuccessful effort of her Republican challenger, former Representative Ronald A. Sarasin.

title: Queen Juliana Flies to New York
description: AMSTERDAM, Jan. 6 (Reuters) Queen Juliana of the Netherlands flew today to New York for a 10day visit with her youngest daughter, Princess Christina, a Government spokesman said. Princess Christina, 31 years old, lives in New York with her Cubanborn husband, Jorge Guillermo, and their child, Bernardo, who was born in 1977. Queen Juliana will return home on Jan. 16.

title: The Need for the Arts: A Legislator's Realization..
description: IFIRST met the folk singer Harry Chapin shortly after I was elected as a Huntington representative to the Suffolk County Legislature. Harry said something to me then that I've kept in mind ever since, wondering when I'd have to act on his advice. He told me, Please don't ever be afraid to admit you made a mistake. Trust the people to understand. Well, I almost made a mistake I would have regretted and I want to talk about it.

title: CRIME
description: It's a neat title: BISHOP AS PAWN (Vanguard, $7.95). Seems that a bishop has been kidnapped by mistake; the parish priest had been the intended target. This parish priest is Father Dowling, and he has ap- peared in two previous mysteries by Ralph Mc1nerny. Father Dowling is not the average priest, one who dispenses homilies and easy nostrums. He has been through the mill himself, is tough, yet has compassion. As noted here when Her Death of Cold (the first Father Dowling book) appeared in 1977, the unsentimental, clearminded Father Dowling is the Catholic equivalent of Harry Kernelman's Rabbi David Small.

title: Company May Drop Bid For Maine Oil Refinery
description: PORTLAND, Me., Jan. 6 The Pitt ston Company of New York has said that its plans for a $600 million oil refinery at Eastport may have to be abandoned because of a,finding by the Fish and Wildlife Service that the existence of the bald eagle in this part of the country would be threatened by a refinery.

title: Glass Blowing Becomes an Art Form
description: WITH a hissing cloud of steam and sparks around his hand, it was hard to tell what Stephen Fellerman was using to protect his hand from the whitehot ball of glass he was shaping. It was wet newspaper that he cupped around the 1,800degree glass, while rotating the blowpipe with his other hand.

title: Shakeup Is Expected at 49ers
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 6A major shakeup in West Coast football circles is expected to begin perhaps as early as next week and conclude just after the National Football League completes its season with the Super Bowl jan 21.

title: Judith Chamberlain Married to a Builder
description: Judith C. Chamberlain, a teacher in Washington, was married there yesterday to Christopher Wong, a Washington realestate developer and builder. The ceremony was performed in St. Alban's Episcopal Church by the Rev. William Wade of the National Cathedral School, where the bride is head of the Latin department.

title: Oil Problem: How to Cut Consumption  And Inflation
description: THE Carter Administration is committed raising energy prices. The Carter Adminis tration is committed to reducing inflation. Ergo: The Carter Administration has a prof: tem  one that may prove as frustrating to the Presi dent during his next two years in office as were his original energy proposals during the first two. Economic forecasters say energy prices will climb this year by perhaps 12 percent at the consumer level. In 1978, by contrast, the fuel and power components of the Consumer Price Index rose 4.5 percent.

title: Curbs on Strip Mining Put Off After Industry Enlists Aides to Carter
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 - The coal in- dustry and the Department of Energy, by enlisting inflationfighting economists in the White House, have forced a delay of six months on costly new Federal envi- ronmental curbs on strip mining.

title: The Age of Information: A Quiet Revolution
description: INDUSTRIAL revolutions are usually signalled by the gnashing of gears, the whirring of textile spindles and the clanging of steel. But a quiet revolution is going on today, changing the face business and the social fabric  its name is telecommunications. An empty and overused word for many people, telecommunications is, nevertheless, a frontier industry that is reducing the journey into the future to a series of small steps.

title: Resignation by Head Of cological Hearing May Delay Westway
description: The resignation last week of the hearing officer in charge of the key airquality hearings on the proposed Westway threatened to delay further that controversial $1.16 billion highway project planned for the west shore of Manhattan from the Battery to 92d Street.

title: BEHIND THE BEST SELLERS
description: Arthur Schlesinger Jr. faced two uncommon problems as a historian in writing Robert Kennedy and His Times, published by Houghton Mifflin.

title: Spurs Defeated by Late Rally; KnicksRally Defeats Spurs, 108105; Knicks Box; SAN ANTONI0(105); KNICKS(100)
description: Joe Meriweather lent a quick helping hand last night as the Knicks defeated the San Antonio Spurs, the hottest team in the National Basketball Association, 108105, last night before a crowd of 15,932 at Madison Square Garden.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS Rural China Visited
description: MADISON, Wis.I returned this winter to a north China village where I had lived last summer. I wanted to find out if the happy movement in a more democratic direction had liberated only China's urban dwellers.

title: A New Theater Opens and PAF Is the Star
description: HUNTINGTON STATION RIGHT smack in the middle of the suburbs  a fact of geography that used to spell death for anything even resembling culture  the PAF Playhouse, the only major regional theater in the United States specializing in original drama, is alive and well and prospering as it prepares for the official inauguration of its new theater with a gala opening on Thursday night.

title: E. Germans Capture 4 Events
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 6  East Germany, led by Barbara Krause, demonstrated tonight at Harvard's Blodgett Pool that it is still capable of navigating in international swimming competition as it won four of the seven openingday events at the women's international invitation meet.

title: Headliners
description: The laborer is worthy of his hire, said Luke's Gospel, establishing the principle that it's all right to pay the clergy for their trouble. And who has taken more trouble than Herbert W. Armstrong, founder of the Worldwide Church of God? The church, started in the 1920's, has become one of the nation's most prosperous denominations, with 70,000 members instructed to contribute at least 10 percent of their incomes, a yield church officials have said now runs to $70 million a year. Last week, a California court placed the church in temporary receivership, following a claim by state officials that Mr. Armstrong and his chief assistant, Stanley R. Rader, were pi Ifering church assets and diverting them to their own use and benefit on a massive scale, amounting to several million dollars a year. The state's suit claims that in recent months Mr. Armstrong and Mr. Rader sold church property in California, destroyed church records, and failed to file required financial reports. Mr. Rader issued a statement denying all wrongdoing. A hearing is scheduled for Wednesday to determine if the receivership will be permanent.

title: A Scholar's Papers
description: 19th and 20th Centuries. Selected Papers. By Meyer Schapiro. Illustrated. 277pp. New Yorlz: George R raziller. $20.

title: Overnight Delivery: The Battle Begins
description: In the drafty airport freight terminal in Memphis where the Federal Express Corporation sorts its packages, hundreds of bundledup workers scurry about on a chilly morning, keeping an eye on a giant countdown clock as they hurl layers of cartons onto a labyrinth of conveyors.

title: Lilli Palmer Understands a Gesture
description: By Lilli Palmer. 265 pp. New York: Macmillan.

title: Worst Point
description: AS strenuously as educators labor to keep the secret, one of the happiest discoveries of adulthood  or the saddest, depending upon one's point of view  is that success or failure in school has almost nothing to do with life after the last report card. West Point, the United States Military Acade- my, is, like her sister academies, an important exception. Entering West Point is in some ways like entering a monastery: an elaborately coded and regulated existence bearing little relationship to the world outside the Army, but binding men (and now women) with lifelong ties of loyalty, secrecy, exclusivity and shared humiliation.

title: Tharp Troupe at BAM For 8 Dates Next Month
description: Twyla Tharp and Dancers will return to the Brooklyn Academy of Music for eight performances from Feb. 15 to Feb. 25. The company, which has not been seen in New York for two years, will premiere four new works, including a set of three dances from the film Hair, which Miss Tharp choreographed and in which some of her (lancers performed.

title: New Health Research For Women Is Planned
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 6 (AP) The college that pioneered the education of women physicians in the 19th century is leading the drive for women's health research in the 20th century.

title: On the Liberal Arts And the Job Market
description: WHEN all is said and done  and while little is done, much is being said liberalarts education is still a sound investment. Liberalarts education does not guarantee a job after college, but all too often neither does vocational or technical education. The general nature of a liberalarts curriculum remains  on balance much more a blessing than a curse.

title: No Decision Now on Oil Price Controls
description: Secretary of Energy James R. Schlesinger said last week that the Administration would delay its decision on whether to remove price controls from gasoline and crude oil until it became clear when Iran would resume oil exports. Together, these controls are holding the price of gasoline and other petroleum products down by perhaps 7 cents a gallon, according to most estimates, and the announcement implied at least a small reprieve for inflationbattered consumers.

title: Around the Nation
description: CLEVELAND, Jan. 6 (UPI) - The man who attempted to lift Cleveland out of default was shifted to another job today by Mayor Dennis J. Kucinich, who also hinted that further cabinet changes might be on the way.

title: GrownUp Murdoch Eager to Start Fresh
description: They would film The Murdoch Spot at one of those I'll-just-die-if-I-can'tgetin places, like Studio 54 or Regine. The background neonle would be the obligatory beautiful, in the obligatory degree of undress, doing the obligatory Travolta Tango. The camera would ZOOM in on the man with the Munchkin chubby cheeks, smiling like Miss America, who would say, I come from Cranbrook, British Columbia, but I love New York, eh?

title: Food
description: The dining habits and eating preferences of Americans are, at times, curious. It is a commonplace that the public, by and large, dotes on foods made with or containing a stuffing (or a farce as it is often came)  sucn wings as turkey, goose and chicken, eggplant, tomatoes, onions and so on. Oddly, however, while stuffed fish fillets (generally filled with crab or shrimp) are not all that uncommon, a whole stuffed fish  which can be delectable  is something of a rarity on the tables of this nation.

title: POLITICS
description: He could roll with the revolt by arguing that the county government is responsible for only a small portion of the tax load, do some token budget cutting to show that he's got religion too and finally emphasize other aspects of his record in office.

title: DINING OUT; Where Seafood Is Simply Good; * Noah's
description: IF you are interested in a good seafood restaurant on the North Shore, you might try Noah's in Great Neck. It occupies a sprawling white house that had been long known as Maude Craig's. In honor of its new identity, the interior has been spruced up with bright blue- and green-patterned walls and carpets, white trellises and a profusion of plants. mostly plastic.

title: Linda G. Sheffer Is Betrothed
description: The engagement of Linda Galloway Sheffer, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Albert L. Sheffer of Weston, Mass., to John Kenneth Larabee, son of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Larabee of Severna Park, Md., has been announced by the future bride's parents. Miss Sheffer is a senior at Williams College. Her fianc, an alumnus of Williams, is a graduate student at the University of Virginia.

title: Caretakers Will Find it Hard to Fulfill Last Week's Vow to Continue Old Policies
description: ALGIERS  From Baghdad to Rabat, across the Arab world, the death of Algeria's Houari Boumediene has sent out ripples of concern and uncertainty. The absence President Boumediene, an unflinching, seriousminded champion of Arab militancy, could alter the balance forces between socalled radical and moderate Arab regimes and might lead to the resolution of an inconclusive st rupgle in the Western Sahara.

title: Adrianne M. Harun Wed to A.G. Scovil
description: Adriarme Marie Harun, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Harun of Mendham, N.J., was married there yesterday to Alistair Gavin Scovil, son of Dr. and Mrs H. E. D. Scovil of Gladstone, N.J.

title: NEW MIDEAST TALKS CONSIDERED BY U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6  The United States is considering a twotier set of negotiations in Washington to complete a peace treaty between Egypt and Israel, Administration officials said today.

title: Skiing Cuts a Swath CrossCounty
description: CROSSCOUNTRY skiing has been around longer than the snowshoe, but only recently has it captured the fancy of the American public. Today, crosscountry ski trails abound within Westchester's 443 square miles of greenery. Some are formally marked and twist and turn through parks and golf courses; other trails, carved out by more adventurous skiers, wind through wilder spaces where the snow is devoid of human tracks and the wind whistles across fro/en thickets.

title: OREN TO PERMIT MilDENTIST TEETH

title: Other National Events
description: A death, a dead heat and other complications in the Nov. 7 elections made it hard to say which party would control the Pennsylvania House of Representatives. Until last week, that is, when the House began its new session with 101 Republicans, 98 Democrats and two seats still subject to recount. The unanimous Republicans squashed a Democratic attempt to put off election of a Speaker until everything had been settled. They then chose their own man, H. Jack Seltzer. The outcome was a relief for the new Republican Governor, Richard U. Thornburgh, whose party is outnumbered 27 to 23 in the state Senate.

title: What's Doi'g in PUERTO RICO
description: HISTORY AND POLITICS  Puerto Rico was called Borinquen by its Indian population when Christopher Columbus first dropped anchor in 1493. He promptly renamed the island San Juan, but years later, a mapmaker confused the name of the island with that of its main port, Puerto Rico (Rich Port). The island then became Puerto Rico and the port San Juan. The island is 100 miles long by 35 miles wide and is one of the most densely populated com- munities on earth, with a population of 3.3 million. The standard of living is ex- cellent compared with other Caribbean and Latin American countries but poor compared with that of the United States. It is a land of marked contrasts with opulent highrise office buildings casting their shadows over dismal shanties built on stilts over fetid streams.

title: Kurds Lose All Round
description: Iraq has its differences with Iran and Turkey but has shared with them a perennial trouble Kurdish nationalism. All three countries have large Kurdish minorities, (Those Kurds, plus Soviet community, are believed to number 12 million.) Last month, leaders of the Iraqi, Iranian and Turkish wings of the Kurdish Democratic Party, which is banned in all three countries, met in Paris to discuss future strategy but reportedly reached no decisions. The movement has fallen on hard times. Iraq's recent reconciliation with Syria scuttled what was left of the Kurdish struggle achieve autonomy in north Iraq. Syria agreed end assistance to Jalal Talabani, who was once top aide to the Kurdish chieftain, Mustafa Barzani, and fled to Syria after the Barzani insurrection collapsed in 1975. That revolt died when the Shah of Iran ended his aid to the rebels. The Shah later allowed the Kurdish chieftain, now SO, to go Washington. There, according to Middle Eastern political gossip, he is being kept on ice by the Cen- tral Intelligence Agency. The Kurds, while angry at the Shah, are fearful of his possible replacement by a radical Shiite Moslem regime. The Kurds are Sunni Moslems. This has helped them integrate most successfully in predominantly Sunni Turkey.

title: Fireman Burned Saving Boy, 4
description: A fireman suffered burns to a wrist, his back and his ears after rescuing a 4-year- old boy from a burning apartment build- ing in Harlem Friday, fire authorities said. A spokesman for the Fire Depart- ment said the fireman  Lieut. Thomas Neary, 38, of Merrick, L.I.  fought his way into the burning apartment, at 301 West 147th Street, after he was told there was an infant inside. He forced the door open, searched the apartment and was about to leave when he came upon En- rique Jones, who was lying semicon- scious in a rear hallway, the spokesman said. The boy was taken to Harlem Hospi- tal, suffering from burns over 10 percent of his body and smoke inhalation.

title: Three Striking Current Shows
description: Each painting has a name to itself, and when they are set out in full they form as resonant a set of titles as has been devised since the heyday of the 19thcentury history-painting. A hundred years ago, studios all over Europe were silting up with canvases that were called, as Cy Twomblys are, The Shield of Achilles, Heroes of the Achaeans, The Vengeance of Achilles, The Achaeans in Battle, The Fire That Consumes All Before It, The Shades of Achilles, Patroclus and Hector, The House of Priam, The Trojans in Battle, Shades of Eternal Night and The Trojan Heroes. After a long period of disfavor some of those ponderous evocations are now being rediscovered and held up to admiration; and as for the subject matter, it is as evocative as ever it was. The Shield of Achilles by W.H. Auden and King Priam by Michael Tippett are key works of the period since World War II in poetry and opera respectively, and Peter Brooks London production of Shakespeares Troilus and Cressida made us think all over again about the resonance of the Trojan War. We are all Troywatchers, whether we know it or not.

title: BodySnatching Pods Are Back, Courtesy of Philip Kaufman
description: SAN FRANCISCO I never wanted to do a remake, confesses director Philip Kaufman. Nevertheless, he's done remake; and his version of the 1956 science fiction film The Invasion of the Body Snatchers has earned critical esteem (Janet Marlin wrote in The Times, the creepiness is so crazily ubiquitous it becomes funny, while Pauline Kaet of The New Yorker hails it as the American film of the year). Perhaps more important, Mr. Kaufman's Invasion of the Body Snatchers, made on a modest $3.5million budget, ranks, along with Superman and California Suite, as one of this holiday season's box office hits.

title: The Strike in Iran Is Another Test for the Multinationals

title: Other Ideas &
description: A new Gallup study commissioned by the American Librry Association gives bibliophiles something but not much  to rejoice over. Surveying a representative sample of 1,515 men and women, Gallup found that 59 percent had visited a public library and 77 percent had read a book in the preceding year. For the previous month the comparable figures were only 59 percent and 51 percent, and there were 6 percent who had never read a book at all. As for the impact of television, 28 percent said it was something they saw on the screen that led them to read a book. But 43 percent acknowledged that if they had watched the tube less, they would have read books more.

title: Trapping Welfare Tenants
description: As New York City landlords no longer find it profitable, low- and moderateincome housing is abandoned to city ownership. Costs rise so much that disinvestment  no mainte- nance or tax payments for years wnne all income is pocketed  yields more profit than longterm ownership. Neighborhood deterioration dooms even profitable buildings with good tenants and landlords. Permitting welfarepayment levels to fall mercilessly behind costs contributes to abandonment, as recipients have less with which to pay rent  $160 a month, on the average. (Recipients now seek help in court because the Department of Social Services allows less for rent than must be paid in controlled apartments!)

title: Getting Rid of a Problem With Water
description: IN most cases when a toilet flushes sluggishly and does not seem to carry waste away as efficiently as it should, the first thing the home handyman or handywoman will suspect is a clogged or partly blocked drain. However, if, after probing with a drain auger and vigorous working with a plumber's force cup, the drain seems to show no signs of a clog or obstruction and the toilet still does not flush as forcefully as it should, then chances are that the problem is because of a slow or inadequate flow of water into the bowl during the flushing cycle.

title: In Retrospect: Seven by Visconti
description: The name of the late Italian director Luchino Visconti often evokes the image of a fastidious, selfindulgent artist whose vision of life was lavishly operatic and whose themes invariably centered on the suffocatingly decadent. It is an image borne of such films as The Damned, a luridly Wagnerian indictment of Nazi Germany made in 1969 and the 1971 Death in Venice, an overwrought yet visually beautiful verson of the Thomas Mann novella in which the dramas of repressed homosexuality supersede the subtler implications of the book.

title: Teacher Burnout A Growing Hazard
description: AFTER 10 years of teaching in a Westchester County school, Mary P. wants to quit. Depressed, exhausted, bored, she suffers from a debilitating disease  teacher burnout. And, like her, thou- sands of teachers across the country will be stricken this school year. They will either leave the profession after years of training and dedication, or remain in the classroom immobilized by inertia, no longer caring.

title: Laura Antonelli Is Star Of 'Wifemistress' Film:The Cast
description: If "Wifemistress," which opens today at the Little Carnegie, is going to be popular, which I think may be the case, then let's hope it's a hit for the right reasons. The guiding force behind this movie is what might be called Frederick's of Hollywood Feminism, and it allows for scenes like the one in which spectacularly buxom Laura Antonelli, clad in a filmy negligee that has just about fallen off, picks up a pamphlet entitled "The Emancipation of Women" and knots her pretty brow, as if she were thinking. Maybe she is. Maybe you will be, too. Neither one of you will be thinking about the emancipation of women, that's for sure.It's too bad movies like this, or last year's "Dona Flor and Her Two Husbands," bother to masquerade as anything other than the soft-core porn they essentially are (although each of them is something of a travelogue, too). "Wifemistress" sustains an elaborate plot, and every now and then a political point rears its gratuitous head. But every situation boils down to somebody's making eyes at Miss Antonelli. And the only elements of suspense involve the matters of when (midway through the story), whether (of course) and how graphically (not very) she will begin to make eyes back.As the film begins, Miss Antonelli is a turn-of-the-century Italian heiress confined to her doll-filled bedroom while her husband, played by Marcello Mastroianni, goes philandering all over the very scenic countryside. The wife, called Antonia, is lonely and neglected, her only companion a buxom young woman who parades around in a boyish haircut and a fetching camisole. For reasons that are not explained but have a certain steamy logic of their own, this young woman secretly fools around with Antonia's husband and also sleeps peaceably in Antonia's bed.But then the husband has to go into hiding, because he is wrongly suspected of murder, and by the same steamy logic he finds a room that looks directly into Antonia's bedroom. Antonia is not in her bedroom, at least not for a while  being liberated from her husband's oppressive ways has restored her health, and sent her off to run his business and find out about his hobbies. He was a wine dealer, so Antonia must visit inns and drink. He was a rake, so Antonia must visit bordellos and find out what he did there. In the interests of accuracy, she must even do a bit of it herself.But he also wrote political pamphlets, and that's what's supposed to make this a movie with a message. Antonia does, after all, begin running her husband's business. She does discover that her husband wrote tracts about women's suffrage and atheism, even if their contents are never discussed. She does meet other liberated women, even if they do make passes at her. She does eventually become what her husband calls "a complete woman," even if the term seems to pertain exclusively to her frigidity and the curing of same.Is there any point to this kind of pretension? Well, it may attract an audience that feels more comfortable with monkey business if it's disguised as serious business. But all this prurient dissembling has a way of getting on one's nerves, as do the movie's numbingly repetitive string score and its stubborn refusal to come to a prompt conclusion.Watching Miss Antonelli run through her coy paces is by no means uninteresting. But watching Mr. Mastroianni is surprisingly unrewarding, because he spends virtually all of the movie cooped up in an attic room, looking sad. Occasionally, Mr. Mastroianni peers out his window into Miss Antonelli's window and glimpses something that makes him genuinely distressed. The director, Marco Vicario, is aptly named.

title: A Renaissance Puts The 92d Street Y on The Musical Map Again
description: Eight month niter becoming education di rt.mor of the 92d St. YM- YWHA in 1973, Omus Hirshhein presented a benefit recital by Alicia de Larrocha in the Y's Kaufmann Con- cert Hall in Order to raise money tor tuture cultural events. Invitations were mailed to 7,000 people. Eight orders came back. Though a lastditch advertising campaign helped avert disaster, 100 seats stayed empty in the 850seat hall.

title: The Region
description: Since early last year, when she seems to have rehabilitated herself with the voters by appearing decisive during a snowstorm, Gov. Ella T. Grasso has been flying as high politically as one of the state helicopters she's taken to using. Mrs. Grasso, who was sworn in last week for another term, is in the enviable position of presiding over a state whose budget, for the third straight year, is running in the black. In a speech to the General Assembly, she said her priorities would include fending off new taxes (which, due to a new school financing plan a court has required the state to produce, could be a difficult matter) and otherwise exercising the fiscal austerity she said the voices of November had told her they wanted.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: PEOPLE move from the city to the suburbs for various reasons. Some want a bit of land and the space of a house, some even like mowing lawns and some want more trees around them than there are in a city block.

title: Wilderness Proposals Last Week Pleased Neither Environmentalists Nor Timber Cutters
description: DENVER  In the Old West, before bureaucrats took resolving what are now called multiple use conflicts, folks used to just up and have land wars. When the sheepmen fell afoul of the cattlemen, when the sodbusters tangled with the cowboys, the lead would fly until the difference opinion had been settled. Nowadays, one side fires off a public relations campaign, the other replies with a barrage lawsuits and both sides try to stampede the bureaucrats.

title: India Pursues the Largest, Noblest Experiment Ever
description: New Delhi  The bands in New Delhi's night clubs were playing Guy Lombardo sounds as usual at the stroke of midnight last Sunday, but the toasts were in coffee or soda pop with, at best, a bit of booze sneaked in under the table  as this capital city celebrated its driest New Year's Eve in memory. Because it was an officiallydesignated dry day, no liquor or beer was for sale anywhere in New Delhi. The new Government attitude was expressed by the official who explained, a bit primly, that revellers who feel the need of alcohol can take a drink at home before they go out.

title: A Delightful Absurd Person Singular in Stamford
description: IWOULD like to begin this review with a question I don't plan to answer. Is regional theater- intended to serve the same purpose as summer stock or a Shubert Theater outside of New York City  that is, is it sup- posed to offer the public a chance to see the recent Broadway hits it might have missed? I ask this because of the Hartman's current production of Absurd Person Singular, which closed its Broadway run only three years ago.

title: Louise Boone Will Be Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Rowan Boone of Princeton, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Louise Mabee Boone, to Edward Morton Read, son of James M. Read Jr. of New York and the late Mrs. Henrietta Read. A June wedding is planned.

title: SIHANOUK IN PEKING ON WAY TO THE U.N.
description: PEKING, Jan. 6  Norodom Sihanouk, Cambodia's former ruler, arrived here today and China's Government press agency announced that he was on his way to New York to present Cambodia's case against Vietnam to the United Nations Security Council.

title: The Ins and Outs of Balconies
description: Richard Walker, a broker with Douglas EllimanGibbons & Ives, was showing a client a, topfloor apartment on Fifth Avenue when they glanced out of the window at some terraces across the street.

title: This Week in Sports
description: Coach Kevin Loughery will come back from his threegame suspension by leading the New Jersey Nets against Phoenix tonight .and against Chicago Wednesday at Piscataway. They play at home again Friday, taking advantage of the Knicks Western trip. After facing Los Angeles Madison Square Garden on Tuesday, the Knicks head for a Friday contest against Denver.

title: Some Colleges Are Bobbing Up Everywhere
description: THE nation's colleges and universities are traveling across the country establishing offcampus centers in the manner of an academic McDonald's setting up hamburger franchises. Pepperdine

title: WASHINGTON The Dreams Of January
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5  At the beginning of the New Year, there's a feeling that Washington's dreams about human rights, arms control with Russia, reconciliation with China, mace in the Middle East and all that  are running ahead of its means. But for some time in American history the month of January seems to have been a time for yearning and dreaming.

title: 53 Editors Chosen for Pulitzer Prize Advisory Jury
description: The jurors, who will meet in March to begin judging, submit from three to five nominations in each of 12 categories to the Pulitzer Prize board, which may accept or reject these reports in making its prize recommendations to Columbia, which administers the awards established by Joseph Pulitzer.

title: New Iran Cabinet Unable to Bring in Main Opposition
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 6 - The makeup of the Cabinet announced today by Prime Minister Shahpur Bakhtiar showed that he had failed to win the alle- giance of the leaders of the main religious and secular opposition groups, but it in- eluded technocrats of proven administra- tive ability.

title: SMUGGLING OF DRUGS DESCRIBED AT TRIAL
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 6 - Allen Behan was 23 years old, living with his mother and in need of money to go back to school in the fall of 1977.

title: Making the Most Out of Lunch
description: It is widely recognized in the corporate world that a business lunch can provide a rewarding opportunity for chairman or president to assess a highlevel candidate for his organization.

title: The Crash 50 Years Later
description: Few years in recent memory have so served as shorthand for a major historic event as the year 1929. After 50 years, the stock market crash of Oct. 29, 1929, haunts the world as possibly the greatest economic catastrophe of the 20th Century.

title: U.S. and Russia and China
description: An American Ambassador's Unique Perspective on EastWest Issues. By Jacob D. Beam. 317 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Co. $10.95.

title: The Women at Cyanamid
description: An American Cyanamid plant in west Virginia last year began excluding women workers of childbearing age from areas with lead concentrations high enough to harm a fetus. Five women had themselves sterilized in the belief that otherwise they would have been transferred to lowerpaying jobs, or even dismissed. They claim they were pressured into having the operations. The company claims it tried to discourage sterilization and declares itself mystified as to why the women would take such drastic action to avoid transfer. Similar cases have been reported in other companies, and more such cases are apt to arise as women gain access to hazardous jobs.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: IN most cases when a toilet flushes sluggishly and does not seem to carry waste away as efficiently as it should, the first thing the home handyman or handywoman will suspect is a clogged or partly blocked drain. However. if, after probing with drain auger and vigorous working with a plumber's force cup, the drain seems to show no signs of a slug or obstruction and the toilet still does not flush as forcefully as it should, then chances are that the problem is because of slow or inadequate flow of water into the bowl during the flushing cycle.

title: Barbara Ann Foley Wed to Jay Durepo
description: Barbara Ann Foley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Foley of New York, was married yesterday to Jay Scott Durepo, son of Mrs. Robert F. Durepo of Avon, Conn., and the late Mr. Durepo. The ceremony was performed in Christ Church, Methodist, by the Rev. Dr. F. Roderick Dail.

title: . . .But Pity the Poor Ph.D.
description: LANDING a job in New York City these days is difficult under the best of circumstances  and practically impossible if you hold a Ph.d. As one who recently went the rounds of likely employers of a Doctor of English, I discovered that those three letters, once the prized peacock of academia, have been transmuted into an albatross around the neck.

title: Sunshine Is Helping Florida Bargaining
description: MIAMI FOUR years ago, Florida paso.d a sunshine law requiring that publicschool collective bar2aining take place in public.

title: Thomas Bewick: The Nonpareil of English Wood Engravers
description: 1828) was to illustration in general and wood engraving in particular what Constable was to painting, in that he declassicized nature, making it supple and alive. Older than both Constable and Wordsworth by about 20 years, the artist was a near contemporary of Blake's and may with him be regarded as a herald of the Romantic movement.

title: Speakers, Audiences And a Matchmaker
description: For what speakers? Well, for one, former President Gerald Ford. And Henry Kissinger, Ronald Reagan, Mike Wallace, David Brinkley, Yitzhak Rabin, John Lindsay, Jacob Javits, F. Lee Bailey, Arthur Burns, Frank Gifford, Truman Capote and Archbishop Fulton Sheen.

title: It's Getting Tougher For a Loan Defaulter
description: WASHINGTON FOR the first time since the Federal Government began to offer generous loa s to college students for their studies only to get taken as a .soft touch by many  Washington seems to he getting on top of the default problem.

title: Yankee Ingenuity and Economic Growth
description: WITH the Jan. 1 establishment of Connecticut's new Department of Economic Development, it would be wise to ponder appropriate and achievable objectives for this new agency. Connecticut, through the Department of Commerce and its predecessors, has been down this road before, as have neighboring states. Usually, such economic development agencies are introduced in the expectation that, merely be establishing them, new jobs wil suddenly appear. Only rarely have such departments been given the programs and the money and rarely have they had the imagination  to affect economic trends or job creation in any significant way. Established and then forgotten, economic development agencies usualy concentrate on promoting the virtues and beauties of their states and on raiding other states for corporate headquarters.

title: Wallace, at the Last, Tries to Erase Unfair Verdict
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Jan. 6 -- In surprising Conclusion to a political career built on the promise of segregation forever, Gov. George C. Wallace is devoting his final days in office to an attempt to prevent history from recording the very unfair judgment that he is an enemy of black people.

description: WASHINGTON AFTER decades of steady and substantial growth, Westchester has had a population loss since 1970 that is the third largest of any county in the state outside of New York City.

description: MIAMI  After two years of less hostile relations, the United States and Cuba have their backs up again, with each side under considerable, pressure not to make concessions. Pride and global strategy are the glue holding both to the flypaper of impasse.

title: Questions/Answers
description: As a youngster, I used to grow sweet potatoes indoors and they flourished into handsome vines. I have tried to show my 6 yearold how to grow them, too, and we are not having any luck. Any clues? L.O.M Bayside, N.Y.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: 20TH CENTURY JOURNEY, by William L. Shirer. (Pocket/Wallaby, $6.95.) The memoirs of a boy from a small town in Iowa who became famous as a foreign correspondent and contemporary historian (The Rise and Fall of the Third Reich). This volume ends in 1930, when he's 26 and covering Europe for The Chicago Tribune. He tells a great number of entertaining and tragic stories, Malcolm Cowley observed these pages; mostly, they are about other people.

description: Scientific acoustical evidence establishes a high probability that two gunmen fired at President John F. Kennedy. . . . [He] was probably assassinated as a result of a conspiracy.

title: WESTCHESTER HOUSING
description: NOW that the ceiling on mortgage rates has been raised, Westchester banks still have two complaints: The new 9.5 percent ceiling is still too low, and there is not enough money in savings accounts to !end out on mortgages.

title: Disabled Worker Held In Nashville Dam Blast
description: NASHVILLE, Jan. 6 (UPI) - A disabled construction worker was charged today with the bombing of the huge J. Percy Priest Dam in an attempt to flood downtown Nashville and pave the way for the looting of business places.

description: ARMONK
