title: Rams Defeated After Scoreless First Half, 280
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan 7  The Dallas Cowboys completed the matchup for the Super Bowl today when they scored four touchdowns in the second half and again denied the Los Angeles Rams a spot in pro football's ultimate contest. The Cowboy victory, by a score of 280, paired Dallas against the Pittsburgh Steelers two weeks from today.

title: De Gustibus
description: Only a few short months ago I was convinced that the final word had been offered about the origin of the hot dog in America. And now comes a note from our everfaithful wordsource man from Lancaster, Pa., Henry E. Funk.

title: Legal Gambling Acquires Status as Revenues Rise
description: The business of legalized gambling in the metropolitan region has overcome questions concerning its morality, intimations that it is a tool of criminals and arguments that it is supported by those least able to afford it. In growing into $5billionayear business, it has become a necessary source of revenue for state governments, providing more than a halfbillion dollars yearly to the budgets of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: CAMBODIA'S REGIME REPORTED IN FLIGHT
description: PEKING, Monday, Jan. 8  The embattled Cambodian regime is evacuating large numbers of Cambodians from the eastern part of the country in the face of Vietnam's invasion, according to people who arrived from Phnom Penh Saturday by plane. The Government's aim, the sources said, is to leave the Vietnamese facing a vast empty space.

title: 631 Cultists' Bodies Wait in Delaware Base Hangar
description: DOVER, Del., Jan. 7 (AP)  More than six weeks after the mass deaths at the Guyana commune of the People's Temple, the bodies of 631 victims remain stacked in a freezing airplane hangar at the Dover Air Force Base, and the Federal Government has no plans to move them.

title: Concert: American Symphony
description: EVEN if one agrees with Barnum about the necessity of having a gimmick, the American Symphony Orchestra was decidedly stretching a point by entitling its program in Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon Homage to Nationalism. Not only was this a rather flimsy disguise for three overworked warhorses, but two of the pieces could even be argued to represent examples of their respective composers more international styles.

title: Political Cabaret, Even Censored, Is a Place Where Poles Can Laugh
description: CRACOW, Poland  The dollar is going down, down, down everywhere, the master of ceremonies shouted in the packed cabaret. He paused for effect, then added, because in Poland its value is going up.

title: Selling the Home, Not the Land
description: A builder in Connecticut has achieved a striking sales success at a woodsy development of imaginatively designed homes built on land that was leased, rather than sold, to middleincome home buyers.

title: Black Leaders Eye Candidates For Rizzo Post
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 7  Leaders of black voters in Philadelphia, whose numbers increased by 33 percent last November to crush Mayor Frank L. Rizzo's effort to change the city charter to permit a third term, are listening with caution to promises from men who want to succeed the Mayor.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Partial list of scheduled meetings for week follows:

title: Hartford Skywallk Plan Stirs Dissent
description: HARTFORD, Jan. 7  City business interests are fighting with neighborhood groups here over a plan to build a $6 million system of overhead pedestrian walkways linking eight downtown buildings. If these are successful, more are planned.

title: A Modern Soviet Woman Emerges From the Islamic Veil
description: ASHKHABAD, U.S.S.R.  The veil gone, and the mask of silence imposed, for centuries on the women of Central Asia has disappeared. A demand for a dowry is now a crime, punishable by up to three years in prison, and the universities are populated with a new breed of woman seeking a professional life beyond the reach of the ancient Islamic traditions of inequality.

title: The Wrong Hole, Inevitably
description: LOS ANGELES SOME things in the National Football League are inevitable  one, that the Dallas Cowboys will go to the Super Bowl almost every year and two, that the Los Angeles Rams will not. Yesterday, for the fourth time in the last five postseason tournaments, the Rams lost the National Conference championship game  this time by 280. Not that one play ever loses any football game but if the Rams had one play to do over again they would revert to the situation late in the third quarter when they had a fourthandone situation (one foot, actually) at the Cowboys' 14yard line. At the time the Rams were trailing, 70, and if they could go in for a touchdown, it would be anybody's game. Anybody's trip to the Super Bowl, too. From the sideline Ray Malavasi, the Ram coach, sent in the play known as 34 lead  a handoff to Jim Jodat who would follow Doug France, the huge left tackle on the Rams' offensive unit.

title: Oilers Routed As Rain Mars 345 Game
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 7  The Houston Oilers, their long dormant Super Bowl dreams buoyed by two playoff victories on the road, had their trip to Miami washed away in a deep cold sea of rain and a powerful, overwhelming performance by Pittsburgh that brought the Steelers a 345 victory in today's American Football Conference championship game.

title: Travelers Bid Approved
description: Shareholders of Keystone Custodian Funds, manager of a variety of mutual funds, have approved the acquisition of their company by the Travelers Corporation, a multipleline insurance company. Travelers will pay $18 a share in stock, or a total of $20.4 million, for all Keystone Custodian Funds common stock.

title: Strike in Iran Halts $2 Billion in Imports
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 7  More than $2 billion worth of imported goods have piled up at Iran's borders, halted by a customs strike.

title: Books of The Times
description: WHEN Al and Birdy were kids  strange best friends near Philadelphia in the 1930's  Birdy's bike was stolen. He got it back, with no more damage than a few bent spokes, some scratches on the handlebars and a front wheel that needed straightening. According to Al:

title: Chess:
description: Emanuel Lasker, world champion from 1894 to 1921, wrote in his Manual of Chess: On the chess board, lies and hypocrisy do not survive long. The creative combination lays bare the presumption of a lie; the merciless fact, culminating in a checkmate, contradicts the hypocrite.

title: The Silvering, As It Were, of Television
description: The central principle of television has been: Don't tell the viewers, show them. So the things they have wanted to see least of on their screens have been what they dismissiveiy call talking heads. And they have regarded programs which were nothing but talk as not television  they'd be just as good on sound radio.

title: Marian Osterweis Married to Judd Kessler
description: Marian Osterweis, an assistant professor in the department of community and family medicine at the Georgetown University School of Medicine, was married yesterday to Judd Kessler, an assistant general counsel for Latin America and the Caribbean with the Agency for International Development.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: GOING OUT Guide

title: The Editorial Notebook
description: European visitors to these shores, from Alexis de Tocqueville to Gunnar Myrdal, have instructed us shrewdly on the vagaries of our national life. Now Eugene lonesco, the Rumanianborn French playwright, back in Paris after a trip here, has made his contribution to a valuable tradition. Writing in Le Figaro, Mr. lonesco reported that wherever he went he encountered antiAmerican Americans, who were never happier than when they were blaming themselves for all that is wrong in the world. The playwright, known for his sense of the absurd, concluded that to be appreciated in this country, one must, above all, never say that Americans are not the worst criminals of humanity.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Pierre Cardin, the internationally known fashion designer, said in Paris that the Chinese Government had named him as a consultant to its textiletrade agency. Under the agreement with Peking, Mr. Cardin will advise the Chinese on how to style their textile products to make them more marketable in the West.

title: The Hammer-and-Sickle, and Star of David
description: The situation of the Russian Jews is very ambiguous, because they constitute the only minority in the Soviet Union to have no territory of its own.

title: Swimming: U.S. Wins 3 Races
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 7  The United States swim team averted a shutout tonight at the Women's International Cup by winning three of the seven events on the final night at Harvard University's Blodgett Pool. The East Germans, who also won three races tonight, dominated the twoday meet by taking seven of the 14 events.

title: Sheriff's Officer Is Slain in Hospital
description: A sheriff's officer in New Jersey was killed with his own pistol early yesterday by a wounded prisoner he was guarding in a hospital ward, according to the police. The prisoner escaped, but was recaptured.

title: Oilers and Water Don't Mix
description: PITTSBURGH DURING World War II when the Steelers were one of the most softbitten teams in the National Football League, their best running back was an intelligent character named John Grigas. On the 10th and last Sunday of the 1944 season the team had lost nine games and was going for No. 10 against the Chicago Bears, but Grigas needed only 46 yards to lead the league in rushing. At 5 A.M. he was out inspecting the playing surface of Forbes Field, the old baseball park that the Steelers used. Duquesne and Pitt had played there Saturday, leaving a morass that had frozen overnight. Leaving a note for his roommate, Grigas walked out of football then and there, never to be seen in pads again. His note read:

title: Grand Magic at Theater Club
description: CALDERON did it better. Life was a dream to his Prince Sigismund, immured in a tower from infancy, freed briefly and shut up once again.

title: TV: In Amateur Night, The Cast Is Professional
description: AMONG show business people the phrase amateur night in Dixie has for years been used to express an absolute degree of derogation. How appropriate that Amateur Night at the Dixie Bar and Grill was chosen as the title for a production that really hits bottom. This madefortelevision film will be seen from 9 to 11 o'clock tonight on NBCTV.

title: Commodities
description: THE silver futures market last year proved to be an exercise in frustration for the bulls and an expensive experience for those on the short side of the market. While silver prices in 1978 rose 27 percent to $6.07 an ounce, the bulls saw platinum soar 93 percent to $350 and gold advance roughly 90 percent to $226 an ounce.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: The credit markets flickered with encouragement last week as the dollar fared fairly well in foreign exchange trading and moneysupply growth slowed, but this newyear optimism evaporated last Friday and interest rates seemed headed higher once again.

title: Events
description: METROPOLITAN OPERA. Lincoln Center, Strauss's Elektra, 8.

title: United Names 7 to Carrier's Board
description: The United Technologies Corpora. tion announced over the weekend that it had named seven of its directors to the board of the Carrier Corporation, despite renewed Federal antitrust action and the opposition of Carrier's management.

title: A Big Meal on Campus Is Little Cafe's Success
description: ITHACA, N.Y.  Julie Jordan's childhood daydreams usually cast her as the leading force of a lively literary salon. Her adult reality finds her directing pot scrubbing, floor mopping and the kneading of gigantic batches of homemade wholegrain bread. But as owner  and central figure  of the popular Cabbagetown Cafe just outside the gates of Cornell University, Miss Jordan is, after a fashion. fulfilling those childhood wishes.

title: News Summary
description: MONDAY, JANUARY 8, 1979

title: Washington Watch
description: WASHINGTON PROPOSED standards for new buildings are coming from the Energy Department in February, and, if all goes as planned, they could save thousands of barrels of oil within a few years. Ironically, the standards are virtually unrelated to the National Energy Plan, passed late last year after an 18month legislative battle.

title: Notes on People
description: Arkady Shevchenko, the Soviet career diplomat who defected last April while serving as an Undersecretary General at the United Nations, was secretly married about two weeks ago, sources in Washington said yesterday. Mr. Shevchenko, who was believed to be abroad, could not be reached for comment. But the sources identified his wife as an American, and said they had been engaged for some time.

title: CanadianChinese Trade Talks
description: PEKING, Jan. 7 (Reuters)  Canada's Trade Minister, John N. Horner, arrived here tonight with a highlevel delegation of businessmen for talks with Chinese officials on expanding trade and economic cooperation. Mr. Horner will meet tomorrow morning with Foreign Trade Minister Li Chiang in the Great Hall of the People.

title: Drawn Slowly Into the Indochina Maelstrom, Cambodia Has Sunk in a Decade of Agony
description: Until a decade ago, Cambodia was a country on the fringe of warfare in Indochina. It was a nation troubled by economic problems, political corruption and internal dissent, but clinging to a shaky neutrality and the traditions of a gentle, artistic and reserved people who hoped against hope that the tragedy unfolding in Vietnam would bypass them.

title: Judge Is Expected to Rule in Suit Against Striking Steel Haulers
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 7 (AP)  A decision is expected tomorrow in a suit by seven steel companies contending that a steel haulers' strike is in violation of an injunction issued in 1970. But the strike, which has been blamed for sporadic violence against working truckers, is not likely to be immediately affected.

title: ESSAY
description: WASHINGTON  The investigation of Bert Lance is virtually concluded. A fiveman team of Justice Department prosecutors, which has been presenting evidence to an Atlanta grand jury, is finishing its prosecution memo.

title: Angling in the Dead of Winter
description: WITH snow swirling about the eaves, many anglers dream of stalking bonefish, tarpon and permit on the vast, shimmering flats of the Florida Keys. But such hegiras are not always possible, which generally leaves the Northern angler with only one alternative to being housebound: ice fishing.

title: Radio
description: 69 A.M., WKCR. Piano Sonatas, Soler; Endimione a Ciatia, Scarlatti.

title: New York's 1.3 Inches Of Snow Turns Slushy But Cold Wave Is Due
description: New York City's second significant snowstorm of the year proved to be an overnight wonder yesterday as warming temperatures changed the snow to rain by midmorning and melted much of the 1.3 inches of snow that had fallen during the night, leaving slippery streets and a sea of slush.

title: Sacrifice Marks Efforts to Give To the Neediest
description: Carol Goodman of the Riverdale section of the Bronx sent $15 to the 67th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, explaining that her donation came from money she earned in a parttime job during her senior year at Hunter College High School.

title: LONDON'S HESS VOID IS LARGELY UNFILLED
description: LONDON, Jan. 7  As the suspension of The Times and The Sunday Times ends its sixth week with no sign of their return, the void the two papers have left in ferociously competitive but striferidden Fleet Street remains largely unfilled.

title: Refinery Workers Union Declines To Call Strike as Deadline Passes
description: DENVER, Monday, Jan. 8  The Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers Union allowed a Sunday midnight contract expiration date to pass without accepting any industry offers but declined to call a strike immediately.

title: Pianist: Marra Marlowe
description: MARYA MARLOWE, a young pianist with a master's degree from the University of Arizona and a list of teachers that includes Lili Kraus, gave her New York recital debut Saturday night at Carnegie Recital HalL Miss Marlowe otnnously cares deeply about the music she plays, and is vividly aware of its expressive possibilities. Her vitality and spontaneity, however, were overshadowed by wrong notes and restless interpretive tendencies.

title: Rock: XTC, an English Group
description: XTC is an English newwave rock quartet that ended a threenight run at CBGB's Saturday. The group would seem to have a lot going for it  talent, a diverse style, stage personality, recordcompany support. And indeed, its lateshow set had its real charms. But something seemed to be missing, and that something keeps one from including XTC among the very finest newwave bands.

title: Regrets About Kent State
description: Almost nine years after National Guardsmen killed four students and injured nine more during antiwar demonstrations at Kent State University, the State of Ohio has agreed in an outofcourt settlement to pay $675,000 to the families of the victims. After unconscionable delays, the books are finally being closed on the disputes that arose from the events of May 4,1970 events that came to symbolize the domestic tragedy of America's involvement in Vietnam and Cambodia.

title: Lack of Ranking Rankles Temple
description: After seven weeks of the basketball season the list of unbeaten major colleges has dwindled to five teams. Four of them  Louisiana State, Illinois, Arkansas and Indiana State  are ranked among the nation's top 20. Temple is the other, and is awaiting recognition.

title: Britain and Brunei Sign Accord on Independence
description: BANDAR SERI BEGAWAN, Brunei, Jan. 7 (Reuters)  Britain and Brunei signed a formal agreement today that will make the tiny oilproducing Asian sultanate independent in five years.

title: Decision Nearer On Unit to Build 20 Power Plants
description: After nearly five years of planning, hearings and litigation, New York State's Public Service Commission is approaching a decision on whether to approve a controversial new power consortium that would build and operate up to 20 new electric generating plants costing an estimated total of $43 billion by 1998.

title: Violin and Voice Recital Offered by Boatwrights
description: HELEN AND HOWARD Boatwright are a husbandandwife team of long and respectable standing. Mrs. Boatwright is a soprano who has appeared many times on New York concert stages. Mr. Boatwright is a composer and violinist who once headed the school of music at Syracuse University. Saturday after loon at Carnegie Recital Hall they offered an engagingly delivered program of music worth hearing.

title: Jack Paul Marash, 67, Director Of Rights Panel in White Plains
description: Jack Paul Marash, executive director of the White Plains Human Rights Commission, died Saturday at his home, 21 Salem Place, White Plains. He was 67 years old.

title: Heat Forces Player From Cricket Test
description: SYDNEY, Jan. 7 (Reuters)  England's bowlers, hampered by the absence of Bob Willis, who had to leave the field with heat exhaustion, kept Australia down to a firstinnings lead of 96 at close of play here today on the second day of the fourth test.

title: Bitter Cold Assails West Slope of Rockies
description: BOISE, Idaho, Jan. 7  Temperatures as low as 53 degrees below zero have turned fire pumper trucks to giant wheeled ice cubes in West Yellowstone, Mont., and created ice dams on several Western rivers. Meanwhile, there were rain, snow, freezing rain and bitter cold in much of the eastern twothirds of the nation.

title: Brooklyn Wins Fifth
description: Alex Lloyd scored 32 points to lead Brooklyn College to a 9783 City University Conference basketball victory over Hunter College yesterday. Lloyd made 16 of 23 shots from the field and added 12 rebounds to lead Brooklyn to its fifth victory against seven losses.

title: Cabinet Aide Named CBS News Vice President
description: Roger D. Colloff, who since October 1977 has been special assistant to James R. Schlesinger, the Secretary of Energy, is joining CBS News as assistant to Bill Leonard, presidentdesignate of the division.

title: Tennis: Miss Austin Wins
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (UPI) Tracy Austin used her patient baseline game to upset topseeded Martina Navratilova, 63, 62, today and capture the $24,000 first prize in the $125,000 Washington stop of the women's professional tennis tour.

title: Soccer: Pesa First Choice in Draft?
description: ORLANDO. Fla., Jan. 7  By consensus of the coaches, the best college soccer player in the country is a junior college student who lives in Elmhurst, Queens.

title: ABROAD AT HOME
description: BOSTON, Jan. 7  Will General Alexander M. Haig be marching through the snows of New Hampshire a year from now? His abrupt announcement that he will resign in June as Commander of NATO forces in Europe certainly strengthens the impression that he has his eye on the White House.

title: New Rule Brings a Crisis To Men's Tennis Tour
description: WITH the future of men's professional tennis in the balance, top players, their agents and officials of the sport will hold meetings in New York this week in an attempt to resolve severe differences over the 1979 Grand Prix circuit.

title: Coop City: Paradise or Paradise Lost?
description: From a distance, sitting next to 83 acres of what is euphemistically called landfill, Coop City looks like a stark, futuristic, postwar world in which grace and beauty were first destroyed and then forgotten. It seems a completely utilitarian landscape  highrise cellblocks sheltering a city of more than 60,000 people a model of efficiency rising from the midst of rubble.

title: Blast Wrecks Tanker Unloading in Ireland; 47 Are Feared Killed
description: BANTRY, Ireland, Monday, Jan 8 (Reuters)  An explosion tore apart a 31,000ton French tanker as it was unloading its cargo at the oil terminal here early today, and the police said 42 crewmen and 5 dockworkers were feared dead.

title: Moscow Hails Vietnam's Liberation of Phnom Penh
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 7  The liberation of Phnom Penh, as Soviet press reports from Hanoi called it tonight, appears to have come more quickly than Moscow thought it would, although a commentary issued here indicates that it has the support of the Kremlin.

title: More Childless Wives Conceive Through Use of Frozen Sperm
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 7  Increasing numbers of infertile couples are choosing to have children who are artificially conceived with sperm that has been frozen and thawed, a process that may reduce the chances of miscarriage and birth defects.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: American Bankers Life Assurance Company of Florida announced the resignation of John P. Walsh as president and chief operating officer. R. Kirk Landon, chairman and chief executive officer of the company, will assume the additional post of president.

title: Fighting Likely to Continue, But as Irregular Resistance
description: The capture of Phnom Penh is unlikely to end resistance to the Vietnamesesupported insurgents who drove the Government from the city.

title: HANOI REPORTS CAMBODIAN CAPITAL CONQUERED BY INSURGENT FORCES; LONG GUERRILLA CONFLICT FEARED
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 7  The Cambodian capital, Phnom Penh, was captured today, Vietnam and the insurgent front it is backing in Cambodia announced tonight.

title: Mrs. Kreps Sees 22% Growth
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP)  Commerce Secretary Juanita M. Kreps said today that national economic growth would be sluggish and that unemployment would rise in 1979, but that there would be no recession.

title: The City
description: Detectives yesterday found the medallion taxicab whose driver was found shot and killed on the West Side Saturday morning after an apparent robbery. But they have no other clues in the case.

title: A Doctor Examines the Myths and the Facts of Fitness
description: SPORTS enthusiasts, both amateur and professional, are probably more susceptible than any other group, with the possible exception of dieters, to anecdotal advice, undocumented dogma and downright quackery. Seeking to improve their performance or simply test their mettle, they fall prey to wellintentioned but often totally unscientific advice about how and when to eat, dress. train, sleep and even indulge in sexual intercourse.

title: Fire Dept. Expands Experiment on VoiceOnly Calls to Cut False Alarms
description: The New York City Fire Department announced yesterday that it would expand its successful monthlong experiment aimed at reducing false alarms by responding only to those voiceoperated fire alarm boxes where there are spoken requests for help.

title: Canadian Rate Increases Draw Political Criticism
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 7  The Bank of Canada's decision to raise its discount rate for the seventh time since the beginning of last year has drawn fire from the Government's political opponents, who charge that such interestrate increases have a depressing effect on an alreadydepressed economy.

title: McEnroe, Fleming Win Doubles
description: LONDON, Jan. 7 (UPI)  John McEnroe and Peter Fleming, the young lions of American tennis, rallied today to defeat Ilie Nastase and Sherwood Stewart in four sets to capture the $200,000 world doubles championship in their first attempt.

title: Practicing the Politics of Less
description: No one really knows how to manage the politics of less, but it appears to us that New York's Mayor Koch has made a sly, perhaps even a shrewd beginning. Responding to an order from the Financial Control Board, the Mayor has published his administration's tentative suggestions for cutting the city's 1980 expense budget.

title: Japanese Concern to Supply Tools To U.S. Steel's Mine Project in China
description: TOKYO, Jan. 7 (AP)  Okura and Company said yesterday that it would supply the U.S. Steel Corporation with machinery and equipment for use in a $1 billionplus plan to develop iron ore resources in China, a plan that was confirmed on Friday by steel company sources in Peking.

title: Miss Krupsak Offended By Cuomo's Complaints
description: ALBANY, Jan. 7  Just back from her Virgin Islands vacation, former Lieut. Gov. Mary Anne Krupsak says she is astonished at the implications of profligacy on her part in reports by her successor that she had left only

title: Susan Wilson Wed To Michael Gilbert
description: Susan Klein Wilson of Livingston, N.J., and Michael S. Gilbert of Hackettstown, N.J., were married yesterday at the Birchwood Manor in Whippany, N.J., by Rabbi Peter E. Kasdan.

title: The Show On the Sideline
description: OOO. . .kay, folks, welcome back  heeyyyy. We're going to run a little play now that's an old favorite of ours, and we hope it's one of yours too. It's called Sweep Wide Right, and it goes something like this. Take it, offense....

title: Aide Denies Council Was Enlisted in Mining Case
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7  An official of the President's Council of Economic Advisers complained today that it was false and unfair to say that the council had been enlisted by critics of environmental controls on strip mining to oppose and delay the imposition of the controversial new mining regulations by the Interior Department.

title: Jobe Triumphs In Biathlon
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Jan. 7 (AP) Glenn Jobe, of Kirkwood, Calif., a member of the United States biathlon team for the past three years, captured the 20kilometer biathlon here today to remain in the running for this year's national team.

title: TV: Ladies in Waiting, a Drama
description: THE Ladies in Waiting on tonight's publictelevision Visions series (Channel 13 at 10 o'clock) are a group of waitresses playing out their personal vignettes in the locker room of a restaurant. They are the chief inhabitants of an original play by Patricia Resnick, a 25yearold writer who, it is stressed, has had the experience of waiting on tables in three Florida restaurants.

title: Lotto, a Failure, Is Discontinued By Massachusetts State Lottery
description: BOSTON (AP)  The Massachusetts State Lottery Commission says that Lotto flopped, and the game has ended.

title: Affirmed Finishes Third in First '79 Start
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 7 (AP)  Affirmed, winner of the Triple Crown last year, finished third today in his first start as a 4-year-old. Little Reb led nearly all the way in scoring a 2length victory in the $65,200 Malibu Stakes before a crowd of 26,405 at Santa Anita.

title: Sporting Gear
description: Thermarest is the answer for hikers, climbers and the like who want a mattress they can carry easily and don't have to blow up. The pad  sold in two lengths, four feet and six feet  is constructed of opencell foam, is enclosed in an airmattress cover, weighs one and a half or two pounds and can be rolled into a very small bundle. When you unroll one and open the valve, the foam expands, sucking in air. Close the valve and lie down, and you have the comfort of thick foam. The waterproof cover traps warm air inside  you can regulate how much  and keeps out moisture. The prices are $32 (for the fourfoot pad) and $42 (for six feet). There is also a Thermarest cushion for stadium sitters, which costs $15. Order directly from Cascade Design, 568 First Avenue South, Seattle 98104, (206) 6234400.

title: Revolt Reported in Afghan Province
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan, Jan. 7 (Reuters)  Thousands of guerrillas, some armed only with old muskets, are converging on a strategic town in eastern Afghanistan in an effort to oust the proCommunist Government, Afghan dissidents said today.

title: PEKING DENOUNCES HANOI IN U.N. PAPER
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 7 The Chinese Government presented a statement to the Security Council today that condemned the invasion of Cambodia and accused Vietnam of towering crimes and of acting as a surrogate of the Soviet Union in its expansionist strategic plan.

title: Sports Today
description: N.Y. Tech at City College, 8 P.M.

title: ArtWork Thefts Seen Pointing to CrossCountry Gangs
description: The recent disappearances of a Rembrandt painting from a San Francisco museum and of three Cezanne works from a Chicago facility point up the dramatic increase in thefts of valuable art works from museums, galleries and private collections in the United States.

title: Survey Says World's Civil Liberties Have Increased
description: Political rights and civil liberties increased for 563 million people in 24 countries last year and decreased for 144 million people in 8 countries, according to the annual worldwide survey by Freedom House.

title: Advertising
description: PAUL W. ARDAJI, a 31yearold Jerusalemborn Arab, thinks big. He's determined to be running the biggest ad agency serving the Middle East within three years. And he'd very much like to be in charge of the agency that conducts the advertising and publicrelations campaign in the United States for the Arab image.

title: $8 Million in Cancer Grants
description: Grants totaling more than $8 million were announced yesterday by the American Cancer Society, The Associated Press reported. The society said the grants were part of an estimated $41 million it expected to allocate for research in 1979.

title: This Year, TV Officials Seem Secure
description: WINTER usually brings a chill to the executive suites of the television networks. It is a season for management shakeups, triggered most often by a network's poor competitive performance during the fall.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TOMORROW

title: Bond Activity Resuming
description: After a threeweek endoftheyear vacation, the credit markets will get back to work this week with a moderate schedule of new taxexempt and international bond issues. The corporate bond market will not face its first test in 1979 until next week, however.

title: SteelersOilers Set Records
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 7 (UPI) The following records were set or tied today in the Pittsburgh Steelers' 345 American Football Conference title victory over the Houston Oilers:

title: Thomson Retrospective
description: THE Virgil Thomson retrospective concert held Saturday night at Alice Tully Hall was a heartwarming occasion for several reasons.

title: Take Your Choice
description: Yellow and white perch, crappies and rock bass  no length or bag limits  are fair game all year round in New York State. The pickerel season closes March 15; the length limit is 15 inches, and the creel limit five daily. Black bass may not be taken in winter.

title: SCIENTISTS DISCUSS NEW CITY IN NIGERIA
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 7  Bigness is not necessarily bad if it serves a cultural, emotional or economic purpose, says one of the designers of the new capital city that Nigeria is preparing to build in a remote, rural area north of the humid lowlands of the Niger and Benue Rivers.

title: Carter Aide Says Koch Agreed To More City Budget Cuts Soon
description: President Carter's chief domestic policy adviser said today that Mayor Koch, in recent conversations with White House aides, had committed himself to a program of budgetary actions in the next several months to lessen the chances of much more drastic budget cutbacks for New York City in 1980 and later.

title: Track: Walker Runs 1,500 in 3:37.4
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Jan. 7 (AP) John Walker has proved he has overcome the leg malady that has plagued him in recent years.

title: Market Place
description: WALL STREET has had a lingering aversion to conglomerates ever since Litton Industries had a down quarter in the late 1960's, thus calling into the question the concept of continual growth through acquisition. In fact, thereafter, a group of analysts that followed the conglomerates fell on such bad times that the group was unable to assemble a quorum and had to dissolve.

title: Their Wedding
description: Weddings are back in fashion. Take it from David and Elizabeth Emanuel. They're not only married, they're building a reputation as designers of wedding dresses. One of their dresses, with a 12foot train, swept down the aisle at Westminster Abbey.

title: The Region
description: A hangar and three small planes were destroyed by a fire at the Westchester County Airport in Rye last night after an explosion at about 6:45 P.M.

title: Renewing the LawEnforcement Agency
description: HACKENSACK, N.J.  High on the, agenda for action during the new session of Congress is the proposed reauthorization and reorganization of the Law Enforcement Assistance Administration, the Federal agency responsible for Federal aid to state and local crimecontrol projects. The beleaguered agency does not lack for critics.

title: Karl Kuerner, at 80
description: CHADDS FORD, PA., Jan. 7 (UPI) Karl Kuerner, 80, a farmer who became a close friend and favorite model of the painter Andrew Wyeth, died in his sleep Saturday night at his home here.

title: Beauty Is Best In Spaniel Show
description: RYE, N.Y., Jan. 7  A red cocker spaniel bitch, Ch. Russ' Winter Beauty, owned by Larry and Norma Russ of Navarre, Ohio, was chosen tonight best of 722 spaniels at the American Spaniel Club's specialty in the Rye Town Hilton Inn. The event ushered in the 1979 dogshow season.

title: Skiing: Stenmark Wins Giant Slalom
description: COURCHEVEL, France, Jan. 7 (UPI)  lngemar Stenmark of Sweden won his fourth World Cup race of the season today  the 32d in his threeyear career  by the largest winning margin recorded in a World Cup men's giant slalom.

title: U.S. Calls for Vietnamese Pullback And Notes Fear of War Widening
description: WASHINGTON. Jan. 7  The United States called today for the speedy withdrawal of Vietnamese forces from Cambodia and the avoidance of direct Soviet and Chinese involvement in the conflict at all costs.

title: N.C.A.A. Committee Urges Football Playoff
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 6  Recognizing the demand for a major college football championship playoff, the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Extra Events Committee unanimously recommended today that the N.C.A.A. approve a fourteam playoff tournament involving teams to be selected from the major college bowl games.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: What is the New York Rangers' cumulative record, through last season, against the five other teams that were in the National Hockey League the year the Rangers joined?

title: In Soviet, Too, Quest for Beauty Leads to the Plastic Surgeon
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 7  On Park Avenue, the plastic surgeon's outer office would probably be adorned with house plants and contain glossy women's magazines. In Moscow, the way to Dr. Antonina Akhabadze's office is past plain wooden desks smothered with letters.

title: Stanley Frank, a Writer And Consultant, at 70
description: Stanley B. Frank, a freelance writer and creative consultant to Hill & Knowlton Inc., the publicrelations concern, died Saturday of a heart attack at his home in New York City. He was 70 years old.

title: Deaths
description: POLSKYArchie. Fitth Avenue Synagogue records with deep sorrow the death of our esteemed member. To his beloved wife, Ida, and to the entire family, we express our heartfelt sympathy.

title: 3 New York Agencies May Sue Comptroller. On Appointee Status
description: ALBANY, Jan. 8  Three state agencies are preparing to sue the State Comptroller to determine whether several new appointees to their boards are properly in office and legally able to do business. The appointees are among 68 under challenge by the Republicanled State Senate.

title: ClothesCrazy Katy Keene Comes Back
description: Annie may be wowing them on Broadway, Superman may be soaring toward high profits on the silver screen, Brenda Starr, Reporter may be heading for a television series. But

title: Memory Loss Curbed By Chemical In Foods
description: ASURPRISING variant of the proposition that you are what you eat is being explored as a promising strategy for dealing with some forms of memory ,impairment, which is among the most distressing, difficult and common afflictions of old age.

title: Dividends
description: MONDAY, JAN, 8, 1979

title: HighYield Certificates: Fewer Ads
description: Many financial institutions across the country have stopped the aggressive promotion of the new sixmonth savings certificates linked to the interest rates on Treasury bills as rates have escalated to record levels in excess of 10 percent.

title: More Tunnel, Less Light
description: WASHINGTON  Finally. it looked like a proverbial light at the end of the tunnel.

title: STATE MAY OVERSEE CLEVELAND FINANCES; Governor Is Considering Panel tc Manage Funds  Land Sale Voted, Averting Layoffs
description: CLEVELAND, Jan. 8  Gov. James A. Rhodes of Ohio, evidently worried that Cleveland's struggle against bankruptcy is not producing many results, is considering the formation of a financial management assistance panel for the city, inspired by New York City's Emergency Financial Control Board.

title: Theater: Hitting Town By Stephen Poliakoff
description: TWO plays by Stephen Pollakoff, the young British writer, were seen in New York last year: Strawberry Fields and City Sugar. Both were bleak accounts of the lives of workingclass youth, told in harsh and glittering style.

title: Spending on Senate Campaigns Averaged $900,000
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8  The Senate, historically described as the most exclusive gentlemen's club in the world, is also becoming the most expensive to join.

title: Civil Defense Limits Suggested by ExArms Negotiator
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8  Paul C. Warnke, former director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, said today that a civil defense race between the United States and the Soviet Union could upset the their strategic balance and suggested that both explore possible curbs on civil defense preparations as part of a future strategic arms limitation treaty.

title: A OneMillion Penny Deposit
description: Edwin Rommel of Cold Brook, N.Y., with coin bags that contain his one million pennies. The 200 bags held rolled coins that weighed more than three tons. Mr. Rommel made his $10,000 deposit at the Oneida National Bank in Utica yesterday, saying that he had begun to save the pennies 20 years ago.

title: Dinner to Honor Carter March 2
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Jan. 8 (UPI)  President Carter will be honored at a $1,000-a-plate fundraising dinner here on March 2. Lew R. Wasserman, board chairman and chief executive of MCA Inc., disclosed the dinner plans yesterday. He said that the money would help to prepare the Democrats for the 1980 campaigns.

title: Louisville 112, Marshall 64
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 8 (AP) Darrell Griffith hit a careerhigh 30 points tonight as Louisville trounced Marshall University, 11264.

title: Sara Carter Bayes, 80, a Pioneer Of Country and Western Singing
description: LODI, Calif., Jan. 8 (UPI)  Sara Cartet Bayes, the last of the singing Carter family that helped popularize country and western music, died early today of heart condition. She was 80 years old.

title: Kuwait Sets Price for Crude
description: KUWAIT, Jan. 8 (AP)  Kuwait informed its customers today that the price of its crude oil for the first quarter of the year would be $12.83 a barrel. The decision implements the resolution adopted by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries at Abu Dhabi last month.

title: Seton Hall 85, Lehigh 51
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Jan. 8 Led by Jay Boyle, Seton Hall University broke loose in the second half tonight to defeat Lehigh University, 8551, for its third straight victory and ninth in 13 games.

title: Resorts Chief Is Linked to Payoffs
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 8  A deputy attorney general said today that Resorts International should be denied a permanent casino license because it deliber- ately chose to associate itself with organized crime in its Bahamian operations. The company has a history, which still is manifest, the state official said, of acting to purge itself only after questionable associations had been publicized.

title: 50 Die in Tanker Blasts in Ireland
description: BANTRY, Ireland, Jan. 8 (AP)  Two explosions cut a French oil tanker in two today and threw crewmen into a sea of flaming oil. The police estimated that 50 people were killed.

title: Bill Yields Drop At Weekly Sale
description: Yields on threemonth and sixmonth Treasury bills declined yesterday in the Government's weekly sale of these shortterm securities.

title: The Editorial Notebook A New Chinese Revolution
description: Joseph Stalin wrote that there can be no revolution without a revolutionary doctrine. The point applies to what is now going on in China. The new leader of China, Teng Hsiaoping, is often described as a pragmatist. However, Mr. Teng has spent a long career as his party's top administrator and can be counted on not to ignore doctrine but to employ it for his own purposes. He is doing so.

title: High Court Allows Life Sentences in Drug Offenses
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP)  Even though two of its members denounced the statute as unreasonably severe, the Supreme Court today turned back challenges to a New York City law that provides life imprisonment for the sale or possession of small amounts of hard drugs.

title: World News Briefs; Trucking Strike Disrupts British Oil and Food Supply
description: LONDON, Jan. 8  A truck drivers strike that started in Scotland is now disrupting vital industrial deliveries and oil and food supplies in England as well.

title: St. Francis 69, F.D.U. 67
description: RUTHERFORD, N.J., Jan. 8 Clarence Thornton, a freshman guard, hit jumper with one second left tonight to give St. Francis College of Brooklyn 6967 victory over Fairleigh Dickinson University.

title: Steel Pact Approved In Germany
description: Union Leaders Vote Strike End

title: Koch Is Assailed By 1V.A.A.C.P. On Hospital Cut; Califano Is Asked to Order Inquiry on City's Plans
description: The local branches of the National As. sociation for the Advancement of Colorer People yesterday warned Joseph A. Cali. fano, the Secretary of Health, Educatior and Welfare, of possible racial confron tation and disorder if Mayor Koch at tempted to dismantle New York City': municipal hospital system.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Irving Salomon, a U.N. Delegate
description: SAN DIEGO, Jan. 8 (AP)  Irving Salomon, a businessman who served as a United States delegate to United Nations meetings in the 1950's, died yesterday at a convalescent home at the age of 81. He was a resident of San Diego.

title: 1978 Prices Up 7.3% in E.E.C.
description: LUXEMBOURG, Jan. 8 (Reuters)Consumer prices in the nine Common Market countries rose by 7.3 percent in 1978, official figures issued today showed.

title: Cernetary,Negotiations Stalled; Union Leader Ends Hunger Strike
description: Cemetery workers negotiators failed to reach agreement on a new contract last night, and Sam Cimaglia, president of the union, announced he was ending a fiveday hunger strike at the insistence of his 2.000 members.

title: Steel Output Down in Week
description: Steel production last week fell 6.4 percent to 2.43 million tons from the previous week's 2.59 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The total for 1979 so far (the same as last week's output) was up 5.2 percent from 2.31 million tons in the similar period of 1978.

title: Market Place
description: Small Concerns: Hidden Value?

title: Radio
description: Music

title: High Rates Move Koch Step Closer to Postponing $100 Million Note Sale
description: Mayor Koch moved the city a step closer yesterday to postponing its longawaited effort to borrow money publicly when he said that high interest rates made him inclined to put off a $100 million note sale scheduled for this month.

title: Article 1 -- No Title
description: CLUES SOUGHT IN WHALE DEATHS: American and Mexican scientists studied 56 sperm whales beached in Baja California, Mexico, seeking a reason for the mass

title: Stresses a Trip Would Be Temporary, but Return Is Viewed as Difficult
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8  After hoping for many weeks that Shah Mohammed Rim Pahlevi would remain in Iran and put down its disorders, the United States has now advised him that it would be best for stability in Iran if he left the country temporarily, Administration officials said today.

title: No Free Ride for Amtrak
description: To judge by the mail, many readers are unhappy with our opposition to heavy Federal subsidies for Amtrak. Some deplore the lack of civility on buses and airlines, or point out the importance of intercity trains to those who ride them regularly. But these complaints do not add up to a convincing case for passing on twothirds of Amtrak's cost to the nation's taxpayers, especially when vital Government programs are threatened by budget cuts.

title: Indictment of Graiver Is Dropped
description: A State Supreme Court justice in Manhattan yesterday dismissed charges against David Graiver, the missing banker, but declined to rule on whether Mr. Graiver was dead.

title: Abdut New York; Romance of the Leviathan
description: Any number of people think Frank 0. Braynard is an extraordinary New Yorker because of the balance of fun and grandeur that he brought billowing into our waters under the name of Operation Sail in 1976. But those who truly know Mr. Braynard realize that the harbor extravaganza, which he conceived and directed out of pure, deep love of the sea and its ships, was only a distraction from the day-to-day maritime passion of his life.

title: The Riot in Borough Park
description: Last Dec. 2, a crowd of Hasidic Jews pushed and shoved their way into the 66th Precinct police station Borough Park, Brooklyn. They overturned files, ripped doors off hinges and littered the floor with official papers. Police reinforcements rushed to the scene. So did Mayor Koch. He urged the Hasidim, who were demonstrating about a murder that had already been solved to on home

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: Book by Robin Cook Brings $1 Million
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 8  Sphinx, a lady-archeologist-in-jeopardy novel by Robin Cook, the author of Coma, has been purchased by Orion Pictures for approximately $1 million. Orion, formed last March by the former top

title: Steeler Didn't Get His Wish
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 8 Joe Greene didn't get his wish for a particular opponent in the American Conference championship game, and he won't get it for the Super Bowl. That, however, will not deflate the Pittsburgh Steelers confidence one snowflake.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Batinovich Leaving Coast Regulatory Post

title: Vietnam Asks U.N. Security Council Not to Meet on Cambodia Issue
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 8 Vietnam relayed to the United Ndtions today a strong protest from what it de: scribed as the new government of Cambodia against any Security Council hearing of charges brought by the defeated reeime.

title: Rice Signs a 7Year Contract With Red Sox for $5.4 Million
description: Jim Rice, the American League's most valuable player last season, signed a sevenyear, $5.4 million contract with the Boston Red Sox yesterday. The contract is the largest in American League history and second in major league history only to tile fouryear, $3.2, million contract that Pete Rose signed last month with the Philadelphia Phillies.

title: Pesa, 20, First Choice in N.A.S.L. Draft
description: Njego Pesa, a forward from Ulster Community College, was the first player selected in yesterday's North American Soccer League draft at the Waldorf Astoria Hotel. He was picked by the Dallas Tornado, who are trying to rebuild after missing the playoffs last year.

title: Trade Mart Is Reported Set in China
description: Japan to Help;

title: Lee Marvin to Fight Suit of ExCompanion Over Promise of Life Support
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 8  Lee Marvin, the actor who won an Academy Award in 1965 for portraying a gunslinger in Cat Ballou, will defend himself in Los Angeles Superior Court tomorrow against charges by his former mistress that he promised to support her for life if she gave up her singing career to serve as his cook, companion and confidante.

title: ExChiefs Reported in Mountains
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 8 The defeated leaders of Cambodia are thought to be hiding in the Cardamom Mountains southwest of Phnom Penh, according to a report today in the Government newspaper Izvestia.

title: Ballet: City's Symphony in C Is a Crystal Palace
description: IT seems only appropriate that George Balanchine's ballet to Bizet, Symphony in C, was called Le Palais de Cristal at its Paris premiere in 1947. It is truly a crystal palace of a ballet.

title: Science Library; The Art of Natural History: Animal Illustrators and Their Work
description: By S. Peter Dance. 224 pages. The Overtook Press. $60.

title: Profit Reported At Winnebago
description: Winnebago Industries Inc., a leading manufacturer of recreational vehicles, with emphasis on motor homes, reported yesterday a net profit of $237,731, equal to one cent a share, for the quarter ended Nov. 25. This contrasts with a loss of $747,777 in the prior year's period.

title: Oil Workers, Awaiting U.S. Approval, Likely to Acicept Amoco Pact
description: DENVER, Jan. 8  The Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers Union, bowing to President Carter's voluntary wage guidelines instead of calling a strike, is apparently willing to accept a contract proposal from the Standard CM company (Indiana). But official approval is being delayed until the union is certain that the pact is acceptable under the guidelines.

title: Shotgun Blast in Face Cuts Down Policeman Responding to Holdup
description: A 28-year-old Transit Authority policemen was seriously wounded by a shotgun blast in the Bronx last night while investigating a robbery of a tavern near the Jerome Avenue and West 176th Street station of the IRT.

title: Francine G. Gordon Married in Caracas
description: Francine Grace Gordon, daughter of Sylvia Myerson Grace of New York and the late William Grace, was married yesterday in Caracas, Venezuela, to Gonzalo Plaza, director of Venezuela's Department of immigration and Naturalization. The ceremony was performed at the home of the bridegroom by Judge Olga Fortoul of the First Parochial Court of Caracas.

title: Opera: New Jerseyans Offer Andrea Chnier
description: THE most enticing part of Sunday night's scheduled presentation of Andrea Chnier by the New Jersey State Opera was the expected opportunity to hear Giuseppe Giacomini in the title role. the But the Italian tenor, who has made favorable impression at the Metropolitan Opera, withdrew, and so did Mario Sereni, the scheduled Gerard.

title: Music: Sharon Robinson, Cellist
description: ONE of the unfading fascinations of regular concertgoing is watching young performers struggle to discover their individuality as artists. Sometimes the discovery comes suddenly, sometimes it

title: MARCHERS IN PEKING DEMAND DEMOCRACY; Thousands Demonstrate in Square as Others Praise Chou on 3d Anniversary of His Death
description: PEKING, Jan. 8  Several thousand Chinese marched around Tien An Men Square today with banners demanding human rights and democracy while many other Chinese commemorated the third anniversary of the death of Chou Enlai.

title: Venezuelan Oil Output
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 8 (AP)Oil production, on which Venezuela depends for more than 90 percent of its export earnings, averaged 2.205 million barrels a day during the first week of

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: BUSINESS Digest

title: Companies Report Earnings
description: For periods as shown. (N) Indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock E ochanoe,1 A the American Stock Exchange and 10) over-thecounter.

title: N.Y. Tech 77, City College 55
description: Bob Jones scored 13 points, and Keith Haddock had 12 last night to lead New York Tech to a 7755 triumph over City College in Nat Holman Gymnasium. The loss was the fifth in a row for City College, which now has a record of 29.

title: IRVING B. SUNKIN
description: Irving B. Sunkin, a vice president and corporate secretary at Revlon Inc., died yesterday morning at Lenox Hill Hospital after a brief illness. He was 46 years old and lived at 60 East End Avenue.

title: Demand Eases on Mortgages
description: Mortgage loan demand is showing more than a seasonal slowdown, Kenneth M. Plant, director of research at the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corwration, reported yesterday as he commented on the Governmentowned compan''s weekly purchase of housing loans.

title: Association Urged to Bar Paranormal Investigators
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 8  The American Association for the Advancement of Science was urged as it ended a weeklong meeting here today to drop its division of parapsychologv.

title: Cowboy Considers Tactics
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 8  Most of the Dallas Cowboys players and coaches watched the first half of the American Football Conference championship game on television before boarding buses to go to the Coliseum to play the Los Angeles Rams yesterday. They saw the Steelers destroy the Houston Oilers in the freezing rain, and they were impressed. Then they went out and destroyed the Rams, and they were imnressive.

title: Schnellenberger to Coach University of Miami Team
description: MIAMI, Jan. 8 (AP)  Howard Schnellenberger, former coach of the Baltimore Colts and currently the Miami Dolphins offensive coordinator, today was appointed the new head football coach of the University of Miami.

title: Byrne Will Ask State Takeover Of Some Buses; Proposal Today Would Be for the Subsidized Lines
description: TRENTON, Jan. 8  Governor Byrne intends to propose tomorrow that the state take over the two dozen bus companies it now subsidizes, to impose rationality and coherence on bus transportation in the state.

title: SIHANOUK REQUESTS AID OF U.S. AND U.N.; Criticizes Successors but Pleads for Help Against Vietnamese
description: PEKING, Jan. 8  Prince Norodom Sihanouk, Cambodia's onetime ruler, appealed for help from the United States and the United Nations today against Vietnam's invasion of his country. He urged the United Nations to intervene militarily to expel the Vietnamese.

title: Partridge Stolen on 12th Day
description: LISBON, Jan. 8 (Reuters)  Thieves broke into the aviary at the Lisbon Zoo on Saturday  the 12th day of Christmas and stole 90 parakeets, 40 Chinese ducks and a partridge worth $1,000.

title: Kentucky 90, Mississippi 64
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Jan. 8 (AP) Dwight Anderson, a freshman, scored points during a gameending 184 scoring burst tonight as Kentucky defeated Mississippi, 9064, in a Southeastern Conference game.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Clorox Company, Oakland, Calif., diversified householdproducts and foodservice company, has elected its chief executive officer, Robert B. Shetterly, to the additional post of chairman. Also announced was the election of Richard M. Oster to the newly created position of vice chairman and the election of Edwin H. Shutt Jr. as president and chief operating officer.

title: Deaths
description: SEMMESAlva Helen purring on Jan. 6, 1979, of Garden City, beloved wife, mother and grandmother. Also survived by a sister, Marie purring Goldsmith of NYC and a niece, Elizabeth Inman of Virginia. Memorial services at the Cathedral of the Incarnation., Cathedral Ave. Garden City, Mon. Jan 15, 1979 at 8PM.

title: Around the Nation; Brown Calls for Tax Cuts Of $1 Billion for California
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 8 (AP) Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. proposed cuts of $1 billion in taxes and the elimination of 5,000 state jobs today in an inaugural address filled with emotional attacks on government spending.

title: Hirsch Is Booked With 4 Tied to Brooklyn Melee
description: Assemblyman Samuel Hirsch and four other men from the Borough Park section of Brooklyn were arrested yesterday when they surrendered on complaints that grew out of demonstrations by Hasidic Jews in Brooklyn on Dec. 2. The demonstrations were provoked by a murder and charges of inadequate police protection.

title: Phnom Penh Falls Again
description: The swift fall of Phnom Penh is startling to those who remember the long siege by which Pol Pot took the Cambodian capital four long years ago. But the military outcome was predictable.

title: S.E.C. Revises Filing Rule
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that large institutional investors that control $100 million or more in stock must file reports on their holdings on a quarterly, rather than annual basis.

title: Deaths
description: HAMMONDAnne Hall. Are 92. Member of the Marble Collegiate Church, N.Y.C. On Dec. 18, 1978. Of Lynchburg, Va. Formerly of Beacon and Haverstraw, N.Y. Wife of the late Harold H. Hammond. Sister of Martha H. Stewart of Lynchburg. Also survived by 2 nephews. Friends may attend entombment services at Mt. Rest Cemetery, N. Main St., Stony Pt. N.Y. at 12 Noon, Wed.

title: Senator Church Emulates Fulbright's Role on Panel
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8  The Senate Foreign Relations Committee, soon to have a new chairman and as many as six new members, is in the midst of transfor- mation, with its chairmandesignate, Senator Frank Church, bent on restoring the panel to the prominence in foreign af- fairs it once had.

title: Resettlement Is Begun For Vietnam Refugees On Ship in Philippines
description: MANILA, Jan. 8  Sixteen of the more than 2,300 Vietnamese refugees stranded aboard a cargo ship in Manila Bay were brought ashore today by a Philippine naval vessel for the start of an interna- tional resettlement effort.

title: U.S. to Sue To Halt Bid By H.F.C. On Concern
description: WASHINGTON Jan. 8 (AP) - The Government said today that it would file a civil antitrust suit challenging proposed $76 million acquisition by the Household Finance Corporation of the American Investment Company.

title: Chicago Grand Jury Hands Up Indictments In Seven Sex Slayings
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 8  John Wayne Gacy Jr. was indicted today in the murder of seven young men. Twentyseven badly decomposed bodies have been removed from shallow graves at his home northwest of Chicago over the last two weeks.

title: U.S. Copter Falls in Antarctica
description: SCOTT BASE, Antarctica, Jan. 8 (Reuters)  A United States Navy helicopter has crashed in northeast Antarctica, injuring four men, the American Forces Radio said today. A Navy Hercules plane rescued the six passengers and crew members yesterday and flew them to a hospital at the American base at McMurdo Sound near here.

title: 40 Die in India in Guerrilla Raids
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 8 (Reuters)  The death toll in attacks by Naga guerrillas on villages in northeastern India rose to 40 today after the discovery of 10 more bodies, the Press Trust of India news agency reported. It quoted the Chief Secretary of Assam State, R. S. Paramasivam, as having said that the Nagas, who have been flighting for independence for more than 25 years, burned down more than 300 houses during the raids Friday on five villages.

title: LIBERATION GROUP SAYS IT HAS FORMED REGIME IN CAMBODIA
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 8  A day after the capture of the Cambodian capital by Vietnamese forces, the Hanoi-sponsored Cambodian liberation movement announced the formation of a government today.

title: Imbalance of Population a Key Soviet Issue
description: DUSHANBE, U.S.S.R.  A few acquaintances, gathered recently for an evening of food and conversation, began to ask one another how many children they had. For the Tadzhiks, Uzbeks and other Central Asians, who predominated in the group, the numbers were high  8, 10, 12. Then it came an ethnic Russian's turn to reply. He had three, he said. They all laughed at me. he recalled.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a transmission error, an article in The Times on Dec. 31 misstated the age range involved in an Administration proposal.to phase out Social Security benefits for students. The range would be 18 to 21.

title: California Bars Church of God Leaders at Offices
description: PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 8  In a stormy confrontation between church and state, courtappointed armed guards turned away executives of the Worldwide Church of God when they attempted to enter their offices here this morning.

title: Redlining on Insurance Criticized by Abrams
description: Redlining in fire and property insurance, which forces property owners into the costly Fair Access to Insurance Requirements plan, was criticized yesterday by State Attorney General Robert Abrams.

title: Lafleur Extends Streak To 21 on EmptyNet Goal
description: MONTREAL, Jan. 8 (AP)  Guy Lafleur extended his scoring streak to 21 games tonight with an emptynet goal as the Montreal Canadiens recorded 31 National Hockey League triumph over the Minnesota North Stars.

title: Rhode Island 73, Brown 51
description: KINGSTON, R.I., Jan. 8 (AP)  Sly Williams poured in seven field goals as Rhode Island took an early 249 lead tonight and went on to an easy 7351 victory over Brown. Williams, averaging 25.5 points a game, finished with 26 points.

title: Retrial Ordered for 2 Croatians
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 8 (Reuters) A Federal judge today ordered a retrial of two Croatians who seized hostages at the West German consulate last August to demand the release of a Croatian separatist leader jailed in Cologne, West Germany. Judge Thomas McMillen, citing a prejudicial error in their sevenday trial last November, set aside their conviction for imprisoning the West German viceconsul with a deadly weapon during a 10hour siege at the consulate.

title: The City; City Aims to Reverse Postal Service Move
description: Peter J. Solomon, New York City's Deputy Mayor for Economic Development, yesterday urged three Postal Service officials to reconsider moving their regional office and 250 employees from the city to New Rochelle. He asked for up to 60 days for his office to find space somewhere in Manhattan. They said they would let him know within a few days.

title: Sulfa Residues In Cited
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP)  Government tests show that illegal amounts of sulfa drugs continued to show up in almost one out of every 10 hogs slaughtered to provide the nation's pork supply last year.

title: News Summary
description: TUESDAY, JANUARY 9, 1979

title: Deaths
description: ALTSCHULERT1Ille beloved thither of Fred and Marcia, Jerry and Linda cherished grandmother, loving sister of Lilly Kessler, Annette

title: China Said to Seek Japan's Help On Plan to Modernize Economy
description: TOKYO, Jan. 8  China has approached Japanese experts for advice in. planning its ambitious 10year program for modernizing the economy, a Japanese economist has disclosed.

title: Interrupt Will Return To WNET
description: We interrupt this flow of news to inform you that We Interrupt This Week, the show dropped on Dec. 29 by WNET/13, will be back on television next month, thanks to popular demand and a bundle of money.

title: OTB Simulcasts Are Facing a Delay
description: By STEVE CADY

title: TV: Paper Chase Stays
description: IN a society that in its gloomier moments perceives itself as being bled white by the exactations of lawyers, the process by which within a mere three years innocent

title: Street Academy Is Boot Camp For a BedfordStuyvesant School
description: Maggie Houston, a 16-year-old from the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn who is called DeeDee, dreaded the gantlet she said she had to run everyday trying to get to class at Boys and Girls High School.

title: Notre Dame Drubs Davidson by 9563
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., Jan. 8 (AP) Bruce Flowers scored 15 points and Stan Wilcox hit for 14 as No. 2ranked Notre Dame rolled over Davidson, 9563, in college basketball tonight.

title: Budget Retrenchment Spreading To Suburbia in New York Region
description: The fiscal retrenchment that has been preoccupying Albany and City Hall for the last four years is spreading to metropolitan area suburbs, with Suffolk County on Long Island preparing a referendum on spending and taxes and at least three counties laying off workers.

title: Bucks, Led by Johnson, Defeat Rockets, 116104
description: MILWAUKEE, Jan. 8 (AP) Marques Johnson scored 21 of his 36 points in the second half, and Brian Winters had 27 points, leading the Milwaukee Bucks to a 116104 triumph tonight over the Houston Rockets in a National Basketball Association game.

title: CHARLES MINGUS DIES AT 56: A leading bass player and composer for years, the jazz musician suffered a heart attack in Mexico. Page B6.
description: Charles Mingus, 56, Bass Player, Bandleader and Composer, Dead

title: A.I.A.W. Assembly Approves 3-Division Alignment
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 8  A restructuring of intercollegiate sports championships was approved today by the Association for Intercollegiate Athletics for Women.

title: Music: Larry Guy Plays New Works for Clarinet
description: ONE of the healthiest aspects of the Hear America First contemporary music series, now in its seventh season, is a completely nondoctrinaire attitude toward programming. No one composi- tional philosophy ever seems to dominate these concerts, and generally it is possible to hear a wide variety of styles on any given evening.

title: CarterKoch Harmony a Summer Memory
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8  The White House and New York's City Hall have engaged in a series of maneuvers recently that has raised the level of tension between them. Clearly, the cooperation that prevailed through last summer  when, hand in hand, Mayor Koch, President Carter, Governor Carey and their allies won Congressional approval of the city's loanguarantee legislation  has given way to an atmosphere of strain and clelensiveness.

title: OBSERVERLosing Speed
description: I cannot pinpoint with certainty the moment at which I lost touch, writes a middleaged friend. It wasn't when everybody was eating Colonel Sanders Kentucky fried chicken because I distinctly remember eating the stuff with some regularity in those days and thinking nothing of it.

title: New Master's Program Specializes in Generalizing
description: GRADUATE degrees normally imply specialization, but now there is a graduate degree in liberal arts designed to allow students to build on their undergraduate  ate background or to broaden the education they got in college, where career objectives often stymie efforts at learning about literature, philosophy or basic science.

title: Army 81, Kings Point 73
description: KINGS POINT, L.I., Jan. 8 (AP) Marty Coyne scored a careerhigh 17 points tonight to help Army to an 8173 victory over Kings Point.

title: New Evaluation Ordered On ATests and Cancer
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (UPI)  President Carter has reportedly ordered Federal officials to take a new look at the possibility of a link between aboveground atomic tests and cancer among Utah residents.

title: Unsold U.S. Bonds Hurt Prices
description: The credit markets sagged yesterday under the weight of the unsold new 9 percent Treasury bonds that dealers are holding in their inventories. The 15year bonds declined a quarter of a point, lifting their yield to 9.08 percent.

title: Supreme CourtRoundup Busing Plans in Ohio Schools Face Review
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 The Supreme Court agreed today to review busing plans ordered by Federal courts in two Ohio city school systems. The cases, involving longrunning integration battles in Columbus and Dayton, give the High Court a chance to clarify recent ambiguous  and, to civil rights groups, distressing  decisions about how much and what kind of segregation a judge has to find before he can order systemwide busing or other remedial action.

title: State Dept. Aide Is Nominated
description: WASHINGTON, Jan 8 (AP)  President Carter said today that he would nominate K. Mathea Falco, 33 years old, to be Assistant Secretary of State for international narcotics matters. She is currently an adviser to Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance and director for international narcotics control matters.

title: G.& W. Holds 94% Of Simmons Co.
description: Gulf and Western Industries announced that through its tender offer for the Simmons Company, which ended on Jan. 5, it had acquired 4.5 million shares of Simmons common stock, thus bringing its Simmons holdings to 6.7 million shares, or 99 percent of the outstanding shares.

title: Dr. Jessie D. Read, 75; A Jersey Gynecologist
description: Dr. Jessie D. Read, a New Jersey gynecologist and obstetrician for more than half a century, died at St. Anthony's Hospital North in Westminster, Colo., after a heart attack while on vacation in Denver. She was 75 years old and lived in Westfield. N.J.

title: Reform, N.C.A.A. Is Told
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 8  In chal- lenging the National Collegiate Ath- letic Association to "reform or be re- formed," the majority members of a 14-man Congressional subcomittee suggested today that the association take specific steps to correct "unfair- ness" in its enforcement and penalty procedures.

title: Japanese Help China on Plants
description: TOKYO, Jan. 8 (AP)  Five Japanese companies have received orders from China to build factories worth about $707.7 million in the latest deal made so far in China's industrial modernization program.

title: Bridge:

title: Notes on People; 2d Chef to Mayor Koch Ends Tour at Mansion
description: Things were in a stew at Gracie Mansion yesterday because of the dismissal of yet another chef to Mayor Koch. Steven Philips, a 24-year-old native of Allentown, Pa., ended his cook's tour at the mansion, forced out to make way for Lauren Kaye, 25, who attended the La Varenne cooking school in Paris. With Mr. Philips being told to turn over his toque blanche to Miss Kaye, the position of Gracie Mansion chef became the first job in the Koch Administration to undergo a double turnover. Mr. Koch's first cook, Rozanne Gold, was shown the kitchen door last fall.

title: WALLACE TOWNSEND

title: Screen: A Woman Finds Ego:Forced Liberation
description: "LA FEMME DE JEAN" ("John's Wife"), the second feature by Yannick Bellon, a new French film director whose work is being showcased this week at Joseph Papp's Public Theater, has been correctly described as a Gallic "An Unmarried Woman," though Miss Bellon's film was actually made in 1974, before the release of the Paul Mazursky picture.Like the American film, "La Femme de Jean" is about a beautiful, intelligent, resourceful, upper-middle-class woman coping with sudden loneliness and loss of ego after her weak, foolish, unreliable, childish, aging husband walks out on her for another woman.The parallels don't stop there. Nadine, the abandoned Parisian wife, is beautifully played by France Lambiotte  a publicity woman whose first film role this is  and though she mopes around and cries a lot at the beginning, it's not long before she attracts the attentions of a man who's not only younger than her husband, but also far more interesting, more attentive, franker, sexier and more sure of himself."La Femme de Jean," like "An Unmarried Woman," stacks the cards in favor of the heroine who has been liberated in spite of herself. At this point, it might be interesting to see a movie in which (1) the husband isn't such an obvious bad investment and (2) the heroine isn't saved by the director-writer's romantic temperament.On the basis of this film, Miss Bellon is a competent director though not a very surprising one. She has a numbing fondness for beginning scenes by panning her camera horizontally to discover the scene's real subject, for closeups that don't emphasize a point as often as they ask for pity and for overlapping sounds that sometimes make one think the projectionist has mixed up the reels. However, Miss Lambiotte, her star, is a real find. The other performances are adequate."La Femme de Jean" will be screened at the Public Theater today, Thursday and Saturday. Miss Bellon's "Somewhere Someone," her second feature, will be shown tomorrow and Sunday, and her "Never More, Always," on Friday.

title: Screen: 'Tattooed Tears':Musicians Union to Honor Shubert Organization Head
description: LIKE all good documentaries, "Tattooed Tears" touches on a number of subjects beyond its immediate view, which is of life at the Youth Training School in California, a correctional institution for men who are still young in years (17-21) but who already seem exhausted. The film, which opens today at the Whitney Museum of American Art, was produced, directed, photographed and edited by Nick Broomfield and Joan Churchill. It's a superior work in its field."Tattooed Tears," a reference to the homemade tattoos with which one young prisoner has decorated his face (one tear for each year at the school), opens with the statement of a former director of the California Youth Authority to the effect that rehabilitation in such institutions is impossible and that their only purpose is to protect the people outside.The film goes on to show not only the physical and emotional tensions that are integral to life even in a comparatively well-run prison, but also the particular stories of four inmates, including an apparent schizophrenic. Only one of the four, a young black man named Brian, can articulate his frustrations, and he seems to be on the edge of total despair, having entered the school with a three-month sentence and seen that sentence grow to three years because of penalties for various minor infractions.A third young man, the tattoo artist, copes with his fate by refusing all cooperation, and a fourth, a fellow who displays the disconnected elation of a speed freak, attempts suicide and, when the opportunity arises again, severely slashes his leg. This, he explains, is one way of creating a little excitement when you're in solitary.The stories are infinitely sad, but even sadder are the implications that a second-rate society, doing its level best, not only will never solve these problems but also can't even alleviate them. The counselors and therapists we see in the film appear to be decent, conscientious, hard-working people, yet the manner in which they've been educated and trained makes it seem most unlikely they will ever do much good. Because they talk in the jargon and clichs of their trade, they seem almost as far removed from reality as the young men they are supposed to help.In one hilarious and frightening sequence, a school counselor attempts to convince his young listeners of the joys of American capitalism, as opposed to the miseries of Soviet Communism. He talks about sirloin steaks, freedom to travel and the ever-present possibility of making a million dollarsby legitimate means, of course. The audience remains skeptical. As this film demonstrates, Americans these days are talking more and more and saying less and less.

title: The Region; Censured Company Again Under Inquiry
description: A Long Island manufacturer suspended 10 years ago as defense contractor because of alleged gross overpricing, is again being investigated by Congress and the Pentagon on charges of fraud and overpricing, according to Representative Thomas J. Downey, Democrat of West Islip. The Cardwell Condenser Corporation, Lindenhurst, L.I., was accused by Representative Downey of selling anchors worth $7 to the Government at the inflated price of $32 each, and electric motors valued at $79.75 each for $245. The House Armed Services Subcommittee On Investigation, Mr. Downey said yesterday, planned to hold hearings on the matter when Congress reconvenes this month.

title: Personal Health
description: THERE is probably no aspect of human nutritional needs that is less well understood and appreciated than the socalled micronutrients or trace elements. These are substances that the body requires in tiny amounts to maintain normal health and growth, but which can be deadly poisons if consumed in large doses.

title: Teaching Was Easy, But the Grading Hurt
description: WHEN Yale University asked me to participate in its lecturer series this past term, I agreed in part because I thought the association might help redeem my undistinguished, indeed embarrassing, record as an un- dergraduate at the University of South Dakota almost 20 years ago. By combining the demands of infatuations, indifference, immaturity and impatience, I managed to stumble my way to a bachelor's degree in political science with a grade point average just a whisker above 2.0.

Connecticut sent the game into overtime with a basket at the buzzer by a senior guard, Randy LaVigne, who tied the score at 62. The victory was UConn's eighth straight.

title: New Yorker Seized by Spanish

They said the drug, valued at almost $40,000 on the black market, was concealed in a false compartment of the gas tank in Mr. Manchester's Dutchregistered car.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP)  The United States Chamber of Commerce said today that Congress should reduce the Federal deficit for the next fiscal year by $4 billion more than President Carter is expected to recommend, and urged lower taxes and reform of tax laws to stimulate business investment.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS Rhodesia Isn't Vietnam
