description: LONDON  The Irish writer Conor Cruise O'Brien once. remarked apropos Africa that when people do not understand any political situation, they try to explain it by an analogy: hence the misleading comparisons between Rhodesia and Vietnam.

title: Newfoundland Seal Harvest In March Stirs Early Storm
description: The harvestbyclubbing of newborn seals in Newfoundland does not begin until March, but yesterday friends and foes of the practice opened their own season on public opinion in New York City, promoting their disparate positions with visiting experts, press releases, brochures, contradictory statistics, color movies. coffee and breakfast Danish.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Consolidated Foods Corporation, Chicago. has formed a Frozen Foods Group and appointed Thomas F. Barnum its president and chief executive officer. Mr. Barnum, formerly president and chief executive officer of the Kitchens of Sara Lee, one of the companies in the new group, will be succeeded by William P. Mahoney, currently senior vice president of Consolidated Foods.

title: Islanders' Streak Now 21 After 71 Victory
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Jan. 9  After a sluggish opening and a somnolent first half of the second period, the New York Islanders broke out with a burst of scoring tonight to overwhelm the Los Angeles Kings, 71, in the Nassau Coliseum. The New Yorkers scored four times in the second period.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: $830 Million in Cash Bid for McGrawHill By American Express
description: In one of the biggest takeover attempts sin record, the American Express Company, best known for its travelers' checks and credit cards, offered yesterday to pay $830 million in cash for McGrawHill Inc., one of the nation's largest publishers.

title: Chester Watson, BassBaritone
description: Chester Watson, a bassbaritone who sang with opera companies and other music groups in New York and other cities for many years, died in his sleep Monday at his home in Manhattan. Mr. Watson, who also was a voice teacher, was 65 years old.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: A DEAR friend of mine, of Italian hackground, swears that this actually happened, writes Richard Hatch. He is bachelor, living with an elderly aunt who indulges and spoils him, cooking every sort of oldworld delicacy for his pleasure.

title: Brown Stresses Conservatism in Inaugural
description: SACRAMENTO, Jan. 9  After a secondterm inaugural speech in which he staked his claim as the Democratic Party's fiscal conservative, Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. said in an interview today that it would be premature to discuss whether he intended to challenge President Carter in 1980.

title: Companies Report Earnings
description: For periods as shown. (N) indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock E xchange,(A) the American Stock Exchange and (O) Overthecovn ter.

title: Chemicals Peril Kentucky Creek
description: WEST POINT, Ky., Jan. 9  Officials of the Environmental Protection Agency said today that they had identified 13 hazardous chemicals, including suspected cantercausing agents, in an analysis of industrial waste contained in 600 steel barrels found floating in flood waters near Louisville.

title: Cambodia Fighting Said to Persist, But Hanoi's Victory Seems Secure
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 9  Western analysts reported today that fighting was continuing throughout much of the area of Cambodia held by Vietnamese forces, but they believed it involved rearguard actions that could not reverse the Vietnamese advance.

title: Neureuther Victorious In World Cup Slalom
description: CRANSMONTANA, Switzerland, Jan. 9  Christian Neureuther, a veteran West German skier, scored an unexpected victory today in a World Cup slalom race as Ingemar Stenmark, the overwhelming favorite, fell during the first run.

title: Helen C. Dobson, at 90, Served Long as a Red Cross Volunteer
description: Helen C. Dobson, a former board member of the New York City chapter of the American Red Cross Overseas Service League, died Monday after a brief illness in a nursing home in Rye, N.Y. She was 90 years old, arid before entering the nursing home in 1900, she lived at 220 East 73d Street in Manhattan.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: Fixedincome prices fell yesterday, pushing interest rates higher for the third consecutive day. The chief impetus behind the credit market's latest decline was a statement by the Federal Reserve chairman, G. William Miller, that he knew of no reason not to continue a policy of monetary restraint.

title: Bridge:
description: Enthusiasts in the metropolitan area who enjoy the challenge of regional competition will be able to put their talents to the test at a new and convenient location during the next five days.

title: In Cambodia, Bubonic Plague Out, Cholera In
description: WASHINGTON  The collapse of Pol Pot's Khmer Rouge regime, which brought suffering, death and summary executions to Cambodia for nearly four years, is cause neither for mourning nor celebration, for it is tied to Vietnamese annexationism and imperialism.

title: Suspect in Mass Deaths Is Puzzle to All
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 9 In the clean, welllighted world of middleclass America, the hardworking, outgoing, communityspirited man next door is not supposed to be the suspect in the worst instance of mass killings in the United States in this century.

title: The Region
description: WHITE PLAINS  A subcommittee of a state task force studying new ways of financing public education decided to press an appeal of a lower court decision overturning the current method of financing. The task force will bypass the Appellate Division and go directly to the state's highest court.

title: Carl Schutzman, 69, TV Expert, and Wife Die in an Auto Crash
description: Carl Schutzman, a former technical director for CBSTV, and his wife were killed Sunday on their way from Ottawa to New York when the car Mr. Schutzman was driving skidded on ice and collided with another vehicle. Mr. Schultzman was 69 years old and his wife was 67.

title: Socialists Win Right to Keep Backers Secret
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9  The Socialist Workers Party has won the right to keep secret the names and addresses of its political contributors to protect their constitutional right to freedom of association.

title: Goodyear Cites Gains
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company said yesterday that its fourthquarter results were stronger than originally projected and that the company expected to report record sales and earnings for 1978.

title: Market Place
description: THE normalization of relations with China may some day bring a settlement of 30yearold claims by holders of Chinese bonds, but many in Wall Street believe current speculation in the issues to be excessive.

title: Wine Talk
description: THE year 1978 had a number of peaks  in terms of great bottles  for this writer and here are some of the highest of them. One of the most unusual was a bottle of ice wine from Edmeades Vineyards in Mendocino County in California. Ice wine is created when the ripe grapes are frozen on the vine. The water in the grapes freezes and drops away, leaving only the essence of the fruit to be vinified.

title: Smoke Victim Revived After Heartbeat Ended
description: A 55yearold man from Bayport, I...I., who was resuscitated several times after his heart stopped beating as a result of smoke inhalation yesterday was reported in critical condition at the Brookhaven Memorial Hospital in Patchogue.

title: Notes on People
description: In Paris yesterday, Isaac Stern received a promotion in the French Legion of Honor, and in New York, his agent said the violinist would be the first major American soloist to tour mainland China in the postWorld War II years. Mr. Stern will appear in concerts in several Chinese cities in June, and exchange ideas with musicians in Chinese orchestras, his agent said.

title: Connors Is Unimpressed By McEnroe Reputation
description: Eddie Dibbs had not seen John McEnroe in several months. Hey, are you growing or something? Dibbs, who is 5 feet 7 inches tall, teased the 19 year old Douglaston, Queens, professional as they posed for pictures yesterday on the eve of the Grand Prix Masters tennis tournament at Madison Square Garden.

title: Syrian and Iraqi Leaders to Meet
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Jan. 9 (AP)  The presidents of Syria and Iraq will meet here on Jan. 20 to strengthen their renewed political and military alliance, the Government newspaper Tishrin said today. The paper added that the SyrianIraqi military committee would meet in Damascus before the two presidents, Ha fez alAssad of Syria and Ahmed Hassan alBakr of Iraq, get together.

title: Real Estate
description: WHEN the Knickerbocker Hotel opened on Times Square in 1906, 500 people were turned away from the dining rooms. Where do all these people come from who fill up new hotels as fast as they are opened? asked a news account at the time.

title: Pullman Unit's China Deal
description: Pullman Inc. announced yesterday that Kellogg Continental B.V. Netherlands, an affiliate of its Pullman Kellogg division, had been awarded a contract by the China National Technical Import Corporation to provide advisory consulting, training and administrative services to the Chinese company. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Bankers Say Shah's Fortune Is Well Above a Billion.
description: Mohammed Riza Pahlevi may be losing a kingdom in Iran, but the pain of his exile, if and when it comes, will be considerably eased by one of the largest private fortunes in the world.

title: Mitsubishi Denies New Chrysler Tie
description: TOKYO, Jan. 9 (Reuters)  Mitsubishi Motor said it would be meeting with Chrysler Corporation officials today and tomorrow, but the Japanese concern denied reports that it was considering taking a financial stake in the American car manufacturer.

title: Assembly Unit Approves A Bill for a Death Penalty
description: ALBANY, Jan. 9  The Assembly Codes Committee today revived efforts to restore the death penalty in New York State as it approved a capitalpunishment bill and sent it to the floor

title: Private Lives
description: HE is itemizing, as though to find out if the world adds up. The items are pinned to a cork board. He looks at them through a spyglass that comes with the compact edition of the Oxford English Dictionary. One could, if one wanted to, think of them as the wings of various butterflies of empirical reality. One shouldn't, because that's fruity thinking. They are merely random. Consider:

title: Q&A;
description: Q. I have counted no fewer than 18 different shapes of pasta on my supermarket shelves. Are they all made from the same dough, differing only in shape?

title: U.S. AGENCIES BACK GENERIC DRUGS' USE IN BID TO CUT COSTS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9  Actions that Government officials said were aimed at saving consumers as much as $400 million a year on prescription drugs were begun by Federal regulatory agencies today.

title: Music: Sills Farewell
description: LAST night in Alice Tully Hall, the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center started something and Beverly Sills finished something. It was the opening concert of the new Vocal Chamber Music Series  the other two events will take place Feb. 1 and March 6. It also was, as far as New York audiences are concerned, the end of Miss Sills' distinguished career her last appearance on a stage in the city. She is scheduled for still one more role next May, in a new Menotti opera in San Diego. Then, in July, she will take over as manager of the New York City Opera.

title: Obituary 1 -- No Title
description: HERMINA R. CANTOR

title: Television
description: 8:00 P.M. The Music for UNICEF. Concert (4)

title: Youth Is Given Life and 99 Years In Murder of Son of Dan Topping
description: MIAMI, Jan. 9 (UPI)  A 19yearold Miami man was sentenced yesterday to consecutive terms of life imprisonment and 99 years for kidnapping murder in 1977 of Robert Topping, son of Dan Topping, a former owner of the New York Yankees, and stepson of Rankin Smith, the owner of the Atlanta Falcons.

title: Best Buys
description: YOU walk into a supermarket, looking for this week's crop of bargains. You know that Green Giant corn is advertised at 3 cans for $1. But the cans in the supermarket are clearly marked 37 cents. You pick up the corn, preparing for a battle at the checkout counter.

title: In Moscow's Cold, Everything Freezes but Rumors
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 9  Muscovites, who are among the world's most creative rumormongers, worked themselves into a new frenzy of fantasy last week as they spread the word that the capital was headed for a cold snap that would make the record low of 35.8 degrees below zero Fahrenheit the previous weekend feel like a breath of swing.

title: Sihanouk Arrives to Plead the Case Of Cambodia Before U.N. Council
description: Prince Norodom Sihanouk arrived in New York last night to ask the United Nations security Council to aidthe fallen Cambodian Government of Prime Minister Pol Pot.

title: PESSIMISM IS FOUND ON WAGE INSURANCE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9  Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal has privately warned President Carter that his proposal for real wage insurance, a key component of the voluntary antiinflation program, will meet stiff resistance in Congress and entails great political risks, Administration officials said today.

title: Pier Luigi Nervi, Architect, Dead at 87
description: Pier Luigi Nervi, the Italian engineer whose soaring, taut buildings of reinforced concrete are among the most dramatic structures 20thcentury architecture has produced, died yesterday at his home in Rome. He was 87 years old.

title: Hospital at Last Identifies Its ShoppingBag Lady
description: An elderly shopping bag lady who has spent the last two months in the Presbyterian Hospital was identified yesterday as Hungarianborn Julia Simon, one of the legion of homeless, independent, often eccentric women who live on the city's streets.

title: Court Upholds Guilty Ruling On Hunt Soybean Violation
description: CHICAGO, Jan. (AP)  A Federal appeals court today upheld a ruling that the Texas millionaire Nelson Bunker Hunt and his family were guilty of violating Government speculative limits on soybean trading.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Former Gov. Rudy Perpich of Minnesota, the maverick from the Mesabi Range who was defeated in an upset last November, is going to work for Control Data Corporation overseas.

title: Obituary 2 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Obituary 6 -- No Title
description: Death

title: Jessie Swift, 100, Led A Hospital in Brooklyn
description: Jessie Williams Swift, who had been president of the Brooklyn Thoracic Hospital, now .part of Brooklyn Hospital, from 1931 to 1947, died yesterday in a nursing home in Trumbull, Conn. She was 100 years old and had lived most of her life in Brooklyn Heights.

title: Postal Service Is Reconsidering Move From City
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9  The United States Postal Service said today that it would reconsider moving its Northeast regional headquarters from New York City to New Rochelle if the Koch administration could find alternative space in the city at the right price.

title: U.S. Seeks Channels For 700 New AM Stations.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9  The Carter Administration plans to try to open the way for the creation of up to 700 AM radio stations and the development of lowpowered television stations that. could serve rural areas and even some urban communities.

title: PEKING SAYS TAIWAN CAN KEEP AUTONOMY UNDER UNIFICATION
description: PEKING, Jan. 9  Teng Hsiaoping, the senior Deputy Prime Minister, said today that Taiwan could retain both its government and its armed forces and remain fully autonomous after it was reunified with the Chinese mainland.

title: 600,000. of New York City's Pupils Will Get New ReadingAbility Test
description: A new citywide reading examination to diagnose the academic deficiencies of 600,000 publicschool children in New York City's elementary and junior high schools will be administered in October, Schools Chancellor Frank J. Macchiarola announced yesterday.

title: Hepatitis Carriers Called A New York School Peril
description: A potential new public health hazard from hepatitis carriers in New York City schools is being watched by Federal officials because of possible national implications.

title: Stars, Stripes and Memories at China Fete
description: PEKING, Jan. 9  In 1946 a Marine Corps pilot named John Glenn spent six months flying his Corsair fighter over the railroads and plains of northern China to check whether Communist guerrillas had sabotaged the supply lines of American truce teams.

title: Albee Directs Albee Coming to Columbia
description: Edward Albee, the Pulitzer Prizewinning playwright, will direct eight of his own oneact plays in a series of performances entitled Albee Directs Albee at Columbia University next month.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Tuesday, Jan. 9, 1979

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Injured Girl's Parents Plan to Sue M.T.A. Over Railroad Accident
description: The parents of Elizabeth McFadden, the 11yearold Long Island girl whose leg was reconnected by surgeons two weeks ago after it was severed by a Long Island Rail Road train, said they planned to sue the Metropolitan Transportation Authority for $7.5 million in damages.

title: How to End Watergate
description: In one sense, Watergate will end in nine days, when former Attorney General John Mitchell leaves a Federal prison camp in Alabama, the last of the convicted conspirators to be released. In another sense, the story is far from over and whether it is brought to a satisfactory conclusion depends on the Congress that convenes in five days.

title: The Dance: Walter Terry Looks Back
description: AS the title of his recent book, I Was There, indicates, Walter Terry, dance critic of The Saturday Review, has been present at dance events for the last 44 years. A master raconteur, he has shared the observations of a lifetime of dancewatching with lecture audiences throughout the country. On Monday at the church hall of Christ Church United Methodist, he brought his genial eye to bear on dance as religious expression in a program entitled Be Jubilant My Feet.

title: Young Man Slain in Lobby of Dingy Gramercy Park Hotel
description: The Hotel Irving, an illkept, residential hotel on Manhattan's historic Gramercy Park, was the scene early yesterday morning of its second homicide in three years. In the 1930's and '40's the hotel housed such movie stars as John Garfield, but over the years the quality of its clientele and maintenance has slipped.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: Splashy Colors

title: Taiwan AT A GLANCE
description: The island of Taiwan (formerly Formosa) has, with its related islands, an area of 13,892 square miles. It is separated from the Chinese mainland by the 100milewide Formosa Strait. Taiwan has a mountainous backbone that separates a narrow, rugged eastern portion from the broad, fertile western slope.

title: CBSTV Leads in Ratings for 2d Week
description: With powerful assists from the National Football League playoff game between the Los Angeles Rams and the Dallas Cowboys on Sunday and a threehour madefortelevision movie, The Incredible Journey of Dr. Meg Laurel, on Tuesday, CBSTV led the networks again last week in the audiencepopularity ratings, its second consecutive weekly victory.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: American Express offered to acquire McGrawHill for $34 a share, or $830 million in cash or securities, in one of the largest corporate takeover proposals on record. McGrawHill said its initial reaction was negative and urged stockholders to take no action until the company's board had considered the offer. The offering price represented a substantial premium over the publishing company's most recent market price of $26 a share on Monday. [Pages A1, D16.]

title: Obituary 7 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Schlesinger Urges Shift To Gas Use
description: Energy Secretary James R. Schlesinger, signaling a major shift in the Administration's energy policy, said yesterday that the United States would emphasize increased industrial consumption of natural gas, instead of coal, to reduce oil imports.

title: Topics
description: The National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences has just made an error in judgment. It has nominated, for one of its annual Grammy awards, former President Richard Nixon. This is no phonograph needle. The academy thinks that a recording of his televison interviews with David Frost deserves consideration as the best spokenword recording released in 1978.

title: U.S. Informing Turkey About Plan To Provide $300 Million Aid in 80
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9  The United States will inform Turkey, in discussions beginning tomorrow in Ankara, that it will try to provide it with more than $300 million in military and economic aid next year, Administration officials said today.

title: Coal Industry in a Slump As Utilities' Growth Lags
description: Just nine months after the end of one of the longest coal strikes in history, the coal business is in a slump. According to industry analysts, coalmining companies are practically mobbing the few customers who are currently buying. Prices are falling.

title: Takeover Targets Aid Stock Rise
description: With price gains in acquisition targets providihg part of the sparkle, the stock market resumed its winning ways yesterday. Trading volume expanded on the upswing that produced more than 1,000 advancing issues on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Katharine Graham to Step Aside As Publisher of Washington Post
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9  Katharine Graham, the publisher of The Washington Post, said tonight that she would relinquish control of this city's morning daily to her 33yearold son, Donald.

title: A.I.A.W. Seeks to Refine ThreeDivision Alignment
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 9  Buoyed by the increase in athletic budgets and the number of sports for women, voting delegates of the Association for Intercollegiate Athletics for Women (A.I.A.W.) zeroed in today on refining the division structure set up yesterday. That threedivision setup replaced the small collegelarge college system previously used.

title: Letters
description: To THE LIVING SECTION:

title: CAREY TO RESUBMIT 68 RECESS CHOICES
description: ALBANY, Jan. 9  Governor Carey agreed tonight to resubmit his 68 controversial recess appointments to the Republicanled Senate, which rejected them last week as an attempt to evade its power to advise and consent. The Senate agreed to review them promptly, and both sides insisted that their original actions were correct.

title: Husband and Wife in Rape Trial Are Friends Again, Lawyers Say
description: SALEM, Ore., Jan. 10 (AP) John and Greta Rideout, the couple involved in what was believed to be the first trial of a husband charged with raping his wife while they were living together, have told their lawyers that they have made um

title: High Court Bolsters Agencies
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9  In a decision that could significantly strengthen the hand of Federal regulatory agencies, the Supreme Court ruled today that once a judge has made specific findings against a corporation in a suit brought by the Securities and Exchange Commission, those adverse findings are binding against the company in any later suits brought by private shareholders.

title: Its Status Is More Than Token: Subway Kiosk Now Landmark
description: The subway kiosk in the middle of Broadway at 72d Street, one of the few remaining streetlevel architectural artifacts of the original IRT line built in 1904, was designated an official New York City landmark yesterday.

title: Place Is Found for 14 Retardates in Treatment Dispute
description: ALBANY, Jan. 9  New York State plans to start a special program near here to care for severely autistic and retarded children. It hopes to use the program to bring back to New York 14 children it has placed in a Rhode Island school that uses physical punishments and food rewards in its treatments.

title: Entertainment Events
description: METROPOLITAN OPERA, Lincoln Center, Poo. lenes Dialogues of the Carmelites. 8

title: U.S. TO MUTE VOICE IN CAMBODIA DEBATE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9  Although the United States has criticized Vietnam's invasion of Cambodia, the Carter Administration plans to refrain from playing an active role at the coming United Nations Security Council debate over Cambodia, Administration officials said today.

title: Yield 9.93% For Middle South Issue
description: Middle South Utilities, a holding company that controls five electric power companies in Arkansas, Louisiana, Mississippi and Missouri, raised $130 million of equity capital yesterday by selling 8.5 million shares of common stock.

title: U.S. MEDIATORS JOIN OIL WORKERS' TALKS
description: DENVER, Jan. 9  Top officials of the Government's mediation service flew to Denver today in an effort to head off a confrontation between the oil companies and the Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers union, whose bargaining over a new contract poses the first test of President Carter's 7 percent wagerestraint program.

title: EARNINGS
description: The Beech Aircraft Corporation, the nation's secondlargest producer of general aircraft, reported yesterday an increase of 11.9 percent in earnings for its first fiscal quarter ended Dec. 31 on a sales gain of 16 percent.

title: Around the Nation
description: NEWARK, Jan. 9 (UPI)  The New Jersey Board of Mortuary Science censured six Delaware funeral directors today for cremating the bodies of the Rev. Jim Jones and 28 of his followers without New Jersey licenses.

title: Con Ed RateRise Request Backed
description: Two hearing officers of the New York State Public Service Commission yesterday recommended that the Consolidated Edison Company be awarded almost all of the $228 million rate increase it applied for last May.

title: Deaths
description: ADLERMorrisOn Thursday, January 4. 1979 in Miami Beach, Florida. Beloved husband of Esther; dear father of Samuel & Herbert Adler and Mildred Teicher; loving grandfather of 7 grandchildren & 3 greatgranckhildren. Services were held Friday. January 5.

title: Bill Walsh Is Named 49er Coach
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 9 (AP) Bill Walsh was named head coach of the San Francisco 49ers today, becoming the fifth man to hold the job since Edward DeBartolo Jr. bought the team 22 months ago.

title: Excerpts From Text of Byrne Message
description: TRENTON, Jan. 9  Following are excerpts from the State of the State message Governor Byrne delivered to the joint session of the Legislature today:

title: Technology
description: IN Japan a new era of unmanned, fully automated factories, so flexible that they can readily be reprogrammed to turn out different products, is in the offing, far in advance of similar developments in other countries.

title: 60Minute Gourmet
description: ALMOST every ethnic kitchen has a name for stuffed veal rolls, and most of the names, in whatever language, boil down to veal birds. In French, the name is oiseaux sans tte, or birds without heads. It is curious how often I am asked about the origin of the name, when in fact it would seem to be facile and transparent. When the rolls are prepared, they look  with only a slight stretch of imagination  like the bodies of small birds without heads. It is a relatively small matter, but I prefer the name paupiette, which has to do with the olive shape of the meat when cooked.

title: 3 Cuban Exiles Go on Trial in the Murder of a Former Chilean Envoy
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9  Stringent security precautions were taken as the trial of three Cuban exiles charged in the murder of Orlando Letelier, the former Chilean diplomat, got under way here today with the start of fury selection.

title: Byrne Urges Additional Aid Be Provided to Assist Cities
description: TRENTON, Jan. 9  Governor Byrne told the Legislature in his annual State of the State message today that New Jersey's resources would not allow for major new programs, but he called for a shift in state aid formulas to provide extra financial help for distressed cities.

title: Unrest Perils India Economy
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 9 (UPI)  Banking operations brought to a standstill for the last 20 days by employees demanding more money left India's economy in chaos today.

title: $4 Million Is Reported Recovered And Returned in Medicaid Inquiry
description: Charles J. Hynes, New York State's special prosecutor for nursinghome frauds, said yesterday that more than $4 million recovered through his office's investigations had been returned to the Federal, state and local governments that contribute public money for nursing care through Medicaid.

title: Pop: Stars Join to Tape Benefit for UNICEF
description: CYNICISM comes cheap in the world of popular music, and indeed in show business in general, where selfcongratulatory benefits, awash in sentimentality, occur with depressing frequency.

title: Pemex Rises to the Challenge
description: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 9  Long considered both a symbol national pride and a monument to inefficiency and corruption, Mexico's state oil monopoly, Pemex, has surprised its many critics by rising to the challenge posed by the country's huge new oil discoveries.

title: Survivor Faces Massacre Suspect
description: BALTIMORE, Jan. 9  An elderly and ailing Latvian migr, at a deportation hearing here today, confronted a former Latvian policeman whom she accuses of aiding Nazi executioners in 1941 by herding Jews to their deaths before a machine gun.

title: TV: It's Awards Night For Circus Performers
description: FOR some time now the television networks have been presenting shows that award prizes to the best performers in various categories, generally chosen in ways that would not necessarily gain the approval of the Honest Ballot Association.

title: Pacific Phone Plans $2 Billion Outlay
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 9 (UPI) The Pacific Telephone Company said today that it would spend $2 billion on capital construction in 1979, a record amount.

title: A Close Call on the Ice at Central Park
description: After the warm and rainy spell over the weekend, the ice was thin at the boat lake in Central Park and warning signs were posted. One youngster ventured out anyway, and when a foot broke through the surface, he froze where he stood until help arrived. Today, bitter cold temperatures in the low 20's should firm up the ice a bit.

title: High Court Voids an Abortion Law Limiting Doctor Choice of Method
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9  By a 6to3 vote, the Supreme Court today declared unconstitutional a Pennsylvania law that required a doctor performing an abortion to choose the abortion method most likely to save the life of a fetus that might be old enough to survive outside the womb.

title: Republicans Will Put Off Project For Funds Through Credit Cards
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9  The Republican National Committee announced today that it had decided to put off its plan to raise money by promoting Visa credit cards and would join the Democrats in asking the Federal Election Commission if the project was legal.

title: Butcher, Baker, ChocolateMaker
description: IN the last few months there have been a number of new food shops of more than routine interest opening in the city, as well as a few expansions of wellestablished shops. In fairness, it must be stated that most of these new additions are still in the shakedown stage.

title: DROPS IN CURRENCY ERODE CHURCH GIFTS
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica, Jan. 9  Luiz Carlos Weil, a former brewery owner and CocaCola executive, regularly checks a computer in Geneva that monitors the fiscal state of the World Council of Churches. As with many other international organizations caught between fluctuating currencies and inflation, the recent printouts have not brought the church council good news.

title: Lakers Defeat Knicks, 106 to 94
description: Kareem AbdulJabbar's domination is more subtle these days. The 7foot2inch Los Angeles center showed his full maturity last night in the Lakers' 10694 victory over the Knicks before a crowd of 16,532 at Madison Square Garden.

title: Higher and Even Higher Education
description: The Special Events Committee of the National Collegiate Athletic Association has struck a mighty blow for higher education by recommending a postpostseason series of football games to determine a National Collegiate champion.

title: U.S. Revokes Knoetze's Visa; He's Out of Miami 10Rounder
description: Kallie Knoetze, the heavyweight boxer whose record as a constable in Pretoria provoked protests by antiapartheid groups here, yesterday became the first South African athlete barred from competition in this country when the State Department revoked his visa on grounds of moral turpitude.

title: Books of The Times
description: WHILE French existentialism regarded itself as a response to a contemporary crisis of personality, it is difficult for American readers to get on sociable terms with the existential

title: Turkey's 2d Train Crash in Week Kills 30, Hospitalizes Nearly 100
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 9 (AP)  A commuter train crashed into a parked passenger train in heavy fog today, killing 30 people and injuring nearly 100 in Turkey's second major train wreck in five days. Poor visibility was blamed.

title: Eight Flee Israeli Prison
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 9 (AP)  Eight prisoners, most of them convicted murderers and one a convicted Arab terrorist, escaped from an Israeli prison and are being sought, the authorities said today. The prisoners broke out of Ramla Prison yesterday and commandeered a taxi on the Tel AvivJerusalem highway, press reports said. The state radio said the men had hidden in the mess hall, then sawed through bars covering a ventilation shaft and escaped to the roof.

title: FamilyLed McGrawHill
description: At a Business Week staff meeting last spring, one of the magazine's reporters is said to have asked Harold W. McGraw Jr., chairman of McGrawHill, whether his company would consider a merger offer. Mr. McGraw, the story goes, said that an offer in the mid$30's range  more than 50 percent higher than the stock price at the time  might swing the family.

title: Eva Le Gallienne, 80, To CoStar in Movie
description: LOS ANGELES IT has taken Eva Le Gallienne 80 years to become a motionpicture star. Miss Le Gallienne, who will turn 80 years old tomorrow, will leave her Connecticut country house for Los Angeles on Saturday to costar with Ellen Burstyn and Sam Shepard in Resurrection.

title: A Multimillionaire Only Up to a Point
description: Not even the state lottery has given the meaning to the term instant millionaire that Kenneth Steier's bank has.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: MIDNIGHT SUN Some radiant music the other wet, gloomy evening down in Greenwich Village in two lounges  the area's newest and an oldtimer  were cheering reassurance from a pair of pros, Franklin Roosevelt Underwood and Lance Hayward. At their keyboards, both men knew how to brighten a slow night, with their easy smiles and comments making the informal atmosphere even cozier. Casually waging musical war on the weather, they were perhaps never better, judging by the reactions of their small, but enthusiastic audiences. Neither lounge has a cover or minimum tab.

title: Death
description: ROSENFELD  Sarah beloved wife of the late Louis, devoted mother of Sheila Bernstein and Lenore Levi, adored grandmother of Steen, Jeffrey, Jack, Michele and Carol. Dear sister of Ida Gilston, Bessie Rafield, Philip and Max Joseph. Services Boulevard Park West 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY Wed St 12 noon.

title: Chess:
description: The Maroczy Bind, a formation of pawns at QB4 and K4 as against the opponent's center pawn at Q3, is usually set up by White because it takes time for pawn moves and therefore lets niece mobilization lag. The idea is that White, with the advantage of the first move, can afford a small delay in getting the pieces out while Black cannot. Still, situations where Black can safely try the Maroczy Bind should not be overlooked.

title: Stamford Begins Final Phase of Renewal Effort
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Jan. 9  With considerable rhetoric about the future, officials will break ground here tomorrow for the new Stamford Town Center, the final and major section of this city's downtown urban renewal project. But the ceremonies will also celebrate what has already been done to transform a muddy wasteland into a major commercial hub that planners say proves it is still possible to save the centers of older cities.

title: N.C.A.A. to Maintain Division IA Makeup
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 9  One year after it waged a long and loud internal struggle over the makeup of its major college football group, the National Collegiate Athletic Association quickly and quietly voted today to maintain its present Division IA setup at 139 teams, including the eight Ivy League colleges.

title: Advertising
description: SMOKENDERS INC., Phillipsburg, N. J., which has been offering a system to break the cigarette habit since 1969, is close to finding out if television advertising is an efficient way of attracting its second 150,000 graduates.

title: TV: Formats of the Past
description: TONIGHT'S television looks like a tribute to the old days good, bad and indifferent. Suddenly, music, comedy and variety, formats that don't get much exposure anymore, are clogging the schedule. Furthermore, three of the major productions use a time period of 90 minutes, which has become almost extinct as more convenient one, twoand even threehour slots have taken over.

title: Spain's Military, Irate Over Terrorism, Is Bitter Toward Government
description: MADRID, Jan. 9  A savage campaign of terrorism by the Basque organization E.T.A., peaking just as the nation prepares for important elections, has strained relations between military and civilian authorities in Spain than at any other time since the death of Francisco Franco three years ago. This morning a Supreme Court judge was assassinated in Madrid. He was the sixth terrorist victim of the new year.

title: Rhodes to File House Complaint That May Force a Vote on Diggs
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP)  The House Republican leader, John J. Rhodes of Arizona, said today that he planned to initiate steps that could lead to a direct House vote to expel Representative Charles C. Diggs Jr., Democrat of Michigan, from the House.

title: News Summary
description: WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 10, 1979

title: Careers
description: MANY years ago women were not generally allowed to enter mines. The miners thought it would bring bad luck, and they often threatened to strike whenever they heard there might be a woman visitor. Nowadays companies have a hard time keeping women out of mines.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON. Jan. 9  The main problem of United States foreign policy in 1979, as Secretary of State Vance sees it, is to hold a fair balance in Washington's EastWest relations, and particularly to hold the Western alliance together and somehow maintain an evenhanded policy toward both China and the Soviet Union.

title: Croatian's Trial Begins Today
description: COLOGNE, West Germany, Jan. 9 (Reuters)  Stepan Bilandzic, a Croatian exile, will go on trial here tomorrow on charges of having supplied weapons for use against the Yugoslav Government.

title: Argentina and Chile Ask Pope to Mediate Border Dispute
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 9  The Vati??n has persuaded Argentina and Chile to ??ubmit their dangerous border dispute to mediation by Pope John Paul II.

title: Iran's New Leaders Immobilized By Opposition in Most Quarters
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 9  On its first working day in office, Iran's new Government found itself immobilized today by opposition from most sectors of the society.

title: Thaw in ChinaU.S. Ties May Unfreeze '49 Assets
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 9  The normalization of relations with China could mean the recovery of almost $200 million for American companies whose assets were frozen there 30 years ago, according to Government tallies.

title: Dr. H. Houston Merritt, Pioneer Neurologist, Dies
description: Dr. H. Houston Merritt, a pioneer neu rologist and a codeveloper of the antiepilepsy drug called Dilantin, died last night at the Neurological Institute of Columbia Presbyterian Hospital after a long illness. Dr. Merritt, a former dean of Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons, would have been 79 years old this week.

title: Environmental Agency Called Lax On Enforcing Air Pollution Curbs
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9  A new report by the General Accounting Office contends that the Environmental Protection Agency inadequately monitors, inaccurately reports and ineffectively enforces the nation's basic law on air pollution.

title: Firestone's End Urged in Proxy
description: AKRON, Ohio, Jan. 9  The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company's proxy statement, being received by 54,806 stockholders this week, contains a resolution that management liquidate the assets of the company and distribute the net proceeds to the stockholders.

title: Ranger 4Goal Surge Sets Back Blues, 53
description: ST. LOUIS, Jan.9.  For the first 19 minutes of play tonight, few in the crowd of 8,357 could have been blamed for harboring the notion that an upset was in the making for the hometoWn St. Louis Blues against the New York Rangers.

title: Mets Choose Heaton, Fastballer From L.I.
description: Neal Heaton was a Met fan once. He says he's still a Met fan, but now he likes the Yankees more. You don't like cheering on a losing team, he said.

title: Eclipse Award Voted for Phipps
description: Ogden M. (Dinny) Phipps, the chairman of the New York Racing Association, joined Affirmed and Seattle Slew yesterday as the winner of an Eclipse Award.

title: Allied Chemical
description: The industrial chemicals division of the Allied Chemical Corporation announced it had increased prices for its sulfuric acid by $3 a net ton. This increase will raise the price on sulfuric acid on the East Coast from $56.50 to $59.50, in the Middle West from $55.65 to in $58.65, in the South from $52.75 to $55.75 and in the Far West from $57.80 to $60.80.

title: 10% Reward Is Offered In $5 Million Robbery
description: Advertisements in local daily newspapers today offer a reward of up to 10 percent for information leading to the recovery of property or currency seized at the Lufthansa Airlines area at Kennedy International Airport Dec. 11. The robbers got approximately $5 million in unmarked United States currency and almost $1 million in jewelry.

title: Keeping Population Down
description: WASHINGTON.  A report by the United States Bureau of the Census, and an earlier one by two University of Chicago demographers, that the world's population growth has slowed down have been unfortunately misinterpreted.

title: The CareyAnderson Comic Opera
description: Only in America, or in Gilbert and Sullivan, could officers of state create a deadlock like the one Democratic Governor Hugh Carey and Republican Senator Warren Anderson devised for themselves last week.

title: World News Briefs
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 9  Gush Emunim, a Jewish ultranationalist group that has been trying to step up colonization of the occupied West Bank of the Jordan River, said today that it had received official assurances it would be permitted to start a Jewish suburb of the town of Nablus in two months.

title: Israeli Navy Commander Ousted After Winning Acquittal in Rape
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 9  Rear Adm. Michael Barkai was relieved as commander of the Israeli Navy tonight after winning acquittal in a rage case.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report yesterday said the Supreme Court in Washington had turned back challenges to a New York City law providing life imprisonment for the sale or possession of small amounts of hard drugs. It is a New York State law.

title: Mustard: Compliments for a Condiment
description: OF course, you know that black pepper is the most widely used spice in the United States today. But it you were to hazard a guess as to the second ranking spice, the chances are that you'd be wrong.

title: This Year the Truffle Will Be Rarer Still
description: NADAILLACLESEC, FRANCE Gloom has settled on this valley in Prigord as farmers contemplate poor harvest of one of the area's most famous delicacies, the truffle. It appears that this year, following a summer drought, there will be only four tons of truffles, about half of last years's crop, causing prices to double to a staggering $250 a pound in Paris and $384 in New York.

title: Merwin Wins Bollingen
description: The Yale University Library announced yesterday that W. S. Merwin had been awarded the 1979 Bollingen Prize in Poetry in recognition of his achievement in poetry over 25 years.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: St. John's Beats Baltimore By 7552
description: Reggie Carter pumped in 18 points, and St. John's shot 67 percent from the floor in the second half last night as the Redmen snapped a twogame losing streak by defeating the University of Baltimore, 7552, before 2,753 fans at Alumni Hall.

title: Global Buys Soccer Team
description: TORONTO, Jan. 9 (AP)  Global Communications Ltd. announced today that it had acquired the Toronto franchise in the North American Soccer League. Global operates a network of television stations in Ontario.

title: Ciuros Assails City Correction Unit On Suicide of Rikers Island Inmate
description: In a sharp attack on his own agency, the New York City Correction Commissioner, William J. Ciuros, said yesterday that the department was to blame for the recent suicide of an inmate with a known history of mental problems.

title: 3 Killed as Fire Destroys Private Home in Queens
description: At least three children died in a fire that swept through a private house late last night in the Kew Gardens Hills area of Flushing, Queens, the Fire Department said. Five children were injured, and firemen were searching for more bodies.

title: Deaths
description: DeGEORGEMichael, of 64 Bedford St. NYC on Jan 7, 1979, age 62, beloved husband of Anna (nee Rubino), devoted brother of Carmen Saimaso. Reposing at Parazzo Funeral Chapel, 199 Bleecker St, NYC. Funeral Mass Jan. 11 at 9:30 AM at The Church of Our Lady of Pompei, Bleecker & Carmine Sts. Manhattan. Interment at Mt. St. Mary's Cemetery, Flushing, NY. In lieu of flowers. contributions may be made to favorite charities.

title: Economic Scene
description: WITH the worsening of inflation in recent months and the prospect that consumer prices may climb at an annual rate of 8 to 10 percent in the first half of this year, President Carter is in the unenviable political position of trying to persuade labor to accept a cut in real wages to comply with his 7 percent wage guideline.

title: Justices Rule Dismissed Teacher Was Protected in Job Complaints
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9  The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that the First Amendment's guarantees of free speech protect a Government employee against retaliation for privately expressing complaints and opinions about working conditions to his superiors.

title: ZOUNDS! THE ARRIVAL OF FUTURE FOODS!
description: IS this the food of the future? Pizza with fabricated pepperoni and analog mozzarella, polyunsaturated prime ribs of beef with highC mashed potatoes; imitation caviar and sauteed softshell lobster?

title: Lobbyist Criticizes Enforcement By State Commission on Lobbies
description: ALBANY. Jan. 10  A publicinteres lobbyist today charged the state's Tern porary Commission on Lobbying with Ia> enforcement and with maintaining a su perfluous and expensive New York City office.

title: Vance Would Receive Sihanouk
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10  Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance will receive Prince Norodom Sihanbuk if the former head of state of Cambodia asks for an appointment, a State Department spokesman said today.

title: Last Union Settles in St. Louis Newspaper Strike
description: ST. LOUIS, Jan. 10 (AP)  A 52day newspaper strike here ended tonight when dockhands unanimously ratified new contract with the Pulitzer Publishing Company.

title: Skiing Painter Seeks To Duplicate Splash
description: Almost unnoticed in 1978, a year that produced such top rookies as Nancy Lopez in golf and John McEnroe in ten: nis, was ski racing's Andre Arnold, shy house painter from the small Austrian resort town of Solden.

title: Somoza's Foes Honor Editor Murdered a Year Ago
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Jan. 10 Memorial masses, demonstrations and a nationwide strike marked the first anniversary today of the assassination of a popular opposition newspaper editor whose death sparked the political unrest and violence that have gripped Nicaragua for the last year.

title: Net Up 15.6% At Fannie Mae
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association, the Governmentsponsored company traded on the New York Stock Exchange, yesterday reported from Washington that fourthquarter net income rose 15.6 percent to $51.1 million. or 91 cents a share, from $44.2 million, or 82 cents a share, for the 1977 final quarter.

title: 1,000 Police Attend Slain Officer's Rites
description: RUTHERFORD, N.J., Jan. 10 thousand police officers poured into this small North Jersey community to pay homage to Joseph J. Rybka Jr., the Bergen County sheriff's officer slain early Sunday while guarding a hospitalized burglary suspect. He was eulogized today for dying in service to his community and county.

title: Chinese Plan to Open 169 Special Colleges
description: PEKING, Jan. 10 (Reuters)  China will establish or reopen 169 specialized colleges, the Hsinhua press agency said today.

title: Sound
description: HAVING ushered in the new year with prophecies about the future of audio, let us further pursue the hot topic of digital recording upon which this future unquestionably hinges. Last week, we stressed the matchless virtues of digital recording: pristine sound emerging from a silent background, spanning an undiminished loudness range giving equal due to whispers and thunderclaps. The prospect is so enticing that one runs the risk of disregarding the rather sticky problems delaying entry into the digital era.

title: U.S. Is Urged to Develop Satellite for Solar Power
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 - By the turn of the century, a satellite the size of Manhattan Island could be collecting solar energy thousands of miles away in space and transmitting enough by laser beam to an antenna moored off Sandy Hook to meet almost all the electric power needs of New York City. The catch is the price  perhaps $12 billion.

title: Article 1 -- No Title
description: ASSAILS NEW CABINET: Karim Sanjabi, leader of Iran's National Front, an opposition group, tells reporters that the new civilian Government is formed by a lot of opportunist characters.

title: TV: NBC Documentary On China and Its Destiny.
description: WHEN President Carter announced the normalization of official relations with China several weeks. ago, television wheels quickly began turning to catch up with the broader ramifications of the story. CBS News, for example, hopped around the world via satellite for an hour, gathering asSorted reactions and analyses. Purely by chance, NBC already had a news crew in China looking at new developments in education. That piece can be seen tonight at 10 o'clock.

title: Pilot Center to Help Child Prostitutes
description: TONI and Hollywood were barely audible as they talked with their backs to the audience, but their words spoke eloquently to the occasion: the announcement yesterday at a news conference that the Federal Government is funding for the first time a treatment center for child prostitutes and children involved in pornography, ages 6 to 16. The program, designed as a pilot project, will be operated by Odyssey House, long knOwn for its work in rehabilitating drug addicts.

title: Afghan Insurgents Report Gains Against ProSoviet Government
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan, Jan. 10 (AP)  Moslem guerrillas report gains in their battle against Afghanistan's Sovietbacked Government but say they are short of supplies and are hampered by rough terrain, bad weather and internal conflicts.

title: Stage: Wedding Band By Alice Childress
description: HARTFORD

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Goldin Sees City Facing 82 Gap Of $1, 6 Billion
description: The Total Is $600 Million Above Koch's Projection

title: Shah's Key Foe Offers the West Terms for Oil
description: NEAUPHLE-LE-CHATEAU, France, Jan. 10  Ayatollah Ruholla Khomeini held out today the prospect of a nonaligned Iran enjoying good relations with the United States and its Western allies and supplying them with oil. As a condition, he warned, President Carter must withdraw support from Shah Mohammed Riza Palevi and stop interfering in our internal affairs.

title: World News Briefs
description: MADRID, Jan. 10 (UPI)  Supreme Court judge Miguel Cruz Cuenca, who was assassinated by gunmen as he left his home in Madrid yesterday, was buried in secret today in an attempt to prevent renewed rightwing demonstrations against the Government.

title: Calendar of Events: Books, Pots, Plants
description: Gardening Program, The Bartlett Arboretum, 151 Brookdale Road, Stamford, Conn.

title: McCracken Tells How He and the Metropolitan Opera Fell Out of Harmony
description: MUNICH. West Germany

title: Board Proposes InflationAccounting Rules
description: The accounting profession's rulemaking board proposed yesterday that the nation's larger companies be re quired to report the effect of inflation on their operations.

title: Not Falling Apart Like Skylab . . .
description: WINTHROP, Mass.  It was with sense of relief that I read the recent headlines proclaiming that Chicken Little, long maligned as the ultimate paranoid, was right. The sky is falline.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A music review in The Times yesterday said incorrectly that Beverly Sills's appearance with the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center on Tuesday night was her last on a stage in the city. The statement referred only to concerts; Miss Sills will sing at the Metropolitan Opera in Donizetti's Don Pasquale tonight, next Monday and Jan. 20, and will tour in the opera next spring.

title: Munson Faces Shoulder Surgery
description: Thurman Munson, the New York Yankees catcher, will undergo surgery on his right shoulder in Los Angeles tomorrow, the club announced yesterday.

title: Tapping Aids 911 Rescuers
description: BUFFALO, Jan. 10 (AP) When Teresa Cardina answered the 911 emergency police number late last night, she heard nothing by heavy breathing and a tapping sound.

title: Church Council Reaffirms Aid for Militant Groups
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica, Jan. 10  The central committee of the World Council of Churches voted today to continue a controversial program that grants aid to militant political groups but tempered its support by including a provision that is intended to give the program's critics a stronger voice.

title: Swiss Plan More Franc Intervention
description: GENEVA, Jan. 10  Switzerland's financial authorities confirmed today that top priority would be given this year to a liberal monetary policy aimed at curbing the upward pressures on the Swiss franc in foreign currency markets.

title: Wage Council Ends Loophole
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10  The Council on Wage and Price Stability closed a loophole today by modifying its 7 percent standard for pay increases. The council said that a Minneapolis corn-

title: Rorer and Narco Plan to Merge
description: The Rorer Group and Narco Scientific Inc. announced jointly that the directors of both companies had ap. proved an agreement in principle to merge Narco into Rorer.

title: News Summary THURSDAY, JANUARY 11, 1979
description: International

title: December Retail Sales Gained 1%
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP)  Retail sales increased by 1 percent last month, according to Government figures released today.

title: Envoys Wonder If Somalia Is Returning to Soviet Orbit
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia  In the Horn of Africa politics is constantly shifting, and nations seem to change their alliances as effortlessly as the giant floating sand dunes move about south of this capital city. As a consequence diplomats here appear to be constantly testing the wind and examining minute particles of sand.

title: Radio
description: 78 WNCN. Polonaise de Concert, Wieniawski; Excerpt from Concerto in D, J.C. Bach; Trumpet Concerto, Albinoni; Sonata for Vio. lin and Piano, (K. 302), Mozart; Salut d'amour, Elgar.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: Sports Today
description: BOXING

title: Getty and Mitsubishi Form U.S. Venture
description: TOKYO, Jan. 10 (AP)  Two Mitsubishi companies have established joint venture to develop uranium deposits in New Mexico with the Getty Oil Company, a spokesman said today.

title: U.S. to End Sale of $25 Savings Bond in 79
description: The $25 United States Savings Bond, which so many children received for birthdays, graduations and bar mitzvahs and which so many middleclass American workers bought each week through automatic payroll deductions, will be phased out next year. The $50 bond will take its place as the smallest denomination starting next Jan. 2.

title: Lighting the Way With Bare Bulbs
description: BARE bulbs usually figure in our idea of harshly lit cheap hotels, where they dangle depressingly from the ceiling, or of horrors hidden away in the fruit cellar, where they swing back and forth revealing the family skeleton. If we spot one in an empty apartment, our instinct to slap a shade over it to make the place a bit more homey. They are meant to shine, not to be seen, and are anything but stylish.

title: Events Today
description: EVERYMAN and THE IMPRISONMENT OF OBAT Alt., by Obotunde I iimere. Presented by the Negro Ensemble Company. At the St. Marks Playhouse, 133 Second Avenue, 8.

title: Ohio Senate Honors Hayes in Resolution
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 10 (UPI) The Ohio Senate adopted today a resolution honoring Woody Hayes for his many years of dedicated service to Ohio State University.

title: Puzzling Arctic Haze Is Identified As a Byproduct of Air Pollution
description: By The Associated Press

title: Alice Barbara Silha Wed To John E. Reimann 3d
description: Alice Barbara Silha and John Emile Reimann 3d were married last Saturday in the Westminster. Presbyterian Church in Minneapolis. The Rev. Donald Morrison Meisel performed the ceremony.

title: Urban Leaders Cool to Kahn
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP)  The Administration's chief inflation adviser, Alfred E. Kahn, ran into opposition from urban leaders today when he told  them the country could not now afford to reduce unemployment and rebuild the cities.

title: Piano: Lydia Artymiw Plays Schumann, Liszt at Y
description: LYDIA ARTYMIW's program Tuesday night at the 92d Street Y.M.Y.W.H.A. looked formidable on paper, starting with Schumann's Sonata in G minor (Op. 22) and continuing with nothing less than the Liszt Sonata. But Miss Artymiw (pro nounced arteemew), a Philadelphiaborn pianist, is one of those young lionesses of the keyboard who eats fearsome pieces alive. She flew at the Schumann in a headlong, almilst heedless, fashion that could have resulted in disaster but did not. This sonata demands a fevered approach, particularly in the last movement, and it is impossible to follow the composer's instructions literally. Miss Artymiw gauged the work's span cannily, however, and the feeling of constant acceleration was nicely suggested.

title: Taiwan Trade Surplus
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Jan. 10 (AP) Taiwan had a trade surplus of $1.68 billion in 1978, up from $849.8 million in 1977, the Government reported today. The Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics said exports last year rose 35.7 percent to $12.7 billion, while imports rose 29.5 percent to $11.02 billion.

title: Perils of the Wood Finisher
description: EARLY in the 18th century, when mahogany was introduced to England, the finish consisted of a thick coating of linseed oil and brick dust rubbed in with a flat cork. (I have never determined whether the dust was a coloring agent, an abrasive or a filler.) Later, varnish became the preferred finish.

title: BicycleTire Import Action
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP)  The Treasury Department today ordered special duties on imports of bicycle tires and tubes from a South Korean manufacturer. The Treasury declined to act against other manufacturers on the ground that the subsidies they received from the Seoul Government were insignificant. The major American maker of bicycle tires and tubes, the Carlisle Rubber and Tube Company of Carlisle, Pa., had said that it was injured by the imports.

title: Deaths
description: CANTOR  Hermina. The National Women's Division of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University expresses deep sorrow at the passing of Hermina Cantor ,longtime devoted member of the Women's Division, and beloved mother of Ellen Cohen,Officer of its New York Chapter. To the entire family we extend our heartfelt con. dolences.

title: Wolfpack Is Upset by Maryland
description: RALEIGH, N.C., Jan. 10 (AP)  Ernest Graham scored a gamehigh 24 points, including a turnaround jumper with seven seconds left in the second overtime tonight, to give Maryland an 8281 upset victory over eighthranked North Carolina State in an Atlantic Coast Conference basketball game.

title: Avery Claflin, Banker, Composer
description: Avery Claflin, a banker and composer whose musical works included a setting of the incometax form for fivepart chorus, died yesterday in Greenwich, Conn., after a short illness. He was 80 years old.

title: Easy Living and Easy Losing
description: Sports of The Times

title: Security Council to Meet Today on Crisis in Cambodia
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 10  The 15 nations represented on the United Nations Security Council agreed tonight to convene a formal meeting tomorrow afternoon to consider the Cambodian crisis.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Bank of America has appointed John R. Vella executive vice president and executive officer of the Bank Investment Securities division, and T.J. Flynn Jr. senior vice president for real estate loans.

title: Gala Will Honor Katherine Dunham
description: Katherine Dunham, who electrified Broadway audiences in the 1930's and 40's with her primitivedance revues, will be honored in a gala benefit to be held at Carnegie Hall on Monday, Martin Luther King Day. Miss Dunham will be presented with the 1979 Albert Schweitzer Music Award for her contribution to the performing arts and her dedication to humanitarian work.

title: The Wheel Spins for Resorts International
description: Resorts International is now responding to charges before the New Jersey Casino Commission that it is unfit to run a gambling casino. Resorts opened its Atlantic City gambling palace last May under a temporary license. Since then it has averaged profits of $600,000 a day, about $48,000 of which goes to the state and is allocated to programs for the elderly.

title: COMMODITIES Soybean Futures Drop; Cattle Also Fall Back
description: Declines in soybean prices highlighted the trading on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday. The downward move came at a time when high prices have dominated traders thinking.

title: U.S. Jets Will Visit Saudi Arabia As Show of Support in Tense Area
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10  Responding to Saudi Arabian appeals for a show of American support, the United States announced today that it was sending a dozen advanced F15 fighters and about 300 members of the Air Force to Saudi Arabia for a brief visit later this month.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS Dollar Slips From Lack Of a Support Statement
description: The dollar slid in New York yesterday after the Carter Administration said it planned no announcement soon on new dollarsupport measures. Rumors that the Government would shortly take steps to further strengthen the dollar had spurred it to a good performance against most currencies overseas.

title: Help for the Home Buyer
description: WHAT to buy  a coop, condominium, loft, brownstone, or a home in the suburbs? What about building that special beach house? How much will it all cost? And what about financing? Several lectures and seminars will be conducted in the city to guide the prospective buyer through the laby- ninth leading to home ownership. Here are some courses that will be offered:

title: Fed Assails Delay Plan For Checks
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP)  The Federal Reserve Board acted today to discourage banks from offering distant customers special services that deliberately delay the clearing of their checks.

title: Ski Liability Suit Settled
description: RUTLAND, Vt., Jan. I0 (AP)  An outofcourt settlement has been reached in a $150,000 ski liability suit filed against the Stratton Mountain ski area in Vermont. The suit was brought by Dean Ryder, 32 years old, of Carmel, N.Y., who sustained two broken legs in an accident at the ski area in 1976. The annoucement of the settlement was made by Judge James Holden of Federal Dist rict Court. No details were disclosed.

title: Tut's Old Neighborhood Is Now MassProducing Relics
description: LUXOR, Egypt  A wizened peasant sidled up to an American tourist strolling along the main street of this resort in Upper Egypt and furtively unrolled a tattered newspaper to display a small pharaonic carving. He pointed across the Nile to the yellow hills of the Theban necropolis and, his free hand making chopping motions, whispered in English, Only 10 pounds!

title: Knoetze Appeals Loss of Visa
description: Kallie Knoetze, the controversial South African boxer, appealed the revocation of his visa in Federal court in Miami yesterday.

title: Penguins 3, Canadiens 2
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 10 (AP) Peter Lee scored two goals to lead the Pittsburgh Penguins to a 32 triumph tonight over the Montreal Canadiens.

title: A.I.G. Alters Terms Of Mission Merger
description: Me American International Group said it had revised the terms of its merger proposal with the Mission Insurance Group because Mission was unable to meet one A.I.G. condition that Mission not agree to sell 606,000 of its shares to the American Financial Corporation.

title: Prices Hold As Traders Await News
description: Government and corporate bond prices held steady yesterday while traders and investors waited for today's reports on wholesale prices and the money supply and tomorrow's announcement of employment figures.

title: Group of 30 Will Study Economy
description: PARIS, Jan. 10  H. Johannes Witteveen, former managing director of the International Monetary Fund and once the Finance Minister of the Netherlands, is putting together a group of movers and shakers of the international economy in an effort to hammer out solutions to the world's economic problems, free from partisan political pressures and the glare of publicity.

title: Rally by Chicago Tops New Jersey; Bulls Rally in 4th Period To Defeat Nets, 120-116
description: United Press International

title: Sports News Briefs
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Jan. 10 (AP)  Bob Murphy put together string of nine 3's today on the way to a sevenunderpar 65 that tied him with Charles Coody for the firstround lead in the $275,000 Desert Classic. John Mahaffey was a shot behind.

title: JAMES V. O'GARA, 60 EDITORCOLUMNIST
description: James Vincent O'Gara, for 27 years an editor of Advertising Age, the most respected trade publication in its field, died yesterday of cancer in his home in Hempstead, L. I. He was 60 years old.

title: C.I.A. Had Contact With American in Letelier Case
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10  The covert operations branch of the Central Intelligence Agency once requested preliminary security approval to use the services of an American who last August pleaded guilty to conspiring to murder Orlando Letelier, the former Chilean Ambassador to the United States, according toa C.I.A. official.

title: Peace Corps Permitted To Return to Tanzania
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10  After a 10year absence, American Peace Corps volunteers will return to Tanzania this year as one aspect of the improved relations between the United States and the Government of President Julius K. Nyerere, Administration officials said today.

title: AIR POLLUTION PLAN FOR NEW YORK AIMS TO MODIFY 73 EDICT
description: ALBANY, Jan. 10  New York State today issued a plan for meeting Federal air standards in the New York City area that is markedly less stringent than one proposed in 1973.

title: . . . While Deploring the Loss
description: NEW PROVIDENCE, N.J.  On May 19, 1973, the world's first orbiting space station, Skylab, was launched. Three crews lived, worked and conducted experiments in Skylab. It was a remarkable achievement, proving that man can live and work in space for an extended period of time.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: BREZHNEV LOOKING TO ARMS PACT SOON
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 10  Leonid I. Brezhnev told six Republican Senators today that the Soviet Union wanted the quick conclusion of an armslimitation treaty despite its displeasure over improving relations between the United States and China.

title: The City
description: Police Get Ruling On 2dJob Conflicts

title: A Rhomboid of Rhetoric
description: A month ago, The Economist of London called it the crumbling triangle from Addis Ababa to Kabul. A fortnight ago, Zbigniew Brzezinski enlarged it to an arc of crisis stretching along the shores of the Indian Ocean. /Now Time magazine pictures a Soviet bdar peering hungrily over an even larger crescent of crisis from Indochina to southern Africa. The chorus swells, along with the size of the menaced terrain, chanting a dithyramb of danger.

title: Poll Shows Ford Trailing Reagan in a 1980 Race
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10  Ronald Reagan's support among Republicans for next year's Presidential nomination is much firmer than that of former President Gerald R. Ford, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: World Gold
description: WEDNESDAY, JAN 10, 1979

title: Bruce in Line to Replace Hayes
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 10 (AP)Coach Earle Bruce of Iowa State University appears to be the man Ohio State has settled on to replace Woody Hayes.

title: Two Correction Officers Indicted In Assault on 3 Rikers Prisoners
description: Two New York City correction officers were indicted yesterday on assault charges in connection with an attack with a knife and baseball bat on three Rikers Island prisoners last November, according to District Attorney Mario Merola of the Bronx.

title: U.S. Economy Is Held Awry
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP)  The United States economy is out of step with the rest of the world and should grow more slowly than the economies of other countries this year, the Bank of America's chief economist said today.

title: U.S. Asks Standards On Diesel Emissions; Proposal Upsets G.M.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP)  The Environmental Protection Agency proposed today strict emission standards for dieselpowered, engines, and General Motors reacted almost immediately by expressing concern that the proposals could ban large dieselpowered autos.

title: C.A.B. Unit Alleges Deceptive Pan Am Ads
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10  The consumer protection unit of the Civil Aeronautics Board charged Pan American World Airways today with unfair and deceptive advertising for a $99 roundtrip fare between New York and Los Aneeles and asked for a $50.000 fine.

title: Around the Nation
description: CLEVELAND, Jan. 10 (AP)  Cleveland's financial troubles became even more entangled today when a railroad balked at buying a $1.5 million stretch of right-of-way that the city wants to sell to avoid laying off some 400 employees.

title: A Plan for Increasing Radio Stations in U.S. Is Termed Inadequate
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10  Representative Lionel Van Deerlin, Democrat of California, has called inadequate the proposals by the Federal Communications Commission to increase the number of radio stations in the country.

title: John M. Stratton, at 85, Served On Several Corporation Boards
description: John M. Stratton, a lawyer who served on the boards of directors of several corporations, including Avon Products Inc. and H. J. Heinz, died yesterday at the Greenwich Hospital in Greenwich, Conn., after a long illness. He was 85 years old and had made his home in Greenwich since 1930.

title: THEODORE J. PAHLE
description: Theodore J. Pahle, a cinematographer and television cameraman, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 79 years old.

title: Article 3 -- No Title
description: Associated Press

title: Music: American Brass Quintet, With Some Guests
description: THE American Brass Quintet has long since proved that it needs no assistance devising and presenting stimulating concerts, but for its appearance at Carnegie Recital Hall on Tuesday night. it invited some expert guests to join in the performance of a varied sampling of music for brasses and winds.

title: Move to New York Set By Penn Central Corp.
description: The Penn Central Corporation, a real estate holding company formed from the remnants of the bankrupt railroad, disclosed plans yesterday to move its corporate headquarters from Philadelphia to New York, while keeping most of the company's 300 employees in Philadelphia.

title: ESSAY Now We Know
description: ESSAY Now We Know

title: Justice for the Unjust Parking. Tickets
description: George Turner slammed his fist on the wooden table, snatched his woolen cap from his head, jumped from his seat and rushed toward the grayhaired man who was examining the parking ticket.

title: Taiwan Auto Maker Gets Chase Loan
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Jan. 10 (UPI) The Chase Manhattan Bank has agreed to extend a $16 million loan to Taiwan's Yue Loong Motor Company to finance expansion projects, bank sources said today

title: German Workers Accept Steel Pact
description: BONN, Jan. 10  West German steelworkers voted today to end their 44dayold strike but at the same time signaled a grafting threat to the country's onceplacid labor relations.

title: Cargill Holdings Extends Offer
description: Cargill Inc. announced that its wholly owned subsidiary, Cargill Holdings Inc., now owned or had under contract about 89.5 percent of the MBPXL Corporation common stock. Cargill Holdings said it had extended its tender offer for any and all shares of MBPXL common stock at $27 a share until Jan. 22. The offer was originally scheduled to expire Jan. 8.

title: Fever Redone for PG Rating
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 10  Some time in March, Saturday Night Fever  the sexually explicit, obscenitystudded, wildly successful movie that has already brought Paramount Pictures $100 million in film rentalswill return to movie theaters wearing a demure PG rating.

title: Bergen Brunswig Sees Higher Profits
description: Emil Martini Jr., chairman of the Bergen Brunswig Corporation, said that secondquarter operating earnings would be substantially above a year ago and that if the t rend continued (or the year there is a strong possibility 01 a dividend increase.

title: The Region
description: The Region

title: Chilean Freed Temporarily
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 10  A Chilean Army colonel wanted by the United States to stand trial for the assassination in Washington of Orlando Letelier has been temporarily freed to hand over command of his regiment in a military ceremony.

title: Dr. William Y. Elliott, 82, Dies; A Harvard Professor Emeritus
description: William Yandell Elliott, professor of history and political science emeritus at Harvard University and a former adviser to Government agencies, died Tuesday at his home in Haywood, Va. He was 82 years old.

title: Norway Warns Sweden on Oil Deal
description: STOCKHOLM, Jan. 10 (Reuters) A 20year agreement that allows Sweden regular oil supplies from Norway will fail if Norway is unable to take a 90 percent stake in Volvo, the Swedish auto maker, Bjartmar Gjerde, the Norwegian Energy Minister, said today,

title: House Urged to Get More N.C.A.A. Facts
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 10  Accusing the National Collegiate Athletic Association of having insulted Congress, Representative James Santini, Democrat of Nevada, said today that he would press for more Congressional hearings into the operation of the N.C.A.A. He indicated that new hearings might explore whether or not the N.C.A.A. is in violation of antitrust laws in the way it awards television contracts and restricts TV appearances by member institutions.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Manhattan College Gives Hauge Economic Chair

title: Bakhtiar Says His Regime Faces Danger of a Coup
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 10  Prime Minister Shahpur Bakhtiar was quoted today as having said that Iran faces the danger of a military coup but that he still expects the Shah to leave the country.

title: A Potter Turns To Tapestry
description: IF you can't draw a straight line, Paulus Berensohn advised, draw a crooked line and draw it over and over again. And to prove how easy it is, Mr. Berensohn used the crooked line as the starting point in the singular designs of his needlepoint and bargello tapestries on exhibition at Greenwich House Pottery, 16 Jones Street, until Jan. 27.

title: H.F.C. to Delay Merger Completion
description: The Household Finance Corporation and the American Investment Company have informed Federal District Judge Frank J. McGarr that completion of their proposed merger would be suspended pending a ruling in a Federal antitrust suit filed on Tuesday in Chicago.

title: Dance: Streep Presents Experimental Program
description: SUGGESTIONS, which Harry Streep 3d's Third Dance Theater offered at the American Theater Laboratory on Tuesday evening, was the sort of work in which, first, the first thing happened. Then the second thing happened  but for no apparent reason. It was simply the second thing that happened.

title: Mr. Teng's Taiwan Doctrine
description: China's Teng Hsiaoping showed considerable flexibility in sketching, for a delegation of American senators, an autonomous future for Taiwan. He said the island could retain its government and armed forces indefinitely along with its nonCommunist social and economic system. And while China would continue to assert sovereignty over Taiwan, there was no timetable for its integration with the Communist mainland.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: HOMECOMING The Bellamys of Old London and their servants are due back on Sunday, shifting from educational television to national, commercial outlets and an estimated 50 million American home screens. In a salute to the rerun of  the popular Upstairs, Downstairs, with a bonus of eight unshown chapters, a local gallery has arranged a new display of illustrations and cartoons by prominent artists on the theme of domesticity and domestics

title: Connors and McEnroe Start Off Impressively in Garden Tennis
