description: To the Editor:

title: Prying Out Bell Canada Data, Via U.S.
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 10  Canada's largest consumer group, which has been fighting the country's largest utility over its rate structure, has had to go to Washington to obtain information has been unable to get in Ottawa.

title: Louisville Gas Offering
description: The Louisville Gas and Electric Company, a largely coalbased utility that serves northcentral Kentucky, priced an offering of one million shares of common stock late yesterday at $21 a share, the closing price on the New York Stock Exchange. The stock, which yields 9.50 percent, is being sold through a group led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: Tunisian Chief Home From Bonn
description: BONN, Jan. 10 (Reuters)  President Habib Bourguiba of Tunisia flew home today after more than two months in a hospital here, a Tunisian Embassy spokesinan said. The spokesman had no details of the President's condition, but embassy sources said his health was restored. They said Mr. Bourguiba had suffered mainly from disturbed sleep.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Wednesday, Jan. 10, 1979

title: Deaths
description: O'GARAJames V Jr. of Herrin stead, L I. on January 101h, 1979. Editor of Advertising Age. Beloved husband of Marguerite H. (nee Pot). mer). Beloved father of Maureen, James V. III and Erin O'Gara. Re posing Barnes.SorrentIno Funeral Home, 539 Hempstead Avenue. West Hempstead. Mass of Resurrection, SI. Thomas the Apostle, R C. Church, West Hempstead, 10 A.M. Saturday, January 13th. Infer. menu St. John's Cemetery, Middle Village, N.Y. Memorial service, 11 A.M., Wednesday, January 17th at the Lady Chapel, St. Patrick's CAthedral, N.Y.C. Visitation Thursday 7 9:30 P.M. and Friday 2.5 and 7.91n

title: HOW TO AID THE FUND
description: Checks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and forwarded to P.O. Box 5193, Church Street Station, New York, N.Y. 10249, or to any of the following organizations:

title: Home Beat
description: Mr. Puzzle

title: 2 Sports Teams Continue Help To the Neediest
description: A second gift on behalf of the New York Rangers and the New York Knickerbockers has been received by the 67th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: 2 REPUBLICANS PLAN ANEW TAXCUT BILL
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10  Two Republican members of Congress, Representative Jack F. Kemp of upstate New York and Senator William V. Roth Jr. of Delaware, announced today that they would again sponsor a bill to cut taxes by 30 percent over the next three years and would offer a companion measure to limit increases in Government spending.

title: U.S. Judge Tells Dissident Steel Haulers to End Strike
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 10 (AP) Federal district judge today ordered dissident steel haulers to end a violent nineweek strike and threatened to jail the group's leaders if the order was ignored. But the steel haulers immediately appealed the decision and said the strike would continue.

title: Olinkraft Tie To Manville Set
description: Olinkraft Inc. and the Johns-Manville Corporation said the Federal Trade Commission reported that their findings last month satisfied the Government agency's request for additional information about the comna- nies proposed merger. As a result, the two companies said they intended to close the merger of Olinkraft into wholly owned subsidiary of Johns-Manville on Jan. 19.

title: CREDIT MARKETS Massachusetts Sells Minibonds Quickly
description: BOSTON, Jan. 10  The State of Massachusetts sold $1 million worth of fiveyear, taxexempt minibonds yesterday directly to the public in denominations of $100, $500 and $1,000. The issue promptly sold out.

title: I.T.T. Sees 15% Rise In 1978 Earnings
description: Lyman C. Hamilton, president and chief executive officer of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, said that estimated consolidated earnings for the company in 1978 would be up about 15 percent, from the $4 a share earned in 1977. This is somewhat below the $4.80 to $5 a share projected for the company by Wall Street analysts.

title: Dividends
description: WEDNESDAY, JAN. 10, 1979

title: The TaiwanPeking Game, Like Chinese Chess, Is Subtle
description: PEKING, Jan. 10  In Chinese chess, the object is not to directly capture an opponent's pieces, but to gradually surround and isolate them. This strategy of avoiding a costly frontal assault and instead subtly undermining the enemy is also a basic precept or traditional Chinese statecraft.

title: Husband Says Wife's Rape Charge Saved Marriage
description: SALEM, Ore.. Jan. 10 (AP)  John Rideout said today that his trial and acquittal on a charge of raping his wife had forced both of them to change their lives and had inspired them to give their marriage another try.

title: Michael Koainenko
description: Fire Kills Three Children in Queens

title: U.S. AGAIN STRESSES SMOKING'S DANGERS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 10  Federal health officials will tell the American public tomorrow that cigarette smoking is the largest preventable cause of dea.th in the United States.

title: A.M.C. Sets U.S. Sales Of Renaults
description: SOUTHFIELD, Mich.. Jan 10  The American Motors Company announced today that it would start importing cars made by the French concern of Renault for sale in A.M.C. showrooms, while expanding its exports of Jeeps through the Renault dealer network in Europe and South America.

title: Mergers Down 5% Last Year
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 10 (AP)  Corporate merger and acquisition activity declined 5 percent in 1978, but there were more large mergers worth at least $100 million than in 1977, according to W. T. Grimm & Company.

title: Robert Simpson, 57, Executive Of Chemical Bank and ExEnvoy
description: Robert Simpson, vice president in the international division of the Chemical Bank, died Tuesday at Doctors Hospital in New York. after a long illness. He was 57 years old and lived at 141 East 88th Street.

title: ExCity Official Is Cleared Again On Bus Shelters
description: Mautner Has No Conflict of Interest, Panel Finds

title: Air Travelers Find Service Declining
description: You people in the aisle, get to your seats, a voice snapped over the loudspeaker. But the New Yorker struggling to his seat on the T.W.A. airliner out of Los Angeles had had enough. He dropped his bag and shouted: I've been abused by you people all week, and I'm not going to take it anymore.

title: Koch Says He's Failed To Justify Fund Cuts To Minorities in City
description: Mayor Koch, acknowledging difficulties with New York City's black and Hispanic communities, said yesterday that he had failed to convince minoritygroup leaders that his budget cuts were not racially motivated.

title: Two ByElection Triumphs Help Mrs. Gandhi's Comeback Efforts
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 10  Indira Gandhi's attempt at a political comeback appeared to have gained strength yesterday with decisive victories by her party in byelections for two vacant seats in Parliament.

title: I.C.C. Relaxes Trucking Rule
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11  The Interstate Commerce Commission voted today to relax the restrictions against trucking competition in hauling freight between cities and local airports.

title: Oklahoma Raises Salary
description: NORMAN, Okla., Jan. 11 (AP) The University of Oklahoma Regents voted today to give Barry Switzer, its football coach, a $2,000 raise. Switzer's salary will be $40,000 a year. The regents also permitted Switzer a $3,000 annual expense allowance.

title: Head's New Man on the Slopes Promotes Ski Line for AMF
description: In the late 1950's and early 1960's, when skiing was just beginning to become a bigtime participant sport, Head skis were all the rage. They were the first successful metal skis and they revolutionized the sport. They were more durable than wood and gave better control. With their handsome matteblack color, they meant instant status on any slope.

title: Kenneth Koch Stages Two Plays
description: Although Kenneth Koch is known primarily as a poet  for such volumes as The Art of Love, The Duplications and The Pleasures of Peace  and even as an educator (he has written several books about teaching children how to write poetry), he is also a playwright with a number of plays to his credit. A dozen or so of them have been produced Off Broadway and Off Off Broadway in the last 20 years.

title: U.S. Ends Trust Charge In Iowa Beef Venture
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (UPI)  The Government has dropped anticompetitive charges against Iowa Beef Processors Inc., the nation's largest beef packer, for its joint venture with feedlots in northwestern states.

title: New Rochelle Battles to Brighten Its Image
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Jan. 11 Nearly two years ago this southern Westchester County community overlooking the Long Island Sound hired a publicrelations firm to help improve its persistently poor image, an image local leaders believed hindered the city's rebuilding and revitalization efforts, as well as its ability to attract new business.

title: Publishing: A New Birth For Kenyon Review
description: THE Kenyon Review (193970), one of the most influential periodicals in American letters and the cathedral church of the New Criticism, is being revived  although not with quite the same philo- sophical or esthetic outlook. The first issue of the regenerated quarterly will be unveiled at a luncheon at the Plaza next Wednesday. The editors are Ronald Sharp and Frederick Turner, both associate professors of English at Kenyon, and from Gambier, Ohio, where Kenyon has its site, the two men spoke about the rebirth of the magazine.

title: MANHATTAN
description: WEEKEND MOVIE CLOCK

title: Labor Board Aide Is in Contempt For Defying Court's Bid for Data
description: Judge Henry Bramwell of Federal District Court yesterday found the general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board, John S. Irving, in contempt of court for refusing to depart from board policy and produce in court confidential union membership cards.

title: A $30,000. Slim Watch
description: GENEVA, Jan. 11 (Reuters)  A Swiss watch company unveiled today what it said was the slimmest watch in the world  only 0.07 of an inch thick. The company, Jean Lassale of Geneva, said it would produce three of the slim watches every month at a price of $30,000 each.

title: Iowa Station Losing Its National Voice
description: DES MOINES, Jan. 9  An Ozark Mountains whittler once said that dull, flat land produces dull, flat men. The old rustic must not have owned a radio, else he would have heard, as anyone in America can on any given night, the soft warblings and sharp ruminations of a number of minds in Iowa, state that could have been shaped with a rolling pin.

title: P.S.C. Acts to Weigh Phone Rate Increases Totaling $240 Million
description: ALBANY, Jan. 11 (AP)  The New York Public Service Commission cleared the way today for consideration of a $240 million rate increase requested by the New York Telephone Company.

title: TV Weekend
description: AS a love story, Champions, a Love Story is generously stocked with the solid advantages of an appealing premise. several fine performances and some splendid photography. Then, about threequarters of the way through, the plot suddenly switches gears, preferring the kind of outoftheblue tragedy that gives. G.E. Theater presentations an opportunity to pounce on upbeat endings.

title: New Evidence Is Disclosed to Link Peptic Ulcers of Many to Heredity
description: The strongest evidence to date support. ing a longheld medical theory and observation  that genetic factors are at the root of many peptic ulcers  was reported yesterday by a team of researchers from California and Texas.

title: Businesses Set 3% Rise In Spending
description: WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) Businesses plan to increase their spending on plant and equipment by a sluggish 3 percent this year after inflation is taken into account, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Stacy Keach Is Taking Lead Role in Deathtrap
description: Stacy Keach will assume the leading role of Sidney Bruhl in Ira Levin's comedythriller Deathtrap, at the Music Box Theater next Monday. He replaces John Wood, who is going to England's National Theater to appear in The Broad Land, a play by Arthur Schnitzler, directed by Peter Wood.

title: Art: Impressionist Among Englishmen
description: MATTHEW SMITH (18791959) was the best English painter of his generation. And generation in this context is more than a flag of convenience. Matthew Smith owed his first name to Matthew Arnold, the poet and critic who shaped so much or latevictorian sensibility. He came of age in the last year of the 19th century. Victorian attitudes constricted his childhood and boyhood, and his development was further hindered by a particularly gruesome experience of life on the Western Front during World War I. Such was the delicacy, and such the hesitation, with which he addressed the everyday business of life that very few people would have laid money on his becoming a painter of any stature.

title: The Economy
description: Producer prices rose eighttenths of 1 percent in December, bringing the increase to 9.1 percent for 1978, the biggest gain in prices at the wholesale level since 1974, the Commerce Department reported. The sustained increases at the producer level suggested that no decline in the inflation rate was in prospect for the immediate future. [Page D1.]

title: Advertising
description: TALENTED Shari Lewis and her equally talented little hand puppets are .the stars of the publicservice spots aimed at making this nation's young more aware of nutrition. They have been done by the NBC Television Stations Division and are going to run on the five companyowned stations, the network and, it is hoped, on many of the stations with network affiliation, beginning this month.

title: City Decides to Seek a Loan in Open Credit Market
description: The Koch administration, reported earlier this week to be disinclined to enter the public credit market to borrow money, now intends to go there for early sale of $100 million in shortterm notes.

title: Children's Book Winners Named
description: The nation's major prizes for authors and illustrators of children's books will be given to Ellen Raskin, author of The Westing Game, and Paul Goble, illustrator and author of The Girl Who Loved Wild Horses.

title: Iran's New Chief Calls for Backing Of Arabs, Especially Palestinians
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 11  Prime Minister Shahpur Bakhtiar, seeking a vote of confidence for his new Government, presented his program to the lower house of Parliament today.

title: Stocks Up on Good MoneySupply and Dollar News
description: A rousing rally in key glamour issues led the stock market higher late yesterday. The turning point was news of strength displayed by the American dollar in foreignexchange dealings.

title: Women in Greece Join Military for First Time, Despite Protests of Feminists
description: ATHENS, Jan. 11 (AP)  Hundreds of women enlisted in the Greek military Wednesday over the objection of women's liberation groups who charged that the volunteers would offer themselves for further exploitation in the traditionally maledominated society.

title: Naming a Horse as Tough as Picking a Winner
description: When she goes to sleep at night, Lorraine Marshall can't get the names out of her mind. When she wakes up in the morning, they're still there, waiting to be approved or rejected.

title: Fun for Children
description: Origami Workshop

title: 7.4% TaxFree Bonds Sell Fast
description: A $150 million issue of mediumgrade taxexempt revenue bonds was marketed yesterday at yields as high as 7.40 percent, and it sold rapidly, especially late in the afternoon as the credit markets moved up in price.

title: Students at Purchase Have a Go at Figaro
description: The people I'm working with are total innocents, said Patricia Brooks, the former New York City Opera soprano, in an emphatic tone she might have used to report that they were virtuosos.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Carpenter Technology Corporation, Reading, Pa., a manufacturer of stainless, highalloy steels, has elected Howard O. Beaver Jr. chairman and chief executive officer, and Paul R. Roedel, president and chief operating officer.

title: Soviet Aides Say Brezhnev Put Off U.S. Trip Because of Teng's Visit
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 11  Highly placed Soviet officials have acknowledged for the first time that Leonid I. Brezhnev put off his trip to the United States this month to avoid being upstaged by the visit later of Deputy Prime Minister Teng Hsiaoping of China.

title: Football Deaths Reported At Lowest Level Since '52
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 11 (UPI) The American Football Coaches Association has been told that football deaths in 1978 have dropped to their lowest level since 1952.

title: The City
description: Police Commissioner Robert J. McGuire said yesterday that the Police Department had ordered 2,200 special bulletresistant clipboards that can be used as shields by officers.

title: Deaths
description: ACKERMANN  Katherine Schumacher. On January 10. Beloved mother of Dorothea Hecht and Jean Marie Ackermann. loving grandmother and great grandmother. Service at Frank E. Campbell, Madison Ave at 81 St, today Friday at 2PM. Interment Trinity Church Cemetery.

title: Article 1 -- No Title
description: REMEMBER THE NEEDIEST

title: Five in Family Die in Fire
description: TRAPP, Ky., Jan. 11 (UPI)  A fire early today killed five members of a Clark County family that moved into its twostory frame house just a week ago. Three other family members who had been sleeping on the ground floor escaped. The five victims were upstairs and could not get out.

title: Hudson's Bay Is Store Victor
description: TORONTO, Jan. 11  Sears, Roebuck & Company has a new partner in the ownership of its Torontobased affiliate, SimpsonsSears Ltd.

title: At the Movies
description: VISCONTI was like a guru to me, Giancarlo Giannini said. He gave me an incredible lesson in life near the end of his own life. He was very ill, paralyzed, when we were making The Innocent. He knew he was near death, but he spoke of it with great amusement.

title: Notes on People
description: When, earlier this week, opponents to a plan to open a McDonald's hamburger outlet on Martha's Vineyard won their battle, it was noted that among members of the Stop the Mac Committee were the cartoonist Jules Felifer, Ruth Gordon and Gerson Kanin, and the rock stars James Taylor and Carly Simon.

title: Chairman of Resorts Testifies on Political Contributions in Bahamas
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Jan 11  The chairman of Resorts International, James M: Crosby, testified today that the company made political contributions in the Bahamas totaling $497,500 in cash and checks in four different years in this decade.

title: Sihanouk Appeals to U.N. Council To Get Vietnam Out of Cambodia
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 11 Overcoming opposition by the Soviet Union, Prince Norodom Sihanouk of Cambodia succeeded tonight in bringing an official appeal for help against the Vietnamese invasion of his country to the United Nations Security Council.

title: Those Killer Cigarettes
description: So now we have a new Surgeon General's report on the health hazards of smoking and the message is even grimmer than it was from the same office 15 years ago. The evidence is much stronger that cigarette smoking is implicated in heart disease and cancer, the nation's leading killers; and new data now link it to many more bronchial diseases, allergies and adverse reactions to drugs. Cigarettes pose particular risks to pregnant women, children and workers exposed to toxic chemicals. Summing it all up, H.E.W. Secretary Califano, a reformed threepacksaday addict, concludes that smoking is even more dangerous  indeed, far more dangerous  than was supposed in 1964.

title: She's Confronting the Tensions Between Black Men and Woznen
description: At the age of 27, Michele Wallace is an unlikely hell raiser. She grew up on Harlem's exclusive Sugar Hill, spent summers abroad, got a degree from City College and then a job teaching journalism at New York University. She has also been a researcher for Newsweek.

title: Tokyo Stocks Boom On Low Loan Rates
description: TOKYO, Jan. 11  The Tokyo Stock Exchange, fed by an increasing flood of institutional money, boomed last year, and the exuberance appears to be spilling over into, and even expanding, this year.

title: Music: Veri and Jamanis
description: A full evening of music by Sergei Rachmaninoff for two pianos sounds like too much of a good thing. Such a program was given in Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday night by Frances Veri and Michael Jamanis, and it was a lot more fascinating than might have been expected. For one thing, there was a chance to hear the Six Pieces (Op. 11) for piano duet and the twopiano version of Symphonic Dances (Op. 45).

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Thursday, Jan. 11, 1979

title: American Express Gets Loan
description: The American Express Company, determined to take over McGrawHill Inc., the giant publishing company, has borrowed $700 million to help finance the deal, wellplaced industry sources disclosed yesterday.

title: Woman Mugged On IRT as 20 Watch
description: A 55yearold Liberty, N.Y., woman was struck on the head with a blackjack and slashed on the neck and arm with a knife by a mugger who took $22 from her purse aboard a Lexington Avenue IRT subway train in the Bronx Wednesday. The woman later told the transit police that 20 other passengers aboard the car stood by in silence as it happened.

title: 69th Boat Show Sails Into City Tomorrow
description: The 69th annual National Boat Show officially opens its doors to the public at 10 A.M. tomorrow for a nineday stand at the Coliseum. But sails were unfurled, pennants raised and potted palms were in place yesterday as marine dealers surveyed the more than 500 boats and thousands of engines and accessories on display during the first of two trade days.

title: A Family's Resolve: Get Rid of Shah at Any Price
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 11  The four room mudgray brick house of All Rais Ghasem lies in a teeming district of southern Teheran, one of the many pockets of resistance to the Shah that stretch south of the luxurious residential areas.

title: The Region
description: PRINCETON, NJ. (AP)  The New Jersey Board of Medical Examiners has refused a request by Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich that his license to practice medicine and surgery be reinstated immediately. The board ruled that the temporary suspension would remain until an administrative licensereview hearing had been completed, or until further order of the board. No date has been set for the hearing.

title: `Funny Ladies, Movie Festival, At the Regency
description: IF you liked Funny Girl, you may just love Funny Ladies. Funny Ladies, you see, isn't just one movie. It's 40 movies, grouped as the new series at the Regency Theater on Broadway and 67th Street. Beginning Sunday and running for seven weeks, the series at the

title: George Washington Bridge Is Partially Darkened
description: The strands of lights that hang from the suspension cables on the George Washington Bridge were shut off yesterday when this picture was made at about 1 A.M. During Daylight Saving Time, these lights remain on until mid night, but on Eastern Standard Time, they are extinguished at 10 P.M. to save energy during the longer nights. This view was made from 181st Street looking westward across the Hudson River. Henry Hudson Parkway is in foreground.

title: Auctions
description: AMERICANA auctions in theweeks ahead surpass in number and importance those held in New York during the opening weeks of the Bicentennial, three years ago. Although the first such sale this year is at Christie, Manson & Woods, Park Avenue at 59th Street, on Saturday, Jan. 20, at 10:30 and 2 P.M., the most important events begin later in the month with the dispersal of the late Stewart E. Gregory's folkart collection Jan. 27. This will be followed by the auction of the late Nathaniel Stein's autographs Jan. 30 and a fourday, giantsize, American furnishings extravaganza Jan. 31 through Feb. 3, whose dramatic climax will come with the gaveling away of the Richard Titelman collection of Newport, Philadelphia and Massachusetts treasures. These three sales will all be at Sotheby Parke Bernet, Madison Avenue at 76th Street. And there's more. An Americana sale will be held at Plaza Art Galleries, 406 East 79th Street, on Feb. 1, and two numismatic sales devoted to North American issues are scheduled  one by Harmer Rooke, 3 East 57th Street, will take place Thursday, and the other by Stack's, 123 West 57th Streets, on Feb. 2 and 3.

title: Thailand Preparing Camps for Cambodian Soldiers
description: ARANYAPRATHET, Thailand, Jan. 11  Thai officials and international relief workers began preparing holding camps today for troops of the defeated Cambodian Government who, they said, might soon be forced into Thailand by advancing Vietnamese units.

title: Gasification Process Test
description: SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Jan. 11  Executives of the AllisChalmers Corporation and the Illinois Power Company said today that they expected to demonstrate electricity could be generated 10 percent to 25 percent cheaper with a coal gasification process than with coal under current environmental regulations and existing technology.

title: Business and the Law
description: WHENEVER courts have been racked by delay, the traditional solution has been to add judges and court facilities. The overloaded dockets of most Federal courts presumably had something to do with the Congressional approval last year of 152 new Federal judgeships  a onethird increase in the number of active Federal judges.

title: MANDEL CONVICTION REVERSED IN APPEAL
description: RICHMOND, Jan. 11  A Federal appeals court overturned today the convictions of former Gov. Marvin Mandel of Maryland and five codefendants on charges of political corruption and mail fraud.

title: The Weaning of the Navy
description: Phase Two of President Carter's drive to make sense of the Navy in which he served has now begun. Phase One was last summer's justified veto, upheld by the House, of another $2.4billion nuclear supercarrier. Phase Two began with a rejection of new Navy proposals for a 90,000ton nonnuclear supercarrier.

title: 55 Black Directors Listed at 90 Companies
description: Some 90 major companies now have blacks on their boards, according to a recent compilation by Black Executive Letter, a newsletter for black corporate executives.

title: U.S.Canadian Talks Gain
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 11 (AP)  United States and Canadian negotiators have made progress toward a maritime boundary settlement and a fishing agreement for the Atlantic Coast, according to an External Affairs Department spokesman. They now plan immediate consultations with the fishing industry and regional governments and further negotiating sessions in New York Jan. 1819.

title: BusShelter Pact Awarded by City To New Concern
description: After months of corporate and political infighting and repeated delays, the Board of Estimate yesterday unanimously approved a 10year contract with the Convenience & Safety Corporation to erect and maintain 4,100 bus shelters through- out the city. The board thus look tne business away from the company that pioneered bus shelters in New York three years ago.

title: M1 Is Flat For Week; Bonds Up
description: The money supply, much to the surprise of the credit markets, did not show a big increase in the week ended Jan. 3. In fact, it was flat, and the news set off a moderate rally yesterday in the alreadyrising markets.

title: Lefkowitz Criticized on Coop Plan
description: A tenants' goup said yesterday that in the last week of the administration of State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz, his aides approved a disputed plan for a luxuryapartment cooperative conversion that could bring fees of up to $200,000 to the law firm that Mr. Lefkowitz later joined.

title: Churchmen Debate Vatican's Place in Unity Moves
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica, Jan. 11  Most advocates of church unity attending the meeting of the World Council of Churches central committee here agree that, in one way or another, all ecumenical roads must lead to Rome.

title: Civil Service Union Wins Appeal
description: ALBANY, Jan. 11  A state appeals court restored to the Civil Service Employees Association today the 45,000 New York State employees it had lost to a rival union and ordered further proceedings to determine if the rival had forged signatures to authorize Its election.

title: Cambodian PekingBound, Vows War Will Go On
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 11  Deputy Prime Minister Ieng Sary slipped out of Cambodia today and traveled to China, insisting that Cambodian forces would continue their fight against the Vietnamese.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: The Music for Westchester Symphony, which is not to be confused with the Westchester Symphony, will be roaming the hills and dales of the county this weekend, performing in Tarrytown tonight at 8:30 and in White Plains Saturday night at 8:30, with a program of Ravel, Ginastera and Tchaikovsky under the direction of Siegfried Landau and with a guest soloist, Jerome Lowenthal, at the piano. This is an allprofessional orchestra of from 64 to 74 musicians that will celebrate its 17th birthday in March. In Tarrytown the concert is at Washington Irving Junior High School,. at Franklin Avenue and Broadway, under the sponsorship of the Junior League of Westchester-onHudson. In White Plains it will be at the Highlands School, Old Mamaroneck Road and Hartsdale Avenue. Tickets: $6, $7 and $8. Information: (914) 7251880.

title: Growers Are Worried By Attack on Tobacco
description: WILSON, N.C., Jan. 11  Clifford B. Aycock, the relaxed, 64yearold general manager of the Growers Cooperative Warehouse here in the heart of North Carolina's bright leaf tobacco country, concedes anxiety that the Government's latest antismoking broadside could lead to further bans or restrictions on the industry. But he figures that a man with real political clout  the President of the United States  is on the side of tobacco.

title: Rock: Spirit Lives On
description: WADDED near the bottom of this reviewer's trunk of memories is a hotorangeandpink paisley Nehru jacket he donned during the psychedelic era of 1966 to 1968. It would have been the perfect attire for the performance Wednesday night at the Bottom Line by Spirit, a rock group that was formed in 1967 and two of whose original members, the guitarist Randy California and the drummer Ed Cassidy, are still plugging away 12 years later.

title: Charles S. Stryker Dies; A Director of Reichhold
description: Charles S. Stryker, director and vice president of Reichhold Chemicals Inc., died Wednesday in United Hospital at Port Chester, N.Y., following a brief illness. Mr. Stryker, who lived at 1 Thistle Lane in Rye, N.Y., was 59 years old.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Restaurants
description: FEW things can make us feel older than the realization that this year the Four Seasons is celebrating its 20th birthday. July 20 will mark that date for a restaurant that was spectacularly innovative when it opened and has weathered so well that it is still the handsomest and grandest modern restaurant in the country, if not in the world.

title: Knoetze Granted Injunction
description: Kallie Knoetze's controversyfilled American boxing debut appeared to be on again yesterday after a Federal judge in Florida granted a temporary injunction against the Government's revocation of the South African heavyweight's visa.

title: My Old Friends Reopens 2d Ave. Theater
description: My Old Friends, a musical about the inhabitants of a retirement home, with book, lyrics and music by Mel Mandel and Norman Sachs, will begin performances today at the Orpheum Theater, 126 Second Avenue, at Eighth Street.

title: S.E.C. Survey On Broker Law
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said yesterday that it would survey members of securities exchanges to determine the impact of a law separating brokerage and investmentadvisory activities.

title: Robert A. Wagner, an Executive With RealEstate Company, at 79
description: Robert A. Wagner, a realestate executive, died yesterday at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 79 years old.

title: Inquiry by Legal Grievance Unit Sought on Mark Lane
description: A New York legal grievance committee has been asked to investigate reports that Mark Lane, the lawyer who until recently represented the People's Temple, withheld knowledge that he had believed might have helped to prevent harm to Reprdsentative Leo J. Ryan and other members of his party on their visit to cult's Guyana outpost last Nov. 18.

title: Philharmonic: Haydn
description: VLADIMIR SPIVAKOV, the Russian violinist, made his New York debut in 1975, and has since performed here annually in recital. He has also appeared with several. leading American orchestras. But last night marked Mr. Spivakov's debut with the New York Philharmonic in Avery Fisher Hall, under Erich Leinsdorf's direction.

title: Six Killed in Violence on Jamaica
description: KINOSTON, Jamaica, Jan. 11  Roadblocks and a ban on public gatherings restored calm to Jamaica today after three days of unrest brought about by increases in the price of gasoline and other petroleum products.

title: Stage: Tolstoy's Legacy
description: HEN Leo Tolstoy died he left behind an unfinished autobiographical play that examined with remarkable objectivity a life that was gov- ernes by kindliness, by an obdurate faith in classlessness and by a frustrated yearning to renounce the privilege into which he was born.

title: Television
description: Afternoon

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: What I've got is a president in his last year and, of course, I've got to find someone to replace him. So said Edward F. Gibbons, chairman and chief executive officer of the F.W. Wool- wortn Company, yesterday in explaining a group of executive changes announced the other day. Scheduled to retire later this year is W.R. Harris, who is about to reach the mandatory retirement age, 65.

title: Art: Stuart Davis And William Bailey
description: THE late Stuart Davis (18941964) was a painter much admired in his lifetime as one of the leading American modernists, and since his death  it hardly seems possible that it occurred 15 years ago in what already looks nice a distant era  his work has done more than merely survive. It really lives! When we encounter a Davis painting today in the permanent collection of a museum or in some loan show or private residence, it radiates an instant visual heat that is unlike anything to be found elsewhere in the American art of Davis's generation.

title: McEnroe Is Victor On Connors Default
description: The Grand Prix Masters tennis tournament, mired in controversy since its inception nine years ago, suffered another unexpected setback last night when Jimmy Connors was forced out of the event after defaulting his roundrobin match against John McEnroe because of an injury.

title: Mahaffey Leads Golf By 2 Shots With 132
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Jan. 11 (AP)  John Mahaffey shrugged off the potential disaster of a doublebogey 6 with a string of seven, birdies and carded another sixunderpar 66 that gave him a twostroke lead today after the second round of the Desert Classic.

title: Brascan Sees Successful Sale
description: TORONTO, Jan. 12  Officials of Torontobased Brascan Ltd. say they remain confident the sale of the company's Brazilian power utility, Light S.A., to the Brazilian Government for the equivalent of $380 million in American money will close as planned tomorrow, despite legal actions instituted against the transaction.

title: World News Briefs
description: LONDON, Jan. 11  The trucker's union, ignoring a plea from Prime Minister James Callaghan, broadened its strike today. In response the Government announced tonight that it would set up regionalecommittees to deal with the threat to the economy and food supply.

title: Newspaper Guild Sues The News But Judge Won't Halt Dismissals
description: The Newspaper Guild of New York sued The Daily News in Federal District Court in Manhattan yesterday, seeking to prevent the dismissal of 12 employees of the newspaper's New Jersey edition.

title: Britain Will Retrieve Plutonium
description: CANBERRA, Australia, Jan. 11 (Reuters)  Britain has agreed to take back the plutonium that was buried in southern Australia after British nuclear tests there in the 1950's, it was announced today.

title: Bridge:
description: The deepest finesse yet in 1979 may well hold on to the record for the rest of the year, and may prove to be the most subtle of the year. It was played last Saturday in the international team trials in Cherry Hill, N.J., and the deep finesser was Paul Soloway of Los Angeles, a member of the winning team.

title: The Pop Life
description: POPULAR music is generally thought of as music that is actually or potentially popular. In other words, for all its overt or implied pretensions to artistry, this is music that is meant to be sold as a product. Such piatant commercialism horrifies some artists. But at least the greed is out front, and commerce might possibly be considered a legitimate means of communication between artist and public.

title: How the Critics Responded To NuclearWastes Report
description: Those who want to see the Nuclear Fuel Services site at West Valley, N.Y., decontaminated and the atomic wastes removed contend that the United States Department of Energy is trying to persuade Congress that moving the waste would be too expensive and that West Valley should now become a radioactivewaste dump.

title: News Summary
description: The Shah will soon leave Iran for a vacation, and the United States endorses his decision, Secretary of State Vance said. He called on Iranian military and opposition leaders to support the new civilian Government. Other State Department officials said that Washington had warned Iranian military leaders strongly against attempting a coup. [Page A1, Column 6.]

title: Brooklyn Reporter, Silent on Source, Gets 10 Days
description: A reporter for a Brooklyn weekly newspaper was sentenced to 10 days in jail and fined $250 yesterday for refusing to answer questions in a narcotics trial about one of her sources for an article on drug trafficking.

title: Producer Prices Up 9.1% in '78
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11  A substantial increase in December helped the producer price index to rise 9.1 percent last year, the largest annual increase since inflationridden 1979, the Government reported today.

title: Mannes College and Manhattan School Talk Merger
description: Top officials of the Manhattan School of Music and Mannes College disclosed yesterday that they were discussing a possible merger of the two institutions:. John O. Crosby, president of the Manhattan School, said that the talks had been only exploratory, so far and that it would be late next week before further developments could be expected. Even then, you understand, there may be nothing substantial to report, Mr. Crosby said.

title: Music: Lehel's Budapest Symphony
description: FOR some reason, the Budapest Symphony Orchestra, which played last night in Carnegie Hall, failed to live up to the fine impression it had made in previous American appearances. Presumably the personnel was the same, and the conductor, Gyorgy Lehel, certainly was. But this time there seemed to be lack of spirit in the playing, and the conductor seldom seemed involved with the music.

title: U.S. Plans Note Issue For Swiss
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (Reuters)The Treasury said today that it would sell about $1.2 billion worth of United States Government securities in Switzerland as part of President Carter's program to defend the dollar. The securities, totaling two billion Swiss francs, will be offered to Swiss citizens in Zurich next Wednesday.

title: Books of The Times
description: HERBERT HOOVER. A Public Life. By David Burner. 433 pages. Illustrated. Alfred A. Knopf. $15.95

title: Events and Openings
description: MY OLD FRIENDS, musical, with book, mask and lyrics by Mel Mandel and Norman Sachs. Directed by Philip Rose. At the Orpheum Theater, 126 Second Avenue, 8.

title: Miller, Kuhn Joust Over Player Salaries
description: While Baseball Commissioner Bowie Kuhn was in Boston yesterday decrying once again the rate of escalation of baseball salaries, Marvin Miller of the Players' Association sat in his New York office and called the commissioner's views fantasy.

title: Carey Assailed on Youth Unit Head
description: ALBANY, Jan. 11  Governor Carey plans to name Frank A. Hall, the Massachusetts Commissioner of Corrections, as the director of New York's Division for Youth, top aides to the Governor said today.

title: The Editorial Notebook
description: I love to walk. Unhappily, New York considers walking too pedestrian. Running, jogging, biking, yes; mere walking is not only out but may be dangerous to the health.

title: Russomanno Gets Family Circle Post
description: Robert F. Young, president and publisher of Family Circle magazine, confirmed yesterday that he would hand over the latter title on June 1 to Russ Russomanno, since 1966 the advertising director. His old title goes at the same time to Thomas C. Redd, vice president and ad manager for the Middle West.

title: Wing's Bold Style Nets Success
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Jan. 11  As a realist, Ted Wing knows he cannot win with every horse he drives. He just does not like to admit it.

title: Skier From Siberia Thrives on Storms
description: CRANSMONTANA, Switzerland, Jan. 11  The weather was turning bitterly cold as an overnight storm began to drop more than a foot of snow here. That pleased Vladimir Markeyev because it reminded him of his home Siberia.

title: Hearing on Nuclear Wastes Is Set for Tomorrow Upstate
description: A final public hearing will be held in Buffalo tomorrow on the highly radioactive plant, known as Nuclear Fuel Services. But the upstaters who want it and its toxic contents removed from the Buffalo area say they are not happy about the rules for the hearing as announced by the United States Department of Energy.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Tom R. Ragland, ExExecutive Of Union Carbide Company, 71
description: Tom R. Ragland, retired Union Carbide executive, died Wednesday at his home in St. Michaels, Md. He was 71 years old.

title: Reuss Warns Of Depression
description: Representative Henry S. Reuss, chairman of the House Banking, Finance and Urban Affairs Committee, warned yesterday that the Federal Reserve's abrupt halt of moneysupply growth could be laying the foundation for another massive depression. He noted that there has been no growth in M1 since September.

title: Market Place
description: THE scene on the television set is one of an idyllie vacation about to be ruined by the loss or theft of a vacationer's cash. Then Karl Malden, the actor, appears and announces in stentorian tones that American Express traveler's checks would have prevented this disaster.

title: Music From a Pride of Baths
description: As many New Yorkers and other Americans know by now, the Ensemble for Early Music is a fivemember group of musicians who specialize in a variety of early musical styles that stretch from the medieval to the Baroque. which, for the sake of brevity. we might say ended sometime around 1750. But, as a number of those New Yorkers and other Americans are also aware, the Ensemble for Early Music enlarges by the addition of individuals or other groups to pursue a broad range of interests.

title: Screen: Visconti's 'The Innocent,' an Elegant Finale:Passions Rule
description: THOUGH it's sometimes difficult to associate the neo-realism of Luchino Visconti's early films, especially "Ossessione" and "La Terra Trema," with the operatic indulgences of "The Damned," "Ludwig" and "Death in Venice," the connections are there  and not simply in the visual elegance of all his work. The more profound connections are in the passions that rule Visconti's principal characters, whether a lusty, sex-starved mistress of a roadside inn, a Sicilian aristocrat at the time of Italy's unification, or an upper-class Roman wife who manages to betray her philendering husband in a way that confers on him an unbearable innocence.This last is more or less the heart of "The Innocent," Visconti's last film (completed in 1976 shortly before his death) and among the most beautiful and severely disciplined films he has ever made. It goes a long way toward erasing the memory of "Conversation Piece," that curiously (sometimes ludicrously) awkward talk-film that opened the 1975 New York Film Festival and seemed emotionally charged to some Visconti admirers, who saw it as an old man's summing up."The Innocent," based on Gabriele D'Annunzio's 1892 novel (published in this country in 1898 as "The Intruder"), which I haven't read, may well keep to the spirit if not the letter of the original, as Visconti said some time before his death. More importantly, it exemplifies Visconti's social concerns, though in terms of a story so limited in its field of vision and so precise in its details that it comes as something of a shock when, at the conclusion, one realizes the real magnitude of the work.The turn-of-the-century world of "The Innocent," though small, is no microcosm. It is exactly what it seems to be, a world of fashionable drawing rooms, music rooms and bedrooms in ancient Roman palaces and immaculately tended country villas, where incomes are enormous but invisible, and where affairs of the heart have almost nothing to do with the soul and everything to do with the body.Tullio (Giancarlo Giannini) is a perfect specimen of his time and place. He is rich, handsome, arrogant, self-confident and cruel, with a beautiful wife Giuliana (Laura Antonelli) whom he once loved and now fondles as a sister, which allows him the freedom to pursue his equally beautiful mistress, Teresa (Jennifer O'Neill), a widowed countess who is quite as self-absorbed as he.Though Tullio fancies himself a realist, completely in charge of his emotions, he is struck with a suddenly renewed, totally baffling (to him) love for his wife when he learns she has been having an affair with a young novelist. This new love is different from all the others he has experienced. It may even be real. Magnanimously he offers to overlook Giuliana's indiscretion until he learns that she is pregnant with the novelist's child.Though the novelist conveniently dies, Tullio tries unsuccessfully to persuade Giuliana to agree to an abortion. She refuses to go against church law, which infuriates Tullio, who thinks of himself as an atheist. "The earth is the only country I belong to," he says. "When I die, that's the end of it. I live now." In the most sunny, civilized, well-ordered and well-mannered of worlds, the lives of Tullio and Giuliana are wrecked by their passions, as fatally as if they'd gone down with a luxury yacht in the middle of the Adriatic."The Innocent" has a surprising kind of narrative balance, a shapeliness that is not characteristic of Visconti though it serves to implement his larger concerns with the individual in his own society. In "The Innocent" these concerns are reflected in major scenes as well as in the most seemingly casual images, such as a series of shots of the guests at a piano recital sitting in the manner of beings frozen in time. Even the women's costumes, with their wasp waists, their veils and their parasols, suggest psychological constraints  bonds that eventually snap in the series of revelations that concludes the film.Although "The Innocent" is one of Visconti's most beautiful films, the dcor is essential to its meaning. "The Innocent" is also one of Visconti's most terse, most dramatically economical films. There's not a superfluous frame in it. Further, it is splendidly performed by Mr. Giannini, who indulges none of the comic mannerisms that are standard equipment in his work for Lina Wertmuller, and by Miss Antonelli, whose childlike face and voluptuous body combine to form a kind of ideograph that tells us what the film is all about.It is difficult to judge Miss O'Neill's performance. She looks great but her Italian dialogue has been dubbed, sometimes none too carefully, though for that matter all of the dialogue sounds post-synchronized."The Innocent," which opens today at the Gemini II Theater, is a fitting coda to the Visconti career. It's a film of effortless command in which the director's presence is everywhere felt  and nowhere intrudes.

title: Steel Strike Ends in Ruhr
description: DUSSELDORF, West Germany, Jan. 11 (AP)  Ruhr steel workers returned to work today after settling a 44day strike that cost the industry 1.5 billion marks, or $820 million, in revenue, management announced.

title: Obituary 1 -- No Title
description: A. A. LEMIEUX

title: A.T. & T. Shift Seen In U.S. Suit
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11  In an apparent shift of strategy, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company said today that it might be ready to go to trial in less than a year in the Government's civil antitrust suit charging A.T. & T. with having illegally monopolized telecommunications in the United States.

title: A Good Time to Trade Up for Larger Boat
description: If you've been thinking about trading up to a larger boat, the first quarter of 1979 is the time to act. For the foreseeable future, boat prices will continue to escalate, and probably at even a greater rate than during the last four years.

title: Stage: Joel Grey Stars in Grand Tour
description: THE GRAND TOUR is musical that is often amiable and sometimes more than that. But it is a patchwork, and an incomplete one. Its engaging moments run in different directions, pull different ways, and leave large areas looking decidedly thin.

title: Art. People
description: IT'S a long way from Artforum magazine to Akron, Ohio, but John Coplans has taken longer trips. A former Londoner who grew up in South Africa, Mr. Coplans settled in the United States in the early

title: F.T.C. Charge Names ForemostMcKesson
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP)  The Federal Trade Commission accused a distributor of wholesale drugs today of violating a sixyearold agreement with the agency that prohibited the distributor from receiving payments from suppliers.

title: WASHINGTON Backstairs In the Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11  Members of the Congress are not all back here yet from the Christmas recess and their trips to Moscow, Peking and elsewhere; but their staff assistants are on the job, and they are probably the most powerful and least noticed army in Washington.

title: Hartford's School Chief
description: HARTFORD, Jan. 11  The new Superintendent of Public Schools here, Hernan LaFontaine, has a lot in common with his new employer, the Hartford Board of Education. For years both have been enmeshed in controversies and both are now seeking to find new peace together.

title: Around the Nation
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 11 (AP)  A Federal agency engaged in clearing hundreds of barrels of toxic chemicals from field near here now says it has found thousands more barrels in a second field nearby. The agency said it does not yet know what is in the new group of barrels.

title: Books: An Icy Beauty
description: ANTARCTICA. By Eliot Porter. Foreword by Walter Sullivan. Illustrated. 168 pages. E.P. Dutton. $35.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: LANDOVER, Md., Jan. 11 (AP) Unbeaten Sugar Ray Leonard stalked Johnny Gant through most of the fight and scored a knockout when the fight was stopped at 2 minutes 57 seconds of the eighth round tonight in their scheduled 12round welterweight bout.

title: Regents Special Test Viewed as Bar to 7,000 Seniors
description: Chancellor Frank J. Macchiarola of the New York City schools appealed to the Board of Regents yesterday to suspend the new state policy that could deny high school diplomas this June to the estimated total of 7,000 seniors in the city who have not passed minimumcompetency tests in reading and mathematics.

title: A Macy's Tower Held Bacteria That Cause Legionnaires' Disease
description: Bacteria that cause legionnaires disease were found last fall in a large airconditioner cooling tower on the roof of Macy's department store, which overlooks the West 35th Street area in the garment district where the disease broke out last summer, the New York City Health Department said yesterday.

title: Companies Report Earnings
description: For periods as shown. (N) indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange,(A) the American Stock Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: EARNINGS
description: Teledyne Inc., the West Coast diversified industrial producer, reported yesterday profit increases of 37 percent in the fourth quarter and 27.6 percent in all of last year. The results were well above analysts' estimates and the stock reacted to the news by climbing 7 points to 110 on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.

title: Hussein Appears to Oppose IsraelEgypt Dealings
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Jan. 11  King Hussein of Jordan appears convinced that the stalled peace talks between Egypt and Israel can never produce a Middle East settlernent, and would like to see broader negotiations considered as rapidly as possible under the auspices of the United Nations Security Council.

title: Real Wage Insurance
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11  Even before it is officially presented to Congress, President Carter's proposal for real wage insurance  a truly novel idea for fighting inflation  is in deep trouble.

title: RollerDisco Fashions: Stretch Fabrics on a Runway to the 80's
description: The Inferno, at 5 West 19th Street, was the sprawling discotheque chosen by the designer Betsey Johnson as the site to roll out her, wares  her spring and summer clothing, in a show that was traditional right down to the bridal gown finale and up to the minute in choice of fabric and presentation: Lycra spandex and disco and rockandroll music and 56 roller skaters to do the modeling.

title: Juvenile Felons: State Program Seeks to Nurture Stability
description: Periodically a youngster commits a crime so brutal or so senseless that whatever sense of urban wellbeing remains in the community is shaken for a few days and, perhaps, weakened irreparably. But what happens to the offender, once he has been caugnt aria processed through the juvenile justice system? One of the answers can be found in the northeastern reaches of the Bronx.

title: Pioneer and Paragon of Women Flutists Visits to Aid Mannes
description: You either play the flute once and then forget it, or you get hooked on it. The statement was recently made by someone who should know, Doriot Anthony Dwyer, in the course of a conversation about her benefit recital at the Mannes College of Music on Sunday afternoon. After all, for the last 26 years she has been principal flutist of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, a post in which she has delighted millions of listeners with her virtuosity and musicianship.

title: Illinois Upsets Michigan State
description: CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Jan. 11 (AP) Eddie Johnson scored on a 20foot jumper from the right corner with three seconds left to give undefeated Illinois a 5755 Big Ten victory over topranked Michigan State in college basketball tonight.

title: China Plans Long Belt of Trees
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 11 (Reuters) China is planning to grow a great green wall of trees stretching several thousand miles along the edge of its deserts and highlands, the official Chinese press agency, Hsinhua, said today. The agency said the forestry belt, to be completed by 1985, would protect 32 million acres of farmland and transform vast areas of barren land into grainproducing and animalbreeding regions.

title: COMMODITIES
description: A late flood of buy orders inundated the wheat futures pit of the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday, replacing small minus signs with gains of 8 to 1.5 cents a bushel. Indeed, almost all the gains were posted in the hectic final 30 minutes of trading.

title: U.S. Cites Overwhelming Proof That Tobacco Causes Lung Cancer
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11  An encyclopedic report offering overwhelming proof that cigarette smoking causes lung cancer, heart disease and a host of other serious ailments was issued today by Dr. Julius B. Richmond, the Surgeon General of the United States.

title: Israeli Admiral Is Replaced
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 11 (AP)  Brig. Gen. Zeev Almog has been named commander of Israel's Navy, replacing Rear Adm. Michael Barkai, who was relieved of his command after being acquitted of an attempted rape charge. General Almog, 43 years old, had been teaching at the National Defense College.

title: Looking for Wine Buys at Four Seasons? Think Domestic
description: A bottle of Chteau Latour 1953 at the Four Seasons for $9.50? Or a 1945 Lafite for $16.50? Or how about a 1937 MoutonRothschild for $15? Those are the prices you would have paid had you dined at the famous restaurant when it opened in 1959.

title: Parole Granted to Antiwar Activist Who Bombed Center at Wisconsin
description: Mr. Fine was sentenced to seven years for conspiracy, destruction of Government property, firearms counts and unlawful flight to avoid prosecution.

title: Economic Scene
description: DURING the two decades after World War II, productivity  output per workerhour  grew in the United States at an average rate of 3.3 percent a year. Since 1967, however, the rise in productivity has slackened to a rate of 1.8 percent.

title: New Rochelle AT A GLANCE
description: Only 12 miles from New York, Westchester County's secondlargest city comprises 10.4 square miles on Long Island Sound.

title: Fidelity Seeks Brokerage
description: The Fidelity Management and Research Company, a Bostonbased mutual fund manager, said yesterday that it hoped to receive permission from the Securities and Exchange Commission to operate a retail-discount brokerage firm. The company plans initially to offer the cutrate commission brokerage service in Massachusetts and Connecticut.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRIVING TOMORROW, Jan.13 OCEANIC (Home). Lett St. Martin Jan. 9; due tt A.M. at W. 55th Street.

title: U.S. Clergymen in Plea to Israel
description: More than 950 American clergymen have signed a petition calling on Israel to allow Palestinian Arab Christians and Moslems to return to their homeland in Israeli territory. The petition, circulated by an organization known as Search For Justice and Equality in Palestine, was delivered to the Israeli Embassy in Washington last week.

title: GULF AND OIL UNION AGREE ON CONTRACT
description: DENVER, Jan. 11  The Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers Union and the Gulf Oil Corporation agreed today on a new twoyear contract, the first major agreement under President Carter's wage guidelines.

title: Vance Says Israel and Egypt Agree To Resume Talks on Peace Treaty
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11  Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance said today that both Israel and Egypt had agreed to resume negotiations to conclude a peace treaty.

title: Cournoyer Has Operation
description: MONTREAL, Jan. 11 (AP)  Yvan Cournoyer, the Montreal Canadiens' captain, was reported resting comfortably today after undergoing a back operation yesterday. A spokesman for the National Hockey League club described the surgery as successful.

title: Recital: Josef Suk
description: JOSEF SUK'S violin recital at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Wednesday night proved to be a perfect demonstration of how a firstrate musician with impressive international credentials can succeed in giving a thoroughly boring performance.

title: U.S. Safety Chief Urges Helmets To Cut Deaths of Motorcyclists
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11  The nation's highway safety chief warned the states today that repeal of laws requiring motorcyclists to wear helmets could lead to dramatic increases in the traffic death rate.

title: Upper Vermont to Offer Weekend's Best Skiing
description: With frigid temperatures persisting in the Northeast, the prospects for fine skiing this weekend remained bright yesterday. However, It would be wise for skiers to pick their spots.

title: An Offbeat Season On Off Broadway
description: THERE is a dramatic stir and bustle these days in the world of Off Broadway and Off Off Broadway theater, a scattered world that has dotted New York with tiny professional regional theaters, which not only play to the world at large but also function as neighborhood cultural adornments, often in Spartan surroundings, and dress up a block or a street. You can choose from a varied menu this weekend.

title: Broadway
description: ALL the pieces are falling into place for Brian Friel's new play, Faith Healer, which opens April 5 on Broadway. Ed Flanders has just been signed for the third role and will start rehearsing on Feb. 1 with James Mason and his wife, Clarissa Kaye. Faith Healer reunites Mr. Flanders with Jose Quintero, who is directing. Four years ago they did Eugene O'Neill's A Moon for the Misbegotten on Broadway, and Mr. Flanders won Tony Award for best supporting actor.

title: 7TH DAY ADVENTISTS ELECT BLACK CHIEF
description: Charles E. Bradford was elected yes.. terday as the first black to head the Seventh Day Adventist Church of North America.

title: Tightrope in Iran
description: Sitting relaxed and entirely at his ease in the Frenchstyle living room of his palace in Teheran, Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi leaned back in his chair and contentedly observed to his American visitor: Our system suits perfectly the Persian mind . . . I nave asked myself, why is the state concentrated in me, in my person . . . If I'm in this unique position, it's because of what I represent  the nation . . . I have the people with me. That conversation was in September, 1975.

title: Ohio State Is Set To Name Bruce
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 11 (AP)  An Ohio State University official confirmed today that Earle Bruce would replace Woody Hayes and become the Buckeyes' 20th head football coach.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP)  The Texaco Corporation has agreed to refund a total of $7.88 million allegedly overcharged to several of its large customers for gasoline, diesel fuel and distillate oil, the Department of Energy announced today.

title: Two at Times Honored By Newswomen's Club
description: Dena Kleiman, a reporter for The New York Times, and Teresa Zabala, a Times photographer, have been named winners of the Newswomen's Club of New York's 1978 Front Page. Awards for distinguished journalism.

title: Pope Will Stop Over in Haiti
description: PORTAUPRINCE, Haiti, Jan. 11 (Reuters)  Pope John Paul II will make a fourhour stopover in Haiti on Jan. 31 at the end of his visit to Mexico, according to a Government announcement.

title: Taiwan Premier Rebuffs Peking On Its Proposal for Reunification
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Jan. 11  Nationalist China's Prime Minister flatly rejected today Peking's proposals for reunification with the mainland and described China's move as a trick to induce Taiwan to surrender.

title: Chemical and Crocker Report Big Profit Gains
description: A number of bank holding companies, including the Chemical New York Corporation and the Crocker National Corporation, yesterday reported substantially higher earnings for 1978 and the final quarter of the year, reflecting strong loan demand and higher yields.

title: Carter Warned on Russian Power
description: More than 170 retired generals and admirals have warned President Carter of what they describe as an increasing Soviet challenge to the United States.

title: Russ and Sutton in Deal
description: Russ Togs Inc. and the Sutton Shirt Corporation said yesterday that they had agreed in principle for Russ Togs to acquire Sutton and its subsidiaries and affiliates. Terms call for a purchase price of about $9 million in cash and notes.

title: Nero and The Wall Street Journal
description: When people in racing or breeding want to get a message across to others in the field, they usually advertise in The BloodHorse or Thoroughbred Records or Hoof Beats, official publication of the United States Trotting Association. This makes almost as much sense as Willie (The Actor) Sutton did when asked why he robbed banks. That's where the money is, he said.

title: About Real Estate
description: One of the largest of all the manmade channels on Nassau County's southern shorais called Randall Channel, which empties into Jones Inlet. From a high vantage point along the shore, it is possible to look directly south across the water to Point Lookout and Jones Beach State Park.

title: England Defeats Australia; Now Leads, 31, in Cricket
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 11, (Reuter)  England beat Australia by 93 runs today to score a remarkable victory on the last day of the fourth test match.

title: Czech Dissident Goes on Trial
description: TRUTNOV, Czechoslovakia, Jan. 11 (Reuters)  Jaroslav Sabata, a leading spokesman for the Charter 77 human rights movement, went on trial today charged with insulting a Government official. Dr. Sabata, 52 years old, once a senior Communist Party official, was arrested Oct. 1 when the police foiled a planned border meeting of Czechoslovak and Polish dissidents.

title: Carter Speech Set for Jan. 23
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (UPI)  President Carter will deliver his State of the Union Message to a joint session of Congress on Jan. 23, Jody Powell, the White House press secretary, said today. The address was scheduled for 9 P.M.

title: Duval to Raise Copper Prices
description: The Duval corporation, a subsidiary of the Pennzoil Company, said yesterday that it was raising the price of its refined copper to 75 cents a pound, joining other major producers in a move that has brought copper to the highest domestic price since 1974.

title: City Ballet: Worlds Made by Balanchine
description: ON Wednesday evening at the New York State Theater, the New York City Ballet presented the season's first performances of George Balanchine's The Four Temperaments and Le Tdmbeau de Couperin. Both are major achievements and each is a choreographic world of its own.

title: Text of Vance's Statement on the Situation in Iran
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (Reuters) Following is the text of Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance's statement today on the situation in Iran:

title: VANCE ASSERTS SHAH WILL QUIT IRAN SOON AND U.S. BACKS STEP
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11  Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance said today that Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi would soon leave Iran for a vacation and that the United States endorsed his decision. Mr. Vance called on Iranian military and opposition leaders to lend their support to the civilian Government of Prime Minister Shahpur Bakhtiar.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M., WNCN. Cantos de Espana, Albenix; William Tell Ballet Musk, Rossini; Idomeneo Ballet Musk, Mozart; Dances from The Spanish Lady, Elgar.

title: Dividends
description: THURSDAY, JAN. 11, 1979

title: Carter Acts to Dissociate Himself From Brother's Role With Libya
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 11  The White House acted today to dissociate President Carter from a boisterous tour that the President's brother, Billy Carter, is conducting for Libyan businessmen and officials close to Col. Muammar elQaddafi, the controversial leader of the oilproducing Arab nation.

title: Being a Diagnosis of Inflation: Causes and Cures
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  Inflation is caused by the increasing ability of strong sellers  the great corporations, the trade unions, farmers in conjunction with the Agriculture Department, corporate executives whose compensation is set by boards of directors they themselves select, the numerous legislatively aided groups  to raise their own prices and incomes. And it is caused by an aggregate of public and private demand that is in excess of supply at current prices. So prices are bid up.

title: Where Not to Cut the School Budget
description: New York City's Board of Education last week got some unwelcome news about next year's budget  and some unsolicited advice about how to balance it. Mayor Koch intends to pare school spending by at least $8.5 million. Only $50 million of that will be accounted for by declining enrollment. To economize further, the Mayor's budgeteers suggest eliminating the newly instituted transitional classes for elementary school pupils forced to repeat grades. Such remedial classes to help thousands of lagging students should be the last place to economize.

title: US. Strategy on Iran Stirs a Fierce Debate
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11  The Carter Administration's handling of the Iranian crisis has become the subject of a fierce internal debate, with many officials asserting that interagency disputes and bureaucratic compromises have hampered the efforts of Mr. Carter and his top advisers to fashion and carry out an overall strategy.

title: Carter's Budget for F.B.I. Would Trim 300 Agents
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12  The Federal Bureau of Investigation, to the consternation of some of its senior officials, will lose nearly 300 agents in the 1980 fiscal year unless Congress restores some of the cuts being planned by the Carter Administration, F.B.I. and Administration sources said today.

title: JOHN J. NIETMANN
description: Special to the New York Times

title: 2,840 Russians Saved From Drifting Ice Floe
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 12 (UPI)  Soviet helicopters and a ship plucked 2,890 Russian fishermen from an ice floe just before it reached the open sea and broke apart, a Soviet newspaper reported today.

title: Col. Henry Fairfax Ayers, at 92; An Officer in Both World Wars
description: Col. Henry Fairfax Ayers, retired, died Tuesday at his home in Shaftsbury, Va. He was 92 years old.

title: New York 78 Jobless Rate Down
description: Unemployment rates in New York City, New York State and New Jersey dropped last year to their lowest levels since 1974. However, they were still well above the country's average rate.

title: Artificial Dollar Aim Disclaimed
description: Role May Shift,

title: Israel Finds Crime and Scandals Go With Being Normal
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 12  Asked once about reports of growing crime and political scandals, Golda Meir suggested two possible explanations  either idealism was on the wane or Israel was becoming a normal country.

title: In Tennis, Trust Is a Fault
description: Jimmy Connors was out of the tournament. Tenderly favoring a blistered and bloodied left foot, he had surrendered while trailing John McEnroe, 75, 30, in their Grand Prix Masters singles match Thursday night. Now, behind

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Stratified clouds over the Southeast are moving to the east. Some thunderstorms are over northern Florida. Midlevel clouds are moving eastward from Great Lakes to New England under influence of a jet stream. Another swirl of clouds is advancing across the Rockies and the Central Plains States.

title: Mrs. Moser Records Third Ski TriutTiph
description: LES DIABLERETS, Switzerland, Jan. 12 (AP)  Annemarie Proell Moser, bidding for an unparalleled sixth World Cup, outclassed her rivals today in winning the season's third downhill race by an impressive margin.

title: An Arrest Made in Error In Melee in Borough Park
description: Police Commissioner Robert J. McGuire said yesterday that the police had arrested a wrong man when they took into custody five Borough Park residents last Monday in connection with demonstrations by Jewish residents of the area at the 66th Precinct station house in Brooklyn last month.

title: Carter Studies Freeing Of Four Puerto Ricans
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (UPI) President Carter is considering whether to release four jailed Puerto Rican nationalists involved in shooting attacks in the House of Representatives and on President Truman's residence in the 1950's, sources said today.

title: World News Briefs; Rhodesia Moves Closer To General Mobilization
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Jan. 12 (UPI)  The Rhodesian Government moved closer to general mobilization today with an announcement that white men between the ages of 50 and 59 are to be called up for emergency military service, and the extension of martial law to cover all but a few strips of the country.

title: A.M.C. Curbs Sale Tally
description: DETROIT, Jan 12  The American Motors Corporation, smallest of the four major domestic automobile companies, will no longer publicly disclose its 10day sales results, abandoning a practice prevalent in the automobile industry for decades.

title: DanielHenry Kahnweiler Dies; Art Dealer, Friend of Picasso, 94
description: DanielHenry Kahnweiler, who for more than 70 years was prominent on the international art scene as dealer, publisher, and art historian, died in Paris on Thursday. He was 94 years old.

title: 15 Years for Knifepoint Robbery
description: Earnest Talley, 20 years old, of the Bronx, was sentenced yesterday to the maximum sentence of 15 years in prison for the knifepoint robbery of an insurance inspector in 1977. Justice Fred W. Eggert of State Supreme Court ordered Mr. Talley, of 1690 College Avenue, in the Morrisania section, to remain in prison for at least seven and a half years before becoming eligible for parole,

title: Schmidt Says Bonn Assumes Growing Global Role
description: BONN, Jan. 12 West Germany's participation in last week's Western summit meeting at Guadeloupe brought into the foreground the growth of the country's role as a world decision maker, Chancellor Helmut Schmidt said today.

title: 1 Panel Named for Major Inquiries
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (UPI)  Chief Justice Warren E. Burger today appointed a panel of three Federal judges who, under a new law, would choose a special prosecutor if one is needed to investigate high Federal officials, includine the President.

title: Deaths
description: NASONMrs. Mary Reeves. 77. Beloved wife of Randolph Nason of Dennison Road, Essex, Conn. January 11, 1979 suddenly. Mother of Mrs. Florence D. Shaw, St. Thomas, Virgin Islands, Donald S. Shaw, Ormond Beach, Florida, Mrs. Mary Louise Reynolds, Albuquerque, N.M. and Reid L. Shaw, Schenectady, N.Y. A resident of Essex 10 years and former resident of Bronxville, N.Y. 35 years. Graduate of Horace Mann School, N.Y.C. and Wellesley College, Wellesley, Mass. Memorial funeral service 2:00PM, Thursday, January 18 at First Con gregational Church, Essex, Conn. Interment private. Please omit flowers. Contributions in her name to the Essex Library Fund, Essex, Conn. 01126.

title: COMMODITIES; Soybean Futures Rise 8c Wheat Prices Steady
description: What one observer called a hopeful rally lifted soybean prices about 8 cents a bushel yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. The buying came primarily from speculators, not from commercial interests.

title: Shirts Return Home to CBGB's
description: The Shirts, who came home to CBGB's Thursday night (they'll be there through tonight), are a rock band with a grudge. As they've indicated in several interviews, they feel ignored not only by the rock press here, but also by their record company and by America in general. They came home in two senses Thursday from Europe, where they toured last summer and again in November and December (in December as opening act for Peter Gabriel)  back to CBGB's, where they got their formal start, and to the club that is owned by their manager, Hilly Kristal.

title: South Africa on the Ropes
description: If for some reason it turns out, after all, that the South African heavyweight boxer Kallie Knoetze, who successfully appealed in Federal court State Department decision to revoke his visa, is prevented from fighting in the United States, the exclusion of South African sportsmen, black and white, from all of the primary sports that my country participates in will have been complete.

title: Giants Get Final Word From Paterno: No
description: Joe said it ain't so.

title: `Baroque Music Masters Directed by Judith Norell
description: Baroque Music Masters is the title of a new series at the 92d Street Y.M.Y.W.H.A., which opened on Thursday night. It is under the direction of Judith Norell, a wellknown harpsichordist in this city, who has gathered around her an ensemble of excellent musitians versed in the Baroque style and using instruments that date from the Baroque period or are conies thereof.

title: Conservative Jewry to Vote On the Ordaining of Women
description: Jan Kaufman keeps a kosher home, wears a prayer shawl for worship and travels from New York to North Carolina to serve a small congregation every weekend. She is a Conservative Jew, and she wants to be a rabbi.

title: Mahaffey's Lead Cut To a Shot on Coast
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Jan. 12 (AP)  John Mahaffey retained the lead with a round of 71, but Lee Trevino, experimenting with a new putting technique, moved into strong contention today in the third round of the $275.000 Desert Golf Classic.
