description: ARRIVING TODAY, Jan. 13

title: I.R.S. Is Investigating People's Temple Role in Politics
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 12The Internal Revenue Service has begun an investigation of the political activities of the People's Temple that, sources said, could lead to a revocation of the Temple's taxexempt status and a claim for back taxes amounting possibly to millions of dollars.

title: END OF STRIKE NEAR AT Si. LOUIS PAPERS; Deliverers Settle and Officials Say Sunday Editions Are Planned
description: ST. LOUIS, Jan. 12 (AP)  Members of Local 610 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters voted today to ratify contracts that will end a series of strikes that have shut down the city's two major papers for more than seven weeks.

title: StripMining, Washington Style
description: When President Carter signed the stripmining control bill in 1977, he lamented that it was not more strict. But that was before the battle against inflation came to preoccupy his Administration. Now the President's economic advisers are trying to soften the regulations that have been proposed for carrying out the law. and going about it by dubious means.

title: Dutch Agree to Give 700 Soldiers For U.N. Force in South Lebanon
description: THE HAGUE, Jan. 12 (Reuters)  The Netherlands agreed today to contribute troops to a United Nations peacekeeping operation for the first time.

title: Bloedel Rejects Takeover Bid
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Jan. 12 (AP)  The board of directors of MacMillan Bloedel Ltd., Canada's largest forestproducts company, decided today to resist further takeover attempts by Canadian Pacific Investments Ltd. or its associated companies.

title: Nets Lose to Laker By 1 on Free Throw
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Jan. 13  Tonight's loss, the ninth in 11 games, may have been the worst one for the New Jersey Nets. They felt they had played their best game in a month, maybe longer. They watched a 14point lead melt away in fewer than 41/2 minutes, and their record fell under .500 for the first time since Nov. 3.

title: Patents
description: Ultrasonic Checking In Hospitals

title: Kibbee May Go Along With Tuition Increase If He Gets Guarantees
description: Chancellor Robert J. Kibbee has told the Board of Higher Education that he would recommend a proposed $100 tuition increase at the City University of New York if he obtained assurances from city and state officials that there would be an early resumption of capital construction and no further cuts in the university's budeet.

description: `Before You Damn the Shah of Iran . . .

title: Funds Frozen In K Mart Case
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 12 (UPI)  A Federal judge today froze accounts in a Chicago bank containing more than $900,000 in funds that were mistakenly disbursed by the K Mart discountstore chain in a $2 million computer error. . .

title: Arrows Rout Spirit 117, At Indoor Soccer Match
description: UNIUNDALE, L.L, Jan. 12  After scoring just once in the first 30 minutes, the Arrows exploded for 10 goals in the second 30 minutes at the Nassau Coliseum tonight and defeated the Pittsburgh Spirit, 117, before 5,037 fans.

title: Entertainment Events
description: Music

title: National Steel To Pay Fine
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (AP)  The National Steel Corporation agreed today to pay $3.5 million in fines and to install $21.6 million worth of water pollution control equipment at its plant in Weirton, W.Va.

description: BONN, Jan. 12 West Germany's carefully constructed pillar of labormanagement cooperation, a crucial support for the country's economic strength, is being buffeted by threatening winds.

title: I.R.S. Denies Hounding Journals
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12Two top officials of the Internal Revenue Service, in an effort to reassure scientific and engineering societies, have declared that proposals to revoke the taxexempt status of two such groups were isolated instances.

title: Carter, in Angry Exchange, Ousts Bella Abzug From Women's Unit
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12  President Carter dismissed Bella S. Abzug today as cochairman of his National Advisory Committee on Women after an angry exchange with the former New York Representative at a White House meeting on women's issues.

title: Mandel, Vindicated, Not Expected to Reclaim Office
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 12  I am Governor again, Marvin Mandel said at a jammed news conference today in the Statehouse from which he was driven a year and a half ago as a convicted bribetaker.

title: A $99.99 COAST FARE ALLOWED 4 AIRLINES; C.A.B. Also Expanding RoutesPan Am Price to Be Higher
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12  The Civil Aeronautics Board awarded authority today to four airlines to fly between New York and California for a fare of $99.99 plus tax one way, without restrictions. The authority applies to business as well as tourist travel and is for standard economy service.

title: New Television Network Will Begin With Make Me Laugh, a Comedy Game Show
description: A small, scarcely heralded new television network, founded by independent stations in the country's seven largest cities, will have its inaugural next. Monday, with the premiere of a new five-night-a-week comedy game show with Bobby Van, Make Me Laugh. The New York partner in the venture is WPIX-TV, which will first present the show on Jan. 23.

title: Miss Bellamy Plays M. TA. Activist
description: Carol Bellamy, one of six new members appointed to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority by Governor Carey, made it clear yesterday at the authority's first meeting of the year that she intended to take an activist role.

title: Publicly Traded Funds

title: Japanese Radical Is Sentenced
description: TOKYO, Jan. 12 (Reuters)  A former leader of a Japanese Communist guerrilla group was sentenced today to four years in prison for his role in a 1970 airline hijacking. Hiroshi Kawashima of the Japanese Red Army had been found guilty of providing swords and knives to nine comrades who commandeered the plane.

title: British Inflation at 8.4%
description: LONDON, Jan. 12 (Reuters)  Britain's annual rate of inflation has risen to 8.4 percent from 8.1 percent, Government figures showed today. The Em-

description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 12Moscow and Peking have locked horns here in one of the harshest diplomatic clashes they have fought in an open international forum since breaking with each other two decades ago.

title: Jersey Tax Deduction Aiding Private Schools Still Unconstitutional
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 12 (UPI)  A Federal appeals court today upheld a 1978 decision overturning a provision of New Jersey law that granted a $1,000 tax deduction to parents of children in private elementary and secondary schools.

title: Rod McKuen in Cabaret Act
description: In the personal columns of some periodicals lonely people often end their desperate descriptions of what they're looking for in a lover with the plea, Must be sincere. Making his first New York appearance in more than a decade, a grizzled Rod McKuen oozed just that kind of sincerity at the Other End on Thursday evening. You could tell he was sincere because he sang so badly with not just a frog but several horned toads and a fluffy pillow or two in his throat. But his selfpity sounded smug; his condolences, complacent.

title: Wheat and Chaff In Solzhenitsyn
description: HIGHLAND PARK,N.J.  In his Harvard commencement speech last

title: Endowment for Arts Appoints 2 Directors
description: The National Endowment for the Arts has announced the appointment of David Wilk, 28 years old, as director of its literary program, and Mary MacArthur, 35, as assistant director.

title: Wire Guild at Associated Press Ratifies Contract by 60% Margin
description: The Wire Service Guild informed the Associated Press last night that the union's 790 members working for the agency had ratified their new twoyear contract, under which the employees will receive an immediate pay increase of 5 nercent.

title: About New York; The Subway Route to the Sun
description: It is a cold, sunny morning, with the city's winter sky showing the special bonedeep blue that cries out for the smudge of jet planes rising up and out toward warm resort beaches. A handsome young couple is heeding the call, their expensive getaway outfits of furlined, butterytoned leather exuding their now orthodoxy and license to travel.

description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 12  The California Supreme Court has granted a petition for a rehearing in one of the criminal cases in which its decisions were criticized as inhibiting the police in their law enforcement work.

title: 22,872 at Meadowlands As Harness Season Opens
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Jan. 12  A crowd of 22,872 came out in the snow and cold tonight as the the longest Meadowlands harness racing season 176 nights  began. The previous record was last season's 168night camnaien.

description: COLUMBUS, Ga., Jan. 12 (AP) - Billy Carter, responding to reports that he might have to register as a foreign agent, said today he was not being paid to be host to a Libyan delegation visiting the United States.

description: For a while it looked as though imagination was going to have to give way to reality, as usual.

title: U.S. Again Bids Iranian Military Shun Any Coup
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12  The United States expressed fresh concern today over the possibility of a military coup in Iran, warning leaders of the armed forces there that it strongly opposed such a move.

title: Hospital's Staff Rallies to Stress Need for Logan
description: His name is Quick  Milton Quick and he is supervisor of ambulance service at West Harlem's Arthur C. Logan Memorial Hospital. The service averages 25 to 30 runs on each of two eighthour shifts and 10 on the midnight tour, he says, and we are the fastest in responding and in quality care  we compare with anybody in the world.

title: Kennedy to Seek a Holiday Marking Dr. King Birthday
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 12  In a rousing address that had a largely black audience shouting Amen! and repeatedly rising to its feet in ovation, Senator Edward M. Kennedy pledged today to do all in his power to insure that legislation was enacted to declare the birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. a holiday in every city, town and village of the United States.

description: The January white sale, devised early this century as a way for retailers to dispose of distressed goods during the otherwise slack weeks after Christmas, has turned into a major merchandising event.

description: Most New Yorkers know something abopt the head and heart of their city, but relatively little about the entrails or guts. Under the City Streets, by Pamela Jones, is an entertaining introduction to the homelier side, or nether regions, of the metropolis.

title: Turks Retain Ties to West but Look More to Russians
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 6  On the river that forms part of Turkey's 370mile frontier with the Soviet Union, Turkish and Soviet engineers are working on a joint irrigation project.

description: The MidContinent Telephone Corporation, the nation's fifthlargest independent telephone system, said yesterday that it had executed a definitive agreement under which it would acquire Telephone Utilities of Pennsylvania Inc. in a deal valued at $34.4 million.

description: TOKYO, Jan. 12  Japan has suspended exports to Iran because of the political turmoil there.

description: ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 12 (Reuters) The United States, Britain, France and West Germany have agreed to arrange a meeting of experts in Bonn next week to organize a program of economic and financial aid to Turkey.

title: Offtrack Betting Out of the Money
description: New York City's offtrack betting operation has not paid off as promised when it was started in 1971. Instead of $100 million a year, the city's take has been only about $60 million, and bookmakers, although still illegal, seem to have lost few customers.

description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 12(UPI)  Jack Soo, who played Nick Yemana, the dourfaced, coffeemaking detective on the Barney Miller television comedy series, died of cancer Thursday at University of California at Los Angeles Medical Center. He was 63 years old.

title: School Named for Golda Meir
description: MILWAUKEE, Jan. 12 (AP)  Fourth Street Elementary School has been renamed the Golda Meir Elembntnry School in honor of the former Israeli Prime Minister who died Dec. 8. Mrs. Meir once attended the school. The Mil-

title: Robinson Traded To Suns by Jazz
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 12 (AP)  The Phoenix Suns acquired Leonard (Truck) Robinson, a forward, from the New Orleans Jazz today.

description: BOSTON, Jan. 12 (AP) - Chuck Fairbanks performed recruiting duties for the University of Colorado although he still was under contract to the New England Patriots, he conceded today at a Federal court hearing. The National

title: U.S. Concedes It Promised Peking Not to Sell Taiwan Arms This Year
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12  The Carter Administration acknowledged today that in reaching agreement with China on normalization of relations it had to promise Peking to make no new commitments to sell military equipment to Taiwan this year.

title: A Grand Reopening Draws Closer on Broadway
description: The Apollo Theater, once home of George White's Scandals, will soon ring to the sound of live music and dance again  next month, if the owners, Brandt Theaters, have their way. Built in 1910 for movies and vaudeville, the theater is being renovated along with the Lyric, a few doors down, to house legitimate theater. Both theaters will have their entrances on 43d Street. Yesterday, workmen were steam cleaning the floor.

title: Baryshnikov Dances in Prodigal Son
description: One of the key aspects of Prodigal Son, the last new work given by Serge Diaghilev's Ballets Russes, was its involvement, with one exception, of an allRussian team of collaborators at its Paris premiere in 1929.

title: Meany Says Talk With Carter Eased Some Strains
description: WASHINGTON, Jan 12 (Reuters)

title: Article 1 -- No Title
description: After two Palestinian terrorists escaped from an Istanbul jail Wednesday, troops were called out to join the police in the search for suspects as well as to hunt for Turkish terrorists also wanted by authorities.

title: Hugh and Christie Hefner: Like Father, Like Daughter
description: Hef and Christie. Christie and Hef. In the last year or so, 52-year-old Hugh M. Hefner, head of the multimilliondollar Playboy empire, and his 26-year-old daughter, Christie, a company vice president, have evolved into one of the nation's betterknown fatherdaughter business teams. He has designated her his heir apparent or, as some wags put it, his hare apparent.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: Dollar's Gains Lost In Late Trading

title: Albany Seeks $151.1 Million More
description: ALBANY, Jan. 12  The Legislature today asked for $5.4 million more to carry it through the next three months, bringing its total budget for the fiscal year to $66.2 million, a 17 percent increase over last year's. The request was part of a $151.1 million deficiency budget submitted by Governor Carey.

title: Jersey Casino's PublicRelations Payout Is Described
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 12James M. Crosby, chairman of Resorts International, testified today that Resorts had put cash and stock totaling more than $1 million in escrow for David P. Probinsky, payable if Resorts got a license to operate a casino here.

title: Dr. Murray Israel, 72; Internist Headed Unit In Vascular Research
description: Dr. Murray Israel, an internist, died yesterday at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. He was 72 years old and lived in Roslyn Heights, L.I.

title: Survey Finds Westchester Is Losing Favor Among Company Executives
description: WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 12  Top corporate executives in Westchester County some from companies that were part of the postwar migration from the cities to the suburbs  have indicated in a survey that the county has become less desirable as a business location. Their major complaint is the high cost of doing business, especially the price of energy.

title: Four Cities Are Listed For Teng Visit to U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Tan. 12  Teng Hsiaoping, China's senior Deputy Prime Minister, will visit Atlanta, Houston and Seattle during his weeklong trip to the United States later this month, his tentative itinerary revealed today.

title: Author Makes Appeal For His Lost Chapter
description: Osborn Elliott, the former editor in chief of Newsweek and former Deputy Mayor for Economic Development, is asking someone in the city to return a 25page chapter from his memoirs, the only two copies of which his researcher left behind on a subway platform yesterday morning in lower Manhattan. The chapter is entitled Some Women in My Life.

title: Vietnamese Threaten 2 Cambodian Centers
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 12  Vietnamese troops were reported by Western analysts today to be nearing Cambodia's second largest city, Battambang, the center of the country's rice granary. The city was said to have been bombed heavily for a second day.

title: U.N. COUNCIL TALKS ON CAMBODIA WIDEN; Session May Go On Next Week Many Nations to be Allowed to Take Floor on Crisis
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 12  The Security Council's emergency meeting on Cambodia expanded today to include growing numbers of nations, with prospects that the debate would extend well into next week.

title: A Lack of Details Shrouds Cambodia War
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 12  Guns are firing in Cambodia again, and people are dying. The sources of information on which the world must rely agree on this.

title: News Summary
description: SATURDAY, JANUARY 13, 1979

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: LEST WE FORGET An eloquent spokesman for the survivors of the Auschwitz concentration camp relives the past tomorrow afternoon at 3. In a free lecture presented at Temple EmanuEl, 10 East 66th Street, in the Lowenstein Building, Isabella Leitner will discuss her personal remembrances as a prisoner of the Nazis and her struggle to survive. She is the author of a new book, her first volume, titled Fragments of Isabella: a Memoir of Auschwitz, published by Thomas Y. Crowell and named as a Book-of-theMonth Club alternate selection.

title: OBSERVER The Chinese Inquisition
description: SuddePly every plane from Peking is disgorging more Chinese scholars. What are panty hose? they want to know. What is Sophia Loren? How do you dance to disco music? China has only 22 years, it seems, to become modernized. Pe wishes to be helpful.

title: Dividends
description: FRIDAY, JAN. 12, 1979

title: France Weighs Hotels in China
description: PARIS, Jan..12 (Reuters)  France hopes to build a chain of hotels in China, officials said today.

title: The City; Police HoldSuspect In Officer's Shooting
description: A 28yearold Manhattan man was arrested yesterday afternoon in connection with a barroom robbery that ended in the shotgun shooting of a Transit Authority police officer near the Jerome Avenue and East 176th Street IRT station last Monday night.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Iowa's Bruce Takes Over Hayes's Job at Ohio State

title: Office Buildings Struck by 1,700 In Wage Dispute; Effect on Service Will Not Be Known Till Monday
description: The 1,700 employees who provide heat, airconditioning and general maintenance services in more than 200 of Manhattan's largest office buildings voted yesterday to reject a final management contract offer and went on strike at 12:01 A.M. this morning.

title: Maul Fraud By Six Charged
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 12 (UPI)  Six persons have been charged with operating a fraudulent investment firm that Allegedly cheated more than 1,000 people out of an estimated $12 million and with setting up two bogus banks in the West Indies to hold the funds.

title: Hardesty Named in Shift At COmmonwealth Oil
description: The Commonwealth Oil Refining Company announced yesterday that it had elected C. Howard Hardesty as chairman, president and chief executive officer and had elected three new directors as part of an overall management reorganization.

title: Judge in Newark Averts Walkout Set by Teachers; Rules Board Must Rehire Dismissed Employees
description: NEWARK, Jan. 12 A Superior Court judge's ruling today that the Newark Board of Education's dismissal of more than 1,100 employees last month was invalid has averted a strike by more than 8,000 teachers and school employees scheduled for Tuesday.

title: Digest BUSINESS Digest; The Economy

The change was considered statistically insignificant, and little variation was reported in the jobless rates for the major demographic groups.. Total employment was 95.9 million, only 100,000 more than in November. Over the last year total employment rose by

title: Philadelphia Council Is Ordered To Sign a Contract for Housing
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 12 (UPI)  The Philadelphia City Council has been ordered by a judge to sign by Jan. 19 a contract for the construction of the Whitman Park Townhouse Droiect.

title: 100 Witnesses End Testimony In Murder Trial of Cullen Davis
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 13 (UPI)Testimony from 100 witnesses was completed today in the murder and conspiracy trial of T. Cullen Davis, a Fort Worth industrialist. District Judge Wallace Moore dismissed the jury until Tuesday and said several motions in the case and instructions to the iury would be areued Monday.

title: Soviet Lofts Cosmos 1070
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 12 (UPI)  The Soviet Union has sent up another of its Cosmos series of satellites into orbit, Tass, the Soviet press agency, reported today. Tass said that Cosmos 1070 was launched yesterday and was orbiting Earth every 89.5 minutes at an inclination of 62.8 degrees and distances ranging between 132.8 miles and 196.2 miles.

title: Yonkers Wavers on Getty Square Plan
description: YONKERS, Jan. 12City officials and merchants here say they have all but given up on the ambitious threeyear effort to turn downtown Yonkers into a major regional retail center and expect to focus on a more modest goal.

title: Madrid Bans Refueling for F15's on Visit to Saudis
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12  The Carter Administration said today that it had encountered problems in its plan to send a squadron of fighter planes to Saudi Arabia later this month because the Spanish Government refuses to allow the planes to land and refuel at an Americanrun base in Spain.

title: Playing Games With Prisons
description: When the United States Olympic Committee sought Federal funds to build a dormitory for the 1980 Winter Olympics at Lake Placid, N.Y., Congress required that the facility be put to some suitable use after the games were over. Along came the Federal Bureau of Prisons, in search of a site for a new prison in the Northeast. The result: Congress voted 322 million to build the dormitory; after 1980, it is to become a mediumsecurity prison for 500 inmates. That is fine for the Winter Olympics, but it is poor corrections policy.

title: Reward for Cezannes Is Doubled
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 12 (Reuters)The Chicago Art Institute today doubled Its reward to $100,000 for the recovery of three paintings by Ozanne. The paintings, valued at $3 million, disappeared last month from a locked storeroom.

title: Earnings Soar At Texas Bank
description: Texas Commerce Bancshares, parent of the Texas Commerce Bank in Houston, yesterday became the latest bank holding company to report a hefty gain in operating earnings for 1978 and the final quarter of the year.

title: Cleveland Newspaper Urged in Union Vote To Reinstate Reporter
description: CLEVELAND, Ohio, Jan. 12  Members of The Newspaper Guild at The Cleveland Plain Dealer demanded today that the newspaper's management reinstate and publicly apologize to a reporter who had beer told that he could no longer report on the Cleveland Electric Illuminating Company because he would be unfair.

title: Islanders Conquer Flames by 41

He started a rookie goalie, Rejean Lemelin, who had made only two previous National Hockey League appearances.

title: Koch Is Said to Devise Plan for Hiring Freeze In Uniformed Services
description: Mayor Koch is expected to announce on Monday that he intends to order a full hiring freeze in the Police, Fire and Sanitation Departments to close next year's budget gap if additional state and Federal aid is not forthcoming, according to high city officials who have been told of the Mayor's intentions.

title: Nehemiah Runs 7.02, Sets Hurdles Record
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md., Jan. 12 Rena!do Nehemiah of the University of Maryland opened the indoor track season in the East in sensational fashion on his home track tonight, flashing to a world best indoor time of 7.02 seconds for the 60yard high hurdles in the National C.Y.O. Invitation meet at Cole Field House.

title: Massacre by Nagas Reported in India Border State
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 12  Tribal raiders from Nagaland, a northeastern state of India, have massacred at least 50 people in attacks on 10 villages in the neighboring state of Assam.

title: JOBS FOR DECEMBER AND UNEMPLOYMENT SHOW LITTLE CHANGE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12  Employment and unemployment were virtually unchanged in December, the Labor Department reported today, but Secretary of Labor Ray Marshall said that the increase in jobholders and the decrease in joblessness over the last two years represented a tremendous national accomplishment.

title: Tunisian Jet Hijacked; 75 Passengers Are Freed
description: TUNIS, Saturday, Jan. 13 (UPI) Four unidentified hijackers commandeered an Air Tunis jetliner with 75 passengers yesterday, and after a ninehour flight over North Africa and the Mediterranean they released all the passengers unharmed in Tripoli, Libya, early today.

title: Headliners
description: Californians are about to find out what the wages of sin really amount to. Such was the condition under which Lee Marvin, the actor, and Michelle Triola Marvin, who legally changed her name to his but did not marry him, lived together for six years. Last week, Miss or Mrs. Marvin's suit for $1 million, based on what she claims was Mr. Marvin's promise to support her for life, reached court. Her attorney will argue that Mr. Marvin's promise, if be is found to have made it, amounts to a contract to share all with her in return for performance of the normal duties of a wife  housekeeping, cooking, companionship. Mr. Marvin has denied any commitment.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: Murry Sidlin, conductor of the New Haven Symphony, quoted Gustav Mahler recently: When he was battling antiSemitism in his efforts to obtain the directorship of the Vienna Opera, he complained, When will they finally  realize that my genius is greater than my nose is long?  Mr. Sidlin, who agrees with Mahler's assessment of himself as a genius, attributes the cornposer's rise and popularity to the acceptance of hlm as the grandest of the Romantics; Mahler took the symphonic form to its extremes in length and variety. He said his day would come and it has. Mr. Sidlin believes Mahler was spurred by the conflicts within himself as both a Catholic and a Jew, and by the artistic and intellectual conflicts of his day, in which Schoenberg, Debussy and Richard Strauss walked the earth at the same time as Freud, in Sidlin's words. Maureen Forrester will be the contralto soloist when Mr.  Sidlin conducts Mahler's Kindertotenlieder at Woolsey Hall in New Haven Tuesday at 8:30 P.M. Mahler's Third Symphony takes up the rest of the program. The morose quality of the songs for dead infants is turned around in the Third Symphony, said Mr. Sidlin. The children's song in the fourth movement is like a rebirth. Tickets are from $4 to $9. Telephone 8650831.

title: A Former U.S. Army Cook, Now Ruler in. Western Pacific Islands: Leads Foes of Military Bases There
description: KOROR, Palau  Five years ago Yutaka Gibbons wore the uniform of the United States Army as a cook and demolition man with the rank of Specialist 5, equivalent to sergeant. Today, as a paramount chief of the scenic Palau Islands in the Western Pacific, he leads the people who oppose proposed American military bases in this strategic chain about 500 miles east of the Philippines.

title: 2 Croatians Indicted Again
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 13 (UPI) Two Croatian nationalists were indicted again yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges that they seized the West German consulate in Chicago and held the employees hostage for 10 hours last Aue. 17. The two  Bozo Kelava, 30 years old, and Mile Kodzoman, 32  were convicted of the charges last November but their conviction was. dismissed Monday by Federal. District Judge Thomas R. McMillen. The judge said he had erred in his instructions to the jury.

description: CAIRO  The future of American archeological expeditions in Egypt, and of other scientific and cultural projects, has been placed in doubt by an approaching cutoff of United States grants from local currency received for grain sales.

title: Palestinian Guerrillas Are Killed in Assault on Hotel. in Northern Israel

description: Looking and acting every inch the Spanish grandee, tenor Alfredo Kraus commands attention on and off stage by virtue of a personality that suggests a man of considerable selfpossession and independence. This aura of aristocratic confidence and sophistication is abetted by a handsome appearance that belies his 52 years and gives credence to roles that usually find him singing romantic leads on operatic stages throughout the world in roles as varied as Nemorino in L'Elisir d'Amore, Des Grieux in Manon, the Duke in Rigoletto, or Alfredo in La Traviata.

description: SOMEWHERE north of Westchester, we have always known, there was a fabled country restaurant called Old Drovers Inn. The food, we were assured in our youth, was great, but the prices, we were warned, were high. We enjoyed knowing it was there, even though we never went.

title: GARDENING
description: IN STORMY New Jersey, winter deals harshly with gardens in general and traditional rock gardens in particular. Ice and matted leaves tend to discourage many alpine plants that would flourish on an open windswept slope.

title: GARDENING
description: THE Rev. Walter Brown and his Oyster Bay First Presbyterian congregation hope that the person who had a certain spruce Christmas tree this year had a merry Christmas, but they can't help wondering if any merriment might not have been tempered somewhat by a guilty conscience. The tree was stolen from where it had been growing alongside the front porch of the church manse.

title: A Struggle for the Hearts And Minds of Smokers
description: WASHINGTON  The 50 million Americans who buy cigarettes are increasingly becoming pawns in a protracted tug-of-war between the embattled tobacco industry and Federal and private pressure groups urging smokers to kick the habit. That fact became strikingly apparent last week as Dr. Julius B. Richmond, the Surgeon General of the United States, issued a new report citing overwhelming proof that smokinct is hazardous to health.

title: Mahaffey Leads by A Stroke
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Jan. 13 (AP) - John Mahaffey dropped a 10foot birdie putt on the final bole for a onestroke lead over Lee Trevino today after the fourth round of the W5,000 Desert Classic.

title: Yonkers Promotes Connolly
description: YONKERS (AP)  Tim Connolly, 25 years old, the former assistant publicity director at Yonkers Raceway, has been promoted to publicity director. He formerly was sports information director at Pratt Institute.

title: Industry's Told to Burn Natural Gas
description: Coal was king during the days the Administration was making its plans to spur alternative energy sources as a way to reduce oil imports. But a funny thing happened on the way to imple- mentation of the policy. A big surplus of natural gas developed, and Energy Secretary James R. Schlesinger found himself in New York last week outlin- ing to petroleumindustry analysts a major shift in policy - a stress on in- creased industrial consumption of natural gas instead of coal to cut oil im- ports.

title: A Katherine Dunham Celebration
description: A young man carefully counts his way through cakewalk strut. Another spirals up into an air turn, absorbed in the simple pleasure of the jump. Older dancers mingle with the young ones, squiring them through difficult phrases or elusive accents. Nearby, two chanting women lunge in and out of deep knee bends, heads shaking rhythmically. The air seethes with noisy private rituals. Give me an unh, not an `uh'... this is a blood sacrifice... down, down, dark, very heavy, Katherine Dunham commands softly, and the women dig into the glistening dance floor as if it were loam.

title: Debra J. Grady Sets Nuptials

title: Fords to Visit Mideast

title: ON THE ISLE
description: Looking around for something to call their musical group, which blends Renaissance, Baroque, jazz and Indian elements to produce an otherwordly sound, five young Long Island must= cians came up with Lothlorien. It is, after all, the name of that other-wordly forest in Tolkien's Lord of the Rings. For almost five years now, the quintet - Jim Palmer, Rebecca Dunnel, Yvonne Cable, Chris Weigers and Larry LeMasters - has been appearing on the local libraryschool circuit, bringing its unusual sound to anyone who would listen. Today at 2:30 P.M. the group moves its flutes, recorders, oboe, cello, string bass, piano, sitar, sarod, tamboura, tablas and drums into the Half Hollow Hills Community Library, 55 Vanderbilt Parkway, Dix Hills, for free concert.

title: Feud Snarls Giants Search
description: Now that Joe. Paterno has spoken up and Bill Walsh is spoken for, two of these candidates as the New York Giants next coach are no longer available. Joe Paterno told Wellington Mara not to bother making him an offer he couldn't refuse; he was content to remain on Penn State's football faculty. Bill Walsh. mean-while, left. Stanford to accept the San Francisco 49crs job. And so the Giants search continues  the search for a director of operations to succeed Andy Robustelli and for a coach who has the director of operation's approval. But both must have the approval of the Maras, who control the Giants stock  Wellington, the club president, and his nephew, Tim, the vice president and treasurer. Quietly, there are indications that the Maras are working on different wavelengths.

description: It's been on the back burner for a long time, since 1974, said actress Ruby Dee, and it's nowhere near what it started out to be. Miss Dee was speaking of her fantasy musical, Take It From the Top, in which she stars with her husband Ossie Davis, opening on Thursday at the Henry Street Settlement Theater. The show, directed by Mr. Davis, was first conceived as a vehicle to introduce poems by youngsters whom Miss Dee had met through her daughter's poetry workshop, but the connecting material by Miss Dee grew and grew. ('I found myself writing a fantasy farce, and now most of the poems aren't in it.') The production, which includes comedy, dance, music and choral speech, will run through Jan. 28. (See Theater)

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: During the Holocaust, art was a means of coping with stress and survival for children confined in concentration camps. Dr. Frances Grossman, who received the Holocaust Memorial Award from the New York Society of Clinical Psychologists for her study of the subject, will present a slide lecture entitled Psychological Study of Children's Concentration Camp Art: A Means of Communicating the Unspeakable, Tuesday at 8 P.M., in the Scarsdale Library at Post and Olmsteads. The children who expressed them in this way lasted two to three years longer than those who didn't, Dr. Grossman revealed about the 7- to 14yearold victims *she investigated. There is very little color in their work, because of the limited materials they would embroider pieces of graph paper stolen from the Nazis, or make collages out of bits of found material and all the work was done in secret. Whereas the adults drew pictures of suffering in a documentary way, the children drew fantasies of food and freedom. Fifty slides of children's work from the Terezin Concentration Camp in Czechoslovakia will be supplemented with readings from their prose and poetry. A special exhibition of drawings by Sarah Swenson, also relative to the Holocaust, will be on view. No charge for admission. Information 7232005.

title: MUSIC

description: When you try to figure out what made you do what you did when you did it, it's rather difficult. I started out with the Lily Cup Company selling paper cups for about 17 years. When I opened my own little business, it was not really an entrepreneurtype business  I was a salesman again. I was the exclusive sales agent for the world for a multiple milkshake mixer, the Multi Mixer, except that the world wouldn't know what to do with it. There had never been a product like it before.

title: The Government Can Do Anything With Gas but Create It
description: Just two winters ago, natural gas was so scarce in the United States that, for want of it, factories were laying off workers and schools were closing their doors. Yet today the nation has an excess of gas  so much so that Energy Secretary James R. Schlesinger last week urged electric utilities and other industrial users to start burning gas anew. It was, as one observer put it, an amazing flipflop in national enerzy policy.

description: BUFFALO, Jan. 13  Federal energy officials presided at an emotional and frequently angry meeting of several hundred upstate residents today over the issue of what should become of the bankrupt atomicwaste reprocessing plant at West Valley, N.Y., about 30 miles southeast of here.

title: Vermont Bank and Fuel Company File Against a Closed College
description: PUTNEY, Vt., Jan. 13 (AP) - The Vermont National Bank filed'a foreclosure action this week against the closed Windham College in Putney and several other creditors to collect on a $150,000 debt and $7,200 in interest.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: LIKE NORMAL PEOPLE By Robert Meyers.

title: Sugar Dispute An Issue Still To Be Settled
description: For four decades, under the JonesCostigan Sugar Act of 1939 and its successor, the Sugar Act of 1998, American producers were protected by import quotas against severe competition from abroad, where prices were often below domestic production costs.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: MY MEMORY was happily jogged the other day. read that the Meadowbrook in Cedar Grove had signed a contract with Actors Equity and will offer a series of plays, the first of which will be Neil Simon's Come Blow Your Horn. The opening per- formance is scheduled for Jan. 31.

title: Who Said Suffolk? I'm FromPeconic!
description: IN Dear Pen Pal: I'm From Suffolk . . . [Opinion Page, Dec. 29], Michael Dorman, who lives in a place called Dix Hills, writes that the Hampton contain no real people. The only real people in Suffolk County, he insists, are the troglodytes in doubleknit suits from western Suffolk County. He insists that the only real people on the East End, as opposed to genuine phonies, are to be found in Riverhead.

title: Steelers Copied Cowboy Methods
description: The persons who run the Cowboys and Steelers, the Super Bowl rivals, share a common policy and a philosophy. Not surprising since Pittsburgh copied its methods from Dallas a decade ago.

title: Limitation of Fish Catches Requires Care
description: There is scarcely anyone including commercial fishermen  who does not believe that the catch of the food fishes off our shores must be limited if the sustained annual yield of the species is to be insured.

title: A Grand Jury Vote Is Getting Near
description: ATLANTA  Since June 1977, Bert Lance has been under uninterrupted Federal investigation. His business affairs and personal finances have been scrutinized by the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Senate Government Operations Committee, the Federal Elections Commission, the Internal Revenue Service and the Federal Bureau of Investigation. One lawyer, a Lance partisan, says that the blizzard of subpoenas have vacuumed up enough documents to fill a railroad boxcar and that the cost of the investigation to the American taxpayer will run in the millions of dollars. He may well be right.

title: President Says He Lacks Control Over His Brother
description: The President, in an interview with NBC News, said that he and Billy are two very independent people and would be counterproductive for him to tell his younger brother to keep quiet in public.

title: POLITICS
description: THE battle of the budget in Nassau County isn't over yet. Nassau County Executive Francis T. Purcell, who had to bow to the refusal of the County Board of Supervisors to increase county real-estate taxes as he had requested, predicted in an interview that the county would have serious fiscal problems before the current year ends.

title: Kennedy, in New Attack, Says Carter Budget Approach Favors the Rich
description: At a time of austerity in Federal spending, it is unfair to concentrate on cuts in direct spending alone, while providing a blank check for all the spending programs contained in the Internal Revenue Codethe tax expenditure programs, Senator Kennedy said.

title: Experimental Rock. Vigorous in Britain
description: Rock is an indisputably American creation. But the British caught on quickly, and from the time of the Beatles onwards, British acts have defined the form in disproportionate strength to the relative populations of the two countries. A re- cent sampling of British new wave disks indicates that there is still a lot of life left in that country's experimental rock camp.

title: Flying to Arabia, Unarmed
description: So a dozen unarmed F15 fighters will tour Saudi Arabia to calm the sheiks in their time of frantic concern about the turmoil in Iran. With this highly visible flyin, the United States Government sayss it serves notice that, though it could not save the Shah, it might intervene directly if as yet unidentified forces threaten the regime that controls a fourth or more of the West's oil supply. To the extent that great powers are expected to make a gesture of response to unsettling events, this one is harmless enough. Unless, of course, it is mistaken for a policy.

title: Anne R. Kalb Sets Wedding April 22
description: Anne Rise Kalb and Abraham Jay Bronner, who expect to graduate from the Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine in May, plan to be married April 22 at Temple Emanuel in Great Neck, L.I.

title: Carey Plan Asks Rent Increases, Loans to MitchellLama Tenants
description: ALBANY, Jan. 13 - Governor Carey will propose limited rent increases for MitchellLama tenants and a revolving loan fund for projects that cannot meet their operating expenses as part of his third effort in the last year to save the debtridden middleincome housing program from bankruptcy.

title: Japanese Learn English Melodically
description: SEVERAL years ago, Jane Hein, a Scarsdale music teacher, saw something that jolted her memory. Walking near her home, she observed young Japanese mothers and their children, and remembered how she felt when she had lived in a foreign country and did not speak its language.

title: Strike Halts Ford Plant in Spain
description: VALENCIA, Spain. Jan. 13 (Reuters) A strike by workers paralyzed the Ford Motor Company's new factory at nearby Almusafes today, union sources reported. The unions have called for a strike every Saturday until management agrees to re. duce working hours.

title: NEW JERSEY HOUSING
description: EVEN in the biting cold, construction and sales have been brisk at Century Tower, a cooperative of 290 apartments in Fort Lee. If nothing else, this attests to the fact that the Century City complex, of which Century Tower is a part, has truly been born again.

description: WANTAGH, L.I., Jan. 13  Last April, in Mexico City, Danny O'Connor was introduced to Jerzy Hauslabor. Now O'Connor believes the meeting will make him a better race walker.

title: Wintering in the Parks: Fit .for Man and Beast
description: At the mention of Yellowstone National Park, images of Old Faithful are immediately conjured, followed closely by pictures of white water rushing wildly through steep canyons and pastoral scenes animals grazing on a distant hillside. And, for those who have journeyed there during a recent summer, memories may linger of endless lines of cars and campers, overbooked motels and an infinity whining children. All are common fare on the country's vacation circuit.

Charles Getman, son of Charles W. Getman of Rochester and the late Virginia Henry Getman. The Rev. title: The Religious Leadership, the Military and the National Front Vie for Power
description: TEHERAN, Iran  Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, who appears to be in his final days in power, and Prime Minister Shahpur Bakhtiar, who is in his first ones, both found themselves confronted last week by the opposition of three separate elements of Iranian society as the country's crisis passed its first anniversary. A year after protests broke out in the holy city of Qom, the Shah and the Prime Minister were under fire from the westernized National Front, from hardline elements in the army who mistrust Dr. Bakhtiar and think the Shah has gone soft, and from Moslem leaders who want an Islamic republic.

title: Efficiency and Reliability Key to Horsepower Race
description: LAST year, Johnson and Evinrude ran neck-and-neck in the outboard motor horsepower race, each with a 235-horsepower unit, and Mercury followed with a 200. This year, the race has been called on account of fuel concerns and a new approach is being worked out.

title: Republicans Named to Vacancies In L.I. Legislature Feel Up to Job

But last Tuesday, Mr. Allgrove was sitting at the horseshoeshaped table in Suffolk County's legislative chamber in Hauppauge savoring the new, much less respectful adult world of which he is now a part.

title: Ivan Tcherepnin Plays
description: In part because he is the son of the late Alexandre Tcherepnin, the Russian composer, Ivan Tcherepnin was able to attract a rather heady crowd for the first of his two evenings Friday night at the Kitchen it isn't often that one encounters Philip Glass, Elliott Carter and Virgil Thomson all in one smallish audience. Born in 1943, Mr. Tcherepnin studied with Leon Kirchner, Karlheinz Stockhausen and Pierre Boulez, and taught in the San Francisco area before becoming associate professor of music at Harvard and director of that university's Electronic Music Studio.

title: Boy Hurt as Montrealer Derails
description: HOLYOKE, Mass.,Jan. 13 (AP) Amtrak's Montrealer passenger train derailed in the Jones Point section of this western Massachusetts city today, injuring one boy and shaking up seven of the 213 travelers aboard. A police spokesman. said that all eight cars had left the tracks shortly before 4:15 A.M. but had remained upright.

title: If You Can't Fight City Hall, Join It and Try
description: if the job of City Council President is ceremonial, as is generally believed, Council President Carol Bellamy hasn't learned that lesson yet. She and the 50 or so young, eager, idealistic people on her staff  the kind who might have worked for Bobby Kennedy charge into issue after issue, from transportation to the city's budget to the South Bronx to a Con Edison rate increase, coming up with thoughtful reports and speeches and press releases. But last week, she put on another hat, as a member of the board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, and she clearly made her presence felt.

title: GARDENING.
description: THE red flowers of poinsettia linger on and generate a bit of ennui at this time of year. Another flower color might help. One such as golden yellow would be closer to spring. There is just enough time for gardeners in this area to catch a glimpse of a rather special yellow flower  the acacia.

title: Aching Palomino Has ion in Ring
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., Jan. 13  It hurts Carlos Palomino's right hand worse when he lands a punch perfectly. Shocks of pain shoot up his arm. His left hand was broken last year; his back still hurts, and there are ligaments in his right shoulder that were put back together by an acupuncture expert of dubious medical background.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: THERE was a great increase in suicides along the Long Island Rail Road's right-ofway in 1978, an increase that neither the railroad nor lawenforcement officers are equipped to deal with or suggest an explanation for.

title: Iran's Exiled Moslem Leader Picks Council to Form a Religious State
description: PARIS,Jan. 13  Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the religious lea'er of Iran's opposition, stepped up his fight today for the ouster of the Shah and abolition of the monarchy, announcing that he had formed the equivalent of a shadow cabinet charged with preparing institutions for an Islamic republic in Iran.

title: Nancy Snider Is Betrothed to Jeffrey Budge
description: The engagement of Nancy Snider to Jeffrey D. Budge has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Eliot Snider of Chestnut Hill, Mass. The prospective bridegroom is a son of Donald Budge, the tennis player, and Mrs. Budge of Dingman's Ferry, Pa. A March wedding is planned.

title: The World
description: For 30 years, Peking's oneChina policy has raised among Nationalist Chinese and their American supporters the specter of an invasion of Taiwan. But the guns of Quemoy and Matsu, the Nationalist outposts that have served as a sort of tripwire against such an invasion, have been silent for a long time. And, if the policy enunciated in Peking last week is pursued, they are likely to stay that way. Visiting United States senators reported that Deputy Prime Minister Teng Hsiaoping proposed a unified China in which Taiwan would keep its autonomy, even its present Nationalist Government and armed forces, as well as its emphatically capitalist economic system, if the Nationalists would only acknowledge unity under Peking's sovereignty. According to the senators, China's demands seemed to boil down to the question of whose flag flies over Taiwan.

title: OIL INDUSTRY HAILS U.S. ROLE IN TALKS
description: If the Government behaves with other unions and industries as it did with us, I'd say it's going to be successful, said Merlin Breaux, a vice president of the Gulf Oil Company who was the chief industry negotiator in last week's contract talks with the Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers Union.

title: A Flat Prospect For German Beer
description: MUNICH, West Germany  A year ago, when the growth in German beer consumption turned flat, brewers blamed the weather: too cold, too wet, too little sunshine. Now, with new figures that show a steeper sales decline, brewers are acknowledging that the problem isn't the rainfall in Bavaria but what seems to be an irreversible change in German life style. West Germany is still the world's largest per capita beer consumer and the world's leading exporter, but its citizens are ever more counting calories and tipping toward wine. After 25 consecutive years of golden growth, the brewery business has been transformed into a nervous, pessimistic and contracting industry.

title: Pound Speaking;
description: IN his lifetime, Ezra Pound was often dismissed as an overextended esthete; in fact, he came close being a Confucius of his generation: a brilliantly selfeducated man who had an uncanny sense of what really mattered in literature but who never flinched from trying by means of his pen and voice to expose and condemn what he perceived to be injustices in the world. Eliot had a flirtation with Charles Maurras and his royalist Action Francaise, but Pound gave his heart and soul to politics and economics; he meant when he embraced Confucius, and the even more passionately activist Mencius. His Chinese mentors had straddled teaching and political theory, and so would he.

title: Alberta, a Chilly Version of the Sun Belt, Begins to Show Its Muscle
description: EDMONTON, Alberta  In the rotunda of the Legislative Building in this provincial capital, a fountain gushes over colored lights, surrounded by 99 potted poinsettia plants. At a time of fiscal austerity for many North American governments, this is an apt symbol of the blossoming of Alberta, a former agricultural backwater fast emerging as the most assertive of Canada's fractious provinces.

title: Why Edwardiana Reigns on TV
description: British television screens, for the past several years, have been awash with Edwardiana. It is as though the whole industry there had collectively agreed. to celebrate the last period when the country could still be thought of as glorious  the highliving years before World War and the Empire's decline, when Britain was more prosperous than at any time before or since; when the middle and upper classes spent money lavishly in climbing the social ladder and the aristocracy felt serenely unapproachable; when fashionable women's clothes used up material and decorations with conspicuous extravagance; when the dinner tables of the wealthy were accustomed to menus of a dozen courses or more; and when town houses and country houses ran with a smoothness only made possible by battalions of servants.

title: Gus Solomons Jr. Offers Two New Dance Works
description: Gus Solomons Jr. has long been one of the wonders of the dance world. His lanky frame has limbs that seem to stretch to infinity and pretzel into the oddest of shapes. A black choreographer, he has worked well beyond the black modern dance tradition, choos- ing to choreograph within the style of Merce Cunningham, with whom he once danced. And best of all, at his best he is unfailingly astringent and playful, though for all that his is fairly private dance. The good news is that a concert on Friday by the Solomons Company/ Dance at the Theater of the Riverside Church proved that Mr. Solomons is still at it all.

title: His SubjectMysteries Of Different Cultures; Richard Weir Last Wave Director
description: I was frightened by a noise heard outside my window last night, by a rasping, an inhuman sound which seemed to come from nowhere. That's a fear we've all experienced at one time or another. Some choose to forget such fears. I choose to remember them, to use them in my work. The speaker was Peter Weir, the firs) of the Australian new wave of directors to win commercial distribution in this country. His is a splashy, twopicture debut  not only will his Picnic at Hanging Rock open in New York next month, but when Mr. Weir's The Last Wave had its premiere in December, The Times's Vincent Canby called it a movingly moody shockfilm and praised the director's ability to find the eerie in the commonplace.

title: A Playwrights Choice of Perfect Plays
description: With the theater season off to a fresh start in the New Year, hope again soars in the breast of every theatergoer that maybe next week - or perhaps the week afterhe will encounter that most elusive of all theatrical creations: the perfect play. To explore the phenomenon, The Times invited a number of leading American playwrights, from Robert Anderson to Tennessee Williams, to name the plays they consider to be the most nearly perfect examples of the dramatist's art. Their replies follow.

Finally, he ap- peared before the United Nations Security Council in New York to plead for help against the Vietnamese onslaught against Cambodia.

Bucking the trend of recent years to informality, all were dressed elegantly the women in long black skirts and similarly styled satin blouses of various harmonious colors and the men in nothing less than full whitetie evening dress. All this, plus the group's excellent stage deportment, was quite refreshing.

title: Hate, Ancient and Modern, Led to Pol Pot's Downfall
description: BANGKOK  When the mopping up in Cambodia is finished, an Indochinese federation of Vietnamese design will exist in all but in name. Perhaps it exists already, because most analysts here believe that the remnants of former Prime Minister Pol Pot's armed forces cannot reverse Vietnam's lightning victory, sealed when its forces conquered Phnom Penh last Sunday. Mr. Pol Pot's brave words about people's war until final victory for eternity if necessary  depend on forces that seem irrevocably beyond his control: the willingness, and the ability, of a significant number of Cambodians to continue fighting against the Vietnamese Army and Cambodian forces trained and supplied by Vietnam. No doubt the most fanatical Khmer Rouge soldiers, and those Cambodians who deem Vietnam the greatest of all evils, are prepared to fight on. But the people whom the Vietnamese are installing in power are certified Cambodian nationalists with unimpeachable Khmer Rouge backgrounds. Mr. Pol Pot was not notably successful at fighting them when he ruled all Cambodia, with a seaport through which China could supply him.

title: IN BRIEF
description: A jump of eighttenths of 1 percent last month helped to raise the producer price index to a 9.1 percent annual rate in 1978, the largest annual increase since the 18.3 percent recorded in 1979, according to the Commerce Department. Producer prices at the finished goods level measure what used to be called wholesale prices, and presage consumer price movements. Gasoline prices were singled out as the largest factor in the December increase, rising 4 percent after adjustment for seasonal factors. Food prices, which had fueled most of the earlier increases, rose at about the same level as the overall index. ... According to the depart- ment, retail sales in 1978 climbed 10 percent - about the same as the rate of inflation. December's gain was 1 per- cent, a mild disappointment to those who looked to Christmas buying to spark a stronger showing. In fact, de- partment stores recorded a moderate 2 percent gain in sales for the month and a 4 percent increase from the year- earlier period. ... Businesses plan to increase outlays for new plant and equipment at an inflationadjusted an- nual rate of 3 percent in 1979 - a set- back for the Carter Administration, which has said that a 7 to 9 percent in- crease would benefit the economy. Last year, according to the Commerce Department, the increase in capital spending was 4.5 percent and in 1977 it amounted to nearly 6.5 percent.

title: OFF AND RUNNING AGAINST INFLATION; After a headlinemaking stint as the provocative head of the C.A.B., Alfred Kahn is rushing into the fight on inflation. Can he bring it under control? Economists think he has a chance  if he stops 'shooting from the lip.; KAHN; KAHN
description: Just before 7 A.M. on most weekday mornings, a craggyfaced, slightly distracted professor with a comic's wit and ready grin puts his paper work aside. Up at 6:15 A.M., he has already spent about 45 minutes reading reports, scrawling notes and dictating into a pocket recorder. Now, he dons a green warmup suit and worn running shoes, stints a swimsuit into a canvas bag and jogs the six blocks from his Capitol Hill town house to the Capitol East Natatorium, a place where, he explains, you nat. By 8 A.M., toweled off from his nat, Alfred Edward Kahn is trotting home to breakfast and the start of his real upstream swim of the day  battling the raging current of inflation. Or rather, as he sees it, the endless sea.

title: Ideas &Trends
description: Peptic ulcers are one of the commonest of serious diseases  and one of the least understood. Doctors have presumed that the causes are both genetic and environmental but have had trouble identifying particular factors. Last week The New England Journal of Medicine reported the strongest evidence to date linking heredity to many peptic ulcers. Specifically, researchers say that persons who have inherited a high level of something called pepsinogen I in their blood are five times as likely as other persons to have an ulcer.

title: Fresh Statistics Last Week Reported Spiraling Outlays
description: WASHINGTON  Even in a society in which the cost of everything keeps going up, the 1978 Congressional elections probably set startling records for political inflation. According to statistics disclosed last week, every candidate for the Senate, whether winner or loser, spent more than $900,000 campaigning. In 1976, the average was $595,000. As for the House, full reports are not yet in, but a sample of a score of Representatives shows that typical campaign spending rose from $36,500 three years ago to over $80,000 last year. Not coincidentally, the average each accepted from special interest groups went from $22.000 to nearli $45.000.

title: The Strange Case Of Ted Bundy;
description: Jon Nordheimer presents a wellwritten narrative of the chronology of the strange case of Ted Bundy (AllAmerican Boy on Trial, Dec. 10). However, some points should be clarified. I was living in Aspen during the Colorado phase of Mr. Bundy's imprisonment. His capture there after his first escape was hardly dramatic. He was pulled over by a sheriff's deputy for erratic driving. Only later did she realize Ted Bundy was the driver. The sheriff was humiliated; so were a host of others. But the sheriff's office wasn't, and probably still isn't, equipped to deal with big city crimes and criminals.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (UPI)  Railway clerks are expected to approve a new contract this week in a major step toward labor peace on the railroads for the next three years, negotiators said today.

title: U.S. Proposal on Taiwan Relations Sets Up Institute to Direct Affairs
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14  In the aftermath of Washington's decision to sever diplomatic relations with Taipei and establish full ties with Peking, the Administration has drafted legislation on the new type of relationship that the United States seeks with Taiwan's government.

title: Chile's Unions Get Outside Help To Break Army's Grip on Labor
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 19  Chilean labor has been so intimidated by repression and unemployment during the last five years under military rule that the only form of organized protest has been a refusal by workers to eat meals in company mess halls.

title: Sugar Dispute Still an Issue To Be Settled
description: For four decades, under the JonesCostigan Sugar Act of 1934 and its successor, the Sugar Act of 1948, American producers were protected by import quotas against severe competition from abroad, where prices were often below domestic production costs.

title: Bosworth Widening Monitoring
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14  Barry P. Bosworth, the chief monitor of compliance with the Administration's voluntary price and pay standards, recently sent a letter to a midtown Manhattan parking garage asking whether an increase in its monthly rates  to $100 from $80  complied with the price standard.

title: President, in Atlanta, Asks Congress to Vote Holiday for Dr. King
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 14  President Carter, promising that his Administration would remain true to the goals of the late Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., called on Congress today to designate the slain civil rights leader's birthday a national holiday.

title: Ballet: Baryshnikov's Temperaments Debut
description: NO fat. That was the kind of programming the New York City Ballet offered Saturday night at the New York State Theater with three of George Balanchine's most cerebral and complex ballets. All are examples of the socalled Balanchine practiceclothes ballets the avantgarde choreography to contemporary music that stems from the style Mr. Balanchine first essayed in 1946 in Four Temperaments, whose score he had commissioned from Paul Hindemith.

title: Steelers
description: PITTSBURGH'S is a bigplay team, and the man who makes the big plays happen is the quarterback, Terry Bradshaw, who has had a better season than his counterpart, Roger Staubach. Bradshaw reached a personalhigh total of 28 touchdown passes in the regular season and completed 56.3 percent of his attempts.

title: Deaths
description: MORABITODorothy. On January 13, devoted mother of Paul, Catherine DeLorenzo and Lillian LaMattlna, also survived by eight grandchildren. Funeral Tuesday 9 A.M. from the E.C. Waldeck Home For Funerals, 7614 4th Avenue, Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday 9:30 A.M. at Our Lady of Angels R.C. Church, Brooklyn.

title: Dance: Icarus by Gypsy Rainbow
description: IT never quite worked. Not on any level. And, presumably, many levels were intended. These harsh words apply to Icarus  Labyrinth of Desire, the mixedmedia com- position that the Gypsy Rainbow Dance Theater of Atlanta brought to the Westbeth Theater on Saturday evening.

title: Debate Rises on Mandatory School Plans for Handicapped
description: The seeds of controversy are being planted in public schools nationwide over issues posed by a new Federal law requiring that a special program of education be designed for each of the nation's 3,554,000 handicapped schoolage children.

title: $100 Cab Ride Is Laid To Language Problem
description: A Japanese businessman said last night that a cab driver had charged him $100 for a trip from Kennedy Airport to the Biltmore Hotel  more than five times the normal rate  threatening to keep his luggage if he did not pay up.

title: Georgia Politicians in Quandary About Backing Talmadge
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 19  When the State Legislature convened here last week, Representative Gerald Talmadge Horton noticed something wrong with his official name tag.

title: Pop: Rush Plays at Palladium
description: ROCK critics spend a lot of time splashing about in the new wave, but an occasional dunking in the old wave probably wouldn't harm them any. Of course, the notion of old wave rock is even vaguer than new wave, because it encompasses anything that isn't new. Rush, a Canadian rock trio that was at the Palladium Saturday night (and again last night), no doubt thinks of itself as venturesome, and it can hardly be denied that a big, demonstrative crowd was on hand Saturday. Even if Rush feels a bit miffed about the way it's ignored by the supposed tastemakers of rock, it can take consolation in its audience's enthusiasm.

title: Carter's Watchman Over Sugar Policy
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14  One of Howard Hjort's earliest memories is huddling on the front porch of his family's eastern Montana farmhouse at the tag end of the Great Depression and watching a hailstorm cut their vegetable garden to pieces.

title: Nets Beat Celtics, 110100
description: BOSTON, Jan. 14  Choose your confrontation. There was Kevin Loughery, the coach of the Nets, versus the officials of the National Basketball Association. There was Dave Cowens, the

title: Events
description: LATER, by Corinne Jacker. Staged by Daniel Freudenberger. Presented by the Phoenix Theater, T. Edward Hambleton. managing director. At the Marymount Manhattan Theater, 221 East list Street, at

title: Miss Caulkins Sets BreastStroke Mark
description: NASHVILLE, Jan. 14 (AP)  Tracy Caulkins set an American record of 1 minute 2.06 seconds in the women's 100yard breaststroke last night at the Nashville Aquatic Club international invitation meet.

title: Phone Company Poll Finds Improvement In Business Climate
description: A survey conducted by the New York Telephone Company reported yesterday that 40 percent of 179 New York State business leaders believed that in the last year the state had improved as a place in which to conduct business, but that half of them believed that it still faced a loss of businesses in the next two or three years.

title: On the Track of Legionnaires' Disease
description: The finding of bacteria, that cause legionnaires' disease in the airconditioning tower atop Macy's Herald Square department store, which was disclosed last week, came only after painstaking medical detective work. In fact, the discovery that there had been an outbreak of the disease in the garment center last summer was itself a result of intensive medical investigation.

title: Bucks 104, Bulls 99
description: MILWAUKEE, Jan. 14 (AP)  The Milwaukee Bucks, sparked by 34 points from Marques Johnson, opened an 11point halftime lead and held off a Chicago comeback for a 10499 victory over the Bulls today.

title: A Planner Among the Planners
description: Vacancies come and vacancies go on the sevenmember New York City Planning Commission, but architects or planners seldom fill them. What used to be a game of borough or ethnic roulette has been formalized by the new City Charter, which specifies that a member of the commission must be appointed from each borough. This procedure, designed to be evenhanded, has turned into an exercise in local party politics.

title: Market Place
description: IS the General Refractories Company about to be aquired, or are the company's shares simply regarded as undervalued in Wall Street?

title: MISSIONARY LEADERS WORRY ABOUT CHINA
description: While American politicians and businessmen try to build new links with a suddenly receptive Chinese Government, few Christian missionary officials see any chance of open evangelical work in China, which was once a fertile field for Western missions.

title: Harris and Waters: Terrific Tandem at Safety
description: DROP them anywhere in romantic history, and they would belong together  as knights, as pirates, as cowboys. Especially as cowboys, because that is what Cliff Harris and Charlie Waters are now  the free safety and the strong safety, respectively, in the defensive backfield of the Dallas Cowboys, who will oppose the Pittsburgh Steelers next Sunday in Super Bowl XIII.

title: Trucking: Deregulation Debate
description: It is clear that the trucking industry fears for its bread and butter in the current trend toward deregulation. However, while the motor transport companies complain to all who will listen that more trucking competition would wither their profits, another and perhaps deeper debate is going on.

title: Woman Kills Family and Herself
description: WINSTONSALEM, N.C.. Jan. 19 (UPI)  A farm wife shot and killed her two young children and her husband today and then took her own life, the authorities said. Found dead in the couple's home near here were Barbara Yokeley, 25 years old; Gerald Yokeley, 27; their daughter, Michael, 6, and their son, Will, 3. Capt. Jim Johnson of the sheriff's department said the the woman apparently killed her husband and son as they slept, called a minister, and then killed the girl and herself. Investigators, he said, were at a loss to determine a reason for the incident.

title: Lummox From The Transvaal
description: KALLIE Knoetze may be a symbol of South Africa's statutory bigotry or he may be a bystander caught in the middle of a racist struggle, depending on your view. On one point, however, there need be no doubt: as a professional fighter he is a lubberly lout.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: One of the nation's top corporate jobs quietly changed hands over the weekend as the board of directors of the ColgatePalmolive Company named Keith Crane as its chief executive officer, replacing David R. Foster, who resigned for reasons of ill health. However, Colgate left Mr. Foster's position as chairman vacant.

title: Housing Aided By Governments At 5Year High
description: Mayor Koch announced yesterday that Governmentassisted housing starts in New York City, which had lagged severely in the last few years, amounted to more than 16,700 in 1978, the highest number in five years.

title: Windmill Owner Tilting With Utility
description: THOMPSON RIDGE, N.Y., Jan. 14  For Martin Greenwald, the answer is blowingin the wind.

title: Votes in '80 Italian Election Sought by Brooklyn Visitor
description: Benigno Zaccagnini, secretary of the ruling Christian Democratic Party of Italy, went on the campaign trail yesterday to court a new block of voters  in Brooklyn.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Senator Schmitt Won't Challenge Alaskan for G.O.P. Senate Whip
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (UPI)  Senator Harrison Schmitt of New Mexico announced today that he had decided not to challenge Senator Ted Stevens of Alaska for the job of assistant Senate Republican leader.

title: Chess: Why Is a Big Swiss Event Tust Like a Haberdashery?
description: Swiss system tournaments with a large entry and few rounds often result in ties for the top prizes, since the leaders do not all get a chance to meet each other, In effect, each player is playing

title: New Freedom Excites Iran Journalists
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 14  The newsroom of Etelaat, a Teheran newspaper, was bright with flowers sent by enthusiastic readers. The reporters were smiling.

title: Number of Rabbis Who Perform Marriages to NonJews Is Rising
description: The number of rabbis willing to perform marriages between Jews and nonJews, while still a small percentage, has risen steadily despite continued opposition by all rabbinical groups, according to Rabbi Irwin H. Fishbein of Westfield, N.J., who has compiled a list of his colleagues who will perform mixed marriages.

title: On the Beach: Saint Laurent And Valentino
description: In the beginning, there was perfume. Then came scarves, jewelry, sheets, shoes. There wasn't much that fashion designers didn't put their hands to.

title: Sports World Specials
description: James H. Van Alen shook up some people in the world of tennis, then a game with particularly heavy emphasis on tradition, when he introduced the Van Men System of Simplified Scoring hack in 1964. VASSS, as it became known, called for 31point matches, each point scored individually instead of with the traditional terminology of 15, 30, 40, deuce, which for the most part has remained.

title: The Editorial Notebook
description: Many Americans today commemorate the 50th birthday of the late Martin Luther King, principal spokesman for the civil rights movement until his assassination in 1968. That movement has been transformed in the years since his death.

title: Television
description: 7:30 P.M. The Muppets (2)

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Why did John Madden, former coach of the Oakland Raiders, always wear what appeared to be skilift tags on his pants as he paced the sideline?

title: Notes on People
description: John Wayne's recovery is right on target, a spokesman for the University of California at Los Angeles Medical Center said yesterday. The 71yearold actor, whose cancerous stomach was removed last Friday in a ninehour operation, was said to be in good condition, with no apparent spread of the disease to other organs. The two most important factors contributing to his excellent early postoperative recovery, the spokesman said, are his general strong physical condition and his positive attitude.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRIVING TODAY, Jan.15

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Washington's involvement in the global sugar industry, long bizarre mixture of domestic and foreign politics, has resulted in efforts by lobbyists on both sides of the question to influence sugar legislation. [Page A1.] Howard Hjort, the Agriculture Department official trying to sort out the sugar problem, has been versed in hard times since his boyhood on a Montana farm. [D4.]

title: NoIron Process For Cotton Shirts
description: Men's allcotton, permanentpress shirts are the new hope of the shirt industry  not just a white hope, either, but in colors, patteras and stripes, too.

title: ALASKANS PROTEST PUBLICLAND ACTION
description: CANTWELL, Alaska, Jan. 14  In an atmosphere reminiscent of the days before the American Revolution, more than 2,500 Alaskans demonstrated this weekend against President Carter's setting aside 56 million acres in Alaska for national monuments.

title: Benitez Wins W.B.C. Title
description: SAN JUAN, P.R. Jan. 14  Carlos Palomino knew the heat would bother him. He didn't know how much until today when the only breeze in the 86-degree weather in Estadio Hiram Bithorn was when he swung and missed at the new World Boxing Council welterweight champion, Wilfredo Benitez.

title: Concordes Begin Texas Service, And Almost Everyone Is Happy
description: GRAPEVINE, Tex., Jan. 14  The Concorde, the supersonic airliner that brought out hordes of angry demonstrators when it began service to Washington and New York City, inaugurated flights at the DallasFort Worth Airport this weekend. Once again it drew a crowd.

title: Marjorie Lawrence, Wagnerian Soprano, Dead at 71
description: Marjorie Lawrence, the Australianborn dramatic soprano whose flourishing career was curtailed by infantile paralysis in 1941 and whose life story was made into a Hollywood film, died Saturday in St. Vincent'Infirmary in Little Rock, Ark. She was 71 years old.

title: Hearings on Sugar Ads
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 19 (UPI) The Federal Trade Commission is to open 10 days of hearings tomorrow to pinpoint problems of advertising aimed at children and to determine what remedies may be warranted. Testi- mony is expected from 88 witnesses, many representing major companies that spend millions of dollars yearly on children's TV commercials. Critics contend that many of the ads are for heavily sugared cereals that arc harmful to children.

title: Jazz: Adam Makowicz
description: WHEN Adam Makowicz, a Polish jazz pianist, made his debut in New York almost two years ago at the Cookery, he was preceded by glowing accounts of a technique and style in the tradition of Art Tatum. This is the kind of burden that no young pianist needs and, although his technique was impressive, the Tatum comparisons and his attempts to live up to them shadowed whatever he had to offer that was his own.

title: School Bus Crash Kills Teacher
description: MADRAS, Ore. Jan. 19 (UPI)  A school bus collided with a truck last night, killing the teacher and injuring at least eight other persons, the state police reported. The bus was carrying a wrestling team. The victim was identified as Rhonda Kay Yost, 30 years old, a teacher at Hermiston High School.

title: Radiation Suit Touches Issue Of Job Danger
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14  Private industry is not the only sector of the nation confronted with the issue of exposure of workers to substances that can cause reproductive problems and birth defects.

title: Susan Feldman Becomes Bride
description: Susan Marian Feldman, daughter of Doris L. Feldman of New Haven and the late Julian M. Feldman, was married yesterday to Dr. Charles Richard Gordon, son of Mr. and Mrs. I. Lewis Gordon of New York. The ceremony was performed at the WaldorfAstoria by Rabbi Ascher M. Yager.

title: News Summary
description: MONDAY, JANUARY 15, 1979

title: A New York Pastry Chef Moves to the White House
description: Keeping the Presidential waistline as trim as necessary to maintain the currently acceptable public image may soon become one of the problems facing the Carter Administration, if not the entire Carter household.

title: Disney Studio to Release PG Film It Didn't Make
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 19  For the first time in 20 years, Walt Disney has picked up and will release a movie not made by the Disney organization. Last week, a deal was closed by Buena Vista, the Disney distribution arm, to release Take Down, a PGrated film about a highschool wrestling team.

title: The City
