description: Stanley Simon, the new Borough President of the Bronx, will appoint Carlos Cuevas, an administrator at Bronx Lebanon Hospital, as his first deputy, it was reported by Mr. Cuevas's predecessor in the post, Robert A. Esnard. Mr. Esnard said that Mr. Cuevas, who is 45 years old, is expected to take on the job as early as tomorrow.

title: Opera: Met Cast for TV Luisa
description: VERDI's Luisa Miller reentered the Metropolitan Opera's repertory Saturday night with a cast substantially different from the one that was heard earlier this season. It was. in fact, a very starry group of singers, a glamorous array seldom encountered these days except on opera recordings. No doubt the company had an eye on next Saturday night's live telecast of Luisa Miller! with the same singers.

title: AGENCY WILL STUDY U.S. WATER SUPPLY
description: The Office of Technology Assessment, a research body responsible for informing Congress about changing technologies, has given top priority to studying the impact of technology on the nation's water supply and the role of technology in insuring the world's future food supply.

title: Knicks Routed, 124104
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Jan. 14 (AP) Phil Ford scored 22 points, 7 during a key thirdquarter surge, to lead the Kansas City Kings to a 124104 National Basketball Association victory over the New York Knicks today.

title: Weekly Lotto Numbers Drawn
description: The numbers Inched Saturday night in New York State's weekly Lotto drawing were 4, 8, 35, 37, 32 and 14. The supplemental number was 20.

title: Congressman Seeking Post Gave Campaign Money to Panel Voters
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14  Representative Henry A. Waxman, a California Democrat who is waging a campaign to become chairman of the House subcommittee on Health and the Environment, contributed $24,000 last fall to the reelection campaigns of 10 of the 29 legislators who will decide the chairmanship contest later this month. He also gave $21,000 to 30 other members of the House and several senators.

title: Bell Issue to Test Market
description: This week, the corporate bond market will undergo its first significant test in a month as the Bell Telephone Company of Pennsylvania sells $150 million of loneterm debentures tomorrow.

title: College Fives All at Sixes
description: The basketball season, one of constant surprises, has left the nation's majorcollege ranks with only one undefeated team  Indiana State. In the last week Louisiana State, Temple, Arkansas and Illinois toppled from the list of unbeaten teams.

title: Sporting Gear
description: Nearly every sportsman who ventures onto or near the water now wears a safety vest. The knock on that item used to be that it was clumsy, ill fitting and funny looking. No more. Companies like Stearns have turned the utilitarian life vest into attractive apparel, with plaids, solid colors, outdoor scenery, camouflage and racing stripes. Today's vests come in belted or zippered styles, with snaps, buckles and Velcro, and they feature pockets, inner linings, cordandring adjustments and the latest in foam flotation material. SansSouci, Stearns' line, offers an assortment of adult vests priced from $30 each at Manhattan Marine, J.C. Penney and Times Square Stores. Stearns' address is Box 1498, St. Cloud, Minn. 56301. Telephone: (612) 2521642.

title: Doctors Set 25Hour Strike At Ten Municipal Hospitals
description: Interns and resident physicians yesterday named 10 municipal hospitals against which they plan a 25hour strike, starting at 7 A. M. Wednesday, to protest potential hospital closings and cutbacks. The New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation immediately disclosed that it had obtained a State Supreme Court temporary restraining order against the strike.

title: Japan and U.S. In Textile Pact
description: TOKYO, Jan. 19 (Reuters)  Japan and the United States reached a compromise agreement here today on strengthened United States import curbs on Japanese textiles for the next three years, foreign ministry sources said.

title: DEPARTURE OF SHAH WON'T BRING PEACE, OPPONENT PREDICTS
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 14  Thousands of demonstrators continued their protests against Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi in Teheran today, and the leader of the opposition National Front said he expected the violence to persist even after the Shah had left the country.

title: Long Road Ahead for Iran
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 14  Local newspapers and some opposition politicians are describing this as the week of decision in Iran's yearlong political crisis. But it appears likely to pass without any longterm resolution of the con- flict that has shattered the country's political structure and hobbled its economy.

title: Connecticut in a Battle on Air Pollution
description: HARTFORD, Jan. 13  At a series of public hearings last week on Connecticut's plan to meet Federal airquality standards, critics of the plan charged that it would mean economic disaster for the state, putting an end to new construction and resulting in a loss of jobs.

title: Shadowboxing With Inflation
description: When the Administration's top economists asked to participate in the final writing of stripmining rules the other day, it seemed at first as if they had found a new zeal for the fight against inflation. Surely such unusual interference in the regulation process, possibly subverting a law that the President himself once pronounced too weak, meant that from here on out, the White House would put inflation first.

title: Commodities
description: IF there is one group that should benefit from the national preoccupation with conserving natural resources and fighting inflation, it is the recyclers, known in less imageconscious times as junk dealers. Today the $18 billion scrap industry is also an increasingly important factor in industrial commodity markets.

title: Outdoors: Botany In the City Parks
description: BUDDING botanists need not wait for spring to begin their excursions afield, and those who live in or near New York City will have a splendid opportunity next month to receive expert guidance.

title: Washington Watch
description: WASHINGTON INCREASING signs of a budget deficit in 1981 appeared last week when budget officials reported that the nation's first attempt at multiyear budgeting had yielded estimates of a slight deficit 1981. A balanced budget in 1981 has been a long- standing promise from President Carter, but it is a promise on which he had begun to hedge even before the latest revelation.

title: The Molasses Disaster: 21 Died 60 Years Ago
description: BOSTON, Jan. 14 (AP)  Sixty years ago, workers and residents in Boston's North End heard several sharp explosions followed by a low rumble. They turned to see a 50foot brown wave bearing down on them from Boston Harbor.

title: Calls to 911 by Automatic Alarms To Be Given Lowest Police Priority
description: The New York City Police Department will downgrade the priority it gives to calls to the 911 emergency number system that are made by automatic alarms.

title: Dr. Lou Te Tchang, 77; U.N. Cartographic Chief
description: Dr. Lou Te Tchang, a former chief of cartographic services for the United Nations, died Saturday at his home at 60 Sedgwick Avenue in Yonkers, following a heart attack. He was 77 years old.

title: ASSEMBLY'S SPEAKER CALLS FOR INCREASE IN WELFARE GRANTS
description: Putting himself at odds with Governor Carey, the new Assembly Speaker, Stanley Fink, called yesterday for some additional help for those people who are properly on welfare. He said he would work to persuade the Democratic majority in the Assembly to back him and to get the Senate's Republican leaders, many of whom oppose an increase, to negotiate and compromise.

title: Giant Ad Insert Is Set for Time
description: The Feb. 5 issue of Time magazine worldwide will carry an advertising insert from Gulf and Western Industries that is probably the most expensive ad ever run by anyone at any time anywhere. At least, Time is making that assertion.

title: Checklist
description: Those about to engage in winter botany and foraging would do well to don suitable warm clothing and a good pair of hiking books, and to carry along a rucksack, a sturdy trowel or a small folding shovel, a pair of pruning shears, a pocketknife and a hand magnifier. A few small plastic bags to hold one's harvesting would also be helpful.

title: Data on Terrorism Is New Venture's Product
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14  Another company has joined the evergrowing list of those out to prove that terrorists are not the only ones who can make money from kidnapping  or the fear of kidnapping.

title: Kennedy Calls Inflation Key
description: BOSTON, Jan. 14 (AP)  The future of President Carter and the Democratic Party is pegged to inflation and economic stability, Senator Edward M. Kennedy said here today.

title: Turkish Defense Minister Quits Over Reported Rift With Premier
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 14 (Reuters) Defense Minister Hasan Esat Isik of Turkey resigned today, and political sources said his action was a result of disagreements with Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit.

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: A short while ago, while on vacation in the Caribbean, I overheard a lady describing a method of cooking chicken that her hairdresser had offered her. As I reconstructed the evening the morning after, the recipe went something like this:

title: Ansonia, Conn., in Surprise Vote, Spurns Proposed Greyhound Track
description: ANSONIA, Conn., Jan. 14  The dozen or so people in the basement of the First Methodist Church here sat unusually quiet last night as Kenneth Hawley at the blackboard and the Rev. Richard L. Schuster with his pocket calculator raced each other to add up the voting results.

title: A Keeper for the Brother
description: The President has done his best to alert the nation that he is not his brother's keeper. But Billy Carter's behavior suggests that he could use one. He has been playing jovial host to a group of Libyan officials and businessmen promoting the image of Colonel Qaddafi's regime and he has sought to demonstrate his influence and hospitality with conduct and comments that can only be described as obscene. Among other things, he attributed Libya's poor standing in the United States not to its opposition to American peace efforts in the Middle East or its support of likeminded terrorists but rather to the fiction that the Jewish media tears up the Arab countries full time.

title: ABROAD AT HOME
description: It is 1980 and Prof. James David Tonsor of Earl University plans to study the Presidential campaign. He has a foundation grant to travel around the primaries, watch the politicians and interview political reporters.

title: 76ers Top Blazers
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 14 (AP) Julius Erving and Doug Collins scored 62 points between them and Darryl Dawkins contributed three vital finalperiod field goals today as the Philadelphia 76ers beat the Portland Trail Blazers. 112106.

title: 2 Million Jobs Threatened by British Truck Strike
description: LONDON, Jan. 14 (Reuters)  About two million British workers are expected to be laid off this week as the effects of a strike by more than 100,000 truck drivers Spread through the nation's industry.

title: Spinks Next Knoetze Foe?
description: MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 19  The next time American television viewers see Kahle Knoetze of South Africa in action. it could be against Leon Spinks.

title: Miami Set for Super Gold Week
description: MIAMI, Jan. 14  While major hotels, restaurants and other touristoriented businesses prepare for the parties, hoopla and big spending of Super Bowl week, local police are busy investigating reports that counterfeit tickets are being sold to unsuspecting fans, and that $30 tickets for the game are being scalped for as much as $200 each.

title: A Plan to Slow Traffic Puts Dummy in Auto
description: BOISE, Idaho, Jan. 14 (UPI)  In a manpowersaving move, the Idaho State Police force is staffing a roadside radar post with a mannequin.

title: Skiing: Buergler Tops the Elite
description: CRANSMONTANA, Switzerland. Jan. 14 (UPI)  Toni Buergler spearheaded a stunning performance by Switzerland's ski racers today by winning a World Cup downhill event.

title: P.L.O.'s Talks With Jordan Provoke Hot Debate Among Guerrillas
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Jan. 14  Eight years after King Hussein expelled Palestinian guerrillas from his country in bitter fighting, Jordan and the Palestine Liberation Organization have embarked upon a cautious yet controversial reconciliation.

title: Job Threats to Workers Fertility Emerging as Civil Liberties Issue
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14  When Christine Schwalm became pregnant several weeks ago, she and her doctor decided that exposure to industrial chemicals on the job might be dangerous to her unborn baby.

title: Carole Joyce Resnick Is Bride Of Richard Crystal of Macy's
description: Carole Joyce Resnick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Israel Resnick of Bellerose, Queens, and Richard Paul Crystal, son of Mrs. Charles Crystal of Sunrise, Fla., and the late Mr. Crystal, were married yesterday at the Carlyle by Rabbi Harvey Tattelbaum of Temple Shaarav Tefila.

title: Books of The Times
description: A POSSIBLE scandal at West Point. Cadet Rysam Parker Slaight 3d learns that on May 25, 1968, while walking punishment tours on Central Area the naked body of a Plebe named David Hand has been found that morning floating in Lake Pooolopen. Maj. Gen. Axel W.

title: TV: Charleston Recalls Era Gone With the Wind
description: RESENTING obvious epigones of Scarlett, Melanie and Rhett, as is done in Charleston, is as suicidal if not so courageous an undertaking as Pickett's charge. This madefortelevision film, which is also the pilot for a proposed series, will be presented from toll o'clock tonight by NBC.

title: McEnroe Tops Ashe, 67, 63, 75
description: Arthur Ashe had the tactics and 2 match points, but John McEnroe took the Grand Prix Masters tennis title and the $100,000 top prize with a 67, 63, 75 victory yesterday.

title: 100 Peasants Stage Peking Protest, Are Barred From Hua's Residence
description: PEKING, Jan. 14 (Agence FrancePresse)  A hundred angry Chinese peasants shouting, We're tired of being 1 hungry! and Down with oppression! tried today to enter the compound that includes the residence of Hua Kuofeng, the Communist Party Chairman, to present their grievances to him.

title: Sara Herzog, President Of Israeli Women's Unit
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 14  Sara Herzog, thefounder and president of the National Religious Women's Organization, died in Jerusalem last night. She was 82 years old.

title: On Sons Becoming Racists
description: RICHMOND, Va.  All my life I've heard it said that the difference between us whites, South and North, is that the Southerner loved blacks as individuals, and hated them as a race, while Northerners loved them as a race, and hated them as individuals. Now I see this pattern emerging in my own family.

title: Lobbyists Worked Offstage to Shape Sugar Laws
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14  When Presidentelect Carter marched down Pennsylvania Avenue in his inaugural parade, a political and economic problem for his new Administration was already building up. It was the sugar problem.

title: Little, But Made Mighty
description: PRINCETON  The idea of the New Influentials has been used by Administration foreignpolicymakers to describethird world countries whose wealth, size, military and strategic importance give them a prominent role in regional politics and in international forums.

title: Obituary 1 -- No Title
description: Child, 2, Scalded to Death

title: West Bank Figure's Fate Typifies Israeli Difficulty
description: HEBRON, IsraeliOccupied West Bank  On the highest hill overlooking this ancient biblical city, .above the tomb of Abraham and the vineyards whose grapes were reputedly the sweetest in Palestine, Sheik Mohammed Ali Jaabari built his mansion four decades ago.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: For a while late last week, people involved in the credit markets began to think seriously that interest rates might have peaked. The feeling passed quickly, however, and rates were heading upward again Friday afternoon.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: FAR FROM HOME Eranga and Prianga, the musical couple making their New York cabaret debut tonight, have been hailed in Europe as ambassadors from the Tea Island, having gained acclaim in performances ranging from Honolulu to Istanbul. Clad in the exotic garb of their native Sri Lanka, with Prianga as guitarist for their singing, the two artists render pop songs in 15 languages, among them English, German, Hebrew, Greek, Spanish, Hawaiian and their own tongue.

title: Vietnamese Drive Appears to Slow Near the CambodianThai Border
description: ARANYAPRATHET, Thailand, Jan. 14  The fighting in Cambodia closed in on the Thai border here today, but Vietnamese forces appeared to be pausing as Cambodian troops sought to evacuate hundreds of wounded soldiers into Thailand with the cooperation of the International Red Cross.

title: $30,000 in Earrings Recovered at Kennedy
description: The Port Authority police yesterday found $30,000 worth of gold earrings that had been reported missing earlier this month from an Iberia Airlines flight. They had been hidden aboard the aircraft, authorities said.

title: Flyers Achieve Deadlock
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 14  Yes, the 11 score between the New York Islanders and the Flyers tonight did indicate the closeness of the game. The capacity crowd of 17,077 witnessed an intense, cleanly played contest that built in tension as Phe teams zipped up and down the ice.

title: Sara Mayfield, Wrote Biography of Mencken
description: Sara Mayfield, writer and biographer of H.L. Mencken, died Wednesday at Druid City Hospital in Tuscaloosa, Ala. She was 73 years old and lived in Tuscaloosa.

title: Dr. Phyllis Lefton Has Nuptials
description: Dr. Phyllis Lefton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Lefton of Asbury Park, N.J., and Frederic Steven Goldstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gabriel F. Goldstein of New York, were married yesterday at the West Side Institutional Synagogue. Rabbi O. Asher Reichel, the bridegroom's uncle; Rabbi Sidney Goldstein, and Cantor Sherwood Goffin officiated.

title: China Acts To improve Railroads
description: China, with technical help from Japan, has begun work aimed at rapid transformation of three rail lines into highspeed corridors, according to knowledgeable business sources here.

title: TV Producers Say Ratings War Has Hurt Quality of Programs
description: The escalation of the networks' audienceratings wars during the last two years has hurt television programs, causing them to be produced in greater haste and in a deeper atmosphere of cynicism than ever before, according to several of the leading television producers in Hollywood.

title: Emerson, Skil Near Merger
description: The merger of the Skil Corporation into the Emerson Electric Company moved closer to realization yesterday as the two companies announced that Skil agreed to sell its chain saw business to the National Union Electric Corporation. Emerson, which also makes chain saws, had made the sale a condition of the previously announced merger plan.

title: Swann: Little Acrobat In the Thick of Things
description: WIDE receivers are a lonely race. We have this image of little guys hanging out there on the end, says Lynn Swann, the allpro wide receiver of the Pittsburgh Steelers. When the running back is seen doing his job you see the line opening a hole for him, the quarterback handing off to him  the team working together. But when we're seen we appear to be detached. It's the receiver alone with the other team and the ball.

title: Sandra K. Baker, Artist, Wed to Jack Bronston, Lawyer
description: The marriage of Sandra K. Baker, an artist, to Jack Edward Bronston, New York lawyer, took place yesterday at Temple EmanuEl. Rabbi David M. Posner performed the ceremony.

title: Pennsylvania Criticizes Poe House Restoration
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 14 (AP)  Edgar Allan Poe's mythical raven is not available for comment, but Pennsylvania officials have taken up the cry of Nevermore.

title: Deaths
description: ACKERMAN  Arthur S. On January 6. Beloved husband of Zelda. Devoted father of Evelyn and Diana. Dear brother of Rose. Dedicated teacher. Graveside services were held January 7.

title: A.D.A. Attacks Gov. Brown's Call for Spending Curbs
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 14  A Democrat cannot be elected President if liberals actively oppose him, the head of Americans for Democratic Action warned yesterday after his organization sharply criticized Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California.

title: China Leads In Steel Buying
description: TOKYO, Jan. 14 (AP)  China was the top buyer of Japanese steel products in November, an industry group has reported.

title: TV: Conway In Special
description: TELEVISION has a nasty habit of devouring comedians whole. The latest distressing example of proven talent being reduced to puzzling fodder can be found on tonight's The Tim Conway Show on CBS at 8 o'clock.

title: Advertising
description: COMPTON Advertising, the 14thlargest American agency worldwide, has added an ethical pharmaceutical capability, Klemtner Advertising, a 35yearold specialty shop with about $21 million in billings.

title: Stage: The Elephant Man
description: USING a real incident as his subject. Bernard Pomerance has written a play about a monstrously deformed man who is rescued from the streets, taken into the London Hospital in Whitechapel, and becomes a celebrated curiosity for British society of the 1880's.

title: More Testing in the Schools
description: The issue of testing, which can always be counted on to provoke controversy, flared up again last week on two fronts in New York City public schools and once again raised some complex questions about both the quantity and quality of the

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Bank of Tokyo Trust Company, an affiliate of the Bank of Tokyo Ltd., has appointed Frederick C. Hertel executive vice president.

title: Murdoch Scores 3 Goals
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 11  Don Murdoch, making only his second appearance after sitting out a 40game suspension during the first half of the National Hockey League season, bombed his way back into focus tonight. The 22yearold wing exploded for three thirdperiod goals, including the decisive tally, in leading the Rangers to a 64 victory over Atlanta.

title: Russians Keep a Tradition Alive In Celebration of Old New Year
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 14  At the stroke of midnight last night, the Russian hostess bid her guests raise their glasses of cognac to the New Year  the old New Year, which many Russians still celebrate on the night of Jan. 13.

title: Game Snowed Out
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 19 (AP)  The N.H.L. game scheduled for tonight between the Toronto Maple Leafs and the Chicago Black Hawks was postponed earlier today because of a blizzard. The Black Hawks, who played last night in Minnesota, were unable to fly into Chicago because the blizzard, which dumped 20.5 inches of snow on the city in a 24hour period, forced the closing of O'Hare International Airport. The Black Hawks announced that the game has been rescheduled for Feb. 12.

title: World News Briefs
description: MADRID, Jan. 14 (Reuters)  Spanish police and demonstrators fought for more than an hour in the northern Basque city of San Sebastian today as hundreds of police reinforcements moved into the region following guerrilla attacks.

title: Alberta's Enviable Oil Nest Egg
description: EDMONTON, Alberta  The rainbow ends here. And the pot of gold is the Alberta Heritage Savings Trust Fund.

title: The Region
description: NEWARK (AP)  Residents of NeW Jersey's largest city face a 6.7 percent increase in property taxes if Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson's 1979 budget is adopted in its current form. The budget is to be presented to the City Council tomorrow.

title: THREE MORE RESIGN FROM WOMEN'S UNIT
description: Three more members of the National Advisory Committee for Women have resigned to protest President Carter's dismissal of the panel's cochairman, Bella S. Abzug, the former Representative from Manhattan announced yesterday.

title: Deaths
description: HERZOGSarah. Beloved Rabbanit. World President of EmunahWorld Religious Zionist Women's Organization. National Religious Women's Organization of Israel, and distinguished wife of the late Chief Rabbi of the State of Israel. Emunah Women of America mourns the untimely loss of our dear Rabbanit and Leader, a revered friend to allot us, a woman of noble character and unusual ability to bring into harmony all activities relating to Religious Zionism and the State of Israel. She had the unique characteristics of being able to inspire others to unwavering devotion to Bretz Yisrael, and the special ability to recall Israel's history with infinite faith in the Almighty. She was able to enrich everyone's life with her capacity for friendship and to inspire everyone with deep commitment to our movement. We will miss her leadership and inspiration. We are deeply shocked and our hearts are filled with sadness but her memory will always be with us as we continue to perpetuate her dreams and to fulfill her aspirations for Israel's children and for Emunah all over

title: Neale Sweet Weds Elizabeth G. Perry
description: Elizabeth Gray Perry, daughter of Dr. Marvin Banks Perry Jr., president of Agnes Scott College, and Mrs. Perry, was married yesterday morning to Neale Edward Sweet, son of Mrs. John Allen Sweet 3d of Farmington, Me., and the late Mr. Sweet. The Rev. George Telford, director of corporate and social mission for the General Assembly Mission Board of the Presbyterian Church of the United States, performed the ceremony at the Perry home on the campus of the college in Decatur, Ga.

title: Heritage Raises Dividend
description: CHERRY HILL, N.J. (AP)  The Heritage Bancorporation has increased its quarterly cash dividend to 30 cents a share, the company announced.

title: Storm Mires the Chicago Area in 20 Inches of Snow
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 19  At least 20 inches of snow swirled to the ground yesterday and early this morning in winds of 30 to 90 miles an hour. Today, residents of the Chicago area were digging out from what is being called the worst blizzard in more than 10 years.

title: Golf: Mahaffey Edges Trevino by a Shot
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Jan. 19 (AP)  John Mahaffey rolled in the uphill, 15foot birdie putt he needed on the 90th hole today and edged Lee Trevino by a stroke in the Desert Classic  the kickoff event for the 10month, $13 million Professional Golfers' Association Tour.

title: China Is Codifying Legal System And Plans to Insure Open Trials
description: PEKING, Jan. 11  In a significant break with the often arbitrary legal practices of the last two decades, China is attempting to set up a new legal system with regular civil, criminal and commercial codes and guarantees of public trials for defendants.

title: Egypt Stresses Palestinian Issue
description: CAIRO, Jan. 14  With Mr. Atherton due back in the Middle East this week in an effort to get the EgyptianIsraeli negotiations restarted, Egypt has again declared its willingness to resume the talks while repeating its demands for Palestinian autonomy.

title: Israel Welcomes U.S. Effort To Revive Talk With Egypt
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 19  The Israeli Government today welcomed the United States effort to revive the stalled peace talks between Israel and Egypt, but indicated it did not expect an early breakthrough in the negotiations.

title: Donny Hathaway, 33, Pop and Blues Singer, Dead in Hotel Plunge
description: Donny Hathaway, a 33-year-old Grammyaward winning singer and composer of pop tunes with blues and gospel undertones, died Saturday after he plunged from the 15th floor of his Essex House room at 160 Central Park South, the police said.

title: Sihanouk Is Admitted To East Side Hospital For Testing and a Rest
description: Prince Norodom Sihanouk of Cambodia, suffering from exhaustion, was admitted to Lenox Hill Hospital yesterday after a night of what State Department officials described as disjointed conversation with Andrew Young, the United States representative at the United Nations, about the Prince's future.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Radiator Steam Kills 3 Children Locked in a Bedroom
description: Three young children died Saturday night when a radiator broke, pouring steam into a bedroom. The police said they had been locked in by their parents, who had gone to a party.

title: Hanoi Says Peking Stirs Clashes
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 14 (Reuters) Vietnam has accused China of sending two warships into Vietnamese waters and provoking almost daily border clashes since the capture of the Cambodian capital of Phnom Penh last Sunday, the Vietnam News Agency reported today. The agency said the Vietnamese Foreign Ministry warned the Chinese Embassy in Hanoi in a note yesterday that China must bear full responsibility for the consequences.

title: Helen L. Weiner Married to Bradley Nitkin
description: Helen L. Weiner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Weiner of South Orange, NI., was married yesterday to Bradley Nitkin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander H. Nitkin of Purchase, N.Y. The ceremony was performed at the Harmonie Club in New York by Rabbi Frederick Margulies.

title: Cowboys
description: THE Dallas Cowboys are an excellent football team but in no way invincible. The intimidating style of the Pittsburgh Steelers, especially on defense, will bother the Cowboys, and this characteristic should be encouraged.

title: Pop: Richard Lloyd's Quartet
description: TELEVISION, one of the first and best of the New York newwave rock bands, broke up last year. The band's leader, Tom Verlaine, still hasn't resurfaced. But now half of the original quartet is active again as part of Richard Lloyd's new quartet, which appeared at Max's Kansas City on Friday and Saturday nights.

title: Bridge:
description: For the first time within memory, a major regional title in the metropolitan New York area was captured by a mother-and-son combination. The vic- tors, in the mixed pairs at the Tristate Regionals in Port Chester, N.Y., last Friday, were Marion and Michael Rosma rin.

title: U.S. Health Officials Warn Elderly About Problems With Medicines
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (UPI) Federal health officials say the elderly have a drug problem, too, and it is one that the officials are beginning to give some attention.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Sharif Khan, one of the world's best squash racquets players, captured his 10th North American open tournament in 11 years by defeating Gordon Anderson of Toronto, 157, 1510, 155, yesterday at the Manhattan Squash Club.

title: Stage: Ijimere's Plays From Africa at Negro Ensemble Company
description: OBOTUNDE IJIMERE's Plays From Africa, which opened last night at the Negro Ensemble Company, are two oneact Nigerian folk tales about heaven and earth, good and evil, love and hate. The simplicity of the senti- ments is matched by tne complexity of the plots. It is difficult to tell one symbolic figure from the other, to differentiate, for example, between the father of the secrets and the father of laughter, neither of which is very amusing.

title: Song: A Satirical Threesome
description: IT must be said for Bill Weeden and Dave Finkle that they are persistent. They began writing satirical songs together 20 years ago when they were at Phillips Andover Academy. In the 60's, they were contributors to Julius Monk's celebrated satirical revues. Seven years ago, they made their debuts as performers singing their own satirical songs at the Duplex, at 55 Grove Street. After a lapse of several years in their performing careers, they are now back at the Duplex from Thursday to Saturday, no longer as Weeden and Finkle, but now as Weeden, Finkle and Fay, the most liltingly named team since Wynken, Blynken and Nod.

title: Sports Today
description: HARNESS RACING

title: ESSAY
description: WASHINGTON  One week ago in this space, the President's business partner and brother was identified as the greatest source of White House worry in the Lance investigation. Although he had claimed a Fifth Amendment privilege in refusing to testify to the grand jury, it was feared that Billy Carter might one day provide some information damaging to all Carters if the Justice Department should follow the tangent into some curious Carter borrowings from Mr. Lance's bank.

title: CARTER WILL SUBMIT TREATY ON MISSILES
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14  President Carter announced today that he would submit a new SovietAmerican agreement on strategic arms to the Senate as a treaty rather than as an executive agreement.

title: Public Employees Seek a Better Image
description: Concerned with their public image, two publicemployee unions are beginning newspaper, radio and television advertising campaigns to persuade the public that civil servants are not, as one union official put it, overpaid bureaucrats who shuffle papers throughout their careers, then retire on inflated pensions.

title: Chicago, Paralyzed in SubZero Temperatures, Begins to Dig Out as Snow Continues
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 15  City workers continued to dig out today from a weekend blizzard here that left more than 20 inches of fresh snow, brought ground transportation on many streets to a standstill and forced O'Hare International Airport to close.

title: Columbia Alters Names Of PulitzerPrize Panels
description: Columbia University, which awards the annual Pulitzer Prizes, announced yesterday that the panel choosing the winners would now be known as the Pulitzer Prize Board and that the persons screening entries for the board's consideration will be called nominating jurors.

title: Imogene Coca's Golden Jubilee
description: I MoGENE COCA'S 50th anniversary in show business was the pretext for a celebration last night that launched the second year of New York State's I Love New York theater promotion at Regine's, twin events simultaneously cheered by many of New York Citys literati and gift terati, almost a minority in a sea of media folk that brought the audience to about 300.

title: Assembly Vote on Death Penalty
description: ALBANY, Jan. 15  The following is the rollcall vote by which the State Assembly passed tonight a bill to restore the death penalty in certain cases of murder:

title: City's Theater License Law Is Ruled Unconstitutional
description: A law controlling licenses for movie theaters in New York City was declared unconstitutional yesterday by a Federal judge who said the city must find a better way to deal with pornography problems that had made Times Square an ugly wormhole in the Big Apple.

title: About New York; Beating the Parking Regulations
description: Every morning people have no choice but to arise and emerge from the apartment buildings of the Upper West Side and face the sunred trauma of new day. The lucky onestear the word of Jacob, who is running around in knickers and long striped socks, splashing and gunning automobiles to life as if they were people. Everythin's gonna be ohall right,  he insists in the cold streets, again and again.

title: Letters: On Social Security
description: Flawed Prescriptions for Curing the System

title: Genealogist Studies The Jewish Heritage Of Some Christians
description: Hundreds of Americans  including some who believed they had only Protestant or Roman Catholic ancestors  are discovering more about their Jewish heritage through the work of Malcolm Stern, a genealogist in New York City.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: HANDS ACROSS THE SEA In A special fundraising event tonight at 8 sponsored by four local Episcopal churches, J. Carter Brown, director of the National Gallery of Art in Washington, will discuss the museum's new East Building, which opened a year ago. The program takes place at All Saints Episcopal Church, 230 East 60th Street, midblock between Second and Third Avenues. Proceeds will benefit the Priory Church of St.Bartholomew the Great in London, built in 1123 and the oldest parish church in that city. The historic structure was also the scene of Mr. Brown's marriage.

title: Deaths
description: SCHACTERDavid. Beloved husband of Julie, devoted father of Helaine Hairnes,loving grandfather of Ronnie Urbach & Todd Haimes, adored great grandfather of Julian Urbach. Interment private. In lieu of flowers contributions to Cancer Care, 1 Park Ave., NYC would be appreciated.

title: St John's Women Defeat Mercy College Five, 7956
description: LingLing Hou tied her career high by pumping in 31 points last night to lead St. John's to a 7956 triumph over Mercy College in a women's basketball game at the winner's gym.

title: Southern Utility Outlay Set
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 15 (UPI)  Directors of the Southern Company approved today the spending of up to $1.5 billion this year on power generating facilities and reviewed programs to spend more than three times that much in the next three years. Directors of the electric utility holding company also voted a regular quarterly dividend of 38 cents a share on Southem's common stock.

title: Market Place
description: Keefe in Shift On Bank Stock

title: Westinghouse Aids Alcoholics
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 15  The Westinghouse Electric Corporation believes that 7,000 of its 120,000 employees may be alcoholics and will begin a companywide program today to do something about the problem.

title: Companies Report Earnings
description: For ,Perkds as shown. (N) cafes stock Is listed on tge New Yoh Stock E xchan0e,( A ) the American Stock Exchange and (0) over-the counter.

title: Drugs Given in Childbirth Imperil Babies, Study Charges
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -Babies born to mothers who were given anesthetics during delivery are much more apt to suffer physical and mental impairment than had been be lieved, according to a new Federal study of obstetric medication. The study was made public today.

title: Aftershock Felt in Malibu
description: MALIBU, Calif., Jan. 15 (AP)  A mild offshore aftershock from a New Year's Day earthquake brought some predawn calls to a sheriff's station and a few radio stations, the authorities said. No damage was reported.

title: Deaths
description: DORFMANMeyer. The Brooklyn Division of the United Jewish APpealFederation of Jewish Philanthropies Joint Campaign notes with deep sorrow the passing of a long time member of the East Midwood Jewish Center campaign committee, who labored devotedly In our community and the corset and brassiere industry In behalf of the endangered and needy In Israel, around the world and here at home. We offer heartfelt condolences to his daughters. Mrs. Ruth Karlitz and Mrs. Florence Kurtis, and the other members of the bereaved family.

title: Powerful Rivals Clash Over Sugar Price Supports
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15  When Rowland Cannon, the president of a large sugar beet processing company, appeared before the Senate Finance Committee last May to urge higher support prices for sugar crops, he said that the issue was something more than whether the growers would receive more money. It was whether the industry would survive.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: International

title: Aide Acquitted By State Justice Of BribeTaking; No Corrupt Intent Found in Taking Las Vegas Trip
description: Lee Miller, a former executive assistant to the New York State Attorney General, was acquitted by Justice Peter J. McQuillan in State Supreme Court yesterday of a charge of receiving a bribe.

title: Asarco Raises Copper Prices
description: Asarco Inc. announced yesterday that it was increasing the price of electrolytic copper by a half a cent to 75.5 cents a pound.

title: U.S.Canadian Textile Accord
description: Washington, Jan. 15 (UPI)Canada and the United States have reached agreement on trade negotiations involving various ? products, the White House trade nego tiator announced today.

title: (Much Ado About) Nothing (in Particular)
description: There is much ado about National Nothing Day, which is today, and it arises from the very idea of setting aside one day on which nothing will be celebrated, observed or honored  24 hours without feast or fanfare, hype or hoopla.

title: Local Officials to Aid in Census
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (UPI)  The Census Bureau will ask local officials in 39,000 communities to help guard against error in its 1980 accounting. Manuel Plotkin, the census director, said the officials would be asked to review local household address counts before the census workers take new counts. The officials will review the preliminary totals and if they believe the count is too high or low, the Census Bureau will recheck.

title: Hurdles Records Seem Limitless to Nehemiah
description: Renaldo (Streets) Nehemiah has these imaginary games. During practice, the urge will suddenly strike him to run over a high hurdle as fast as he can, as if the hurdle is not there, as if he is running in air.

title: November Inventories Up by 1.1%
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP)  Inventories rose at a rapid rate in November, indicating that businesses are stocking goods at a faster rate than consumers are buying them, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: An Illusion of Education Reform
description: In what seemed like a wellplanned omission, Congress concluded its last session without acting on the proposal to create a separate Department of Education. The measure had been overwhelmingly approved by the Senate, but it died quickly when the House leadership failed to bring it to the floor. Now there is a new Congress and, unfortunately, President Carter says that he'll try again.

title: Deaths
description: CURRYMarie Belknap. On January 11, 1979. Wife of the late Charles A. Voss and Archibald Curry. Mother of Mrs Frank Howard and Or. George A. Voss. Sister of Mrs. Frank Evans. Memorial service at BallardDurand Funeral Home, Inc, 2 Maple Avenue, White Plains, N.Y. Thursday. 1PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: Vataha Racquetball Victor
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Jan. 15 (UPI) Randy Vataha, former wide receiver for the New England Patriots, defeated Al Ferrari, a former pro basketball player with the St. Louis Hawks, 218, 2115, yesterday to win a celebrity racquetball tournament and earn $58,000.

title: Hoag Wins Biathlon Race
description: UNDERHILL, Vt., Jan. 15 (UPI) Peter Hoag of Minneapolis won the national biathlon 20kilometer cross-country skiing and shooting race yesterday.

title: Northeast Corridor Railway Project Will Take Longer and Cost More
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15  Transportation Secretary Brock Adams said today that the Government erred two years ago in its projections about rail improvements along the Northeast Corridor and that the project would take two years longer and cost $750 million more than planned.

title: E.P.A. Halts Chemicals Cleanup
description: WEST POINT, Ky., Jan. 15  The Environmental Protection Agency today ended its efforts to remove hundreds of barrels of chemical wastes from a field near Louisville after running out of cleanup funds allocated for the project.

title: Excerpts From Mayor Koch's Level I Proposals to Close the City's Budget Gap
description: Following are excerpts from Mayor Koch's financial plan dealing with personnel reductions and projected savings in city funds in Level I to balance the budget for fiscal 1930:

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Monday, Jan. 15.1979

title: Israel's 78 Inflation Rate At 50%, Highest Since 74
description: TEL AVIV, Jan 15  Israel's Inflation rate approached 50 percent last year, according to official data released today in Jerusalem.

title: Bendix Net Up 32% in Quarter
description: Profits of the Bendix Corporation rose 32 percent in its first fiscal quarter ended Dec.31, William M. Agee, chairman and president, reported yesterday from the company's Southfield, Mich., headquarters. He attributed the record performance primarily to excellent results turned in by our automotive, aerospaceelectronics and forest products business segments.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Only a line or two in the papers the other day noted that Anthony T. Rossi was resigning as chairman and chief executive officer of Tropicana Products, They said nothing about one of the pioneers of the frozen orange juice business; they conveyed nothing of the classic rags-to-riches story of the Sicilian immigrant who came to the United States more than half a century ago to make enough money to produce movie in Africa.

title: Carter Defends Budget as Sound And Sees Increase in Aid to Poor
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP)  President Carter said tonight that his 1980 budget would contain an increase in spending for poor people and that it would allay the fears of the nation's mayors.

title: Beame Asserts Koch Wrongly Takes Credit For Starts in Housing
description: Angered by Mayor Koch's weekend criticism of his record on housing, former Mayor Abraham D. Beame charged yesterday that Mr. Koch was claiming credit for work begun during the Beame administration that resulted in an unusually high number of Governmentassisted housing starts last year.

title: The New Governor of Alabama
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Jan. 15  If George C. Wallace happened to glance across the street from the Alabama Governor's mansion one day about a year ago, he might have been perplexed to see that a neighbor had put up

title: Big Three 10Day Car Sales Up 7%
description: DETROIT, Jan. 15 (AP)  The Big Three United States auto makers started the new year by posting a 7 percent rise in domestic car sales from the total for the corresponding period a year ago, the companies reported today.

title: SAUL RICHMAN, 62, STAGE PRESS AGENT; Known for Ingenious Improvising and Energetic Humor
description: Saul Richman, a theater press agent known for his energetic wit and improvisational ingenuity in promoting his clients, died Sunday of cancer in San Diego. He was 62 years old.

title: American Express Bid Spurned
description: Illegal, Says McGraw; Move To Be Pushed

title: John (Johnny Dio) Dioguardi, 64, A Leader in Organized Crime, Dies
description: John Dioguardi, long described as an organizedcrime leader who specialized in labor racketeering and later in stock fraud, died last Friday in a Pennsylvania hospital while serving his latest Federal prison sentence. Mr. Dioguardi, who was better known as Johnny Dio, was 64 years old.

title: Music Tied to Candle's Flicker
description: A RESEARCH physicist says he has uncovered a subtle relationship between mathematics and music that can help computers compose pleasing music automatically.

title: An Ombudsman Office Is Established by Carey
description: ALBANY, Jan. 15  Governor Carey today signed an executive order creating a state ombudsman office to help people with a governmental problem, personal problem, agency problem find a solution, and to serve as a clearinghouse for information on government programs.

title: Heart is Transplanted in London
description: LONDON, Jan. 15 (Reuters)  Surgeons have performed the first heart transplant to takc place in Britain in five years, health officials said today. Dr. Terence English operated yesterday at Papworth Hospital in Cambridge on Charles McHugh, a 44-year-old plumber.

title: Advertising
description: Catering To Smaller Accounts

title: Interferon Curbs Cancer in 3 Cases
description: INTERFERON, the virusfighting substance, is showing some promise in fighting cancer, according to Dr. Thomas C. Merigan of Stan. ford University, a pioneer in its use.

title: Federal Panel's Staff Urges Safety Devices For Powered Mowers
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (UPI)  The staff of the Consumer Product Safety Commission recommended today that power lawn mowers be equipped with devices that either disengage the blade or shut the motor off when the user lets go of the handle.

title: Bank of New York Profit Up for Quarter and Year
description: The Bank of New York Company announced yesterday that its earnings had increased sharply in the final quarter of 1978 and in the entire year, consistent with a pattern of substantial gains in profits being reported by major banks.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: 1 I I II. In By Vincent ,thk 271 pages. Alfred A. Knorl

title: Article 2 -- No Title
description: TOO LATE FOR THE REBOUND: Andre Griffin of the University of Washington trying to block the basketball after missing a rebound during the game last night at Berkeley against the University of California.

title: Canadians Equity Goal A Failure?
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 15  An attempt to assure Canadian control over new ventures involving natural resources has not been successful in most cases, according to a Government document released today by an opposition leader.

title: Congress, After Choosing Leaders, Scores Inflation and Budget Deficit
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15  The 96th Congress convened today, picking leaders and debating rules, issuing press releases and holding parties, and, when it focused on national problems, deploring inflation and the Federal budget deficit.

title: Forrest James Is Sworn In As Successor to Wallace
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Jan 15 George C. Wallace, who rose to political prominence as a foe of school desegregation, was bused across town today to hear his successor as Governor, Forrest H. James Jr:, take the oath of office with a pledge to give all Alabamians a new beginning free from racism and discrimination.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Yesterday's cold front is apparent as a broad band of clouds now well over the Atlantic Ocean. Considerable moisture is moving by advectioning northeastward from lower California to the Middle West High thin clouds are also spreading eastward across the Ohio Valley. Skies are generally clear over the Southeast.

title: CREDIT MARKETS ShortTerm Rates Continue Up
description: Shortterm interest rates climbed yesterday as more and more fixed-income traders and investor; suspected that the Federal Reserve had decided to make monetary policy slightly more restrictive.

title: A New Editor for Trenton Times
description: TRENTON, Jan. 15 (UPI)  Robert Bentley, editor of The El Paso Times, has been named editor of The Trenton Times, a newspaper owned by The Washington Post, effective early next month. Mr. Bentley, who succeeds Herb Wolfe, is former reporter for The Miami Herald and has been editor of The El Paso Times, a Gannett paper, since 1975.

title: The Region; Jury Still Assessing Theater Fraud Case
description: Jury deliberations will continue today in the trial of seven mut) on fraud charges involving the Westchester Premier Theater.

title: Cubans in Letelier Case Linked to a 2d Murder Plot
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12  The trial of three Cuban exiles charged in the murder of Orlando Letelier, the former Chilean diplomat, got under way today with Federal prosecutor saying he would show that some of the accused had previously cooperated in an unsuccessful attempt to assassinate another Chilean official in Mexico.

title: Drill Sergeant Is Cleared
description: FORT JACKSON, S.C., Jan. 15 (AP) Charges against a drill sergeant for al. legedly maltreating and assaulting three recruits in the First Basic Training Brigade here have been dropped, the Army said today.

title: Residents of Audubon Terrace Area, a Unique Entity, Accept Landmark Designation as Block's Due
description: There are some in the neighborhood who would argue that Louis Wolpin's Imperial Delicatessen nearby on Broadway has as much claim to landmark status as Audubon Terrace. To be sure, the terrace has its sweeping center courtyard. surrounded by the Museum of the American Indian, the Hispanic Society of America and three other cultural in- stitutions, all built in the early 1900's. But Mr. Wolpin has been on the same block for almost 90 years, and when someone orders a turkey sandwich in his delicatessen, he gets turkey off a turkey carcass, not the pressed meat found in other places.

title: Bank Earnings Results Listed
description: For periods as shown. (N) Indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Exchange and (O) over-the-counter.

title: Money
description: MONDAY, JAN. 15, 1979

title: Ebla Ruins Shed Light on Early Urban Man
description: FROM the remains in Syria of the 4,500yearold lost Kingdom of Ebla, scholars are reconstructing scenes from the early stages of civilization suggesting that mankind's first cities may have been far more like those of today than most people imagine.

title: Giants Retract Offer to Carew
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 15 (AP)  The San Francisco Giants today withdrew their offer to the Minnesota Twins for Rod Carew after the Twins and Carew's agent reported that the star wanted to continue to play in the American League.

title: Reagan Urges an Alliance to Defy Big Government
description: MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 15  Former Gov. Ronald Reagan of California sounded the 1980 theme notes of conservative Republicans today with a call for a new,alliance of business, labor and farmem to challenge the arrogance of big government.

title: Hospital Sees Few Days Of Testing for Sihanouk
description: Prince Norodom Sihanouk of Cambodia, who was admitted to Lenox Hill Hospital Sunday because lie suffered from extreme stress and exhaustion, was reported to be in satisfactory condition yesterday, undergoing diagnostic tests.

title: National Book Critics Prize To `Stories of John Cheever
description: Competing against a particularly strong field of nominees, The Stories of John Cheever by John Cheever was named by the National Book Critics Circle as the best work of fiction that appeared in 1978. His book is published by Alfred A. Knopf.

title: Times in Pact For TV Station
description: The New York Times Company has agreed in principle to purchase a VHF television station, KFSM-TV, in Fort Smith, Ark. it was announced yesterday by Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, Times chairman and president, and Robert Buford, president of Buford Television Inc. of Fort Smith, the present licensee. The acquisition is subject to the approval of the Federal Communications Commission.

title: United Press International
description: THREE U.S. STUDENTS KILLED IN AVALANCHE IN ALPS: Rescuers with oxygen equipment tried unsuccessfully to revive William Scott Fenton, 21, of Thomasville, Ga., one of three American skiing students who died yesterday in an avalanche on Mt. Seegrube, near Innsbruck, Austria. Also killed were Denis Long, 22, of Louisville, Ky., and Catherine G. Resnic, 23, of Stockbridge, Mass. About 40 skiers were caught in the slide; five were injured.

title: Obituary 6 -- No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO 3543900 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9.00 A.M to 4:30 PM MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY; NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 33900. WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 9.5300; NASSAU CO. (516) 7470500; SUFFOLK CO (515)6691800; CONNECTICUT (203) 3497767

title: Harlem Ministers Group Says It May Fight Koch
description: NEW YORKERS PAUSE TO REMEMBER DR. KING: Worshipers at Convent Avenue Baptist Church in Harlem attending anniversary service for the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. There were observances throughout metropolitan area, but black ministers at Harlem service used occasion to attack Mayor Koch. Article on page I33.

title: The City; Diamond Dealer Buys 137Carat Gem
description: The 137.02carat Premier Rose, described as the finest diamond of its kind in the world, has been bought in full by its former partowner, GoldbergWeiss Inc. in New York, and the company said it was for sale.

title: Mandel, His Conviction Voided, Back as Governor for 2 Days
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 15 For what he called personally touching and sentimental reasons, Gov. Marvin Mandel of Maryland reclaimed the full powers of his office today for the final two days of a fouryear term that ends at noon Wednesday.

title: Utility Stock Offering
description: An underwriting group led by kid der, Peabody Company is offering today two million common shares of the Pithily Service Company of New Hampshire at $20.50 a share At this price, which is six times earnings. the is 10.31 percent.Bounds with a similar rating yield 10.10 percent yesterday.

title: Executives Assured on Trade
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15  The Carter Administration brought out four Cabinetlevel officers today to try to persuade 500 American business executives that they could have increasing trade with China while continuing to trade with Taiwan under the normalization of relations between Washington and Peking.

title: Frontiers: Space
description: ALL spacecraft orbit something  usually Earth or the Sun, and sometimes the Moon and planets. For the first time, however, there is a spacecraft between Earth and the Sun that appears to be orbiting nothing. It is circling a libration point, a point in space where the opposing gravitational forces of two large bodies (the Sun and Earth, in this case) are exactly counterbalanced.

title: A $250 MILLION TRIM PUT FORTH BY KOCH TO PLUG BUDGET GAP
description: LESS DRASTIC THAN EXPECTED

title: TV: Boat People Details Frustration
description: IN The Boat People, tonight at o'clock, CBS News looks at the condition of thousands of Vietnamese refugees stranded around Malaysia and Southeast Asia. Because the majority of these refugees seek eventual entry to the United States, the subject is emotionally charged, and this documentary makes little effort to soften the fact that American policy in the situation is a mess, if not a disgrace.

title: Bella Abzug's Ouster and Limits of Dissent
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15  President Carter's abrupt tlimissal of Bella S. Abzug from his National Advisory Committee on Women appears to reflect not only his irritation with her confrontational style, but also the urging of his ad- risers to project a decisive image in preparation for the re election drive he is expected to mount in 1980.

title: 549 Police Officers Given Warning on Being Absent
description: Five hundred and fortynine members of the New York City Police Department have been designated as chronic absentees and could face the loss of special benefits and privileges  including promotions  as part of a new departmentwide effort to curb unnecessary absences.

title: Against New Arms For China
description: There are 101 good reasons why the West should welcome Britain's decision to sell Harrier jets  the vertical takeoff fighterbomber, a plane that dispenses with runways and can hover and turn like a hummingbird  to China.

title: Du Pont Seeks Split; Earnings at Record
description: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, the nation's leading manufacturer of chemicals, proposed a 3-for-I stock split yesterday and announced record earnings for the fourth quarter and for all of 1978.

title: Interns and,Residents Set to Strike At 9 of City's Hospitals Tomorrow
description: A committee representing hospital interns and residents said that it would defy court restraining order and that there would be a oneday strike tomorrow at nine municipal hospitals, beginning at A. M.

title: Nixon Will Be a Guest At President's Dinner During Visit by Teng
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15  President Carter has invited former President Richard M. Nixon to a White House dinner in honor of China's senior Deputy Prime Minister and Mr. Nixon has accepted, the White House said tonight.

title: A Slowdown and More Inflation Seen By Retailers at Annual Convention
description: Retailers, already concerned about business prospects, were told yesterday by some of their peers and by economists that their sales would slow down this year and inflation probably would not subside until 1980.

title: Pittston to Sell Coal to Algeria
description: N. T. Camicia, chairman of the Pittston Company, said that Pittston had signed an agreement to supply at least 1,000 tons of metallurgical coal to Algeria's national steel company over a threeyear period beginning next July.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: The WIX Corporation, a manufacturer of filters for automobiles, said yesterday that it had received an offer from the Dana Corporation to acquire up to 45 percent of the outstanding common stock of WIX at a price of $39 a share.

title: Keeping the Press, and the Judiciary, Independent
description: Increasingly, newspapers have been making news as well as reporting it. From a police search of The Stanford Daily to the citation of The New York Times for contempt of court, journalists have been in the public eye as never before.

title: News Summary
description: TUESDAY, JANUARY 16, 1979

title: Frigid Adirondacks Are a Movie Set Again
description: PAUL SMITHS, N.Y., Jan. 12  The wind brought the chill factor in the swirling snowstorm to 10 degrees below zero as the two children huddled in front of a rough log cabin and peered out, with puzzled and frightened looks, at something unusual on the otherwise untouched white surface of the solidly frozen lake. first major feature to be filmed in the Adirondacks in 50 years. Despite difficulties working in cold, the producer believes the setting provides an authenticity that cannot be recreated in a sound studio. An article is on page B7.

title: US. Loses Bid to Block Kerkorian
description: WASHINGTON, Ian. 15  A Federal District Court in Los Angeles rebuffed today an attempt by the Justice Department to prevent Kirk Kerkorian, the controlling stockholder in MetroGoldwynMayer Inc., from completing a $42 million tender offer for 1.75 million shares of a second major film studio, Columbia Pictures Industries.

title: PollutionLaw Impact Brings Confrontation At California Meeting
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 15  Business and union leaders clashed verbally today with Federal regulators and environmentalists over the prospective impact of the latest laws to curb airpollution.

title: OBSERVER Little Brothers
description: Before jumping on Billy Carter, let's remember that it isn't easy being a kid brother.

title: Science Watch; Death of a Satellite
description: After 17 highly productive months, one of the largest and most complex unmanned research satellites ever launched by the United States is dead.

title: Today's TV Critic Pans NBC Movie
description: It is a common .and longstanding practice for NBC News to give over portions of The Today Show to promotional interviews with television stars whose shows will be appearing on NBCTV that evening.

title: Studies Asking: Who's Happy?
description: HAPPINESS, a favored subject of philosophers, writers and poets since the beginning of history, has only recently come under scientific scrutiny, and the results of studies thus far suggest that many traditional beliefs about it are incorrect.

title: Assembly Passes Bill to Reinstate Death Sentences; Vote Is 6 Short of Margin Needed to Override Veto
description: ALBANY, Jan. 15  After three hours of emotional debate, the Assembly tonight approved a bill to restore the death penalty in New York State. The vote was 99 to 52  six short of the twothirds majority needed to override Governor Carey's expected veto.

title: 2 Views of Cambodian Sweep: Local Affair or Soviet Peril
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 The swift success of Vietnam's military occupation of most of Cambodia, with the full approval of the Soviet Union, has caused ripple of apprehension in a number of countries that feel vulnerable to the pro jection of force by Communist powers.

title: The North Stars Blind Owner
description: Each evening the darkness closed in faster for Gordon Gund than it did for others. He found himself bumping into people on the sidewalk. He had to stop driving at night. Another time, in bright daylight, he was piloting a small plane above the Teterboro (N.J.) Airport when the voice from the control tower identified him as No.16 in a holding pattern of planes waiting to land. But, he says now, 'I could only see seven others. They broke the pattern for me, and the tower talked me down. That was the last time he flew a plane. Soon he visited an ophthalmologist who diagnosed his vision problem as retinitis pigmentosa, a hereditary disease that eventually causes total blindness. Now the 39-year-old president of a Princeton, N.J., investment and real estate firm, Gordon Gund has been blind for almost eight years, but he skis, waterskis, skates, swims and jogs. lie also is the vice chairman of the Minnesota North Stars, who played the New York Rangers at Madison Square Garden last night. And he was there with a portable radio plugged into one ear and his mind plugged Into the sounds around him.

title: Ivy Troutman, Actress, Hemingway Character
description: Ivy Troutman, a supporting actress on Broadway in the 20's and 30's, died Friday at her home in Tinton Falls, N.J. She was 96 years old.

title: First Full Explanation
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15  The Carter Administration provided its fullest public explanation today of the decision to normalize relations with China, but in separate presentations, President Carter's two chief foreignpolicy advisers seemed to differ over what the development meant for the Soviet Union.

title: 10 Diplomats From Iran Will Shun Shah's Envoy
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (UPI)  Ten diplomats at the Iranian Embassy here said today that they would no longer work with the Shah's Ambassador, Ardeshir Zahedi.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: I.B.M.'s 3Month Profit Tops $1 Billion
description: The International Business Machines Corporation, producer of more than half of the world's computer hardware, reported yesterday a 27.2 percent leap in earnings for the fourth quarter of 1978. Its profit for the whole year, up 14.4 percent from the 1977 level, topped $3 billion for the first time.

title: Supreme Court Roundup
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15  The Supreme Court agreed today to decide in what courts citizens can bring lawsuits against Federal officials  a technical issue that can nonetheless determine the ease and expense of bringing damage suits to vindicate constitutional rights.

title: Swimsuits for Women Who Have Had a Mastectomy
description: The saleswoman went into the fitting room and said to the woman trying on a bathing suit: You look fabulous. The woman answered, I know. Not so remarkable, except that the woman had had a mastectomy, and a bathing suit is just about the most revealing garment a woman wears in public. If she can look good on the beach, it does wonders for her selfesteem.

title: Notes on People
description: He was married in a Westminster Abbey chapel, but J. Carter Brown 3d, director of the National Gallery of Art in Washington, has a special feeling for St. Bartholomew's, London's oldest parish church. It was built in 1123, for one thing, and is a rare Romanesque survivor, he said. But his interest is personal, as well as arthistorical a few hours after their 1976 wedding and a private reception, Mr. Brown and his second wife, the former Pamela Braga Drexel, went to evensong at St. Bartholomew's for our first communion as man and wife. Increasingly, the ancient church has need of a new roof and other upkeep, and tonight at 8, at All Saints Episcopal Church, 230 East 60th Street, a benefit has been arranged by Anne Perkin, a New York social worker who also learned to love St. Bartholomew's while living in London. The featured performer will be Mr. Brown, who will give an illustrated lecture on the National Gallery's widely praised new East Building and

title: Bridge:; Tristate Regional Tourney Ends in Convincing Victory
description: A convincing victory by four area experts concluded the largestever Tristate Regional Tournament in Port Chester, N.Y., on Sunday. The four Lew Handelsman of Malverne, LI..; Emmet Pollenz of East Meadow, L.I.; Stasha Wroblewski of Tuxedo, N.Y., and Michael Radin of New York Cityheaded a field of 284 teams with a score of 136 victory points, equivalent to bsi percent.

title: Kodak to Lift Camera Prices
description: ROCHESTER. Jan 15 (AP)Eastman Kodak Company said that it planned to raise prices of its still cametas an average of 5 percent on fieday.

title: Hofstra Drops Princeton To a 77 Record, 61 to 44
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Jan. 15  Hofstra held Princeton scoreless during a stretch of 91/2 minutes spanning both halves and went on to a 6144 victory over the Tigers tonight. It was Princeton's seventh loss against seven victories. Hofstra is now 69.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Exagent Accuses F.B.I. Executive Of Perjury in Suit Over Informers
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 15  A retired Federal Bureau of Investigation agent has accused the bureau's secondranking executive of perjuring himself in sworn statements he gave in a longrunning lawsuit against the bureau by the Socialist Workers Party.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP)  The Government filed a new legal challenge today to what it contends is a racially biased system of promoting members of the Detroit police force.

title: World News Briefs
description: PEKING, Jan. 15 (Reuters)  A demonstration by people from different parts of China seeking redress of grievances from the country's leaders quietly faded away today.

title: TV: Murder With Bono
description: A successful songwriter  a description that has to be taken Qn faith  buys a oneman private detective agency as a tax shelter, which doesn't sound like a deal that would gain the approval of the Internal Revenue Service, and, predictably, finds himself involved in a blackmail case involving a beautiful country-and-western singer.

title: Carter to Study Options on Reform Of $80 Billion Domestic Aid Plans
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15  President Carter is scheduled to receive a series of options tomorrow for reforming the Federal Government's complex, sometimes wasteful apparatus for administering more than $80 billion a year in grants in aid.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day yesterday misidentified the new president and chief operating officer of the Getty Oil Company. He is Sidney R. Petersen.

title: Letters
description: TO SCIENCE TIMES:

title: Mrs. Kreps to See Saudis
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (Reuters)Commerce Secretary Juanita M. Kreps will visit Saudi Arabia from Jan. 25 to 29 for talks on trade, the department said today.

title: ISRAEL TO ESTABLISH MORE SETTLEMENTS
description: Move in West Bank and Gaza Is on Eve of New U.S. Peace Effort

title: Robert Walker, at 52; Was a Photographer for New York Times
description: Robert Walker, a news photographer who had been with The New York Times since 1946, died yesterday of cancer at his home, 185 Farnum Boulevard, Franklin Square, L.1. He was 52 years old.

title: Shipping/Mails; Incoming
description: ARRIVING TOMORROW, Jan. 17

title: Rep. Flood Is Sworn In At Recess in His Trial
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP)  Representative Daniel J. Flood used a recess in his trial on perjury and bribery charges today to be sworn in for a 16th term in Congress, then returned to the Federal courthouse for the seating of jurors.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Judge Decrees Fairbanks Can't Sign With Colorado
description: BOSTON, Jan. 15 (AP)  A Federal judge ordered today that Chuck Fairbanks, the head coach of the New England Patriots, cannot sign a contract to coach football at the University of Colorado.

title: SHAH SAID TO PLAN TO LEAVE IRAN TODAY FOR EGYPT AND U.S.
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 15  Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi is expected to leave Iran tomorrow afternoon for Egypt on his way to the United States for an extended stay aimed at relieving the crisis that has torn his country.

title: Briton Wins Equity Plea
description: Tom Conti will be able to repeat his awardwinning performance in Bria Clark's London dramatic hit, Whose Life Is It Anyway? in the Broadway production in spite of an objection raised by Actors Equity Association, it was ruled yesterday by an arbitrator. The arbitrator, Benjamin Roberts, indicated that Mr. Conti had met the requirements of a collective bargaining agreement between Equity and the League of New York Theaters and Producers.

title: G.W. Nutter, ExDefenie Official
description: G. Warren Nutter, professor of economics at the University of Virginia, who was Assistant Secretary of Defense for international security affairs in the first Nixon Administration, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Charlottesville, Va. He was 55 years old.

title: Theater: Eater Is Story Of a 3Wornan Triangle
description: THE entire second act of Corinne Jackees Later takes place on a goodsized sailboat. The widowed mother and her two grown daughters, who have spent the first act in splintery reminiscence onshore, continue their fretful picking at the past onboard.

title: 9 'Rookies' in Congress Have Moment of Glory
description: WASHINGTON. Jan. 15  Like col lege students moving into dormitories, they have selected their offices by lottery. Some of their papers remain packed in cardboard boxes. They have also spent the last few weeks lobbying with their colleagues for committee assignments.

title: Music: Trout Quintet
description: IN preparation for this, its 10th year, the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center asked its subscribers to choose their favorite pieces from a decade of programs. The chosen works then were made the backbone of this anniversary season. Sophisticates may have snickered, but was anyone really surprised that the winner of first place in this election was the Trout Quintet? At any level of sophistication, chambermusic listeners easily find it possible to be hooked on this Schubert masterpiece.

title: Frommelt, Wenzel 1, 2 In Slalom
description: CRANSMONTANA, Switzerland, Jan. 15 (UPI)  Liechtenstein celebrated a double victory today when Paul Frommelt took first place and his teammate, Andreas Wenzel, placed second in a men's special slalom World Cup ski race.

title: Deaths
description: LEVINESol. We deeply mourn the loss of our dear friend and longtime associate. Our heartfelt sympathies to his beloved wife Anne, his child. ren and family.

title: Rally Goes On as Dow Rises 12.39
description: Du Pont, I.B.M. And Gambling Issues Shine

title: Loughery Faces More Penalties
description: Eleven days after his return from a threegame suspension, Kevin Loughery, the coach of the New Jersey Nets, faces further punishment or a stiff reprimand by the National Basketball Association. Larry O'Brien, the N.B.A. commissioner, announced yesterday that he had ordered Loughery; Joseph Taub, the Nets principal owner, and Charles Theokas, the general manager, to his Manhattan office for a 3 P.M. meeting today.

title: Miss Navratilova Gains Revenge on Chris Evert
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 15 (AP) Chris Evert knew she was in trouble when she wasn't nervous. And she was right.

title: Schmidt Backs 2d Term for Carter, Apparently to Quash Report of Rift
description: BONN, Jan. 15  In an apparent attempt to dampen a report of differences between Chancellor Helmut Schmidt and President Carter, the West German leader has said he favors a second term for President Carter,

title: Events
description: COLIN CARR, cellist, 92d Street Y.M..Y.W.H A at Lexington Avenue, 8.

title: Excerpts From Speeches by Vance and Brzezinski on America's China Policy
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15  Following are excerpts from speeches on China policy given today by Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance and Zbigniew Brzezinski, the Whit,: House national security adviser, to a conference of businessmen.

title: CBS Moves Paper Chase in Effort to Raise Ratings
description: If praise could be translated into audiencepopularity rating points, The Paper Chase would not be stuck in the swampy lowlands of the Nielsen list with an average 19 percent share of the audience.

title: Stage: Drrenmatt Premiere at PAF
description: HUNTINGTON STATION L.I.

title: A Sale at Turnbull &
description: LONDON, Jan. 15  The annual oneday sale at Turnbull & Asser, the posh men's store, got underway here today as some 2,000 gentlemen pawed and clawed at cashmere socks, silk shirts and other luxury items knocked down to bargainbasement prices in one of London's most highly anticipated fashion events.

title: About Education
description: TO some people, the word tenure is a synonym for deadwood; to others, it means academic freedom. Professors love tenure as businessmen love the bottom line. Yet many businessoriented university trustees see the tenure system as the coddling of incompe, tents. Even within academia, tenure has become controversial, dividing the young, untenured faculty from tenured seniors who are in no great hurry to make room for those waiting outside.

title: Dividends
description: MONDAY, JAN 15, 1979

title: EDUCATION; N.Y.U. Demanding Proficiency In Writing
description: FFOR half an hour one recent morning, Scott Lackey and his 12 freshman writing students at New York University struggled silently with the task of writing short essays about postholiday depression.

title: Perez Cautions On Oil Output
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 15 (UPI)  President Carlos Andres Perez says that Venezuela, a member of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, should resist any pressure to increase its oil sales abroad because of the slowdown In Iranian oil production.

title: World Gold
description: MONDAY, JAN. 15, 1979

title: Moving Toward Freer Trade
description: After years of negotiation at Geneva, the world's trading powers have tentatively agreed to major revision of the rules governing international commerce., The pact is welcome. It lowers tariffs by an average of onethird. More important, it restricts the use of other protectionist barriers to trade and provides mechanisms for disciplining the rulebreakers.

title: Time Is Seen As the Final Yardstick
description: T0 the ancient Greeks, time was Chronos, the malevolent father all living beings, who invariably ate his own children. Time has also been symbolized as a river, an arrow, a sand glass, an old man with a scythe, a winged chariot and as many other things. Now the National Bureau of Standards is considering making time something more  the ultimate yardstick by which everything else is measured.

title: Young Gets 5 Goals, Stars Rout Rangers
description: Logically, it should never have happened: Minnesota's Tim Young getting five goals on five shots and the North Stars beating the New York Rangers, 81, last night.

title: Deaths
description: AUERBACHJune. Devoted wife of the late Lawrence. Beloved mother of Linda and Richard. Loving daughter of Anne Yagerdorf. Dear mother-in-law of Lisa. Cherished grandmother of Leslie, Brent and Jason. Services Tuesday, 2:15PM The Riverside, West 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Contributions may be made to the National Cancer Institute, In memory of June Auerbach.

title: C. Warren Bowring Jr., 77, Dies; ExHead of Shipping Association
description: C. Warren Bowring Jr., former executive director of the New York Shipping Association, died Sunday at South Nassau Communities Hospital after a long illness. He was 77 years old and lived in Lawrence, L.I.

title: Fighting Near Border Subsides
