description: ARANYAPRATHET, Thailand, Jan. 15  The level of fighting along Cambodia's border with Thailand dropped drastically overnight, according to Thai military commanders monitoring the combat with field radios and spotter planes.

title: Neediest Cases Fund Almost at $ 1 Million As Drive Nears Close
description: Contributions to the 67d annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund neared the $1 million mark yesterday as the campaign entered its final weeks.

title: Sugar Legislation's Rapidly Revolving Door
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15  Early last year, when the sugar growers resumed their drive for higher price supports, the Congressional staff members who helped to arrange several key strategy meetings included Michael McLeod, then an aide to Senator Herman E. Talmadge, Democrat of Georgia, and Dale Sherwin, then a member of the Senate Agriculture Committee staff.

title: Home Loan Weakening Is Expected
description: Mortgage lenders anticipate weaker demand for home loans and they expect interest rates to peak within eight months, a housing economist for the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation said yesterday after the agency arranged to buy $16.8 million of mortgages eight months from now.

title: Bache Chooses A Retailer
description: When you are getting into retailing in a big way, you don't put a steel executive on your board, you find a retailer  even if you are a stockbroker. Harry Jacobs Jr., chairman of the Bache Grip Inc., did just that. He brought on board Harold Krensky, president of Federated Department Stores.

title: A Reporter's Notebook: Sorting Out Shah's Plans
description: TEHERAN, Jan. 15  In what may prove to be the final hours of the Pahlevi dynasty upon the Peacock throne of Iran, truth has become as elusive as a butterfly.

title: The Editorial Notebook Selling Cities Like Soap
description: Melbourne, Australia, is having an identity crisis. The city has announced a $100,000 prize for the best idea for an imagemaking landmark  like the Eiffel Tower in Paris or the Empire State Building in New York. There are only two provisos: the concept should be able to pay its way, and it should become famous around the world.

title: Arab Boycott's Unwitting Participants
description: The ease with which a company can become an unwitting participant in the Arab boycott against banks that have Jewish ties, despite efforts to comply with antiboycott laws, is shown in connection with a recent $33 million loan to Algeria.

title: New Hope for the Crime Code
description: Will this be the Congress that finally brings order out of the chaos that is now the Federal criminal law code? There is new reason for hope. The need for clear, consistent code has been evident for more than decade, but quarrels over the nature of the remedy have left it unmet.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Abbott Laboratories, Chicago, worldwide manufacturer of healthcare products, has named Joseph A. Sasenick president of its Consumer Products division.

title: Deaths
description: FEINGOLDHerman. Knickerbocker Lodge #510, K. of P. sorrowfully announces the untimely passing of Its esteemed brother. Officers and members are requested to pay respects at funeral services at Garlick's Unionport Road at Olmstead Avenue, Bronx on Tuesday, January 16th at 12 Noon.

title: No War Talk for Greene, Only We Get the Job Done
description: MIAMI, Jan. 15  With six talking days left before the Super Bowl, Joe Greene said today that the sports world should encourage the kind of brash, inflammatory talk that has emerged from some Dallas Cowboys in recent weeks.

title: Judge Declares Absolute End To the Strike by Steel. Haulers
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 15 (AP)  A Federal judge directed an immediate, absolute end today to a strike by dissident steel haulers whose leader had refused to order them back to work.

title: COMMODITIES Soybeans and Corn Rise In Light Futures Trading
description: Trading was light on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday, but prices for soybeans and corn showed some sharp increases, mainly because of the impact of the snowstorm that blanketed the area with about 30 inches over the weekend. More was expected late yesterday.

title: State Racing Board Rejects OTB's Florida Simulcasts
description: There will be no live television broadcasts of Gulfstream races into New York City's offtrack betting shops today.

title: Rail Strike Adding to Britons Woes
description: LONDON, Jan. 15  Trains all over Britain were halted tonight by the first of two daylong railway strikes that are expected to add greatly to the disruption already caused by a twoweeklong truck drivers strike.

title: Taxes & Accounting
description: Entertainment Deductions

title: Russians Veto Resolution on Cambodia
description: China Is Said to Be Satisfied

title: Pol Pot Forces Said to Plan Last Stand
description: BANGKOK. Thailand, Jan. 15  Mountainous southwestern Cambodia, between the Cardamom and Elephant ranges and the Gulf of Siam, appears to be the region where the forces of the crumbling Government of Prime Minister Pol Pot are planning to make their final stand against the Vietnamese onslaught, Western analysts said today.

title: Treasury Bills Near Peak Rate
description: The Treasury sold threemonth bills yesterday at an average rate of 9.41? percent, the secondhighest rate MI record, topped only by the 9.90S percent of the record sale on Aug. 24, 1974. The rate last week was 9.316 percent.

title: Deaths
description: CURTISJack of Darien, ?? ?? January 15, 1979 Husband of Agnes Gram Curtis, brother of George Curtis, Paul Curtis and Edwin Curtis. Funeral Service at Saint Luke's Episcopal church, Post Road. Darien ??. on Thursday January 18, 1979 at 1:30 PM. In lieu of flowers memorials may be made to Eisenhower College, Seneca Fails, New York 13148 or The Book of Remembrance Saint Luke's Episcopal Church. Daien Ct 06820

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: ELEMENTARY, CHACHA Sherlock Holmes has just turned 125 years old as of this month, at least according to the pages of his creator, Sir Arthur Conan Doyle. By way of celebration, no less than Roseland is getting into the act, and so, for some lighthearted promotion, is Broadway's Holmes package, The Crucifer of Blood.

title: TV: Edward the Kin Beins Tonight
description: TWO key facts emerge from Edward the King, the 13part British series that begins tonight at 8 on WNEW/5. First of all, the production is, in every way, incredibly splendid. Then, its presenta- tion constitutes a scathing commentary on American programming policies as the networks rush headlong into a plague of juvenilia.

title: The Region
description: Judge Robert W. Sweet instructed the jury in the Westchester Premiere Theater trial yesterday to continue deliberations after the jury reported it was deadlocked on the sixth day of deliberations in Federal District Court in Manhattan. The 12member jury had sent the judge a note reporting that we can get no more than 11 jurors to agree on any verdict. The note added that it seems fruitless to continue.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 16  The Westinghouse Electric Corporation and two Swedish utilities have agreed to settle uranium supply lawsuits pending in Stockholm.

title: Feminist Will Head Women's Panel
description: WASHINGTON. Jan. 16  The White House today selected Marjorie Bell Chambers, an active feminist who is national president of the American Association of University Women, to succeed Bella S. Abzug temporarily as head of the President's National Advisory Committee on Women.

title: Agency Denies Permit For a Maine Refinery, Citing Peril to Eagles
description: PORTLAND, Me., Jan. 16  The Environmental Protection Agency has denied a water discharge permit for the Pittston Company's proposed oil refinery in Eastport, Me., on the ground that the project threatened the survival of the bald eagle.

title: Beekman Place Is Awaiting Iranian Royalty
description: The mailman handed a package to the doorman at 20 Beekman Place. Then he nodded toward the redbrick town house across the street. What's the story  anybody there yet? he asked.

title: Jurors Begin Their Deliberations In Houston MurderforHire Trial
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 16 (UPI)  A jury began deliberations today in the murderforhire trial of T. Cullen Davis, a Fort Worth oil executive charged with attempting to buy the death of the judge who presided at his divorce trial.

title: Dr. Henry Jaffe Dead At 82, Long a Leader On Ailments of Bones
description: Dr. Henry L. Jaffe, an authority on bone pathology, died Friday at the extendedcare facility of New Rochelle Hospital, after a long illness. A resident of Pelham, N.Y., he was 82 years old.

title: Chess:
description: Spatial advantage  the ability, for example, to occupy four ranks of the board while the opponent is limited to three  is the most tenuous element of strategy, requiring the greatest care in exploitation. This, in essence, is what the hypermodenlists discovered after World War 1, mainly, that all advances much be diligently supported or suffer the risk of a damaging counterattack.

title: Katharine Sturges Knight, at 88, An Illustrator of Books and Style
description: Katharine Sturges Knight, an illustrator of books and fashions, died Sunday at a hospital in Manhattan at the age of 88. She lived in Manhattan and in Redding, Conn.

title: Sharing Mr.Koch's Budget Cuts
description: Mayor Koch has met the Jan. 15 deadline set by the Financial Control Board for clarifying his proposed cuts in city spending for the fiscal year that begins July 1. It is not clear, however, that he has met the board's basic demand, a legally balanced budget that moves toward the even more difficult goal of a universally acceptable balance by fiscal 1982.

title: Republic Steel Doubles Its Net
description: The Republic Steel Corporation, the nation's fourthlargest steel company, yesterday reported fourthquarter earnings of $39.37 million, or $2.43 a share, more than double the earnings of $14.96 million, or 93 cents a share, in the fourth quarter of 1977.

title: NICARAGUANS BRACE FOR FRESH VIOLENCE
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Jan. 12 With the virtual collapse of United States efforts to organize a plebiscite to settle this country's political crisis, Nicaraguans are once again bracing themselves for an increase in violence between the Government of Gen. Anastasio Somoza Debayle and the broadbased opposition.

title: Deaths
description: OLDSMITHBertha Loving sister of Helen Schapirp & Rose Friedman. Retired staff member of New York State Department of Taxation & Finance On January 15 at The Jewish Home & Hospital for the Aged Services Wednesday, January 17, 11am, The Riverside, West 76th St & Amsterdam Ave

title: Pennsylvania and Texas Swear Republicans as Their Governors
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Jan. 16  Using a Bible once owned by William Penn, Richard L. Thornburgh was sworn in today as Pennsylvania's 41st Governor in a brief ceremony on the front steps of the Capitol.

title: International Paper Shows Record Profit
description: The International Paper Company, the world's largest papermaker, reported yesterday a jump of 27 percent in fourthquarter profits, to set a record for the period, while earnings for the full year were little changed.

title: Few Like Steel Trigger Prices
description: PITTSBURGH  Domestic steelmakers don't like it; they call it startlingly ineffective. Steel users don't like it; they say it's adding billions of dollars a year to the cost of steel and hundreds of dollars a year to the cost of living. Steelexporting countries don't like it, but are more philosophical; it's the worst solution, they say, except for all the others.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16  President Carter has been philosophizing in private recently about the foreign policy problems of the nation and about his critics at home and abroad who complain about the conduct or misconduct of these affairs. But he's not apologizing for his record or worrying too much about the future.

title: What Koch Left Out
description: The fouryear plan for New York City that Mayor Koch presented on Monday is as instructive for what it does not contain as for what it does. Although the bulk of the report focuses on $250 million worth of cuts and savings that the Mayor is proposing to close next year's budget gap, it ignores the growing and substantial gaps that the city will lace in the following three years.

title: Seeing Things Whole
description: WASHINGTON  What the American Indian and some other ancient cultures have known all along is now generally recognized  that a change anywhere affects everything else. The more science advances us, the more we come to realize the seamless web that is man and nature.

title: About Real Estate
description: One of the three interchanges of new Interstate 280 in Roselatid, N.J., is at Livingston Avenue. What a fine spot for a regional shopping center, Federated Department Stores said to itself in the mid1960's when the highway was still in the development phase.

title: ExAide Testifies He Delivered Money to Rep. Flood as Payoffs
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16  The former top assistant to Representative Daniel J. Flood, the Pennsylvania Democrat, today described several instances in which he said he delivered money to the 16term Congressman as payment for the exercise of favorable Congressional action.

title: Offering by Pemex
description: The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company said that Mexico's Governmentowned oil company, Petroleos Mexicano's of Petnex had raised $100 million in international market with a public offering of five year notes.

title: Retail Post Passed Up
description: In what would be a break with longestablished tradition, Donald B. Smiley, chairman and chief executive of R. H. Macy & Company, reportedly will not stand for election as chairman of the National Retail Merchants Association, a position for which he is first in line.

title: Iran, a Country Adrift
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 16  The din of triumph that echoed through Teheran today expressed the spirit of the moment. But the spirit of the future may have been more truly expressed by a phrase uttered at the same time near Paris by a resolute 78yearold man who has made a revolution. The depature of Shah

title: Iran Oil Outlook Held Dim, With Price Rise Feared
description: Experts on international oil said yesterday that the outlook for a quick resumption of Iranian oil exports remained dim.

title: Music: Triple Threat
description: OVER the last few years, Music With Jens Nygaard has become synonymous with the offbeat: programs devoted to music by such unlikely composers as Dimitri Mitropoulos, George Szell and

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: ACORDING to Melanie Kahane, there are people who love caviar, and people who LOVE caviar. If you are a member of the latter group, as she says she is, once you get your clutches on some, you do not share. You lock yourself in the closet, get under the bed, eat in the bathroom or take whatever other measures are necessary to be alone.

title: Dow Drops 13.08 Amid Dollar Woes
description: Gambling issues and other big winners in Monday's strong market reversed direction abruptly yesterday as stocks generally were hit by selling.

title: Dividends
description: TUESDAY. JAN. 16, 1979

title: 2 Transit Clerks Are Badly Hurt In Flame Attack
description: Two Transit Authority clerks were were critically injured last night when a teenager reportedly sprayed a mixture of gasoline and propane through the coin slot of a robberyproof change booth in Queens, then lit a match and tossed it inside.

title: COMMODITIES
description: If the Treasury's monthly auctions of gold are aimed at depressing the bullion market and bolstering the dollar, it was not evident yesterday. Buyers bid for a record amount of the metal, and offered higher prices than at the last sale on Dec. 19.

title: Cookware Show
description: CHICAGO Belowzero weather and mountains of snow couldn't prevent thousands of houswares exhibitors and buyers from their semiannual rendezvous at the huge McCormick Place exhibition hall.

title: Anthony Liebler, 75, Assistant Prosecutor In Manhattan to 1960
description: Anthony J. Liebler, a former assistant district attorney in Manhattan, died yesterday at St. Mary's Hospital in West Palm Beach, Fla., at the age of 75. He lived in Palm Beach, having moved there in 1969.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: American National Bank and Trust Company of Chicago has elected to its board of directors Walter R. Peirson, executive vice president of the Standard Oil Company (Indiana), and Robert P. Reuss, chairman and chief executive officer of the Central Telephone and Utilities Corporation.

title: Obituary 1 -- No Title
description: NATHAN A. GOLDENTHAL

title: Pension Not A Security, Court Rules
description: WASHINGTON. Jan 16  The Supreme Court, in an 8to decision greeted with relief by both big business and big labor, ruled today that workers who believe they have been cheated out of a pension cannot use the antifraud provisions of the Federal securities laws to sue the pension plan's sponsors.

title: Young Asks New Look at P.L.O.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Jan. 16 Andrew Young has declared that the Palestine Liberation Organization must be viewed realistically because it has captured the imagination of the Palestinnian people and become a tremendous influence in Arab countries.

title: Super Feats A Specialty For Harris
description: MIAMI, Jan. 16  Complete the statement in 25 words or less: Franco Harris is so good that....

description: METROPOLITAN OPERA, Lincoln Center, Verdi's Luisa Miller, 8.

title: Private Lives
description: LIKE most Americans, I want to be liked. For most Americans, being liked is almost a subdivision of ontology. We need it, as if to establish our existence. We are a very needy people. It isn't necessary to be liked by the writers one criticizes; that's business. Nor is it necessary to be liked by the media brats whose racket is to bite their betters on the kneecaps; that's business, too; even parasites have to eat. And I do not require myself to be my own best friend; I married my best friend. But the approval of strangers is something else, an aspic to contain the amour propre.

title: For Train 1330, Woes Begin to Look Familiar
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Jan. 16  For the 5:40 A.M. train out of Grand Central Terminal, the mishap involving its pantograph this morning was the second serious accident in less than three weeks. The train, No. 1330  which does not have the same equipment and crew every day  was derailed near Mount Vernon on Dec. 29 in an incident that appears to have involved a violation of operating rules, and that caused $575,000 in damage.

title: Conrad Hilton's Estate Is Valued At $100 Million in Court Papers
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 16 (AP)  Conrad Hilton, who died Jan. 3 at the age of 91, has left an estate of $100 million, according to documents filed in court.

title: Metropolitan to Get Chinese Garden Court and Ming Room
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art plans to install a Chinese garden court and Ming Dynasty furniture room to be built in Soochow, China, and shipped here from Shanghai, under an agreement signed last month with China in Washington.

title: Islanders Win, 62; Potvin: 3
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Jan. 16  The Islanders, who have jumped out to early leads in most of their games this season and then have thwarted their foes' attempts to play catchup, followed that pattern tonight in beating the Washington Capitals. 62.

title: U.S. Envoy Arrives in Israel to Try to Revive Talks
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 16  An American envoy arrived here today to try to give new life to the stalled peace talks between Israel and Egypt. His arrival coincided with a report by Israeli military sources that Israeli commando units had landed by sea in Lebanon and blown up a building reportedly used as a Palestinian guerrilla headquarters.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: ANOTHER semester has passed into history, and history is probably a little the worse for it, along with a few other subjects. What prompts this observation is another collection of culls from student papers, submitted by Prof. Stanley B. Winters of the New Jersey Institute of Technology:

title: Text of a Statement By Shah on Leaving
description: TEHLRAN, Iran Jan. 16 (AP) Following is the. text of the statement made by Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi to the official Pars News Agency or his departure from Iran today, translated by The Associated Press.

description: To the Editor:

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Tuesday. Jan. 16, 1979

title: Around the Nation
description: Federal District Judge Thomas E. Griesa ordered the Government yesterday to give him all the material that a former agent had given to the Justice Department concerning allegations that the Federal Bureau of Investigation provided false information in sworn statements involving a suit by the Socialist Worker Party.

title: U.S. Colonel in Teheran Called Apparent Suicide
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 16 (Reuters) An American Army officer acting and a military adviser to Iran was found dead in his quarters today, a United States military spokesman said tonight.

title: Musicians to Play Cuba
description: A music festival featuring Cuban and American artists in Havana on March 2, 3 and 4 will mark the first time that major popular, jazz and salsa acts from the United States have given formal concerts in the captial since the Cuban revolution.

title: Powell Denies Dispute on China
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16  The White House today disputed news reports that President Carter's two chief foreignpolicy advisers had differed yesterday on what American recognition of China meant for the Soviet Union.

title: Technology
description: THE collision of a jet airliner and a small Cessna plane over San Diego last September has accelerated Government development of computerized safety equipment known as collision avoidance systems.

title: Loughery Makes His Apologies
description: Coach Kevin Loughery yesterday denied saying that there was a conspiracy against him by National Basketball Association officials, apologized to Commissioner Larry O'Brien about his recent behavior, and said he had no evidence that officials intentionally made calls against his team, the New Jersey Nets.

title: ShortWeight Butcher Posts 5 Bargain Prices
description: To compensate for previous shortweight violations, the Gold Star Market, at 1711 Avenue B, Brooklyn, will sell five cuts of meat to consumers at wholesale prices for one week beginning next Monday, Bruce Ratner, City Commissioner of Consumer Affairs announced yesterday.

title: McGovern Testifies About Meetings With Letelier
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16  Senator George McGovern and a leading member of the Dutch Parliament testified today that Orlando Letelier, a former Chilean diplomat murdered in Washington, helped bring about international economic sanctions against Chile in 1975. Their testimony appeared meant by Federal prosecutors to explain why they believe that agents of the Chilean secret police killed Mr. Letelier in Washington on Sept. 21, 1976.

title: State Correction Unit Accused of Being Lax In Overseeing Prisons
description: ALBANY, Jan. 16  Almost four years after state investigators charged that the state's Commission of Correction did not properly investigate abuses in New York's prison system, the Commission was today accused in a report prepared by the state Comptroller's Office of still failing to effectively carry out its responsibility as the watchdog of the correction system.

title: Letters
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: H. H. Buttner, ExI.T.T. Director
description: Harold H. Buttner, a telecommunications engineer and former vice president and technical director of International Telephone and Telegraph, died last Friday in Bridgeport (Conn.) Hospital. He was 86 years old and lived in Milford, Conn.

title: Money
description: TUESDAY. JAN. 16, 1979

title: Bronx Boy, 15, Guilty After a Trial as Adult
description: A 15yearold Bronx boy yesterday became the first teenager in the state to be convicted under the new law that allows youths between the ages of 13 and 16 to be treated as adults in the criminal justice system, Bronx District Attorney Mario Merola said.

title: Television
description: 4:00 P.M. Presidential News Conference (2,4,7,13)

title: Dollar Outlook Viewed With Caution
description: BONN, Jan. 16  The recent tenuous recovery of the dollar on international markets is unlikely to prove a lasting one, according to European foreign exchange experts, unless more evidence develops that the United States is firmly committed to defending its currency.

title: Iranian Festival Is Over For American Business
description: With the departure of Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, the curtain has dropped on corporate America's Iranian festival.

title: Mediator to Enter Aqueduct Talks
description: The threat of a strike this week by parimutuel clerks at Aqueduct appeared to have eased yesterday after a Federal mediator scheduled a meeting with union and management representatives for next Monday.

title: Resorts Head Tells of Dropping Partner
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 16  James M. Crosby, chairman of Resorts Interantion. al, testified today that he was not aware that his partner in a Bahamas casino might have organizedcrime associations until he read an article in Life magazine saying so. He said he promptly severed the relationship by buying out his partner's interest.

title: Carter Will Meet Press In White House Today
description: President Carter will hold a news conference in the White House at 4 o'clock this afternoon. All three networks and the Public Broadcasting Service have scheduled live telecasts.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: As in most big banking institutions, changes in the top ranks of executives of the Royal Bank of Canada have been in the works for years. So it was no surprise to Rowland C. Frazee, the bank's president, when he was elected last week to succeed W. Earle McLaughlin as chief executive officer of Royal, which is Canada's largest bank.

title: Market Place
description: DISAPPOINTING quarters are anathema in Wall Street, and betterthanexpected quarters can send a stock soaring. Even pennies per share in a given quarter can add million of dollars to the value of a company's shares.

title: Rockefeller calls Parley on Art
description: As controversy simmers over the new artandchina reproduction business he has started, called The Nelson Rockefeller Collection. Nelson A.

title: Notes on People
description: Every good yarn has a sequel, and the latest saga of Billy Carter is no exception. Just to freshen memories, the President's brother caused noticeable cringing at the White House by taking a group of Libyans on a rollicking tour, by making comments about Jews that some thought to be antiSemitic, and, apparently, by stepping out of a limousine and then, in the presence of an Arab diplomat and an Atlanta Journal reporter, urinating on a runway apron in Atlanta.

title: Hospital Strike Barred by Judge; Doctors Defiant
description: Mayor Koch and the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation won temporary injunction in State Supreme Court yesterday barring a oneday strike by interns and residents scheduled to begin at 7 o'clock this morning at nine municipal hospitals.

title: American Express Plan Prompts McGraw Suit
description: The American Express Company, defying a determination by McGrawHill Inc. to remain independent, said yesterday that it was going ahead with its offer to pay $34 a share for any and all shares of the large publishing company in a takeover bid involving $880 million in cash.

title: 5 Banking Groups Lift Earnings
description: Five of the nation's major bank holding companies reported higher fourthquarter earnings yesterday.

title: Flackde and 6 Others Are First Recess Choices Approved by Senate
description: ALBANY, Jan. 16  In the State Senate's first actions on the 68 controversial recess appointments resubmitted by Governor Carey last week, seven appointees were confirmed today, including Robert F. Flacke as the Commissioner of Environmental Conservation.

title: Tony Hill Of Cowboys States Case
description: FORT LAUDERDALE. Fla., Jan. 16  Listen, Lynn Swann and John Stallworth, Tony Hill is tal?? We are the best.

title: Carter's Invitation to Nixon Stirs Differing Reactions on Capitol Hill
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16  President Carter's invitation to former President Richard M. Nixon to attend a White House state dinner for Deputy Prime Minister Teng Hsiaoping of China has evoked widely differing reactions from Mr. Nixon's former critics on Capitol Hill.

title: Economic Scene
description: AN economic system is like a giant mobile hanging from the ceiling: Business or government cannot disturb one part of the system without disturbing the other parts. The economic jargon for this is interdependence.

title: Protecting Yourself From Harmful Noise
description: YOU are awakened at 3 A.M. by a fire siren. No sooner do you doze off again than the rattle and roar of garbage collection disturb Your sleep once more. At 7, the alarm puts an end to your fitful night and, although you feel irritable and tired, you get up to start your day.

title: Blanton Grants Clemency To 52 Tennessee Convicts
description: NASHVILLE, Jan. 16  Gov. Ray Blanton, whose term ends on Saturday, granted clemency to 52 convicts today. including Roger Humphreys, the state's most publicized prisoner and the son of a Blanton political ally.

title: 25,000 Conrail Passengers Delayed by Fire in Bronx
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Jan. 16  A predawn explosion and fire at a Conrail power substation in the Bronx today left hundreds of passengers shivering on dark trains on the New Haven Divison, and upset the choreography of the morning rush hour. An estimated total of 25,000 commuters were delayed up to three and a half hours, or forced to use the Harlem Division or highways that were even more crowded than usual.

title: Sources of Noise Pollution
description: Following are some examples of noise levels of common sources of noise pollution, figured in decibels. (A decibel is a unit of relative power, usually figured relative to 0.0002 microbars pressure or dynes per square centimeter energy. The smallest change of sound intensity that the human ear can detect is approximately one decibel, no matter what the original intensity.)

title: U.S. Is Reported Ready to Indict Officials of Atlantic Coast Ports
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16  Federal prosecutors in New York City are preparing to seek a series of criminal indictments stemming from their threeyear inquiry into alleged corruption in Atlantic Coast ports, a number of sources familiar with the investigation said yesterday.

title: Coast Reporter Ordered To Give Notes to Judge
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 16 (UPI)  A California appellate court unanimously ruled today that a reporter must surrender to a judge in a murder trial unpublished notes and tape recordings from an interview with a prisoner.

title: A Hot Defense Of Hot Soup
description: Every eater has a special set of gastronomic obsessions. One of my most persistent has to do with hot soup, by which I really mean hot soup. Anything less than a curtain of steam mat ooscures an eating partner across the table is to me soup that borders on the tepid, a soup that must be hurried through before it is actually cold and therefore inedible.

title: Deaths
description: ALPERIsaac, the ?? Officers, Trustees and Members of Temple Beth El, Cedarhurst, NY and its affiliates express deepest sympathy or the passing of their member. We grieve with the family on their loss

title: New York State to Try New Negotiation Plan
description: ALBANY, Jan. 16  Governor Carey's administration and New York's largest publicemployees union agreed today to adopt an experimental bargaining method in which each side would negotiate to its last, best offer and an impartial arbitration panel would be forced to choose one proposal or the other.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: ADELBODEN, Switzerland, Jan. 16 (AP)  Ingemar Stenmark won his fourth straight giant slalom ski race today.

title: Melting Pot, CaliforniaStyle
description: BEVERLY HILLS. CALIF. FOR 10 years, Pietro and Margo Fallai argued about whether they should leave their native Sweden to live in California. Pietro, who had founded a successful chain of boutiques, favored the move because he said it would allow them to escape Sweden's dreary weather and crippling taxes. His wife, however, feared that they might be socially isolated in a strange city thousands of miles from home.

title: Wine Talk
description: A BOTTLE of good German wine is a triumph over adversity. The vineyards are so far north that the growers are never really certain that summer will come until it actually arrives. Moreover, the best vines are planted on slopes so steep that the workers say they have to be pert mountain goat to pick them.

title: Shah's Son Greets His Relatives In Tight Security in West Texas
description: LUBBOCK, Tex., Jan. 16  In the postmidnight darkness of west Texas, about two and a half hours before the Shah of Iran left his country for perhaps the last time, an Iranian airliner landed at Reese Air Force Base, which is iust outside Lubbock.

title: Cowboys Plan to Start Newhouse Sunday
description: MIAMI, Jan. 16  Robert Newhouse was promoted today, Randy White declared himself fit, Bennie Cunningham went on the disabled list, Lynn Swann twisted an ankle and the Miami Police Department announced it had a antiterrorist squad at the ready for Sunday's Super Bowl XIII.

title: Innis Reports CORE Is Going to Shut Down Its Elementary School
description: Roy Innis. executive director of the Congress of Racial Equality, said yesterday he was closing the 175pupil private elementary school operated by CORE in the South Bronx because a court order kept the organization from buying heating oil and paying teachers' salaries and telephone bills.

title: Farm Pledge by Strauss
description: MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 16 (AP) Robert S. Strauss, President Carter's special representative for trade negotiations, pledged today that farmers would not be shortchanged during the current international trade talks.

title: Neediest Cases Being Assisted By Late Efforts
description: It only takes a few moments to make a contribution to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, yet many donors to the 67nd annual appeal say they somehow managed to put it off for years at a time, despite the best of intentions.

title: Shearson Profit Up
description: Shearson Hayden Stone, a major brokerage and investment banking firm, reported yesterday a 139 percent increase in profits for its second fiscal quarter, ended Dec. 31, and a 328 percent earnings gain for the first half of its fiscal year. Earnings for the first half, moreover, were higher than for any full year in Shearson's history.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a transcription error, an article on the Style page yesterday. the genealogy of early American Jewish families, misspelled the name of one of family. The correct spelling is Sheftall

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Baldwin Parents Of Blacks Fight Closing a School
description: BALDWIN, L.I., Jan. 12  Black parents who are trying to keep open a small elementary school at which black pupils make up 30 percent of the student body, say they believe that the Shubert school is being closed because it has more black students than any other elementary school in the district.

title: ChryslerTaiwan Deal
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Jan. 16 (AP) The Chrysler Corporation will send a representative here Feb. 4 to sign an agreement with Taiwan for making mediumsize and heavyduty trucks, an official of a Taiwan truck maker said today. Tsao Shuchih, vice president of the Taiwan Machinery and Manufacturing Corporation's truck and bus division, said that Perkins Engine Ltd. of Britain, a partner in the $70 million TaiwanUnited StatesBritain joint venture, would also send an investigation team to Taiwan early next month for market research.

title: Goodrich Pleads No Contest on Taxes
description: The B.F. Goodrich Company said it had pleaded no contest to charges of films ing false income tax returns for 1972 and 1973. Similar charges for 1971 were dropped in Federal District Court in Cleveland. the tire manufacturer said.

title: Democratic Leaders in the Senate Back Liberals for Key Committees
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16  The Senate Democratic leadership moved today to shore up its control of key committees by recommending liberals for choice assignments.

title: South Africa's First '79 Hanging
description: JOHANNESBURG, Jan. 16 (AP) South Africa said today it had hanged Thomas Martganye, a black man convicted last June of housebreaking and robbery. in its first execution of the year.

title: Making a Million in New Jersey
description: What does David Probinsky know? And why is Resorts International making him a millionaire?

title: Pol Pot Forces Said to Retake Key Port
description: BANGKOK. Thailand, Jan. 16  In their first major setback of the war in Cambodia. Vietnamese forces Were driven out of the part city of Kompong Som yesterday after heavy fighting. Western analysis reported today.

title: News of the Theater
description: THE sequel, a staple of Hollywood in recent years, is coming to Broadway. The creators of the 1960 hit musical Bye Bye Birdie hope to raise the curtain in about a year on Bye Bye Birdie 2.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Leeks are finally coming back in the market. A year or so ago. I dined on a fantastic puree of leeks served as a vegetable and would like to know how to make it. Do you have a recipe?

title: Land Seekers Rush to California Gold Hills
description: COLONIA, Calif., Jan. 11  California's gold country is booming again, but this time people are flocking to the mother lode not for gold but for land.

description: For periods as shown, (N) Indicates stock is listed on the New York; Stock Exchange. (A) the American Exchange and (O) Over;the;counter.

title: U.S. Officials React Warily; Put Bakhtiar Odds at 5050
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16  The Carter Administration reacted cautiously today to the departure of Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi from Iran. There was no formal comment, but officials estimated privately that the Government of Prime Minister Shahpur Bakhtiar probably had no better than a 5050 chance of surviving.

title: West German Retailer Seeks 42% of A.&P. In a $75 Million Deal
description: A major West German food retailer announced plans yesterday to acquire 42 percent of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, the supermarket giant whose initials have long been a household term in American retailing.

title: Second Quake Strikes Northern Iran Province
description: TEHERAN. Iran, Jan. 16 (Reuters)  At least 129 persons were killed in the town of Qaen when a powerful earthquake struck Khurasan Province in northeast Iran today, officials said.

title: Cooking With Wines and Spirits
description: THERE may be many a connoisseur and savant in this world who knows his wines and spirits from aquavit and amontillado to zubrowka and zwicker and is not conversant with the notion that almost any spirited potable is at home as a basic conking ingredient. But experienced cooks know that beef bourguignonne is based on red wine, preferably a burgundy; that a sauce bordelaise has a foundation of red wine, preferably a bordeaux. A souffle Grand Marnier, of course, is perfumed with that elegant liqueur and a poulet au riesling is a saut of chicken aromatized with that delicate white wine.

title: New York City Gets Passing Grade On $100 Million Notes It Will Sell
description: The city prepared to go ahead this month with its proposed $100 million note sale after the notes received a passing, but not superior, grade yesterday. The note sale will be the city's first foray into the public borrowing market in nearly four years.

title: 60Minute Gourmet
description: ONE of the greatest boons to fine and hasty cookery in the past decade or so has been the widespread appearance in supermarkets of skinless, boneless chicken breasts. They have a multitude of uses in meals to be prepared in less than an hour. In many cases, much less. They can be breaded and sauteed in butter. They can be cooked quickly under a broiler or on a hot grill. Poached briefly, they can be used in many other dishes.

title: Steel Haulers Vow to Defy Order By Judge to End 9Week Walkout
description: PITTSBURGH. Jan. 16 (UPI)  About 300 independent steel haulers vowed today to continue their strike as individuals despite a Federal court order calling for an end to the walkout.

title: Lawyer Panel Urges Public Control of Legal Ethics
description: BOSTON. Jan. 16  A trial lawyers' study group urged today that the enforcement of legal codes of ethics be taken away from state bar associations and turned over to agencies representing the general public.

title: 32 Die in Venezuela Bus Crash
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 16 (Reuters)  Thirtytwo people were killed and about 20 were injured today when a bus collided with a truck between the towns of Urachiche and Sabana de Parra west of here, the fire department said

title: Excerpts From Panel Statement
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16  Following are excerpts from the press release, issued on Friday by the National Advisory Committee for Women that led in part to President Carter's ouster of Bella S. Abzug as cochairman and to the ensuing controversy.

title: Years of Autocratic Rule by the Shah Threw Iran Into Turbulence
description: At a sumptuous New Year's Eve party in Teheran a little more than a year ago. President Carter praised Iran as an island of stability. Raising his glass, the President wished Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi a happy New Year and told him that such stability was a great tribute to the respect, admiration and love of your people for you.

title: Lebanon Worried About Departure of Some UN Troops
description: BEIRUT, Jan. 16  Lebanese officials and others are worried that a dangerous vacuum is being created in southern Lebanon as some United Nations peacekeeping troops have begun pulling out with the expiration of their mandate this week.

title: Student Appeals in Spying Case; Holds U.S. Wiretap Was Illegal
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16  Lawyers for a Vietnamese student convicted of espionage argued today that a telephone wiretap and hidden microphone authorized by Attorney General Griffin B. Bell in the investigation of the case were illegal and that the conviction should therefore be reversed.

title: Kitchen Equipment Plastic Cutting Boards
description: EMBEDDED in a counter in my kitchen, there is a massive wooden chopping board. I use it as counter space, a handy spot for placing serving dishes and utensils, and for the rough work of boning a chicken or tying a roast. Sometimes I like to just lean on it. But I almost never chop on it. For that I use a much smaller board made of white plastic. The development of polyethylene chopping boards has very nearly made the familiar wooden ones obsolete.

title: Two Young Brothers Die in Fire
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 16 (AP)  Two young brothers, waiting for their mother to return for their joint birthday party, died yesterday as fire swept through their row house in northeast Philadelphia, the police said. Dwayne Harlan, who would have been 6 on Thursday, and his brother, Jerome, who was 2 last Friday, died of smoke inhalation and burns, officials said.

title: Best Buys
description: SHOPPERS searching for an answer to currently high lettuce prices had best look to the sky, suggests a top vegetable specialist for the United States Department of Agriculture.

title: Bridge:
description: For many years, the most original and significant contributions to bidding theory on this side of the Atlantic have been made by Dr. George Rosenkranz of Mexico City. But unfortunately for those who like their bidding to be polished until it shines, his ideas have appeared only in his books on his Romex System, somewhat too sophisticated for the average palate, and in magazines.

title: The Editorial Notebook
description: From this day, we intend to take the offensive and carry our fight for freedom across the nation, wielding the balance of power we know we possess in the Southland. We, not the insipid block voters of some sections, will determine in the next election who shall sit in the White House of the United States.

title: In Pakistan, a Looming Crisis
description: While the yearlong agitation in Iran has preoccupied our attention, another crisis, in neighboring Pakistan, has been gathering. Its causes are largely internal, yet it has been affected by the establishment of a radical Government in Afghanistan and, especially, by events in Iran.

title: Some Noises The Law Forbids
description: Over the last seven years, the City Council has enacted a series of ordinances to regulate the loudness of many everyday noise makers. These ordinances give the police and the Environmental Control Board the power to issue summonses that carry fines ranging from S25 to $1.000.

title: The Chemistry of It All
description: The chemistry of each recipe is different, but, as a general rule, the chief role played by any wines or spirits that may be included is acted by the acids present in the liquid. These substances. typi- cally tartaric acid and malic acid, tend to neutralize alkaline substances that in fish, for example, contribute to the fishy smell or flavor.

title: Obituary 9 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: Sara Boal, Artist and Teacher, 83
description: Sara Metzner Boal a painter and instrictor, died yesterday at Mount Vernon (N.Y.) Hospital. She was 83 years old and lived in Pelham, N.Y.

title: TV Cited on Stereotypes
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16  The United States Civil Rights Commission said today that minorities and women continued to be cast on television as hackneyed stereotypes and that they were underemployed in the television business.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: A Bell System bond issue, the first major test of the corporate bond market in 1979, was offered to investors yesterday at a yield of 9.37 percent, and it sold slowly even though the rate was the highest since October 1975.

title: PetroCanada Plans Offer
description: CALGARY, Alberta, Jan. 16 (AP) PetroCanada said today it planned to offer $65.02 (Canadian) a share for all the common stock of Pacific Petrole- ums Ltd. that it does not already own. Petro-Canada, Canada's national oil company, has 11,479,519 shares, slightly more than 50 percent of the total outstanding. The cost of all the remaining shares would be about $1.3 billion. The offer is subject to approval by the directors of Pacific, formerly controlled by the Phillips Petroleum Company

title: $16 Million to Finish 4 Schools in Brooklyn Voted by City Council
description: The New York City Corner approved yesterday an appropriation of about $16 million to complete four Brooklyn schools on which work was halted three years ago at the height of the city's fiscal crisis.

title: Knicks, Down by 18 Points, Beat Pistons on Knight's Steal, 111110
description: Bob McAdoo doesn't often show his emotions but last night it was different after Toby Knight's slamdunk basket with two seconds to play gave the Knicks a 111110 comeback victory over the Detroit Pistons at Madison Square Garden. The Knicks had trailed by 18 points early in the third period, and the only time they led all night was after the winning basket.

title: A Day That Is Neither Day Nor Night
description: YOU know why God gave us breasts? This mother of mothers was grinning through the telephone. A garden for His cancer. That's why. She kneaded every night. There it rose, that familiar loaf. She was a hostess again as in her best and busiest days, serving herself up. When she was young and pretty, she was a dish. Now she was the main course.

title: Culture Ices Union Cake
description: Twenty years ago, Local 1199 began organizing some of the city's lowerpaid workers  hospital employees. Today, as the 70,000member District 1199 of the National Union of Hospital and Health Care Employes, the union is observing the anniversary of its campaign with a $1.3 million series of cultural programs.

title: Billy Knight Goes Back to Pacers
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 16 The Indiana Pacers reacquired Billy Knight today and sent Rick Robey, a rookie forward, to the Boston Celtics in exchange.

title: Honda to Shift Output to Ohio
description: TOKYO, Jan. 16 (UPI)  Honda Motors is preparing to relocate all of its production lines for large motorcycles to its Columbus, Ohio, factory, it was announced today. The move is de- signed to help offset the United States dollar's slide in value in relation to the yen, a company official said.

title: State Reports $400 Million Rise In Tourism Since New Promotion
description: ALBANY, Jan. 16 (AP)  The State Commerce Department today reported that spending on travel in tourism in New York State had increased by $400 million in the 19 months since the beginning of its I Love New York advertising and promotion campaign.

title: Bail Set Again for Sid Vicious
description: Justice James J. Leff of State Supreme Court in Manhattan set bail yesterday of $60,000 for Sid Vicious, the punkrock musician whose real name is John Ritchie Until last Dec. 7, Mr. Ritchie had been free on $50,000 bail on the charge of murdering his girlfriend, Nancy Spungen. On that date his bail was revoked by Justice Betty Ellerin because Mr. Ritchie had been newly arrested for allegedly as saulting a nightclub patron with a beer bottle.

title: World News Briefs
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Wednesday, Jan. 17 (Reuters)  Six Moslem hijackers seized a Lebanese airliner, held it overnight with hostages, then surrendered here early today and were arrested by Lebanese security forces. In giving up, they released 73 passengers and nine crew members.

title: Founder of Synanon Is Booked On Coast in Attempted Murder
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 16 (UPI)  The founder of Synanon, Charles Dederich, who gave up his fight against extradition from Arizona, was booked today at police headquarters on charges of attempted murder.

title: The Shah Departs, Finally
description: What many in the West, including some of President Carter's advisers, long regarded as unthinkable has come to pass. The Shah of Iran has left his troubled country, not to save his skin but to give a weak new civilian Government a chance. Although diplomatically described as a vacation, and although he and many of his military officers hope it will be temporary, the Shah's trip is clearly a journey into exile.

title: New York Was First In U.S. Aid to States
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16  New York once again ranked first in the total amount of Federal aid distributed to the states in the year that ended Last Sept. 30, according to preliminary figures made available today by the Treasury Department.

title: Periled City Hospitals
description: I am a doctor. Today I will be on strike. marching on picket lines instead of listening to hearts. I am a resident in a city hospital but there is no conflict for me, for Mayor Koch and his top health adviser, Dr. Martin Cherkasky, propose to close down or give away half of the city hospitals in the next three years. I can't go on as usual today when tomorrow the means to treat and to care for my patients will be ripped from my hands.

title: Battle Intensifies Over Authority Of President to Control Agencies
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16  President Carter's fight to control inflation is intensifying a constitutional conflict between his authority to develop national policies and Congress's power to mandate the independence of Government regulators.

title: Study Says Smoking Perils Baby Even If Halted Before Pregnancy
description: HILTON HEAD ISLAND, S.C., Jan. 16 (AP)  New evidence indicates that the negative effects of smoking continue even if women quit before pregnancy, according to a major new study.

title: Fast Swiss Sale of U.S. Notes Seen
description: GENEVA, Jan. 16  The terms announced today for $1.2 billion worth of United States Treasury notes being offered this week assure that the issue will be oversubscribed, according to Swiss bankers.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: Browsing through the vintage finery at the Antique Freaque is like going through an old photograph album. The lacy blouses our greataunts used to wear, a black taffeta coat some woman might have put on for a Nelly Melba concert, even those satin and lace mobcaps women wore to bed to protect their marcel waves. Maurie Welsh, who owns the shop, became fascinated With the workmanship and fabrics of bygone clothes when she inherited her grandmother's flapper wardrobe 10 years ago, began collecting until her closets overflowed and then decided to go into business. The racks hold any number of cobwebby blouses and jackets and fascinating dresses (some of them have appeared in Virginia Slims ads), many Victorian, others from the first half of this century. The lingerie collection, for instance, has some underwear made of silk tricot, a fabric that virtually disappeared with the advent of nylon. Speaking of nylon, check out Miss Welsh's most recent find: several dozen pairs of early nylons (circa 1940), all brand new. The stockings have seams, of course, but more than that. They are decorated with a coy rhinestone flower or two at the back; or campler yet, are painted with pink poodles ($8.50 to $12 a pair). Everything in the shop is cleaned and in good condition. Antique Freaque is in the Antiques Center of America, 415 East 53d Street. Hours are 1 to 4 P.M. on Tuesdays, 1 to 5:30 P.M. on Thursdays, Saturdays and Sundays.

title: American Express Card for SOS, Too
description: As a result of an agreement signed yesterday. American Express charge cards may now be used by members of International SOS Assistance Inc. for medical, dental and optical services as well as annual membership fees.

title: Police Demonstrate Ice Rescue the Hard Way
description: Seven times yesterday Tom Power fell through the ice and into the lake at the botanical garden in the Bronx. Six times Jim Mottle crawled on his stomach on to the ice and rescued him. The seventh time Tom Power pulled Jim Mottle into the water.

title: Music: Legrand Sings Legrand
description: MICHEL LEGRAND, the French composer, pianist and singer, whose musical, The Umbrellas of Cherbourg, based on the 1964 film, is giving previews in the Theater Cabaret of the Public Theater, took to the stage there himself on Monday evening to present a program of his works that was both retrospective and prospective. The concert, given twice during the evening, was a benefit for the Public Theater Building Fund.

title: WQXR Marathon To Aid Philharmonic
description: The Second Annual New York Philharmonic/WQXR Phone Festival  a 55hour radio marathon that seeks to raise $300,000 for the Philharmonic will be broadcast on WOXRAM and FM from 7 P.M. on Feb. 1 to 8 P.M. on Feb. 3. The program will consist of music and interviews, in addition to the solicitations.

title: Seton Hall Subdues Manhattan By 8979, With Galis Hitting 38
description: Only the roof of its new center appears not to have caved in on Manhattan's basketball program this season. The Jaspers suffered their 11th defeat, and their 10th straight, in 13 games last night, bowing to Seton Hall, 8979.

description: WALTER BLESSEY keeps a hard white hat in his care so he will be ready almost instantly to practice his civil engineering profession.

title: The Iran the Shah Is Leaving Behind Has Changed Radically Since '53 Exile
description: The fervor is the same today as It was a quarter of a century ago, when Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi flew out of his country with his dynasty apparently in ruins behind him.

title: Regional Labor Group Defers Trade Boycott Of 3 Latin Countries
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16  Hemisphere trade union organizations, including the A.F.L.C.I.O., decided today to put off setting a date for a planned trade boycott of Chile, Nicaragua and Cuba.

title: A Horse by Any Other Name
description: Steve Cady had an interesting piece in the paper the other day about the naming of race horses, which is sometimes more frustrating than betting on them. Back in the early 1940's an oil zillionaire named William Helis struck the racing establishment dizzy by paying the undreamt of figure of $66,000 for a yearling son of Blenheim II from a mare named Risk. The Jockey Club registry, which has nonnegotiable authority over the naming of thoroughbreds, rejected so many proposed names for the animal that Helis vowed he would register him as Unnamed Colt. If he actually applied for that name it was rejected, too, probably on the ground that if the steed raced as a 5yearold he would have to be rechristened Unnamed Horse. As a last resort, the GreekAmerican owner dipped

title: The City
description: Prison sentences were imposed on two men who pleaded guilty in Manhattan to Federal charges involving the transportation of two teenage girls from Minneapolis to New York to work as prostitutes.

description: If camaraderie and reliving angling and hunting experiences appeal to you, consider joining one of the hundreds of fish and game clubs in New York State as an antidote for the winter doldrums.

title: Narco to Study Offer

Narco said it was studying the offer, which was made on Monday by Daylin, and had retained Kidder Peabody & Company as its financial adviser.

title: Greenlanders Expected to Adopt Home Rule Today
description: GODTHAAB, Greenland, Jan. 16 With the last ballots dispatched to remote settlements by dog sled and helicopter, Greenland's 50,000 inhabitants are preparing to vote tomorrow on a plan for home rule that will remove control of most of their daily affairs from the Danish Parliament.

title: Shah Lands in Upper Egypt, Looking Gaunt and Weary
description: ASWAN, Egyt, Jan 16  The Shah of Iran, looking gaunt and weary, arrived here today aboard his private Jet and was escorted by President Anwar elSadat to the seclusion of a hotel on an island in the Nile.

title: Shah's Departure Hailed In Message by Ayatollah
description: NEAUPHLE-LE-CHATEAU, France,Jan. 16  Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the leading religious opponent of the Shah of Iran, sent congratulations to the Iranian people today on having forcing the Shah to leave the country and called his departure the first step toward ending the 57near reign of the Pahlevi dynasty.

title: Iranian Envoy to U.S. Resists a Revolt in His Embassy
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16  Declaring himself Ambassador of the Shah, Ardeshir Zahedi, Iran's envoy to the United States, stood his ground today as the turmoil that has paralyzed his country finally reached into his embassy.

title: Deaths
description: ??ANDRose Minskoff cultural CenterPark East Day School Notes with sorrow the death of Pose Kourtand, mother of Lcrraine and motheritslaw of Sidney Cooperman, and brother of Lewis Russek, founders of our cultural center. Sincerest condolences to the entire family.

title: Something New in Capital Receptions
description: WASHINGTON. Jan. 16 Swearingin time for freshmen senators and representatives is traditionally a day of parties and receptions attended by supporters and campaign workers congratulating themselves and their winners on the sweetness of having arrived. But even the House Speaker, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., who said that he had seen it all, reported that he had seen something new at the reception for William H. Gray 3d, the freshman Democratic Representative from Pennsylvania.

title: Mars Polar Caps Found to Differ
description: PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 16  American spacecraft orbiting Mars have discovered a surprising difference between the planet's north and south polar caps. The north polar region's permanent covering is water ice, but at the south pole it is frozen carbon dioxide.

title: Music: Slowing Brahms
description: IT was Brahms time at Carnegie Hall last night, with Eugene Ormandy leading the Philadelphia Orchestra in the Tragic Over- ture and the Third Symphony, followed by the D minor Piano Concerto with Claudio Arrau. These are works that conductor and orchestra have performed many, many times, and the purely orchestral section of the program contained no surprises. After conductor has been with an orchestra for 43 years, as Mr. Ormandy has with the Philadelphia, the only surprise would be if there were surprises.

For most of the theatrical and dance celebrities who helped pack Carnegie Hall Monday night to watch three generations of Dunham dancers and musicians, the occasion was one of nostalgia. Yet the presence of so many young people was also testimony to the place Katherine Dunham's name holds in the history of American theater and dance.

description: WICHITA FALLS, Tex.  When I first began to photograph grain elevators in 1972, they were little more to me than libraries of forms, textures and modulations of light that I could make into pictures. In the area of Minneapolis where I lived there were many grain elevators; there was in fact a whole city within the city, built for grain instead of people.

title: Film: A 'Planet' Doomed
description: WELL, our goose is cooked. According to the Bible, all manner of pestilence and destruction are due to come our way. And according to Orson Welles, who narrates most of "The Late Great Planet Earth," Armageddon may just possibly be right around the corner. As Mr. Welles explains it, with a wordiness meant to give us all a good scare, man is besieged by "perils that threaten to send him into the dark abyss of silence known as extinction."What are these perils? You name it, and it's howling right outside the door. Atomic holocausts. Earthquakes. Floods. Famine. Killer bees. According to the film, the Bible cites every one of these things as part of the beginning of the end. You have to read between the lines, perhaps, but the movie is willing and eager to help you out on that score.So the list of prophesied ills is expanded to include environmental pollution, a military crisis in the Middle East, transcendental meditation and the Rev. Sun Myung Moon. A number of scientists, many of them quite distinguished, are interviewed. They all agree that our prospects aren't good.The efficacy of the film's scare tactics is minimized by its applying biblical predictions too generally, and almost cavalierly at times  the most memorable sequence shows a computer conducting a numerological analysis of various politicians' names, to figure out if Jimmy Carter, Ronald Reagan or Ted Kennedy is the Antichrist. And Hal Lindsey, who co-wrote the book upon which the film is based and who appears with Mr. Welles as a co-narrator, speaks coolly, almost enthusiastically, about the prospect of worldwide destruction.Robert Amram, the director, begins the film with some brief dramatizations of biblical prophets, wearing cotton-candy beards and too much gray makeup as they purvey the bad news. The rest of the time, Mr. Amram uses stock footage of tanks, mushroom clouds, missiles being launched, troops marching, and Hollywood extras armed for battle in ancient Rome. His illustrations are no more convincing nor frightening than his grim but sketchy hypothesis."The Late Great Planet Earth," which is rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), contains moderately gruesome newsreel shots of war being waged, and one brief scene featuring the Whore of Babylon.

title: More WagePrice Staff Sought .
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17  Alfred E. Kahn, chairman of the Council on Wage and Price Stability, said today that he needed 90 more people to handle a work load that has exceeded expectations. Most of the work is handling a flood of inquiries about the Administration's wageprice guidelines.

title: The Region

Sandman Jr. was found guilty yesterday of slandering a Cape May police officer whom he accused of police brutality, and the jury awarded $25,000 compensatory damages and $50,000 punitive damages to Robert Marchiano, the officer. title: Market Place

A typical investor would not consider all these bonds for purchase, because those offering the highest yields may be too risky. But at least a dozen of the bonds yielding as much as 12 percent are considered suitable for individuals seeking a high return at a relatively low risk.

title: Scotto, Head of Longshore Local, Indicted on Racketeering Charges
description: Anthony M. Scotto, a politically powerful leader of the International Longshoremen's Association, was indicted in Manhattan yesterday on Federal racketeering charges. He was accused of receiving more than $300,000 in illegal payoffs from several employers of his union's members.

The method he has chosen to carry out the promise is to have citizens commis- sions instead of senators recommend judicial appointments. title: Notes on People; Doonesbury Cartoonist's U.N. Stamp Proves Popular

That may be because the covers and prints are by Garry Trudeau, the Pulitzer Prizewinning creator of the comic strip Doonesbury, who will be on hand to autograph copies of the limited edition of 1,000 items bearing his design. The cartoonist has never before designed a stamp issue cachet, and he agreed to execute this one because it's apolitical and he used to be a stamp collector. The spokesman for the world federation, whose educational programs will benefit from the sales, said the demand is comparable to those for past designs contributed by artists like Marc Chagall, Alexander Calder, Salvador Dali, and Norman Rockwell. The federation's next issue cachet will be by Andy Warhol.

French foreign trade had been in deficit in the two previous years by $2.78 billion in 1977 and $4.56 billion in 1976.

title: How Wax Can Spoil A Candelit Evening

But that table top becomes vulnerable in the relaxed atmosphere of candlelight, for no matter how careful the guests, there can be candle wax blobs, wine drops and food spills. If these are left until the next day's light, it can mean the difference between using a home remedy and seeking protessional help.

title: Lance Told Bank to Cut Loan Rate For Carter Concern, Audit Reports

The rates involved loans or lines of credit totaling nearly $4 million that were granted before the President took office.

Bosworth, director of the Council on Wage and Price Stability, defended the Carter Administration's plan for real wage insurance in a speech to bluechip businessmen in New York yesterday. Afterward he denied that the council had overstepped its legal mandate by requesting broader wageprice information from industry.

title: Film: Georges Franju's 'Shadowman':Horror Buffs' Delight
description: GEORGES FRANJU's "Shadowman" certainly gets off to a brisk start. Rich man to servant: "Reading my mail?" Servant to employer: "Oh, I couldn't help it! This terrible business of the man who steals brains, sir!" As if that weren't bad enough, the brain thief is busy turning the brains' former owners into raccoon-eyed zombies who will follow his every command. And the mad doctor is in cahoots with Shadowman, who has the mind of an archdemon and the funny-looking hooded jumpsuit of a cartoon character.Mr. Franju, best known for the 1960 "Eyes Without a Face" (also known as "The Horror Chamber of Doctor Faustus"), is not kindly represented by "Shadowman"  the dubbing from French into English calls constant attention to itself, and the color photography is often flat and grainy.But "Shadowman" has its quirky merits just the same, even if they're likely to be best appreciated by horror buffs or admirers of Mr. Franju's earlier work. There's a winning lightheartedness in the conception of Shadowman, a creature of vile tactics and many disguises who battles good guys even loonier than he is.The film moves quickly and episodically, with a lot of energy but not much logic, sandwiching effectively Spooky sequences with bland, time-wasting ones. One elaborate, prettily choreographed interlude features Gayle Hunnicutt, as Shadowman's glamorous but subverbal partner in crime, creeping across rooftops, cat-burglar style. Another memorable moment shows Shadowman's troops marching down a hallway en masse, wearing shabby Army overcoats and identical, expressionless face-masks. Their combined blankness and single-mindness are terrifying, even though not much else in "Shadowman" exhibits this degree of wit, or provides this much of a scare."Shadowman," which is rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), contains several violent murder scenes.

title: Con Ed Told to Return $16.8 Million in Fees

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP)  The United States has reached agreements with Taiwan and South Korea to limit the number of color television sets those countries may export to America, the United States special trade negotiator, Robert S. Strauss, disclosed today.

title: SAMUEL WOLCII0K, EXUNIONIST, 82, DIES
description: Samuel Wolchok, an early leader of the Congress of Industrial Organizations and president of its Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union from 1937 to 1948, died Tuesday on a visit to Miami Beach. He was 82 years old.

title: TV: Preview of ABC's Imitation of Animal House
description: ONE of the biggest boxoffice hits of last year was Animal House, a National Lampoon movie about offbeat charac ters in a College fraternity. The wacky comedy, which missed as frequently as it scored, was especially popular with younger audiences. Enter television, always greedy for young, younger and youngest audiences.

title: Clippers Talk to Walton; Star's Concern Is Health
description: SAN DIEGO, Jan. 17 (UPI)  After meeting with Bill Walam yesterday, Iry Levin, the owner of the San Diego flippers, said today the only concern of the 6-foot-11-inch forrner Portland Trail Blazer center was the recovery from his foot injury.

title: Mets, Heaton Break Off Talks
description: The representative for Neal Heaton, the first player chosen in the freeagent draft last week, said yesterday that negotiations had broken off because the offer by the team that chose him, the New York Mets, was substantially inadequate. Joe McDonald, the Mets general manager, sponded that the club's offer, worth $50,500, was final, but that the talks had not ended. We haven't withdrawn it, McDonald said. We would be glad to meet with the player and his group.'

title: News Summary

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Yesterday's Weather at 1 P.M. National Ocianic and Atmospheric Administration /UPI An expanding area of stratified clouds can be seen from the Great Lakes to New England. A band of heavy snow is advancing across Pennsylvania. Another extensive area of cloud cover is located from Mexico to Missouri. The plume effect is being caused by a strong }et stream from Arizona to Kansas. Scattered to broken clouds are over the Rockies.

description: TELEPHONES and accessories exhibited earlier this month at the Winter Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas are eons ahead of the conventional home phone that can do nothing more than ring while you're in the shower. New

title: 3 Seized dn Flame Attack On 2 Clerks in IND Booth
description: Three Queens teenagers, including an 13yearold girl, were in custody yesterday, charged with what the police said Was a revengeinspired flame attack on a subwaytoken booth in Queens that left two Transit Authority clerks critically injured Tuesday night.

title: Carter Says U.S. Wat mid Vietnam And Soviet Not to Threaten Thais
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17  President Carter said today that the United States had warned both Vietnam and the Soviet Union not to let the fighting in Cambodia endanger the security of neighboring Thailand.
