title: Recital: Anna Moffo
description: FOR several years now the big question about Anna Moffo has been: Will she be able to get her voice back into satisfactory singing condition? Satisfactory, in this case, would mean that it would move fluently, would be even in all ranges, could sustain tones without spreading or flatting and prove amenable to expressive coloration. Miss Molfo's voice began faltering seriously in most of these areas early in this decade, which pretty much ended her career as coloratura soprano. The period of vocal retraining has been going on for a long time, but her singing at Carnegie Hall last night suggested that there is still much work to be done.

title: The City; 2 Held in Shooting Of Officer in Bronx
description: Two brothers suspected of shooting transit policeman during a Bronx holdup have been arrested in Virginia, the police announced yesterday. Herbert Austin, 25 years old, was arrested in a motel room in Newport News as he talked by phone to authorities in New York. His 21-year-old brother, William, had already been jailed in Norfolk.

title: Deaths
description: PERKINSHaney W. H Company. The Veterans of the 7Th Regiment announce with deep regret the passing of their esteemed comrade. CHARLES E. HANGLEY, PreSIderrt

title: McGraw Rift: Focus On Role of a Director
description: Just what did Roger H. Morley, president of American Express, learn while serving as a director and a member of the audit committee of McGraw-

title: Space Scientists, at Seminar, Urge New Unmanned Missions to Mars
description: PASADENA, Calif. Jan. 17  The scientists who specialize in studying planets sat around and talked about what they would like to do next, if there was money, to learn more about Mars.

title: Morris Hadley, Began Law Firm
description: Morris Hadley, a retired lawyer, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 84 years old.

title: PetroCanada Backed on Bid
description: CALGARY, Alberta, Jan. 17  The board of directors of Pacific petrol,. urns Ltd. of Calgary unanimously recommended today the acceptance ofan offer for the outstanding shares of the company made by PetroCanada. the Governmentowned oil corporation

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Celtics Trade Awtrey
description: BOSTON, Jan. 17 (AP)  The Boston Celtics traded Dennis Awtrey, a backup center, to the Seattle SuperSontcs today for a No. 1 college draft choice this year. Awtrey was acquired by Boston early in the season, but had an injured ankle and saw limited action.

title: Hers
description: I'M worried about indiscretion. Betraying confidences, violating privacy, airing inner linings  other people's, that is. You could say I have a nerve worrying about indiscretion, since I recently wrote an indiscreet autobiography. Yet much more than it exposed my fellow travelers, it exposed me  which could be charitably construed as honesty rather than indiscretion. Though maybe not  I'm reminded of myfriend Phyllis's remark that ever she met Francine Gray's husband, she couldn't help but visualize him from rather an exotic angle. In any case, it's precisely my own uneasy relation to indiscretion that impels me to write about it.

title: Most of Salvador Hostages Freed
description: SAN SALVADOR. Jan. 17 (AP)  One of two groups of antigovernment peasants that had seized two buildings here yesterday, demanding the release of political prisoners, freed their remaining four hostages today and ended the occupation of the Organization of American States Building, according to the authorities here.

title: Test Well Finds Gas Off Jersey
description: A test well being drilled in the Baltimore Canyon merely to gather geophysical data has turned up traces of natural gas, the United States Geological Survey announced yesterday. The testing also indicated that gas condensate or oil may be present as well, the agency said.

title: Around the Nation; Placard From Boeing 727 May Be Clue in Hijacking
description: KELSO, Wash., Jan. 17 (AP) heavy plastic placard from a Boeing 727, found by a hunter in a wooded area, may be linked to the unsolved hijacking of an airliner in 1971 by a man identified as D. B. Cooper, the authorities said today.

title: Retailer Agrees to F.T.C. Pact
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17  The Federal Trade Commission released today a two-year-old consent agreement under which Federated Department Stores Inc., owner of Bloomingdale's and other department stores, agreed not to pursue certain practices inyolving shopping centers.

title: Cambodia Refugees Dream Of Going Home Once More
description: ARANYAPRATH ET, Thailand, Jan. 16  They know it will not be anytime soon, and they fear that it may never be. But for some of the 15,000 Cambodians living stagnant lives in Thai refugee camps, the collapse of the Pol Pot regime has stirred fresh hopes of some day returning to their homeland.

title: Bechtel Reports On 78 Activity
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 17  Increasingly sensitive to accusations of secretiveness, the privately held Bechtel group of companies  the Bechtel Corporation. Bechtel Power and Bech- tel Inc.  took a new step in implementing a policy of disclosure today when it issued for the first time something approaching an annual report.

title: E.P.A. to Permit Sale of Gasahol As UnleadedGasoline Substitute
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (UPI)  The Environmental Protection Agency will permit the sale of gasahol as a subsitute for unleaded gasoline. Representative Alvin Baldus, Democrat of Wisconsin, said today.

title: More Cancer Found in John Wayne
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 17 (AP)  More cancer has been found in actor John Wayne, whose cancerous stomach was removed last week, his doctors said today. They said there was a probability that it will spread.

title: Physicians Stage Hospital Strike; Impact Is Slight
description: PHYSICIANS STRIKE NINE CITY HOSPITALS: Interns and residents stag- ing a oneday strike yesterday at the Metropolitan Hospital Center at Second Avenue and 96,11 Street to protect pronosed cutbacks and closings. Page 83.

title: Chase Lifts Earnings 62% And. Raises Its Dividend
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation. parent of the Chase Manhattan Bank, reported yesterday that operating earnings had surged 62 percent in the final quarter of 1978. Chase also surprised Wall Street by raising its dividend for the first time in five years.

title: Merger Set For Cross, Kearney
description: Shareholders of the Cross Company and the Kearney & Trecker Corporation voted overwhelmingly yesterday to approve the merger of the two companies, creating the thirdlargest machine tool company in the United States.

title: Blocking Rules Amended
description: The Football Rules Committee of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, hoping to cut down on leg and knee injuries, yesterday outlawed blocking below the waist on three exchange-of-ball plays an intercepted pass or lateral and a recovered fumble.

title: Letters; Westway: What New York Can and Can't Afford
description: To the Editor:

title: Music: The Philharmonic
description: ONE look and you could tell that the stage was set for something pretty special last night at Avery Fisher Hall. Cameras as big as antiaircraft guns were emplaced on stage, right and left, and another weapon peered down from the first tier. Were we in for The Gong Show, maybe, or Name That Tune'? No. As it turned out, the event was New York Philharmonic subscription concert, or something that passed for one, conducted by Zubin Mehta and with I tzhak Perlman as violin soloist. It was the first in a series of programs being televised under the Live From Lincoln Center standard, and a dismaying affair it managed to be.

title: Advertising
description: WHEN you're watching the debut of Pan American World Airlines $20 million campaign during the telecast of the Super Bowl game Sunday, you'll find it easy to identify the specific messages the carrier wants to get across about its new image and new services.

title: SOLDIERS RUN WILD IN IRANIAN OIL CITY
description: Outbreak Comes on Day of General Social and Political Inertia

title: Radio
description: Music

title: 2 Views of Scotto: Progressive Union Leader or Hoodlum
description: To iris admirers, he is a dedicated, progressive articulate leader of the longshoremen's union, an up-from-the-docks scrapper with street savvy, two years of college education and a social con- science, who has cultivated powerful politicians and incurred slanderous enemies to advance the welfare of his union members, the viability of the Brooklyn waterfront and causes ranging from civil rightsto cultural philanthropy.

title: Jobs Plan Said to Be Cut Slightly
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17  President Carter has made relatively small cuts In his proposed budget for Federal jobs programs in the fiscal year 1980, Administration sources disclosed today.

title: QUA
description: Q. Moisture forms in cold weather on all the aluminum window frames in my house, but more so on the kitchen, bath and utility room windows. This causes dripping and puddles on the window sills, and mildew forms on the plaster adjacent to the windows. Several years ago we had storm windows installed, hoping to stop this. It stopped the glass from sweating, but didn't stop the condensation on the frames. I use an exhaust fan when cooking. Can you suggest anything else?  R. L.D., Port Orchard, Wash.

title: COMPANY NEWS; Bates's Sale Terms Of Coal Unit Revised
description: The Bates Manufacturing Company announced yesterday that a revised agreement had been negotiated for the sale of a major pan of its coal operation& to the American Natural Resources Company and had been approved by the board of directors of each company.

title: WASHINGTON, Jan. 17  Imagine yourself sailing along in a satellite a few thousand miles above the earth's North Pole. Look down past the Arctic ice: What is that snowy territory that separates the land mass of the Soviet Union from the halfcontinent that is the United States
description: ESSAY Manifest Destiny

title: U.S., Norway In Trade Pact
description: GENEVA.  the United States and Norway announced today that they had reached a comprehensive understanding at the world trade talks here on all questions concerning their trade with each other of both industrial and agricultural products.

title: Mrs. Van Slyke's Novels Bring 7Figure Advance
description: Lovely young Susan Langdon thought she knew what she was doing when she married worldfamous concert pianist Richard Antonini. She knew about the many women who this superbly handsome, incredibly gifted musical genius numbered among his conquests. She knew about his cele- brated close-knil family, his ravenously possessive mother, his jetpaced world of dazzling glamour and glittering sophistication, his passionate dedication to his career. But she also knew  or thought she knew  Richard, her Richard, the Richard she adored and gave up her career for.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Satellite Photograph

title: Guide to the Region's Lit'rary Landmarks
description: AM curiously affected by emanations from the surroundings, the essayist E. B. White wrote in his midManhattan hotel room one day 30 years ago. I am five blocks from the office where Er-

title: George H. Blohm, 56, President Of Emerald Marine Corporation
description: George H. Blohm, president of the Emerald Marine Corporation, a subsidiiary of the New England Petroleum Corporation, died Wednesday at Roosevelt Hospital in Manhattan, following a brief illness

title: Theater: Madman And Nun
description: THE Madman and the Nun, written in 1923 by the Polish playwright Stanislaw Ignacy Witkiewicz, is ferocious and zany. It is Dadaist in its style and denunciatory in its intent.

title: The Region
description: WHITE PLAINS  A Westchester County grand jury has exonerated a white Pelham police officer who shot and disabled an I8-year-old black Mount Vernon youth who the officer thought was a suspect in an armed robbery.

title: Around the Nation
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Jan. 18 (UPI)  Former Attorney General John N. Mitchell, the last of 25 persons to complete their jail terms for crimes in the Watergate scandal, will be freed from prison tomorrow, nearly seven years after the burglary that led to the resignation of President Nixon.

title: Death by Cancer Reported Lower In Factory Areas
description: TRENTON, Jan. 18  An unpublished study shows that there has been a per- ceptible drop in the death rate from can- cer in industrial urban counties from Connecticut through New York, New Jer- sey and into Pennsylvania and Delaware, a Rutgers University researcher said today.

title: Guggenheim Invokes Spirit Of Mondrian
description: EIGHT years have passed since the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum mounted a major exhibition of the work of Piet Mondrian on the centenary of the artist's birth. Mondrian remains one of the tutelary gods of contemporary pamting  an artist who brought to perfection a mode of pictorial discourse that others have continued to develop with considerable enterprise and imagination Thus, in any exhibition of Mondrian's work, regardless of its scale. We are at once in the presence of a great modernist master and in a realm of art that continues to nourish artists today.

title: Stage: Gorky's Summerfolk
description: NEW HAVEN ENTERING the world of Maxim Gorky's Summerfolk  at the Long Wharf Theater  is like plunging into the middle of a great novel. Those who are unfamiliar with the play may, at first, be dazed by the abundance of characters. It takes time to sort out husbands and wives, lovers and enemies, brothers and sisters. Compared to his countryman Chekhov, Gorky is perhaps less interested in characterization than he is in canvas. Summerfolk, which the author called scenes rather than a play, is a sweeping and penetrating look at a group of middleclass intellectuals in the new Russia after the turn of the century.

title: Broadway
description: John Corry

title: 1980 Olympics Face Threat of a Boycott
description: LONDON, Jan. 18  Delegates from round the world were arriving here today for a meeting that could determine whether the 1980 Olympic Games in Moscow will face a boycott by Asian and Middle Eastern countries.

title: Restaurants
description: AWARE that to most people $15 to $25 a person is a pretty stiff tab for dinner, and that most of the restaurants reviewed here are within these lofty upper reaches, we are constantly in search of more moderately priced eating places offering food that is satisfying esthetically as well as physically. Inevitably, in such a Quest we wind up facing east  whether to the cuisines Eastern Europe or to those of the Near, Middle and Far East. In fact, the more easterly we travel the more beguiling and sensually intriguing are the dishes. At both the Chinese and Indian restaurants below, one can have a delicious and interesting meal for somewhere between $6 and $8 a person. Of course, by choosing the more elaborate offerings, one can also go as high as $10 a person but that would be a far more unusual alternative.

title: Earnings Up at 3 Banks
description: More bank holding companies, including the Bankers Trust New York Corporation, the Continental Illinois Corporation, and the Western Bancorporation, yesterday announced higher operating earnings for the final quarter of 1978 and the entire year.

title: A Study of the American Man
description: An overwhelming majority of contemporary American men believe that family life is crucial to happiness, but good number of them do not place high priority on sex. Very few consider children to be a major element in a successful marriage, and the accumulation of money, they say, has little power to foster contentment.

title: Resorts Chief Testifies on Problems With Exaide
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 18  Tames M. Crosby, chairman of Resorts International, testified today at a hearing on Resorts request for a permanent casino license here that the company had barred its former publicrelations man from New Jersey because he had had petty arguments with the company president, I. G. Davis Jr., and other executives.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: The Mission Insurance Group said that its board had unanimously rejected the unsolicited merger proposals of the American International Group as not in the best interest of Mission and its stockholders.

title: Cervantes Retains His Crown With a Decision Over Montilla
description: Calling on his punch and his experience after age had threatened to betray him, Antonio (Kid Pambele) Cervantes of Colombia retained his world junior welterweight title last night by outpointing Miguel Montilla of the Dominican Republic at Madison Square Garden.

title: REA Case Indictment
description: A Chicago tax official was indicted in Manhattan yesterday on Federal perjury charges involving an investigation of bribes to obtain favorable treatment for REA Express Inc.

title: It Was A Struggle Just to Stay on Course
description: Leaning into the wind, pedestrians tried not to lose ground yesterday at 46th Street and Avenue of the Americas. New Yorkers who ventured outside faced gusts of up to 40 miles an hour as northwesterly winds howled through the city' s concrete canyons. High winds and low temperatures resulted in a belowzero windchill factor.

title: Top Moslem Inside Iran Backs Regime, for Now
description: QUM, Iran, Jan. 18  Ayatollah Shareatmadary, the most powerful religious leader inside Iran, said today that the Government of Prime Minister Shahpur Bakhtiar should be left in power for the time being and warned that if it fell, Iran might go through terrible turmoil.

title: Koch Promises Redevelopment For Waterfront
description: A redevelopment of New York City's waterfront  with marinas, seafood restaurants and recreation and commercial projects  was promised yesterday by Mayor Koch.

title: Byron Janis Pays a Debt at Keyboard to Old Friend in Great Neck Concert
description: Byron Janis has long felt indebted to the late Samuel Chotzinoff, and he is finally getting a chance to express his gratitude. The pianist will donate his services as soloist with the Great Neck Symphony Orchestra in a concert on Sunday afternoon dedicated to Chotzinoff's memory.

title: World News Briefs
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 18 (Reuters)  The captain of the freighter Huey Fong, jammed with 2,700 Vietnamese refugees, was told today that he would be subject to local.laws if he entered Hong Kong waters and might end up in jail.

title: Zeckendorf, Hilton in Statler Deal
description: An investment group headed by William Zeckendorf Jr. has contracted to purchase the Sta tier Hilton Hotel, opposite Pennsylvania Station, for $24 million from the Hilton Hotels Corporation, Hilton announced yesterday. The transaction is expected to be consummated in midApril.

title: Digest BUSINESS
description: The gross national product grew 6.1 percent at an annual rate the fourth quarter, or much faster than expected, the Government disclosed. The Administration said the increase supports its contention that a recession is not likely, but the numbers were a cause concern outside the Administration. The g,rowth rate implied that the Government's efforts to bring about a gradual economic slowdown reduce inflationary pressures were not working. [Page A1.]

title: Beaths
description: HATFIELDRobert G., of Dix Hills, NY. On January 18, 1979. (President and Chairman of the Board of the SevenUp Brooklyn Bottling Co., Inc. and former Director of the Bay Ridge Savings & Loan Ass*n). Beloved husband of Grace (nee Langley). Visitation 25 F. 710PM Sat 8. Sun at the A.L. Jacobsen Funeral Home, Inc.. 1380 New York Ave, Huntington Station, NY. Religious service Monday 11AM followed by entombment in Pinelawn Memorial Park, Farmingdale, L.I.

title: Court Tells 7 Big Banks To Give Data to F.T.C.
description: An appellate court ruled yesterday that seven bank holding companies must comply with subpoenas from the Federal Trade Commission, which .asked for extensive information about connections between major banks and enemy companies.

title: Inflation Eases in Canada
description: OTTAWA, Jan. 18 (Reuters)  The Canadian consumer price index rose 0.3 percent in December after a rise of 0.8 percent the month before, cutting the annual inflation rate to 8.4 percent, the lowest in 1978.

title: Westchester Woodwinds
description: The Hancock Woodwind Quintet will play works by Bach. Darius Milhaud Gioacchino Rossini, Carl Nielsen and Eugene Bozza on Sunday at 3 P.M. at the Emelin Theater on Library Lane in Mamaroneck, N.Y. The quintet consists of Lesley Bell, flutist; Stephen Quint, horn player; Paul Stebbins, bassoonist; Larry Tietze, clarinetist, and Joel Timm, oboist. Admission is $3(S2 for students and the elderly). Information: (914) 6980098

title: World Bank Oil- Work Loans
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Bonn Eases Loyalty Checks for National Employment
description: BONN, Jan. 18  The Government moved today to liberalize loyalty investigations of candidates for publicservice jobs, an issue that has led to a profound and disruptive debate here about the extent of democracy in West Germany.

title: Prince Sihanouk Says He Plans To Stay in the West Indefinitely
description: Prince Norodom Sihanouk said last night that he planned to remain in the West indefinitely and was having his two sons and other members of his family flown from Peking to France.

title: Economic Scene
description: THE Carter Administration has grown fearful thdt the departure from Iran of Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi could be not the end but only the beginning of a time of troubles for oilproducing nations and for the industrial nations dependent upon them. Ironically, it was oil wealth that lifted the Shah and his regime toward vast military and industrial power, and oil wealth that destroyed him.

title: At the Movies
description: WHEN he begins work on Stepping Out at the Astoria Motion Picture and Television Center in Queens in April, George Burns will be returning for the first time to the place where he began his film career a mere 49 years ago, he recalled over brunch at the Friars Club one day recently.

title: G.M.'s Estes Bids U.S. Ease FuelSaving Rules
description: DETROIT, Jan. 18  E.M. Estes, president of the General Motors Corporation, stating that Federal regulations will add $945 to the price of the average G.M. car by 1985, called on the Federal Government today to lighten that burden by easing standards for fuel economy.

title: TV Weekend
description: THIS is the weekend of football's Super Bowl, always one of the most watched events of any year. Super Bowl XIII, which. will be broadcast from Miami on NBC Sundly at 4 P.M., features the Piusburgh Steelers against the Dallas Cowboys. In the inevitable exploitation tie- in, NBC, on Saturday night at 9, will offer a twohour variety special called Super Bowl Saturday Night. O.J. Simpson and Ted Knight are the hosts. So go tackle a television executive.

title: Iran Reports Final Toll of Quake Is 199 Dead and About 100 Hurt
description: TEHERAN, Iran,Jan. 18 (Reuters) The final casualty toll of an earthquake that struck three villages in northeastern Iran on Tuesday is 199 dead and about 100 injured, a senior Iranian aid official said today.

title: OPEC Chief Sees Moderation
description: VIENNA, Jan. 18 (Reuters)'020;OPEC's new chief executive said today that the oilexporting countries would act moderately, as gently as possible, in making future price changes.

title: News Summary
description: President Carter's appeal to Ayatollah Khomeini to cooperate with the new Iranian Government was rejected by the exiled opposition leader, who again emphasized that his followers should seize power. A spokesman also said that the Moslem leader had rejected in advance any possible peace overtures from an emmisary of the Iranian Government. [Page Al, Column 3.]

title: California Senate Seeks to Curb Busing for Integration of Classes
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 18 (UPI)  The California Senate today overwhelmingly passed a state constitutional amendment to limit mandatory busing of school children to achieve racial integration. The vote was 31 to 5.

title: Dispute a Decade Old
description: The steel haulers troubles are more than a decade old and involve conflicts among drivers who own their own rigs and their union, which is made up largely of hired drivers, and the trucking companies that employ both.

title: Outlook on Health Budget
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP)  President Carter will propose cutting out Medicare and Medicaid payments for chiro- practors and limiting fees paid to radiologists and other hospitalbased doctors to hold down health costs in the budget for the fiscal year 1980. it has been learned.

title: Again the Season for the Tripes
description: MIAMI, Jan. 18  Intimidation Bowl - Super Threats Bounce Back and Forth .... Kolb Steeling Himself for Martin Date .... Miami SWAT Team Ready for Super Bowl .. .. Hollywood Henderson Pro Football's Ali . Davis, 34, Girds for Randy White . . . . Super Feats a Specialty for Harris . . . and SG an and on and on, world without end amen.

title: Dance: Mythology of the Japanese
description: ON Tuesday night at Japan louse. Sachiyo Ito and Comy revealed that just as the Greeks have their myth of Pygmalion and French ballet has `Coppelia, so the Japanese have Kyo Ningyo. All these stories somehow con- cem a sculptor or wood carver who, after fashioning the image of a beautiful woman, falls in love with it, then believes that it has come magically to life.

title: World Gold
description: THURSDAY. JAN. 18. 1979

title: Mount Vernon Police Officer Indicted in Drug Case
description: WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 18 (UPI) While Federal and Mount Vernon investigators were wiretapping suspected cocaine dealers, a Mount Vernon police officer was conspiring with the traffickers to bug his own police headquarters, according to indictments handed up today.

title: The Hartford Civic Center: A Year After the Fall
description: An aerial view of the Hartford Civic Center, whose roof collapsed a year ago yesterday only hours after nearly 5,000 spectators left the arena. Gov. Ella T. Grasso presided over a celebration yesterday with a dual theme: A year from its collapse and a year to its reopening. Mayor George Athanson took the occasion to call for grand jury investigation of what he called a massive coverup of design flaws that led to the roof collapse. The Chief State's Attorney is investigating the collapse, but there has been no request to impanel a grand jury.

title: Dance: Sophie Maslow Presents New Approach
description: FOLK and political themes characterized the work of Sophie Maslow in the 1940's, when she came into major prominence as a member of the modemdance choreographic trio that included Jane Dudley and William Bales. Those who still associate Miss Maslow, a former Martha Graham dancer and founder of the New Dance Group, with such dances as Folksay would have been in for a surprise on Wednesday, when the Sophie Maslow Dance Company appeared at the Theater of the Riverside Church.

title: Once More Up the Mideast Mountain
description: It's been a month since President Carter, with that statement and evident pique at the Israelis, pulled back from the effort to turn the Camp David accords into a peace treaty between Israel and Egypt. Now we know what fires were burning in the attic. The Shah was collapsing; a big China deal was falling into place, and the effects of both on SALT and a Brezhnev visit were uncertain. Now we also know, however, that Mr.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of incorrect information supplied by CBS Records, an article in The Times Wednesday listed among artists scheduled to appear in a music festival in Havana March 24, four performers who will not be participating. They are Celia Cruz, Nicky Morrero, Bob James and Stanley Clarke.

title: Ford, Touring Middle East, Meets With Sadat and the Shah in Egypt
description: ASWAN, Egypt, Jan. 18  Former President Gerald R. Ford arrived here today for a visit as the guest of President Anwar elSadat, and both men met with the Shah of Iran.

title: Xerox Sets Acquisition Of WUI
description: The Xerox Corporation and Western Union International announced jointly last night that they had reached an agreement in principle under which Xerox would acquire the international communications company for about $207 million in stock, at yesterday's price for Xerox.

title: Stars Win, 100 to 99, Before 573
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Jan. 18Another rivalry is born in sports. It features the New York Stars and the New Jersey Gems, the two local teams in the Women' s Basketball League, a professional outfit that started operations this year.

title: The Editorial Notebook
description: PETER PASSELL

title: U.S. Criticizes New Outposts
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18  The United States expressed its regret and concern tdday over Israel's decision to establish new settlements on the West Bank of the Jordan River and the Gaza Strip.

title: And Now, Racquetball Chic
description: A few years ago, racquetball players simply got into cutoff jeans and sweatshirts or loose shorts and Tshirts when they were ready for a game. Their only consideration was comfort.

title: Public Meeting Called On Sale of City Notes
description: A public meeting at which information will be given on the city's $100 million note sale will be held at 2 P.M. today in the groundfloor auditorium at Chase Manhattan Plaza.

title: A LookAlike of Oswald Is Reported Dead at 41
description: DALLAS, Jan. 18 (UPI)  A man whose uncanny resemblance to Lee Harvey Oswald led to years of harassment by theorists and investigators of the assassination of President Kennedy has died in selfimposed seclusion, according to his relatives.

title: Man and Woman, 18, Charged With Assault In Subway Booth Fire
description: A young man and woman, both 18years old, were arraigned in Queens Criminal Court yesterday on charges of arson, assault and attempted murder in connection with Tuesday night's firebombing of a subway token booth that severely burned two clerks.

title: John A. Barr, 70, Dies in Illinois; A Leader of Montgomery Ward
description: John Andrew Barr, retired chairman of Montgomery Ward & Company, and dean emeritus of the Graduate School of Management at Northwestern University, died Tuesday at Evanston Hospital in Evanston, Ill. He was 70 years old and lived in Wilmette, Ill.

title: Portland Stove In Bankruptcy
description: PORTLAND, Me., Jan. 18  The Portland Stove Foundry, which has manufactured woodburning stoves for 102 years, said it had been hurt by imports of cheap, woodburning stoves and had filed a petition in the United States Bankruptcy Court here seeking a courtapproved arrangement with its creditors.

title: Market Gains
description: Powered by glowing reports of fourthquarter profits, the stock market moved ahead yesterday after two losing sessions.

title: Business and the Law
description: ACITY of lawyers  that's Washington. It also a place where the word fungible, a lawyer's adjective meaning interchangeable, applies not only to such commodities as toothpaste and currency but also to people. One day a lawyer is working for the Government; the next day he is in private practice.

title: The Super Problem: Not Enough Tickets
description: MIAMI, Jan. 18  Although 77,000 tickets were available for this year's Super Bowl game in the Orange Bowl, between 250,000 and 300,000 tickets could have been sold. That estimate was made today by Don Weiss, executive director of the National Football League and the No. 1 man on the staff of Commissioner Pete Rozelle.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Cocoa futures prices flipflopped yesterday, falling in the morning and rising late in the trading session on the New York Cocoa Exchange. At day's end the March cocoa bean delivery closed at $1.59 a pound, up half a cent.

title: H.R.A. Computer Puts Surprise in Paychecks
description: New York City programmed its Human Resources Administration computer this week to write out semimonthly pay checks for 13,500 home attendants - $4.5 million worth.

title: Movie:'Circle of Iron':Fortune-Cookie Lessons
description: Circle of Iron," which opens today at the Loews State and RKO 86th Street theaters, is a fairy tale for small boys with big, deadly feet. A young, very tough martial-arts warrior  we know he's tough because be sleeps sitting up  goes off in search of a book that contains all knowledge. Before he finds the book he finds David Carradine four times, in four different disguises. Each time Mr. Carradine appears, there is a great deal of whooshing and kicking on the screen.The young fighter, played with too much hearty ha-ha-haing by Jeff Cooper, learns a lot of solemn lessons on his journey, none of which ought to be unfamiliar to fortune-cookie connoisseurs. (Seekers take note: "You can't step twice on the same piece of water.") But the ultimate point of his quest is pretty well nonexistent, and the movie's stabs at wisdom are dopey enough to undermine its action sequences. Even after his pilgrimage is over, Mr. Cooper has a long way to go.Roddy McDowall and Christopher Lee both appear in small roles and preposterously ill-fitting headpieces. Eli Wallach wins the film's What's a Nice Guy Like You Doing in a Place Like This? award by turning up in a vat of oil, in which he has supposedly been soaking for 10 years, hoping to get rid of his genitals. He explains this in a mercifully brief speech that doesn't bear repeating.The movie so evidently comes to life when Mr. Carradine is on the screen, and so emphatically falls apart without him, that one can't help regretting his choice to do most of his acting with his feet these days. "Bound For Giory" notwithstanding, Mr. Carradine has devoted most of his recent movie appearances to either driving fast cars or pulverizing martial-arts rivals. Even in roles that don't begin to utilize his full talents, his delivery is effortlessly wry, and he's able to make lines not even marginally intelligent sound wise."Circle of Iron," which is dedicated to the memory of Bruce Lee, is derived from a story initially written by Mr. Lee and James Coburn (with help from Stirling Silliphant), about a young warrior and an older, all-knowing martial-arts seer. Although Mr. Lee and Mr. Coburn reportedly planned to co-star in the film, it's hard to imagine Mr. Coburn in either role.

title: Vietnamese Said to Recapture a Key Cambodian Port
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 18  Vietnamese troops have retaken the Cambo. dian port city of Kompong Som but are suffering reverses in southeastern Cambodia near the Vietnamese border, Western analysts said today.

title: An 18thCentury Evening
description: The EighteenthCentury Ensemble will play works by Bach, Francois Couperin and others on authentic period instruments Sunday at 7:30 P.M. in Christ and St. Stephen's Church, 120 West 69th Street. Tickets are $4 (S2 for students and the elderly). Information: F741371.

title: F.C.C. Rejects Bid By A.T.&T. on Cable
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 The Federal Communications Commission, for the second time, has turned, down an application by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and others to lay a cable between Florida and St. Thomas in the Virgin Islands.

title: Pakistan, Worried by Afghanistan, Looks to China
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Jan. 18 surprise visit to Islamabad by Deputy Prime Minister Li Hsiennien of China this weekend is seen here as a demonstration of Peking's support for Pakistan at time of extreme uneasiness in this country over the emergence of a proSoviet regime in neighboring Afghanistan.

title: German Bank Tightens Credit
description: BONN, Jan. 18  The West German central bank announced today the first significant tightening in the country's credit since 1973 in order to contain surging money supply caused by the'020;bank's support of the ddllar on foreign currency markets.

title: Farm Bureau Rejects Subsidy Rise
description: MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 18  The American Farm Bureau Federation, the nation's largest farm organization, notified Congress today that the majority of its members wanted no increase this year in Government grain subsidies or price support loans.

title: AvonTiffany Tie
description: Avon Products Inc. and Tiffany & Company said that they had signed letter of intent whereby Tiffany would become a wholly owned subsidiary of Avon. Under the agreement, Tiffany shareholders would receive 0.845 shares of Avon capital stock in exchange for each share of Tiffany common stock owned by them. The two companies recently announced they were holding discussions concerning the possibility of a merger. Tiffany has about 2.3 million common shares outstanding.

title: Westinghouse Rise Clouded by Suits
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation, which has been embroiled for three years in a series of lawsuits over uranium supplies, reported yesterday that net income for the final quarter of 1978 was up 44 percent from results in the comparable 1977 period and up 2.2 percent for the year.

title: Niebling Choosing Farmer's Life
description: The dean of municipal financing is going to try farming. Walter Niebling, manager of the minicipal finance department of the Merrill Lynch White Weld Capital Markets Group, is going to pack it in next May after 29 years and move to South Hero, Vt., on a island in Lake Champlain.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: CONCORDIA GLEAM (Concordia Une-Boise-Oriffin Steamship Comp'snY). Tenerife Jan. 77, Las Palmas 20. Barcelona Feh 7, Genoa 1. Naples S, Lirnassol 10, BeIrld 11, Latakia 13 and Piraeus 15, sails from Port Newark. N J.

title: Ballet:
description: THE New York City Ballet is not a company usually identified with fairytale ballets. Yet fairy tales are popularizations of myths common to all cultures and there are many ways of them.

title: Election Panel Report Challenged
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18  Several members of Congress today challenged the accuracy of campaign spending report smade public by the Federal Election Commission, contending that spending and surplus figures listed for their races last year were far higher than the actual amounts.

title: U.S. Plans to Launch 2 Exploratory Satellites
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP)  The space agency said today that it would launch two satellites next Thursday, one to study the Earth's ozone layer and the other to try to determine what has been causing electrical discharges that have been disrupting orbiting payloads.

title: $1 BILLION TRIMMED FROM ENERGY PLANS FOR COMING BUDGET
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18  About $1 billion of the national budget savings that President Carter has ordered to keep next year's Federal deficit under S30 billion has come out of the energy budget, according to Government and industry officials.

title: Ayatollah Rebuffs Carter
description: NEAUPHLE-LE-CHATEAU, France, Jan. 18  A spokesman for Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini said today that Iran's militant opposition leader rejected President Carter's plea for cooperation with the Government of Prime Minister Shahpur Bakhtiar and emphasized that he wanted his followers in Iran to overthrow it and seize power. The spokesman for the 78-year-old head of Iran's Shiite Moslems told reporters at the Ayatollah's headquarters-in-exile here, The Bakhtiar Government is declared illegal and must go. No buts, ifs, whens or hows.

title: Yale Gives Its Own Version of Buried Child
description: With a playwright as difficult to pin down as Sam Shepard, both in person and in his work, it's no wonder that his most recent effort, Buried Child, should inspire more than one production. There's one version, well received by the critics, now playing Off Broadway at the Theater de Lys. And, beginrang tonight, there will be another on the boards in New Haven, at the Yale Repertory Theater.

title: Abuses Charged By Councilman In Adult Homes
description: Adult homes, in which more than 6,500 New York City residents live, have become satellite mental institutions and are plagued by many of the same abuses that marked the nursinghome industry, City Councilman Antonio G. Olivieri charged yesterday.

title: Strikes Alienating the Ordinary Briton
description: LONDON, Jan. 18  Roddy McCabe, one of Britain's striking truck drivers, squinted into the snow blowing outside an idle London dock this morning as he tried to explain the industrial dispute that has badly disrupted the nation's transportation and commerce.

title: NEW WITNESS FOUND IN 1973 REILLY CASE
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn.,Jan. 18 A new witness in the Peter Reilly murder case said in a statement sworn, signed and notarized here today that he saw two brothers, Tim and Michael Parmalee, running out of the Falls Village, Conn., home of Barbara Gibbons on the night in September 1973 that she was murdered, and that, sometime later, one of the brothers confessed that they had murdered the woman.

description: Andre Laguerre, the former managing editor of Sports Illustrated, who was credited with turning the magazine into publishing success, died yesterday of heart attack at his home at 3 East 71st Street.

title: NewFound Species Challenges Views on Evolution of Humans
description: CLEVELAND. Jan. 18  A prevously unknown human ancestor that lived in Africa three million to four million year ago and had an unexpected combination of a smallbrained, apelike head and fully erect body has been discovered by two American anth oriists.

description: Onyema M. A. Okorie does not want them to finish the revolution without him, so he is going back to his roots.

title: Oil Demand In U.S. Up 1.4% in '78
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) American demand for petroleum products rose just 1.4 percent last year, significantly lower than the rises in the two previous years, according to figures from the American Petroleum Institute. Demand was up 6.9 percent in 1976 and 5 percent in 1977.

The change was not substantial, and stiff opposition to the rule continues,. but the incident was symbolic of new mood at the agency.

description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 18 (UPI)  An explosion and fire in a subway train under San Francisco Bay has halted service indefinitely through the tube linking Oakland and San Francisco, a spokesman for the Bay Area Rapid Transit District said today.

description: PARIS. Jan. 18 (Reuters)  President Valery Giscard d'Estaing of France, who left today on a threeday visit to Rumania, returned to Paris because a violent snowstorm in Bucharest prevented his plane from landing. officials here said.

description: The best overall ski conditions of the season prevailed in the Northeast yesterday as maintenance crews at resorts from northern Vermont to the Poconos in Pennsylvania were busy packing newly fallen snow from Wednesday's storm.

title: Publishing: 50 Years Of Queen Mysteries
description: IT was just fifty years ago that the prublishing house of Stokes brought out The Roman Hat Mystery,' by a pseudonymous author who went by the name of Ellery Queen. thus starting one of the longest and most successful careers in the field of mystery and mayhem. In the course of the next decades, Queen turned up in hard cover and in paperback, founded magazine that is still running, appeared on radio, in movies and on television and has had a very respectable career overseas.

title: Film: On the Yard Views Prison and Prisoners
description: PRISON movies are  unfair. Whether they are good or bad, they can grab and hold our interest. Conflict is built into them. It's as much a part of the prison landscape as cellblocks, walls, the presence of the guards, the tensions of the prisoners. Will they or won't they break out? Who's going to flip? Which one's the stoolie? I don't usually run to see a prison movie, yet I've sat through lots of them, some quite terrible, and never once thought of walking out. Something is always bound to happen in a prison movie  and you can't say that about every movie set in the wideopen spaces.

title: Alfred J. Dillon, 86; Was One of Designers Of World's Fair in '39
description: Alfred Joseph Dillon, secretary-treasurer of Bartholomew and Dillon Inc., designers, died Dec. 26 at his home in Hancock, N.H., after a long illness. Mr. Dillon was 86 years old and lived in New York until 1950 when he and his wife, the former Augusta Bartholomew, moved to Hancock.

It is torn between its desire to relieve the poverty and suffering of people fleeing from economic misery or political tyranny abroad, and its fear of taking on more refugees than the country can absorb.

title: Cleveland News Protest Ends
description: CLEVELAND, Jan. 18  Members of the Cleveland Newspaper Guild have voted to end a byline moratorium at The Plain Dealer, protesting the transfer of reporter covering utilities news..After meeting on Tuesday between The Plain Dealer management and three Guild representatives, a joint news release was issued, saying that Robert H. Holden, reporter, would be reassigned to general reporting duties on March 1.

title: Alcoa and Reynolds Report Big jumps in Nets
description: Two major aluminum companies the Aluminum Company of America and the Reynolds Metals Company yesterday reported sharply higher earnings for the fourth quarter of 1978 and for the full year. Both companies benefited from rising demand, particularly from aerospace companies, and from a series of price increases.

title: Senta Driver's Troupe in Class of Its Own at P.S.1
description: Senta Driver is both the dance world's wit and its enfant terrible. What is one to make of a choreographer who has her dancer circle the stage intoning, deadpan, the names of historical ballet figures? Or who coolly goes against tradition and has a female raise a male dancer in a lift? Or who, for that matter, names her modern dance group Harry'? On Sunday, in the culmination of a sevenweek residency at P.S. 1, the experimental art complex in Long Island City, Miss Driver will explore yet another odd kinetic conceit. In Crowd, a work in progress, her company will be augmented by 15 lifesized white plaster and burlap sculptures by Carol Parker which, holding fans and inclining in very human attitudes, resemble frail ghosts.

title: Advertising
description: 'I got this crazy idea, said Allen G. Rosenshine, executive vice president of Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn, that everybody's concerned about the actors strike, yet if you follow the logic of the commercialtesting services you'd find that you don't need actors or actresses.

title: Rights Amendment Vote Stands
description: CHEYENNE, Wyo., Jan. 18 (UPI) The Wyoming Senate yesterday defeated for a second time a move to rescind the state's 1973 ratification of the Equal Rights Amendment, which would prohibit discrimination on the basis of sex.

title: Slides on BrownLung Disease Are Ended After Union Protests

title: Music: Harmonic Choir
description: TIBETAN Buddhist monks, Mongolian nomads and the contemporary composervocalists Meredith Monk and Joan Labarbara have all explored particular singing technique. By sing- ing a deep fundamental tone and then manipulating the shape and resonating capacity of their mouths, they produce two simultaneous musical events, the original tone and a delicate, flutelike harmonic tone above it. With practice the singer learns to control the harmonic tone and play wavering melodies with it.

title: Premier Tries to Restore Calm

title: Randolph Signs 5Year Extension
description: Willie Randolph, a key figure in the New York Yankees late-season surge to their second straight World Series championship, signed a fiveyear extension on his current contract yesterday for terms estimated at close to $1.5 million.

title: The Feds Prescribe Generics
description: The customer who buys a common tranquilizer under its heavily advertised brand name, Equanil, may pay $7.50 for a hundred tablets. But the customer who buys essentially the same drug under its generic name, meprobamate, may pay as little as 94 cents. The high cost of brandname drugs taxes patients with limited incomes - and drives the nation's health costs .ever higher. By one Government estimate, a switch less costly equivalents could cut $400 million a year from the nation's $8billion drug bill. Thus it is welcome news that two Federal agencies are taking major steps to encourage wider use of generic drugs.

title: Brokerage Firm Merger
description: The Angeles Corporation, which provides regional brokerage firms with investment products, and Mitchel, Schreiber, Watts & Company, a floor broker on the New York Stock Exchange and other securities exchanges, announced yesterday an agreement in principle for the acquisition by Angeles of Mitchel.

title: Stella Shows His Metal In Sofia
description: WNETHER or not Frank Stella is the best painter around could be argued. Three, four, perhaps five other candidates could be adduced. But beyond a doubt it is Mr. Stella's work that makes the most ferocious, immediate impact. This was proved when he showed new paintings at Knoedler's in October 1976, and it is being proved all over again the Castelli Gallery, 420 West Broadway, where his series metal reliefs has just gone on view through Jan. 27.

description: MOSCOW, Jan. 18 (Reuters)  Gen. Fyodor F. Kuznetsov, once head of the Soviet Army's Main Political Administration, has died here at the age of 74, the armed forces newspaper Krasnaya Zvezda reported today.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18  Because of robust consumer demand for autos, television sets and other durable goods, the economy grew by an unexpectedly high annual rate of 6.1 percent in the final three months of last year, preliminary Government figures showed today.

description: TOKYO, Jan. 18  The Government has called on consumers and industry to save energy in an effort to cope with a marked reduction in oil supplies from Iran.

title: About Real Estate
description: The basic message of New York State's new plainlanguage act might be summed up in the words, Use everyday language and use it clearly. Easily said but not easily done, say the lawyers who have recently been revising mortgage and lease documents. To avoid the repetition and the terms of art that made these documents tedious or unintelligible to the layman, some fear, may be to create the ambiguities that lead to uncertainty and litigation.

title: Art People

It's the usual story: The building has gone coop and the new owners, forced to make major improvements to qualify for a certificate of occupancy, have asked for triple the monthly stipend.

title: One American Listening Post in Iran Is Reported Shut
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18  Central Intelligence Agency officials were reported to have told a House committee today that the turmoil in Iran had forced the United States to close down one intelligence listening post but that a more important,one needed for verifying Soviet compliance with a new strtegic arms limitation accord was still functioning.

title: Chicago Struggles to Get Out From Under
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 18  I knew there was 29 inches of snow outside and that it was bitter cold with belowzero temperatures, so when I left Evanston at midday on Monday I had the modest goal of getting home by nightfall, said Norma Green, a writer who lives on Chicago's Near North Side. The trip normally takes about an hour by train but they weren't running. So I had to take a bus. At first it didn't seem too bad. Everybody at the bus stop was in good spirits, like people were after the last big blizzard, in 1967. But then we began to notice that we couldn't feel our feet and hands anymgre.

title: Money Supply Off In Week
description: To the surprise of the securities markets, the nation's money supply, or demand deposits at banks and currency in circulation, declined markedly in the week ended Jan. 10, raising hopes that inflation might diminish and fears that a recession might get under way.

title: Republican Step May Block Arms Pact With Soviet
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18  In a move that will almost certainly inject even more controversy into the coming debate over a new armslimitation treaty with the Soviet Union, Republicans added moderate rtnd two rotvervatives today to the Senate Foreign Rela ions Committee.

description: UV Industries announced yesterday a plan to liquidate itself and distribute the proceeds to its stockholders. The company said it wanted to do this because it feared a takeover attempt and a possible recession, and it wanted to take advantage of tax benefits.

description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 17 The Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations, in statement today, criticized remarks by Andrew Young, the United States representative here, as appearing to condone the philosophy and tactics of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

description: Bob Harris was dismissed yesterday as the consulting meteorologist of The New York Times and as the on-the-air meteorologist of WCBSAM, the allnews radio station, after it was learned that he had misrepresented his academic credentials.

title: Government Hot Line Invites Tips on Fraud
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (UPI)  The General Accounting Office today opened a free nationwide hot line that taxpayers can use to alert Federal officials to fraud, abuse and waste in Government.

title: Even After Blanton Was Ousted, He Tried to Aid 30 More Convicts
description: NASHVILLE, Jan. 18  Even after former Gov. Ray Blanton had learned that he bad been summarily removed from office here last night, he and his legal counsel were still trying to commute the sentences of an additional 30 convicts when law enforcement agents and aides of Lamar Alexander, the new Governor, swept into the Capitol to take control of the state government.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Jan. 18 (AP) Denis Potvin, the New York Islanders outstanding defenseman, will be sidelined for about two weeks with slightly separated right shoulder, the National Hockey League club announced today.

title: Israelis Raid Into Lebanon After Jerusalem Bombing
description: JERUSALEM, Friday,Jan. 19  Israeli troops struck deep into southern, Lebanon today to attack Palestinian guerrilla bases; military sources here said. The attack was in apparent retaliation for a bomb explosion in Jerusalem yesterday.

title: Toyota and Nissan Output at Records
description: TOKYO, Jan. 18 (UPI)  Toyota Motor and Nissan Motor announced today that their automobile production in 1978 reached a new high because of brisk domestic demand.

title: Brokers Still Out in Italy
description: MILAN, Italy, Jan. 18 (Reuters) Stock exchanges throughout Italy were closed today for the second successive day as brokers continued a strike. The brokers are protesting what they call the Government's indifference toward their business, an attitude that they say was exemplified by the nomination last month of a show business personality, Bruno Pazzi, to the stock exchange watchdog commission. Mr. Pazzi vice president of the Show Business Association of Italy.

title: RCA Profits Rise by 15%
description: Profits of the RCA Corporation climbed 15 percent both in the quarter and the year ended Dec. 31, the company reported yesterday, with its Hertz auto renting as the No. 1 moneymaker.

title: Chief Witness Against Rep. Flood Denies That He Is Seeking Revenge
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP)  Stephen B. Elko, a former top aide to Representative Daniel J. Flood and now his chief accuser in a perjury and bribery trial, denied t day that he had agreed to be a Government witness to seek revenge against the Pennsylvania Democrat.

title: Carew Deal Stalled
description: Rod Carew reached agreement yesterday on a contract to play with the California Angels, but the Angels offer of compensation was turned down by the Minnesota Twins.

title: American Testifies Chilean Officer Instructed Him to Murder Letelier
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18  A selftaught American electronics expert testified today that a top official in the Chilean secret police ordered him to murder Orlando Letelier, the former Chilean diplomat.

title: On Begin's Right, a Fury Taunts Him
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 18  Perhaps the best way to gauge the distaffde that Prime Minister Menachem Begin has traveled on the path to Middle East peace is to look back at the political associates who chose to stay behind.

title: Koch and Miss Bellamy Clash Over Budget
description: Mayor Koch and City Council President Carol Bellamy clashed yesterday over the city's program to eliminate the budget deficit. Miss Bellamy insisted that socalled contingency cuts be incorporated into the plan, and the Mayor suggested that her criticism was illinformed and unrealistic.

title: Notre Dame 8869 Victor Over Dons
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Jan. 18 (AP) Orlando Woolridge, a sophomore, led Notre Dame in scoring with 18 points and rebounding with seven tonight as the topranked Irish routed San Francisco, 8869, in college basketball.

title: Concert: San Francisco Composers
description: THE second of the three Reich Music Foundation concerts at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum on Wednesday night was devoted to two composers currently based in San Francisco, Ingram Marshall and John Adams. Their music was both more akin to Steve Reich's and more successfully individual than that on Tuesday's opening program, although it seems to be common in the music presented by the Reich ,Foundation, most of their pieces went on rather too long.

title: Preston Pearson Is Questionable
description: MIAMI, Jan. 18  Preston Pearson, the Dallas Cowboys leading pass receiver this season, jammed a bone below the ring finger of his left hand today 10 minutes from the end of practice and was listed as questionable for Sunday's name.

title: Mrs. Mondale Visits Manhattan School
description: Joan Mondale, wife of the Vice President, showing her appreciation to a group of young musicians during a visit to Public School 199 yesterday. At left Billy Taylor, a jazz pianist and head of the Jazzmobile, which gives free concerts around the city. Mr. Mondale returned to Washington yesterday.

title: The City
description: The Conciliation and Appeals Board authorized the owner of 2,500 apartments on the Upper West Side to collect a hardship rent increase of almost percent a year, retroactive to 1975, despite a contention by tenants that the owner made a profit of $1 million during the year for which he claimed the hardship.

title: Aid to Neediest Enables Family To Make a Visit
description: It was the Friday before Christmas, and Mrs. F. wanted to take her three children to her mother's home in Monmouth County, N.J. But because her estranged husband had stopped sending support money, she was penniless, unable to make a 60mile trip for the lack of $18.80, her estimate of what the trip would cost.

title: CriminalJustice Report Spurs Debate by Experts
description: A special committee of New York City lawenforcement officials has recommended that prosecutors powers be strengthened, that the use of the grand jury be curtailed and that enforcement of laws prohibiting gambling and prostitution be deemphasized.

title: Successful Writing Couple Become a Hot Property
description: He dedicated his new book to her, calling her his wife, which she really isn't yet, and won't be. until March 17. She, in turn, dedicated her new book to him. That, in itself, is almost enough to make them the city's newest literary darlingsbut wait, there's more.

title: The Pop Life; Will success spoil Disco 92?; John Rockwell
description: IN the world of popular music, it's interesting to speculate what are fads and what is simple, old-fashioned reality. In the case of radio station WKTUFM, better known as Disco 92, that speculation takes on a special interest  not least to the owners of the station.

Sunday at 11 A M. and P.M. in Avery Fisher Hall, Uncoin Center. Tickets, $3 to $8. Reservations and Information: 757-3460.

title: Iran's Military Waits Silently
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 18  The Iranian Army, a creation of the Pahlevi dynasty, has reacted more favorably than anticipated to the departure of Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi.

title: Mayor Praises, Shanker Assails Schools Analysis
description: A critical analysis of the publicschool system by School Chancellor Frank J. Macchiarola drew praise yesterday from Mayor Koch and protest from Albert Shanker, the president of the United Federation of Teachers.

title: Weekly News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times in the last week. Answers appear on page 26.

title: Paul Meurisse, 66, French Star Of Cabaret, Stage and Screen
description: PARIS, Jan. 19 (AP)  Paul Meurisse, one of France's leading film and stage actors, died of a heart attack in the American Hospital early today, only a few hours after he had left a Paris stage. lie was 66 years old.

title: Tuffy Leemans Dead at 66.
description: Alphonse (Tuffy) Leemans, a star running back for the New York Giants from 1936 through 1943, died at his home in Hillsboro Beach, Fla., yesterday. Obituary appears on page 26.

description: WASHINGTON

title: Clifford S. Strike, at 76; ExConsulting Engineer
description: Clifford S. Strike, retired consulting engineer for post World War II building construction projects here and abroad totaling $3 billion, died Thursday at Scripps Memorial Hospital in La Jolla, Calif. He was 76 years old.

title: Kennedy Plot Theory May Draw a Challenge
description: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Jan. 19 (AP)  Representative Harold S. Sawyer, Republican of Michigan, has reportedly decided to dissent from the House Assassination Committee's opinion that a conspiracy led to the assasSinatin of President Kennedy.

title: For Iranian Rug Merchant, March Is a Joyous Release
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 19  Ali Darakshan had many things to worry about today: his closeddown carpet business, his dwindling savings, the rash of burglaries in his section of the Teheran bazaar.

title: $2.5 Million in Securities Lost By Messenger in Wall St. Area
description: A Wall Street messenger lost $2.5 mil- lion in negotiable securities yesterday af- ternoon while carrying them from an in- vestment banking firm to a bank in the financial district. according to the notice.

title: GeorgiaPacific Merger
description: The GeorgiaPacific Corporation said yesterday that it had completed the previously announced acquisition of the Hudson Pulp and Paper Corporation in a taxfree exchange of shares. The closing had been delayed pending clarification of certain tax matters related to the merger.

title: Rozelle To Revise TV Agenda
description: MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 19  The Na- tional Football, League will alter its schedule of televised games next sea- son in response to last fall's ratings, Commissioner Pete Rozelle said today. Rozelle said that this year there would be fewer games televised nationally on Sunday nights but more on weekday nights other than Monday.

title: Cardinal Cooke Commends AidGiven Neediest
description: Terence Cardinal Cooke, noting that New York, from its earliest days, has been the symbol of hope for a better life, sent a gift of $300 to the 67th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: OBSERVER The Silk Hair Shirt
description: Scarcely a day passes this political season without the spectacle of some statesman threatening to introduce us to austerity. Since catchwords like this don't normally seize a politician's fancy unless he thinks they will help his next campaign, we can only conclude that our leaders detect a great continental yearning for austerity.

title: WEST IS CONSIDERING MISSILE FOR EUROPE ABLE TO HIT SOVIET
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19  The leaders of the United States, Britain, France and West Germany are considering development of a new intermediaterange nuclear missile that would be based in Western Europe and be capable of striking the Soviet Union, Carter Administration officials said today.

title: Loews Wants All Of Bulova
description: The Bulova Watch Company disclosed yesterday that the Loews Corporation would soon offer to buy the 68 percent of Bulova it does not yet own for $10 a share, or about $24 million.

title: Graham Center to Present Choreographers Series
description: The Martha Graham Dance Center will present a special Choreographers Series, featuring works by members of the Graham company. Performances will take place Tab. 9 and 10 at P.M. and Feb. 11 at 2:30 and 7 P.M. at Marymount Manhattan Theater 221 East 71st Street.

title: WMCA Series on Jewry Will Begin on Feb. 4
description: A weekly radio magazine focusing on Jewish life and tradition, will have its premiere Feb. 4 on WMCAAM.

title: 8 Albee Plays Will Tour Overseas
description: The series or eight oneact Edward Albee plays to be presented at Columbia University from Feb. 6 to 18 under the direction of the author will also tour universities and arts centers in the United States and in Japan and South America for 10 months.

description: Boy, 3, Was in City Clinic for Routine Cleaning

title: Gen. Maurice Challe Dead at 73; Led 1961 Coup Against de Gaulle
description: PARIS, Jan. 19  Gen: Maurice Challe, who led an unsuccessful military coup against President de Gaulle to keep Algeria under French control nearly 18 years ago, died yesterday of cancer at his home here, the general's family announced today. General Challe was 73 years old.

title: Robert L. Anderson, Specialist In Technical Engineering, at 51
description: Robert L. Anderson, consulting engi neer and a partner in the firm of Sidney Bowne, died Monday at his home in West Islip, L.I. He was 51 years old.

title: Khomeini Calls Shah Dethroned, Vows to Take Over
description: NEAUPHLE-LE-CHATEAU, France. Jan 19  Contending'that today's demonstrations in Iran had already dethroned the Shah, the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini said that we will take power through the legitimate referendum of the streets.

description: Special to The New York Times

title: Letelier Defense Queries Blocked
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP)  A federal judge ruled today that the Americanborn former Chilean agent who had admitted to having planted the bomb that killed Orlando Letelier, a Chilean diplomat, does not have to testify about assassination plots against Chileans in Rome and A rnpntina

title: COMMODITIES
description: Silver futures moved up slightly yesterday despite bearish news and lumber futures declined in otherwise dull preweekend trading on the commodities markets.

title: Cost of Synanon Arms Is Now Put at $60,000
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 19  Investigators in California who are conducting an inquiry into Synanon, the drug rehabilitation organization, have asserted that the organization purchased a total of 152 pistols, rifles and shotguns and more than 660,000 rounds of ammunition.

title: Summa and Hughes Air Payment
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 19  The estate of the late Howard R. Hughes and two companies he controlled have agreed to pay at least $30 million to former stockholders of Air West airline in settlement of a stock fraud and manipulation suit brought by the Securities and Exchange Commission in 1975.

title: TV: Andy Griffith Tries to Fly From Junkyard to Moon in Salvage
description: Andy Griffith has gone and done it this time. After eight years as the lovable sheriff of Mayberry and shorter stints on less successful series, all of which exploited his downhome manner, followed by a long layoff to count his money, this likable performer has come out of the woods and has caught his foot in a bear trap.

title: First of 198 New Apartments Open in ChurchSponsored Renovation of Harlem Block
description: Moving day is always hectic and usually unpleasant, especially when it comes in winter, but for Desimona Mandevill, moving day was yesterday and it was beautiful.

title: White House Fails to Mend Fences With Key Women's Groups
description: A week atter the socalled Friday Night Massacre in which Bella Abzug got a pink slip from the White House, the scorecard on the National Advisory Committee for Women read: 15 mem- bers on, 25 members off.

title: Citibank Alters Prime Formula
description: Citibank announced yesterday that was changing its formula for calculating its prime rate on corporate loans each Friday morning.

title: 2 Break Hurdles Record
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 19  In what may become one of the more interesting rivalries between now and the 1980 Moscow Olympics, Renaldo Nehemiah and Greg Foster finished in a dead heat and set a world indoor record in the 60yard high hurdles tonight at the Philadelphia Track Classic.

title: Police Want to See Reilly Witness
description: In a sworn statement released to The New York Times and The Hartford Courant, but not to the State's Attorney's office nor to the police, Mr. Wilcox said that he had seen two brothers running from the house of Barbara Gibbons the night she was murdered and that one of the brothers had later confessed to him that they had killed the 51-year-old woman, who was Mr. Reilly's mother.

title: Unmaking a Treaty
description: Whether President Carter had the right to terminate the defense treaty with Taiwan without some consent from Congress is a question of stupefying complexity. And the legal issues are snarled by the debris of a Chinese civil war that is still not completely resolved. What Senator Goldwater has posed as a legal problem, therefore, is really a political issue. We hope that the courts will let the political system decide it.

title: $13 Million Earnings Reductio
description: Texaco Inc. announced yesterday change in its accounting policies that will reduce its earnings over the last 10 years by about $185 million. The immediate effect, however, will be to increase Texaco's fourthquarter earnings by $21.1 million, the company's figures showed.

title: Thursday's Fights
description: By The Associated Press

title: Soviet Reports Lag in Oil and Coal; Emphasis on Natural Gas Expected
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 19  The Soviet Union released economic figures for 1978 today that showed shortfalls in the production of oil, coal, steel, cement and other key commodities and suggested a shift of emphasis to natural gas in the country's energy planning.

title: Take It From Top, Musical Play
description: Take It From the Top is described as a musical play, but it has virtually no music, only an occasional piano or percussion accompaniment and snatch of song here and there.

title: Robert J. Quinn, at 73
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 19 (UPI)  Robert J. Quinn, who headed Chicago's Fire Department for 21 years, died last night in Florida while visiting friends. The former Fire Commissioner, who was 73 years old, was one of the most enduring administrators who served the late Mayor Richard J. Daley.

title: Faculty Members Ask Mannes Music College To Halt Merger Talks
description: Faculty members of the Mannes College of Music have demanded that the school's board of trustees immediately desist from all merger talks with officials of the Manhattan School of Music. Officials of both schools disclosed recently that what they termed exploratory discussions had been held about the feasibility of consolidating the institutions. At a meeting of Marines faculty members last Wednesday, a resolution of noconfidence in the board was adopted unanimously, according to two teachers who had been designated at the meeting as faculty spokesmen.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: FREDERICK W. M. JANNEY
description: WASHINGTON,Jan. 19  Frederick Wistar M. Janney, director of personnel of the Central Intelligence Agency, died yesterday of a heart attack while playing squash at the Metropolitan Club. He was 59 years old.

title: McGraw Suit Names Executive
description: McGrawHill Inc. yesterday accused Roger H. Morley, president of the American Express Company, of being a Trojan horse on the McGrawHill board of directors, gathering secrets for an American Express takeover of the ni hi ch nP ennrem

title: Nashville Police Assign a Guard To Blanton Foe
description: NASHVILLE, Jan. 19 (UPI)  John Jay Hooker, a lawyer seeking to revoke 34 commutations that Gov. Ray Blanton granted to state prison convicts just before he left office, was placed under protective custody by the police today because of reported threats on his life.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Soviet production of coal, oil, steel and cement fell short of goals last year, according to figures published in Izvestia, the official Soviet newspaper. Natural gas production provided one of the few bright spots among the key Soviet economic statistics, leading some experts to believe the Russians will soon begin to shift some plants from coal or oil to gas. [Page 1.]

title: Vietnamese Said to Assault Ruins Of a 2d Famous Cambodia Temple
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 19  Vietnamie troops were assaulting Cambodian soldiers at the famous temple ruins of Preah Vilumr, an 11thcentury sanctuary high on a steep cliff on the Thai border. Western analysts reported today.

title: Council Elects Mandelbaum
description: Rabbi Bernard Mandelbaum has been elected executive vice president of the Synagogue Council of America, succeeding Rabbi Henry Siegman, who has become executive director of the American Jewish Congress. Rabbi Mandelbaum, who is 57 years old, is a former president of the Jewish Theological Seminary and president of the American Israel Cultural Foundation. The synagogue council is the national coordinating body of Conservative, Orthodox and Reform Judaism.

title: Miss Sackl Takes World Cup Slalom
description: MEIRENGEN, Switzerland, Jan. 19 (AP)  Regina Sackl of Austria won her second slalom race of the 1979 World Cup series today, and her compatriot, Annemarie Proell Moser, increased her lead in the World Cup standing.

title: Legislators Ask Action On Dollar
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19  Two key members of Congress warned President Carter today that his success with the package arranged last Nov. 1 to defend the dollar would be shortlived unless he and other world leaders drew up a compact to reduce the supply of dollars in the world.

title: Haskell George Ward
description: No, Haskell Ward told Mayor Koch, he couldn't go to work restructuring the New York City antipoverty apparatus. The Mayor's campaigntime rhetoric about poverty pimps had turned everybody off.

title: Franklin Trial Goes to jury
description: Jury deliberations began yesterday in the trial of three former officials of the Franklin National Bank who were charged with concealing large loss* by the bank before it collapsed in 1974.

description: DETROIT, Jan. 19 (AP)  Two airplanes crashed within 10 minutes of each other tonight, killing six persons at Detroit Metropolitan Airport and four persons at Kent County Airport in Grand Rapids, Mich., the authorities said.

title: Affirmed to Race
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 19 (AP)  Affirmed. the 1978 Triple Crown winner, will attempt to end a string of four consecutive losses tomorrow when he faces eight rivals in the $115,200 San Fernando Stakes at Santa Anita. Steve Cauthen will be aboard Affirmed, who will carry the high weight of 126 pounds in the I 1/2mile event for 4-year-olds.

title: White Is Ordered To Stand Trial In Two Slayings in San Francisco
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 19 (UPI)  Dan White, the former San Francisco Su- pervisor, today was ordered to stand trial for the murders of Mayor George Mos- cone and Harvey Milk, a Supervisor.

title: Laurel Brandt Bride Of A.B. Leavens 3d
description: In the Tower Room of the Mohonk Mountain House in New Paltz, N.Y. yesterday evening, Laurel Helen Brandt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norman H. Brandt of Roslyn Heights, LI., became the bride of Arthur B. Leavens 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leavens Jr. of Frontenac, Mo. Justice of the Peace Wilfred G. Doolittle of Rosendale, N.Y.. performed the ceremony.

title: U.S. Delays Its Approval Of Project in South Bronx
description: The project, a 732unit cooperative proposed for the desolate Charlotte Street area, where President Carter stood in 1977, was endorsed two months ago by the New York City Board of Estimate - but only after a sometimes acrimonious debate over its advisability.

title: U.S. Nuclear Submarine Boarded During a Protest in New Zealand
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Jan. 19 (Reuters)  The United States nuclear submarine Haddo was boarded by a man protesting nuclear arms today as it entered Auckland Harbor for a sixday visit.

title: South Africans Cling to a Lovely Old City
description: CAPE TOWN  Like most other residents of Cape Town, Isobel Hutton celebrates the mountains and the sea that surround this city. Almost every evening for more than half a century, she has sat on her storm on Windsor Street, in the shadow of Table Mountain, watching the sun go down over the harbor and Table Bay.

title: Boycott of Olympics Is Averted
description: LONDON, Jan. 19 - Voting for what its president described as a medium penalty and a compromise, the Inter- national Amateur Athletic Federation settled today its dispute with 21 Asian and Middle Eastern countries and averted a threatened boycott of the 1980 Olvmnic Games in Moscow.

description: The strength of the Nixon Administration was also its weakness, making something like Watergate inevitable.

title: Alex Weinzimmer, at 75, Active In Religiout Affairs in New York
description: Alex Weinzimmer, a clothing manufacturer, died Wednesday in Miami Beach. He was 76 years old and lived in Miami Beach.

title: The Pope's Visit to Mexico
description: PUEBLA,. Mexico, Jan. 19 - The planned visit of Pope John Paul II to Mexico Jan. 2630 is awakening longdormant religious passions that could disturb the delicate balance of power that has existed between church and state for 90 years.

title: Two Graham Alumni Dance At Riverside
description: Among the most impressive elements of the Martha Graham Dance Company in 1975 were the claming and strong stage presence of Takako Asakawa arid David Hatch Walker. Miss Graham casts a strong spell, both on her dancers and their future audiences, and so it was unsurprising that that indelible print marked and even vitiated a good deal of the work presented Thursday at the Theater of the Riverside Church by Asakawalker, the moderndance group founded in September 1977 by the two former Graham dancers.

title: Federal Pollution Rules Impact On Inflation Found to Be Slight
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19  Federal clean air and water programs have had an inflationary impact on the economy, but the impact has been relatively small and is declining, according to a study released today by two Federal environmental agencies.

title: Newark Schools Prepare for Cuts
description: Under the plan by the Newark Board of Education to dismiss more than 1,100 school employees citywide, including 65 security guards, three of the Spencer school's six guards will be laid off.
