description: BARKINFrances. (nee Cohen. Devoted wife of the late Dan W. Barkin. Dear mother of Herbert and Bunny Barkin of Stamford and Bernard and Barbera Barkin of Greenwith. Loving grandmother and great grandmother. Devoted sister of Stella London. May Cohen and Selma Feinman. Services Friday, January 19. 1979, Westchester Riverside Chapel, 21 W. Broad St, Mount Vernon, N.Y.. 12:30P.M.

title: Jury Reaches No Verdict In Trial of Police Officer
description: After five hours of deliberation, a Brooklyn Federal jury failed to reach a verdict late last evening in the trial of a 29-year-old former New York City police officer who is charged with civilrights violations in the shooting death of a black college student nearly six years ago.

title: Stocks Slip 1.65 After Early Gains
description: Takeover situations provided the stock market with its best gainers yesterday, while prices generally traced an irregular pattern.

title: Mitchell, Last Watergate Prisoner, Is Freed on Parole
description: Special to The New York Times

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in The Times Jan. 12 about a study on the use of helmets by motor- cyclists incorrectly stated a finding of the study. It showed that people not wearing helmets were twice as likely to suffer bead injuries as those wearing them and three to nine times as likely to suffer fatal head injuries.

title: Bank's Audit Shows Billy Carter Had Large Personal Loans in '77
description: Billy Carter and his wife personally borrowed money from the National Bank of Georgia in August 1977, at the same time that the family peanut business he was managing was delinquent in its payments to the same bank, according to documents on file in the Sumter County courthouse in Americus, Ga.

title: A MILLION MARCHERS RALLY FOR KHOMEINI IN TEHERAN STREETS
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 19  A great river of humanity flowed down Teheran's main street today as the people of the Iranian capital demonstrated their support for Ayatollah Ruhoilah Khomeini's crusade for an Islamic government to replace the Government of Prime Minister Shahour Balditiar.

title: Summer Dressing: Bright Colors and Stretchy Fabrics
description: Summer is a happy time, so color is important for the mood, Giorgio SantAngelo explained at the opening of his summer collection this week.

title: U.S. and Israeli Aides Still Differ Over Treaty
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 19  An American team headed by Alfred L. Atherton Jr. ended a third day of talks with Israeli officials without reaching agreement on disputed articles in a peace treaty between Israel and Egypt.

title: Schering Marketing Deal
description: The ScheringPlough Corporation announced yesterday that it had signed letter of intent to market prescription pharmaceuticals made by Reckitt & Colman Ltd. of England in Latin America. Under the proposed agreement, ScheringPlough, through its pharmaceutical subsidiaries, would acquire rights for the commercial development of designated prescription medicines discovered or acquired by Reckitt & Colman. Reckitt & Colman produces a wide range of pharmaceuticals.

title: Walter Strickland, ExPresident And Board Leader of Best & Co
description: Walter Strickland, a retired president and chief executive officer of Best & Company, died Thursday in the Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 86 years old and lived in Bronxville.

title: Carter to Make 7th Nomination Of a Woman as a Federal Judge

title: Mr. Nixon and Henry  of Navarre
description: If Paris was worth a Mass in 1593, our reference to that remark the other day is worth an explanation. It is attributed to Henry of Navarre, who, after making it, became Henry IV, the first Bourbon king of France. Raised as a Protestant, he became a Huguenot leader and defeated the Catholic League in battle. But he could not conquer Catholic Paris, not until his timely conversion. A tolerant and conciliatory man, he is said to have remarked, on embracing Catholicism, Paris is well worth a Mass. He was politically wise; Paris agreed, and his coronation soon followed. We continue to think that, with the top man in China coming to visit, President Carter was tolerant, conciliatory  and politically wise  to invite former President Nixon to the White House. As we said, if Paris in 1593 was worth a Mass, China in 1979 is worth an extra place at dinner.

title: Levi Strauss to Buy Stock
description: Levi Strauss & Company, the maker of jeans and apparel, said yesterday that its directors had authorized the company to repurchase up to two million of its common shares through tender offer. The offer will be at a price of $43.50 a share and will be made as soon as practicable.

title: Swiss Oversubscribe U.S. Notes
description: GENEVA, Jan. 19  The Swiss National Bank officially announced today that a United States Treasury offering of $1.2 billion in notes denominated in Swiss francs had been heavily oversubscribed, confirming earlier indications of strong investor interest in the largest single franc issue ever offered in Switzerland.

title: U.S. Envoy to Taiwan Leaves After 41/2 Years
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Jan. 19 (UPI) The former United States Ambassador here, Leonard Unger, left for home today after more than four years of service that ended with President Carter's severance of diplomatic relations with Nationalist China last month.

title: A School on the East River Is Coping With Problems Like the U.N.'s
description: Out on the East River, clinging to the edge of Manhattan on landfill put there for it, a spinoff from the United Nations is try ing to cope with some of the same problems that beset the international organization  diversity of language, conflicting national interests. multiplicity of cultural backgrounds and political Up1 heaval. It is the United Nations International School, called UNIS, where nearly 1,500 students from 106 countries attend classes taught by men and women from 42 countries.

title: ILLEGAL CHEMICALS IN MEAT INDICATED
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19(AP) A draft report of a new Government study indicates that 19 percent of the dressed meat and poultry sold in supermarkets may contain illegal residues of chemicals suspected of causing cancer, birth defects or other toxic effects.

Why then have years of inflation gone by without a nickel's increase in the basic benefit levels? Challenging the prevailing fiscal conservatism in Albany, Mayor Koch and Assembly Speaker Stanley Fink are now calling for at least some raise in benefits this year. Their plea ought to be heeded.

title: O.J. Makes It to the Super Bowl
description: MIAMI, Jan. 19 - The disco beat was thumping. The lights were flashing. And the bodies were swaying. This, too, is part of the Super Bowl XIII scene- the set of Super Bowl Saturday Night where O.J. Simpson was wearing a tuxedo with a redsatin lining. In his younger years, O.J. Simpson al- ways liked to say that he would never go to the Super Bowl unless he were playing in it. um now he is nearly 32 years old. Now his dream of playing in the Super Bowl has turned into a nightmare of frustration. And now he's here as the co-execu- tive producer and host of the twohour en- tertainment special that will be seen on the NBC network tomorrow evening. The disco scenes in the show were videotaped last night in the Miami airport's international terminal. When not running with a football, O.J. Simpson is perhaps best known for running through airports. And now he was on camera in an airport in a television show that somehow symbolizes his versatility  hundreds of players have made it to the Super Bowl as participants but he's the only one ever to make it as a producer.

title: UNTOLD STORY OF THE

Without looking up, he said, Why don't you give this to the Egyptians?

title: IN BRIEF

For the latest week on record, M1, consisting of checking accounts and currency and coin in circulation, stood at $359.5 billion, up 4.1 percent over the last six months and 6.2 percent over the last year. Analysts have been expecting large jump in the money supply figures, and have suggested, following large revision in last week's MI total. that the numbers are suspect.

title: Saving Oil by Selling It
description: The shutdown of the Iranian oil industry has stretched world fuel supplies tight, increased American dependence on Arab sources and raised the prospect of shortage. Yet the oil fields of Alaska's North Slope are operating well below capacity, and development of other promising Alaskan fields has slowed. The cause is entangled in Federal and state regulations for the production and use of petroleum products. Fortunately, that tangle need not be unraveled completely solve the problem. The solution is curious but effective: reduce American reliance on imported oil by exporting oil, Alaskan oil. If Congress assents to a swap of Alaskan crude for Mexican crude owned by Japan, North Slope production should nearly double by the early 1980's.

title: Future Events; January Enders; Very Fine Fling; Thirsty Singles; Antique Dreams; Pops Go the Whistles
description: Jan. 24  A party for the Finest starts at 7:30 this evening at Police Headquarters, where mounted polic officers will greet guests, including Governor Carey, Mayor Koch and some former mayors, who will be piped into the building by the Police Department's Emerald Society Fife and Drum Corps. The police horses were acquired for the department through the New York City Police Foundation, the party's beneficiary, a private group that supports special needs in the department for which the city has no funds. Present and former police chiefs will be among the dancers to Bert Kent's orchestra. Everybody will sit down to dinner in the vast auditorium. Anyone who wants a tour of the building will get one. And then conies the disco. It's a wear-what-you-want night in a waydowntown place at 1 Police Plaza, just south of Chinatown, that few New Yorkers would ever get to see were it not for the public tours arranged by the foundation, which also has a Brooklyn outdoor education and leadership program, and helps with anticrime undercover taxicabs. And should the city be too poor to buy them, the foundation will try to raise money for bulletproof vests for police officers. Tickets: $150 from 7518170.

title: LOVE CANAL, U.S.A.
description: In the years since Rachel Carson's Silent Spring, a great national concern has arisen over air and water pollution. It now appears that pollution seeping into the earth itself has gone largely unnoticed and in some cases may be far more dangerous as a direct cause of cancer and other severe human illnesses. Toxic chemical waste, says John E. Moss, who was chairman of the House Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations before his retirement this month, may be the sleeping giant of the decade. Not until the nightmare of the Love Canal unfolded in Niagara County, N.Y.. last summer did Americans become aware of the vast dangers of ground pollution. But the problem since then seems only to be worsening.

title: A Minor Victory in the Wage War

The new contract between the nation's oil refiners and the Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers Union may not be all the Government might have wished, but it certainly is all anyone had any right to expect. The industry has avoided a strike and the na- tion has avoided what could have been the first serious blow to the President's antiinflation policy.

Hartford during most of this century has scarcely had the image of a swinging metropolis. Yet over the past dozen years or so the city that Mark Twain once called the best built and handsomest town I have ever seen has been undergoing a massive rejuvenation.

title: Cutting Loose With the Blues

In fact, overzealous fans recently went so far as to fashion a gigantic homemade trophy for the group, bearing the inscription: Best Damn Blues Band This Side of Chicago.

title: Martha Foley, Discoverer
description: THERE was no memorial service for Martha Foley  no funeral, no condolences sent or received. At the time of her death in 1977, at age 80, she was living in a small tworoom furnished apartment in Northampton, Mass. The only items in the apartment that were her own were some books, a multivolume Kraus reprint of Story magazine, a typewriter, and a used file cabinet that she'd bought from a local barbershop. And yet for half a century, this woman whose death  and life  went virtually unnoticed and unsung had been a major force in American literature. Editor of the annual Best American Short Stories collection for the previous 37 years, and before that cofounder and coeditor of Story magazine, she labored ceaselessly to find friends and homes for the American short story  for what Ted Solotarott in his introduction to the 1978 Best Stories calls the most beleaguered of our literary forms and the waif of the magazine and publishing industry.

The second half is a onehour version of Pinafore in costume. Mr. Meadmore's father, Norman, is the artistic director, following a 10year stint as a director for the D'Oyly Carte Company. We both go on as extras now and then, said Andrew, whose wife is the company's leading soprano and whose is the costume designer and wardrobe mistress. title: A LongSought Ancestor Finds A Place on the Tree of Man
description: Once it was so simple: Man descended from the apes. That was easy to believe because of the anthropocentric assumption that anything more primitive than man must be just a stage on the way to creatures eligible to vote. Discoveries in Africa from 1925 to the present have complicated the picture, and it is now thought that a million years ago and more, earth was populated with more or less manlike creatures, descended not from apes but some forefather of both apes and men. Some of these manlike creatures are indeed the ancestors of modern men; others, notably the robust australopithecines, were nobody's ancestors, and after 1.5 million years of coexistence with early men, they died out.

The Far- rents collected and edited a 20-volume anthology called Le Tresor des Pianistes, containing music from the 16th century to the middle of the 19th, and the Da Capo Press, under Miss Friedland's direction, has issued a facsimile edition in 23 chronologically arranged volumes, as was originally planned by the Farrencs.

title: Politics, Village Style
description: TARRYTOWN THE surroundings were modest and the manner informal as more than 40 members of the Westchester County Village Officials Association gathered for buffet supper of rigatoni and chicken in the cafeteria of the Olivetti Corporation here. As the meal came to an end, Mayor James McElroy of Elmsford, the president of the association,- which represents officials from 22 villages in the county, called the business session to order with a shrill whistle rather than a gavel.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Softcover plot). There was a touch of paradox in the air around Sniffen Court last Thursday evening. The cluster of quaint early 19thcentury houses on Manhattan's Murray Hill was the scene of a birthday party for the Quality Paperback Book Club, a mailorder club catering to the late 20thcentury's withit young people. The QPBC is the child of the 52-year-old Bookof-the-Month Club; its director, Lorraine Shanley, just 27.

title: PEOPLE
description: The ColgatePalmolive Company has named Keith Crane, president and chief operating officer since 1975, to replace David R. Foster as chief executive. The move fills half of the job Mr. Foster left for health reasons. He was also Colgate's chairman, and that position remains open.

title: C. P. Hall Fiance Of Deborah Mixer
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Mixer of Hanksville, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Britt Mixer, to Christopher Patrick Hall, son of Mr. and Mrs. James M. Hall of Summit. N.J.

title: JURY IN PUERTO RICO STUDIES 2 SLAYINGS
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Jan. 20 - A Federal grand jury has begun an investigation to determine whether the police were justified in killing two young advocates of Puerto Rican independence who were suspected of attempting to sabotage a Government communications tower.

title: Ski Touring
description: This is the time of year when farmers study seed catalogues; it is also a good time to collect brochures and to think about where you would like to spend your next vacation.

title: Party Leaders Criticized the Government Last Week But Did not Break With
description: ROME  The Italian Communists are at a crossroads, hesitating and pondering which way to go. Should they continue their de facto alliance with the Christian Democrats, the country's other leading party, or shoUld they provoke a break that would leave them where they were a few years ago as the perennial opposition party, strong enough to make Italy ungovernable but too weak and distrusted to assume even a share of government power?

title: Notre Dame Defeats South Carolina, 8273
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Jan. 20 (AP) Kelly Tripucka scored 22 points and Tracy Jackson, a reserve, had 21 today as topranked Notre Dame turned back South Carolina, 8273, in college basketball.

title: BEHIND THE BEST SELLERS
description: I rang up Mary Renault at her home in Camps Bay, Cape Town, South Africa, to ask her a few things about the state of the ancient and modern world. She lives in both. In her new novel about ancient Greece, The Praise Singer (Pantheon Hooks), she writes in the first person about the life of a sixthcentury bard during the time of the tyrants, the Persian Wars and the flowering of the arts. In her own life, the 73-year-old author lives up the slope of a mountain overlooking the sea, tending to her myths of the past while beyond, in a climate of rnntpmnt and despair, apartheid reigns.

title: Ann L. Leland Plans to Be Wed
description: Mrs. George H. Leland of New Vernon, N.J., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Ann Louise Leland, to Matthew Graham Lowe, son of Mr. and Mrs. Reginald J. Lowe of Chatham, N.J. The bride-to-be, an alumna of Elmira College, is the daughter also of the late Mr. Leland. Mr. Lowe is a graduate of Bucknell University.

description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Jan. 20 (Reuters).Cyprus has expressed concern about a decision by the United States, France, Britain and West Germany to provide economic aid to Tuikey that is not linked Ito progress in the negotiations to settle the Cyprus dispute, the Cypriot press agency said today. Turkish troops invaded Cyprus in 1974 and still occupy about a third of the island.

title: Other World Events
description: Persistence has won out for 3,000 Vietnamese crammed aboard a freighter off Hong Kong. After waiting a month, they were allowed to disembark last week. Officials relented after Britain, Canada and West Germany agreed to grant asylum to refugees already in Hong Kong camps.

title: First Refugees From Freighter Land in Hong Kong
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 20  An initial group of 372 Vietnamese refugees were taken ashore in Hong Kong under strict police control today after having waited for 29 agonizing days aboard the crowded, battered freighter Huey Fong outside the territorial waters ot this British colony.

title: Tennessee Capital Still Tangled by Pardons and Steps to Undo Them
description: NASHVILLE, Jan. 20  Within hours after former Gov. Ray Blanton was removed from office here Wednesday to stop him from freeing any more prisoners, a Nashville radio station was broadcasting a song entitled I Was Almost Commuted.

title: HOLE CLINIC
description: HEN faced with the task of hanging a wide mirror or very heavy picture frame on a wall, it is always better to try to drive screws for the mounting hardware into the 2-by-4 studs inside the wall, rather than merely use plastic plugs for plaster or hollowwall anchors for drywall construction. Long screws driven into wood are less likely to vibrate loose or pull out under stress - especially if the walls develop serious cracks.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: BONN  Under Chancellor Helmut Schmidt and his Foreign Minister (and coalition partner) HansDietrich Genscher, Bonn's foreign policy has entered a new phase  that of a reemerged European great power. Mr. Schmidt's foreign policy is the first to fully combine two elements: On the one hand, the heritage created by his predecessors  a secure Western base established by Konrad Adenauer and the opened channels of Ostpolitite and greater diplomatic freedom created by Willy Brandt  and, on the other hand, West Germany's new economic resources.

title: HONE CLINIC Mirror, Mirror on the Wall: How to Hang It There Safely
description: WHEN faced with the task of hanging a wide mirror or very heavy picture frame on a wall, it is always better to try to drive screws for the mounting hardware into the 2-by-4 studs inside the wall, rather than merely use plastic plugs for plaster or hollowwall anchors for drywall construction. Long screws driven into wood are less likely to vibrate loose or pull out under stress especially if the walls develop serious cracks.

title: Boos Turn to Cheers as Gov. Brown Addresses California Democrats
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 20 There was booing today when Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. began to speak to the California Democratic Convention, but only cheers were heard when he finished 90 minutes later.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 - The Demo- cratic National Committee and Ruth Car- ter Stapleton, President Carter's evange- list sister, have something in common: selected lists of the names, addresses and ZIP codes of some 10,000 past and poten- tial contributors.

title: Shipbuilding Strike Authorized
description: PITTSBURGH, Jan. 20 - Lloyd McBride, president of the United Steel Workers Unions, granted authority yesterday for a strike by Local 8888 at the Newport News, Va., shipbuilding and drydock company'of the Tenneco Corporation. The strike is authorized on or after Jan. 31. The company is the Navy's largest private shipbuilder.

title: Carol Fein, S.B. Ross, Lawyers, Are Married

title: U.S. Soccer Squads Regrouping
description: The United States Soccer Federation is making another effort to establish worldwide credibility for American soccer afters poor international show ing last month by the American Youth Word Cup squad.

title: Talk With Wilfrid  Sheed
description: IF Wilfrid Sheed had chosen to devote himself exclusively to criticism he could have picked up where Edmund Wilson left off. He didn't so choose, to which we owe the fine novels Max Jamison, People Will Always Be Kind and, most recently. Transatlantic Blues. Some of his most admired criticism appeared in the monthly columns he did for the Book Review under the heading The Good Word. Now, in a volume called The Good Word & and Other Words (Henry Robbins/ E.P. Dutton, $10.95), he collects most of them. The Other Words of the title are book reviews he wrote for us outside his column and pieces he published elsewhere.

title: INTERVIEW The Senate's Dean Is Still Going

title: Food
description: Chicken is and has been for centuries the bargain food at the meat counter, so it stands to reason that the lesser parts of poultry are the best buy ever. Those parts are, of course, the necks, backbones and wings. Chicken wings can be some of the most tempting parts of the bird. The skin is rich in flavor; the meat (so close to the bone) is admirably tasty, and the versatility of this part of the chicken is a blessing cooks. In proof, we offer here three completely different, but equally delectable, recipes for chicken wings.

title: GARDENING
description: THE winter winds doth blow. A time for gardeners to stay snug and warm inside. Their homes will be especially cozy they have a substantial collar of greenery around them. title: New Stress On Steel Middlemen
description: PHILADELPHIA - For six generations a member of the Potts family has been managing the Horace T. Potts Company, a steel service center founded in 1815. Last November, the company was sold to a United States subsidiary of CreusotLoire, a French maker ofspecialty steel. Though Horace T. Potts 3d remains as president, he expects to be the last of his family to head the company. It's going to be different, Mr. Potts says. It's far from being your own boss.

title: Police Chase the Blues Fora Jazz Trumpeter
description: Seven weeks ago someone broke into the Brooklyn apartment of a jazz musician, Lester Bowie, and stole his $2,000 trumpet. Mr. Bowie was desolate. Within hours, though, the police founit the trumpet in a nearby pawn shop and Mr. Bowie's blues were gone.

title: That'll Teach the Singer Children
description: John Singer was a short, ruddy man of 47 who was born in New York and soon after taken by his parents to Nazi Germany. The times being what they were, he joined the Hitler Youth Movement, an experience that evidently led him to prize racial purity but to hate regimentation. When he came back to the United States at 17. he brought both feelings with him. He moved to high mountain valley in Summit County, Utah, and set out to create a selfreliant life as a Fundamentalist Mormon. He built a log farmhouse and outbuildings, took a wife and they had seven children.

title: As Knicks Sag, So Do Leaders and Fans
description: It's not easy being Sonny Werblin, president of Madison Square Garden Corporation or Mike Burke, president of the Knicks. They oversee a big investment in the Knicks, but attendance is down sharply, the Knicks are playing poorly and there is constant discontent among the fans. Both have sat through games where the Knicks, once celebrated and cheered, have been booed when they were not playing well or when they lost big leads. The Knicks are resorting to promotional gimmickry to sell tickets. The Knicks already have had a Ball Day; coming is a Ski Mask Day.

title: ISRAEL BARS RETURN TO 2 ARAB VILLAGES
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 20 - With the at- tention of Israelis focused on the raid into southern Lebanon, on Palestinian bomb explosions in Jerusalem and on another American effort to revive the flagging Middle East peace talks, the Government quietly disclosed this week that it had no intention of permitting the return of Arab villagers to two small northern communi- ties they were forced to leave 30 years ago.

title: Super Bowl: 48 Views And Nonviews
description: The Super Bowl is one of the orost celebrated sporting events in the world  its magnetism and popularity seems to affect everyone differently. The New York Times polled a sampling of wellknown personalities from the arts, politics, and sports in an effort to learn what, if anything, they would be doing on the day of the Super Bowl, and which team they favored to win. The followMg list was compiled and edited by Eric Lincolmafter interviews by Ann Noble, Adam Shub, Marianne Costantinou, and Suzanne Daley.

title: Port Authority Nets $38 Million
description: ALBANY, Jan. 19 (UN) - The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey netted $38.4 million in 1977, according to report issued yesterday by New York State. The Department of Audit and Con- trol reported that bridges and tunnels were most profitable for the authority, netting $68.6 million, $2.9 million more than in 1976, and that the major loser was the Port Authority TrarsHodson train line, which lost $44 million on gross revenues of $14.6 million. The World Trade Center. paying $24.4 million in interest alone, lost $20.9 million.

title: Miss Tierney Becomes Bride Of Lieutenant
description: In St. James Roman Catholic Church in Red Bank, N.J., yesterday after- noon, Barbara Ann Tierney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard H. Tierney of Red Bank, became the bride of Lieut. (j.g.) Edward Peter Messmer, U.S.N., son of Edward F.. Messmer of East Meadow, L.I., and the late Geraldine Messmer. Msgr. Joseph F. Sheehan performed the ceremony, and me pas- tor, the Rev. Frederick Valentino, cele- brated the nuptial mass.

title: Can a Committee Revive the Beaumont?
description: When it was revealed last month that the Vivian Beaumont Theater in Lincoln Center was scheduled to reopen in late 1979 or early 1989 under a new artistic management, the news sent a seismographic wave through the theatrical community. It was not merely that many playgoers had become discouraged about the $10 million theater's ever opening again (it had, after all, been dark since July 1077, when Joseph Papp removed his New York Shakespeare Festival). People were also taken aback by the details of the new announcement. Instead of operating in traditional fashion under one or two artistic directors, the new Rearound will have a, artistic government consisting of five directors Woody Allen, Sarah Caldwell, Liviu Ciulei, Robin Phillips and Ellis Rabb and one playwright, Edward Albee. The executive director of the as-yet-unnamed company will be Richmond Crinkley, and the chairman of the company's board of directors will be John S. Samuels 3d. Both Mr. Crinkley, formerly the executive director of ANTA (American National Theater and Academy), and Mr. Samuels, a millionaire Texas businessman who has recently become involved in performing arts institutions, are relatively new forces in New York theater. Under this diversified leadership, the 1,100 seat Beaumont will be primarily devoled to classics, and the intimate 299si at Mitzi Newhouse to new plays.

title: ABOUT CARS Keeping in Tune for the Winter
description: riOR many drivers, a tuneup is the thing to do just before summer vacation trip. title: Geraldine Hogan Married to James Kaplan
description: In the Church Center for the United Nations at noon yesterday, Geraldine Hogan, a nutritionist, became the bride of James S. Kaplan, a lawyer. The Rev. George Nicholson, a Roman Catholic priest, and Rabbi Roy Rosenberg officiated.

title: 3Week Snarl Is Feared On Coast Transit System
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 20 - The Bay Area Rapid Transit system, once hailed as a spaceage method of relieving auto congestion and pollution, accomplished just the opposite this week. On Wednes- day a fire destroyed a rushhour com- muter train, killing one fireman and in- juring 46 others.

title: Debra H. Iowis Betrothed to James Veghte

title: Downtown Finds a New Role As Retail Hub
description: Downtown Manhattan has traditionally been a good place to make money; now it is becoming a good place to spend it.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Most of the first settlers from the Old World saw in this country only a howling wilderness to be subdued, wilderness that seemed an inexhaustible source of forest products. Now, more than three centuries later, there is a struggle to preserve a modicum of that wilderness in something like its original form.

title: MOSLEMS AND MY IN IRAN HOLD TALKS ON NATION'S FUTURE
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 20  The Iranian armed forces and Islamic leaders have opened delicate and highly tentative negotiations on the future of this strifetorn country in the wake of the departure of the Shah, informed diplomatic sources said tonight.

title: Bismarck To Hitler
description: By Gordon A. Craig. 825 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $19.95. German unity, from the Prussian victory over Austria in 1866, which established Prussian hegemony in Germany, to the defeat of 1945, which ended Germany's second and final bid for world power. It is a work great erudition, packed with detail, and of wide range, dealing with all aspects of government and social life.

title: Outdoor Sports in the Adirondack Mountains
description: One remote and quiet place to vacation at any time of the year is the area that is adjacent to the forever wild Adirondack Forest Preserve in northern New York State. For this time of the year, Adirondack Ski Tours is offering through midMarch fiveday wilderness vacations for $325 a person.

title: A Centennial Year For a Seed Company
description: In 1879 an upstate farmer named Joseph Harris sent out a seed catalogue to a few friends. This month the 1979 edition of the Harris Seed Catalogue will arrive in the mailboxes of over 250,000 home gardeners. In the intervening century, a farmhouse business blossomed into one of America's foremost seed houses.

title: Serban Takes On a Boy-Meets-Girl Musical
description: Joseph Papp, who is producing it, says he's doing it for love. Andrei Serban, who is direct;ing it, hopes it will provide theatergoers with an experi;ence that reaches the heart. Michel Legrand, who wrote the music for the original film version, says he has been trying for years to get someone to make a stage musical out of it.

title: Jane Wells Fiance Of Thomas Sadder

title: Eyeball-to-Eyeball Over Ski Goggles
description: KETCHUM, Idaho - This former mining town a mile south of Sun Valley seems an unlikely setting for a saga of classic business competition. But here on the Sun Valley Road, within a block of each other, are the two major producers of expensive fogresistant ski goggles - Scott U.S.A. and the Smith Goggle Company. They are bat- tling headto head, employing similar resources and marketing strategies, for domination of a welldefined market of some four million hardcore skiers.

description: The dream of living in England in our own cottage was going to come true at last. My husband and I had the month of April off and we found another couple to go with us. Then the search began. The four of us spent several evenings poring over Furnished Holidays in Britain and Where to Stay in the West Country.

After devoting five ane a half years to the book Mr Malamud, in a gentle but ver firm voice, said no, he would no state its theme in a discourse of a few minutes. That, he said without make would leave the reviewers. But in the next hour he did touch on other things: his passion for revision, the dark side of his art, th, fascination of teaching, the influence of an older generation.

Parents whose kids are in cults and who made their peace with the idea suddenly feel it's no longer a matter alternative life style but a matter of life and death,', he says.

description: NANTUCKET. Mass., Jan. 20 (UPI) The 630foot tanker Afghanistan, carrying 46 crew members and 230,000 barrels of gasoline, ran aground today off Nantucket, a Coast Guard spokesman said. title: Rise Reported in Child Neglect
description: THE crime of child neglect is democratic. It is likely to strike in wealthy Fairfield county communities as in the less affluent towns that dot New London County and it is as apt to victimize an adolescent as a toddler. More difficult to identify, prove and treat than either physical or sexual abuse, the number of cases of neglect is sharply increasing, according to state officials.

title: The Nation
description: Question: When is a good economic report a bad political report? Answer: When it shows the economy to have such energy that the slump most analysts expected to hit by summer looks to be postponed to late 1979, or even 1980, when politicking for the next election will be well under way.

title: The State Has a $22 Million Question
description: In a remote way, the Love Canal disaster in Niagara Falls  the deformed children, the displaced families, the $23 million spent on cleanup  can be blamed on the invention of alternating current.

title: Artists Put Down Roots in L.I. City
description: It may come as a surprise to the occupants of the Mayflower Ice Cream factory in Queens, but to BettyAnn Felderman the building is too Vermeer. Bloomingdale's in Manhattan may have become famous for its fashionable dry goods, but in Long Island City its water towers are what Mrs. Felderman has put on canvas and now she has her eye on a red Silvercup sign.

title: Researchers Help Provincetown In Move to Halt Migrating Dunes
description: PROVINCETOWN, Mass., Jan. 20 The Cape Cod National Seashore will start a research project this spring to try to learn how to stabilize shifting dunes that threaten to engulf part of this windbuffeted town at the tip of Cape Cod.

title: She Knows Balanchine Ballets by Heart
description: Adozen New York City Bal let dancers are at the New York State Theater re. hearsing a seven-year-old work by George Balanchine. Mr. Balanchine himself is not directing this runthrough; he is probably thinking ahead to his next ballet. Instead, a small woman perched on a stool in front of the dancers is communicating to them the fast. paced movements of the choreography for Stravinsky's Violin Concerto. An this woman  Rosemary Dunleavy knows by heart not just this work by dozens of Balanchine ballets. It is a: amazing feat of memory, to say the least.

title: B. & O. Train Derails
description: BOOTHWYN, Pa., Jan. 20 (UPI) -Five cars oia Baltimore & Ohio train, one believed to contain liquified chlorine, derailed today in Upper Chichester Township. The police said there was no leakage and no reports of injuries.

title: Khomeini Says He Plans to Return To Teheran Within Next Few Days

title: 18 Die, 3 Missing in Hoboken Fire; Inferno in Tenement Believed Set
description: HOBOKEN. N.J., Jan. 20  A fire believed set by an arsonist raced through a fivestory tenement building here early this morning. killing at least 18 members of three families who were trapped by the collapsing roof and stairwell.

title: Thailand Blocks Cambodians Seeking to Cross Border
description: TA PHRAYA, Thailand, Jan. 20  Five Thai border guards, their jungle fatigues laden with ammunition clips and grenades, lounged at a dusty roadside soup stand near here this afternoon, watching a Thai Air Force spotter plane dip in and out of Cambodian airspace.

title: No Matter How You Cut It, a Cord =128 cu.
description: YEARS ago, when everyone from foresters to farmers cut trees for firewood, and a fire blazed in every home, there was no standard measurement for quantity of firewood. Today, while nearly everything in the marketplace has come to be meted out in regulation quantities, one vestige of those early days remains: There is still no nationally binding measurement for wood.

title: Peru Ousts Chilean Ambassador
description: LIMA, Peru, Jan. 20 (Reuters)  Peru today expelled Chile's ambassador and executed a former airman for having given military secrets to Chile, the Government said. Julio Vargas Garayar, 27 years old, a retired noncommissioned officer, was shot by a firing squad after court martial convicted him of treason, the Air Force Ministry announced. The

title: MARIE GILLESPIE LANE
description: Marie Gillespie Lane, who was active in philanthropic endeavors, died yesterday at Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx. Mrs. Lane was 73 years old and lived in Rye. N.Y. Before that, she lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: The New Pope Comes to Confer With a Latin Church Militant
description: MEXICO CITY  On his first trip abroad since becoming pontiff, Pope John Paul II will arrive in Mexico this week on a delicate mission - to forestall an open rift between the conservative and progressive wings of Latin America's Roman Catholic Church. By coming to inaugurate the third Latin American Bishops' Conference in Puebla, the Pope gets an opportunity to define the role of the church in society and assert his personal authority over the region's 300 million Catholics.

title: Pension Case

title: Super Curfew Adventures
description: MIAMI, Jan. 20  One of the Super Bowl commandments is that the players are tucked into bed like small children the night before the game, never to wander. But history disagrees. The night before Super Bowl I,not a Packer was stirring. Or so Vince Lombardi thought. His assistant coaches had checked the Sports of The Times hotel rooms of Green Bay's gladiators and all were accounted for. But what Vince tornbarcli did not know was that under the blankets of his bed, Max McGee was wearing a suit and tie. Vince Lombardi had established .a $5,000 fine for any Packer breaking the team's 11 o'clock curfew, but Max McGee had caught only three passes that 1966 season.

As if to prove the truth of the author's vision of the Soviet world, the manuscript of this Gogolstyle Catch22 had to be smuggled out of Russia to be published.

Instead, wrapped in cotton wool and notarnish bags, much old family silver has languished in hidden wall safes or in bank vaults, brought out into the light once a year to be checked against insurance inventories or, as is happening more frequently these days, to be sold.

title: Russell Sherman in Piano Recital
description: Russell Sherman, a Bostonbased pianist who has not appeared frequently in New York, but has built a following here through recprdings, gave recital at the Metropolitan Museum on Thursday night. A slightly built man with tremendous keyboard taciiity ana a markedly individual approach to everything he plays, Mr. Sherman indicated at the outset that this would not he an ordinary recital. Four short pieces by Brahms were extraordinarily expansive and inward, the pianist giving the impression in three Intermezzos that he was performing for himself, unaware that he was being overheard. There was some quirky playing here, but much of it was also entrancingly sweet and sensitive.

title: Decorating
description: Those vases, candlesticks and pretty little boxes that designers call decorative accessories  the nonessentials that lie beyond function, yet fall short of art  are currently under the gun. Too busy, too difficult to main- tain, argue the less-is-more set, though all but the crankiest minimalists agree that a room looks forlorn without any accessories. On the other side of the issue are the champions of clutter who maintain that a bit of dust is a small price to pay for the glitter and romance of a table topped with treasures. Regardless of which position one takes, a problem persists: Where to find objects of beauty or distinction that deserve to be displayed? Traditionally, such things were gathered on travels to exotic, farflung bazaars. Today, however, shopping expeditions tend to be reduced to lunchhour sprints through midtown. Fortunately, even in these tamer precincts, objects exist to satisfy collectors of all persuasions.

title: Headliners
description: Into the thunderous breach created when President Caner fired Bella Abzug as chairman of the President's National Advisory Committee on Women has stepped, at least temporarily, Marjorie Bell Chambers, who is national president of the American Association of University Women, former president of Colorado College for Women and a registered Republican. Though a certified feminist on the issues, Mrs. Chambers, herself no stranger to elective office  she sits on the city council of Los Alamos, N. M.  is nevertheless reputed to be milder and more lowkey in her approach to them than Mrs. Abzug. Though she lobbied on Capitol Hill for the successful extension of ratification time for the Equal Rights Amendment, she has avoided involvement in more controversial issues such as lesbian's rights and abortion. No one is quite certain what kind committee Mrs. Chambers will be chairman of, though. Of its 90 members, 26 were said to have resigned in protest over Mrs. Abzug's dismissal, but since then some have reconsidered their resignations.

title: 'Max Havelaar,' a Dutch Film About the Evils of Colonizing:The Cast
description: "Max Havelaar," the Dutch film that is competing for this year's Oscar as best foreign-language film, is an exceedingly long, sincere, elaborately produced contradiction in terms. It's a movie that exposes the evils of 19th-century Dutch colonialism in terms that are so naive and romantic that the audience will always be ahead of it even while taking in the exotic flora and fauna of Indonesia, where much of the film was shot. It's as if the Hardy Boys had dipped into the works of Frantz Fanon and decided that now was the time to grant independence to Algeria. The movie's heart is in the right place, but its mind is muddled.The film, which opens today at the Plaza Theater, is the work of Fons Rademakers, one of the more prominent directors in the Netherlands. It's based on a 19th-century novel by Multatuli, the pen name of Eduard Douwes Dekker, a Dutch civil servant who became his nation's Harriet Beecher Stowe, fictionalizing his experiences on behalf of justice for the wretched of the Dutch colonized earth in the East Indies.The title character, played by Peter Faber with the uncomplicated vigor one associates with old-fashioned costume pictures, believes himself to be a man with a mission to reform Dutch colonial rule in Java. He's the sort of fellow who doesn't hesitate to dive into shark-infested waters to save his son's small dog or to intervene when some gross white settlers are verbally abusing a pretty Javanese girl. One has the feeling that Max would help an old lady to cross a street even if she didn't want to go, though the movie makes nothing of the vanity that is integral to his obsession.When Max is posted to the poor Javanese province of Lebak, he attempts to expose the corruption of the native regent only to earn the enmity of his superiors in the civil service and of the regent. Ultimately it isn't the regent who gets bounced, but Max.The physical scale of "Max Havelaar" is so big that it almost invests the film's essential clumsiness with the properties of myth. At its best moments, which are very few, the movie has a kind of fairy-tale simplicity. Occasionally it aspires to a sophistication that seems completely out of character, as in one scene in which Max confounds his dinner guests with a definition of beauty that seems beyond the comprehension of the man we know.Contradictions of all sorts sap the movie's credibility. Mr. Rademakers frames the narrative with heavily ironic shots of righteous, well-fed Dutch burghers singing for the salvation of their colonial subjects, but ends his film with a montage showing Dutch soldiers putting down rebellion in a manner that seems meant to recall My Lai. Because the Netherlands did not give up its East Indian colonies until after World War II, one must wonder how the locals survived until then.Must peculiar is the film's introduction, early on, of the titles of some of the works that Max Havelaar wrote ("Marriage as Prostitution," "Slavery in Europe"), which suggest that he might have a mind much more interesting and complex than is demonstrated by the film itself.Though "Max Havelaar" now runs close to three hours, one suspects that some helpful footage has been cut. Either that or Dutch viewers know the story well enough to fill in what seem to be gaps to us. To someone coming on the film cold, "Max Havelaar" is a very mixed pleasure, Its most interesting aspect is the color photography of Jan De Bont, which, in certain sequences, recalls the muted tones that John Huston sought in his "Moby Dick" by (if I remember correctly) printing a black-and-white negative over the color negative. The purpose was to create the effect of a sort of liberated sepia  that is, a sepia in which other colors supplement the sepia tones. Whatever the method, the results are sometimes very beautiful.

title: Sporting Gear
description: Tennis players who have trouble keeping the ball in bounds when they hit hard should like the Tournament 17 string. The narrower diameter creates more bite, and this, combined with the string's low trampoline effect, increases control. The best results are achieved with high-resiliency racquets, such as those made of steel, aluminum, graphite fiberglass. Another feature of the string is that it is impervious water. Many pro shops carry the Tournament 17 and will restring racquets for $20 to $28 each, but it can also be ordered in a 36foot coil for $7.50. The manufacturer is Holland Products, Box 6085, Lancaster, Pa. 17603, (717) 3944319.

title: Wrong Route for Nuclear Shipments

title: Aid to Neediest Tops $1 Million For the 9th Year

title: Venezuela: Economic Star Dims
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 21 -Venezuela, once Latin America's brightest economic star because of its enormous income from petroleum, closed its books for 1978 with its biggest balance-of-payments deficit in history, a growing foreign debt, a downward trend in oil revenues and increasing dependence on imported goods and services.

title: World News Briefs
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 21 (Reuters) - Clashes were reported today in Cambodia between the troops loyal to the routed Government of Pol Pot, the Cambodian Prime Minister, and forces controlled by Vietnam.

title: Bonn Offers Aid Package To German Shipbuilders
description: BONN, Jan. 21 - The Government has unveiled a plan to increase aid to West Germany's shipbuilders, thus reinforcing the position of shipbuilding as one of the most heavily subsidized business sectors of the world economy.

title: Sandra R. Shaiman Wed To Bruce Steiner, Lawyer
description: Sandra Ren Shaiman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Shaiman of West Orange, N.J., was married yesterday to Bruce Darrell Steiner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius Steiner of Jericho, L.I. The ceremony was performed at the Town and Campus in West Orange by Rabbi Oscar Kline of Maplewood, N.J.

title: Westchester Disputes Business Survey
description: WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 20 - Westchester government officials, stung by a survey of corporate leaders that indicated increasing dissatisfaction with the county as a business location, have called the results misleading and, in some cases, contradictory.

title: Topics
description: Some years back, the Scouting movement tried to, make itself more relevant to city youth by stressing urban survival skills. Last week, 26 Girl Scouts participated in a camping outing on one of the tallest mountains in New York City.

title: Recital: Judith Blegen In PoetryInspired Songs
description: ON the surface, Judith Blegen's recital Saturday night at the 92d Street Y.M.Y.W.H.A. was a model of its kind. Miss Blegen, unlike most opera singers, takes naturally to the concert hall and She fillS it easily With a lignt nut Urideniably prettx, evenly textured soprano. Furthermore, she sang an enterprising and unhackneyed program built around songs inspired by English and American poets.

title: Underwriters to Set Interest Today For a Note Issue by New York City
description: At 9 o'clock this morning a conference call is to take place between New York and San Francisco that will determine whether New York City takes a first step into the publiccredit market after four years of depending on pension funds, hank and the Federal Government.

description: COLORADO SPRINGS, Jan. 21 (UPI) - The incidence of child abuse among military personnel stationed at Fort Carson is double that of local civilians because most of the Army families are poor and under severe pressure, a psychiatrist said today.

description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 21 was not clear today whether Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. or Assembly Speaker Leo McCarthy won yesterday's shootout at the California Democratic Convention, but it was clear that things are not going to be the same around the California State Capitol.

description: The Right. Rev. Better-Be-Good has just delivered an impassioned oration from the Book of Bad Breath.

title: John Wayne Reported Improving
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 21 (UPI) - John Wayne shows continued improvement following cancer surgery Jan. 12, the U.C.L.A. Medical Center reported today. Tice hospital issued a short statement on the 71-year-old actor's condition: Mr. Wayne continues to improve. His vital signs are stable.

title: Foreign Firms Join Big Board
description: The New York Stock Exchange announced that the first wholly Europeanowned securities firms would start trading on the exchange on Feb. 1. They are the Europartners Securities Corporation, which is jointly Owned By live European GOMM, and the Transatlantic Securities Company, a unit of Lombard Odier & Company, a Swiss investment banking house.

title: Solomon Plans to Resign as Chief Of G.S.A., White House Asserts
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 - A White He spokesman said today that Jay Solomon plans to resign as administrator of the giant, scandalplagued General Services Administration in the next few months.

title: 2 REPORTED SEEKING TO QUIT IRAN PANEL THAT REPLACED SHAH
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 21 - Two members of the regency council formed to excercise the Shah's powers in his absence have reportedly asked to resign in response to pressure from Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini. Prime Minister Shahpur Bakhtiar said the report was untrue and insisted that he would never give in to the Moslem leader's demands that he step down.

title: Dissent Voiced On Plan to Still Cape Foghorn
description: NORTH TRURO, Mass., Jan. 17 - A Coast Guard proposal to silence the foghorn at Highland Light here, near the tip of Cape Cod, is being greeted by grumblings of discontent from local fishermen that have yet to reach the Coast Guard's ears.

title: Letters
description: I have just read George Nodelman's Jan. 4 letter, adding still more perspective to the thought and controversy. generated by the recent Oregon trial, on rape of a woman by her husband. I am truly appalled by Mr. Nodelman's outlook on both this particular perversity of rape and his misunderstanding of the crime as a whole. His observations are also an extremely frightening insight into a society that has developed so acute an understanding of rape that it actually appears to condone this action.

title: Ford Reports the Shah Felt Let Down by U.S.
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 21 (UPI) - Former President Gerald R. Ford says the Shah of Iran told him during their meeting in Aswan, Egypt, that he is disappointed at how little support he got from the Carter Administration during his last weeks in Teheran.

description: EVERYONE in New York City knows about the Joffrey Ballet but not everybody knows about the Joffrey organization's junior company, the Joffrey II Dancers, simply because the group spends most of its time performing elsewhere in the country.

description: PASADENA. Calif., Jan. 21 (AP) Leaders of the Worldwide Church of God, which is under investigation by the state, will leave California to seek a safe haven. a top aide said today.

description: MIAMI, Jan. 21 - In the crowded, tiny locker room, the first man to be surrotmded was Thomas Henderson, the symbol of the Dallas Cowboys. He was doing his best to fight back tears.

description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Jan. 21 (AP) - Jimmy Connors beat Eddie Dibbs, 62, 36, 75, in the final of the 5175,000 Birmingham international indoor tennis tournament today.

description: MOSCOW, Jan. 21 (AP) The Kremlin has awarded Patrick Clancy, chairman of the Socialist Party of Australia, the Order of People's Friendship: the Soviet news agency Tass reported today. Tass said Mr. Clancy was honored on his 60th birthday, for his energetic activities for the development of friendly relations between the peoples of Australia and the Soviet Union.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: W. Paul Tippett has an adjective selector in his office. Mr. Tippett is the new president of the American Motors Corporation. His office is in Detroit, and an adjective selector is a new weapon that A.M.C. executives can use in their effort to turn their company's image around.

description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 21- The Shah is gone, but he isn't really gone, said 23-year-old Iranian chemicalengineering student this morning at the University of Southern California. They have replaced tyranny with another. Balthtiar must go!

title: Frederick Wilcox Dupee, Critic And a Partisan Review Founder
description: Frederick Wilcox Dupee, professor emeritus of English at Columbia University, literary critic and a founding editor of the Partisan Review, died Friday at his home in Carmel, Calif. He was 74 years old.

title: Protecting Judges and the Public
description: Independence is one of the most valued features the Federal judiciary under the Constitution. But re. sponsiveness is an indispensable quality for American institutions. Can both be achieved at the same time? Last year the Senate posed a serious threat to judicial independence by passing a bill to permit removal of Federal judges by a method short of impeachment. Fortunately the House didn't even consider the bill. And now there are signs that the Senate, also, is moving toward a more modest and defensible proposal.

title: Boeing Contract for Grumman
description: The Boeing Company announced yesterday that it had awarded a major contract to the Grumman Corporation of Bethpage, L.I., to build a substantial part of the Boeing 757, a new fuel-efficient widebodied jet that is scheduled to PO into service in late 1980.

title: Outdoors: HistoryRich Unspoiled Island
description: PORTSMOUTH ISLAND, N.C.ENSCONCED in a pit blind on remote Shell Island in Core Banks Sound, squinting through the pelting rain at distant flights of ducks and geese, I became singularly aware of the sometimes ludicrous lengths to which a waterfowler will go for his sport. Joel Arrington of Raleigh, N.C., and I had begun our vigil on the island, a narrow shell heap with sparse vegetation perhaps a mile from Portsmouth Island, a halfhour before dawn, and eight hours later we had fired only two shots, bagging one widgeon.

title: News Summary

The Ayatollah has said that when he returned to Iran he would replace the regency council with an Islamic revolutionary council. [Page 1, Column 6.]

description: PHILADELPHIA Jan. 21 (AP) Food Fair Inc. has announced a preliminary consolidated net loss of $52.5 million, or $7.13 a share, on sales of $2.8 billion for the fiscal year ended July 29, 1978.

description: After a calm in the sea of televison comes the storm. The sluggish competition among the networks that has prevailed since the Christmas season lull that filled the schedules with reruns, news documentaries and secondrate movies - has been a respite to prepare for the biggest contest of the television season, known as the February sweeps. .

Alfred L. Atherton Jr. But he added that the decisions would not be made public until Mr. Atherton bad passed them on to the Egyptian Government.

National Hockey League clubs such as the Montreal Canadiens, the blinders and the Philadelphia Fivers are the No. 1 red flags, but weak teams like the St. Louis Blues and the Minnesota North Stars seem only to turn the Rangers into pussycats.

description: HOBOKEN, N.J., Jan.21 - Firefighters found the badly charrud body of a 19XX victim today in the rubble of a tenement building where authorities say an arsonist set off a blaze in a stairwell early Saturday morning.

description: MIAMI, Jan. 21  The big play of Super Bowl XIII today was a penalty a 33yard assessment against the Dallas Cowboys when Bennie Barnes, their left cornerback, was called for pass interference, specifically for tripping Lynn Swarm of the Pittsburgh Steelers midway in the fourth auarter.

title: Commodities
description: TODAY promises to be an unusually long one for traders on the New York Cotton Exchange, although the final bell will actually sound 10 minutes earlier, at 2:50 P.M. The reason is that at 3 P.M. the Government will issue its first 1979 estimate of nIantine intentions by cotton farmers.

title: Photograph Shows Mrs. Carter With Suspect in Mass Slayings
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (UPI) White House photographer took a picture last spring of Rosalynn Carter shaking hands with John Wayne Gacy, a mass murder suspect, and the First Lady later autographed it for him, the White House said today.

title: NEW YORK IS FACING VAST JOB TURNOVER
description: Revised Federal regulations may require that more than 7,000 New York City employees be laid off and replaced on Oct. 1 in a massive labor turnover that may alter the quality of the city's work force. The revised regulations have already affected Mayor Koch's budget plan.

title: Shift in Philosophy Splits New Mexico Democrats
description: ALBUQUERQUE, Jan. 21 - A weeklong battle between liberals and conservatives has left Democrats as only the nominal majority in the New Mexico Legislature.

title: EL SALVADOR REGIME ACCUSED ON RIGHTS
description: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 21  The InterAmerican Human Rights Commission has accused El Salvador's rightwing military Government of murdering political opponents and of torturing others in clandestine orison cells.

title: Khomeini Demands Review of Iran's Foreign Deals
description: NEAUPHLE-LE-CHATEAU, France, Jan. 21 - The Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini said today that all business contracts Iran had placed with American and other foreign companies should be re- viewed and those that go against the in- terests of our people should be canceled.

title: Bridge:
description: Assumptions by a Declarer Can at Times Be Hopeless A declarer who faces a difficult task in a game contract must often make some assumptions about the lie of the adverse cards. He frequently will say to himself: I must assume favorable breaks in the key suits, for otherwise I have no chance.

title: Stephen Kals Weds Willys H. Schneider
description: Willys Hope Schneider and Stephen Andrew Kals, New York lawyers, were married yesterday at the Regency Hotel. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Amiel Wohl and Rabbi Immanuel Lubliner.

title: The City
description: The cost of feeding a family of four rose by 10.8 percent in New York City in the past year, a rate almost three times higher than any year-to-year increase since 1975, officials reported.

title: Algerians to Pick Leader Feb. 7
description: ALGIERS, Jan. 21 (Reuters)  Elections to choose a successor to President Houari Boumediene, who died in December, will be held Feb. 7, the Government said today, with the results to be announced two days later. The sole candidate will be selected by a congress of the ruling National Liberation Front that starts on Saturday.

title: Pittsburgh Wins in Super Bowl, 3531
description: In the highestscoring game of the Super Bowl series, the Pittsburgh Steelers defeated the Dallas Cowboys yesterday, 3531, at Miami. Pittsburgh became the first team to win three Super Bowls, and Terry Bradshaw, the Steelers quarterback, was the unanimous choice for the mostvaluable player of the game. The National Football League's championship contest was the finest performanceof Bradshaw's professional career as he passed for 318 yards and four touchdowns. He set Super Bowl records in both categories.

title: Skiing: Neureuther Wins Cup Slalom
description: ICITZBUEHEL, Austria, Jan. 21 (UPI) Christian Neureuther of West Germany, a 29-year-old veteran who has twice returned from selfimposed retirement, edged the three: time World Cup champion, Ingemar Stenmark of Sweden, today for first place in a World Can slalom race.

title: TV SPORTS
description: TONIGHT

title: 2 LIBERAL SENATORS MOVING TO PROTECT SECURITY OF TAIWAN
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 Senators Edward M. Kennedy and Alan Cranston, both supporters of President Carter's normalization of relations with China, will open a drive tomorrow to assure that Taiwan will retain some of the security assurances in the mutualdefense treaty after it is terminated at the end of this year.

title: Dividend Meetings; Partial list of scheduled meetings for week follow?.; MONDAY;  TUESDAY; WEDNESDAY; THURSDAY; FRIDAY
Duet Susan Carew, Lawrence Raiken
description: SUSAN CAREW, soprano, and Lawrence Raiken, baritone, put together an unconventional program of duets and (counting on the assistance of baritone Edward Ehinger) a miniature opera to introduce themselves as a duo at the 18th Street Playhouse on Tuesday night. They sang Rossini's Cat Duet, the Fly. Duet from Offenbach's Orphte aux Enfers and a scene from Gilbert and Sullivan's The Pirates of Penzance in the first portion of the program and filled the second with Donizetti's Rita. Norman Carey was the piano acaxnpanist.

title: Music: Vienna Choir Boys Both Cherubic and Wry
description: ONE of the nice things about the Vienna Choir Boys, who were heard Saturday night at Carnegie Hall, is their knack for presenting cherubic entertainment without overdoing the sweetness. With their pure voices and innocent, earnest faces, the choir boys automatically provide enough sugar to satisfy any normal musical appetite. What keeps the show from cloying is that it always includes a cunningly miniaturized opera or operetta in which sentimentality is parodied rather than encouraged.

title: A Quick Fix for Turkey
description: The rescue operation for Turkey that was launched at the Guadeloupe summit seeks to inject a vital political element into a financial logjam. The United States, West Germany, Britain and France are aiming at more than emergency and mediumterm aid for the country at NATO's southern flank. Their obiective. wisely. is to make it politically as well as economically feasible for Prime Minister Ecevit to apply the main .austerity measures that are .demanded of him by the International Monetary Fund and Turkey's private creditors.

title: Vladimir Vysotsky, Balladeer Of Soviet Underground, in Debut
description: IN his book, The Russians, Hedrick Smith describes Vladimir Vysotsky as the most popular of all the Russian underground balladeers. A wellknown film and stage actor (his roles include Hamlet and Brecht's Galileo), he has released at least five official disks, and his more trenchant songs are eagerly distributed from hand to hand through tape recordings.

title: Golf: Crenshaw Fires A 61 for 4shot Lead
description: PHOENIX, Jan. 21 (AP) - Ben Crenshaw, adjusting his putting stroke in the middle of the round, fired a spectacular 10-under-par 61 today and established a fourstroke lead going into today's third and final round of the weatherabbreviated Phoenix open golf tournament.

title: 'Hillbilly Women Is Set For Premiere on Feb. 16
description: Hillbilly Women, a new play by Elizabeth Stearns, will have its premiere on Feb. 16 at the Actor's Studio, 432 West 44th Street. It is based on book of the same name by Kathy Kann that profiled a group of Appalachian women.

title: Cutting of Health Plans Abroad Expected to Affect U.S. Debate
description: WASHINGTON. Jan. 21 Record rates of inflation in the cost of medical care are causing some of the world's indust rial nations to cut back on pioneering lifelong health programs.

title: Mite Unit Bid for Rivet
description: The Mite Corporation announced that, subject to certain conditions, Mite Holdings Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary, proposed to make an offer to purchase any and all of  the outstanding shares of the Chicago Rivet and Machine Company for $28 a share in cash. Based on the 866,264 common shares outstanding of Chicago Rivet, the proposal is valued at $2A.2 million.

title: Stage. Broadway Songs Bv Arthur Schwartz
description: DANCING IN THE DARK, the anthology of Arthur Schwartz music at the Manhattan Theater Club Caba ret, is more cabaret act than show, but that should not diminish one's enjoyment of the evening. Not every revue can be Ain't Misbehavin  In contrast to the Fats Waller musical that charged out of the Manhattan Theater Club into a long. run on Broadway. Dancing in the Dark is lowkey and mildmannered, a melodic sheaf of songs from a veteran Broadway composer.

title: Washington Watch; Steven Rattner; Value Added Tax: Is U.S. Ready?; Changes for Leading Indicators; ForeignOwned Businesses in U.S.; Another New Publication; Briefcases
description: WASHINGTONAnew tax is waiting in the wings. Congressional tax leaders are pushing for enactment of a value added tax, a sort of national sales tax. The Administration opposes the idea on the grounds that it is inflationary and that it discriminates against the poor. But V.A.T. is likely, ponetheless. to become an issue on Capitol Hill.

title: Shah Plans to Leave Egypt Today
description: ASWAN, Egypt, Jan. 21 - Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, who left Iran five days ago in what could become permanent exile, will depart from Egypt tomorrow. Egyptian officials said tonight.

title: Chess
description: Soviet Union's Champions Keep Their Ranks Closed No young hopeful made a breakthrough into the tiny circle of the top prize winners in the 46th championship tourney of the Soviet Union in Tbilisi. Mikhail Tal. a former world champion, and Vitali Zeshkovsky, another well-established grandmaster, shared first prize with 116 scores, while Lev Polugaevsky, a world championship candidate in the last two cycles, took third place with 107.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22  A $100,000 new paint job for the White House and $100,000 new roof for the Vice Preside:it's residence on Massachusetts Avenue are two of the larger housekeeping items included in the new budget of the Executive Office of the President.

title: The Coach Everybody Knows Now
description: MIAMI, Jan. 22 - Now that his Pittsburgh Steelers had won the Super Bowl for the third time, Chuck Noll mentioned today that he planned to take a few days off. Then he was asked what he would do on those days off.
