title: Citicorp Commercial Paper
description: The average rate on Citicorp's 90 day commercial paper declined yesterday for the fourth consecutive week as the bankholding company sold $100 million of the shortterm notes at an average rate of 10.378 percent, down fvom 10.651 percent last week and from 11.102 percent a month ago. The company, parent of Citibank, received $592 million of orders for the notes at rates ranging from 10.350 to 10.380 percent.

title: Queens School Board Challenges Chancellor's Power to Suspend It
description: A Queens school board, in its latest bat- tle against racial and ethnic surveys and quotas, has started a challenge in State Supreme Court against powers of the Chancellor of Schools to suspend or re- move local boards.

title: ResearchCottrell Pact
description: ResearchCottrell Inc. said yesterday that it had signed a preliminary agreement to purchase the Power Application and Manufacturing Company (Pamco) of Denver for more than $16 million in cash. Pamco designs and fabricates products, mostly for gas transmission, oil and gas drilling and production, mining and agriculture.

title: The City
description: Pleas of not guilty were entered and bail was denied as three teenagers were arraigned yesterday on charges of murdering a subway tokenseller by setting her afire in a booth in which two women were working, the Queens Dis- trict Attorney's office said. Two of the defendants, William Prout, 18 years old, and Peter Grassia, 16, were re- turned to custody and the third, Linda Krauss, 18, was ordered to undergo a mental examination.

title: C.A.B. Urges Lower London Air Fare
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (UPI)  The head of the Civil Aeronautics Board warned today that his agency might strip Pan American World Airways and Trans World Airlines of valuable routes to London if they failed to cut fares on those routes this summer.

title: Germans Are Caught Up By Holocaust Telecasts
description: COLOGNE. West Germany, Jan. 23 With the baby in bed, a bottle of white wine and a bowl of pistachio nuts on the table, HansChristoph and Ursula von Lindeiner sat down in front of the television last night and turned on Holocaust.

title: Well Pollution Termed Rising
description: The problem of polluted wells in the New York metropolitan area is becoming increasingly severe, according to health officials.

title: Radio
description: 6-9 A.M., WKCR. Rudepoema; Quartet No. 17; Guitar Concerto; Bachianas Brasikiras, VillaLobos.

title: Dust Blast at Grain Elevator Kills One Worker and Injures Another
description: LEXINGTON, Feb., Jan. 23 (UPI) - A grain dust explosion accompanied by a huge ball of fire ripped through a grain elevator today, knocking two employees more 75 yards away from the structure onto the frozen ground below.

title: Israelis and Palestinians Intensify Shelling ofEach Other Over Border
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 23- Palestin- ian gunners fired rockets into northern Israeli towns today, and the Israelis re- sponded with the heaviest shelling of tar- gets in southern Lebanon since their inva- sion of last March.

title: Breakdown in Nicaraguan Talks Creates New Problems for Carter
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23  The apparent collapse of a 15week effort by a threenation mediation team to negotiate a solution of Nicarggua's civil strife has left the Carter Administration with serious new political problems both in Central America and at home.

title: Albany Called Hurt by U.S. Budget
description: ALBANY, Jan. 23 Although the number of dollars it gets from the Federal Government under the budget submitted by President Carter yesterday will re main about the same, New York State will end up shortchanged because of the effects of inflation and the need to spend more as a result of some of the proposed programs in the budget, the director of the state's Washington office said today.

title: Chicago Notes Are Sold at 5.9% to 6%
description: Chicago, unlike New York City. has not failed in recent years to make timely repayment in cash on its notes, and this distinction helped it sell shortterm securities yesterday yielding 6 percent or less, well below the 8 percent on New York's new issue now being marketed.

title: 60Minute Gourmet
description: ONE of the basics in food preparation - perhaps the most important basic, in fact is the balance of flavors in any given recipe. In a salad dressing, for example, the ratio of oil to vinegar lemon juice is vital. The same can be said for nuances in flavors and what marries well with what. It is an indisputable fact that some flavors complement certain foods better than others. As you learn more about cooking, you realize that nutmeg complements cheese dishes, that the flavor of rosemary teams well with veal and chicken and liver, that garlic and oil go well in robust tomato sauces, and so on.

title: West Chemical In Bankruptcy
description: After two years of losses, West Chemical Products Inc., said yesterday that it had filed a petition under Chapter XI of the Federal Bankruptcy Act with the clerk of the United States District Court in New York City.

title: Article 1 -- No Title
description: Article 1 -- No Title

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Three former officials of the Franklin National Bank were convicted on charges of conspiracy to falsify bank records to conceal foreignexchange losses that led to the collapse of the bank in October 1974 in the largest American bank failure on record. [Page A1.)

title: An Englishman's Necktie: Thereby Hangs a Tale
description: LONDON

title: Mrs. Ramsay Convicted of Plotting A Kidnapping, Freed on 2 Counts
description: Maria Petra Ramsay was convicted yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan of conspiring to kidnap her former husband, Joseph Gales Ramsay 3d, the 82-year-old heir to a $7 million for- tune who divorced her in 1975 and termi- nated her temporary alimony.

title: M. WILLIAM PETERS
description: M. William Peters, assistant treasurer of the SCM Corporation, whose principal products include office equipment, foods and chemicals, died of cancer Friday at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 53 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Bridge:
description: The absence of its star partnership did not prevent New York's most-successful squad from winning yet another title during the last weekend.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: KILL DEVIL HILLS, N.C. - When the telephone rang in my room at 4 A.M. at the Sea Ranch Hotel, it was, I must confess, with considerable pleas- ure that I thanked the establishment's clerk for waking me, then rolled over and returned to sleep.

title: 2 Union Aides Are Arraigned On Bribe Count
description: Two teamsters union officials who al- legedly coerced WNET/Channel 13 into breaking its contract with a moving com- pany of which the officialsdid not approve were indicted yesterday on charges of soliciting a bribe from the president of the moving company.

title: Bid by Montgomery Ward
description: A spokesman for the Mobil Corporation said yesterday that negotiations were under way between its subsidiary, the Montgomery Ward Company and the Allied Stores Corporation for the purchase of Allied's AlmartJ.B. Hunter discount store division. The Mobil spokesman said that consideration was being given to purchase of all 10 of the Ahnart stores by Montgomery Ward. Among them are three in Memphis plus locations in Louisville, Ky Knoxville, Tenn.; Wilmington, Del., and Rochester.

title: Carter Is Chided on Tastes in Food
description: PARIS

title: Economic Scene
description: Leonard Silk

title: Deputy Mayor on the Firing Line
description: New York's Mayor Koch has placed a heavy bur- den on Haskell Ward, his new Deputy Mayor for Human Services, who will also be Health Services Ad- ministrator and chairman of the Health and Hospitals Corporation. Mr. Ward, who is black, comes from the unfinished and sometimes chaotic job of reorganizing the city's antipoverty programs, an experience that did little for his reputation among black and Hispanic lead- ers. Now, he will be at the center of a much hotter controversy about cuts In the city's health care system.

title: Article 4 -- No Title
description: REMEMBER THE NEEDIESTI

title: Gasoline Prices Seen Increasing
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23  Secretary of Energy James R. Schlesinger told the Joint Economic Committee of Congress today that gasoline prices would rise about four cents a gallon this year because of inflation and the recent 19.5 percent oilprice increase by members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

title: Around the Nation
description: SAN DIEGO, Jan. 23 (AP)  More than 2,000 union workers at farms that produce nearly onethird of the nation's winter lettuce crop were off the job today in a strike that could mean still higher lettuce prices for consumers. Negotiators were meeting in San Diego. .

title: Planning Board Is Against a Tower On 62d St. as Dangerous Precedent
description: The New York City Planning Commis- sion yesterday informed the developer of a proposed highrise apartment tower on 62d Street behind the Knickerbocker Club on Fifth Avenue that it would oppose his project as a dangerous precedent for midblock development.

title: Going OUT  Guide
description: STYLE SETTER Edward VII got into the family business quite late. 1901, when he was 60 years old, he became King of Great Britain and Ireland. His mother, Queen Victoria, never thought too highly of him, never envisioning that his name would be the title of a television series on family comings and goings at the palace. The fashion industry of the day, however, had high regard for the King. His Edwardian attire - top hat and neat boots, for instance - set high standards for Britain's 19thcentury beautipeople.

title: Song: Margaret Whiting
description: AFTER celebrating American song writers singly and in pairs for the last 20 weeks, the Salute to American Songwriters series has reached a dazzling finale in the Atrium of the Citicorp Center, where Margaret Whiting is wrapping up the whole American song-writing kit and caboodle with a program that stretches from Stephen Foster to Leon Russell, from Tin Pan Alley to Broadway to Hollywood.

title: Mays, on First Try, Elected to Hall of Fame
description: Twentyeight years after his rookie season with the New York Giants, Willie Mays was elected into baseball's Hall of Fame yesterday and responded by saying: I give you one word - love. I had no sorrows about baseball.

title: White House Lobbying for Budget Support
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23  Using the same techniques that lobbyists for special interests have perfected, a special team of White House Congressional liaison officers has been working the Hill for the last two weeks in behalf of President Carter's 1980 budget.

title: Bank Earnings Results Listed; BA N CONIO (0); COMMERCE BANCSHARES (0); FIRST BANK SYSTEM (0); FIRST CHICAGO (N); HUNTINGTON BANCSHRS (0); MERCANTILE BANCORP (0); SO. CAROLINA NATIONAL (0); NORTHWEST BANCORP (N); UNION PLANTERS(()); U.S. TRUST (0)
description: For periods as shown. (N1 Indicates stock is listed on the New York stock Exchange. (A) the Arri....rican Exchange and (O) overthecoonter.

title: The Most Natural Ballplayer
description: On the morning that Willie Mays knew that his election to the Baseball Hall of Fame would be announced, he thought be would be tired after the flight from San Francisco the evening before. But when I woke up, I was full of thrills, he was saying now. Don't ask me what kind of thrills but they were there. He was standing behind a lectern on the stage of the Imperial Ballroom of the Americana Hotel yesterday, wearing a bright blue plaid suit, a blue shirt and an orange tie surely the colors were significant. Blue and orange are the colors of the Mets, his last team. Orange is also one of the colors of the Giants, both in San Francisco and before that at the Polo Grounds, when Willie Mays played stickball in the Harlem streets. But when the significance of the orange tie was mentioned to Willie Mays later, his eyes widened_ No, he said I never gave that a thought. Willie Mays had just grabbed the perfect tie without thinking, just as he used to make the perfect swing or the perfect catch without thinking. Willie Mays was perhaps the most natural ballplayer of all, one who not only thrived on the joy of baseball but who also projected that joy to all those who cherish the game.

title: Senate Unit Urges Pullout Halt
description: WASHINGTON. Jan. 23 (Reuters) special task force of the Senate Armed Services Committee recommended today that the withdrawal of American ground troops from South Korea be halted in view of new intelligence estimates of North Korea's armed strength. To pro- ceed with the withdrawal now would neither serve the security interests of the United States nor contribute to stability in northeast Asia, it said in a report.

title: Miss Evert Upset By Greer Stevens
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Jan. 23 (AP) - Greer Stevens of South Africa upset Chris Evert, 6- 2, 63, in Miss Evert's hometown tonight in a women's professional tennis tournament.

title: Mack, 13 Years on Rams, Will Quit After Pro Bowl
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 23(AP) Tom Mack, an offensive guard and a perennial AllPro who never missed a game in 13 seasons with the Los Angeles Rams, confirmed today that he was retiring.

title: Exxon Offers Laser Devices
description: The Exxon Corporation introduced family of laser devices yesterday, thus entering a field that could soon revolutionize telephone, computer and other informationprocessing systems.

title: Filling of Top House Panels Shows Allies Can Be Useful
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 - When House Democrats chose five new mem- bers for the Ways and Means Commit- tee last week, one of the winners was Representative Frank J. Guarini, an obscure New Jersey freshman. The universal reaction around Capitol Hill was Frank Who? Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. conceded that he had never even met the new committee member.

title: Suspected Agents Quit Hamburg Before Police Can Take Them In
description: KARLSRUHE, West Germany, Jan. 23 (Reuters)  A married couple who had been indentified as Communist agents by an East German defector disappeared from their Hamburg home before the police could arrest them, the federal prosecutor's office said today.

title: World News Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) Twelve Air Force F15 fighter planes left Saudi Arabia today after a weeklong visit intended to reassure the Saudi leaders of American support during the turmoil in Iran.

title: Israel Officially Silent On Death of Guerrilla But People Applaud It
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 23 - Newspaper and radio commentators here today ap- plauded the assassination yesterday in Beirut of Ali Hassan Salameh, who under the name Abu Hassan had been described as the planner of the massacre in 1972 of 11 members of the Israeli Olympic team in Munich.

title: Connors to Defend Title
description: MEMPHIS, Tenn., Jan. 23 (AP) -- Jimmy Connors will return to Memphis next month to defend his United States indoor title, officials of the event said today.

title: Carey's Nominee for Niagara Post Turned Down by New York Senate
description: ALBANY, Jan. 23 - Insisting that there was no vacancy in the chairman's post to fill, the Republicancontrolled State Senate today turned down Governor Carey's nomination of Allen E. Dekdebrun as chairman of the Niagara Frontier Transportation Authority.

title: Group Says More Israeli Oranges Will Be Poisoned in '79 Than '78
description: COPENHAGEN, Jan. 23 (AP) A terrorist group has warned that its agents will be poisoning more oranges from Israel this year than in 1978, officials in the Danish Government said today.

title: Private Lives
description: John Leonard

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: By The Associated Press

title: U.S. Says 1985 Autos Must Meet 27.5-Mile-a-Gallon Fuel Standard
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 - Transporta- tion Secretary Brock Adams said in a re- port to Congress today that the Govern- ment would hold the automobile industry tea 1985 fuel standard of 27.5 miles a gal- lon of gasoline, even though there have been complaints about the cost of the pro-gram.

title: Beaths
description: MULCAHY--Henry A. On January 23,1979 of Tenatly,NJ. Beloved husband of Henrietta (nee Specker). Devoted father of Thomas H. of Colchester, Vermont & Mrs. Susan Ulrich of Worthington, Mass. Dear brother of Dr. Thomas Mulcahy, Sister Paul Marie, C.S.C.. Mrs. Elizabeth Lauritano & Or. Michael J. Mulcahy. Also survived by 5 grandchildren. Friends may call at The Barrett Funeral Home, 148 Dean Drive, Tenafly, NJ on Wednesday from 24 8. 79pm. Funeral mass, Thursday 10am, St. Cecelia's Church. Englewood. Interment Fairview Cemetery, Fairview. NJ. Contributions to The Heart Fund would be appreciated.

title: Bonn Sees 4% Growth, 3% Inflation
description: BONN, Jan. 23 - The West German Government forecast today a year of strong growth, low inflation and reduced for its economy, representing the best outlook for 1979 among major industrialized countries.

title: HAROLD M. SPIVEY
description: Harold M. Spivey, former senior vice president of the North Side Savings Bank in the Bronx, died Friday in Indian River Memorial Hospital in Vero Beach, Fla., at the age of 70. His home was in Vero Beach.

title: Wine Gains in U.S., But Beer Still Leads
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (UPI)The average American drinks 22.4 gallons of beer, 1.85 gallons of wine, two gallons of hard liquor and 359 cans of soft drinks a year, according to industry statistics released this week by the Commerce Department.

title: Billy Hunter Is Named Coach at Towson State
description: TOWSON, Md., Jan. 23 (AP)  Billy Hunter, who was dismissed last season as manager of the Texas Rangers, was named today baseball coach at Towson State University.

title: News Summary
description: WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 24, 1979

title: Resorts Head Admits He Kept 68 Manager Who Had Crime Ties
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 23 The presi- dent of Resorts International conceded today that he had retained Edward G. Cellini as a casino manager in the Baha- mas for more than a year after the com- pany's security unit reported in a confi- dential memorandum in 1968 that Mr. cellini had had criminal associations.

title: Chess:
description: It's a rare privilege to be a pupil of Mikhail Botvinnik, the world champion from 1948 off and on until 1963 and now in retirement, because the man who put Soviet chess on the map has no patience with anyone lacking some potential of one day vying for the championship. It is therefore a good idea to keep track of who gets the gold stars in the old master's classroom.

title: Careers
description: Elizabeth M. Fowler

title: Coast Utility Regulators Named
description: Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California filled two vacancies on the fivemember Public Utilities Commission yesterday. His move apparently was aimed at balancing consumer and business interests.

title: Newsman Is Charged With Assaulting Billy Carter
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 23 - A Washingtonbased journalist said to have an intense interest in the financial affairs of the Carter family was charged with assault today after an altercation with the President's brother, Billy Carter, at BilIv's Service Station in Plains. Ga.

title: Trident Missile Is Tested
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Jan. 23 (UPI)  The 18th Trident missile in the Navy's $23.97 billion Trident program was successfully flight tested today from a landbased launching pad. It was the last of the land series and was successful, said a spokesman for the Air Force Eaktern Test Range.

title: Policeman Held as Robber
description: HAUPPAUGE, L.I., Jan. 23 (AP) The Suffolk County police say Charles A. Bauer, a Nassau County police officer, walked into the National Bank of North America on his day off here yesterday and robbed it of $4,000. Officer Bauer, 36 years old, of Smithtown, was charged with firstdegree robbery.

title: U.SChile. Pact on Letelier Bared
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23  The United States signed an agreement with Child last year in which it apparently agreed to restrict the information it would make available to the world about the investigation into the murder of Orlando Letelier, the former Chilean diplomat.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: DETROIT, Jan. 23 (UPI)  Volkswagen of America will begin marketing Volkswagen replacement parts in the United States under a new Autobahn label, and will make them more readily available to VW owners, the company said today.

title: French Winding Up Deal for Korvettes
description: After three hectic decades of changes in management and policy, Korvettes Inc. apparently will soon get a new owner, its fourth, through a $30 million, majoritycontrol purchase by the French Agache Willot group of companies

title: 10 Food Depots and Restaurants Named as Health Code Violators
description: The New York City Department of Health released yesterday the names of 10 food establishments it said had violated the Health Code. They are:

title: Stocks Climb Briskly on Profit News
description: The stock market moved ahead briskly yesterday on the strength of generally improved corporate profits and dividend increases, as well as some signs of an easing in shortterm interest rates. Supplementing these favorable developments was a stronger dollar in European currency trading.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Satellite Photograph

title: DISCOVERIES
description: We thought that if we closed our eyes, retro fashion would go away. No such luck,Everything from bustiers (read the Merry Widow bra of the 1950's) to chippie shoes has been copied and is now flooding the stores. If you loved the recent Paris fashions and think that the 40's and 50's were cute, then retro is your thing.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: American Brands Inc., has appointed Felipe Silva president of its American Cigar division.

title: TV: 'Kaz Continues on Offbeat Way
description: ONE of the very few new series in recent months to elude the massive wave of network cancellations is Kaz, occupying CBS's 10 P.M. Wednesday slot. Kaz is Martin Kazinski, who earned his law degree and passed the California bar exam while in prison. He specializes in lost causes. The result in terms of iormat is part Columba, part Perry Mason and all Ron Leibman, whose performance as Kaz is the superglue holding this Lorimar series together from week to week.

title: Football Hall Selects Davis
description: Ernie Davis, the 1961 Heisman Trophy winner from Syracuse, and three other persons have been elected posthumously to the National Football Foundation's College Football Hall of Fame for 1979.

title: CARTER PUSHES FOR ARMS PACT AND CURB ON INFLATION TO SET 'NEW FOUNDATION FOR PEACE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23  In a sober State of the Union address that stressed efficient government rather than new programs, President Carter tonight ecalled on Congress to help build a new foundation for the future by controlling inflation and strengthening peace through a new strategic arms accord with the Soviet Union.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: HAPPY ENDINGS. By Margaret Logan. 164 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $7.95.

title: Warnings to Israeli Arabs
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 23  Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan and Defense Minister Ezer Weizman, who are considered the most conciliatory members of the Israeli Cabinet on the question of Arab relations, issued warnings today that appeared to reflect growing Israeli concern over increased Palestinian guerrilla attacks.

title: U.S. Jury Is Told of Customs Fraud in TV Imports
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23  A Federal grand jury investigation is hearing testimony that some of the nation's largest re tailers and a group of Japanese electronics companies took part in a widespread customs fraud to conceal the true extent of the dumping of Japanesemade television sets in American markets, Govern ment sources said.

title: A Scot's Birthday Dinner
description: TOMORROW, one nation will celebrate the birth of its national hero. He is a hero who is neither states- man, revolutionary patriot nor fa- ther of his country. He is, oddly enough, a poet.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: ST. LOUIS, Jan. 23 (AP) - Rejean Houle scored two goals and Guy La- fleur, Pierre Mondou and Mario Trem- blay added a goal and an assist each, powering the Montreal Canadiens to a 63 triumph over the St. Louis Blues in a National Hockey League game tonight.

title: TV : Mandrake Appears
description: THE first few minutes of Mandrake, which will be shown from 8 o'clock to 10 tonight on NBCTV, have something of the texture of the old Saturday movie serials, which make it a distinct improvement over most made-for-television films.

title: A Modest Defense of Wage Insurance
description: Much of the Administration's antiinflation pro- gram is borrowed from earlier Presidential efforts to curb prices: wage and price guidelines a la Johnson, budget restraint a la Ford, monetary restraint a la (early) Nixon. The one really innovative feature is Mr. Carter's proposal for wage insurance, a tax break for workers who risk the loss of purchasing power by settling for wage increases within Federal guidelines.

title: About Real EstateIdle Garden City Site Coming Alive as Office Center Rises
description: In the Garden City and Mineola area of Nassau County, Franklin Avenue is a name synonymous with shopping. There have been spacious Lord & Taylor and Saks Fifth Avenue stores there since the 1950's, and a little later came a large Bloomingdale's.

title: The Region
description: A Conrail investigation of the Dec. 29, 1978 collision of two New Haven line commuter trains has concluded that there was nothing to be found to have contributed to this accident other than man failure.

title: Shah Remains Secluded in Morocco
description: MARRAKESH, Morocco, Jan. 23 The Shah remained secluded all day today in a palace in the palm groves here and there was no indication where he would go next or when he would leave.

title: Iran Gas Cutoff Hurts Soviet Republics
description: MOSCOW, Jan., 23 - The interruption of naturalgas deliveries from Iran to the Soviet Union since last October has caused serious economic problems in the Soviet border republics of Armenia and Azerbaijan, according to official accounts.

title: Civic Units Named for Grants
description: Grants ranging from $10,000 to $30,000 have been announced for eight civic agencies as recipients of the 1978 Exxon Corporation Leadership Awards for services rendered to the city's youth, families and communal and cultural development.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Peter Smith Gets 4 Months; Admitted Theft of $70,000
description: Peter P. Smith 3d, a former New York City official, received a fourmonth jail sentence yesterday for the theft of $70,000 from a law firm.

title: Judge Sets in Motion Distribution of Assets From People's Temple
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 23 (Reuters) A Superior Court judge today set in motion legal machinery to dissolve the $12 million assets of the People's Temple.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS On Taiwan, Fear and Loathing
description: MADISON, Wis.  Scared students from Taiwan have often shyly showed me letters from their parents telling of visits from the Taiwan military security apparatus. These letters said that the militarysecurity people told them, get your youngsters to stop their political activities. The alternative was the usual threat delivered by those offering protection.

title: Shah Said to Accept Sadat Proposal to Reside in Cairo
description: CAIRO, Jan. 23  The Shah of Iran has accepted an invitation from President Anwar elSadat to take up residence in Cairo after his current visit to Morocco, it was reported today.

title: Armco Net Gains 9.2%
description: Armco Inc., the nation's fifthlargest steel producer, reported fourthquarter net income of $56.7 million, equal to $1.24 a share, up 9.2 percent from the 1977 final quarter, on sales of $1.16 billion up 26.9 percent. Results for 1978 emphasize the solid financial base developed through continuing diversification, said William Verity, chairman.

title: Detroit Takes Convention News As .a Sign Renewal Is Succeeding
description: DETROIT, Jan. 24 - The Motor City's struggle to rebound from more than two decades of economic decline got a lift today when the Republican National Committee voted to hold the party's 1980 national convention here. The decision, which is expected to pump millions of dollars into the city's economy, put a little strut into Detroit's stride.

title: Wells Ends 7Up Career
description: When Ben H. Wells retired from the SevenUp Company last week, it marked the end of the founding family's participation in the St. Louis producer of soda pop. Mr. Wells was a son-in-law of the late Frank Y. Gladney, one of the three men who started the comnany in 1929.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Prices of silver futures shot forward late in the session yesterday as rumors swept the New York Commodity Exchange that a Kuwaiti holder of a sizable number of March contracts stood ready to take physical delivery of the metal.

title: One Federal Agency: How It Makes Rules
description: WASHINGTON

title: Judges Find Criminal Courts Wanting
description: For certain New Yorkers, the number 346 brings to mind a line of clothing from Brooks Brothers. For others the number is the sh&thand by which Summons Court at 346 Broadway, the lowest court in the city; is known.

title: Butcher, Cutting as Ordered, Has Few Ribs to Spare
description: A Brooklyn meat market that was sentenced to sell certain cuts at wholesale prices for a week was the envy of its Sheepshead Bay business neighbors yesterday as customers in unaccustomed droves were nearly knocked down along with the prices.

title: GEORGIA BANK BARS A LANCE REPAYMENT
description: ATLANTA, Jan. 23  The board of di- rectors of the National Bank of Georgia today rejected a special audit committee recommendation that Bert Lance and President Carter reimburse the bank for income lost on lowinterest loaris and, in Mr. Lance's case, for losses related to ex- pense payments that were not properly documented.

title: Beaths
description: SCHROER--Carlyle. Suddenly on January 23, 1979. Brother of Eli- zabeth Sterl & Herbert Schroer. Also survived by 2 nieces & 2 nep- hews. Reposing Wednesday 2.4 & 7- 9Pan at Woodlawn Morticians, 4418 White Plains Road, Bronx. New York. Religious services Thursday 2pm. Cremation to follow at Wood- lawn Crematorium.

title: Elvin Charles Stakman, 93, Dies; Authority on Diseases of Wheat
description: Elvin Charles Stakman, the pioneering  plant pathologist who established the methods for identifying and combating diseases of wheat and other important food crops, died Monday in St. Paul. He was 93 years old.

title: Detroit Chosen by G.O.P. For Its Convention in 1980
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 - The Republican National Committee decided today to hold its 1980 Presidential convention in Detroit despite complaints by opponents that the Middle Western city was depressing.

title: Oilers Reward Coach
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 23 (AP) - Bum Phillips, coach of the Houston Oilers, who led the team into the playoffs last season for the first time since 1969, signed a threeyear contract today. The terms were not announced. His previ- ous twoyear contract was to expire Jan. 31. Contracts were offered to all present members of the coaching staff, a club spokesman said.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: In 1976, William E. LaMothe, as president and chief operating officer of the Kellogg Company, gave a speech blistering the Federal Trade Commission. He attacked the commission's shared monopoly theory, under which it had been trying for four years to break up concentration in the breakfast cereal industry.

title: Eastern Air Off in Quarter
description: Eastern Air Lines Inc.. the country's fourth largest air carrier, reported yesterday that profits for the fourth quarter had dropped a sharp 55 percent although earnings for the year improved 141 percent, setting a company record.

title: Orders for Durables Down 0.1%
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) - Orders for durable goods, an indicator of the nation's economic health, declined in December for the second consecutive month, the Commerce Department said today.

title: To Thank City, Diplomats Help Neediest Cases
description: The diplomatic community in New York City provides a substantial backing to many local endeavors and their support is much in evidence in the 67th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Ford Weighs Plant
description: PARIS, Jan. 23 (Reuters)  The Ford Motor Company is studying the possibility of setting up a major assembly plant in either France or Austria, and suggestions for the project have been submitted to the Governments of both countries, a Ford spokesman said today. There has been speculation here that Ford may build an assembly plant employing about 8,000 workers in the Lorraine area in eastern France, in the context of Government plans for reviving the region's ailing economy.

title: Entertainment Events Theater Music Dance Cabaret
description: ICE CAPADES, 1979 edition, starring Dorothy Harni At Madison SquareGarden, at 7:30.

title: Opera: Butterfly at Met
description: THERE are three moments in Madams Butterfly that never tail to bring down the house: the end of the love duet, CioCioSan's rapturous sighting of Pinkerton's ship and the latter's aria of farewell. The performance at the Metropolitan Opera on Monday night, the first Butterfly of the season, made history of sorts, for all three surefire applausegetters were greeted with stony silence.

title: Corporations Report Their Sales and Earnings Results for the Quarter
description: For periods as shown. (? indicates stock is ? on the New York Stock Exchanges ? the American St? Exchange and (0) over-thecounter.

title: Snail Darter and Whooping Crane Win the First Test of Species Act
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 - In the first test of the amended Endangered Species Act, the snail darter and the whooping crane came out winners today.

title: Recital: Joseph Fuchs
description: THE most striking piece on Joseph Fuchs's violin recital program Monday night at Carnegie Hall was Ralph Vaughan Williams's Concerto Accademico in D Minor (1925). It was striking because it is a lovely, not very wellknown work, because unlike the solo or piano-accompanied pieces that abound on recital programs, it paired the solo violin with a 23piece string orchestra, and because in it Mr. Fuchs did aboutitis best playing of the evening.

title: Bank Links With China Upgraded
description: China is actively expanding its relationships with major American banks in what appears to be a further effort to facilitate trade with the United States.

title: Letters
description: I am struck by Howard Gardner's suggestion ['Getting Acquainted With Jean Piaget, Jan. 3] that one may teach the conservation of matter to receptive small child by showing that, blindfolded, one cannot tell the difference between a whole and a broken cookie.

title: Concern Rises in Mahwah Over Its Water's Toxicity
description: MAHWAH, NJ., Jan. 23 Twice since November, state water inspectors have taken samples from the four drinking wells along the banks of the Ramapo River here, and twice laboratory tests have found that high levels of suspected cancercausing chemicals have polluted the wells.

title: Carter Due to Ask Teng for Help on Korea
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23  When Deputy Prime Minister Teng Hsiaoping visits next week, President Carter plans to ask him for his Government's help in dealing with a potentially dangerous situation on the Korean Peninsula, according to Administration officials.

title: Wagner Says the Pope Is Eager to Visit City For Fall U.N. Meeting
description: Pope John Paul II has made preliminary plans to visit New York City for a United Nations session next fall, according to former Mayor Robert F. Wagner, the special United States envoy to the Vatican.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: GUGUELMO MARCONI (Italian Line Cruises Inter. national). Left St. Thomas Jan. 21; due B A.M at W, 55th Street.

title: Lakers Rout Knicks Despite McAdoo's 45
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Jan. 23 - The Knicks can take one small solace from tonight's devastating 148124 loss to the Los Angeles Lakers before 11,562 fans at the Forum  they won't have to play again in the Los Angeles area until next season.

title: Topics Promoting Interest
description: Citing the costs of administration, the Treasury has announced it will soon replace the familiar old $25 sav- ings bond with a S50 model. Why sell it at any price?

title: How Safe Are Nuclear Reactors?
description: In 1975, the Federal Government issued a supposedly comprehensive study of the safety of nuclear reactors. The report, named for its principal author, Norman Rasmussen, professor of nuclear engineering at M.I.T., estimated the chances of a catastrophe to be tiny, about as likely as a meteor killing large numbers of people. But now the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, which once praised the report as a realistic assessment. has disowned it. That leaves the nuclear safety debate about where it was before the threeyear, $3million study was launched. There is considerable evidence that reactors are safe; some reason to fear a major accident, and no good theory for assessing the magnitude of risk.

title: Budget Balancing
description: ARLINGTON, Va.  President Carter's proposed fiscal 1980 budget, which would contain a $29 billion deficit  down from the 1979 deficit of $37 billion  shows his concern for reducing the Federal deficit and moving toward a balanced budget for 1981. Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California also seeks a balanced Federal budget, but wants to mandate it by a constitutional amendment.

title: Disks.
description: A Berlin Potpourri

title: Mayors Group Vows to Oppose
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29  Calling President Carter's budget proposals disappointing abandonment of earlier commitments to the cities, the United States Conference of Mayors vowed today to take its fight to Congress to preserve urban and social programs that the Administration wants to scale down to save money.

title: Tires of 49 Tow Trucks
description: Perhaps out of mischief, perhaps out of spite  or, perhaps, because he had parked his car on a city street one day, and found a few hours later that the po- lice had towed it away someone went to the Police Department's car pound on a Hudson River pier at 36th Street the night before last and slashed the tires on 49 city tow trucks.

title: What a Wrecker's Ball Leaves, He Loves
description: LENNIE SCHECHTER is a small, diffident, singleminded, agile man of 28, with a sallow face and burning eyes and unalterable convic- tions, and what I admire about him is this: his devotion to the architectural past of New York City and his dripping contempt for almost everything built after the First World War.

title: The City
description: A 49-year-old Queens woman who had reportedly left work early because she was not feeling well was shot and killed on a Whitestone street just a few blocks from her home yesterday afternoon, the victimof two teenagers who had decided to shoot up their quiet residential neighborhood, according to the police.

title: Parr, L.I. Developer, Is Acquitted Of Charges He Stole $3.6 Million
description: Ronald J. Parr, a Long Island devloper, was acquitted yesterday of criminal charges that he stole $3.6 million from creditors who backed his efforts to build New Town complete with quarter horse race track, condominiums and shopping center, in the pine barrens of Suffolk County.

title: Roosevelt Island: Town Within a City
description: Children walk to school as minibuses carry commuters to the tram to Manhattan. Roosevelt Island, which stretches for two miles and goes under the Queensborough Bridge, is a futuristic onestreet town, whose inhabitants often forget that they are residents of New York City. It is paradise to some, a prison to others, home to all. The islanders opinions of life in their East River community appear in article on page B8.

title: U.S. Diplomat Brings New Israeli Proposals To Egyptian Capital
description: CAIRO, Jan. 24 (Reuters)  Alfred L. Atherton Jr., the American special envoy, arrived herelonight, bringing new Israeli proposals aimed at overcoming difficulties that are preventing the signing of a peace treaty, the official Middle East News Agency reported.

title: Events
description: JULIUS CAESAR by Shakespeare. Directed by Mi- chael Landham. Presented byfthe New York Shake- I speare Festival. PublicAnspacher Theater, 42S LafayetteStreet&

title: State Considering Building Power Plant in South Bronx
description: ALBANY, Jan. 24  At the urging of Governor Carey and Mayor Koch, the Power Authority of the State of New York is trying to find a site in the South Bronx where it could construct a 700megawatt power station.

title: GARDENING
description: A PROBLEM shared by virtually all serious gardeners is the hard-to-find plant. Catalogues quite often solve the problem, but the trick is to find a source fairly close to home.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: CHERRY HILL, N.J., Jan. 24 - Garden State Park's new ownership agreed in principle today with the Bank of New Jersey for an extension to July 4 of the remaining payment for  the track property. Formal ratification of the agreement is expected from the track stockholders at a meeting next Wednesday.

title: NEW STORM AFFLICTS MIDWESTERN STATES
description: High winds and snow afflicted much of the Middle West yesterday, bringing Chicago a new seveninch layer of show on top of the 20 inches that fell in a bliz-

title: Economic Scene
description: WASHINGTON

title: VW to Join Chrysler in Brazil Unit
description: BONN, Jan. 24  The Volkswagen company said today that it was acquiring a 67 percent stake in the Brazilian subsidiary of the Chrysler Corporation in a transaction valued at $50 million.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Satellite Photograph

title: Japan Posts Record Surplus
description: TOKYO, Jan. 24 (UPI)  Despite repeated pledges to reduce its favorable trade balance, Japan had a record trade surplus of $18.3 billion last year on a customs clearance basis, nearly double the 1977 level of $9.7 billion, the Finance Ministry said today.

title: Court Backs President On Rules Intervention
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24  The Justice Department won a dismissal today of lawsuit challenging the right of White House economists to intervene in the Interior Department's preparation of forthcoming regulations to control strip mining. A Government lawyer predicted, however, that the issue would be before the courts again soon.

title: WNET Holds Open Meeting
description: The turnout was sparse for comparable events in Boston and Washington, but there was an overflow crowd of more than 100 at the Carnegie Endowment International Center Tuesday afternoon for the first board meeting of WNETTV that was open to public observation.

title: 2d Devaluation by Brazil
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 24. (Reuters) L- Brazil devalued its currency, the cruzeiro, for the second time in nine days. fixing its new rate at between 21.65 and 21.79 to the United States dollar, the Brazilian central bank announced today. The new rate, a drop of 2.5 per cent against the previous 21.12, is to take effect tomorrow

title: TV: Opera and More From Lincoln Center
description: IN the last week or so, I have seen a couple of major Lincoln Center presentations twice - once at the center and once on television. The inescapable conclusion is that the state of the art in televising such events is rapidly reaching perfection.

title: Islander Game Restated
description: BUFFALO, Jan. 24 (UPI)  The Buffalo SabresNew York Islanders National Hockey League game that was postponed last Sunday has been rescheduled for Feb. 19 in Buffalo. The game was postponed when the Islanders were unable to travel here because of poor weather conditions in New York. The Sabres said tickets dated Jan. 21 would be honored for the game.

title: Sutherland Dispute Raises Control Issue
description: A dispute between the Metropolitan Opera and Joan Sutherland, one of the century's most highly acclaimed sopranos, has boiled over into an open argument over who should decide what wnrisa are to be produced at the Met.

title: U.S. Won't Get Involved In Indochina, Aide Says
description: Richard C. Holbrooke, Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs, told the Asia Society yesterday that the United States did not have a direct involvement in Southeast Asia and will not aet involved.

title: Limit. Is Put on Foreign Players Allowed in Pro Soccer League
description: A ruling Tuesday by the Labor Department to limit the number of foreign players who may enter the United States for the 1979 season was viewed yesterday as a victory for the North American Soccer League Players Association.

title: Senate Panel Briefed By Vance on Progress In Soviet Arms Talks
description: WASHINGTON. Jan. 24  The Administration stepped up its efforts today to win Senate support for a new arms-limitation accord with the Soviet Union by sending Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance to Capitol Hill to brief the Foreign Relations Committee and by inviting key senators to the White House.

title: Wired Man Robs Bank
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Jan.24 (UPI) A man who asserted his wife was being held as a hostage by persons who had wired a remote control bomb onto his body has escaped from a Knoxville bank with an undetermined amount of money.

title: Bridge:
description: A Rare Auction Comes Up In Jamaica Vacation Game

title: House Panel Blames Intelligence Agencies and Policy Makers Over Iran
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24  A House committee said today that both the American intelligence community and Carter Administration policy makers had to share blame for the failure to perceive the depth of the crisis in Iran and to forecast that it could lead to Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi's departure.

title: Panel Urges Investigation in C.I.A. Officer's 'eath
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24  The Senate Intelligence Committee today asked the Justice Department to investigate a num- ber of troubling questions that it had been unable to answer in its own investi- gation into the death of John A. Paisley, the former Central Intelligence Agency analyst whose body was found floating in Chesapeake Bay last autumn.

title: U.S. Asks Buyer Views On Appliance Efficiency
description: WASHINGTON. D.C. THE Federal Government is getting ready to develop energy efficiency standards for consumer products, according to The Associated Press, and is interested in comments and suggestions from the public. The idea, of course, to save energy by making more efficient products available.

description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT Wednesday, Jan. It 1979

title: Moscow Rejects British Position On Sale of Warplanes to Peking
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 24 (Reuters)  The Soviet Union today rejected arguments that possible British arms sales to China should be seen as part of ordinary trade and not as a threat to dtente.

title: Market Place
description: Robert Metz

title: Chamber Concert: Hear America First
description: HEAR AMERICA FIRST is the name of a newmusic organization that presented a concert Tuesday night at Carnegie Recital Hall entitled Vintage 79. Peculiarities abounded in all this nomenclature. Hear America? One composer was Australian. First? One piece dated from 1948 and had been heard here before (at least in its original, complete version). '79? The most recent piece on the program was composed last year.

title: Home  Beat
description: THE floodgates have opened. It looks as if this will be the Year of the Reproduction, and before we are drowned in the deluge, here is news of the state of the it can be described thus  art, from Paris.

title: Legally Blind Student Aids Vision Tests of Retarded
description: A legally blind Queens high school student has won honors in the annual Westinghouse Science Talent Search for a research project on vision tests administered to the mentally retarded.

title: Birth of New Foundation:
description: WASHINGTON. Jan. 24  It was coined at a brainstorming session in a speechwriter's office the week before Thanksgiving and then virtually forgotten until it was resurrected and made the theme of President Carter's State of the Union address.

title: Marshak Quits The Presidency Of City College
description: Robert E. Marshal, the president of City College in New York for the last nine years, said yesterday that he would resign his post this summer to return to research and the teaching of theoretical physics.

title: U.S. Is Seeking A List of Donors To Communists

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) - Representative Daniel J. Flood, on trial on Federal bribery, conspiracy and perjury charges, is giving up his powerful chairmanship of a House Appropriations subcommittee, an aide said late tonight.

title: Arrows Beat Houston, 87, On Segota's Overtime Goal
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 24  Branko Septa scored his third goal of the game at minutes 44 seconds of overtime last night to give the New York Arrows an 87 triumph over leagueleading Houston. The Arrows moved within two games of the leaders in the Major Indoor Soccer League.

title: Japanese Leader Facing 3 Problems in Parliament
description: TOKYO, Jan. 24  The six-week-old Government of Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira faces major tests in the parliamentary session that will open tomorrow in the presence of the Emperor.

title: Coalition Established to Oppose Trims in Social Security Benefits
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24  About 20 organizations representing the aged, labor, women, blacks, the poor, students and churches have banded together to oppose President Carter's proposals to trim or eliminate some Social Security benefits.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: ,Activist Priests in Latin America Risk Death for a Cause
description: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 24  The peasants have been warned not to talk to us, the Rev. Rutilio Grande said as he showed a visitor around an impoverished hamlet in El Salvador. The landlord's gunmen have told them they'll be shot they're caught with us. But a few weeks later, it was the activist Jesuit himself who was murdered outside his church.

title: Dybeck to Arbitrate in Steel
description: Alfred C. Dybeck is strictly a middleman. In fact, his Pittsburgh office is about halfway between the headquarters of the United Steelworkers union and the skyscraper headquarters of United States Steel Corporation.

title: GROMYKO RECEIVED BY POPE JOHN PAUL
description: ROME, Jan. 29  Pope John Paul H, who is flying to Mexico tomorrow on his first major trip as Pontiff, today received Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union for a meeting that was described by Vatican sources and Communist diplomats as being important for churchstate relations in Eastern Europe.

title: Railroad Is Told to Pay Mid Man $5.6 Million
description: The Penn Central Railroad was ordered yesterday to pay $5,616,000 in damages to an Astoria, Queens, man whose contact with an 11,000volt electrical line resulted in brain damage, severe burns, broken back and what his lawyer termed psychological injury.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: In the 72-year-old history of the American Electric Power Company, one of the nation's largest utility holding companies, there have been six presidents. Yesterday, Richard E. Disbrow was named the seventh. His appointment was announced by W.S. White Jr., chairman of American Electric, which has assets of $7.85 billion.

title: Farm Income in 1978 Put at 2dHighest
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 The Agriculture Department today increased its estimate of how much money American farmers netted in 1978, placing the total at $28.1 billion, the secondhighest ever recorded. But the department had little encouragement to offer consumers on the price front.

description: Paul Goldberger

title: Jan de Klerk of South Africa Dies
description: Jan de Klerk, a former speaker of the South African Senate and a strict and outspoken segregationist, died at a clinic in Johannesburg on Tuesday night after long illness, it was announced yesterday in Johannesburg. Mr. de Klerk was 75 years old.

title: BAR PANEL PONDERS DISPUTE OVER CULTS
description: Lawyers representing the Rev. Sun Myung Moon's Unification Church and parents trying to detach their children from the controversial movement's influence clashed in a freeswinging argument yesterday over the issues of constitional rights and the role of government in curbing what might be considered spurious religious cults.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: FRENCH DRESSING This is Harold Venokur's story: In Paris he discovered a French chanteuse at Chez Patachou, a Left Bank cabaret, and invited her to sing in hisplace if she came to New York. Mr. Venokur expected to open a cabaret in the city.

title: Continental Corp. Plans to Build 35Story Skyscraper Downtown
description: Construction is expected to begin in few months on the first major new office building to be erected in Lower Manhattan in several years.

title: 10Day Sales Up at G.M., Off at Ford and Chrysler
description: DETROIT, Jan. 24 (AP)  The General Motors Corporation said today that its domestic sales in midJanuary had increased 36.7 percent to 136,898 cars from the total for the corresponding period a year ago.

title: A Country Place: It's Far From Paradise
description: APLAGUE on both your houses, says the wicked witch in the Broadway version of The Wiz, and the lion's horrified rejoinder, Not my country place!, never fails to get knowing laugh from the audience. The fantasy of a peaceful, bucolic retreat where one can get away from it all a little place in the country to which you and yours will blithely depart every Friday at 6 to return refreshed and renewed on Sunday night  has become part of the American Dream. But the mountain greenery myth is one that badly needs debunking.

title: Dow Down By 0.44 as Rally Fails
description: The stock market turned downward yesterday after failing in an attempt to push through to its best closing level since last October.

title: Italian Terrorists Kill a Union Aide
description: ROME, Jan. 29  Gunmen belonging to the Red Brigades terrorist organization today shot and killed a Communist labor union official in Genoa as he stepped into his car to go to work.

title: Q&A
description: (1 .Although we keep the heat on at night, the upstairs windows are soaking wet every morning, and they are turning greeen with mold. We have storm windows with an air space at the bottom. My parents and sister, who live in different houses that have different types of heat, are having the same problem. Have you an answer for us? --D.G., Springfield, Mass.

title: Keep Our
description: ZANZIBAR  It is only 22 miles from the coast of East Africa to this is- land of cloves and intrigue; but there is an aura of splendid isolation here, a feeling of being cut off from the rest of civilization.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: REDCLIFF, Rhodesia  We had to accept this thing called majority rule, Ian Smith said. It was made clear to us that unless we did, the few friends we had in the world could no longer afford to be our friends. Even the South Africans . . .

title: Five Radicals Vandalize China's U.S. Liaison Office
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24  Five men from a leftist organization attacked China's liaison office here today to protest the coming visit of Deputy Prime Minister Teng Hsiaoping.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: By The Associated Press

title: Connally Enters Republican Race For Presidential Nomination in 80
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29  John B. Connally, the Houston lawyer, banker and politician, announced his candidacy for the 1980 Republican Presidential nomination today and said that, while the nation is basically strong, the only missing ingredient is leadership.

title: Sheraton Adding 2 Midtown Hotels
description: The Sheraton Corporation announced yesterday that an investment group heads had purchased the leases on the 50story Americana Hotel and the City Squire Motor Inn. The two properties, on opposite sides of Seventh Avenue at 52d Street, had been operated by Americana Hotels Inc., a subsidiary of American Airlines.

description: A Big Defensive Hammer, How to Wield It Effectively

title: France Rejoins Geneva Arms Parley
description: GENEVA, Jan. 27  France, occupying the seat it left empty for 17 years, joined the international community's main arms negotiating forum today as the disarmament conference here began its first session in an expanded format set by the United Nations.

title: Misdemeanor Charge Is Called Too Lenient In CrossBurning Case
description: RIDGEFIELD, Conn., Jan. 24  The police in this affluent, predominantly white Fairfield County town announced today that they had filed misdemeanor charges against five young men who allegedly burned a cross early Christmas

In my judgment, the pri- vate healthinsurance companies, both profit and nonprofit, can continue to play a principal role under a national healthinsurance plan in offering

title: BRITAIN STAGGERING UNDER LABOR STRIFE
description: LONDON, Jan. 29  Britain edged closer to industrial paralysis today as the number of workers laid off as a result of national truck drivers strike mounted and as the nation braced for another 24hour railroad shutdown tomorrow.

title: Some Support and Sympathy for the Shah Are Still Heard in Teheran
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 24  In his neat parlor, a grizzled Iranian businessman murmured today, Lots of people like Shah but are afraid to say so.

title: U.S. to Ship Fuel Urgently to Iran
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24  The United States has agreed to a request by the Iranian Government to arrange an emergency shipment of 200,000 barrels of diesel fuel and gasoline to Iran, the State Department said tonight.

title: New York Plan On Teacher Jobs Faces Challenge
description: The Community School Boards Association, representing 28 of the city's 32 local school boards, intends to challenge a plan by the School Chancellor that would prohibit school districts in poor and minoritygroup neighorhoods from hiring their own teachers.

title: Calendar of Events: Annual Winter Antiques Show
description: The 25th annual Winter Antiques Show, with 74 antiques dealers participating this year, opens Saturday at the Armory.

title: Capitals Turn Back Erratic Rangers, 51
description: LANDOVER, Md., Jan. 24 - The Washington Capitals, until recently one of those faceless, formless expansion teams that dot the sports landscape, simply overpowered the Rangers tonight and posted a 51 victory.

title: U.S. Tests Nuclear Device
description: YUCCA FLAT, Nev., Jan. 24 (UPI) United States scientists today conducted the first announced underground nuclear test of the year. The explosion was deto- noted 1,070 feet below the desert surface.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRIVING TODAY. Jan. 25 GUGLIELMO MARCONI ( Italian Line Cruises international). Left St. Thomas Jan.21; due A.M. at W. 55th Street.

title: Tracks Will Offer FreeTicket Plan
description: In an unusual wedding of bar, ness racing and thoroughbred racing. Roosevelt Raceway and Aqueduct joined forces yesterday in a sevenweek freeadmission plan that will begin Saturday night.

title: It's Still Winter in New York
description: This week, for the first time in four years, investors did not keep their hands in their pockets when New York City offered to sell $125 million in shortterm notes. Instead, they bought them at a lower interest rate than experts had predicted. This merits celebration, but those who dance in the streets should watch out for ice. The fiscal winter is not over.

title: De la Sierra a Master Planner at Warner
description: An architect is a master planner, Rafael de la Sierra commented yesterday in a soft Spanish accent. He is Cuban by birth.

title: Rally Continues On Prospects of Inflation Drop
description: This week's rally in the credit markets received new impetus yesterday from comments by G. William Miller, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, that prospects had improved to control inflation.

description: The Region

title: CavaliersBeat Nets,123 to 114
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J. Jan. 25 - A heated discussion tonight between Bill Fitch, the Cleveland coach, and Terry Furlow, a substitute guard, proved more interesting than the Cavaliers easy 123114 victory over the Nets at the Rutgers Athletic Center.

title: HELPFUL HARDWARE
description: WHEN security is involved, esthetics are often over- looked. One goes to a neighborhood hardware store and asks for the best deadbolt, or other lock, available. But good looks and security are available in one product, although it is not sold at the hardware store on the corner.

title: The Success Behind Britain's Crisis
description: Five years ago, Britain's Labor Party drove Prime Minister Heath and the Conservatives out of power on the justified claim that they could not control the unions  at that time, the coal miners who were making winter more bitter by an allout strike. The prospect arises that the Conservatives, now led by Mrs. Margaret Thatcher, may return the electoral favor by defeating Labor on the same indictment: that Britain's growing domestic economic chaos demonstrates that the Labor Party cannot control the nation's unions.

title: Advertising
description: IT did not take long for Harold Danenberg, the new president of the Mennen Company's domestic operation, to get the agency roster to his liking. He has been on the job about two months, and yesterday he announced that SSC&B, which he worked with when president of the Lehn & Fink Consumer Products division of Sterling Drug Inc., would be joining Mermen's agency lineup.

title: Regents Back Remedial Program
description: ALBANY. Jan. 24  Responding to statewide assertions that students will not be able to meet new competency standards in reading and mathmatics, the State Board of Regents agreed today to set up special remedial programs over the summer for those who do not pass the tests.

title: Deaths
description: ABRAHAMS1saac A.. Devoted huSband of the late Rose Freezer Abrahams. Beloved father of Bernice Secunda, Helen Sheingold & Ruth Geldon. Cherished grandfather and Oreatgrandfattier. Services Friday, 12 noon at the Riverside, Bronx., 179th St & Grand Concourse. Contributions to the Hebrew Home for the. Aged, 5901 Palisades Ave. Bronx 10471

title: FOOD LED WAY IN PRICE RISES
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24  Consumer prices rose again in December to give the nation a 9 percent rate of inflation for 1978.

title: Holocaust Audience Far Bigger Than West Germans Anticipated
description: BONN, Jan. 23  The West German telecasts of the first two segments of Holocaust were seen by about 34 percent of the possible viewing audience, More than double the 15 percent predicted.

title: Singh, Ousted Minister, Rejoins Indian Cabinet
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 24  Charan Singh, who was ousted as Home Minister seven months ago, rejoined Prime Minister Morarji R. Desai's Cabinet today, ending a feud within the governing Janata Party.

title: Amtrak Plans To Remodel Train
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24  Amtrak's board of directors today authorized $9.8 million to remodel and refurbish the Broadway Limited, operating between New York and Chicago, including installation of the latest type of electric heating and airconditioning.

title: Letelier's Assassin Declares Cuban Did Nothing Directly to Help Me
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24  Michael V. Townley, the American who has admitted planting the bomb that killed Orlando Letelier, the former Chilean diplomat, I testified today that one of three Cuban exiles on trial here on charges connected with the murder had done nothing directly to help him.

title: Studies Indicate New YorkWelfare Far Exceeds Federal Poverty Line
description: Amid growing pressure to increase New York State welfare grants, new studies by state and New York City officials estimate that relief clients in the city now have incomes equal to what Federal budget prescribes for a lower level of living. That level is well above the socalled poverty line.

title: About Uniondale
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Jan. 24  Other universities may break the news about Australopithecus afarensis, but Hofstra University has a man who monkeys around in the computer center to mask his humanity and hit the state lottery.

title: Sound
description: ONE fruitful method of spotting the turning points of cultural history is to trace the origin of words denoting new thoughts or things. Etyologists scrutinizing the 1970's will note the emergence of the word simulcast, meaning the simultaneous broadcasting of a program over television and FM radio, with the picture going the nonnal route while the sound is sent out in wide-range stereo by a collaborating radio station. The. virtue of lifelike sound is thus added to television, benefiting in particular programs in which music plays an important part.

title: AIRPORT IS CLOSED

title: Vienna Opera to Visit
description: THE Vienna State Opera will make its United States debut next.fiill with a 17day engage- ment'at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington. The visit ny me lustonc 110-year-old company will begin on Oct. 26 and will include 14 perform- ances of four operas plus three concerts by the famous Vienna Philharmonic, which is the opera's orchestra.

title: Vermont Journey Proves All in Vain
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 29 (AP) - It took the University of Vermont basketball team 7 hours 48 minutes today to get from Burlington, Vt., to Philadelphia for a basketball game against La Salle College. And it proved a losing cause as La Salle won, 10088.

title: Connors, McEnroe Win;Nastase Bows
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 24  Jimmy Connors, John McEnroe and Guillermo Vitas began their bids tonight for the $250,000 United States Pro indoor tennis championship with straightset victories in the second round.

title: ExHughes Aides Accused of Plot
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Jan. 24  Howard R. Hughes's former aides, doctors and top executives siphoned at least $50 million from his vast financial holdings by manipulating and isolating the drug-addicted industrialist in the last years of his life, according to a lawsuit filed Nevada District Court today.

title: Teamster Talks Recessed
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP)  National contract negotiations between the teamsters union and the trucking industry were recessed today after two days of talks until Feb. 6. The current threeyear contract, covering some 300,000 drivers and warehouse workers, expires March 31.

title: A Toy Train Collector's Trip Into History
description: ANYONE over 14 years of age who is still interested in toy trains, so the adage goes, will collect trains for the rest of his life. This would certainly apply to Rob- ert Davenport, immediate past presi- dent of the Train Collectors Associa- tion whose collection of toy trains is on exhibit through March 5 (Mondays through Saturdays, 9:30 A.M. to 4:30 P.M.; Sundays, noon to 5:30 P.M.), at the Museum of Our National Heritage, a modern building in the pleasant coun- tryside of Lexington, Mass.

description: Gillette's Paper Mate division has announced a new product breakthrough that will truly bene- fit fallible mankind: a ballpoint pen with erasable ink and an eras- er.

title: Court at Child Custody Hearing Bars Public Over Synanon Issue
description: SAN RAFAEL, Calif., Jan. 24 Marin County Superior Court judge excluded the public today from a child custody hearing over charges by the father of a 4-year-old boy that Synanon, the controversial drug rehabilitation (organization, provides an undesirable environment in which to raise children.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a transmission error by The Associated Press, a table in Business Day on Tuesday incorrectly reported the stock dividend declared by the Crane Company. The dividend is 2 percent, equal to one share of common stock for every 50 shares outstanding.

title: 'Apocalypse Now Will Open, at Last
description: Next Aug. 15, some 41 months after filming began, Apocalypse Now, Francis Ford Coppola's saga of the Vietnam War; will have its world pre- miere at New York's Ziegfeld Theater. This will be followed by an opening in Lis Angeles several days later.

title: Shah Greets the Press in Morocco
description: MARRAKESH, Morocco, Jan. 24 The Shah of Iran and the Empress, ap- pearing strained and ill at ease, greeted the press briefly today for the first time since their arrival here Monday, but no questions were allowed.

title: Nets Rise at Monsanto, Celanese and Abbott
description: Three major chemical companies announced sharp earnings gains for the quarter ended Dec. 31, extending an industry pattern of earnings reports that were better than most analysts had expected.

title: Jailed British M.P. Has Surgery
description: NORWICH. England, Jan. 24 (Reuters)  John Stonehouse, a former Member of Parliament and Cabinet minister who is serving a sevenyear sentence for insurance fraud, deception and theft, is recovering from openheart surgery, prison officials said today.

title: Probes Show Venus in Terrifying Light
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif., Jan. 24 The surface of Venus seems closer to the fire and brimstone concept of Hades than any region known. Sulfurous and so hot that lead and zinc would melt, it may be even more hellish because of the tumultuous occurrence of continuous thunder and lightening.

title: Sardi Flips An Attacker On 44th St.
description: When a 21-year-old man walked up to Vincent Sardi and Ira Ashley early last Tuesday on West 49th Street brandishing a knife, Mr. Sardi did not stop to think: I grabbed his arm and flipped him over my shoulder, said the owner of Sardi's Restaurant.

title: Rescued: One Chest
description: THIS is the story of a 75-year-old chest and how it was rescued. The chest was built around the tarn of the century, to store tools. It was made of pine, with wide boards. To make it more decorative, molding was put around the underside of the lid and around the base. A panel shaped like a flattened pyramid was fitted on too of the lid.

title: Juilliard Symphony Plays Mahler
description: ALICE TULLY HALL is hardly the place you would expect to encounter Mahler's Symphony No. 7, but James Conlon and the Juilliard Symphony squeezed them- selves onto the stage of that modestly proportioned room on Tuesday night and delivered themselves of a gener- ally faithful though unidiomatic per- formance of the 90minute, five-move- ment work.

title: Sports Today
description: Roosevelt Raceway, Westbury, L.I . , 8 P.M. Meadowlands Race Track, East Rutherford, N.J., 8 P.M.

title: Claude C. Vickery, a Broker, 86; Naval Officer in Two World Wars
description: Claude C. Vickery, an insurance broker who was a retired commander in the Naval Reserve, died Saturday. He was 86 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: A Black and Blue Rainbow
description: In an icy parking lot at Aqueduct, red taillights glow the braking cars of homewardbound horseplayers slip and slide toward the exits. Somewhere in the fogshrouded infield hedges, ducks and sea gulls grub for shelter. Another winter racing card at the Big A has ended, and the dark shapes tractors have already begun another costly night of dragging harrows around the salted onemile inner track to keep from freezing.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: The Consumer Price Index climbed sixtenths of 1 percent in December, bringing its gain for 1978 to 9 percent, the Labor Depart- ment reported. The increase for the year was the largest since a gain of 12.2 percent in 1974, following the quadrupling of oil prices by Mid- dle East producers. The rate of increase in December was reduced by a sharp decline in property taxes in California because of Proposi- tion 13, the Labor Department noted. [Page Al.]

title: World News Briefs
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Jan. 24  A Taiwanese pleaded guilty today to having organized a rebel group to overthrow the Chinese Nationalist Government on Taiwan and told a military court that he had acted on orders of the Chinese Embassy in Tokyo.

title: Rain and Wind Snarl City Traffic
description: Heavy rains and galeforce winds lashed New York City yesterday, snarling rushhour traffic, delaying airline flights, causing a rash of power blackouts and serving as a soggy prelude to a light snowfall that was forecast for this morning.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: The Bally Manufacturing Corpora- tion said yesterday that it had received Federal grand jury subpoenas calling for various documents relating to what Bally understands is an investigation of the slot machine industry for possible antitrust violations.

title: Clarification on Loans To President and Lance
description: An article in The New York Times yesterday reported erroneously that a special committee of the National Bank of Georgia had recommended that the bank seek reimbursement from Bert Lance and President Carter for lowinterest loans made by the bank.

title: Doubt on Banks Standby Loans
description: Banks have been expanding into a new line of business in recent yearsinsuring the performance of contractors in the explosion of development projects overseas, many of them in Iran and elsewhere in the Middle East and there is concern in some circles they may be courting unusually high risks.

title: Music by Philadelphians
description: WAS it Eugene Ormandy's idea that the Philadelphia Orchestra should play an allRachmaninoff pro- gram for its concert at Avery Fisher Hall last night or did William Lock- wood, director of Lincoln Center's

title: Tobacco: Profit Despite Attacks
description: For the last 13 years, every pack of cigarettes made in the United States has been inscribed with a Government warning of the dangers of smoking.

title: Chrysler Deal Discussed
description: DETROIT, Jan. 24 (AP)  Chrysler's agreement to sell 67 percent of its Brazilian subsidiary to Volkswagen came five months after Chrysler sold its British, Spanish and French subsidiaries to the French auto maker Peugeot.

title: Races Curtailed After Jockeys Balk
description: There was racing, but not as usual, at Aqueduct yesterday. Poor conditions on the winterized track compounded by a pelting rain and gusts of 30 miles an hour prompted jockeys to decide, after two races, that the track's surface was unsafe. The stewards readily agreed.

title: 200,000 Join Strike in Spain
description: MADRID, Jan. 24 (Reuters)  Some 200,000 engineering workers in Madrid joined garbage collectors and gas workers on strike in Madrid today. The 48hour stoppage by the engineering workers was in support of their demand for wage increases of $71 to $85 a month and a guaranteed minimum monthly wage of $428.

title: Film: 2 on the Prairie
description: PRAIRIE FIRE is full of beautiful, desolate images of the - Great Plains, the kinds of images Terrence Malick went to such lengths to recreate in Days of Heaven, only this time it's the real thing.. John Hanson and Rob Nilsson have compiled footage shot by Mr. Nilsson's grandfather, Frithjof Holmboe, in North Dakota between 1915 and 1921, and used it to trace the brief history of the Nonpartisan League in that region.
