description: Hopes that they may ease the misfortune of others are often mentioned by contributors to the 67th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

Hickox; stepfather of Lisa H. May, Kyra H. LeRoy. Ashton Hawkins and grandfather of 12. Services will be held at Trinity Church, Roslyn, on Saturday January 27 at Noon. Linen of New York, to Eugene Charles Kelly, son of Dr. Elizabeth Kelly Fry of Indianapolis and the late Dr. Kevin Kelly. The Rev. Warren Raymond Webster 2d performed the ceremony.

title: $2 Billion Seen In China Trade
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (UPI) United States trade with China, which totaled less than $400 million in 1977, may approach $2 billion this year because of the establishment of normal diplomatic relations, the Government estimated today.

He sent a mission to China and purchased all sorts of dragon statuary and pagoda trimmings to dress up the streets back home.

title: ITALY'S COMMUNISTS WITHDRAW SUPPORT FROM GOVERNMENT
description: ROME, Jan. 26  The Italian Communist Party announced today that it was withdrawing parliamentary support from the Christian Democratic Govern:. ment of Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti; making its fall virtually inevitable.

title: A Measure of Efficiency
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP) Worker productivity, a key influence on the nation's inflation rate and living standard, grew by a mere 0.4 percent in 1978, the smallest rise since the 1974 recession, the Government said today.

title: TravelersKeystone Tie
description: The Travelers Corperation. a multipleline insurance company, announced yesterday that it had completed the acquisition of Keystone Custodian Funds Inc. for $20.3 million. Keystone is a Bostonbased mutual funds manager with $1.6 billion under management.

title: California TruckRate Battle
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 26  The national debate over relaxing Federal regulations in the trucking business may find a pilot project in California.

title: Troops Kill at Least 15 in Teheran As 100,000 Protest for Khomeini
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 26  Soldiers shot and killed at least 15 civilians today and wounded dozens of others as more than 100,000 supporters of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini staged anti-Government demonstrations here in defiance of martial law.

title: Hoffman Finishes Agatha Film

title: Talmadge Reported Feeling Well
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Jan. 26 (AP) Senator Herman E. Talmadge was reported in good spirits today at the Long Beach Naval Regional Medical Center, where he is being treated for alcohol abuse. His attitude is good, said Lisa Gill, a spokesman from the Georgia Democrat's Washington office. He spent a good night, and his spirits are high. Mr. Talmadge's press secretary, Gordon Roberts, has said that the 65-year-old Senator may require a fourweek stay.

title: Being Sensible About CETA

title: 2 Koreas Ask Reunification Talks
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 26  North and South Korea have proposed to each other that they resume talks for reunification of the Korean peninsula that have been deadlocked since 1973, but they differ on who should do the negotiating.

title: Going Too Far on Juvenile Crime
description: Moved by increasingly .frequent cases of brutal juvenile crime, the New York Legislature has passed successively tougher juvenilejustice reform acts. These culminated in last year's law, which treats violent 13- and 14-year-olds as adults. Now state correc- tions officials threaten to go further, indeed, too far. They want to incarcerate the convicted adults in the maximum security prison at Elmira. There is every reason to treat savage crimes severely, but what reason is there to surrender all hope of rehabilitating adolescents?

Well, Geraldine Fitzgerald would, for one, and she is so infectiously cheerful that she has everyone foottapping in her onewoman program of chitchat and song called Streetsongs, now playing at the Roundabout/Stage One.

[Page 1, Columns 45.]

description: Julian N. Trivers, an electnnics executive, died of complications Thursday night following surgery at Glen Cove (L.I.) Community Hospital. He was 61 years old.

Her children and visitors to her home have complained of headaches, and the strong gasoline odor in her basement has kept the family from working and playing there.

Officials said the Crown Prince would arrive about March 1 to discuss the stalemated EgyptianIsraeli peace talks, the outlook for an overall settlement in the Middle East and the disruption of oil supplies resulting from the turmoil in Iran.

description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Jan. 26 (AP) James Bailey scored only 6 points to- night, but Rutgers was able to hold off a late Duquesne rally and win, 7067, to- night in college basketball action.

title: Reforming the G.S.A
description: The following article, by the Administrator of the General Services Administration, was written for the OpEd page in December. President Carter's press secretary, Jody Powell, told newsmen Tuesday after Mr. Carter met with Mr. Solomon that the President was looking for a replacement for him but that no time had been set for his departure. Later Mr. Solomon said that he would remain on the job until his investigation of corruption in the agency was on a firm footing. Scandals in the G.S.A. include alleged payments for supplies never delivered and for work never done, and fraudulent use of credit cards. Presidential advisers reportedly have been upset by Mr. Solomon's disclosures about the progress of the investigation.

title: Out in God's Country, Stenciled Footprints
description: PARADISE VALLEY, Ariz. Slickrock that leaps unexpectedly into a dome, an arch, a spire causes a similar leap in the hiker's pulse.

title: NBC Dismisses a Vice President In Investigation of Irregularities
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 26 (AP)  NBC dismissed a vice president in New York today, a network spokesman said. The action was taken as the network continued its investigation into irregularities in expense vouchers, the spokesman said.

title: Andree Juliette Brun Plays Piano
description: Andree Juliette Brun's recital at Alice Tully Hall on Thursday night was a prolonged demonstration of wellschooled pianistic competence, but not much more. Most of the French musician's program consisted of the musical equivalent of junk food, which did not help, but she also played in consistently unimaginative fashion that did not provide substitute nourishment.

title: SIX ARAB STUDENTS IN ISRAEL CONFINED
description: TEL AVIV, Jan. 26  Israeli authorities, concerned over a recent increase in guerrilla activities, have ordered six Israeli Arab students suspected of circulating a leaflet supporting the Palestine Liberation Organization to leave Jerusalem's Hebrew University and return to their homes.

title: Judge in London Bars Picketing by Striking Drivers in Secondary Boycott
description: LONDON, Jan. 26  A High Court judge issued a temporary injunction today that barred picketing at a company not directly involved in a strike by truck drivers that has caused widespread shortages of raw materials.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: A New Catalogue From Sears
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company has just published most unusual catalogue 'not of retail merchandise but of grievances against the Federal Government. This 34page booklet is styled as a lawsuit against the Attorney General and nine other officials and agencies with which Sears has been involved in a long dispute over job discrimination. But it seems as much a sales tool as the thick catalogues the company mails to million American homes each year. Although it offers a fascinating look at the history of employment and civil rights, it hardly seems the kind of complaint that the courts can seriously entertain.

title: Mild Spell Puts Freeze On Big Apple Ski Fete
description: The New York City Park Department yesterday called off its Ski the Apple festival that had been planned for this weekend. Mild temperatures were blamed.

title: Antiques Show: Elegance at the Armory
description: I have an antique, you know, announced Ed Koch, just a touch defensively , as if anyone ever could have thought otherwise. I have an antique brass bed that my sister bought from farmhouse 20 years ago. Then he added with satisfaction: She bought it for $9.

title: Details on F.B.I.'s Illegal BreakIns Given to Justice Dept.
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 23 - A retired agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation who says he spent 20 percent of my career conducting illegal burglaries for the bureau has provided the Justice Department with detailed information about some of the most sensitive of the bureau's operations.

title: Your Money Checking on Social Security
description: THE Department of Health, Education and Welfare is in the last stages of trying to prune from its regulations the forbidding, opaque verbiage that may have deterred some people from regularly checking their Social Security earnings records.

title: New Glenda Jackson Film Opens:The Cast
description: Brut productions, which once brought you Glenda Jackson in. "A Touch of Glass," this time presents her in circumstances that are decidedly dclass. "The Class of Miss MacMichael," a rowdy reform-school story, features Miss Jackson as the standard good-Samaritan teacher whose fellowship with her students incurs the anger of the school's heartless supervisors.Ordinarily, this situation lends itself to sentimental moments (between the teacher and a few favorite students), heated arguments (each time the teacher does battle with the authorities), and sporadic incidents of violence (someone in the class, sooner or later, is bound to attack someone else). It also lends itself to classroom comedy, because sharing the kids' raucous jokes is the teacher's simplest way of showing which side she's on. "The Class of Miss MacMichael" incorporates all of the above, albeit somewhat wearily. It includes certain elements of confusion, too.Miss Jackson, seen here at her very frumpiest, always projects so much intelligence that even her light comedy roles take a serious turn; without sacrificing the humor, she manages to suggest that her behavior deserves to be taken seriously.But Oliver Reed, cast as the principal of the trade school where Miss Jackson works, is exclusively engaged in broad clowning, none of it very funny. Mr. Reed is forever pointing his chin at the heavens to suggest hauteur, and delivering such whiplash gestures it's a miracle he doesn't do the other actors bodily harm. Mr. Reed makes such a nonsensical antagonist for Miss Jackson that the whole tenor of her struggle becomes bewildering. How can one believe in her dedication to her class of happy hoodlums when the enemy is too much of a fool to be a villain?In all fairness, Mr. Reed is by no means the movie's only fool. Miss Jackson, in the interests of proving herself a good sport, smiles tolerantly when her students break into her apartment after hours and paint half of the place purple.Michael Murphy, in the thankless role of the American fellow Miss Jackson sips wine with after a long hard day, is understandably peeved by the extent to which the students have taken over his friend's life, and eventually he asks her to make a choice. In movies like this, there is usually only one choice to make. The one real stroke of originality of "The Class of Miss MacMichael" is its forestalling Miss Jackson's having to make any decision at all.Miss Jackson does nothing here that she hasn't done better elsewhere. The kids behave badly but act well, becoming nastily memorable as they revel in one another's bad company. Rosalind Cash, as one of Miss Jackson's fellow teachers, is a calming influence, imperturbable and half a beat behind everyone else. She provides a welcome contrast to Mr. Reed's hooting and hollering.

title: I've Been Composing All My Life, Off and On
description: I i a film documentarian should ever decide to do the definitive drama about the archetypal American composer, struggling against philistine indifference and foundation neglect. Samuel Barber would be the worst possible choice for a subject. His has been a different sort of legend, that of music's golden boy whom success discovered early and went on following like a welltrained puppy.  I was the youngest ever elected to the Academy of Arts and Letters, he recalled in an interview in his Fifth Avenue apartment not long ago. I think I was 25. Then, Andy Wyeth got in, and he was younger. Even the ultimate laurel wreath of American success, television exposure, has not been denied Mr. Barber: this Wednesday night, for instance, his Pulitzer Prize opera Vanessa, first done at the Metropolitan 21 years ago, will be presented on Channel 13, and broadcast simultaneously on FM over WNCN. This is a new production, taped last spring at the Spoleto USA Festival in S.C.

title: Other World Events

At the same time, the twolevel war between Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization  underground between agents, above ground in Israel and south Lebanon burst out with new fury. In Beirut, Ali Hassan Salameh, the reputed organizer of the 1972 Palestinian attack at the Munich Olympics, was killed by a remotecontrolled bomb. the overt war, artillery and rockets blazed across the IsraelLebanon border until the resumption of a tenuous truce.

title: DINING OUT; Ups and Downs, Italian Style; *Alex & Henry's

title: Headliners
description: It can't be easy. Last Thursday Laurie Koehler. a 17-yearold from Ridgewood, Queens, won first prize in New York City's high school photography contest for film backgrounds. Miss Koehler, who is legally blind but does quite well with the right glasses, took pictures of possible film locations around the city to be published in a brochure intended to attract movie companies. Earlier, Miss Koehler was one of 300 students the nation  80 from New York State  honored in the Westinghouse Science Talent Search, the United States largest high school science scholarship program. Her entry was an eye chart to test the vision of the mentally retarded, using symbols devised by the Lighthouse for the Blind. The retarded may not know the alphabet, or may have very short attention spans, and Miss Koehler's chart uses the symbols  a house, an apple and an umbrella  to assess their vision more accurately than with the standard alphabet chart.

Recording is often more important than interpretation.

title: A New Look at Schubert's Operas
description: Schubert's operas, unperformed during his lifetime and still largely unknown today, have perplexed musicians for over a century. There are a total of 16, eight in full score and eight more either lost or in fragmentary forth, and taken together they consume more space in the complete edition of the composer's works than any other vocal or instrumental form - Melancholy proof of Schubert's industrious labors to achieve popular success in an idiom that constantly eluded his grasp. How could a composer of such lyrical gifts and a songwriter of such dramatic perception fail at opera?

description: BANGKOK, Thailand  Twenty Vietnamese refugees arrived in Los Angeles last week, after three months spent aboard the freighter Hai Hong, wandering from port to port in Southeast Asia in search of a nation that would allow them to come ashore. They were the lucky ones. Thousands others uprooted in the continuing mass exodus from Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia have still to find refuge. Officials involved in helping them believe the problem can be solved only if individual governments can be persuaded to accept much greater number of refugees. But increasingly, governments have debated side issues instead of solutions.

title: BOOK ENDS
description: WHAT would you do if you were a prolific author (with 199 books to your credit), had two favorite publishers and wanted to give each of them the privilege and the pleasure of publishing your 200th book. This is not a question that troubles the sleep of most of our citizenry. However, it was a question that confronted Isaac Asimov, best known for his sciencefiction writings, though his works range from astronomy to Shakespeare. Mr. Asimov's solution has a logic that is surely logical in the scifi world he is so close to. He sent each of the two publishers new manuscript. Houghton Mifflin received Opus 200, collection of pieces: Doubleday received the first volume his autobiography, In Memory Yet Green. Mr. Asimov simply called each one his 200th book. The next one, incidentally, will be number 202. There'll be no 201.

title: Rajko Orchestra and Dancers
description: In Hungarian, rajko means gypsy child, and the members of the Rajko Hungarian Gypsy Orchestra and Dancers, which comes from Hungary, average only 19 years in age. Friday night, they stormed into Avery Fisher Hall and unleashed such a riot of talent and energy it was exhausting just to watch and listen.

title: Doubts Cast on the President's Optimistic Outlook for 79
description: In his budget message, in his State of the Union address, in his report to Congress on the economy, President Carter last week hammered at the theme that inflation must be controlled. Sometimes such travelers have been directed to alternate hotels - usually inferior ones  but frequently they have simply, as they say in the trade, been walked out the front door.

title: TV VIEW
description: Several weeks ago, a network executive, who happens to be affiliated with NBC, proclaimed that violence and sex would no longer serve as plot fodder on televiSion series. The millenium, seemed, had arrived. Weekly series might now occupy themselves with politics economics his tory, ambition, greed, power  all those little things that daily govern most people when they aren't busy consuming Procter & Gamble products. But, of course, the proclamation was nonsense, hanging on the thin publicrelations thread connected to the proposition that if something is said often and prominently enough, the public may eventually accept it as being valid.

title: Fire Drills Are Ordered For Subways on Coast
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 27 (UPI) Passengers on subway trains under San Francisco Bay will have to leave the trains and enter a pedestrian gallery during unscheduled fire drills at least once a month,_a lire official has ordered.

title: CHILDREN'S BOORS
description: By Steven Caney. Illustrated. 414 pp. New York: Workman Publishing. Cloth, $12.95. Paper, $6.95. (Ages 9 and Up) A good reviewer reads every word of each book under review, but this time I didn't even come close. I was too busy getting ready to stencil my walls, dowse for water, make some Philadelphia soft pretzels, and start a jug band, all courtesy of Kids America. This is a diverse, superbly imaginative and seemingly bottomless compendium of things to do, read and think about, and although its actual shape is rectangular, there are going to be a lot of grandparents, babysitters, camp counselors and, especially, children to whom it looks remarkably like a life By Tomie dePaola. Illustrated by the Author. Unpaged. New York: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. Cloth, $6.95. Paper, $1.95. (Ages 3 to 6) In this wordless picture book, Tomie dePaola's little old lady, round and solid as a homemade doughnut, encounters problems in fixing pancakes for her breakfast. First there is a shortage of ingredients, then a hungry dog and cat eat up the batter. Solution: Invite yourself to the neighbors for breakfast. Mr. dePaola's renditions of a New England farm kitchen, in tans, mauves and brick reds, are cozily appealing, if a little static in their pacing.

title: Pope, Opening Parley Of Bishops in Mexico, Urges Spread of Faith
description: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 27  Pope John Paul II opened an important conference of Latin American bishops today, urging the bishops and all Roman Catholics of Latin America to follow a traditional spiritual direction without ever straying along twisted paths and dragging others with us His remarks seemed to be criticism of Latin American priests who espouse social activism under a socalled theology of liberation.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS. Making Peace and Keeping It
description: LOS ANGELES  For more than decade, it has been plain that of all the disasters of the Vietnam War the worst might be the lessons we would draw from it. Our political Elites, re- coiling from that remote ambiguous struggle, concluded that improving our ability to project force into distant places was a danger to the world and to us. If we improved our force, we'd be more apt to use it and become mired down.

title: The Old Become Both Older and Younger
description: WASHINGTON - Just before the Carter budget was published last week, it still contained a surprising proposal. It suggested raising the minimum age for receiving Social Security from 62 to 65. At the last moment the idea was deleted for further study, but the President did propose reductions in Social Security benefits.

description: Until last week, Jack Cunningham was set to pack up his two-year-old poultry processing plant and move it from the Hunts Point Market in the South Bronx to Maryland. Basically, his complaint was that while government inspectors said that his 800 workers had to have more work space, City Hall was meeting his appeal for help with roughly the velocity of a speeding pullet. Now, bigger quarters have been found in the market for Gourmet Poultry Specialites, which, Mr. Cunningham says, is the largest employer of minorities in the area. Henry Weber, a meteorologist, follows a similar routine at 6 P.M., recording information from gauges behind his house.

title: Matteo's  Artful  Ethnic  Mix
description: Bath Bharata Suite? A dance piece like this, which combines two such divergent cultural manifestations as the epitome of European Baroque music and South Indian classic dance is guaranteed to raise the hackles of the mildest of ethnic purists. The dance, choreographed by the noted Americanborn ethnic specialist La Meri and last performed in New York 30 years ago, represents a oncepopular attitude that is now out of fashion in a world struggling to preserve distinctive cultural heritages.

title: WASHINGTON `A Worker And A Yearner
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 - It should probably be remembered that Nelson Rockefeller died at his desk late on Friday night after almost everybody else had gone home for the weekend. He was a worker, a yearner, and builder to the end.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP) Mayor Diane Feinstein of San Francisco and 38 Congressmen have urged President Car, ter to make good his 1976 campaign pledge to lead a drive for stronger gun control.

description: THE state foresters in this region provide a splendid service that deserves wider notice. They make available to qualified property owners supplies of tree and shrub seedlings at nominal cost.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: Bernard Pomerance's The Elephant Man is easily the most riveting new serious play we've had to contend with all season. I don't know pre- cisely how many people are going to be able to contend with it if it sticks to its plans for a limited run, ending two weeks from today, in the useful out tar worn ample auditorium at St. Peter's Church in the 54th Street Citicorp Building. At the moment, there aren't enough seats to go around. But I suspect we'll be hearing of an extention or a shift to larger quarters, and if I were you I'd keep an ear perked up for just such an announcement. You don't want to miss the musically precise staging of Jack Hofsiss (literally musical, since the evening's horrors and gratifications are linked together by an accomplished cel- list), the piercingly intelligent performances of Carole Shel- ley, Kevin Conway and Philip Anglim, and the emotional and imaginative challenges the author so cruelly, so blood- curdlingly, offers his listeners.

title: Mary Sanderson Fiance Of Carl James Accettura
description: The engagement of Mary Katherine Sanderson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John V. Sanderson of Sunnyside, Queens, to Carl James Accettura of Columbia, Md., son of Mr. and Mrs. Guy Accettura of Wyckoff, N.J., has been announced by the future bride's parents.

title: Debate Over Nuclear Safety Before Michigan Court
description: CHARLEVOIX, Mich., Jan. 27  District Judge David W. Fershee is to decide by next month whether his court is the proper forum for a debate on the degree of threat to life and health inherent in nuclear power plants. The dispute arises from a case of trespassing on the grounds of a nuclear power plant.

title: Fashion Designers Find a New Market
description: ACCORDING to Florentine designer Aldo Gucci, people who wear the very best should drive the very best. That, he says, is why he drives a Gucci Cadillac Seville and why he expects that others will want to do the same.

title: Losing Streak At 97 for Cauthen
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 27 (AP)  Steve Cauthen extended his losing streak to 97 today after failing to ride a winner in eight attempts, although he placed third in the $65,200 El Encino Stakes, won by B. Thoughtful before a crowd of 39,566 at Santa Anita. .

description: WASHINGTON RETURNING to the House of Representatives after a twoyear absence, during which he switched parties, Peter A. Peyser, now a Democrat, has had no trouble picking up where he left off.

description: WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 26- Dr. James f. X. O'Rourke, the Westchester County Republican chairman, knew that any bngthy introduction of Henry A. Kissinger at the party's annual dinner last tight would be superfluous, but he had to say something. he explained.

title: What to Do Until the Sandman Comes: A Fly-by-Night Account
description: My husband, Charlie, and I are on our way home from a twoweek visit to Hawaii. We have, for various reasons, decided to abandon our original plan of breaking our flight in Los Angeles, where we had hoped to get a good night's sleep, and have opted instead to stay on board our 747 and continue overnight to New York. We will sleep on the plane.

title: City Ballet In Entente Cordiale
description: There was a lot of marching and flagwaving at the New York State Theater on Friday, when Entente Cordiale entered the New York City Ballet winter repertory. The fulllength program of three ballets, one celebrating America, one France and one England, is an evening of parts, spotty, gaily perverse and, occasionally, of felicitous invention.

title: U.S. Indicts Jerseyan and His Concern in the Pirating of Hit Recordings Worth Millions
description: A 49-year-old New Jersey man and his recordproduction company were indicted last week on Federal charges of illegally duplicating and marketing millions of dollars worth of hit records, eighttrack tapes and cassettes by Elvis Presley, Linda Ronstadt, Fleetwood Mac, Kiss and other popular recording artists.

title: Joined Twins Sent Home
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Jan. 27 (AP) Lisa and Elisa Hansen, twins born joined at the head, have been sent home from the University of Utah Medical Center pending further surgery to separate them. A hospital representative said that the 1-year-old girls were in good condition and that no date had been set for the next round of surgery.

title: If Suffolk Abolished Its Legislature.. .
description: THREE years ago, Nassau County asked its residents to decide whether to replace the present Board of Supervisors with a County Legislature. The voters overwhelmingly favored the present system, under which the Supervisors of the three towns and two cities also run the county government, casting votes weighted according to their towns population

title: Queens Man Killed in Accident
description: EGREMONT, Mass., Jan.27 (AP)  A 22-year-old . Queens man was killed shortly after 7 a.m. today in a headon collision on Highway 23 in this western Massachusetts town. The police said car driven by the victim, Vasa Sfera of Glendale, collided with one driven by 23earold Helene Stori of Ancramdale, N.Y. She and two passengers in the Sfera car were treated at Fairview Hospital in Great Barrington.

title: Wood, Field and Stream Exposing the Mysterious Atlantic Sturgeon
description: Commercial fishermen have been catching Atlantic, sturgeon in their Hudson River nets for many years, but until recently little was known about the numbers and habits of this hardy and primitive fish whose smoked flesh and salted eggs (caviar) are highlyprized by gourmets. Now, much of the mystery surrounding the Hudson's sturgeon has beep swept away as a result of research bonducted by William L. Dovel, a marine biologist, and funded by the Boyce Thompson Institute, the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation and the Federal Government.

title: Spivakov - A Modest Master
description: At his New York debut in 1975, Vladimir Spivakov, the Russian violinist, received glowing reviews; since then, following his annual recitals and orches- tra appearances in this country, those reviews have glowed even brighter. The Times has called him an extraordinary artist who has no superiors among violinists in the world today. The New York Daily News said his playing was godlike, creating sounds perhaps no other living violinist has ever before successfully attempted. For the San Francisco Chronicle, he can be justly compared to Heifetz, and the Chicago Tribune said that not since David Oistrakh's first appearance here has there been such a supercharged debut. He has everything.

title: More Long Island Residences for Retarded Are Planned Despite Community Hostility
description: BAY SHORE, L.I. --- The people who live in the threestory Colonialstyle house at 32 Brentwood Road are not very different from many other suburbanites. Phil Bernhardt belongs to a local bowling league and has a 145 average and five trophies to his credit. Lillian Sfratta has decorated her bed with stuffed animals and displays a picture of John Travolta on her dresser.

title: ON THE ISLE
description: Some pages from American musical history will be turned back today on the Island when an International Art of Jazz Quintet pays tribute to the late Duke Ellington in Garden City and Pete Seeger, the granddaddy of folk musicians, shows up in Huntington for the annual PAF Benefit Concert. Featuring Russell Procope and Harold Ashby, graduates of the original Ellington orchestra; Dill Jones, Ronnie Cole and Peck Morrison, the cabaretstyle jazz gig gets under way at 4 P.M. at the Ethical Humanist Society, 38 Old Country Road. Tickets are $3.50; for students and the elderly, $2. In Huntington, at the high school, McKay Avenue, Mr. Seeger will join Harry Chapin and Steve Goodman in two performances: at 2 P.M. for a familyoriented audience and at 8 P.M. for a general conference. Donations are $6.50 for the after$8.50 for the 2718423.

title: New Law May Curb Thefts and Stabilize Insurance Rates
description: E had parked his 1976 Corvette outside his home in Harrisburg, Pa., but the next morning it was gone. Vanished. A month later the New York City police spotted the stolen car abandoned in Astoria, Queens. The door had been forced and the ignition wires jumped, but otherwise the sleek $10,000 Stingray seemed little the worse for its travels.

title: CRIME
description: In his last book, Blood Brotherhood, Robert Barnard took a close look at the clergy and some of its eternal (though sel- dote publicly discussed) problems. Now Mr. Barnard has Corned his keen intelligence and sense of the absurd to an entirely different subject provincial opera. The book is DEATH ON THE HIGH C'S (Walker, $7.95), and it is a delight, despite the gimmicked title (and, come to think of it, there are no high C's in Rigoletto, the opera that occupies central part of the action).

So he protested, he caused change in the nominating system and last week he was rewarded with five votes out of a nossible total of 432_

description: The Brooklyn Bridge is showing its 95 years, and others among New York City's 51 bridges are in even worse shape. The estimated cost of fixing them up: $350 million. title: West Indies Hopes Slim Against India in Cricket

title: Prime Minister's Trip Last Week Could Be an Omen
description: CAPE TOWN, South Africa  If a journey of 10,000 miles begins with a single step, a 14mile round trip by helicopter taken by Prime Minister P.W. Botha last week could conceivably have marked the beginning of an odyssey for South Africa. Mr. Botha, four months in office, choppered out across the cold waters of the South Atlantic that separate this port city from Robben Island, a onetime leper colonythat has served in recent times as the country's most notorious political prison.

title: New Jersey/This Week
description: BLOOMFIELD (Bloomfield College, Franklin and Fremont Streets) - Long Day's Journey Into Night, in an Actor's CafeTheater production. Thursday through Saturday, 8:30 P.M. (through Feb. 10). $3.5045.50; students and the elderly, $2.5044.50. (201) 4297662. Westminster Theater.

title: The Rockefeller Gift
description: Nelson Rockefeller was born, of course, to every conceivable advantage and made the most of it through years of political and personal trial. For those blessed with wealth and influence. he set an extraordinary standard of concern and effort in the service of the cotuntry, New York State and his family, always promoting the nation's economic and military strength and fostering public as well as private support for the arts, education, science and health. He stood for enlightened internationalism against recurrent waves jingoism and for liberal capitalism against a persistent undertow of reaction.

title: Cutting Ice Is Her Career
description: SOME people go to Paris in the spring. But when May and early June roll around, it's home to Dix Hills for Melissa Militano, home to her parents splitlevel house and to sunshine, rest, tennis and golf.

title: FollowUp on the News
description: Mashpee Uprising

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: KRISTIN LAVRANSDATTER. The Bridal Wreath. The Mistress of Husaby. The Cross. By Sigrid Undset. (Bantam. 3 vols., $1.95 each.) This trilogy, which helped Sigrid Undset (18821949) win a Nobel Prize, follows a 14thcentury Norwegian woman from girlhood through troubled courtship, a stormy marriage and the devastations wrought by the Black Death to final, triumphant spiritual fulfillment. Undset was noted for her ability to bring modern realism and psychological insights to a remote time. This classic work has never before been available in paper covers.

title: Robinson of Amexco
description: When James Dickson Robinson 3d, the 43-year-old chief of American Express, bid for McGrawHill Inc., he apparently did not foresee the vehemence with which the McGrawHill board, spearheaded by its chairman, Harold McGraw, would oppose the move.

Tne group, picked at a meeting of the Honors Court and announced by Vincent dePaul Draddy, the foundation's chairman of the board, includes live backs, two ends, one tackle and one guard.

title: Notre Dame Upset By Maryland, 6766
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md., Jan. 27 Larry Gibson, a 6-foot-9-inch senior from Baltimore, provided a thrilling finish to one of'the season's most exciting games today when he completed a 3point play with one second remaining to give Maryland a 6766 triumph over Notre Damei the topranked college team in the nation the last two weeki.CHAMPAIGN, Ill. Jan. 27 (AP) Marty Bodnar's layup at the buzzer after a steal by Tom Staton gave Michigan a 5654 victory over Illinois today in a Big Ten contest.

title: Patricia A. Kidera Sets Aug. 4 Bridal

title: `Holocaust in Germany
description: A surprising onethird of West German television viewers tuned in to Holocaust, the American television drama depicting Nazi Germany's slaughter of Jews, despite the fact that it was shown only on regional channels. And the response by those who called the stations after seeing the program was largely favorable. That response may influence the coming debate in the Bundestag on extending beyond this year the deadline for prosecuting capital offenses committed in World War II.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: THOSE who are fortunate enough to have a woodburning fireplace in their house know that a crackling fire is a welcome sight on a cold winter night - in addition to serving as a valuable source of emergency heat during a power failure or when the central heating system is out of commission_ But little pleasure is derived from fireplace that smokes persistently when a fire is lit, or one that will not keep a fire burning uniformly unless it is constantly poked and frequently fed with additional kindling. In most cases these problems are caused by one of two things: either the fire was not properly built or there is a basic fault in the way the fireplace was designed.

title: Deaths
description: ROCKEFELLERNelson Aldridge The officers, directors, and staff the USO of Metropolitan New York express their deepest sympathy the family of the late Nelson Rocke feller. He was a great New Yorker and a great American. The founding by and ongoing support of USO by members of the Rockefeller family through the Rockefeller Brothers Fund and through personal gifts very much appreciated.

title: Edward Burns Jr. Marries Miss Reid
description: Winthrop Reid, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fergus Reid Jr. of New York and York Harbor, Me., was married yesterday to Edward Elliott Burns Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Burns of Sodus, N.Y., and Sarasota, Fla. The ceremony was performed in the Episcopal Church of the Incarnation by the Rev. Herbert Draesal of White Plains, assisted by Canon Robert Lewis.

title: UNTOLD STORY OF THE MIDEAST TALKS
description: For the statesmen engaged in the momentous effort to bring peace to the Middle East, 1978 opened on an uncertain note. Behind them - as recounted in last week's installment - were President Sadat :s journey to Jerusalem, the establishment of a hot line between .Jerusalem and Cairo, and the direct talks between Sadat and Prime Minister Begin at the Egyptian city of Ismailia by the Suez Canal. But at Ismailia, basic disagreements emerged and the momentum faltered.

description: MIDLAND PARK N ErskineDewitt map used at the time of the Revolutionary War shows a house and a mill along the Waragaw Brook, :specifically where Goffle Road and Paterson Avenue cross.

title: New Jersey Puts a Premium On Balancing Car Insurance
description: TRENTON  In New Jersey, as in many other states, it is the law that all cars on the highway must be insured. Providing that insurance is a big, lucrative business in New Jersey, worth $1.1 billion a year in oremiums.

title: Despite a Club's Bias, Stony Brook Expected To Back a New Lease
description: STONY BROOK, L. I., Jan. 24  The Brookhaven Town Board is due to vote next week on whether to renew its lease for town land with the Stony Brook Yacht Club, and it appears that the town is powerless to do anything but approve it, although town officials say the club denies full rights to women members.

title: Downey at 30: W ays and Means to New Roles

Downey. once the youngest member of Congress, on today reaching the grand old age of 30 are now focusing on such matters as depressed trajectories, assistance to the elderly and, just perhaps, trying to keep up with young women on the basketball court.

title: JURY OBTAINS DATA ON CARTER BUSINESS

Alaskans. many of whom have recently participated in such protests against President Carter  he was burned in effigy last month in Fairbanks  have a common grievance: The Federal Government still holds title and maintains full control over twothirds of the land allocated to the state 20 years ago.

Whatever her secret, it was readily apparent to an appreciative audience at her recital Friday night at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

They make no claim to being confessions, and so the charge of disingenuousness seems critical to no purpose. In any case, who doesn't expect diaries or autobiographies to be written from a personal point of view? Therein

title: IN BRIEF
description: Liggett Group Inc., the nation's sixth largest cigarette producer, and maker of such brands as L&M, Lark and Chesterfield, plans to swear off cigarettes completely. It said it agreed to sell its United States cigarette operations to company headed by a North Carolina shipping and real estate executive, Dolph Overton. Liggett sold its foreign cigarette business last year to Philip Morris Inc. Liggett said the transaction to sell the domestic operation would net the company about $122 million after the division's liabilities were settled, but would also result in an after tax charge against earnings of $35 million. Liggett, based in Durham. N.C., has been diversifying in recent into wines, liquors and foods.

title: Dina Del Guercio Is Married to Bradley B. Cruickshank
description: In the Winship Memorial Chapel of the First Presbyterian Church in Atlanta yesterday evening, Dina Maria Del Guercio, daughter of the late Carol Werber lden of Plantation, Fla., and the late Eligio Del Guercio Jr. of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and Landrum, S.C., became the bride of Bradley Beachy Cruickshank. He is a son of Mrs. William A. Cruickshank of Boca Raton, Fla., and the late Mr. Cruickshank.

title: Deaths
description: SPICERJames A. James Alfred Spicer was born Nov.1, 1927 in Qu eens, N.Y. He passed away sudden- ly, Saturday morning in, New York Hospital. He had played as planist at College Hall in the late 1940's and he was well known in both the European and New rork arts scenes. Over the last 39 years, he had been manager of such artists as the Paul Taylor Dance Company the Living Theatre, and Cecil Tay lor, the jazz pianist; among many others. He edited numerous books, including Julian Beck's .The Life of the Theatre, and Judith Malina's The Enormous Despair . He was prime mover and organizer of numerous avant garde groups tour ing in Europe from the late 1953's through present. As well, he was Prominent in the early ??? Broadway seem, having been one of the creators of the nowfamous Mon day Night Series, at the Living Theatre, which presented such artists as Merce Cunningham, Allen Ginsburg. John Cage, and exhibits with such artists as Warhol. Raus chenburg, and Johns. Mr. Spicer is survived by a brother, Howard of Newfield, N.Y.. a sister, Dorothy Hoppach, and his moiner Louise Spicer, both of Tampa. Fla. Private cremation will be held. A special memorial service will be held Wednesday evening at the Judson Church, Washington Square, Greenwich village.

title: Krishna Cult Is Sued Over Solicitations at Airport
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 26- Members of the Hare Krishna religious cult have been accused of beatings, death threats, shortchanging and fraud while soliciting funds at the Los Angeles Airport.

title: Children's Books Are Her Lifetime Story
description: 0 NCE upon a time, a young girl grew up in Woodside, Queens, in a house filled with books and pictures. Of all the books in her parents house, though, Elizabeth Billington's favorites were those by Randolph Caldecott, the 19th-century English illustrator of children's books who was among the first to interpret, rather than just decorate, the texts.

title: WESTCHESTER HOUSING
description: FOUR energyefficient houses are being planned and built by novice on her former family estate. They will have heat-saving systems that the builder, Mary Jo Crandall, hopes will cut fuel consumption by at least half.

title: 'Your Turn, My Turn,' French Comedy Film:The Cast
description: Franois Leterrier's "Your Turn, My Turn," the French comedy that opens today at the Cinema Studio 1, looks like a natural consequence of "Cousin, Cousine," taking a very romantic view of an extramarital affair, though not simplifying the obstacles to the affair's happy conclusion. Most unusual about the new film, however, is its hard-line antikiddism. You haven't seen a film in years in which the children, who are meant (I think) to be realistically observed, have behaved like such monsters. After seeing "Your Turn, My Turn," you may want to present yours with one-way tickets to Disneyland. These children are smug, demanding and impossibly high-toned brats of the sort who prefer health foods to good old-fashioned, teeth-ravaging candies.The movie is an adaptation by Daniele Thompson, Mr. Leterrier and Franoise Dorin of a novel by Miss Dorin. It's about Agnes (Marlene Jobert), the mother of a small boy and the bored wife of Serge (Daniel Duval), a rock-music promoter who has more time for his mistresses than for Agnes. Quite by accident, Agnes meets and falls in love with Vincent (Philippe Leotard), the divorced father of a 10-year-old daughter. Vincent is Mr. Right. He's a successful building contractor and a decent, down-to-earth fellow, something that seems to be associated with the way he dresses. Serge buys his clothes in boutiques. Vincent wears conventional clothes but he never, never wears a tie.The only impediment to the affair of Agnes and Vincent is her 7-year-old son, Jerome (Vladimir Andres), a precocious, self-centered boy who's never at a loss for words and who thoroughly disapproves of his mother's lover, though Serge couldn't care less. When the chips are down, and Agnes must choose between Vincent and Jerome, the lover hasn't a chance. That, however, is not the end.Actually, "Your Turn, My Turn" is both better and worse than this synopsis indicates. It never displays the cruelty that gave "Cousin, Cousine" some backbone. It has moments of such thick sentimentality and cuteness you may feel as if you're sitting in bubble gum. Yet, occasionally it is very funny and it has some very attractive supporting players, including Sylvie Jolly, who plays Vincent's physiotherapist-sister, a liberated lesbian, and Micheline Presle, still very beautiful and elegant, though her role here is virtually disposable.Most importantly, the film has Miss Jobert ("Rider in the Rain," "That Wonderful Crook"), who is not the world's greatest actress but who may be France's most accomplished professional gamine. Small, red-haired and pleasingly freckled, Miss Jobert is aging without apparent damage. She has also dropped a lot of her laughter-through-tears moments that punctuated her earlier performances.Miss Jobert's Agnes is made of sturdy stuff. Also she seems to be a woman of intelligence and taste. I'm still not sure if Miss Jobert has great facility as an actress or is merely facile. In any case she's most pleasant to behold in this sort of nonsense, whether she's running into her lover's arms  no one matches her for footwork that expresses both need and abandon  or simply lounging around the house in a terry-cloth dressing gown, sitting in such a way that an expanse of upper thigh is always discreetly exposed.Mr. Leotard makes a nice foil for her, but because the movie is seen almost entirely from the woman's point of view, the character exists as not much more than a sex symbol. The film's treatment of Agnes's women friends, all of whom are seeking liberation of one sort or another, is well meaning but sometimes very silly."Your Turn, My Turn" is a mixed bag. The English subtitles are adequate and, in one case, rather overprotective of the audience's ignorance. When someone says he is going to the movies to see "Jour de Fte," the subtitle tells us instead, "I'm going to see a Tati film."

title: Arts and Leisure Guide Of Special Interest
description: She represents the new generation very well, The Times's Jennifer Dunning wrote of choreographer Rachel Lampert. The comment might also characterize the Dance Theater Workshop's adventuresome winter series at the American Theater Laboratory, which will be introduced on Thursday by Miss Lampert's company in a fullevening dancetheater work. The series offers a crosssection of dance, from the highly experimental work of Kenneth Rinker, an early member of Twyla Tharp's troup who is now on his own as choreographer and who will appear at the end of the series in midMarch, to the more traditional, such as tapdancers Jane Goldberg and Charles Cook, who represent the current interest in the form. A lowcost subscription pass is available for those interested in seeing the entire spectrum. (See Dance)

title: Soviet Sensitivities Have Been Heightened by Peking's Pragmatic Foreign Policy
description: MOSCOW - Among the major failures of recent Soviet foreign policy has been its inability to isolate China. Ever since the SinoSoviet split in the early 1960's, the Russians have growled menacingly at all who have befriended Peking, hoping to mark China as a dangerous ally. For years Moscow tried to convene a conference of European Communist parties read Peking out of the movement, and for years the recalcitrant Yugoslays, Rumanians and others in Western parties refused until, in 1976, the Russians finally had to give up. Since Rumania insists on maintaining good relations with China, the Soviet Union has not even been able to get its own Warsaw Pact alliance to endorse an attack on Peking. After the death of Mao Tsetung in 1976, and especially in the past six months, China has launched a vigorous new foreign policy. Last August, it signed a friendship treaty with Japan. The same month, Chairman Hua Kuofeng ventured directly into the Soviet Union's sensitive backyard by visiting Yugoslavia, Rumania and Iran. And to top it all off, Deputy Prime Minister Teng Hsiaoping arrives in Washington today for a tour of the United States.

title: Tavern Mural Puts Inside on the Outside
description: HUNTINGTON RUSTY PETTIT was afraid that some of the regular patrons of Finnegan's Restaurant and Bar here might not like the idea of having their portraits painted on the wall outside. But Mr. Pettit, owner of Finnegan's, decided to go ahead anyway and let a 23-year-old muralist, Philip Charles Jordan, recreate the inside of Finnegan's outside on a concrete wall facing an alleyway.

title: Double Bill Presented by Opera Ebony
description: In the double bill presented by Opera Ebony in the Beacon Theater on Friday night, Mozart's elegant and sardonic little farce, The Impresario, came off better than Menotti's popular melodrama. The Medium. Both works were given well prepared and generally polished productions and, for change, an attraction at the Upper West Side theater drew a nearly full house.

title: Elizabeth Jane King Engaged To Thomas Everett Griess Jr.
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. J T King of Lubbock, Tex., of the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Jane King, to Thomas Everett Griess Jr. also of Lubbock. He is a son of Col. Thomas E. Griess, U.S.A., and Mrs. Griess of West Point, N.Y. A summer wedding is planned.

title: New Homes for Retarded Divide Communities
description: THE people who live in the threestory Colonialstyle house at 32 Brentwood Road are not very different from many other suburbanites. Phil Bern- hardt belongs to a local bowling league and has a 145 average and five trophies to his credit. Lillian Sfratta has decorated her bed with stuffed animals and displays a picture of John Travolta on her dresser.

title: A Times Sq. Youth Shelter Seeks Evictions to Expand
description: An emergency shelter for runaway youths at Eighth Avenue and 44th Street is seeking to evict four neighborhood merchants to expand services to what its founder calls the thousands of Times Square nomads, drifters, hustlers and prostitutes crying out for help.

title: For a Choice in Scarsdale
description: AS a resident of Scarsdale I feel very much deprived in the months preceding the March election. I am envious when compare other villages throughout Westchester with Scarsdale. The residents of those other municipalities have something that people in Scarsdale lack - voter input in the selection of elected officials.

title: Western Union Loses a Monopoly
description: The Western Union Corporation's 36year monopoly on domestic telegram service was ended last week by the Federal Communications Commission. There were no tears shed at Western Union.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: KOLN EXPRESS (Hapag-Lloyd-U.S. Navigation). Le Havre Feb. 4, Antwerp 6, Rotterdam 7, Hamburg 8 and Bremerhaven 9; sails from Port Elizabeth, N.J. SEALAND GALLOWAY (SeaLand). Bremerhaven Feb. 2, Rotterdam 3 and Algeciras 6; sails from Port Elizabeth, N.J.

title: Peter Horneffer Fianc of Barbara Williams
description: Mr. and Mrs. Rufus M. G. Williams of Glyndon, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Williams, to Peter Julian Horneffer, son of Mrs. Michael Homelier of New York and the late Mr. Horneffer.

title: DINING OUT
description: AN old and historic house turned restaurant, maintained with a charm appropriate to its pedigree and serving good food, is worth visit. Such is the Country House Restaurant in Stony Brook, believed to date from 1710.

title: 3 Give Photographic Impressions of the Danes
description: WHITE PLAINS

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: By David Wallechinsky and Irving Wallace.

title: April G. Alexander Sets August Bridal
description: The engagement of April Gay Alexander, daughter of Irene K. Alexander of Lloyd Harbor, Huntington, L.I., and Dr. John T. Alexander, also of Huntington, to Mark Elliott Cushing, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles S. Cushing Jr. of Rochester, has been announced by the future bride's mother. An August wedding is planned.

title: Sunday Observer
description: Modernized China begins for the tourist at Peking's Richard M. Nixon Airport, a vast concrete-and-glass airopolis on the Mongolian border some 120 miles from the capital.

title: Dream Cars of the Past Offer a Glimpse of the Future
description: THEY'RE gone now  most of them dismantled, destroyed, forgotten. A few are collecting dust in the laboratories. .They were the experimental cars of the past, cars we all got a glimpse of at auto shows but never got to drive. Each was exciting, different from the next. They were one-of-a-kind vehicles that were never put into production.

title: Director Michael Crichton Films a Favorite Novelist
description: LONDON

title: Girl Survives 11Floor Plunge
description: CHICAGO, Jan. 27, (Reuters)  A 9yearold girl plunged 11 floors down an elevator shaft and survived with no more than a broken leg and gashed forehead, doctors said Tuesday. Bewanda Vaughn fell as she climbed out of the elevator when it stuck between the 11th and 12th floors in the apartment building where she lives.

title: Nakamura and Kabuki to Open Kennedy Center Theater
description: WASHINGTON  Kanzaburo Nakamura, whom the Japanese call their living national treasure, will be one of the Grand Kabuki dancers performing this evening in an openingnight gala that will dedicate the new Terrace Theater at the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts.

title: A Small Town in Japan
description: A Portrait Oa Japanese Village, By Ronald P. Dore. Illustrated. 322 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $11.95.

title: ANTIQUES
description: INTEREST in painted furniture and folk art seems to have lagged in the state here for several months, but buying attention has now again focused on these related segments of American antiquecollecting,

title: Irsay, in Los Angeles, Has Meeting on Moving Colts
description: - LOS ANGELES, Jan. 27 (AP)  Robert Irsay, owner of the Baltimore Colts, met with Los Angeles Coliseum officials today to discuss the possibility of moving his National Football League team to Los Angeles in 1980.

title: Sarah Sultan Plans May Bridal
description: Esther Sultan of Williston Park, Li., has made known the engagement of her daughter, Sarah Sultan, to Michael Orlowitz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Orlowitz of Penn Valley, Pa. A May wedding is planned. The future bride, daughter also of the late Howard Sultan, graduated from Cornell University and received a master's in social work from Bryn Mawr College. Her fianc is a magna cum laude alumnus of Temple University.

title: Around the Nation
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 27  A Federal district judge handed out stiff sentences ranging from four to 10 years yesterday to eight men convicted of smuggling 17,000 pounds of marijuana from Thailand to Oregon two years ago.

title: A Welcome Newcomer in Darien
description: DARIEN

title: U.S. Asks Iranians to Scale Down Orders for Arms
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27  The Carter Administration, faced with a cutoff by the Iranians of funds for new purchases of American military equipment, is seeking an agreement with Iran on scaling down purchases of $12 billion in hardware and support services ordered by the Shah but not vet delivered.

title: Only Talented Animals Need Apply
description: DOUGLAS L. GRUBER is looking for models with animal magnetism, and the more the better. When models come to him with their photographs and portfolios, within 10 minutes he has a feeling for what he calls their charisma, but the real test often comes in the studio when the model has to eat 12 cups of dog food, and eat it with obvious gusto.

title: Late TV Listings
description: 11:30 A.M. (Channel 2) Face the Nation: Senator Edmund S. Muskie, Democrat of Maine.

title: Letters-
description: I read Seymour Zuckerman's letter ['Survival Guide, Dec. 10] with amused interest. He does not grasp the total effect of economic forces in his attempt to analyze the tight rental market.

title: Zoeller Leads by 2 Strokes
description: SAN DIEGO, Jan. 27 Fuzzy Zoe11er, a lighthearted Hoosier who doesn't think winning is everything in pro golf, rushed out of the field this afternoon to take a twolstroke lead in the third round of the 28th San Diego'open. On six birdies and only one bogey, Zoeller shot 67, five under par for the Torrey Pines south course on a bluff beside the Pacific Ocean.

title: Victoria Eyre Fiance of Banker
description: The engagement of Victoria Park Eyre to Jack Van Horn Whipple 2d has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Carstairs Eyre of Locust Valley, L.I., parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of George Amiel Whipple 2d and Hope Whipple of New York.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: ONE of several appeals of these two books  Leon Trotsky, by Irving Howe, and Antonio Gramsci. by James Jolt that both of their subjects evolved their theories in historical practice. This has

title: News Summary
description: As Shahpur Bakhtiar's peace overture toward Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini failed, violence broke out again in Teheran. Troops fired on demonstrators just west of Teheran University, where more than 20 people were killed Friday, and kept up a steady fusillade for five hours. By nightfall at least 28 people had beenkilled and hundreds wounded. Bakhtiar's trip to Paris is out of the question for the time being, an aide of the Prime Minister said after Ayatollah Khomen rejected the propozial for a meeting. We have to try to work out another compromise formula Page Al, Column 6.

title: I.T.F. Backs Rule Changes
description: LONDON, Jan. 28 (UPI)  The International Tennis Federation today agreed again with rules drawn for this year's Grand Prix circuit, raising the prospect that the world's major tournaments could go ahead without the headline stars.

title: Fitness Poll Yields Some Surprises
description: CONTRARY to popular beliefi, people who exercise regularly do not sleep less, eat less or smoke less than people who are inactive, a national survey shows. Nor are highly active people more likely to have lost weight in recent years than those who do some, but relatively little, exercise.

title: 2 CBS News Programs Exported on Cassettes
description: In Amman. Jordan. The CBS Evening News With Walter Cronkite and the television news magazine 60 Minutes play to an American audience of about 100 people in the video lounge of the Raytheon Corporation's recreational facilities.

title: Resilient Chinese Leader
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28  The leader who arrived here today to repay Richard M. Nixon's visit to Peking was out of sight and out of mind at the time of that first trip by an American President to China not quite seven years ago.

title: The Region
description: HOBOKEN (UPI)  Hudson County authorities plan to bring evidence before a juvenile court judge today indicating that several children set a fire in a Hoboken tenement that killed 21 people last week.

title: The City
description: Two Queens men were arrested yesterday and charged with murdering the mother of one of them for inheritance and insurance money, and then faking a burglary to hide evidence of the murder.

title: Teng in the U.S. To Meet Carter And Widen Ties
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28  Smiling and applauding his hosts in the traditional Chinese fashion, Teng Hsiaoping, the senior Deputy Prime Minister of China, arrived this afternoon to begin the first official visit to the United States by a top Chinese Communist leader.

title: BAKHTIAR PEACE BID TO KHOMEINI FAILS; VIOLENCE RENEWED
description: 35 DEAD IN TEHERAN CLASHES

title: GLENN FLANAGAN
description: PUERTO VALLARTA. Mexico Jan. 28 (AP)  Glenn Flanagan of St. Paul Minn... who fought for the featherweight championship of the world in 1952. died today of a heart attack while vacationing in Mexico. He was 52 years old.

title: Market Place
description: BEECH AIRCRAFT, a pioneer in building private planes, had a bumpy journey in the stock market last week as takeover rumors made the rounds once again.

title: A Zurich Opinion: Rates Still Climbing
description: Dismissing the rally in the credit markets last week as a brief reversal, a leading analyst of fixedincome securities predicted over the weekend that interest rates would climb higher than expected this year and remain there longer.

title: A Series Hero for Sale: The Marketing of Bucky Dent
description: THE first thing you notice about Bucky Dent is that he is handsome. So handsome, in fact, that it is possible not to notice second thing about Bucky Dent.

title: Golf: Triumph for Zoeller
description: SAN DIEGO, Jan. 28  Fuzzy Zoeller, a happy-go-lucky 27-year-old Hoosier who likes a good time on and off the golf course, won the 28th San Diego open today, his first victory since he ioined the PGA Tour at the end of 1974.

title: Ford Halts Output Of New Engine
description: DETROIT, Jan. 28(UPI)  The Ford Motor Company has halted production indefinitely on its new turbocharged engine, available in Mustangs and Capris, to correct a defect.

title: Sports World Specials
description: The Harlem Globetrotters, always on the lookout ,for hot talent to lend a new wrinkle to their slightly familiar act, have come to terms with several social roadblocks in making their latest acquisition. a raw, thickskinned rookie who comes to play.

title: Aid to Neediest Helps Aged
description: Many of New York's elderly live out their lives in fear, loneliness and financial uncerlainty. The 67th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Find helps provide mach needed social services to assist some of these older New Yorkers obtain a fair measure of dignity and comfort.

title: Harold Weissman Weds Judith Reiter
description: Judith Dana Reiter, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Gabriel Reiter of Margate, N.J., was married yesterday in the libiary at the St. RegisSheraton to Harold H. Weissman, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Morris Weissman of Canonsburg, Pa. Rabbi Alan W. Miller performed the ceremony.

title: Algeria Requests Higher Gas Prices
description: The El Paso Company announced yesterday that at the request of Sonatrach, the Algerian national oil and gas company, the price Algeria charges El Paso for liquefied natural gas would soon be renegotiated.

title: Radical Surgery Is Questioned In New Study of Breast Cancer
description: A biologist who has been studying the results of followup surveys in this country and abroad has raised anew the question of whether radical surgery is the most effective treatment for cancer of the breast.

title: Knicks Drop Fifth in a Row, 122105; Richardson Stirs Excitement; A Promethean Effort; Need Overall Improvement; Knicks Box Score; KNICKS (105); WASHINGTON (122)
description: LANDOVER, Md., Jan. 28  The Knicks fivegame, eightday road trip ended today the same way it had begun  with a onesided loss and some fingerpointing at Bob McAdoo's defensive play.

title: Historian Says Eisenhower Never Sought Divorce
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (UPI)  The editor of the papers of Dwight David Eisenhower said today that suggestions that Eisenhower wanted to divorce his wife, Mamie, at the end of World War II and marry an Englishwoman are untrue.

title: To Aid Taiwan, American Group Will Organize New Flying Tigers
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Jan. 28 (Reuters) Representative George Hansen said today that a delegation he had brought here would organize an assistance project for Taiwan to be named the New Flying Tigers.

title: ESSAY
description: WASHINGTON  At the White House state dinner for Teng Hsiaoping, polite eyecontact will be made as the glasses are raised. But the words chosen by the strange concatenation of leaders past and present will hardly reflect what each of them must be thinking.

title: Letters
description: Princeton, N.J., Jan. 20, 1979 The writer is McCormick Professor of Jurisprudence, emeritus, at Princeton University.

title: Susan Lynn Bloom Bride Of Laurence Baron Jones
description: The marriage of Susan Lynn Bloom, an associate counsel with New York State United Teachers,. to Laurence Baron Jones, a lawyer with the New York firm of Winer, Neuburger & Sive, took place yesterday at the Jewish Community Center of Harrison, N.Y. Rabbi Norton Shargel performed the ceremony.

title: Success of Ten's Visit to U.S. Tied To How 3 Crucial Audiences React
description: WASHINGTON. Jan. 28 Administration officials say that the success of the visit of Deputy Prime Minister Teng Hsiaoping to the United States may depend on how its results are judged by at least three crucial audiences.

title: Sears Suit on U.S. JobBias Rules Puts Past Alliances to Strict Test
description: Sixteen and a half years ago, when 32-year-old white Birmingham lawyer named Charles Morgan Jr. spoke to business group the day after a bomb had destroyed four young black lives and a church in the city. the civil rights problem in America was brutal, but seemed relatively simple.

title: Canadian Wins Award To New Choreographers
description: BOSTON  Constantin Patsalas, a soloist with the National Ballet of Canada, won the $5,000 Boston Ballet Award in the first annual International Choreographer's Competition here Saturday night.

title: Fanfare Planned for Senate Chamber
description: ALBANY. Jan. 26 A champagne reception. a dinner for 250 public and private leaders's and a Capitol celebration by 1,500 movie will give the newly renovated Senate Chamber its official sendoff Tuesday.

title: Rioting and Death Invade a Quiet Lane in Teheran
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 23  Frenzy, fear and a kind of dignity came today to Bahrami Lane. a drab little side street off a major square in Teheran, as soldiers Bred again and again on thousands of antiGovernment protesters taunting them and the Prime Minister with cries of Death to Bakhtiar!

title: A Diet Clinic Helps Obese Youngsters
description: The doctor is a tiny. 103pound pediatrician who looks as though she could wash down five sausage pizzas with five chocolate malteds each day and not gain an Ounce.

title: Around the Nation
description: MONTEAGLE, Tenn., Jan. 28 (AP) Fortysix drums of radioactive nuclear waste spilled and broke open on Interstate 24 tonight when a truck overturned near here, Civil Defense officials said.

title: Khomeini Declares That Bakhtiar Must Quit Before They Can Meet
description: NEAUPH LE-LE-CHATEAU, France, Jan. 28  Plans to hold talks here on resolving Iran's political crisis were thrown into confusion today when Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini abruptly rebuffed peace overtures by Prime Minister Shahpur Bakhtiar.

description: TONIGHT television is offering two productions that are considerably above average and. with typical scheduling perversity, they are running against each other. The Corn Is Green is on CBS from 9 to 11, Backstairs at the White !louse on NBC from 8 to 11.

title: Bush Says campaign Seeks Matching Funds After Only 3 Weeks
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28  George Bush said today that in three weeks of fundraising he had qualified for Federal matching funds for his Presidential campaign.

title: Decade After Coast Spill, Offshore Oil Under Cloud
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 28 Ten years after the oil well blowout at Santa Barbara, the picturesque resort community of Spanishstyle buildings and gleaming beaches has largely regained its traditional serenity.

title: Poll Finds 46% Still Oppose Ties With China at Taiwan's Expense
description: After more than a month of publicity and explanations for the Administration's decision to establish full diplomatic relations with China, a substantial plurality of the American people still disapproves of recognizing Peking at the expense of relations with Taiwan, according to the latest New York TimesCBS news poll.

title: Jersey Rejects Fast Action on Mercury Peril
description: WOODRIDGE, NJ., Jan. 2 State environmental officials told a rare Saturday meeting of the Town Council yesterday that mercury contamination here posed no immediate health hazard, and they continued to reject demands from local officials for quick action against the pollution here and in the nearby Hackedsack Meadowlands.

title: Ali: Spinks Will Get Title
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 28 (AP)  Muhammad Ali keeps insisting that he never will return to the ring and leans toward Leon Spinks as his successor as world heavyweight boxing champion

title: Bridge:
description: For half a century following the famous cruise during which Vanderbilt codified contract bridge, every world title, with one minor exception, was won by players from Europe and North America. But the picture has changed completely since 1975: Brazil has emerged as a major power in the bridge world

title: Brooklyn 71, Lehman 60
description: Robert Requena scored 22 points and Larry Vitelli had 17 to lead Brooklyn College to a 7160 victory yesterday over Lehman College in a City University Conference game at the loser's court. Keith Yearwood of Lehman led all scorers with 24 points. Brooklyn's overall record is now 69 and 22 in the conference. Lehman is 410 over all and 14 in the conference.

title: Welcoming the Year of the Ram
description: Flags, dragons and banners wound throught the streets of Chinatown to the accompaniment of firecrackers yesterday as the Chinese community here celebrated the lunar new year. The flag of Nationalist China was carried by one marcher, but, according to the police, there were few political overtones. Some believe that people born this year will be wise, gentle and passionate.

title: Weekly Lotto Numbers Drawn
description: The numbers picked Saturday night in New York State's weekly Lotto drawing were 32, 13, 21, 35, 2 and 30. The supplementary number was 18.

title: Detective Kills Murder Suspect; Says He Thought Man Had Gun
description: A Brooklyn homicide detective shot and killed a 29-year-old murder suspect last night when he mistakenly thought the man was pulling a gun on him, the police said.

title: Kings 137, Cavaliers 109
description: KANSAS CITY. Jan. 28 (AP)  Otis Birdsong scored 30 points and had 10 assists today to pace the Kansas City Kings to a 137109 victory over the Cleveland Cavaliers.

title: New Albany Room Is Retaining Best of the Old
description: ALBANY There is not much work in New York State by Henry Hobson Richardson, the immense, rotund and energetic man who was perhaps the greatest American architect of the 19th cvntury. But now there is one more of his designs than there were six months ago.

title: Deaths
description: KRINGSTEIN-Dr Abraham.Beloved father of Dr Gilbert, and Maniyn Susman, adored grandfather, dear brother. Services Tuesday ? the Riverside Brooklyn, Ocean Parwav at picsoect park.

title: Arab Countries Fear Spread of Iran's Shiite Revolt
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Jan. 28  The emergence of a mass movement of Shiite Islamic revivalism, led by Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini of Iran, has aroused profound concern in the Arab world, particularly in Iraq and the sheikdoms of the Persian Gulf, where oilbased economies are vulnerable to a variety of potentially troublesome outsiders.

title: Iran Crisis Stoked by Obstinacy of Factions
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 28  This strategic, potentially wealthy country 1 has spun out of control, and only the opti! mists here can see a way of braking the  downward spiral toward civil war.

title: Chess:
description: Not only did Yale University win the PanAmerican intercollegiate team championship for the first time and not only did the team win every match, but also no player lost a game in the tournament, which was sponsored by the University of Chicago and the Illinois Institute of Technology and held in Chicago.

title: Connors Crushes she by 63, 64, 61
description: But Jimmy Connors survives. And with his 63, 64, 61 victory over Ashe in the final of the United States Pro Indoor tennis championship today, the 26yearold connor, Collected $10,900 and again demonstrated why he remained The most formidable figure in the sport.

title: Pope Warns Bishops Against Political Role by Clergy
description: PUEBLA, Mexico, Jan. 28  In a clear and powerful message. Pope John Paul II tonight told a conference of Latin American bishops that Christians had a responsibility to address social and political problems, but he ruled out political activity and new ideologies and theologies for the clergy.

title: BELL WILL SHAKE UP IMMIGRATION UNIT
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (UPI)  Attorney General Griffin B. Bell, angered by rampages in the United States by Iranian exchange students, is directing a major overhaul of immigration control procedures.

title: Old Conflicts Are Bared at the Letelier Slaying Trial
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28  The evidence being presented to the jury on the sixth floor of the United States Court House only a few blocks from the Capitol concerns a single violent act: the explosion of a powerful bomb that killed Orlando Letelier, a former Chilean diplomat. and an assistant. Ronni Moffitt.

title: Theater: Wings Comes to Broadway
description: A WOMAN having a stroke . would seem to make a difficult and resistant subject for play. Wings mounts and soars on this resistance like the airplane that serves as its distant motif.

title: LIU SHAOCHI'S DEATH REPORTED BY PEKING
description: Liu Shaochi, the former Chinese head of state who became the principal victim of the Cultural Revolution, was reported dead yesterday by Peking's official press agency in the roundabout fashion that it often uses to report on delicate matters.

title: Washington Watch
description: WASHINGTON THE President has finished with the budget for the 1980 fiscal year, which commences Oct. 1, but the Congress . , has yet to begin, and its leaders have already made clear that changes area virtual certainty.

title: Rangers on RollerCoaster
description: What's with the Rangers? As if following a premeditated plan to torture their fans with grandiose victories followed by ignominious defeats, they have become the National Hockey League's most schizophrenic performers.

title: Miss Stevens Triumphs
description: HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Jan. 28 (UPI)  Greer Stevens, playing in only her second tournament since knee surgery 10 months ago, outlasted Dianne Fromholtz, 61, 26, 64. today to win $150,000 women's tour event. It was her first major victory.

title: Afghan Rebels Seeking Help From Arab States
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan, Jan. 28 (Reuters)  Afghan dissidents are seeking arms from Saudi Arabia and other Arab countries to help their insurrection against the Sovietbacked regime in Kabul, informed sources said today.

title: News of the Dance Elgin Will Be Theater for MediumSized Troupes
description: No one has ever accused Eliot Feld of timidity, but the choreographer's latest project might cow the most arrant of heroes. Well, we bought the Elgin Theater, Mr. Feld reported matter-offactly the other day, referring to theLate Decostyle movie house that has long stood empty on the corner of Eiehth Avenue and 19th Street. Should all as planned, in six months New York will have a sorely needed 500seat dance theater with basement dressing rooms, rehearsal studio and even green room and bar, all designed by Hugh Hardy of Hardy, Holzman & Pfeiffer Associates.

title: Walter B. Schleiter, ExOfficial For Muller
description: Walter B. Schleifer, a former partner and vice president of Muller & Phipps (Asia). an export company, died Saturday at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston, from a stroke after a long illness. He was.78 years old and lived in Manhat tan.

description: American Boardcasting companes has named gilbet E levassrur Jr ?????? vice president of ABC pub- listing division

description: PARIS, Jan. 28 (AP)  High Echelon, an 851 shot, went ahead in the last 50 yards today and captured the $235,000 Prix d'Amerique trotting classic at Vincennes Race Track.

title: Lynn Pearlman, a Buyer, Is Married to David Minkow
description: Lynn Alison Pearlman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Pearlman of Orlando, Fla., was married there yesterday to David Lawrence Minkow, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Minkow of Port Washington. L.I. Rabbi Chaim Rozwacski performed the ceremony at the Marriott Inn.

description: Salvatore DeCarlo, a retired day adroom foreman in the composing room of The New York Times, died Saturday at the age of 69 He lived at 48 Page Drive in Oakland. N.J.

title: U.S. SAID TO SUPPORT FREEING MISS HEARST
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28  The Department of Justice has recommended that President Carter exert executive clemency and commute the sentence of Patricia Hearst, the publishing heiress who was convicted Of participating in a 1979 armed bank robbery, key Administration sources said today.

title: Denville Couple Killed in Crash
description: SUCCASUNNA, N.J., Jan. 28 (UPI) A Denville couple were killed and their two children were injured in a two-car collision in this Morris County community early yesterday morning. The couple, indentified as John Olender, 34 years old, and his wife, Darrylyn, 32, died, according to the police, when their car slammed into the rear of another car at the intersection of Route 10 and Hillside Avenue. The two children, Shana, 7, and Christopher, 11, were tx)th taken to Dover General Hospital with head injuries. The driver of the other car, Loise DeMastro, 24, of Randolph Township, was not injured.
