title: C.A.B. Urged To Bar Merger
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP)  The Justice Department and the Transportation Department opposed the merger of Continental Air Lines and Western Airlines in separate papers sent to the Civil Aeronautics Board today.

title: E.P A. Air Surveillance Reported
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29  The Environmemal Protection Agency conducts extensive aerial photographic surveillance of industrial facilities, usually without informing the comparie involved, as part of its enforcement program, according to documents obtained in a Freedom of Information action.

title: Cauthen Taken Off Affirmed
description: ARCADIA, Calif. Jan. 29 (AP)  Steve Cauthen, the 18-year-old jockey currently mired in a deep losing slump, has been replaced as the rider of Affirmed, Laz Barrera, the horse's trainer, announced today. Barrera named Laf fit Pincay to ride the 1978 Triple Crown winner in Sunday's $200,000added Strub Stakes at Santa Anita.

title: Tomboy and Gun Enthusiast
description: SAN DIEGO, Jan. 29 (AP)  Brenda Spencer's classmates described her today as a tomboy and a gun enthusiast who had difficulty adjusting to school.

title: Gov. Brown's Got More Than Mellow Folks
New York Banks Lower Brokerage Loan Rates
description: Major New York banks lowered the interest rate they charge on loans to securities dealers by onehalf percentage point to 11 percent, but loan officers said they thought the reduction would not lead to a general reduction in rates of corporate loans. The prime rate, now 11 percent, should remain there, they said.

title: Rostropovich Conducts Britten's War Requiem
description: THE mustering of forces Friday night at Carnegie Hall was an impressive affair, and the resultant performance of Benjamin Britten's War Requiem (Op. 66) by Mstislav Rostropovich and the National Symphony Orchestra made a strong, tender case for the music.

title: Deaths
description: HOWESLilian Hawley. Died Saturday, January 27, 1978. Wife of the late Dr. William Edward Howes of Brooklyn, NY. Member of the D.A.R. Former TreasurerGeneral of the National Society of the Colonial Daughters of the 17th Century, and past President of the Brooklyn Women's Club. She is survived by her sister, Mrs. Raymond Kautz, and her brother. Robert Hawley, both of San Marino, CA; her daughter, Mrs. Grace Lee. of DenniSport, MA; her son, John and three grandchildren, Thomas. Elise and William, of Killingworth CT. Services will be held at St. Ann & the Holy Trinity Church, Brooklyn Heights, on Thursday at 2pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the St. Ann & the Holy Trinity Church of Brooklyn Memorial Fund would be appreciated.

title: Museum Plans Dandelion With Paper Bag Players
description: Dandelion, a musical fantasy based on Darwin's theory of evolution, featuring the Paper Bag Players, will be performed at the American Museum of Natural History from Feb. 24 through March 18. The show, for adults and children, has been presented at several theaters in England.

title: Nixon, at Teng's Dinner, Said to Plan a China Trip
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29  Former President Richard M. Nixon returned to the White House tonight for the first time since his tearful farewell on Aug. 9, 1974, as he resigned the Presidency under threat of impeachment.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: The dollar turned in a mixed showing yesterday in relation to other major currencies. Volume was light on the world's foreignexchange markets as traders awaited the release today of American trade statistics for last month.

title: Getty, Sun Profits Up
description: The Getty Oil Company, the Continental Oil Company and the Sun Company yesterday joined the parade of oil companies reporting higher earnings for 1978's fourth quarter and for the full year.

title: Iran Cancels Nuclear Plants
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Cuevas Retains Title, Stopping Clark in Second
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 29 (AP)  Jose (Pipino) Cuevas, the 21-year-old slugger from Mexico City, made short work of his eighth World Boxing Association welterweight title defense when he knocked out Scott Clark of Orlando, Fla., in the second round tonight.HAMAMATSU, Japan, Jan. 29 (AP)  Betulio Gonzalez of Venezuela, world flyweight boxing champion, narrowly kept his title tonight in a 15round draw with Shoji Oguma of Japan.

title: Cash Prices
description: MONDAY. JAN. 29, 1979

title: Statements at the Graveside
description: Following are remarks by a 15yearold son and a 23yearold granddaughter of Nelson A. Rockefeller made during graveside services for Mr. Rockefeller yesterday:

title: Taxes &
description: Richard Phalon

title: New Debate Seen on Why Man First Walked Erect
description: The new theory links the emergence of bipedalism, as anthropologists call the ability to walk on two legs, to the advent of the nuclear. family, extensive food sharing and the more or less continuous sexual availability of males and females in a pair bond.

title: Bridge:
description: Legend has it, rather implausibly, that the crocodile sheds tears to give an appearance of compassion, thus tempting the unwary victim within reach of his jaws. Crocodile tears at the bridge table. however. are quite different They are shed by a player who has missed a golden opportunity to close his jaws at the right moment. A surprising feature of the whole business is that the possible victim is the crocodile's partner  who is likely to be angry that he has not been swallowed.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Dolphin D. Overton 3d mortgaged everything he owns to finance the projected purchase, anounced last Friday, of the Liggett & Myers Tobacco Company, the domestic cigarette operations of the Liggett Group, for about $122 million. Was it a good idea?

title: CREDIT MARKETS Lower Bond Yields Halt Rally
description: The rally in the credit markets, which began Jan. 18, continued early yesterday and then faltered during the afternoon, producing the first decline in eight trading days.

title: Letters
description: U.S. Senator from Wisconsin Washington, Jan . 26,1979

title: List of Guests at Dinner for Visiting Chinese Leader
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 Following a guest list provided by the White House for the dinner honoring Teng Hsiaoping, the visiting Chinese Deputy Prime Minister.

title: EDUCATION
description: PULLMAN. Wash.

title: Dividends
description: MONDAY, JAN 9 1979

title: National Steel Net Gains
description: The National Steel Corporation of Pittsburgh reported yesterday that its fourthquarter earnings more than doubled, to $38 million, or $1.98 a share, compared with $16.5 million, or 85 cents a share, in the yearearlier period.

title: Text of Statements by Carter and Teng at Welcoming Ceremony
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) - Fol- lowing are the texts of remarks today by President Carter and Deputy Prime Minister Teng Hsiaoping at a welcom- ing ceremony for the Chinese leader at the White House.

title: Science Watch
description: A new study by scientists at the University of Michigan suggests that both environment and heredity are responsible for repeated findings that American blacks have significantly higher bloodpressure levels than American whites.

title: Cho Lin, Wife of Peking Leader, Has Known the Perils of Politics
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29.- Chinese political wives don't have it easy, either. The grandmother with the quick, winning smile who stood next to Rosalynn Carter on the South Lawn of the White House today, clutching a handbag that looked like alligator, has twice gone into political oblivion along with her husband.

title: American Express Lifts $34 Bid
description: The American Express Company yesterday raised its offer for McGrawHill Inc. to $40 a share, contingent on an end to what it described as the publishing company's scorched earth policy aimed at preventing a takeover.

title: Public Gets Film Role In Canada
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 29  A ghost story and a thriller  The Changeling, a $6.6 million film starring George C. Scott, and Agency, a $4 million production starring Robert Mitchum  are pioneering a dramatic change in the Canadian movie industry: The films are being financed as a Governmentregulated, taxshelter investment, on a par with building apartment houses or exploring for oil and natural gas.

title: German Study Finds Evidence for Motive Of Mobbing Birds;
description: A GROUP of German scientists has found evidence to support the theory that groups of prey animals engage in mobbing  approaching, following or even attacking real or imagined enemies  to teach younger animals the techniques for discouraging predators.

title: Steel Output Up for Week
description: Steel production for the week ended Jan. 27 rose 5.8 percent to 2.558 million tons from the previous week's 2.418 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: CORRECTION
description: The byline on the foreign affairs column. Making Peace and Keeping It, on Sunday was incorrect as a result of art editor's error. The author is of course Albert Wohlstetter, not Alfred.

title: Giants Lose FrontOffice Candidates
description: Two candidates for the Giants directorofoperations job were eliminated yesterday  John Ralston, by signing as vice president in charge of administration for the San Francisco 49ers, and Gil Brandt, by apparently being tied up by the Dallas Cowboys through the college draft in May.

title: Coal Wastes Used To Construct Reefs
description: RESEARCHERS on Long Island think they may have found the answer to a major problem that the nation will lace when its oil resources run out in several decades and coal becomes the main energy source. At the same time, they hope to aid commercial and ama??ur fishermen.

title: Pope Tells Mexico's Indians He'll Speak for the Oppressed
description: OAXACA, Mexico, Jan. 29 Pope John Paul II visited one of Mexico's most backward regions today and pledged to act as the voice of the poor and oppressed. But few of the 15,000 Indians who listened to him in a village near here understood him.

title: Knicks Lose, 107104; Streak Is Now at Six
description: The Golden State Warriors have something to be thankful for  the Knicks.

title: Jazz: His Students Play A Memorial to Tristano
description: Six pianists performed, and most of them echoed Mr. Tristano's manner of reharmonizing standard tunes, his penchant for improvising lines with great rhythmic variety, and his early experiments  the first on record  with freeform improvisation. The most impressive was Sal Mosca, who has grown over the years into an eccentric original, with a touch and harmonic sense that are instantly recognizable. But Liz Gorrill, Mr. Tristano's most recent protege, also turned in exciting work, with her dark, boiling dissonances and broken rhythms.

title: Tires of 90 School Buses Slashed on L.I.
description: ST. JAMES. L.1 Jan. 29 Seven thousand Smithtown schoolchildren had to walk or be driven to school this morning by their parents because vandals had slashed the tires of 90 school buses,along with 20 other spare vehicles owned by Bimco Industries Inc.

title: Concert: Maureen Forrester Sings Cycle by Elgar
description: Enigma Variations. So, Maureen Forrester's performance of the five songs at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Sunday night might have set any casual music listener to wondering where these evocative pieces have been hiding. Serious record collectors would not wonder, of course, because Dame Janet Baker commited the cycle to disk many years ago.

title: American Air Earns $8 Million
description: While a number of other major airlines were experiencing losses or sharply curtailed profits, American Airlines Inc. continued its turnaround, apparently right through the end of the year. The company reported preliminary profits yesterday of $8 million for the fourth quarter of 1978, compared with a loss of $12.1 million in the yearearlier period.

title: Khomeini Keeps Op War of Words Against Bakhtiar
description: NEAUPHLE-LE-CHATEAU, France, Jan. 29 Iran'is exiled religious leader, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, having been forced again to delay his return because of the closing of the Teheran Airport, stepped up his war of words with the Bakhtiar Government today.

title: Kennedy Assails Cuts President Is Proposing For Law Enforcement
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29  In another attack on the Administration's budget priorities, Senator Edward M. Kennedy accused President Carter today of making unwise, unnecessary and unfair cuts in the 1980 budget of the Law Enforcement Assistance Administration.

title: Questioning Of Iacocca Expected
description: Lee A. Iacocca, former president of the Ford Motor Company and now president and chief operating officer of the Chrysler Corporation, has agreed to submit to a detailed interrogation by Federal prosecutors investigating allegations that Ford Motor paid a bribe to an Indonesan Government official. sources familiar with the case said yesterday.

title: Differences Fade as Rivals Mingle to Honor Teng
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29  The heads of CocaCola and Pepsico, the United Auto Workers and General Motors mingled tonight as they all honored Deputy Prime Minister Teng Hsiaoping at a state dinner at the White House.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: KIERKEGAARD once said that he would have been happier as a police spy; he had, he thought, a decided talent for it. This nice relationship between metaphysics and betrayal seems to me to be almost a condition of literary modernism, the weather of our bad dreams. We are all spies, but is there anything to spy on except one another?

title: Gerard Moran, a Rutgers Law Professor Dies at 53
description: Gerard R. Moran, a professor at the Rutgers University School of Law in Newark, died of cancer Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 53 years old.

title: Dance: Daniel Maloney Troupe
description: In Minstrel Show, the forced jollity of a parade of strutting and grinning black minstrel show characters gave way to vignettes that depicted the actual misery of life in the Old South. That those grins were only masks was demonstrated in scenes showing poverty, lechery, drunkenness and even infanticide.

title: World Gold
description: MONDAY. JAN 29, 1979

title: Agreement on Fund Cited
description: LAUSANNE, Switzerland, Jan. 29 The staging of the 1984 Summer Olympics in Los Angeles became threatened again today when the city's organizing committee and the United States Olym pic Committee could not agree on terms of a final contract. The contract was to have been signed tonight with the executive board of the International Olympic Committee.

title: Stock Prices Off and Dow Drops 3.98
description: Stock prices staged a modest retreat yesterday in slow trading following last week's show of strength.

title: Deaths
description: ROSENHarriet. Died Jan. 29. Woodlands Community Temple expresses deep sadness at the death of our congregant and long time member of our School Board. Harriet Rosen and extends condolences to her husband, Harold, her children. Gary and Barl, her parents. Dr. Philip and Hazel Gottlieb, and her sister, Muriel Hackel. Service Tues., at 10:30 A.M., Woodlands Community Temple, 50 Worthington Rd.. Green. burgh, N.Y.

title: About Pocantico Hills
description: POCANTICO HILLS, N.Y.. Jan. 29 Joe Canzeri..the best advance man Nelcoo Rockefeller ever had, darted about on his ultimate mission today, watching the mourners cars, manning the walkietalkie, seeing his master's ashes into the winter earth.

title: Rise in Saudi Oil Output Foreseen in First Quarter
description: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia (UPI)  An authoritative source says that Saudi Arabia will increase its oil production by one million barrels a day, to 9.5 mil-lion barrels a day, during the first quarter of 1979. Oil companies would have to pay a 5 percent premium for the extra output, the source said.

title: Carey Praised By Macchiarola On School Plan
description: The New York City Schools Chancellor, Frank J. Macchiarola, yesterday praised Governor Carey's new budget formula, which is designed to equalize the financing of public schools, but warned that was crucial that the Legislature insure that the funds be spend to improve education rather than to cut local property taxes.

title: Ayatollah, the Symbol of Revolt, Eludes Definition
description: NEAUPHLE-LE-CHATEAU, France, Jan. 29  The Iranians who chant the name of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini and paste his picture on their car hoods see in him a hatred for a corrupt monar- chy, a desire to regain an Iranian identity that has been blurred by foreign influ-  ence and a turn toward a new but un- defined way of life.

title: Sports Today
description: Nets vs. Lakers, at Los Anzelar (re.eve) Cbannel 9, 11 P.M.)

title: Debut: Robert Edwards, Pianist
description: THE sheer dependability of Robert L. Edwards's playing on Jan. 14 at Carnegie Recital Hall made his New York debut recital a pleasure to listen to. The pianist. who teaches at Kansas State Uni- versity, is obviously a sensitive musician, and his technique is such that. even when confronted with the likes of Liszt's treacherous Sonata in B minor. he handled the notes accurately and incisively. Mr. Edwards also knows how to produce a fullbodied tone without forcingthe big climaxes were invariably robust without turning clangorous

title: Italian Prime Minister Defends Government's Record as Terrorism Rises
description: ROME, Jan. 29  Against a back, ground of increasing political terrorism, Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti went before Parliament today to defend the  record of his 10-month-old Government, insisting that it was a success despite its loss of majority support. He is expected to resin tomorrow.

title: New Test Is Planned On Shroud of Turin
description: A GROUP of research laboratories has developed a technique that, a spokesman says, can tell on the basis of a microscopic fragment whether the Shroud of Turin is 2,000 years old, as it would have to be if it once covered the body of Jesus.

title: Callaghan Sees Key Union Chiefs
description: LONDON, Tuesday, Jan. 30 Amid indications that some of the strikes that have so disrupted the country this month were ending, Prime Minister James Callaghan met yesterday with Britain's top labor union leaders in an effort to restore his Government's special relationship with the unions.

title: The Region
description: Layoffs Approved In Newark Schools

title: ReverseTraffic Lane Speeding Buses to Queens
description: Moving north against the southerly flowing rushhour traffic on Manhattan's. Second Avenue, the express bus headed toward the Queensboro Bridge at 59th Street like a rebellious buffalo defying the will of the herd.

title: Stage: McCarter Presents New Anne Commire Play
description: PRINCETON, N.J.

title: Byrne Unveils 1980 Budget With $243 Million Increase
description: TRENTON, Jan. 29  Governor Byrne unveiled a 1980 state budget of $9.6 billion today, up $293 million from the present level. Suggesting that the size of the state government may have to be shrunk in the coming years, the Governor sought no new taxes or new programs.

title: What's the Diameter Of the Regents Exam?; They are not only changing the rules, but also holding accountable only those playing by the old rules: the students
description: Can you read, though not necessarily comprehend, and supply accurate substitutes for deleted words in passages dealing with swing bridges?

title: Syracuse Five Beats West Virginia, 9074
description: SYRACUSE, Jan. 29 (AP)  Dale Shackleford, Syracuse's senior captain, scored 27 points to lead the Orangemen to a 9074 victory over West Virginia in college basketball tonight.WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 29 (AP)Matt Brown scored 19 points and Scott Easton collected 18 to lead Army over Rensselaer, 8454, tonight.CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Jan. 29 (AP) - Jeff Lamp scored 32 points, including the goahead basket with 2:33 remaining in the game, as he led Virginia to a 7371 victory tonight over Temple.

title: U. S. Disaster Agency Rejects State's Appeal F'r Love Canal Funds
description: The Federal Disaster Assistance Administration has rejected an appeal by New York State for reimbursement of most of the $23 million spent on cleaning up the chemically poisoned Love Canal neighborhood of Niagara Falls, which President Carter declared a Federal disaster area last August.

title: Money
description: MONDAY. JAN 29. 1979

title: Deaths
description: page="D19">data

title: Advertising
description: Philip H. Dougherty

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Satellite Photograph

title: The CityZoo's Stolen Birds Found in Brooklyn
description: Five of the six exotic birds stolen from the Central Park Zoo over the weekend were recovered alive in Brooklyn yesterday, according to the police, who said the carcass of the sixth bird was also found.

title: Television
description: 6:00(4)School: Alive and Well!

title: Past Casts Shadow on Cambodians in U.S.
description: Khauv Kheong recalls arranging his eldest daughter's marriage in Cambodia, after investigating the prospective bridegroom's family, which had sent an emissary to propose the union. He consulted an astrologer, and explained the situation to his daughter.

title: Treasury Bill Yields Mixed
description: Yields were mixed on Treasury bills in the weekly auction yesterday in both the 91day and 182day maturities.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Ashland Oil Inc., Ashland, Ky., has elected Kenneth B. Denton corporate administrative vice president.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M., WNCN. Henry VIII Dances. German; Canzonetta, Mendelssohn; Pomp and Circumstances Marches. Elgar; Violin Concerto, excerpt. Haydn; Iberia, excerpt. Albeniz.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Rain in Brazil helped depress soybean prices yesterday for most of the trading session on the Chicago Board of Trade. A rally in the last 15 minutes, however, raised prices to close to Friday's levels in nearby contracts. But while more distant contracts managed to show a slight gain, soybean prices finished mostly lower.

title: Deaths
description: LYLELouisean (nee Vose). Age 83, of 325 E. 77 St., New York City, died Friday, January 26. 1979, In Wetherstield Conn. Born In Maine and lived in New York for many years. Widow of Alexander Lyie. Survived by a sister, Mrs. Adelaide Vose, of Wethersfield. Graveside service will be today at 1:30PM In the Woodlawn Cemetery, New York City.

title: Papal Delay For Arguello
description: Alexis Arguello, the World Boxing Council junior lightweight champion, was supposed to be in Rimini, Italy, over the weekend getting ready for next Sunday's televised defense against Alfredo Escalera. Teddy Brenner, the former president of Madison Square Garden boxing who marks his return as a match- maker with this bout, finally reached the Nicaraguan at Mex- ico City, where Arguello had been training.

title: TERENCE M'CARTHY, WRITER, DEAD AT 69
description: Economic Consultant Wrote About Rape Case of 3 Florida Blacks and Concert by Robeson

title: BirthDefect Suits Worry Doctors
description: ARECENT New York Court of Appeals ruling that held physicians liable in certain circumstances for the lifetime care of children born with some disorders has been applauded by geneticists and consumer groups, but has sent shivers through the medical profession, particularly among obstetricians.

title: TV: Triangle Fire With Torn Bosley.
description: THE Triangle Factory Fire Scandal, which will be seen on NBCTV from 9 to 11 o'clock tonight, gets right down to that network's recent standard for madefortelevision Movies  and lust about everything else.

title: $1.12 Billion Latin Loans
description: Mexico and Ecuador have completed greements for 10year bank loans totaling $1.12 billion, a spokesman for the Bank of America announced yesterday.

title: Rockefeller Is Buried On the Family Estate; Son, 15, Leads Eulogy
description: POCANTICO HILLS, N.Y., Jan. 29 The ashes of Nelson Aldrich Rockefeller were buried today in a wooded hillside grave site here after a simple service attended only by members of the Rockefeller family.

title: Market Place
description: Robert Metz

title: Music: A Night of Three Premieres
description: THERE was one classic on last night's program of the American Composers Orchestra in Tully Hall. It was Men and Mountains by Carl Ruggles, the maverick American composer who died at the age of 95 eight years ago. Otherwise Lukas Foss conducted works composed within the last decade or so. These included his own Orpheus of 1972, Louise Talma's The Tolling Bell (1967) and Joseph Schwanter's Aftertones of Infinity (1978). The Foss and Talma works were New York premieres, and the Schwanter was a world premiere.

title: Queens Church Meeting Robbed by Gunmen
description: Two armed men burst in on a board meeting at the First Methodist Church in Jamaica, Queens, last night, fired warning shot and forced the minister and 14 board members to put their wallets and purses on a table. The robbers then gathered up the wallets and purses, and escaped with an estimated $400 in cash.

title: Engineer Corps Says It Had Waterway Authority 63 Documents Admitted
description: GREENVILLE, Miss., Jan. 29  Lieut. Gen. John W. Morris. Chief of the United States Army Corps of Engineers, maintained in Federal Court today that the disputed authority to expand the design of the giant TennesseeTombigbee Water way had been granted by the Secretary of the Army and properly financed by Congress in subsequent yearly appropriations.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Preparatory committee for Conference on Science and Technology for Development  10:30 A.M.

title: Hitachi in China Contract
description: TOKYO, Jan. 29 (AP)  Hitachi Ltd said today that China had contracted to buy 80,000 color television sets, more than eight times the number of sets exported to China last year. Under the contract with China's Ministry of Light Industries, Hitachi will ship 10,000 of its 20inch sets every month starting in March, a spokesman for the giant electrical concern said. He did not disclose the value of the contract

title: Issue and Debate Should State Authority Replace N.Y.R.A?; The Background; For Abolition; Against Abolition;New York City money that had formerly gone to the State.; The Outlook
description: Ten days from now, Ogden M. (Dinny) Phipps of the New York Racing Association will receive a national Eclipse Award in San Francisco for distinguished contributions to the sport of thoroughbred racing in 1978.

title: History's Biggest Blast Prompts a New Hypothesis
description: The investigation of the event was hampered by the fact that no scientist reached the area until 19 years after the explosion, and probably no phenomenon in history has evoked so much scientific speculation. The theoretical explanations have ranged from spontaneous nuclear explosions to spaceships from other worlds to falling comet heads.

title: Rockefeller Scope: Finance to Resorts
description: By almost all accounts, David Rockefeller is the world's bestknown banker. Even before he became chairman and chief executive officer of the Chase Manhattan Bank in 1969 he began converting Chase from a domestic to a global institution.

title: About Education
description: Since then, this socalled pioneer, who had enjoyed a lifetime of trust by psychologists, educators and politicians, has been exposed as a fraud, largely as a result of the skepticism of two Americans, Prof. D. D. Dorfman of the University of Iowa and Prof. Leon Kamin of Princeton.

title: The New Rural Japan
description: Shinohata people seem frequently to reminisce about the past, generally variations on the theme: how poor we were then, how much better off now.

title: Kraft Profit Up 26% in Fourth Quarter
description: Kraft Inc, the world's largest processor of dairy and packaged food products, reported yesterday profit increases of 26 percent for the fourth quarter and 19 percent for all of last year, reflecting improved operating profit here, overseas and Canada.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: The Rockwell International Corporation, the $5.7 billion multiindustry company based in Pittsburgh, announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement in principle to sell its domestic Admiral appliance business to Magic. Chef Inc., producer of kitchen appliances, for an undisclosed amount to be paid in cash, notes and nonconvertible preferred stock.

title: Nations Discuss Cocoa
description: GENEVA, Jan. 29  Hopes were voiced today for bringing the United States, the world's largest consumer of cocoa, into a pact to stabilize its price. A meeting of 40 nations was opened here by the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development in an effort to establish such a pact.

title: African Policy's Big Test
description: WASHINGTON  Few foreignpolicy initiatives have represented as sharp departures from the past, contained as many innovative ideas or demanded as much diplomatic skill and patience as the Carter Administration's policy toward Africa.

title: The Appeal Continues
description: A widow's mite, said the note attached to one of the thousands of donations received recently by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: OBSERVER
description: A page from Teng Hsiaoping's briefing book for an American visit:

title: Obituary 9  No Title
description: Memorial Services

title: Vladimir Spivakov Plays Violin at Carnegie Hall
description: SINCE his first appearance in this country four years ago, Vladimir Spivakov has picked up a sizable following, and one n understand why. This reviewer. v had missed hearing the Sian musician in previous ght up with him on MonCarnegie Hall. Mr. Spivarecital there, with Boris pianist, that was surpris-

title: World News Briefs
description: Dr. Sakharov identified the Armenian as Stepan Zadikyan, a former student at Yerevan University. He said he had learned that two other persons had also been convicted in the case.

title: Nuclear Test Set for Tomorrow
description: LAS VEGAS. Nev., Jan. 29 (AP)  The second announced underground nuclear test of the year is scheduled for Wednesday at the Nevada Test Site, the Department of Energy said today. The weaponsrelated test will have a yield of from 20,000 to 150,000 tons of TNT. a dppartment spokesman said.

title: 4 Israeli Arab Students Endorse Arab Terrorism
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 29 (AP) - In an unusual act of defiance against the Gov- v ernment, four Israeli Arab university stu- dents today publicly endorsed Arab ter- rorist actions and called for an Arab na- tional state in what is now Israel.

title: Weitz Fashions His Own Auto
description: John Weitz began designing fashions at the age of 16 and in the 39 ensuing years he became famous for his men's, women's and children's apparel. Now he is designing an automobile. And thereby hangs a tale.

title: Paris Couture: A Backward Glance At the Silver Screen
description: PARIS, Jan. 29  You wouldn't believe what Paris has in store for you for spring. Well, some of you might those who haven't changed their style for 30 years. The Paris couture collections are under way. These are the made-to-order clothes that women from Duluth, Minn., to Cairo yearned for until the rise of ready-to-wear here in the 1960's. Now, of course, they can find clothes with a Paris label at their neighborhood haberdasher.

title: James Spicer, Set Up Off Broadway Plays, AvantGarde Jazz
description: James Spicer, for 30 years an organizer in Off Broadway productions and avantgarde jazz, died of cancer Saturday at New York Hospital. He was 51 years old and lived at 240 East 27th Street.

title: U.S. to Devise New Tactics on Mideast
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29  The Carter Administration said today that since its latest approach for resolving the issues holding up an EgyptianIsraeli peace treaty had failed, a new plan, possibly another Camp Davidstyle summit meeting, would have to be devised.

title: Pianist: Sayuri Iida Plays
description: THERE is no telling why Sayuri lida chose to open her recital on Jan. 22 at Carnegie Recital Hall with Mozart's Sonata No.7 in C (K. 309). The young Japaneseborn pianist, a student of Sascha Gorodnitski's at the Juilliard School, dispatched the notes efficiently enough, but, with its brittle articulation and unstinting fortes, her playing conveyed little affection for the piece

title: Carter Clears Miss Hearst's Release
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29  President Carter commuted the prison sentence of Patricia Hearst today, opening the way for her to leave prison on Thursday.

title: N.F.C. Wins Pro Bowl, 137, on Hill's Score
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 29  A Dallas Cowboy duo, Roger Staubach and Tony Hill, gave the National Football Confer- ence AllStars a.137 victory over the American Conference team tonight in the Pro Bowl. The game at the Coli- seum drew 38,333 fans.

title: Below Tupelo's Calm, a Residue of Tension
description: TUPELO, Miss. - There are no outward signs on the cleanswept downtown streets that this northeastern Mississippi town was the scene last year of several confrontations between militant blacks and the Ku Klux Klan.

title: Basketball Recruiting No Problem for Irish
description: Digger Phelps, Notre Dame's coach, has the easiest recruiting job in college basketball.

title: EARNINGS
description: The United Technologies Corporation, which owns 47 percent of the Carrier Corporation stock and hopes to acquire the leading airconditioning equipment producer this year, reported yesterday a 25 percent jump in fourthquarter profits on a sales gain of 19 percent.

title: One Filibuster Per Issue
description: By voting against a motion to stop a filibuster, 41 of the 100 members of the Senate can block any legislation. That is not necessarily pernicious and we agree with the Senate majority leader, Robert Byrd, that there is a right to filibuster. But we also agree strongly with him that on any one issue, one filibuster is enough. Still, present rules permit multiple filibusters. Even the threat of a filibuster has become a serious problem, making the Senate, in Mr. Byrd's term, a spectacle. The time has come to do something about it.

title: Power Body Sees Slower Need Rise
description: ALBANY, Jan. 29  Staff experts of the Public Service Cornmission predict demands for electricity in New York State will grow more slowly in the next 15 years than projected by the public utilities, which already have lowered their estimates of power needs.

title: Notes on People
description: Muhammad Ali Receives a Top Honor From Koch

title: James Soby, 72, Art Connoisseur And Trustee of Modern Museum;
description: James Thrall Soby, collector, critic, organizer of exhibitions and former trustee and benefactor of the Museum of Modern Art., died yesterday in a hospital in Norwalk, Conn. He was 72 years old.

title: YUSUKE HAGIHARA
description: TOKYO, Jan. 29 (AP)  Yusuke Hagihara, an authority on celestial mechanics and a pioneer in astrophysics in Japan, died of a heart attack today. He was 81 years old. He received the James Watson Prize from the United States National Academy of Sciences in 1961 for his studies in celestial mechanics.

title: U.S. Casino Inquiry
description: ATLANTIC CITY  The Federal Securities and Exchange Commission plans to investigate the activities of Resorts International since 1970. the attorney for the company told the New jersey Casino Control Commission.

title: Business Records
description: Perobors Fled try

title: Around the Nation
description: ST. LOUIS, Jan. 29 (AP)  A judge today dissolved a restraining order against picketing by striking St. Louis teachers and dismissed a school board suit seeking a temporary injunction against the strike.

title: PRESIDENT AND TENG CONFER FOUR HOURS; DIFFER OVER SOVIET
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29  President Carter and Teng Hsiaoping, China's senior Deputy Prime Minister, opened three days of talks here today with sharply divergent public views on Soviet intentions and on the wisdom of concluding new strategic arms limitation agreerriPnt

title: May Gadd, 88, Expert On English, American CountryStyle Dance;
description: May Gadd, an internationally recognized expert on English and American country dances, died of a stroke Saturday at St. Vincent's Hospital. Miss Gadd, who lived at 350 Bleecker Street, was 88 years old.

title: A Voice Against Liberation Theology
description: No event of Pope John Paul II's brief reign so far aroused more anticipation than the speech he gave Sunday to the Latin American bishops. He addressed himself to the basic and divisive question of the proper role of the church and its priests in working to end social and political injustice.

title: Guide GOING OUT
description: HERITAGE HARVEST Starting this week, the New York Public Library is displaying another of its exhibitions reflecting the country's creative past. Ninety authors and 200 titles are represented in the letters, manuscripts and first editions on view through October in the Berg Exhibition Room of the library's main building, Fifth Avenue and 42d Street. The catalogue for The Awkward Age: American Writers of the 1890's reminds us that no other period in American literature produced the same mixture with such abundant zest for life and truly characteristic humor.

title: Big Board Labor Talks
description: A Federal mediator resumed efforts yesterday to avert a strike of 2,100 workers that could disrupt operations of the New York Stock Exchange and much of the financial district here.

title: IRAN, EASING RETURN OF KHOMEINI, IS SET TO REOPEN AIRPORTS
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 29  The Ira- nian Government announced tonight that 'he country's airports would reopen at dawn tomorrow, amid indications that the way was being smoothed for the re-  turn of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini from exile in France this week.

title: Miss Hearst Is Grateful to Carter And Praises Courageous Decision
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 29  Patricia Hearst yesterday expressed gratitude, pleasure and surprise over President Carter's decision to commute her prison sentence.

title: Japan Fears Oil Cutbacks
description: TOKYO, Jan. 29- Japanese oil industry executives said today that they were extremely concerned about a reported shortfall in oil production in

title: Wage Plan Proposed to House Unit
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29  The Carter Administration took its proposal for real wage insurance to the House Ways and Means Committee today amid preliminary signs that the committee's Democrats would approve the measure and send it to the House floor.

title: TV: An 11:30 P.M Look At MindControl Studies
description: ABC NEWS documentaries these days are exhibiting pronounced schizoid symptoms. Those tackling sensitive issues from fresh angles, both technical and interpretive, have been encouraging. Two outstanding examples were Youth Terror and a portrait of the Palestinians. But those dabbling in inherently sensational subjects, such as the occult, have generated understandable nervousness.

title: Witness Alters Letelier Statement
description: WASIUNGION, Jan. 29  A Government witness in the trial of three Cuban exiles accused of murdering Orlando Letelier, the Chilean diplomat, testified today he was wrong when he identified one of the defendants as the man who visited a New Jersey apartment later found to contain explosives.

title: Cardinal Delargey of Wellington; Head of Church in New Zealand
description: 1 AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Jan. 29 (AP)  Reginald John Cardinal Delar gey, the Roman Catholic Metropolitan of New Zealand, died of cancer today in Auckland, the Government announced.

title: Events
description: METROPOLITAN OPERA, Lincoln Center, Puccinos Tosca, 8.

title: Excerpts From Toasts by Carter and Teng
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29- Following arc excerpts from the toasts given by President Carter and senior Deputy Prime Minister Teng Hsiaoping at the state dinner in Mr. Teng's honor at the White Hauce:

title: Deaths
description: AGULNICKDavid. Beloved husband of Martha. Loving father of Barry & Jeffrey. Services Monday. 9:30, at Schwartz Brothers. Forest Park Chapels. Queens Blvd & 76th Rd, Forest Hills

title: Ford Fund Picks A New President After Long Hunt,;
description: After a yearlong nationwide search, the Ford Foundation yesterday named Franklin A. Thomas, a lawyer and one of New York City's most prominent blacks, to be its next president.

title: Events/Sports
description: 7:30 P.M., WBAU: College Basketball. Adelphi vs. Merchant Marine Academy.

title: Pioneer G.M. Economist
description: Henry L. Duncombe Jr. retires this month at the age of 65 as vice president and chief economist of the General Motors Corporation after 22 years. But, more than just a leading economist with a staff of 35 professionals, Mr. Duncombe is a symbol: He was the first economist ever to be elected an officer of the big auto maker.

title: Clearing Away West Side Ruins
description: While the battle still rages over what sort of thoroughfare will replace the moribund West Side Highway below 42d Street, demolition is progressing below 14th Street on the old highway's steel superstructure  and on the dilapidated piers crumbling into the Hudson. This view looking south from Gansevoort Street shows the wreckage from some of those piers as demolition progresses, clearing the West Side for what may later.

title: Ayatollah's Opp'sition to Shahs Goes Back Many Years
description: NEAUPHLE-LE-CHATEAU, France, Jan. 29  Although Ayatollah Ruhollah 'homeini's ideas and methods of .operation are far from clear, the road that brought him to Paris and to his present position of influence can be traced with some exactness.

title: 1978 Hutton Profit at Peak
description: The E. F. Hutton Group reported yesterday record revenues and earnings for 1978. The brokerage firm holding company said that earnings for the year rose 75 percent to $28.2 million, while revenues jumped 56 percent to $522 million.

title: Gimbels ShakeUp: Chief Retires
description: Martin S. Kramer, the 58-year-old chairman and chief executive of Gimbel Brothers Inc., announced yesterday that he would retire early as part of dramatic reorganization of its retailing operations by its parent company, Brown & Williamson Industries of Louisville, Ky.

title: Mr. Teng and the Triangle
description: China's leader has come to the United States with a message that, while by no means unexpected or out of character, is still breathtaking. The Soviet Union, says Teng Hsiaoping, is an international bully that will grab all it can take and may stumble into a world war even though it is already outmaneuvering its adversaries by intrigue and diplomacy. Mr. Teng proposes to respond with a new and grander policy of containment that would align, if not formally ally, the United States, China, Japan and Western Europe against the Kremlin. The immediate American contribution, he suggests, should be larger spending on arms and less reliance on dtente with Moscow.

title: Unitas, Butkus: Two of a Kind
description: When the Pro Football Hall of Fame committee meets each year, there is always a discussion of each candidate. Sometimes a discussion turns into a debate. But when the credentials of Johnny Unitas and Dick Butkus were introduced recently in their first year of eligibility for the shrine at Canton, Ohio, the discussion lasted about as long as it took to pronounce their names. Yesterday their election was announced, with that of Ron Mix, the offensive tackle who projected the credibility of the American Football Leaeue with the San Diego Chargers, and Yale Lary, the Detroit Lions defensive back and punter of two decades ago. Few players in National Football League history have dominated their positions as Johnny Unitas and Dick Butkus did  Unitas as the Balti- more Colts quarterback, Butkus as the Chicago Bears middle linebacker. They also attempted to intimidate each other occasionally. During a timeout once, Johnny Unitas wandered toward the Bears defensive huddle.

title: Libya to Cut Oil Supplies
description: The Libyan National Oil Company has informed several of its minor customers that they can expect their oil supplies to be curtailed starting Feb. 1. The communique cited technical reasons for a production shortfall.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan 29 (AP)Larry Robinson and Guy Lafleur each scored two goals tonight as the Montreal Canadiens routed the Philadelphia Flyers, 73.

title: Steelworkers Midnight Strike Seems Certain at Big Shipyard in Virginia
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29  After a longsimmering threat, a strike at the nation's largest shipyard became all but certain today when Federal mediators failed in a final effort to avert the walkout tomorrow of thousands of members of the United Steelworkers of America at the Newport News Shipyard and Dry Dock Company in Virginia's Tidewater area.

title: Deaths
description: RIVIECCIOAntonio On January 28, 1979 of Fairview, N.J. Husband of Ann (nee Rotondero). Father of Francis, brother of the late Ralph. Grandfather of Anthony, Anna and Celeste. Funeral on Wednesday. January 31, 1979 from A.K. Macagna Funeral Home, 495 Anderson Avenue, Cliffside Park. N.J. at 9AM. Funeral MaSs at St. John the Baptist at 9:30AM. Interment Holy Cross Cemetery, North Arlington. Viewing hours Monday and Tuesday 24 and 79PM.

title: Assembly Passes Bill to Equalize Insurance Rates
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Bill Koch Wins U.S. Ski Title
description: WATERVILLE VALLEY, N.H., Jan. 29  Bill Koch, the 23yearold crosscountry skiing star from Guilford, Vt., stopped for 10 seconds during his 15kilometer journey today to correct a problem. Then he went on to defeat a teammate, Stan Dunklee, for a national title.

title: Obituary 8  No Title
description: In Brmoriam

title: Music: Collegiate Chorale in Devotional Program
description: FOR his Collegiate Chorale program at Carnegie Hall on Sunday night, Richard Westenburg selected two religious works that lent themselves to gentle, introspective treatment and treated them both just that way. Cherubini's Requiem No. 1 in C minor and Verdi's Four Sacred Pieces, however, added up to a long evening of stolidly conducted devotional music. Mr. Westenburg seemed concerned primarily with choral tone production and balances, paying less than enough attention to such equally important matters as tautness and momentum.

title: News Summary
description: TUESDAY, JANUARY 30, 1979

title: New Answers for Mom, I'm Bored
description: There are roughly three million mothers and fathers raising children in the New York metropolitan area, according to the latest from the United States Census, and many among them are constantly looking for ways to occupy their offsprings free time.

title: Corporate Move  To Norwalk Site To Be Given Up
description: NORWALK, Conn.. Jan. 29  Almost four years after buying one of the great estates on Long Island Sound for use as coporate headquarters, the Continental Group announced today that it was abando?ing the plan because of continuing, al??? unsuccessful, litigation by a group of residents.

title: Tibetan Is Called Ready For Talks With Chinese
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 29  The Dalai  Lama is ready to talk to the Chinese if they so desire, a spokesman for the Tibetan spiritual leader said here today.

title: San Diego Girl Slays 2 With Rifle And Wounds 9 on School Grounds
description: SAN DIEGO, Jan. 29 - A 16-year-old girl who calmly told a newspaper reporter by telephone that she was doing for fun opened fire with a rifle at an elementary school today, killing two men and wounding a police officer and eight children.

title: Music: Pentagon Brass Quintet
description: IN one way, the Pentagon Brass Quintet, which appeared Jan. 21 at Carnegie Recital Hall, was throwback to earlier centuries when composer and performer tended to be the same person. Not only did the five players meld into a precise and sonorous ensemble, but two also turned up as composers on the program, and third was listed as a transcriber.

title: From Brooklyn Restoration to Ford  FoundationMan in the News
description: When President Carter asked him to become Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, Franklin Augustine Thomas turned him down because, he recalled yesterday, the Cabinet post was not what the last 10 years had positioned me to be able to do.

title: Call to 911 for Stricken Rockefeller Did Not Identify Him, Tape Shows
description: Megan Marshack. the aide who summoned help after Nelson A. Rockefeller suffered a fatal heart attack last Friday night, did not identify herself or Mr. Rockefeller in a call to the police and was so distraught that police and emergency medical operators had to ask her repeatedly to calm down and clarify the location and nature of the emergency.

title: Son Saves $20, Father Doubles Aid to Neediest
description: His 16yearold son's continued support of The New York Times Neediest cases Fund prompted George J Nagorski, of Manhattan's East side to double the contribution be made to the year's 67th an nual appeal.

title: Banks a ProfitGuide Headache
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29  The Carter Administration is struggling to devise a formula to bring banks, some of which are reporting their biggest earnings gains in years, within its wage and price guidelines.

title: President and Wife Will Attend Memorial Service for Rockefeller
description: As flags in New York and the nation's capital fluttered at halfstaff, the White House announced yesterday that President and Mrs. Carter would fly to New York City on Friday to attend a nondenominational memorial service for Nelson A. Rockefeller, the former Vice President and fourtime Governor of New York who died of a heart attack Friday at the age of 70.

title: Bail Is Set at $100,000 for Suspect in 747 Hijacking
description: Irene McKinney was arraigned yesterday in Federal Court in Brooklyn on charges of air piracy in Saturday's commandeering of a 747 jetliner, and bail was set by Magistrate John Caden at $100,000.

title: Excerpts From Governor Byrne's Budget Message
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Yale Raises Fees and Reduces Student Body
description: NEW HAVEN, Jan. 29  Yale University announced today that tuition and room and board fees for the next academic year will total $S,140. an increase of 8.5 percent over the 197579 school year.

title: BUSINESS. Digest
description: American Express raised its offer for McGrawHill to $40 share from $34 and made it contingent on an agreement by the McGrawHill board not to oppose it. The publishing company said would consider the new offer. It also asked the New York Stock Exchange to halt trading in McGrawHill shares until after a board meeting tomorrow, although trading was already suspended. Maxwell M. Geffen, one of the largest individual holders of McGrawHill, said the new offer should be presented to shareholders. [Page Dl.]

title: Boston U. Threatened by Strike As Teachers Talks Deteriorate
description: BOSTON, Jan. 29  Relations between members of the first faculty union to gain a foothold at a major private university and one of the nation's most outspoken college presidents continued to deteriorate today as Boston University officials laid down the battle lines for what could be a long strike.

title: Construction Set To Begin Today On a New Hotel
description: Construction of a $42 million hotel will begin today on the former site of the Central Commercial High School, on 42d Street between Third and Second Avenues

title: Deaths
description: SLAVINAugusta E. On Mon. Jan29, 1979. Beloved mother of Elizabeth Green. Loving grerdmother of Richard Martin. Dear sister of Arthur & Charles Fitasatrick. Repos- ing at Martin A. Gleason Funeral Home, 14920 Northern Blvd., Flush- ing. N.Y. Mass of Christian Burial St. Ann's R.C. Church on Fri, Feb 2, at 9:45AM. Visiting hours 25 & 710PM

title: It's SmallPond Time Again
description: OXFORD, England  As a professor in an American university in 1968, I was asked one day by a student of philosophy to sign yet another letter of protest about conscription and the war in Vietnam. I said that I would probably sign but that I needed to read the letter first, to which he immediately replied that if I wanted to read the letter before signing, That already shows that you are not one of us. Us meant radicals, as opposed to wishywashy liberals, who niggle about words in a legalistic way.

title: Carter's Image in SurVey: Honest, but Not a Leader
description: After two years in office, President Carter still inspires a firm image of honesty and competence among the American people, but a majority of the public think he has not turned out to be a strong leader, according to the latest New York Times/ CBS News national roll.

title: Rhodesian Whites Vote to Accept Limited Rule by Black Majority.
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia. Jan. 30 White Rhodesians voted overwhelmingly today to accept limited black rule of this southern African nation, which has been dominated by whites since the first colonial Settlements in the 1890's.

title: News Summary
description: The return of Ayatollah Khomeini was authorized by the Iranian Government, and the elderly Moslem leader began preparing for a flight home tomorrow from exile in France. A tumultuous welcome awaits the revered Shiite. [Page Al, Column 1.]

title: About Real Estate
description: The venerable mill city of Paterson, N..T., is moving forward with a downtown revival effort based on the notion of reuse of the underutilized mills. themselves.

title: Notes on People
description: Richard M. Nixon didn't spend all his time in Washington with Chinese and American dignitaries. Before slipping off yesterday to New York for a visit with one of his daughters, the former President found time to drive to Arlington Hospital, in Virginia, to visit his old friend and onetime senior White House adviser, Bryce N. Harlow, who is recovering from an attack of emphysema. His daughter, Tricia, and her husband, Edward N. Cox, a New York lawyer, expect their first child in March. After his brief visit with them last night, Mr. Nixon was due back in Washington today for a meeting with Chinese Deputy Prime Minister Teng Hslaoping, at Blair House.

title: English Cup Final Set
description: LONDON, Jan. 30 (AP)  Nottingham Forest, holder of the English League Cup trophy, qualified today to meet Southampton in the final. Nottingham drew, 00, with Watford to qualify, 31, on aggregate score. Southampton scored a 10 upset over Leeds at The Dell to win, 32, on aggregate and gain the final.

title: Minor Quake Hits Jersey and Parts of 2 Boroughs
description: A minor earthquake shook floors and rattled windows throughout central New Jersey yesterday and its tremors reached across Staten Island and into southern Brooklyn.

title: CORRECTION
description: An obituary in The Times yesterday incorrectly gave the date of a memorial service for May Gadd. The service will be held Friday, Feb. 9. at St. Paul's Chapel of Columbia University

title: Professors at Farmingdale Charge Bias
description: FARMINGDALE, L.I., Jan. 27  Prolessors at the Agricultural and Technical College here are paid salaries lower than those at other campuses in the State University of New York system, and they are annoyed about that

title: Deaths
description: ADLER  Estera. ??????????? OHAB Zedek. , Manhattan records with deep sorrow the passing of our beloved member. To the entire fa-mily, we extend our sincerest con-????

title: $121 BILLION BUDGET WITH NEW TAX CUTS IS OFFERED BY CAREY
description: ALBANY, Jan. 30  Governor Carey proposed a $12.7 billion budget today for the 197980 fiscal year that included modest tax cuts over three years, limited increases in local aid and an admonition to local governments to contain Spending.

title: Kitchen Equipment
description: THE case against the conventional kitchen oven is easy to make: It is too large for most of the jobs it does, requiring the heating of much unused space; distributes heat unevenly: and it is difficult to clean. A device that's designed to remedy those problems and do more besides is the home convection oven, scaleddown version of the ovens that are increasingly used in professional kitchens, especially for baking.

title: Tripling of Federal Financihg Of Public Radio and TV Urged
description: The Carnegie Commission on the Future of Public Broadcasting released comprehensive report yesterday that calls for a new structure for public radio and television and for a commitment by the Federal Government to a larger, more independent and betterfinanced noncommercial system than now exists.

title: A New Plan for West 42d St.
description: It is at once tawdry and dazzling, the block of theaters, street vendors, hustlers and fastfood outlets on 42d Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues, and it has been a test for city planners for decades. They have tried to clean it up by producing big plans, small plans and mediumsized plans, and none of these efforts have done more than make a dent in the street's celebrated sleaziness.

title: Pastry That's Fit For a President
description: PROMPTLY at 8 o'clock tomorrow morning, Albert Kumin, the pastry chefelect, takes up his new office in the White House bake shop. Although he has al- ready prepared desserts for several state dinners, his official term of office begins tomorrow. Once installed, he will roll out his incomparably crisp pastry crusts, whip up his richer-thanvelvet chocolate creations and in general attempt to lure the Presidential family and honored guests from their rigid diet routines.

title: Iranian Aides Believe That Soviet Is Root of AntiU.S. Broadcasts
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 30 (AP)  Two mysterious radio stations are bombarding Iran with broadcasts denouncing the Iranian Government and the United States. Iranian officials say they believe both stations are controlled by the Soviet Union.

title: Braths
description: PEARLMANHarry. The members of the Board of Trustees and administration of the Jewish Hospital and Medical Center of Brooklyn record with deep sorrow the passing of a dedicated and devoted honorary member of the Board. Our heartfelt sympathies are extended to his bereaved family.

title: EARNINGS
description: McGrawHill Inc., the unwilling target of a proposed takeover bid by the American Express Company, reported yesterday improved earnings for both the fourth quarter and for all of 1978.

title: Farewell to Bonwit's
description: Saturday's generation goes to Bloomingdale's, and so did Saturday's generation's greatgrandparents in the last century. They also went to B. Altman's, Lord and Taylor's and Bonwit Teller's. The New York stores have had surprising longevity and durability in the fickle fashion world; when one of them closes, the occasion is noted with more than ordinary regret. And there have been closings - Arnold Constable, Franklin Simon and Russeks on Fifth Avenue, McCreery's and Stern's on 34th and 42d Streets, as the carriage trade moved uptown and the subway trade moved out.

title: Fraiberg Resigns Metromedia Post
description: Lawrence P. Fraiberg, president of Metromedia Television, the national broadcast group that operates WNEWTV, Channel 5, in New York, has resigned with the explanation that he wished to return to his former career as an independent producer of programs. He said in a statement he would continue as executive producer of Metromedia's cultural and children's programming.

title: The Region
description: A fire early Tuesday that the Suffolk County police called arson virtually destroyed a twostory frame house that had been bought recently by a black family in a white neighborhood in Deer Park, L.I.

title: Nets Lose On Coast, 127 to 108
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif. Jan 30  There was no lastquarter comeback tonight for the New Jersey Nets. They fell behind early to the Los Angeles Lakers before 10,162 fans at the Forum and wound up losing their first game in California this season, 127108. Lou Hudson led the Lakers with 22 points and John Williams, who again did not start, scored 16 points for the Nets.

title: Rockefeller Had Heart Ailment, Doctor Reports
description: Nelson A. Rockefeller was treated shortly before his death by his physician forsymptoms of a heart ailment. Dr. Michael M. Baden. New York City's Chief Medical Examiner. said yesterday.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30  If the United States and China are to work together for that new world order they both say they want, they are going to have to do a lot better than President. Carter and Deputy Prime Minister Teng Hsiaoping did in their first meeting here in Washington.

title: Two Out In Flyers ShakeUp
description: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 30 (AP) The Philadelphia Flyers, in their worst slump in eight years, dismissed Coach Bob McCammon and his assistant, Terry Crisp, today. McCammon was replaced by Pat Quinn, coach of the Flyers Maine farm team in the American Hockey League.

title: Oklahoma Evacuees Back Home
description: ARDMORE, Okla., Jan. 30 (AP) About 1,000 persons who were evacuated from their homes at noon yesterday hen a toxic gas leaked from a derailed train began returning home today.

title: Mr. Howe Fails
description: ALBANY  The recently released Howe Report, commissioned by Mayor Koch, to suggest how to reduce the huge burden that the City University of New York represents to the city's taxpayers, is titled The City University of New York: Facilities, Finance, and Governance. It should be headed The City University of New York: Everything You Ever Wanted to Build ... (But Were Afraid You Could Not Afford).

title: Letters
description: It's an outdated phrase, perhaps, but I would beg to differ with Pierre Cof fe, the chef in charge of catering the recent summit meeting on Guadeloupe ['Carter Is Chided on Tastes in Food, Jan. 24] Rather than refuse President Carter's request for a hamburger because you don't ask a twocap chef for hamburger, it seems to me it would have been proof of his true twocap status if he had served the President the best hamburgers he'd ever had.

title: Celtics Deal White to Warriors
description: Thirteen National Basketball Association championship banners hang in Boston Garden, remindeis of the Celtics past. But the ranks of Boston players linked to those titles dwindled to two yesterday when Jo Jo White was traded to the Golden State Warriors for a 1979 firstround draft choice.

title: BLUMENTHAL WARNS KOCH OVER U.S. AID
description: Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal told Mayor Koch at a private meeting in New York City on Sunday that the city would have to carry out its contingency cuts to balance next year's budget, Carter Administration aides said Yesterday.

title: Carey Tax Plan Aims Its Relief At Few Groups
description: ALBANY,. Jan. 30  The program to cut taxes presented today by Governor Carey is aimed primarily at certain groupssmall and mediumsized corporations, three specific industries, the elderly and those earning more than $19,000 a year. Several of the measures, the Governor said, were aimed at keeping business decisionmakers from moving out of the state.

title: Market Place
description: IT is often said these days that stocks are cheap, but there is relatively little enthusiasm for equities. And this is so even though prices for the Standard & Poor's 400 industrial stocks are averag- ing 8.8 times earnings, the lowest since the 1940's. Market-price-to-book ratios, meanwhile  1.25 for the sane index at the end of 1978  are also as low as they have been since that period.

title: Freshman in House Learns Tough Lesson
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29  Like many freshman Congressmen, Michael L. Synar ran on a platform of balanced budgets and efficient government. But last week, when President Carter's budget was submittted to Congress, Mr. Synar was horrified at the proposal to slice $400 million out of a sewage construction program.

title: 17 of 633 New Garbage Trucks Arrive
description: The first of New York City's new garbage trucks arrived yesterday and were earmarked immediately for the Crown HeightsFlatbush area of Brooklyn.

title: Islanders Beaten, 54; Rangers 53 Victors
description: UNIONDALE, L.I.. Jan. 30  The two teams the Islanders used to kick around, the North Stars and Barons. finally put a good game together tonight and handed New York its second straight defeat at home. 54.

title: New Bids to Be Sought For East River Marina
description: City officials plan to seek new bids for the construction of a marina and recreation area in lower Manhattan on the East River. north of the South Street Seaport.

title: Sparkling Waters: Ten Rated in a Tasting
description: IT was not a matter of much interest to me as long as it was an innocent beverage that Americans were consuming by the thousands of gallons in the fancy saloons and salons of Manhattan. to the beginning was a bit annoyed at guests in my home who demanded it in lieu of. my super dry (brand name deleted) martinis straight'up with a twist of lemon or my incredible margaritas served in a chilled saltrimmed glass. I was fascinated to find six packs of the stuff jampacked, along with the lesser, inexpensive cuts of meats, in the shopping carts of a few middleincome families in my fashionable hometown of East Hampton. I could keep my peace when I saw it sipped by certain ladies of the evening (they linger for hours over one small bottle) at one of my favorite hotel bars in midtown. I am used to the cyclic and harmless aberrations of Americans.

title: China Rejects Projects Of Two U.S. Scientists In an Exchange Group;
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30  China has rejected, at least temporarily, the applications of two American social scientists who were scheduled to begin research there this spring. The move raises an important question of reciprocity in ChineseAmerican relations.

title: Allied Seeks Bonwit Stores
description: The Allied Stores Corporation yesterday confirmed trade reports that it was negotiating with Genesco Inc. to purchase the 12 Genescoowned Bonwit Teller branches other than the main store on Fifth Avenue.

title: Salomon Review Of Bond Market
description: The best investments in 1978 were industrial common stocks and money market obligations such as threemonth certificates of deposit and Treasury bills. Salomon Brothers reported yesterday in its annual review o; the bond market.

title: N.F.C. Gets a Small Consolation
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 30  It may not be the same as winning the Super Bowl, but for the National Football Conference last night's 137 Pro Bowl victory was the next best thing.

title: Circus Maximus Takes Early Lead in Florida Sail
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Jan. 30 (AP)  Circus Maximus, owned and captained by John Raby of Rahway, N.J., took the early lead today in a 370mile sailing race from St. Petersburg to Fort Lauderdale. Rahy's boat was pulling away fast when the fleet was last sighted some 25 miles away.

title: Economic Scene
description: THE West German Finance Minister, Hans Matthofer, was in the United States this week to confer with his counterpart, Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal, to try to get a clearer picture of where the United States economy and the dollar are heading.

title: How Budget in Albany Has Grown Since 1959
description: ALBANY, Jan. 30(AP)  New York' State's budget has grown to about seven times the size of two decades ago.

title: Around the Nation
description: BOSTON, Jan. 30 (AP)  A settlement was reached tonight in the three-monthold cemetery workers strike, which has delayed the burial of about 700 bodies.

title: 6 Killed and 4 Injured In Building Explosion At Prison in Missouri
description: LEAVENWORTH, Kan., Wednesday, Jan. 31 (AP)  Six men were killed and four were injured yesterday in an explosion at a machinery building at a Federal prison farm, the authorities said.

title: Deaths
description: HURLEYRev. Robert F. On Janua ry 71, 1979. Presiding Judge Diocesan Marriage Tribunal. Ordained April 3. 1945. Beloved son of the late Robert and Florence (???? Wil- liams). Devoted brother of Thomas. Florence ?????, Dorothy ???????? ?????? Leyendecker. Bernadette Lathbury and Althea Hurley. RePosing ???. James Cathedral Parish Center until Wednesday. 7 P.M. Mass of the Transferral 8 P.M. Con celebrated mass of the Christian Burial, Thursday, 10:30 A.M. at St. James Cathedral. ?????? Brooklyn. Interment St. John's Cemetery. For further information Call the Cronin Funeral Home (212) 6241398.

title: G.M. Settles F.T.C. Case

description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 30  Long lines of people have become a familiar sight outside the Los Angeles Superior Court building where Lee Marvin, the actor, is defending himself against a suit in which the woman he lived with for more than six years is seeking more than $1 million.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: The credit markets. after muddling through most of the day. resumed their rally late yesterday after the Chase Manhattan Bank lowered its prime rate to 11 percent from 11 3/4 percent.

title: Carter Names Choice To Investigate G.S.A.
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP)  President Carter said today that he would nominate Kurt W. Muellenberg to be inspector general of the scandalridden General Services Administration.

title: Dissidents Charge Ford Misused Company Funds; Ford Denied Similar Charges; Entertainment Costs Cited; Henry Ford Faces New Fund Charges
description: In the latest round of a running court fight, dissident shareholders in the Ford Motor Company charged yesterday that Henry Ford 2d had improperly diverted corporate funds to pay for political dinners and a host of personal expenses, including opulent office, sauna and gym facilities and private airplane trips and other favors for family and friends.

title: Tremor Caused a Tumult At Palisades Seismic Lab

title: The Editorial Notebook Office Landscapes and Inner Space
description: Almost half of the offices in America are being done over today40 percent of a recent sampling of corporations had remodeled or redesigned in the last five years and half of American office workers are miserable. This conclusion is drawn from a recent survey of office workers, their employers and office designers questioned about the best working environment.

title: News of the Theater
description: The cast will be headed by Tony Roberts, last seen on Broadway in 1972 in the musical 'Sugar. He will star in the role of the lover in this threecharacter comedy set in a motel room. Bob Dishy will play the husband and an actress yet to be cast will portray the woman wooed by one man and wed to another.

Small wonder that a ca- pacity audience at Carnegie Recital Hall on Jan. 19 showed no signs at all of putting up a struggle against the musical blandishments of Sylvia Alexander, flutist, and Jerry Willard, guitarist.

Her manifold cantributions to the cultural life of Hofslra were greatly admired. She will always be remembered for her charming & gracious personality. We extend our heartfelt condolences to President Lord & to his son & daughter.

title: BUSINESS Digest
description: Chase Manhattan reduced its prime rate to 11 1/2 percent from percent in the first cut in two years in the key lending rate by major bank. The action came as a surprise to other bankers, and some called it premature. Chase noted that some shortterm money market rates have recently fallen, but said it would be a mistake interpret its cut in the prime as a signal that interest rates in general had passed their highs. [Page D1.]

title: Chase Cuts Prime Rate To 11
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank announced yesterday that its prime rate would be lowered by a quarterpoint to 11 percent, effective today. The move marks the first time in two years that ma ior bank has reduced its prime rate.

title: What the Ford Foundation Omitted
description: There is such a thing as an excess of delicacy. When the Ford Foundation announced this week that it had chosen Franklin Thomas as its next president,it could not find the words to celebrate the fact that, among other things, he is black. The foundation knew, of course, that this fact gave the appointment a special dimension and excitement, but it let the photographs tell the story and left it to others to make the irrelevant observations.

title: Tang's American Business Trip
description: Teng Hsiaoping, China's senior Deputy Prime Minister, who is in hurry to turn his nation into an advanced industrial country, will have glimpse of American business and industrial life on a trip that will resemble the quick swings made by America's corporate elite.

title: Teng, on Capitol Hill, Says Peking Must Keep Taiwan Options Open
description: WASHINGTON. Jan. 30  Deputy Prime Minister Teng Hsiaoping assured members of Congress today that China hoped to unite Taiwan to the mainland by peaceful means and would fully respect the present realities on the island. But he said he could not categorically rule out the use of force because that would limit Peking's leverage in talks with Taipei.

title: Philharmonic Gets $750,000 For Concertmaster's Chair
description: The New York Philharmonic has received a $750,000 grant from the Charles E. Culpeper Foundation to endow the concertmaster's chair.

title: Canada Fines Levi Strauss
description: TORONTO, Jan. 30 (Reuters)  The Canadian subsidiary of Levi Strauss & Company of San Francisco was fined $150,000 (Canadian) here for price fixing and refusing to supply retailers who sold its products at discount prices.

title: Music: Unnatural Sound
description: THE Mongolians started it, and now it's all over town. No, it isn't a new strain of flu. It's a peculiar vocal technique, practiced for centuries by Central Asian nomads, that involves singing a primary tone, tensing the throat and altering the shape of the mouth cavity, and producing delicate, wavering harmonics above the original tone. Last weekend alone one could hear vocalists using this technique at the Kitchen (Meredith Monk), the La Mama theater annex (Harmonic Choir) and at the grand opening of the Natural Sound Center, a performing space at 246 Eighth Avenue that will be home for Natural Sound, directed by Kirk Nurock.

title: Kapadia Success Again
description: Darius Kapadia, a 28-year-old native of Nagpur, India, recalled yesterday an old Lebanese expression, If you succeed in Beirut, you'll succeed anywhere in the world. And Mr. Kapadia, who did succeed in Beirut, at least for while, is now proving the point.

title: Virus Toll Now 50 in Naples
description: NAPLES, Jan. 30 (Reuters)  The deaths of three children today brought the toll in an outbreak of a mystery virus in the Naples area to 50. The disease has been labeled the poor people's bug because all its victims have come from the Naples slums.

title: Killing of Burros Viewed As Way to Halt Damage
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP)  Burros running loose in Grand Canyon National Park are devouring desert scrub and threatening native plant and animal species, according to the National Park Service. As a result, the service has proposed a plan to shoot many of the animals.

title: Personal Health
description: EACH year Americans pay about $1 billion for the care of a body part they apparently can live very well without - the gallbladder. This threeinch, pearshaped organ is the storage depot for bile, substance produced by the liver which is essential for the digestion and absorption of fats.

title: COMMODITIES
description: A volatile mixture of strong demand and Tumors about a break in the interest rate structure caused sharp advances in copper and precious metals futures yesterday.

title: Bella Abzug Disagrees With New Panel Leader
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30  Bella Abzug and the woman who replaced her as head of the National Women's Advisory Committee disagreed tonight on whether the panel had lost its credibility since Mrs. Abzug's dismissal.

title: On the Shelves: Some Good News
description: ADD cream cheese to the long list of foods that have been improved by industry until they have almost reached the point of inedibility. Check the gums and stabilizers listed on any standard brand cream cheese such as Breakstone's and Philadelphia and you will know part of the reason why this once fluffy and delicate cheese spread now seems more like sticky clay.
