title: Ayatollah Is Expected to dead Home Tomorrow to a Huge Reception
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 30  The Iranian Government tonight authorized the return of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, and the elderly Moslem leader began preparing for a flight home Thursday from exile in France.

title: Film: 'Billy in the Lowlands'
description: JAN EGLESON'S "Billy in the Lowlands" is an extremely engaging movie that reveals itself with the kind of un-self-conscious discretion that is the way of some friendships. It grows on you. At first it seems as if it can scarcely talk, and when it does talk, it doesn't say very much, being about people who are inclined to punctuate their sentences with "You know what I mean," when they themselves have only the fuzziest of notions and want help. Eventually, though, you see in "Billy in the Lowlands" unexpected resources of compassion and humor and, more important, of unsentimental honesty. It's a modest, awkward movie, but it's also a good one.Billy Shaughnessy (Henry Tomaszewski) is a teen-agers you may think you've met in a number of other movies, but never quite so unglamorized. Billy thinks he's hip, when he's only lazily bright. He's basically decent but can't help sliding into trouble out of carelessness. He lives with his mother and younger brother and works in a foundry  his parents have been separated for years. When asked, Billy says his father farms artichokes in California. Sometimes he says his father is a businessman. The only constants in the fantasy are that Billy doesn't often see his father and that his father lives in California.Mr. Egleson, who wrote and directed "Billy in the Lowlands," keeps Billy's problems small, though we can understand how large they loom to him. Arrested for joyriding in a car stolen by a friend, he's packed off to a juvenile correction center that's not especially tough but is monumentally uninterested in him. His grandfather's death and the report that his father is coming east for the funeral prompt Billy to walk out of prison to begin a series of sadly inconsequential adventures. The climax  a reunion with his father  is a surprise only to Billy.According to my program notes, the cast includes amateurs and professionals, though, with one exception, I'd be hard put to tell which are which. Mr. Tomaszewski, I assume, is an amateur, but his dimly understood anger and his earnestness of small purpose are something more than a performance. They are the tone and style of the movie that understands Billy and the contradictions within him, "They're never going to catch me," says Billy when he walks out of prison, adding, "I don't care how long it takes."Of the other actors, Paul Benedict is of the other actors, Paul Benedict is splendid as Billy's father, a lean, ravaged man who lives in Toledo, Ohio, not California, the sort of boozer who carries his bottle in the brown paper bag it came in. The two have a fine, agonizingly inarticulate scene on the beach at dawn near a deserted amusement park. Says the father, "You know, Gramps invented the harpoon." "No kidding," says Billy, thinking that perhaps, at long last, he has stumbled on to something to distinguish his otherwise profoundly undistinguished heritage. "No," says his father. "He just used to say that.""Billy in the Lowlands" knows how life in the land of the blue blue collar looks. It catches the tempo of the speech, as well as the background sounds of traffic, whistles, transistor radios. Best of all, the movie appreciates the people without bending them into melodramatic poses."Billy in the Lowlands" opens today at the Entermedia Theater on Second Avenue at 10th Street, beginning a three-day run in the American Mavericks Festival that is showcasing independent films. Among the features that will follow "Billy" are Penny Allen's "Property," John Carpenter's "Dark Star" and Henry Jaglom's "Tracks." The festival is one of the more interesting movie-happenings in town at the moment.

title: China Policy of Freckles Brown
description: The American itinerary of Teng Hsiaoping, senior Deputy Prime Minister of the People's Republic of China, includes a barbecue and rodeo in Simonton, Tex , day after tomorrow. Nothing could be more fitting, for no matter what you read in the papers, the first steps toward normalization of ChineseAmerican relations were not taken by Richard Nixon or Chou Enlai or Henry Kissinger and it didn't happen in diplomatic chambers in Peking or Washington. Long before Nixon or Gerald Ford or Jimmy Carter or those other characters got into the act, a little old bullrider named Freckles Brown was making goodie points at a rodeo in Kunming in Yunan Province.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30  G. William Miller, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that it would be premature to say that interest rates have peaked. He suggested they would have to go higher if the robust economic growth of late last year continued.

title: Notre Dame Remains No.1

title: Best Buys
description: MEAT eaters aren't the only ones affected by the rising cost of beef. As consumers search for meat substitutes, everything from chicken to pork City of New York Department of Consumer Affairs reported that a pound of butter dropped to $1.71. We probably won't see another drop until spring, peak time for milk production. In any event, the reduction in beef herds will continue to affect the price of butter.

title: Wine Talk
description: PUTTING together a basic wine cellar is always a challenge, but a fascinating one. A few years ago, say around 1974, it was much simpler than it is now. Wine prices were low compared with hamburger, movie tickets and other necessities. Not anymore. Wine prices have climbed along with everything else we need or enjoy. Which means that choosing an interesting small collection will be harder than it once was.

title: Private Lives
description: ONE of the many reasons I refuse to buy Betamex is that I have seen the future and scares me. The future will be pretty much as E.M.'Forster imagined it back in 1911, in a short story called The Machine Stops. That is, we won't live in homes but in living centers, combination of cocoon and communications module, somewhere in one of Buckminster Fuller's tetrahedral cities.

title: Tokyo Says Russia Builds Bases On 2 Islands Off Northern Japan
description: TOKYO, Jan. 30  The Soviet Union has stationed about 5,000 troops on two islands off the coast of Hokkaido, the northernmost of the main Japanese islands, and is building bases there, Japanese officials said today.

title: CATHERINE BAXTER

Also in the program are compositions by Roberto Gerhard and Richard Wernick, as performed by Clark Terry, Zoot Sims, Jimmy Maxwell, Joan Heller and the Contemporary Chamber Ensemble, conducted by Arthur Weisberg. Tomorrow's concert at the Whitney, at 7 and 9 P.M., features the New York premiere of John Cage's Empty Words (Part 4); with the composer as solo reciterchanter in the work, based on Thoreau's Journal. Admission is $1.50

title: The Promise of Public Broadcasting
description: By apt coincidence, the Carnegie Commission's report on the future of public broadcasting appears on the eve of commercial television's sweep month, when popularity ratings are taken, with millions of dollars advertising revenue at stake. By contrast, public broadcasting is small business, but its goal is high  in E.B. White's words, the idea of excellence, not the idea of acceptability.

title: Books of The Tirnes
description: GREAT DAYS. By Donald Barthelme. 172 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $7.95.

title: SHIPYARD WORKERS STRIKING IN VIRGINIA
description: NEWPORT NEWS, Va., Wednesday, Jan. 31  The United Steelworkers of America put up picket lines here last night at the Newport News Shipyard and Drydock Company, beginning an important test of labor's ability to organize in the largely nonunion South.

title: FRED FLEIG
description: Fred Fleig, secretarytreasurer of the National League for 26 years, died in San Francisco Sunday night. He was 71 years old.

title: U.S. Is Helping China Reenter World Tennis
description: A program to bring China back into international tennis competition has been undertaken with the help of United States professional players.

title: House Panel Elects a Chairman Who Gave Funds to Colleagues
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30  Representative Henry A. Waxman, a liberal California Democrat who gave 324,000 in campaign funds last fall to 10 members of the House Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee, won the chairmanship of that panel's influential Health and Environment Subcommittee today.

title: TV RATINGS
description: Following are the top 15 national television shows of the past week (Monday, Jan. 22. to Sunday, Jan. 28). listed according to their rank in the ratings compiled by the A.C. Nielsen Company. A rating is a percentage of the total number of United States households with television sets.

title: Entertainment Events
description: BILLY IN THE LOWLANDS, directed by Jan Egleson; starring Henry Tomaszewski; at the American Mavericks Festival, Entermedia Theater, 189 Sec, end Avenue.

title: World News Briefs
description: PARIS, Jan. 30 (Reuters)  The French police detained 23 Basques today in a move directed against the Basque guerrilla organization E.T.A. Seven were expelled to Spain.

title: Steel Imports Down 34% in December
description: Imports of steel in December fell 34 percent from the yearearlier level, but the total for last year  21.13 million tons set a record, as expected. .

title: Trade Gap For 1978 A Record
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30  The trade deficit of the United States in December was $2.04 billion, lifting the excess of imports over exports for all 1978 to $28.45 billion, a record, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Talks Progress On Wall Street
description: Considerable progress was made in 15 hours of contract negotiations between securities workers and three Wall Street institutions that handle the bulk of the nation's trading in stocks, mediator reported yesterday.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., Jan. 30 Ralph A. Baker, a jockey from Barrington, and John S. Salvaggio, Mount Holly trainer, have been given reduced penalties after pleading guilty to charges arising from racefixing at Garden State Park race track from December 1974 to May 1975

title: Advertising
description: Gillette Leaving Thompson

title: Heaviest Budget Ever Is Bound in Bullion
description: ALBANY, Jan. 30 This year's budget was bound in covers of bullion gold, as one aide to Governor Carey put it, and at 1,095 pages and six pounds it was the thickest and heaviest in the State Budget Division's 50year history.

title: Dayan Will Fill In French Officials On Peace Talks With Egyptians
description: PARIS, Jan. 29 (Reuters)  Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan of Israel began an official twoday visit to France today by meeting with Prime Minister Raymond Barre. Officials said he would also hold talks with Jean FrancoisPoncet, the Foreign Minister, primarily on the IsraeliEnvotian peace neffotiations.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30  A merger between Pan American World Airways and National Airlines, far from being anticompetitive as alleged by the Justice Department, would help the big international carrier become a stronger factor in the overseas market, Pan Am said today.

title: CARTER BUDGET GETS SUPPORT IN SURVEY
description: The American people generally support President Carter's tight budget, seeing spending cuts as a key way to curb inflation, but they still want to make exceptions for particular programs or tax breaks, the latest New York Times/CBS News poll shows.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia  Southern Africa's whites are facing not only crisis of race relations but something that may be still more portentous: the end of the automobile way of life.

title: The Lady In Gray
description: We Argentines are as melancholy as our tangos. But one day in September 1955 we were as blithe as Brazilians.

title: Diplomats Obtain Cosmos' Iarusci
description: Robert Iarusci, who has played with the last three North American Soccer League champion teams, was sold yesterday by the Cosmos to the Washington Diplomats for an undisclosed sum.

title: National Inventors Day Feb. 11
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP)  President Carter saluted'the nation's inventors today and paid a special tribute to Thomas A. Edison. Mr. Carter proclaimed Feb. 11 as National Inventors Day and noted that it would mark the anniversary of Edison's birth.

title: Corporations Report Their Sales and Earnings Results for the Quarter
description: For periods as shown. (N) indi cates stock is listed on the New Yor1 Stock Exchanpe,(A) the Americar Stock Exchange and (0) overthe counter.

title: George Dunham Jr., Once Served As a TV Executive in Binghamton
description: George Dunham Jr., a retired television executive, died yesterday of cancer at his home in Binghamton, N.Y. He was 69 years old.

title: Commodity Tables Explained
description: Next to each commodity In the table is a key to the exchange on which it is traded, the minimum contract size and the monetary units represented by the figures in the table. Open Interest is the number of contracts outstanding each month and not liquidated by delivery of the commodity or by an offsetting contract. The exchange keys are:

title: Metropolitan Diary; Lawrence Van Gelder; MOTHER GOOSE IN SUBURBIA; THE EXTERMINATOR (With apologies to G.C.); ICE DANCERS; WHAT'S IN A NAME
description: THE other day, while standing on the minibus we Roosevelt Islanders ride the tram, writes Alan Levine, I noticed a young man dressed in whites. Obviously a resident or intern, he was telling a friend seated next to him about his recent experience on the neuroloeical service.

title: Some British Drivers Win 20% Raise in Key Accord
description: LONDON, Jan. 30  The strike by truck drivers that has crippled British industry for more than three weeks appeared to be nearing an end today on terms close to what the strikers had sought.

title: Citicorp Note Sale Today
description: Citicorp, faking advantage of the late January rally in the credit markets, speeded up its floatingrate note sale, increased its size to $500 million from $200 million and priced the issue initially to yield 11.05 percent.

title: The City
description: The City Council's Finance Committee has approved a subcommittee's recommendations that prearraignment procedures be 100 percent implemented in Brooklyn to cut the time police officer must spend initially in court. The committee also recommended the procedures be adopted in Manhattan in stages.

title: Market Loses Ground; Dow Drops by 3.99 Points
description: Corporate takeover situations produced the biggest market winners yesterday, as stocks generally moved lower after a brief afternoon rally.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: We've barely recovered from all those Star Wars robots and now Superman has flown into town with things emblazoned with the S logo. We promise not to follow either the hero or the fad out the window, so we will mention only a Superman doll that has just winged into a shop called Design Point, at 15 Christopher Street in Greenwich Village. The stuffed doll is silkscreened on felt and its face is a good likeness of Christopher Reeve, who plays the title role in the movie. Naturally, he is attired in red and blue and wears the obligatory red cape. The price is $27. Design Point's hours are noon to 6:30 P.M.,. every day, including Sundays.

title: Archpriest Giragosian, at 83; Served Armenian Church in U.S.
description: Archpriest Khachadour Giragosian of St. Illuminator's Armenian Apostolic Cathedral at 221 East 27th Street died Sunday in St. John's Hospital in Long Island City, Queens, oat the age of 83. He lived in Jackson Heights, Queens.

title: Washington, Fearing New Outbreaks, Also Recalls Its Nonessential Aides
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30  The United States today ordered the evacuation of all dependents and nonessential American officials in Iran and urged that other American citizens leave as well because of worsening security there.

title: Consumer. Outbursts Mark Hearing on Con Ed Increase
description: Elderly homeowners, community activists, realestate brokers and members of the Westchester County Legislature were among those who spoke in anger yesterday at a hearing on a preliminary recommendation for a 9.4 percent rate increase for the Consolidated Edison Company.

title: Song: Zehava Gal, Mezzo
description: gie Recital Hall, is not a timid singer. A small, handsome woman with a proud bearing, she approached her program of German, French and Spanish songs with concentrated intensity, applying rich assortment of vocal and verbal nuances. Generally, her voice did everything it was asked to, and well. It did, however, weaken considerably around and below the break, diluting many of the smokier inflections.

title: U.S. Steel 4thQuarter Profits Soar to $94.6 Million
description: The United States Steel Corporation reported yesterday that its profits for the fourth quarter soared to $94.6 million from a quarterly low of $9 million in the final quarter of 1977.

title: Syria and Iraq Delay Merger
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Jan. 30 (AP) Syria and Iraq ended a highlevel meeting here today with a decision that more time and study would be needed to ar- range a merger of the two countries, which had earlier hoped to announce full union soon. Vice President Saddam Hussein of Iraq said before boarding plane for Baghdad that the two countries must first unite their rival branchesof the Beath Socialist Party.

title: Satellite Photograph
description: Yesterday's Weather at 1 P.M.: National Oceanic end Atmospheric Administration/UPI

title: Study Mostly Welcomed
description: President Carter said the report by the Carnegie Commission on the Future of Public Broadcasting would provide a focal point for continued discussions by Government and public broadcasting on the industry's future.

title: Theater: 'The Auction Tomorrow
description: STAMFORD, Conn,

title: Israel, Reviving AntiTerror Policy, Razes 4 Homes
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 30  The Israeli Army blew up the homes of four suspected or convicted Palestinian guerrillas in the occupied West Bank of the Jordan River today, in a resumption of its policy of retaliating against acts of terrorism.

title: Coast Sniper Vowed She Would Do Something Big
description: SAN DIEGO, Jan. 30  Wally Spencer's eyes were red this morning as he looked out at the driveway at the 300 children arriving at Cleveland Elementary School across the street. Just 24 hours earlier, his 16-year-old daughter, Brenda, had fired 40 shots from a .22caliber rifle at arriving school children, fatally wounding the school's principal and custodian and injuring eight children and a police officer.

title: U.S. Bonds for Your Future
description: Since 1941, United States savings bonds have helped to finance the national debt. Today there are $80 billion

title: The Shape of Suits to Come
description: The things that characterized Chanel have endured.

title: 60Minute Gourmet; Steak Diane; Mlange des Legumes (Mixed buttered vegetables)
description: IN a recent column, I mentioned in passing a dish that enjoyed overwhelming popularity back in the days when I first came to New York. To tell the truth, I never dined on the dish in its place of origin, but numerous customers who came to the Pavillon while I was chef there would request it.

title: Train Jumps Tracks At Port Washington
description: A Long Island Rail Road train jumped the tracks at the Port Washington station last night, suspending overnight service between Port Washington and Great Neck and leaving this morning's service in doubt.

title: MALCOLM MUIR DIES; LEADING EDITOR, 93
description: Malcolm Muir, who began as a file clerk and rose to head the boards of the McGrawHill Publishing Company and. later, Newsweek magazine, died of bronchial pneumonia yesterday at his home at 435 East 52d Street. He was 93 years old.

title: Q&A
description: Q. One of your recent recipes called for washing spinach in cold water and shaking dry before adding it, almost immediately thereafter, to boiling, salted water. Why would you want to shake it dry when it is going back into water?

title: Wild Bird at Home at Village Florist's
description: A wild song sparrow has taken up residence in a Greenwich Village flower shop. The small brown bird flew into Flowers by Arno, at 18 West Eighth Street, last October and has remained there even though the shop's door was wide open for a month after its arrival.

title: Excerpts From the Governor's 197980 Budget Message to the State Legislature
description: ALBANY, Jan. 30Following are excerpts from the budget message Governor Carey will present to the Legislature tomorrow:

title: Technology
description: SUDDENLY productivity, or output per manhour, has become the watchword, newly stressed by President Carter's closest economic counselors as the real ceiling on the nation's economic growth. And along with that has come a worry over the decline in technological innovation.
